name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the report by Georgi Pirinski, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on establishing a European Platform to enhance cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work (COM(2014)0221 – C7—0144/2014 – 2014/0124(COD)) (A8—0172/2015).

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: Rapporteur. – Dear Madam President, Commissioner, honourable Members, I would especially like to thank the shadow rapporteurs, as well as the partners of the Luxembourg Presidency and the Commission, for the particularly constructive approach and contributions that have made it possible to draft this draft decision.  Undeclared work, in its increasingly diverse forms, today deprives them of their fundamental social and labour rights, often putting them in conditions of de facto exploitation, leading to serious market distortions, causing companies that comply with the rules to overcome extremely unfair competition from employers using such work and depriving tax and insurance systems of due revenue and payments. It is to these disadvantaged communities and institutions that we owe this platform and its early and effective activation.  The need to set up this platform becomes even more urgent in view of the escalating threats not only to labour mobility, but also to one of the four indivisible fundamental freedoms– that of the free movement of people and of the very existence of the Union. And I would like to share the view that it is this awareness of urgency, which has increasingly been shared by both fellow parliamentarians and the Luxembourg Presidency and the Commission, that has become the driving force for reaching a constructive agreement around the final draft decision presented to Parliament today. The compromise thus reached commits all Member States to be responsible members of the Platform.  The platform is intended to expand Member States' capabilities to address the many painful problems caused by undeclared work through enhanced union-level cooperation between the relevant national authorities, together with the social partners and with the participation as observers of a wide range of agencies and organisations concerned.  Accordingly, the mission of the Platform was defined as to prevent, restrict and counteract undeclared work and to promote the conversion of such work into declared work.  The proposed platform option, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, will not have the power to lay down rules and norms. Instead, it is called upon to offer the necessary basis for responsible consideration of information, experience and solutions as the basis for shared conclusions aimed at effectively addressing the challenges of undeclared work. The activity within the scope of the Platform includes a wide range of concrete actions in the implementation of its mission. It depends on the decisions of individual Member States to use, where appropriate, the conclusions resulting from such actions and on the institutions of the European Union to take into account those falling within the responsibilities of the Union.  It is true, there were doubts – is the platform at all necessary, will it not undermine the freedom of action of the Member States, is there really room for added value at Union level for action to tackle undeclared work? Rest assured that, in the course of the consultations, the full scope of such doubts and reservations was the subject of the most detailed and comprehensive examination, which made it possible to reach a widely shared consensus and thus to agree on a mutually acceptable and therefore workable draft decision. As a result, the question ultimately boils down to the following: are we truly committed to a common cause against gross violations of fairness in undeclared work, or will opponents find themselves in the position of benefiting all those who exploit so-called labour and therefore make profits as a result of extreme unfair competition, while depriving budgets of income and payments due.  That is, are we about to prevail on the power of the law, or in the prevailing cases, do we leave freedom to rule the so-called "law of the jungle"? It is an obvious choice in respect of which parliament is impossible to have two opinions on.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, a deeper and a fairer internal market and the fight against social dumping are absolute priorities for me and for the Commission. Personally I do not like the term social dumping – we are talking about people here, not about goods – but when it comes to undeclared work, we should not camouflage its dramatic effects by using soft words. Undeclared work deprives workers of any protection. It deeply affects the quality of their employment; they can be made to work long hours in bad health and safety conditions without any recourse to justice. People receiving envelope wages, or cash in hand, are sometimes left with little or no pay at all after months of hard work. As a matter of fact, they might not have the right to redundancy payments or unemployment benefits or to any other benefits. They are not building up their pension rights. Undeclared work is not only unfair to the workers involved, it is also unfair to businesses that do play by the rules. We know that small and medium—sized companies are the first to suffer from such unfair competition. Undeclared work also undermines the sustainability of public finances and social security systems, as no taxes or contributions are paid on undeclared activities. Although undeclared work is hidden – which makes it difficult to measure precisely – we know it is widespread in all Member States and difficult to eradicate. Estimates suggest that the shadow economy may reach 15% to 20% of GDP in some Member States. That is why the establishment of a European platform to enhance cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work and to tackle undeclared work is such an important and big step forward. It will encourage cooperation between Member States through exchanging best practices and information, developing expertise and analysis, facilitating innovative approaches to the effective tackling of undeclared work, and contributing to a horizontal understanding of matters. It foresees a multi-disciplinary approach, bringing together the expertise of different enforcement authorities such as labour inspectorates, social, tax and immigration authorities. Such a multi—disciplinary approach has already been implemented with good results in some Member States, and I am glad that the European Platform builds upon those good examples. It is only through a holistic approach, across borders and across disciplines, that we will be able to tackle this complex phenomenon effectively. I would like to stress the importance of the inclusion of bogus self—employment in the activities of the Platform. This too is an area in which the development of expertise and exchange of best practices is needed. Finally, I note with satisfaction that the social partners will play an important role in the platform and that close cooperation with Eurofound and the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work (EU-OSHA) is foreseen. I would like to thank Parliament for all its efforts in making a timely agreement on the platform possible. In particular, I would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur, Mr Pirinski, and to Ms Ulvskog for chairing the trilogue so competently. I would also like to thank the entire negotiation team for their efforts and constructive approach. The Council will now adopt a decision on the platform on 24 February, allowing for the official signature, to which I look forward during the March plenary. In the meantime, we are already preparing for the first meeting of the platform to take place before the summer. I am committed to doing everything possible from my side to make the platform a success. The platform will regularly inform you about its activities and submit its work programmes and reports to the European Parliament and the Council, as well as to the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. I count on your valuable input and support.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – It's nice that the platform against undeclared work is coming. Such exploitation does not fit in the European Union. Many small self-employed people, as the Commissioner said, also complain about unfair competition from companies employing undeclared workers. Even the functioning of the internal market as a whole is undermined by undeclared work.  I am pleased to see that many of the proposals from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection have been adopted. It is a pity, however, that Parliament is not automatically represented in the platform. That is why I hope that the Commission will report to Parliament annually on the platform, even though it is formally obliged to do so regularly.  I would have liked the platform to also promote operational cooperation, but it is not explicitly foreseen. I also think it is only as if Member States should appoint a representative, but are not obliged to participate in all the activities of the platform. Nevertheless, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I warmly congratulate Mr Pirinski on the outcome of the trilogue.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Madam President, precarious work has deteriorated much during the economic crisis. Irresponsible employers blackmail people in need of work, and fear of unemployment pushes workers to work in conditions of illegality.  The platform to combat undeclared work will try to put order in the jungle of unregulated work. Firstly, it is important to extend the role of the platform. The Initial Proposal of the European Commission defines as undeclared work any legal work not declared to the official State authorities. Undeclared work, however, now takes too many forms of employment, e.g. five-hour work is declared, but in reality it is eight hours, overtime is done but they are never paid, there is false self-employment, a cut in contributions up to and including the extreme phenomenon of unpaid work.  The platform is now obliged to examine all this. Member States, the European Commission, employers and workers together with employment agencies must sit around a table to understand the situation of undeclared work across Europe. Today, when introversion prevails and nationalism comes back, it is crucial that we listen and learn from each other. In addition, we must try to develop joint actions to combat cross-border undeclared work.  Is that enough? We wanted strict mandatory actions imposed by the European Union. I also regret that a representative of the European Institute for Gender Equality has not been included as an observer of the platform's work. We believe that women's bodies should be heard every time they have to contribute with their experience and suggestions. We're not reconciling, we're just getting started.  I would like to say a big thank you to our rapporteur, Mr Pirinski, who was a model negotiator. I would also like to congratulate the Luxembourg Presidency and say that when people believe in the same cause and work with determination they may not achieve everything they wanted, but they certainly make it difficult for offenders. Good power to all, and we don't stop here.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – Dear Commissioner Marianne Thyssen, honourable colleagues, honourable colleagues. Working on the black is certainly one of Europe's most important problems, which has very serious budgetary implications. However, even more than the budgetary implications, of course, are the important consequences that working on the blacklist has for the people who do this work. Social dumping is inadmissible in Europe these days. But it is governments that are primarily responsible for preventing black working in their country. People who, in different life circumstances, agree to this form of work, are usually not well enough aware of the long-term consequences this entais. And of course... these long-term consequences are much worse than those in the short term, when people get some money so they can survive. However, as has already been mentioned, these forms of work are very different and are very differently addressed by the states. It is therefore right that we, even at European level, establish some common guidelines, some guidelines for preventing black work. And by setting up a platform, that is exactly what we will achieve. Of course, I also advocate that the involvement of the social partners is extremely important, but it is also right that we have maintained the principle of subsidiarity. Thank you at this place once again to Mr Pirinski. The negotiations were long, they were hard, but in the end we came to a good compromise.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I too would like to add my voice to the thanks of my colleague Georgi Pirinski and all those involved. After all, undeclared work has huge consequences for our European economies. Unfair competition is on the increase massively in many sectors, and this has consequences not only for companies that want to offer fair offers, but also, in fact, many social consequences for the workers concerned. Before this platform, the European level has carried out almost no initiative to combat undeclared work and unannounced employment, even though we are actually living in a European labour market. If we look at national labour controls, their competence ends at the respective national borders. The platform can really only be a first step, but it is a step in the right direction. I share what one of the previous speakers said: we need more commitment to combating undeclared work. In fact, the identification of letterbox companies, controls on national services and also cross-border labour controls are still unresolved. It is good that all Member States must participate in the platform in a binding manner. It is very good that trade unions, which often reveal where the problems of undeclared work are, where we really need to change something, are involved. But we need binding rules and common cross-border controls across Europe.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, firstly I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Pirinski, and all the shadows for their work on this file. There has been a great deal of cooperation and I think we have all benefited from that. Undeclared work is a very serious subject which impacts on all the Member States. It particularly affects tax evasion – which is a real problem – benefit fraud, illegal immigration, and of course it undercuts legitimate businesses and entrepreneurs and undermines workers as well. So I think that this platform is a really good example of just how the European Union should operate. It recognises the sovereignty of Member States and it adds value by sharing experience and best practice and cross-border cooperation. So this is where we can really see an enhancement through this platform – an enhancement of cooperation between the Member States – while recognising their individual sovereignty. We need to recognise that the level of undeclared work varies from state to state; for example, in the UK, according to the OECD data, the level of the informal economy is about 1.7 %, whereas in some Member States it is as high as 30%. My group had four priorities. First, the scope of the platform would be limited and focus on enforcement, exchange of best practice, and knowledge-sharing, rather than creating and mandating standardised approaches. Second, it is important that it fully respects the principle of subsidiarity and the competences of Member States. Thirdly, although participation is compulsory and mandatory, which is fine, the activities are entirely on a voluntary case-by-case basis. And lastly, while social partners can play a valuable role, they should not be on an equal footing with Member States. So we have a really good platform here. (The speaker agreed to take two blue-card questions under Rule 162(8)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support If I understood your speech well, it essentially focuses on cooperation and less on mandatory rules. However, some believe that cooperation could be very well facilitated by the introduction of a European minimum wage based on a uniform principle and covering all countries. Would you support this or oppose it?

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Good morning to my West Midlands colleague. I note that you say it must be done with sovereign countries cooperating and with no particular enforcement, as I think one of the other colleagues has just mentioned. That was in the speech. Is there any conceivable reason why any of the good things that you point out could not be done by an independent sovereign United Kingdom dealing with our friends in Europe without being under the auspices of the EU? This seems to me particularly normal, just a normal agreement. Why can we not do this on our own?

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: blue-card answer. – In response to the first question, minimum wages have absolutely nothing to do with the platform on undeclared work. I think you misunderstood what I was saying. You realise that there are different activities that the platform will undertake, and each of those will be voluntary. The Member States can pick and choose which aspects are particularly important to them, and it seems to me that enhanced cooperation is a very good way of us working together. To Bill Etheridge: well of course, if you come from your party, you do not want anything at a European level. I beg to differ. I think that there are cases, and this is one, where the European Union can add value. Those are the cases we should be participating in and joining. It is so much better that all the Member States are agreed. We have a way of tackling undeclared work which is indeed cross-border. If you want to go and set up your own organisation in the UK, you are going to have a lot more difficulty, because here we have the means of communicating and dealing with the other countries on a level footing, with nothing compulsory in there.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur Mr Pirinski, and indeed the shadow rapporteurs and specifically Yana Toom, for their full commitment to ensuring that we could set up this European platform that will enhance cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work. The fact that membership is mandatory means that all Member States must participate, and therefore they must be involved in exchanging information and developing expertise and analysis, and that in itself will contribute to a horizontal understanding of all matters related to undeclared work. However, while participation is mandatory, any recommendations for action that are supported by the platform are voluntary for Member States to implement. This approach is much more carrot than stick, and I believe that those Member States having participated in the development of tools for sharing information, and for the enforcement of shared practices to tackle undeclared work, are much more likely to implement such action themselves. The platform will not contradict any national legislation and will not propose harmonisation of any laws, but it will provide a strong framework for enhanced cooperation. The extent of undeclared work in the EU is up to 18% of EU GDP, and it is important to remember that undeclared work has negative outcomes both for workers themselves and for society. Many of the workers are in a vulnerable position: they often have to accept poor working conditions and there is very often no commitment to health and safety, no social protection, no pension contributions, precarious working conditions, etc., whilst society loses out because of tax and social security forgone and also unfair competition between companies. In our next debate we look at the anti-tax-avoidance package, which recognises the importance of coordinated action. Equally, this type of coordinated action under the auspices of the European platform will operate both at national and cross-border level.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: gue/NGL Group. Madam President! First of all, thank you both to the Commission and to the rapporteurs for your hard work.  With the EU's internal market, we have seen severe social dumping. Workers have been plunged into unsustainable competition for worse and worse wages and working conditions. It only gets worse when the work is black. It is deeply damaging not only to the individual worker who loses his rights, but also to our community. We are losing sustainable and good jobs and we are losing important income tax. In this light, it is a very good and positive initiative. Coordination is really needed.  But why not go even further? Why do we not set the Member States really free and give them a free framework to introduce controls and require registrations when they think it is true? Let us take a look at, for example, the european Union' s Norway, where a welcome committee welcomes workers, makes sure they have their papers in order and tells them about their rights. We need to take a hard line against employers who exploit the system and use the single market for social dumping.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, undeclared work is a very big, but very often invisible, problem in the European Union. Studies say that the informal sector amounts to 18.4% of GDP in European Union Member States. This has a lot of negative effects: it creates massive fiscal losses for our societies, it means unfair competition and, in fact, punishes those employers who are abiding by laws and employ with fair and decent conditions. Most importantly, it exploits workers, limits their access to social security and undermines their basic rights. We need to tackle undeclared work, and if we want to be successful in this we need to fight together on a European level. With this platform we are taking a first step: to exchange best practices, to inform workers about their rights in all European Union Member States and to push the Member States to take more decisive measures in order to tackle undeclared work. If we want to safeguard fair competition, social security and workers’ rights, we should take this platform only as a starting point for developing even more joint European efforts to address undeclared work, be it the coordination of labour inspectorates, the protection of whistle-blowers or the development of determined political measures against those employers who are actually exploiting undeclared workers. Let us tackle the big challenges in a big way – on a European level. Undeclared work is without doubt one of those big challenges, so let us use this platform to tackle undeclared work and to take steps in order to create a socially-sound architecture in the European Union.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the only jobs the Employment Committee seems able to produce are pretend jobs, sitting on platforms such as this, where civil servants, national agencies and other assorted hangers-on – ably assisted by a secretariat – can gather. We hear a lot in this place about the evil and immoral practices of companies who avoid tax. Many of them, of course, come from the Luxembourg area, where our own President Juncker was prime minister for 15 years. But we should note that tax avoidance, unlike tax evasion, is not illegal, even though many people – particularly those who have never worked in the private sector and had to keep a company in the black – struggle to know the difference. The reason companies avoid tax is that private companies can put their money to better use than the public sector ever will. The GBP 55 million a day Britain sends to this place is a prime example. But if we had an economic outlook which was conducive to business – something George Osborne does not seem to grasp at all – there would be less need for tax avoidance, undeclared work and social security payments. But this is par for the course for the European Union, as is the provision of taxpayers’ money for wining and dining. But we have found money, despite the huge public debt weighing down Europe’s economies, to give nearly a quarter of a million euro a year alone for this platform to be frittered away on hotels, restaurant bills and first—class travel. Economic history shows that it is deregulation which promotes economic growth and jobs, in which case we need to scrap this ridiculous talking shop – and, while we are at it, let us scrap some jobs in Brussels, Strasbourg and Luxembourg and we might be a bit more competitive. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, of course, undeclared work must be prevented and discouraged. And why not at European level thanks to a platform bringing together all the Member States? However, I am afraid you are taking the problem upside down. Before tackling the effects, you should ask yourself what causes unreported work. An employer, on the one hand, and a worker, on the other, both agree to pay no taxes, no taxes and no payroll taxes.  What for? Because work no longer allows the employer to prosper and workers to live. To supposedly adapt and support globalization because of your fiscal policies and austerity policies that destroy jobs by the millions, what are the choices of an employer and a worker?  The employer can either file for bankruptcy and disappear, or relocate and destroy jobs in his country, or call on seconded workers, to the detriment of national workers, or, and this is the purpose of our report, not to declare these workers. On the other hand, the worker, with or without a job, can either emigrate to better skies, but it is not simple, or take advantage of unemployment insurance, but that is not enough, or go around all the aid associations to feed, dress and stay, but as a family, it is complicated, or work in the dark, simply to fill their refrigerator.  It is better understood, therefore, that your platform will not change anything, let alone with the massive influx of so-called "political" refugees that you wish to welcome and the China that you are bringing into the WTO concert. The only solution to reduce undclared work is to put in place a strong policy of economic recovery that necessarily requires Community preference, intelligent protectionism and investment aid.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Madam President, when undeclared work throughout the Union rages at 20%, while in Greece it exceeds 36% and in profitable sectors such as tourism 44%, particularly hitting women and young people and the Union's main aim, as it states, is to reduce so-called non-wage costs by exempting employers and the State from the cost of insurance, it is literally a mockery to worry about reducing undeclared work. As even "aspirin" measures are not proposed by the platform. It treats it only as unfair competition between companies, as a vehicle for squeezing wages, as an incentive to partially convert black work into flexible work, part-time and rotating employment, blocks, exploitation of apprenticeships, social cooperative entrepreneurship, slave trade offices.  Of course, black work will continue to exist because it's in your system's interest. For example, in Greece the increase of insurance and tax contributions to 75% of the total income to self-employed and farmers, with the new SYRIZA-ANEL plan, will increase undeclared work, remove them from insurance, pension and care. The new general reduction in wages and employer contributions, the increase in unemployment is a tombstone for the insurance system and the Funds.  Reply to this "Armageddon" of the European Union and government SYRIZA-ANEL give single workers, self-employed, poor farmers with their general nationwide strike on February 4th.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Undeclared work is not a cavalier offence! In Germany alone, their volume last year amounted to EUR 340 billion. Anyone who issues bogus invoices, who evades social security contributions in a gang-related manner, who thereby seriously harms society, must expect to be sentenced – quite rightly so.  I welcome the European platform, a prime example of European added value, as opposed to what the right has just said. Instead of thinking separately about how to prevent undeclared work, competent authorities should exchange best practices from member states. Data should be shared and operational measures coordinated. And all this is to be done by the platform – at a reasonable cost, incidentally: EUR 2.1 million per year from progress funds.  It is important to me that the enforcement guidelines, but also the manuals with successful procedures, are not mandatory. As a result, effective national testing systems remain unaffected. Unfortunately, the former EU Commission was a thorn in the side of the precise controls, for example on German construction sites. She did not shy away from a lawsuit before the ECJ and lost. I am counting on the new Commission of Jean-Claude Juncker and, of course, on Marianne Thyssen.  Practice has clearly shown that abuse and the informal economy can only be effectively combated through a high level of control. This creates a strong internal market with broad acceptance. I believe that a good basis for this is the compromise that has now been reached in the trialogue – a really good and important start.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you for letting us have this debate. Undeclared work leads to serious losses to public finances when countries miss out on taxes and social security contributions. It also leads to distortions of competition where operators who do not declare their goods and services gain an unfair cost advantage. Undeclared workers are also more often exposed to precarious working conditions and the exploitation of rogue companies. In some cases, we can even.m.  When companies do not pay social security contributions for the employee, important social security and pensions are also lost. Reducing the black sector would thus also increase security in the labour market. I would therefore like to welcome the establishment of this platform as a first step towards combating undeclared work, and I particularly welcome the fact that the social partners should be represented in the work of the platform. The parties are de facto our labour market and I am sure that their participation will make the platform effective.  However, I would urge the Commission not to stay here. At the same time, we must combat poverty and unemployment so that people do not have to accept any job at any cost, and we must also establish and enforce cross-border laws that ensure that employees cannot be exploited. that they are given the right to a level playing field for equal work and that victims of crime have access to courts and a judicial system where they can speak.  '(The Speaker agreed to answer a question ('blue card') in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)'

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Nobody supports undeclared work, but don’t we have to look at the root situation of society? There will, by society’s nature, always be people who fall below the threshold and who carry out undeclared work. Surely the argument should be taking the case forward for deregulation – we have got to deregulate, which is the direct opposite of what takes place in the European institutions, and actually give small businesses, small and medium enterprises – the lifeblood, certainly, of the British economy – the opportunity to move forward and actually create employment, rather than over-regulation, which is forcing more people into this area of undeclared work.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: answer ("blue card"). –It was difficult to understand any issue in this, but I can only say that small companies that compete with other small businesses by having unfair conditions for their employees, these small companies are probably quite angry that we do not have proper rules on employee conditions that everyone can live by, and that we do not have a legal system that ensures that they go there if they cheat , because cheaters are what they are.

name: Czesław HOC
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There is no doubt that the phenomenon of undeclared work in the wider world must be tackled or even combated. However, it would be best if we created a system in which it would not pay for economic operators to create such bad practices. The Union platform should therefore also provide an impetus for a concrete strategy and the allocation of EU money, measures to radically reduce labour costs, i.e. tax credits, subsidisation programmes, service vouchers for employers, facilitating labour market rules, creating financial incentives for friendly employment and strict enforcement of labour law and its culture, including a campaign to raise public awareness of the great harm of undeclared work. And that's what I'm calling for.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I am one of those who think that today is a good day for Europe and for European workers because we finally raise to the European level a problem which affects everyone and which can only be finished by step from a European perspective.  Clearly, the scourge – and you have said it very well – of the submerged economy is terrible and distorts everything: statistics, taxation, social security financing. It distorts even the very notion of democracy because certain regions, certain areas, are accustomed to living outside the law. And that's intolerable. The only advantage he thinks he has: the overexploitation of the most desperate.  It is very good that Europe has taken the first step, only the first step, to look globally at this problem and, with the help of the Member States, to solve it and, above all, to restore the dignity of workers on this continent.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Madam President, the right-wing policies followed in Portugal, in line with the guidelines and policies of the European Union, have contributed to the deregulation of labour legislation, the attack on collective bargaining and the deepening of mechanisms for devaluation and precarious labour.  In Portugal it is the Authority for Working Conditions which concludes that the austerity policies imposed by the troika contributed to the increase in situations of work in whole or in part undeclared, the false provision of services, false paid internships or false voluntary situations. It points to the use of fixed-term employment contracts and the use of temporary work as a contribution to job precariousity. For this Europe outside it will be no different.  Combating precariousness and undeclared work can only pass, within the framework of the sovereignty of the Member States, through links that guarantee security and stability, the valorization of collective bargaining, wages and work with rights, that is, the opposite way to what the European Union has been imposing.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – So, work on the black, of course, as you have said many times, has very serious negative consequences on many segments, first of course on workers' rights, on their pension... pension status, including social rights and so on. And, of course, also on the budget, the budget of the country, the municipality and, finally, the European Union. However, it is true that, after this platform, which is certainly to be welcomed, concrete measures must follow. And I think there are still a lot of frameworks where we can help combat the work of the black. One of these is, of course, an appropriate tax policy, which should be stimulating, which should push employers and workers into the working-no relationship. Public procurement can be an excellent facilitator for the need for those who wish to work with the State, with municipalities, these companies, to show that they fulfil all the conditions for employees. The mapping of activities in the field of active employment policy, social policy and, above all, the updating of data so that we have timely and correct data here on the true number of people working on the black. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Thank you very much, Mr. Soltes for accepting the blue card. My question is do you agree that the difference in the percentage of black work that exists between member states, where some countries have 1.5% -2% and some other countries up to 30%, can this be resolved more and more strongly at the European level, by exchanging experiences and even by creating one inspectorate at European Union level that would be in the function of solving such a problem right now?

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: The answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. - Of course. I think that the protection of workers' rights should, of course, also be established at European level. If we have a so-called ombudsman who cares about human rights, surely one of human rights is also the right to work, to a decent life. And so it would not be too bad to think about this platform forward, even for the so-called Inspector-General at European level, as has been thought of from the General Prosekjutor at European level. For someone who, on the one hand, would take care of a consistent exchange of information between Member States and promote good practices so that this difference you are talking about – from one and three per cent to 40 per cent – would not increase, but reduce.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are now close to the vote that will establish the platform for cooperation in the fight against unead work. The creation of this platform is certainly a good thing in order to promote cooperation and coordination between inspectorates, but it is undeniable that this structure will have costs on the Union's budget, and that is why we will have to ensure that this is not yet another European bandwagon, but that it really serves the purpose for which it was created, namely to combat unead work.  As I know only too well, in my country, those who work in the black economy are subjected to precarious working conditions and extreme exploitation practices, such as caporalato, which affects not only migrants, but also Italian citizens, as demonstrated by the shameful episodes of the deaths of southern agricultural workers this summer. There are also many abuses related to the misuse of vouchers. With this vote, therefore, we hope to make our contribution to making the fight against unead work increasingly a European issue.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Madam President, in our European Western society, the commodification of human activities has long been the rule, in contrast to food activities that persist in some parts of the world.  The more commodification is caricatured through the globalization of trade, the more the criterion of profitability and productivity takes over the necessary rules of respect for individuals. This globalization takes the lead on the recognition of professional activities as the cornerstone of a country's economic prosperity and the sustainability of quality social protection. This structured social protection is one of the most remarkable characteristics of the social evolution that all European countries have shared over the past two centuries. Inherited from the Christian humanism of mutual aid and relief to the weakest, it was structured with the industrial revolution of the 19th century. But globalization is sweeping away these hard-won social advances with opaque and subterranean profits. The cost of a worker has become the adjustment variable, associating fraud with indecent contributions and wages.  The fight against undclared work is an urgent obligation and all the more important because the new digital industrial revolution is an extraordinary boon to create all the conditions for widespread fraud. It is the very survival of our economies that is at stake. Europe appears to be a very bad step in regulating and curbing the phenomenon. Only states can hope to be effective. I therefore say yes to international cooperation to improve working conditions for workers, but not to a European hyper-regulation totally ineffective in view of the porosity of external borders and the free movement of people and goods. The proof is the 10,000 migrant children who would have been lost in a matter of weeks.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Madam President, we must in any case stop the continued exploitation of workers. It is a disgrace to Europe in 2016 that undeclared work has such an extent. Every worker must have secured social assistance, insurance, a fair wage and a pension that guarantees him a comfortable life afterwards.  However, the Union is only interested in words for workers. You are degrading even the most basic workers' rights, citing a supposed competitiveness, you are turning entire countries, such as my country, into special economic zones and you have the audacity to talk about workers and protection.  Come to Greece and say that. In Greece where with your policies you have created a huge humanitarian crisis and you claim that this is the way to the future. We're giving you this future. We are fighting for our own future in a different European Union. We say 'no' to a Union of protectors of large international capital, a Union of chief executives, which, with the tax raids ordered and carried out by its domestic submissives, seeks to destroy every trace of the national economy in order to distribute the debris to its multinationals.  Moreover, all of you who are interested in workers' rights have been steadily seeking, for a long time, to replace the European working class with hordes of illegal immigrants, knowing, of course, how much easier it will be to exploit this new workforce and achieve a downward assimilation, again in the interests of multinationals.  After all, remember that President Schultz himself had asked for 50 million new immigrants for Europe. But know that the people wake up and send you and your policies to the garbage of history, wherever you belong.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. Thank you, Madam President. Dear colleague, you have said, among other things, that you do not want the big capital, the big businesses, to be protected. But do you agree that it is only through collaboration between Member States that we can identify undeclared work and, precisely, not protect infringements of workers' rights in large or small companies?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), answer a question with a "blue card". – Dear colleague, you probably didn't understand well, or the interpretation was wrong. I didn't say that thing. I said that we must protect all workers, because everyone has equal rights, whether they work in small businesses or in large enterprises. But, unfortunately, these policies protect multinationals and not workers' rights.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: Madam President, Madam European Commissioner, dear Marianne Thyssen, mr rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, in a Eurobarometer study in 2013 for the European Commission, undeclared work would represent between 15 and 20% of the GDP of some Member States of our Union.  We are all aware of this: undclared work is a real threat to our economic and social models. Behind this term lie serious situations, such as the exploitation of workers, precariousness, unfair competition and, of course, heavy losses for states and their social security systems, among others. The progress of undclared work undeniably leads to a sense of injustice for the vast majority of our fellow citizens who respect the rules. In addition, we have unfortunately seen that this phenomenon can lead some states or regions to bankruptcy. The creation of this European platform is not additional legislation, but a link of cooperation between states, which should lead our far-right colleagues, who are strong proponents of any new European legislation, to vote for it (I do not understand their inconsistencies). This platform will show that the European Union is opening its eyes to this system of unfair competition and that it intends to provide a concerted response between states. In addition, let us not forget that the fight against unreported work must also be played upstream. Indeed, much of the problem also lies - we must have the courage to say so - in national legislation that is often unsuited to the world of work and to the evolution of society. As the Eurobarometer survey shows, 50% of respondents consider unreported work to be beneficial to both parties. The roadmap is therefore clear for the Member States: to combat undclared work, but also to give our companies and our employees less burdensome administrative and fiscal rules in order to promote economic growth, and thus job creation.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – In these times of choosing between no work, undeclared work or flexible work, many people find themselves in a rock and a hard place and it is therefore all the more important that abuses, such as undeclared work and bogus self-employment, are brought to light and employees can simply make use of their existing formal rights. I would therefore like to thank Mr Pirinski and his team for the great efforts to achieve this platform to combat undeclared work. It is a first step in the right direction in the fight against abuse of workers, against abuse of social security and the undermining of a level playing field between companies. It is also hoped that this platform will increase understanding between Member States and improve cooperation. These are all positives.  It is also positive that the participation of social partners as members of this platform will help to identify problems in specific sectors in specific countries. That is why it is important that all Member States commit themselves to this approach. In Belgium, for example, this approach has already led to Secretary of State Tommelein receiving really large amounts of additional contributions to social coffers.  With that, the platform is part of the puzzle and I ask the Commissioner: where is the labour market integration package? Because in addition to this platform and the enforcement directive, we also need proposals to close the gaps in the legislation.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The report on the establishment of a European platform to strengthen cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work, i.e. undeclared work, is the result of difficult negotiations and a convincing success of the ECR's position. It has finally become clear that the capacity of the Member States in this area is very different and that there is no point in resolving these issues completely at European level. Some countries have a good grip on the problem and it would be foolish to overlay it with additional regulations and regulations. There is a compulsion for member states to become members and to participate in regular consultations, but no one is forced to adopt the various policies. The goal remains more or less an exchange of experience. The weaker countries can benefit from the experience of the stronger countries, and the EU has the role of mediator and organiser. In view of the continuing centralisation in many policy areas, this is a sign of common sense, which is why I am happy to support the report. It would be nice if we could continue to see such approaches in the future.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – Madam President, the prevention and dessuasion of undeclared work must be an effort for everyone, the European Union and the Member States. Undeclared work harms the Union economy, jeopardizes the financial sustainability of social protection systems, generates unfair competition, disfigures market laws, leads to a lack of social and labour protection for workers and often has a cross-border dimension. A large number of undeclared workers are particularly vulnerable, particularly women, migrants and domestic workers.  A particularly worrying area in this area is the use of young trainees to temporarily replace absent professionals. Under the cover of vocational training, some companies are actually using these young people for non-specialized professional tasks, not paying them or paying them much lower wages than the work done.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Madam President, the progress of unreported work is indicative of the dysfunctions of our societies and the global crisis we are experiencing. Austerity, which is causing a decline in opportunities, is putting pressure on stable employment and pushing to work in the dark. This is unfair and detrimental to the workers concerned placed in insecurity without social guarantees.  This is bad for the whole community, because it pulls down all working conditions and denies social rights, it is a lack of funding for social protection and in state revenues, and guidelines like the one on seconded workers allow fraud. The quitus given by the Commission to the new model based on self-entrepreneurship also maintains it. In addition, the new "Uber" models are making a new type of wage, free of any social obligations for the contractors. The platform is a good decision, but we should work more deeply, revising the Directive on Seconded Workers, regulating the status of cross-border workers, setting up a European body of labour inspectors and creating, in the face of new economic models, the conditions for job security and social protection for all.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, for economic recovery to be reflected in all strata of society, it is necessary to continue to create employment that is becoming of increasing quality. And the first step must be to fight undeclared work and its negative implications for society. On the one hand, it affects workers, their rights, their working and wage conditions and the acquisition of pension rights. On the other hand, it has a negative impact on social protection systems, causes unfair competition in the company and encourages the development of a submerged economy. Just a few weeks ago, a very noteworthy fact appeared in the press: in Spain, one of the countries with a high unemployment rate, it is estimated that there can be more than 4 million undeclared workers , or 18% of the working population – of which 1.3 million are directly blamed on labour fraud. The role played by the social partners in combating this scourge is essential and Member States may only convert undeclared work into formal work if supported. To do this we must carry out measures that favor recruitment and control, and the platform will serve as a basis for support to better understand the reality we face and fight abuses.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Georgie Pirinski, for his really professional work and the excellent negotiation, but not only to the scale of undeclared work, but also to the public's tolerance for this phenomenon. I therefore call, first of all, on the Member States to pay as much attention as possible to prevention and the education of workers, so that illegal activities are simply unjustifiable. We must educate the public about the negative consequences of undeclared work, because, on the one hand, workers working in such work are without any social guarantees, receive lower wages, then lower pensions, on the other hand, states collect less tax, which has a negative impact on social protection systems, on the domestic economy of countries, and ultimately distorts competition. I would also like to point out that undeclared work is also prevalent in sectors where women are mainly employed, such as grandparents, children, the sick, the care sector for people with disabilities, household work (cleaners, nannies), it is difficult to control these sectors and to get those people out of the shadows, and people working there in many cases do not have any social guarantees. I therefore very much hope that the European platform on undeclared work will be effective and will help to strengthen cooperation between Member States. Commissioner Thyssen, speaking, you said that you would make every effort to get this platform into operation before the summer. I wish you the best of luck to be.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – The platform provided for in this report can only contribute to reducing unregistered work if it actually helps, through the exchange of information and experience, to identify the true, numerous and diverse causes of this phenomenon, without attempting to impose a single way of seeing and acting on the Member States. Too high taxes and other mandatory financial burdens, sometimes lower salaries, are considered to be a common reason for staying in the grey economy. But it can also be a lack of legal jobs and too high a price for certain services in some countries and too high wages. Rigid legislation contributes to the development of the grey economy, another reason being a legitimate lack of confidence in the social security system, especially pension systems, which have been used by some governments in recent times to supplement the budget on an ad hoc basis – and low interest in the law in general. Attention should also be paid to the actual acceptance of undeclared work among employers and workers. Dealing with these problems is primarily the task of the Member States.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: – Madam President, strengthening cooperation at European level to prevent and deter undeclared work is extremely important not only for the European economy and its treasuries, but also for the citizens themselves. Undeclared work and work in the grey sector seriously undermine people's ability to benefit from the social benefits that should be available by default. These include, for example, the accumulation of insurance and pension periods, the use of rest, sick or maternity leave, the additional overtime payment.  Very often, workers in Europe are put in a dead end and, under duress, agree to such arrangements. High unemployment rates further contribute to this. We must therefore welcome measures aimed at addressing this phenomenon and encourage both cooperation between Member States and between national authorities at central and regional level.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Undeclared work is an economically and socially costly phenomenon: it spoils the market, deprives workers of their rights. Therefore, this platform is very necessary, but it would be bad if its activities focused solely on control. Many employers and employees take up or offer black jobs out of desperation, poverty, lack of good regulations or too much tax burden.  I therefore call for, among the various tools to combat undeclared work, to focus on transparency of legislation, facilitation of the tax system, on reducing the burden on employers and on the preparation and arrangement of rules on temporary, secondary and seasonal work. Better regulations are particularly needed in the homework market, which is mainly occupied by women and which is very difficult to control, because we would violate the domestic mir. There are good examples of solving this dilemma: we have a well-functioning service voucher system in Belgium, france. And that's why you should go in that direction. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The domestic labour market will grow intensively due to europe's ageing, demographics, increased retirement age, longer presence of women in the labour market, due to the capital pension system. Therefore, it is very necessary to prepare recipes for this market. In conclusion, clear rules, facilities for entrepreneurs, and only then control.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have before us an important text which will serve to create a high-level European body with an absolutely central objective, that of combating undeclared work. We are well aware that this problem is not only a burden on public finances, generating tax evasion and unfair competition between companies, but above all represents a source of serious risks for workers and society in general. It is a threat to the health and safety of workers who are often employed in wearisome and dangerous sectors, such as agriculture, construction and industry. It is a problem for the maintenance of the social fabric, also understood in a geographical and gender sense. It also affects the most vulnerable groups, including refugees. It is therefore right that the European Union should strive to find a solution and to have representatives of the Member States, the European Commission and civil society, including trade unions and employers, sit at the same table and identify the European dimension of the problem. In my opinion, a long-term objective that we must set ourselves is precisely that of regularising unead work. I am pleased with the efforts we have made to improve the text, together with my fellow Members, starting with the rapporteur, Mr Pirinski, who has done an exceptional job for which I would like to thank him. It is now important, Mrs Thyssen, that the choice we are making should be implemented quickly by the Commission efficiently and concretely.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: I believe that this report has taken a good path, and I would like to emphasise that. Undeclared work is a major social problem and damages the economy because competition is not fair. All Member States must therefore work well together to tackle undeclared work effectively and efficiently.  It is therefore a very good idea to set up a European platform to enable the effective and rapid exchange of data and information. It is logical and necessary for the European Union to play a role in this. I would also like to note that the rapporteur has ensured that the Union respects the powers of the Member States and does not go beyond its supporting role. Each Member State should have the scope to develop a tailor-made approach to the various problems it faces. As the report takes this into account, I can fully support it.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, regularizing undeclared work is fair to improve the situation of clandestine workers without rights, precarious workers, victims of all kinds of abuses, but it is also essential to combat the deterioration of public services.  Eurostat has shown that, more submerged economy, more cuts. I therefore welcome the determination to coordinate a European multi-level action against this true scourge by also incorporating regional contribution.  I also welcome the acknowledgement that this problem particularly punishes women and that special sensitivity is required with them and with some of the sectors and situations to which inequality traditionally condemns them.  Finally, I support that we place a lot of emphasis on tax measures and any order that turn clandestine employment into a bad business and treat those who offer it as what it is: a pirate who traffics in the need of his fellow citizens and attacks our social model.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Madam President, undeclared work is a social and economic scourge with very deep and complex roots which seriously harms workers in their social and labour rights, which has serious budgetary implications and leads to a reduction in tax revenue and social security contributions.  I therefore welcome the Commission's initiative to create a European platform to strengthen cooperation in the fight against undeclared work, for which the participation of the social partners is indispensable. But in addition to sharing good practices on how Member States articulate the prevention and penalisation of such abusive situations, it is essential to promote properly declared work and also to combat abuses on workers. I am referring not only to paid activities which become unlawful because they are not properly declared to the competent authorities, but also to false self-employment situations.  However, we can only effectively prevent undeclared work if we create real incentives for workers and employers to realise that they only have advantages in declaring the work done.  I therefore call on the Commission's attention to the need to reduce labour taxes globally and to increase the benefits of workers and their families in terms of social assistance.  I call on the Commission to encourage Member States to diverge into other forms of tax revenue and to invest in health care, pensions and unemployment support, which will limit the temptation to escape from the tax authorities through the deregulated employment relationship that constituted undeclared work.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is particularly important to me that letterbox companies fall under the responsibility of the platform to combat undeclared work. Why? Constructions such as letterbox companies are not only used to exploit social security systems, but workers and workers may be worse off in the event of litigation. Likewise, of course, tax avoidance is open. Undeclared work is a scandal – not only traditional undeclared work, but also one or other form of new self-employment, because behind these forms of new self-employment, single-person societies often, hide nothing but forms to circumvent the application of labour law, social standards. And this is, of course, a scandal that is to be combated by this platform to combat undeclared work. It is also of particular concern to me that there is a platform to combat undeclared work in order to create confidence, to create the confidence of the labour inspectorates beyond the various borders, in order to know what is actually going wrong in the individual countries. That is why, of course, I am very much looking forward to the first reports that we will receive and the development of guidelines for the enforcement and control authorities of the Member States. And at the end of this long journey, I hope that there will be something like a European labour inspectorate.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Madam President, unreported work is a crucial issue, particularly in its place in the underground economy. If the fight against this form of work is a prerogative of the Member States, it is essential to establish synergies at European level.  It is with undisguised enthusiasm that I will vote in favour of the creation of this platform. The negative repercussions of unreported work are numerous, too numerous for the State budget, for the balance of social security systems, for companies because it creates unfair competition, for employees who lose their rights in terms of pensions, unemployment, access to health care, protection against accidents at work. Indeed, an accident at work is a disaster for the worker, who is not protected, and also an economic disaster for the company, especially if it is an SME, which may be forced to close its doors. I would like to stress the importance of the role of social partners in this platform. It will also have to tackle mailbox companies and fake independents, which we must fight to combat social dumping within Europe.  This platform is a first step, but this will need to be pursued through the establishment of a social inspection service in the Member States to enable the exchange of information. I am convinced that the European area must become an area against social dumping and an area of social justice.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, today we must congratulate ourselves on taking such a positive and relevant step in combating undeclared work in Europe. A platform for cooperation between States on good practice, but which will combat one of the most worrying economic and social phenomena we have: a problem for European society, a huge problem, equivalent to 20% of gross domestic product in Spain, and in some countries between 10% and 35%; with workers who are victims of this phenomenon, without security, without rights and who are often the most vulnerable in our society; a problem for our economy, because it distorts the labour market; and a very big problem for public coffers in many of our countries. This platform has several very positive elements that we want to highlight: that has included, to combat it, fraud of law in recruitment, not only undeclared work; that all Member States will be part of the platform, which is very relevant; and that social actors will play a leading role in this cooperation. A positive step, but we believe that it will only be one step and that there will be much to be done. We can take more incisive measures, which is also what a problem like this requires, to combat a scourge for our economy and for our society.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, today the underground economy in Europe is worth EUR 2,100 billion. This reporting fraud poses three problems: an infringement of workers' rights, an impoverishment of state coffers and unfair competition between European companies. Among them, small and medium-sized enterprises, which account for 99% of their total, are the first victims. The platform we are adopting today must be seen as a first step in combating undclared work, because it is finally putting all Member States around the table. It will open an in-depth dialogue between their various administrations and will also limit the use of fake self-employment and mailbox companies. In border areas, this cooperation will clarify responsibilities and limit the current legal uncertainty. However, this platform should not remain an empty shell. It must become operational without delay and allow for a real strengthening of controls and sanctions. It will probably have to focus on the frauds related to the secondment of workers one day as well. But beware, a simple platform won't solve everything. States must also engage in a genuine policy to combat impunity, to adapt taxation and to promote entrepreneurship to encourage a return of workers to legality.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: –  Madam President, first can I just note that it is a bit odd that today’s debate on this matter occurs after the negotiations have been so painstakingly – and, on behalf of Mr Pirinski, brilliantly – concluded in the trilogue. Why are we having the debate after the matter has already been agreed? Surely that of itself is undeclared work by Parliament? Secondly, I would just like to respond to our colleagues from UKIP, although as usual they are not actually here for the debates. (Mr Etheridge: Yes we are!) Not the ones who spoke; neither of the ones who spoke have stayed to listen to the rest of the debate, they have done their little bit of theatre and buggered off as usual. They gave us a load of nonsense about how we must not have these measures because it is anti-competitive. They tried to give us lessons about competitiveness and economics, and as usual they do not understand competitiveness and they do not understand economics. The whole point is that, at this end of the labour market, you need regulation in order to have a level playing field. The people who suffer from this lack of regulation, as well as workers, are precisely those small and medium enterprises whose competition is not from massive multinationals, it is from people below them in the labour market not paying taxes, not paying social costs and thereby getting an unfair advantage. If you understood anything you would understand that. (Applause)

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her We have already heard many examples today of why the fight against undeclared work is very important – both for our Member States and for the many workers. One reason is the empty public coffers and the high level of indebtedness in many Member States.  If you look at the figures for undeclared work in the Member States, they are already very frightening: Greece with 24.6% of gross domestic product, Italy 21.6%. But my own country, Germany, also has a lot of catching up to do; we are currently at 13%.  There are also positive examples in Europe. For example, Austria with less than 10%, which is 7.5%. The creation of a platform with the binding participation of experts from all Member States is therefore, in my view, a right and important step. It is about the exchange of best practice examples.  It was important for me to note that the new body primarily supports tried and tested and functioning methods of undeclared work at national level and creates a constant flow of information between the competent authorities. Harmonisation of control methods has been successfully avoided, which might have led to a weakening of best practice in the Member States. In my view, therefore, the exchange of methods of combating is the right thing to do; this should be a priority, not the adoption of binding requirements by the platform. I believe that we have found a common sensible solution with the Council and will continue to support this.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, despite its crucial budgetary competition and social implications, undeclared work has not yet received as much attention as it should have on a European level. As the 2013 Eurofound report on the topic pointed out, there are no obvious explanations regarding the dynamics of undeclared work. For example, contrary to what most people would expect, undeclared work does not necessarily go up in times of austerity, and reduced taxes and increased deregulation do not automatically lead to less undeclared work. However, what is obvious from the figures presented is that there are some Member States which are more efficient than others in dealing with this problem. The size of the undeclared economy in Austria compared to its GDP is almost five times less than the endemic proportion reached in my country, for example. If through this platform we succeed in transferring some proven practices across sectors and Member States and regularising a part of the grey economy, we would not only bolster fair competition and ensure more sustainability for public finances, we would also put an end to the exploitation of millions of undeclared workers who do not have the social protection or health and safety guarantees that others enjoy. In addition, results in dealing with undeclared work in a cross-border manner would also contribute to restoring much-needed trust in the functioning of the single market. (Applause)

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: – Unfair competition undermines citizens' confidence in the European project. As far as I am concerned, with the creation of this platform, Europe is taking an important additional step in the fight against undeclared work, bogus self-employment and other fraud.  It is the government's job to guard against the rules of the game, but in a single market, fraud does not stop at national borders. That is why I think it is right for Europe to take responsibility for this too. Responsibility towards workers who are denied their social rights by undeclared work and fraud. Malpractice is particularly pre-occurs in dangerous occupations and in vulnerable groups, such as low-skilled women or migrants. But also responsibility to the Member States which are losing their income as a matter of fraud and whose social security is so under pressure. Freedom of movement within the EU is our greatest achievement and we must not allow it to be undermined by unfair practices. Cooperation is therefore the key word. That is why I call for this important fight not to get bogged down in contradictions between Eastern and Western European Member States, for example. Everyone has to go in the bath. This is essential to ensure the proper cooperation of all the inspection services of our Member States. In concrete terms, I would like to emphasise the need for further and urgent digitisation of data exchange such as the Internal Market Information System and the EESSI system. This platform is certainly a step in the right direction, I am convinced of that. However, we can and must go much further. That is why, together with you, I am looking forward to the proposals on our Commissioner Thyssen's labour mobility package.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – The issue of undeclared work, as well as bogus employment, concerns all Member States, and although it is their responsibility to have the majority of the powers to prevent and discourage it, I am convinced that action at European Union level is equally desirable and can produce good results. Undeclared work has a negative impact on Member States' budgets and administrations. However, it should not be forgotten that this is, above all, a social problem that has a negative impact on the working, social and family lives of many millions of our citizens. The complex nature of the problem of undeclared work means that only cooperation between partners at all levels can contribute to its solution. I believe that the platform's responsibilities have been correctly defined. It has been given specific tasks, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity. I am also pleased that the social partners have also been involved and have been recognised as members of it. I hope that the Platform will be a place of real cooperation between partners and will be able to develop common enforcement strategies.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I first and foremost appreciate the report and the need for this platform. I think it's late, but it's good that we've now leaned on this issue. As a member of the IMCO committee and as shadow rapporteur for this report, I no longer want to repeat the disastrous effects of black work in the internal market, both on workers, on SMEs, as you, Commissioner, have stressed, but obviously also on budgets. I believe that a measure taken needs to be monitored, which is why I have allowed myself to make this amendment, so that you do not report to the European Parliament every four years, but every year, because I believe in sharing examples of good practice from other countries, and I do not believe, like colleagues on the right, that without cooperation, we can diminish work in the black. I also believe that it is important – and I have also proposed – that social dialogue partners be consulted and that we find ways to make workers aware, and societies, that it is disastrous in the long run for workers to accept black work. It is very important that we devote a great deal to this area.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, the common European labour market undoubtedly needs to set certain minimum standards that comply with European principles such as justice. Undeclared work is a problem for the Member States in particular, but it is also a problem for the Union as a whole. Unfortunately, the volume of undeclared work is increasing, the Czech Republic has also avoided this trend and we are already at about 19 – the volume of undeclared work, which is, of course, a phenomenon that we cannot like, and therefore the Czech Republic will certainly be involved in this common platform, which does not mean increased regulation, but a very good opportunity to share examples of good work and find procedures that will allow Member States to effectively combat this trend , which, of course, harms the labour market, employers and also employees. Efficiency and the minimum costs that will be incurred on this platform are important.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, undeclared work is interwoven with the whole process of deregulation of industrial relations. It is linked to the huge unemployment that exists and the pressure on employers to have black work. At the same time, undeclared work also means a huge loss of contributions to insurance funds. We see this, in particular, in Greece, where we have a huge tax evasion. A tax evasion that undermines the entire functioning of the insurance system.  In my view, of course, if the state wants to, it can hit tax evasion and it can do so effectively. I therefore think it is important to recognise the problem at European Union level, I think it is important that there should be this platform and the exchange of good practices, but it is a competence purely of the national state. And that is where we need to aim for a real hit to undeclared work and an increase in insurance contributions.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, undeclared work is a serious problem for the whole Union. But under no circumstances should we confuse undeclared work with tax evasion. Memoranda, austerity policies, high unemployment rates burden citizens and push many workers into safety, with businesses supporting this practice, making the most of workers and many Member States turning a blind eye.  The creation of a platform to prevent and prevent undeclared work can be helpful, without replacing national labour authorities, and we are in agreement as the Left. However, the solution to combat undeclared work and wage dumping can only be solved when Member States set protective laws in favour of workers, when they enshrine collective bargaining and collective agreements.  Also, for us, the neoliberal policies of harsh austerity and the memoranda that push workers into poverty and job uncertainty must be overturned with the mobilisation of workers.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, you might correct me if I am wrong, but I thought it was a standing procedure that, when there are too many speakers to be taken during ‘catch-the-eye’, there would be one speaker allowed from each group. I do not believe that anyone from the EFDD has been called.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Mr Etheridge, as far as I know, it is up to the Chair, and it depends also on the time spent on the debate. Today I took all the blue cards from the floor, and this of course impacts a bit on the timing we have. I am not supposed to take necessarily from each political group.
