I was trying to be fair here and, for example, you yourself from the EFDD Group spoke, but I also took a blue card from you. So I think you should be satisfied to have participated in the debate today.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Today you are going to approve the decision to step up the approach to undeclared work, and tomorrow, as a colleague here pointed out, you will also vote on the package to combat tax avoidance which you are about to discuss. These two files reinforce each other. Both are initiatives to make it clear that Europe is an area, that Europe is a community based on values and where social justice has a place. Both dossiers will ensure, including this platform to combat undeclared work, that there is a better level playing field for business - certainly SMEs crave it - that everyone pays their fair share, both to the social security authorities and to the tax authorities, and that undeclared work is combated and preferably converted into regular work, into quality jobs, which is better for everyone.  The platform involves all the relevant authorities, including the social partners. It is good that they also have a voice, because they know the reality at the grassroots better than anyone else. The platform provides a structure, but not a straitjacket, to put your hands together and act effectively. The platform does not replace member states' inspections. Nor does it take powers from the Member States. It does, however, ensure that the possibilities available to the Member States are supplemented. It will encourage the Member States - and this is the intention - to make their inspections more effective and, why not, to be inspired by each other's best practices for their policies. By working together, everyone will win, I'm not just convinced of that. I hear you share that view.  You can count on the Commission to do everything we can to give that platform the support it needs, and it goes without saying that, as agreed, we will keep the European Parliament informed and report regularly at the appropriate time and on a regular basis.  As far as the mobility package is concerned, that is not directly the subject of this debate, but several questions have been asked about it. Well, as far as the mobility package is concerned, I hope, along with many of you, that we will soon have the political circumstances in which we can launch this optimally, because also that mobility package serves the level playing field and social justice, of course in addition to facilitating the labour mobility that we continue to need in the internal market.  I would like to congratulate the rapporteur once again, as well as all the negotiators who have cooperated in the trialogue, and I look forward to the results with you.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I believe that the debate this morning has served a very important purpose. As the Commissioner began her initial intervention this morning, she highlighted the particular severity of the complex problem of undeclared work and the corresponding need for clear talking and for very definite and unequivocal conclusions, and she stated further intentions for action. I would like to highlight what I believe has been the underlying conclusion: that the various direct impacts of undeclared work on workers, tax and social security systems, and unfair competition, finally come back down to a threat to the very fabric of society in each of the Member States and throughout the European Union. If I am not mistaken, yesterday evening President Draghi began his intervention by pointing out that, at present, the European Union is faced with increasing infringements relating to social cohesion – economic, territorial and social cohesion. It is not by chance, I believe, that he began with that point, because whatever efforts for job creation, investment and fiscal responsibility we want to implement, if the basic fabric of the society in which we are trying to implement such measures is being destroyed, then they are hopelessly forsaken. Therefore I believe, as has been pointed out, that this platform has seemingly built an acceptable balance between the concerns for individual Member States’ rights and the need for Union input so that the problem is better tackled. I see that the time is over. I can only second the intention which was mentioned. We hope the platform is put into action before the summer. We very much support the statement by Commissioner Thyssen, and we support bringing this debate again and again back to this Chamber, to the committees of Parliament, since clearly we need much more discussion, sharing and vigorous action.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. Each State has autonomous legislation on the fight against undeclared work and an independent scope, but the Commission has given a common minimum definition. This has been recognised in any lawful activity of a nature, but not declared to the public authorities. This is a particularly acute scourge in Italy, where it contributes to tax evasion and avoidance, as well as determining generally deplorable working conditions. The idea of a common European platform for the exchange of good practice and comparison between Member States and between them and the social partners is certainly a useful tool, but the direction must be to identify more incisive macaisms, both with regard to repression and prevention of the phenomenon.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – Initiatives like this do not get rid of the risk of passing through authentic monuments to hypocrisy. In recent years, it has been the Policies, Guidelines and Impositions of the European Union, translated at national level by the right-wing policies implemented by successive governments, which have led to a growing deregulation of labour legislation, an attack on collective bargaining, the increasing precariousment of labour relations, the increased exploitation of workers.  In Portugal, it is the Working Conditions Authority itself that confirms the very significant increase in situations of total or partially undeclared work, false provision of services, false paid traineeships and false voluntary situations – following the intervention of the Troika (IMF-ECB-EC) in the country. Intervention, remember, cauted in this Parliament by them who now express dismay at the increase in undeclared work and enthusiastically support this initiative: right and social democracy.  It's a case to say they do evil and the caramunha. Or "well preach Friar Thomas, look at what he says, don't look at what he does." It is necessary, yes, to attack precariousness head-on. This implies, first of all, reversing measures recommended and imposed by the EU at national level. It is not enough in itself, but it is an indispensable first step.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. – We agree that work must be all declared and with rights, but the fight against this work should not penalise the workers and workers who are imprisoned in it. I would like to point out that it affects women and migrant people very importantly. It is necessary to dignify work, that all workers have social and labour rights and decent wages. Therefore, in addition to disencouraging undeclared work, it is necessary to eliminate these labor reforms that suppress rights, make workers and workers precarious and enshrine the figure of the poor worker. We must also owe the regulatory convergence of the TTIP. We know many cases of false self-employed workers as a consequence of the precariousity associated with the practice of subcontracting. We are often talking about former employees of companies who are forced to become independent in order to continue working, but in conditions of great precariousness. A European minimum wage and a universal basic income are indispensable instruments in this struggle.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – I welcome the European initiative to develop a platform to strengthen cooperation between Member States with a view to preventing and discouraging undeclared work. This phenomenon is harmful to the undeclared active workforce which cannot be engaged in professional development activities, maintains a low level of productivity, does not receive medical insurance and pension insurance. But undeclared work has even more serious consequences for people who get older, no longer have the full capacity to work and no access to a pension scheme, having to resort to welfare and charity. That is why this European platform should become operational as soon as possible, and that Member States and all social actors should give it due attention.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the decision adopted on the Corporate Tax package (2015/2980(RSP)).

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I made a commitment to you some time ago, in a previous debate, to provide the quick answers you expect to the challenges of tax evasion and evasion. The package we adopted last week is making that promise a way. This debate is an opportunity for me to present this answer and it also confirms, in line with the measures adopted last year - you remember our two packages in March and June - that it is possible to act quickly and clearly on corporate taxation.  First of all, at the beginning of this debate, I would like to welcome the decisive role of the European Parliament on these issues. Your House has given valuable support to the Commission in redefining the contours of fairer, more transparent and more effective taxation in terms of content, but also in terms of political impetus. This topic could not and could not progress without your commitment. Our institutions, the Commission and Parliament, as you know, are often in tune. On what? On the absolute need to adopt concrete measures to really combat abusive tax optimisation and strengthen tax transparency, which is our common goal. The measures recommended in various reports presented to this House last year by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and similar measures by their nature or effect (TAXE) have highlighted these convergences and, unsurprisingly, many of the measures contained in the package reflect - you can and will see - the recommendations made by this House. So I'm very happy to be here this morning, in tune with you, but let's now come to the package itself. Our desire for reform is very simple and deeply shocking: some companies today do not pay their fair share of taxes, or even pay taxes at all. This is a situation that has become, for many of our fellow citizens, absolutely unbearable. This strategy, which I would describe as a circumvention strategy, takes advantage of an international and European tax system that is clearly no longer adapted to today's economy, that is, an economy that is global, mobile and complex. In response to this, to combat this inadequacy, the package I am presenting to you rests on four pillars. First, effective taxation, not theoretical, taxation of companies. It's very simple: companies have to pay their taxes where they generate profits. Second, a qualitative leap for tax transparency. Thirdly, a healthy and fair tax competition, and finally a fine articulation between the internal dimension of the European Union, which we must address, and the external dimension, which we must also take into account. I come back to those pillars, in that order. First: effective taxation. The initiatives presented last week will ensure this effective corporate taxation. This means that, in reality, there must be a strong link between taxation and where the profits are generated. To this end, we will rely, with your support, on two instruments: a directive and a recommendation.  We first drafted a proposal for an anti-tax evasion directive. I do not want to go into the details of the provisions here, but the proposed initiatives will, in particular, prevent companies from transferring their profits to subsidiaries located in low-tax states, and then prevent companies from circumventing certain laws limiting the deductibility of interest, using so-called "hybrid" instruments or entities and , and, finally, to counter the practices of certain companies that transfer their assets from one state to another in order to avoid paying, precisely, the tax on those assets. These measures, as you can see, are in line with the recommendations made last year by the ECON and TAXE committees. In truth, we are following through on your own work.  This directive is supplemented by a recommendation to prevent misuse of tax treaties. You are familiar with these practices: some companies set up artificial structures to access the most advantageous tax treatment, under various tax agreements with other Member States or with third countries. Our recommendation tells Member States how to make their tax treaties more watertight to these tax treaty shopping practices. The second pillar is decisive and fundamental to me. It's the fight I want to fight during this mandate, which is tax transparency. At the heart of our action is the country-by-country information directive. This text is a manifestation of our commitment to a real revolution in tax transparency within the Union. In concrete terms, the measures I am presenting to you this morning will enable the exchange of key information on certain companies between the tax administrations of the Member States. What is it about? I want to be specific. The draft guidelines implement OECD recommendations on the publication of country-by-country financial information. You know what is at stake: it is about allowing administrations to better control irregular transfers of profits between companies. So today we are proposing to transpose the standards as recommended by the OECD. It's a first step. I know that many of you want to go further in terms of transparency and make the country-by-country reports of companies public. I will tell you things in the simplest way - and you already know it - that is also my wish. I have expressed this on several occasions in this House and outside, and I have been trying in my political practice for a long time not to have double-talk. I am therefore in favour of publishing country-by-country information. A number of parameters must then be taken into account, and the Commission will submit a proposal on this point in the spring.  What is the problem? Our services are looking at the best approach. We have conducted a public consultation, we are conducting an impact study and the problem must be this: is there a contradiction between this increased publicity that you want - like many others, like many others, like other members of the Commission, you know that some have spoken out in this area - and the competitiveness of our companies and their ability to invest. If so and if there is this contradiction, we will have to wait a bit. Otherwise, we must move forward resolutely. That is what this impact study must say. You know my wish, you know my will, I think at the same time that we must act on this matter with a lot of pragmatism and not by letting ourselves be guided by ideology. Transparency and competitiveness are two objectives that we must pursue together. The third pillar is that we want to restore healthy and fair tax competition between companies within the internal market. I am talking, both about competition between economic players, such as businesses, and between Member States. Let's first look at what's happening at the corporate level. There is now a profound imbalance in the tax burden between SMEs and multinational companies. When I talk about certain companies — I will be more specific now — multinationals have the means to aggressively plan tax. That does not mean that everyone does, I do not want to be in a trial of intent. I am simply saying that they have the means, with the legal services at their disposal and with their own internal organization, to do so. It is therefore SMEs, which represent the core of Europe's productive fabric, that are at a disadvantage. To put it another way, there are significant distortions of competition against companies that pay their fair share of taxes. We estimate that the tax burden on SMEs is up to 30% higher - that's a considerable number! - than that which weighs on multinational companies. This situation is unacceptable and cannot last any longer. The measures proposed by the Commission therefore directly target the increasingly aggressive tax regimes of multinational companies that have the means to evade tax.  The package will also restore fair tax competition between Member States by protecting their taxable base. This is the principle of base erosion and profit transfer (EBITB), which you know. Some Member States have already taken the measure of tax evasion and have adopted measures to counter its effects, but others have not followed or - to be more than lenient - not yet followed and this has resulted in a particularly unfair situation where the anti-abuse measures taken by some Member States are, in fact, undermined by more permissive legislation that is taken elsewhere. The package I am submitting to you will therefore allow the Member States to return to an equal footing within the Union, and that is a necessity. Finally, the last pillar: we are developing a genuine external strategy of the European Union. Our initiatives aim to provide a comprehensive response to a global problem. Let's be frank: we need a common approach at European level vis-à-vis the outside world, in addition to the internal measures that will be taken by the Member States.  Our new strategy therefore tackles the risk of external tax erosion and promotes greater cooperation between the Union and its international partners. I am thinking, first of all, of the non-cooperative third countries, which pose a real threat to the balance of the internal market. The Commission intends to work with its international partners to promote good international tax governance. That is what is happening at the OECD; that is what is happening in the G20. I say this here firmly: we will not hesitate to toughen the tone in the face of states that persist in the wrong direction. As you can see today, the package presented to you hits hard, with a series of solid and consistent measures.  Our new European strategy thus proposes the establishment of a European list - and I stress the two words: European list - of non-cooperative third countries. So far, as you know, I have taken the initiative to have a list that is, I would say a kind of best of, medley of national lists with their inequalities. Some have no non-cooperative states, others have 85. Some have certain criteria and others have less or have different criteria. It was not satisfactory, but at the same time it made a difference. This has provoked a debate and changed a number of states that have felt targeted and have already come off this list. I do not want to name names, because there have been virtuous behaviours. However, the European list I am proposing would be based, as the European Parliament has suggested, on objective and fair criteria decided by the Member States, as well as on an ongoing dialogue with these countries: effective corporate taxation, tax transparency, sound and fair tax competition, and external strategy. These are the four pillars of the anti-tax evasion package that we are submitting to you.  I would now like to say a word that may be a little more technical - but behind the technique, there is often policy - concerning more precisely the implementation. The package allows for comprehensive and coordinated implementation of OECD recommendations. What are the parameters that we have to deal with? To put it simply, we must both avoid the effects of variable geometry, because not all Member States of the European Union are members of the OECD, and take into account the specifics of our internal market. To avoid a partial or disparate application of EBITB measures, which would de facto doom our package to failure, a common approach was therefore essential. In addition, some specific initiatives go further than the EBITB recommendations. It is also because we have fed on the debates that have taken place in this House and the discussions in the Council, and it is also because we are a Union, therefore with a stronger integration than a system like the OECD. In our previous discussions, some in this House had questioned the competitiveness and economic attractiveness of the Union. I would like to reassure them that the initiatives proposed this morning are not hostile to them. On the contrary, I deeply believe that transparency and competitiveness go hand in hand. The provisions I suggest will avoid a patchwork of national legislation, which would seriously damage the internal market and therefore the economic activity of European companies. All this shapes a tax system in Europe that will be favourable to companies that play by the rules and not favourable to those that play with the rules. So it is clearly the first ones that we must focus on. A few words to conclude, first of all to look before us towards what awaits the Commission, towards what awaits you for 2016. This anti-tax evasion package, which is, as you can see, very ambitious and very comprehensive, arguably the most ambitious and comprehensive that has ever been proposed by a Commission and examined by this House. However, it is only the beginning of a series of initiatives that we will present to you in the coming months. We will have another big event this year: you know that 2016 will be the year of the rebirth of the ACCIS, the Consolidated Common Base (CCCTB). THE ACCIS has the merit of providing a comprehensive response to the problem of profit shifting within the Union, while providing companies with an optimal framework for their economic exchanges. So I want to keep or rather pick up the tempo on this project. The Commission's services are currently working on a proposal which should be a proposal step by step, because we have seen that a one-block approach has not convinced the Council and what I want, as always, in tax matters is to marry the desirable and the possible. The possibility, ladies and gentlemen, I must say, is through the agreement between us, but also through the consensus of the States, since you know the decision-making process in this area, which requires unanimity. Some may regret it. That is how our institutions are made and of course we must respect that sovereignty. But one step at a time! Through the package that is the subject of our discussions today, the Commission reaffirms more than ever its commitment to the fight against fraud and tax evasion. I have already said this before you, I hope forcefully, and I repeat it even more forcefully: we must fight these forms of economic inefficiency that create social injustice. The most honest actors, the taxpayers, now have to bear the costs of these distortions unfairly and these are considerable sums that are lost for growth, for public services, for hospitals, for security, for schools, for public transport and for the economy in general.  We need to re-inject more justice and transparency into international taxation and our own European taxation. The measures presented in 2015 were already a very significant step in this direction. In particular, I recall the long-awaited directive on the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings, to which your Parliament has provided so much. The package we have just adopted represents a further major step in this demanding but indispensable path. I fervently hope that Parliament and the Commission will continue together in the coming months on this path to finally make tax transparency and a fairer international tax that we want: a reality.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to welcome both the content and the timetable of the package that you have just presented to us, which is very much in the case of the recommendations that our Parliament adopted at the end of last year. I would also like to welcome the quality of cooperation between our institutions and regret the absence of the Dutch Presidency, which could have told us what consequences it intends to draw from these proposals during the six months of its mandate. Parliament will play its part during this period, extending the debate to all national parliaments, those of the 28 Member States of the European Union and, beyond that, those of all the countries that the OECD has associated with its work. We will do so in May. We must understand that, under the pressure of public opinion after the LuxLeaks scandal, pressure that we relay in our institutions, a change of mindset is taking place for everyone. The Google case is a comical example of this: for years, our countries have competed in great secrecy to be the one that would be the most tax-efficient with regard to these types of multinationals, and now we are going to see competition, at least apparent, to be the one that makes these kinds of multinationals pay the most. This makes urgent the second part of your proposals, Commissioner, that is, the harmonisation of the corporate tax base within the European Union. With regard to the publication of business results, we will see that, in the face of this change of mindset, some multinational companies will make their results public, country by country, and will see it as a trade argument. The others will be forced to follow. The Commission and our institutions should not arrive after the battle, so let us propose this publication from the outset.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group, Mr President, I shall begin by greeting the Commission for fulfilling its promise, for presenting an ambitious proposal and for following a path that is a historic change in the way the European Union has been dealing with the problem of direct taxation.  In fact, the Commission has played a leading role and has responded to the public pressure, which this Parliament interprets, so that taxation is not a factor of relative injustice and a factor of incoherence in the internal market where so much is harmonised and where we control each other with regard to budgets as well. And budgets aren't just expense, they're also revenue. I also welcome the Commission for having been concerned about giving a European response to the OECD initiative, but I think that Europe must stop being a follower of the OECD to be leading, within the Framework of the OECD, in combating fraud and tax evasion, and it is also in this sense that I interpret the current proposal. We must go further and the path has been written in this Parliament's TAXE report. The Commission recognises this and I thank the Commission for that very fact. In fact, there are still elements, such as the definition of what a tax haven is, what is a permanent establishment, in which we would like the proposals to be stronger, but we believe that it is not yet possible to ask for this.  I would also like to stress that this Parliament hopes, and also reflected this in its text TAXE, for the Council to take on this change in the philosophy of European policy. We have to go further. The CCCTB has to come to fruition. The report, country by country, has to be public. We must move forward in dimensions that are the only ones compatible with the internal market and with a single currency, and in that respect we regret and we are surprised at the absence here of the Dutch Presidency. This is because, and I quote the TAXE Report, Member States with a key role in facilitating tax evasion must assume their responsibilities and lead efforts to strengthen tax cooperation in the European Union. Let us hope that the Dutch Presidency will fulfil this plan.

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. I have to say that the Commission's communication is really not good. I hear too much talk about higher taxes and a little too little talk about lower taxes and more efficient businesses. Companies are not cash cows. It is they who provide jobs, prosperity and you make it right.  We must ensure that everyone pays their taxes fairly, including multinationals. That they can't evade those taxes. We do this precisely by sharing information, by working together between tax authorities, by opting for more transparency. But also by staying vigilant. And I stand firm: we remain vigilant on three points: 1. Smaller Member States must also remain competitive and taxes must be reduced. That is why we need healthy tax competition between Member States. It would therefore be a bad idea to harmonise taxes at European level;  2. We must not be blind to that international context. If the Commission wants to impose more obligations, which go beyond what has been agreed internationally, then we are primarily in the foot; 3. We are counting on the Commission to keep its word and, in any case, that no additional burdens will be placed on the shoulders of small and medium-sized enterprises. That is in the Commission's texts. We also assume that this will be made permanently hard, because that is the only way to ensure that we have to pay less tax and that everyone pays their taxes fairly.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which The European Commission's proposal for two directives is a major milestone in the creation of fair tax competition in Europe. That was also the bottom line, the conclusion that we drew as the TAXE Committee – with a report that was adopted here by the majority of the house. First of all, therefore, congratulations, Commissioner Moscovici, on your proposals, which also incorporate the OECD recommendations into a binding law. From the perspective of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, the key is that the 28 national tax laws create loopholes – not as before – that can then be used by a few – especially international corporations – to reduce their tax burden to virtually zero. For example, when the Sunday Times reports that six of the uk's top 10 companies did not pay corporation tax in the UK in 2014, even though they report global profits of GBP 30 billion, it shows the whole dimension. And there are clear indications on the table that small and medium-sized enterprises, which cannot use these tax avoidance schemes, are being penalised. The effect is estimated at 20-25%.  That is why, from the point of view of a social market economy, it is essential that we create framework legislation at European level that has led to a level playing field, to fair competition. During our visits, for example in Switzerland, we have seen how such a competition can be organised. The automatic exchange of information is one thing, but also a common corporate tax base. However, we do not see them in these proposals. Hence the question: when can we expect this? And now the attack is also coming from the UNITED States; this is where the US government wants to put pressure on – it sees its corporations at a disadvantage. We expect you, Commissioner, to make a statement on this here, because we believe that the United States, too, must move so that together – the United States and the Europeans – we can achieve a better global framework that prevents aggressive tax avoidance in the future.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Moscovici, U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders – the Main Street candidate, not Wall Street – scored a fantastic result in the Iowa primaries tonight. Sanders, like my group, the left faction, is outraged that the working population is the stupid, while global corporations like Google do not pay taxes. More and more people, whether in the USA or Europe, are also outraged by this. Only the Juncker Commission continues to do business as usual. This is their third tax package, and yet LuxLeaks could continue to repeat itself. With their interest rate barrier, corporations can continue to shift 30% of their profits to low-tax countries. In doing so, they are scratching the edge of what the OECD still considered permissible. They also fail to tax group subsidiaries in tax havens: the tax may be 60% lower than the tax of the country of residence; at a tax rate of 12.5%, as in Ireland, only 5% tax is due. In the OECD, it would originally have been at least 10%. Every secretary pays more tax than Google and Co. Mr Juncker said LuxLeaks should actually be called EU leaks. He is right. However, they continue to pretend that there are no tax havens in the EU, and there is no sanctioned blacklist. The EU cannot therefore claim a leading role in combating aggressive tax competition. The honest taxpayers can no longer afford such a Commission, such a bunny-footedness!

name: Eva JOLY
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, the proposals you are putting forward are another step towards ending the tax avoidance of large companies in Europe. For example, I would like to welcome the exit tax proposal, which would tax at least once profits are relocated to countries outside the European Union. However, when you look at them closely, the texts on the table are incomplete. As it stands, they will not put an end to the most cynical tax practices. Parliament, I hope, will weigh its weight to strengthen this text. Here, I do not want to downplay anything, but to say that if things do not move fast enough, the primary responsibility lies more and more clearly with the Member States which, behind the speeches, continue to engage in destructive tax competition. The ultra-beneficial tax adjustment (3% over ten years) granted by the British Minister Osborne to Google is part of this dynamic that tramples on the spirit of European cooperation. Mr Moscovici, you must now give the means to as many people as possible, including the European Parliament and civil society, to put governments under pressure so that in the coming months the anti-EBITB action plan will be completed and that, in the coming years, the newly drawn rules will be respected in each of the 28 Member States. That is why you must finally give clear support to the public nature of the publication of financial information, country by country. The battle against tax injustice will not be won in the corridors of the Council or the Department of Finance, not when job blackmail has become the norm, not when ministers have become chief lobbyists of the interests of the largest groups.

name: Tim AKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, there is a reason why tax should be decided by nation states and not the European Union. The diversity of culture across the European continent means each country has its own strengths. For instance, the French have their wine, the Germans industry, the Spanish tourism. These have not become clichés without some truth behind them. Each of these cultures needs to be able to reflect its strength in its own tax system. Tax is a subject for each country to address multilaterally, not via the EU, because the EU’s solution to every problem is to harmonise. Competition between states in taxation also encourages them to get better value for money when they deliver public services. In this single market, Google was free to pay its corporation tax in the lowest tax bracket it could find. The EU’s solution will not be to close loopholes but to hike taxes across the EU, chasing companies who pay their fair share out of the EU entirely and taking thousands of jobs with them. If anyone thinks EU powers over corporation tax are a good thing, just look at what they have done with VAT. Under EU law, Member States have to beg permission from the Commission to reduce VAT, but there is free rein to increase this tax. Look at the UK’s Green Deal: a 5% VAT rate on energy-saving materials. Obviously this is a welcome policy to keep heating bills down and make sure people are warm in the winter; but what did the EU do? It took the Green Deal to the European Court of Justice, and now the Green Deal is gone – killed off by unelected judges. The EU’s record on tax kills jobs and stifles innovation. Anyone who still thinks corporation tax will be safe with the EU is, frankly, out of their minds and, with the EU’s damaging policies, they may well be out of a job too.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner Moscovici, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has Google's parent company, Alphabet, is currently the most valuable company in the world, with a market capitalization of 550 billion dollars. At the same time, the Italian authorities are suspected of having evaded taxes amounting to EUR 227 million between 2009 and 2013. Google recently compared it to the UK government, where €170 million in taxes were repaid. Google, like other corporations, uses tax-saving schemes in various European countries. In the course of the LuxLeaks affair, this has entered the public consciousness. According to a study by the European Parliament on behalf of the TAXE Special Committee, the EU loses up to EUR 190 billion each year through profit shifting, special tax arrangements, inefficient tax collection and similar practices. The EU and the Member States can no longer afford this. That is why a firm approach to aggressive tax planning is needed for free tax competition and fair tax competition. The Commission's proposed approach to this matter, namely fair tax competition, is based on three central pillars. On the one hand, this is to ensure effective taxation in the EU. Parliament has also been very active in this with the TAXE-1 report, and a TAXE-2 will certainly follow. And the Commission is now following with the anti-avoidance directive. The main issue is that profits should also be taxed where they are incurred. A second point is greater tax transparency. Here, too, Parliament has already been active: the Ferber report, the automatic exchange of information, and the Commission now wants to revise the directive on administrative cooperation. This is an important step. It is also important that country-by-country reporting comes, and it is also a good moment that the Member States of the European Union will implement this automatic exchange of information within seven months. A third important point is the guarantee of a level playing field, as has already been mentioned. SMEs usually pay 30% more tax than multinationals, which must be abolished. And secondly, an external strategy is needed. Tax havens must be highlighted. Only in this way can fair tax competition be possible, both for the interests of businesses and of the Member States.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, in order to attract investors and achieve sustainable economic growth, the tax burden on commercial enterprises must be properly and fairly distributed. Today, when we live in the age of globalisation, technological developments directly affect the economic environment and enable multinational companies to circumvent restrictions on the tax system of the various states, to make smaller profits and to profit at the expense of the peoples of all countries. That is why we must not adopt a common system of taxation which is flattening and does not take account of the economic specificities of the countries. The fair distribution of tax burdens can only be done within the framework of the national state, which, in implementing its budgetary policy, can take measures to protect the interests of small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the backbone not only of the national system, but also of the European system, so that thousands of people do not lose their jobs. , as unfortunately has been the case in recent years in my home country of Greece.  In this way, the national state will be able to adopt a social economic policy and then work with the other States to prevent the illegal and irrational speculation of multinational companies.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the package presented last week by the European Commission and Commissioner Moscovici certainly goes in line with the fight against this aggressive taxation of some multinationals, which has done so much damage to European SMEs and European public coffers. It's definitely a good start.  In the European Union billions are lost every year because of the taxation of some companies, money that could be used for public services, such as education or health care, or also to generate jobs and public growth.  We cannot tolerate citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, as I said before, who show their unequivocal commitment and effort from paying more because of large companies, some large companies seeking to evade taxes. In this case, we have done a lot of work through the TAXE Commission to bring to light everything that has happened in recent years and the agreements between large multinationals and some Member States, because for us transparency is and will be a priority.  Now is the time to look forward to making sure and ensuring that past mistakes are not repeated. We must move towards a fiscal union to avoid entering a fiscal war, and that both multinationals and SMEs are subject to the same rules of the game.  Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that what was presented last week — as I said at the beginning - is a good starting point and I think we should ask the Commissioner to implement it, to be a reality as soon as possible. And I think you have the support of this House.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is very interesting to hear this morning what the rules proposed by Commissioner Moscovici are going to trigger here in this House. On the one hand, we have those who say that companies are dairy cows, we have to come to even less taxes. I would point out that the average multinationals pay 1% or less! Yes, what does it mean even less? No more taxes at all? Then, on the other hand, we hear that the Commission is going to be buisness as usual. This is how we talk about our own work here in the House! In recent months, with the TAXE Committee of Inquiry, we have only created the climate for the Commission to present proposals today – and as early as last summer – that go beyond anything that has been possible over the last ten years. We must work together with the Commission on this. We need to ensure that companies of any kind that operate multinationally pay a fair tax rate, which can vary from country to country, but they must be subject to fair taxation and pay taxes. If we want to do that, however, we must look at the Commission's proposals calmly and carefully. Then we can certainly call on the Commission to be bolder and to help it go beyond what is on the table today. That, for example, companies with an annual turnover of more than 750 million are used not only for public reporting on where which company pays how many taxes. Let us take all the big companies as we have defined them elsewhere, from an annual turnover of 40 million. In doing so, you would have subject most of the multinational actors to a reporting obligation and you would have the transparency to be able to derive the necessary measures from this. Transparency is the key word. Country-by-country reporting, which is not made available to the Commission by the Member States, will prevent it from having the necessary transparency to be able to play its role as guardian of the Treaties. We want this transparency, we want you to be able to fill this role. I believe that Parliament will continue to give you its support by a large majority in the future. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), question with "blue card". – I believe that no one doubts that we need to crack down on tax evasion, tax fraud, and multinational companies paying their taxes as all businesses pay for them. Under no circumstances should we flatten tax rates. With a common single corporate tax rate, and even by raising this tax rate, what they will achieve is to destroy small and medium-sized enterprises in their countries, but also to lead any foreign companies to leave to other countries outside the European Union.  In other words, in fact, at the moment we are going to hit any countries that have stayed in the European Union and are financial centres, because they transparently have low tax rates, they do not escape tax, they do not launder money, there is full transparency, and if it is made clear that the common single tax rate will not be introduced, but that competition will continue, then I believe the European Union itself will be protected.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank the If you have noticed that we are not talking today about the unification of corporation tax, but that we are talking about a standardisation of the corporate tax base in an overall context, then much has already been gained. Because that's what it's all about. We want to know: how much is tax paid at all?  If Member States continue to have the chance to calculate so little what companies have to pay taxes on, for example, that they could, for example, impose a tax rate of one hundred per cent and still pay no tax, then you have gained nothing. We need transparency to know what the tax base is. Only then does the discussion about any tax rates make sense; but only then can we assess whether companies pay taxes at all or whether, as in the past, tax rates of 1% or less are the norm for multinational scoundan groups.

name: Ashley FOX
text: – Mr President, I can give a cautious welcome to Commissioner Moscovici’s proposals to introduce new rules on corporate disclosure. Requiring multinational companies to provide annual information on sales and assets to tax authorities is necessary to tackle aggressive tax avoidance. The United Kingdom has placed greater tax transparency at the heart of our G8 agenda and was one of the Member States that initiated the OECD/G20 base erosion and profit shifting project. The Commission is right when it asserts that Member States cannot tackle this problem alone. But I hope, Commissioner, that you also realise that the EU cannot tackle this problem alone either. It has to be dealt with at the international, rather than the European, level. My fear is that there are those in the Commission and in this Parliament who see this problem as another excuse for more Europe. I do not support plans for a common corporate tax base. This is unwanted interference in the rights of Member States to decide their own tax policies. By acting through the OECD, we will ensure that Member States not only fulfil their obligations but also remain competitive in the international markets. We must ensure that multinational companies pay their fair share of taxes. The best way of ensuring this is to keep tax rates low and tax codes simple. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I was interested to hear you talk in your speech about competition and free enterprise and drawing the line at an EU-wide corporation tax level. Is this something that you would consider yourself personally as a red line, where the UK just simply must always say no? And if the movement towards this continues, what would your decision be on which way you would vote in a referendum, were a common corporation tax part of the deal?

name: Ashley FOX
text: blue-card answer. – I am pleased that tax policy remains an exclusive competence of the Member States and that the Member States retain a veto, and I am certain that any Conservative government now or in the future will veto a common corporate tax base. I therefore see no prospect of it or common tax rates coming into practice.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: – There is a package here to tackle tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning, and we very much support that goal, because we agree that everyone should pay their fair share of taxes, citizens, SMEs, but certainly also the multinationals, who should not get away from the dance.  So it seems that the good things are being done here, but that's not the way it is. Because not only do you have to do the right things, you have to do those good things right. That is why I think it is a missed opportunity that there has not been a proper impact assessment. I regret that the international context in which we have to operate in order to remain competitive has not been fully understood. And that there are still some vagueness in it, some broad definitions, for example of the anti-abuse provision, which will allow you to get ambiguity and differences of interpretation, which will lead to a walk to court. And then we create jobs, but only for lawyers. And that's not what we meant. So we are going to look at these proposals meticulously and where necessary we will try to improve them. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. Thank you, Mr. President. Dear colleague, you talked about a necessary impact study. I want to ask you, regarding the Commissioner's claim that SMEs are under three times more tax pressure than large companies: do you think that this package solves the Small Business Act, which needs to be tested for SMEs? Do you think that this legislative package solves the problem of SMEs?

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: "blue card" answer. – I cannot judge that at the moment. But I'm sorry, too. That is why, especially in the light of vice-president Timmermans' agenda for better regulation, I regret that not all these aspects, including for SMEs, have been taken into account, because then we would be better off valuing it. Now, as parliamentarians, we have to do this again through our own impact assessments through our discussions with the whole field itself. I think that's a missed opportunity.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, despite good intentions and goodwill, the Commission's proposal remains a handful of nothing. The Luxleaks scandal and the others that followed showed one side of the european project's greatest injustice. We have multinationals that are tax-easing, billions of euros that are lost every year to public accounts and which obviously translate into money that is lacking in health, in public schools, and which have as reverse a brutal tax burden on those who work and in small and medium-sized enterprises. Having said that, I have nothing against country-by-country notification, as long as it is public, and I have nothing against betting more on transparency, but I want to ask you, Commissioner, when do we start taking concrete action where they take serious action on the abuses that have been made by multinationals? When do you really think about the issue of tax havens? When do you really think about the definition of permanent establishment? When do you really care about the protection of warning launchers, through which we know about these scandals? It is that, in order to ensure the confidence of European citizens, Commissioner, to ensure that confidence in the European project, much more needs to be shown that they are worth more than the businesses of multinationals, which are systematically protected by this Commission.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, I am convinced that the Commission’s tax package indicates a genuine desire to challenge the power of multinational corporations to use their cosy relationship with governments to minimise their tax payments. The era of there being one rule for corporations and another for the little people must come to an end. I am less convinced about the commitment of UK Chancellor George Osborne to the fight against tax avoidance. He may be good at pretending to do something radical in London, but in Brussels he is doing everything he can to make sure these proposals do not become law. So I was pleased to see him calling for public country-by-country reporting of company profits and tax returns – but perhaps he needs to check the voting records of his own Members here in this House, who recently voted against an amendment to achieve just this. As MEPs who represent small businesses and citizens who are bearing an unfair tax burden, we are tired of tax competition and even more tired of competition over tax rhetoric. We are tired of politicians who make the right noises when the latest scandal hits the headlines but then vote to protect corporations and their sweetheart tax deals. As Greens, we are determined to end corporate tax avoidance, and as shadow rapporteur on the country-by-country reporting part of the package, I will be watching how Osborne behaves when the Commission package reaches the Council. It is then that his words will be tested with action, and the British people will not forgive him if he continues to protect the corporations and his words issued in the heat of the moment are seen to mean nothing.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for this proposal I have to say that the expression 'the mountain has given birth to a mouse' would be very good. It is a classic of the Community method that the Union should try to solve very serious problems by using inadequate remedies. We would expect much more courage from the Commission, because we know that we will then have to fight with the Council for satisfactory agreements and we are well aware of the approach of some Member States for which deeds tell us more than a thousand words. I wonder, for example, where the Dutch Presidency is today. They are probably committed to finding some agreement and a new measure of tax advantage to attract businesses, to the detriment of their European partners, as they have done all these years, in good company, together with Belgium, Ireland or President Juncker's Luxembourg.  The European Commission says nothing about these shameful practices, because it knows full well that there is no common will to do so at European level, but rather it is a race to take advantage of neighbouring countries, facilitating only large multinationals to the detriment of small and medium-sized enterprises. In this regard, I would like to understand why, in its proposal, the Commission does not refer to a 'country by country reporting' that is public, because that is what the citizens of Europe are asking for and is the only way to make it effective.  Transparency must be the key to everything, because only in this way will we be aware of how multinationals and The Member States really act, the same states that say they are ready to cooperate but then refuse to provide documents or delete all compromising information, as we have all seen extensively in the work of the TAXE Committee.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the European Commission last week presented two texts to continue the fight against tax optimisation. The initiative is commendable, though incredibly late. The French ENF fully supports the ACCIS plan and the ban on the six tax optimization schemes. With regard to the publication of country-by-country financial information, we are in favour of an exchange between administrations, but not a public display of business economic data. On the other hand, I regret some of your weak proposals compared to those of the OECD, such as the deduction of interest to the tune of 30% of EBITDA when 10% would be reasonable. Furthermore, I note that a number of countries, such as Italy, the United Kingdom and Belgium, have entered into redress procedures with multinationals aimed at paying down past unpaid debts, which the FN has been asking for for France for a year in the TAX committee. These "Robin Hood" states have brought hundreds of millions of euros into their public coffers. Even if these revenues are below the actual tax shortfall, this is already progress. Mr Moscovici, your countrymen would have enjoyed the same tax justice when you were finance minister. Today, I hope that your friends in the French government will achieve similar results to relieve the tax burden on taxpayers.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, the problems highlighted in LuxLeaks or disclosed by Google’s tax deal with the UK will not disappear on their own. We need to act. Furthermore, fair taxation protecting those who are not avoiding taxes will not appear out of the blue. Those who understand the agenda are well aware that we need more coordination and more cooperation, and we need to agree on mutual functional rules. There is no country—by—country solution in this case. That is why I welcome the Commission’s initiative, which is based on a clear agenda highlighted by the OECD BEPS project, the Commission’s Action Plan and also work by Parliament. You are proposing the implementation of some key BEPS recommendations, and you have my support. I hope we will soon also get the support of the Finance Ministers in the Council. But this is just the beginning. We need to implement all the BEPS sections, and we need to fight for implementation, not only in the EU but also globally. Secondly, there is a list of specific EU recommendations, such as improving the function of codes of conduct, better measurement of the tax gaps or increasing transparency. Last but not least, the CCCTB project is very important. This is not just to improve the possibility of collecting taxes but also to create a better environment for companies operating in Europe. I believe you can count on the support of most of the Members of this Parliament. I hope we will succeed and make the tax system in Europe better.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, in the wake of the SwissLeaks and LuxLeaks cases and the establishment of a special committee in the European Parliament, you have presented several tax packages to try to curb tax evasion by multinationals. Let us not be afraid of words, I think you are one of the Commissioners who pursues the most ambition to restore order in the House of Europe, through a fairer and more inclusive taxation.  Of course, not everything is perfect, but all your actions are moving in the right direction - it is important to stress this - and I encourage you to go even further in this matter. Some of your proposals follow the recommendations of our special committee, others are more cautious. Thus, we proposed in our final report to set up an automatic and comprehensive exchange of information on tax rulings between Member States. Last year, one of your proposals took up this measure, but avoiding some recommendations, which is unfortunate. I am obviously thinking of the publicity of these exchanges, but you are here to tell us that you want to continue and move forward, and I am delighted. This new package of proposals is obviously another step in the right direction to counter tax evasion and avoidance. I am thinking in particular of two other measures included in the report of the special committee TAXE, namely the automatic exchange of information in the context of the publication of country-by-country information and the chapter on the consolidated tax base.  Unfortunately, however, I do not think there are certain elements that are crucial to prevent multinationals from organising the parade. I am thinking in particular of the clear establishment of the profit zones of multinationals, which would force them to pay their taxes in the countries where they are engaged in economic activity and not in a tax haven. We know that Google is a champion of this kind of practice, but it is not the only one, and we all know that a multinational that does not pay taxes in the country where it operates economically obviously undermines the social model of our societies, namely financing for all health, social security , education, employment aid and security. Finally, our regret, Commissioner, is the tax package that you have just presented and which is not intended to harmonize corporate tax in the European Union. This is a difficult measure to implement, but it would allow for healthier and fairer competition. We can see that there is still a long way to go in the field of tax evasion. I hope that Parliament will follow you and can even go further, since I have heard many echoes in this regard.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I welcome the tax avoidance package. Many multinationals, through aggressive tax planning, exploit loopholes and mismatches in national laws and, because of that, they end up paying derisory levels of tax that have absolutely no connection to the profits they make. The OECD estimates that corporate tax evaded at local level is somewhere between EUR 100 and 240 billion annually and at EU level it is somewhere between EUR 50 and 70 billion. Those are obscene amounts of money forgone and, as you said, Commissioner, there can be no social justice or equality while this regime continues. The Commission tells us that the OECD’s Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) initiative is not sufficient. So the challenge for the EU is to drive this issue as a global leader while at the same time not damaging EU competitiveness or the potential for foreign direct investment. Our response must be proportionate and effective. Finally, it is not just the Council, the Commission and Parliament that will drive this issue; consumers will play a hugely important role, and that is why I believe public country-by-country reporting would be a very powerful tool.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, it was said today that multinational companies do not pay taxes. In fact, these companies do not pay taxes, not today, but for decades, with the full cooperation of the governments of the countries of the European Union. This situation stems from the process of liberalization of economies and capital movements, stems from the increasingly evident capture of political power by the power of large corporations. We cannot therefore disconnect this framework of fiscal iniquity from the current process of capitalist and deeply liberal integration of the European Union.  The tax package presented today represents a mere process of intentions whose results we will have to evaluate. Nothing is said in this package about the enormous influence of the consultancy industry on governments and the European institutions themselves. It would be interesting for the Commissioner to tell us who commissioned the impact study on the public disclosure of country-by-country reporting. Was it the PWC, which also did a study on country-by-country reports of financial institutions?  Still on country-by-country reports, will the same threshold remain that exempts 80 to 90 % from multinational companies? And with regard to the registration of interested parties, will we be able to scrutinise who are the people who hide behind the tools and vehicles used to drain profits to tax havens? Finally, the issue of tax havens. Are we going to watch the same film from the past again, with politically traded lists that left the biggest tax havens out, such as the City, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Luxembourg? Will tax administrations have the necessary resources? These are questions we ask and continue to follow.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, you come to us from France, less and less the homeland of human rights, it must be noted, but always the homeland of romance and love, and that must be given back to you. In France, one does not rush to the object of one's desire: one knows the importance of foreplay.  The problem, of course, is that when it comes to tax justice, after SwissLeaks, after Offshore Leaks, after LuxLeaks, the preliminaries keep going. But at some point, you have to act well, at the risk of obviously seeing the object of your desire go away, disappointed. What would "act" mean in this case? That would mean, and you said it yourself: to impose a country-by-country publication on companies, a public publication. You said you were in favour of it, and I believe you. Multinational companies must therefore declare not only how much profits they make, how much tax they pay, under what name they operate, how many people they employ, what tax arrangements they benefit from in all countries, and this information must be available to all our fellow citizens. We need to fully implement the OECD recommendations. However, I note that in the package you are proposing, which this time deserves the name of the package, you forget certain things: the obligation, for example, to have anti-abuse clauses in all bilateral treaties is, in your package, only a recommendation and not an obligation. I also see that the rules on foreign-controlled enterprises are not fully taken up either. We have to go further because the OECD has not taken care of everything. I take the example of this new means of tax evasion called 'patent boxes', the 'Patent Boxes', which the OECD completely ignores. I think it's up to you to fill those gaps. I would remind you that the OECD is an organization that makes recommendations, while you are at the initiative of the legislation. Finally, we must impose a common and consolidated corporate tax base, i.e. agree on what profit is and distribute that profit on an objective basis among the Member States by applying, of course, a minimum rate. All of this, you mentioned more or less directly in your speech. You tell us that you want to consume the act, and I believe you. But then, go ahead, don't hold back! It's really time to go! Of course, the question we can all ask ourselves is whether the Member States are, like Pierre Moscovici, in love with tax justice... Here, judging by the reaction, for example, of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, the Netherlands, but also of my country, to the recent decisions of your colleague, Mrs Vestager, I have reason to doubt it... The question is how to arouse desire... In any case, I hope that this institution, together with the Commission, will be able to arouse a burning desire on the part of the Member States, so that we can finally put an end to the scandal of this tax war which, I recall, has as its main victims small taxpayers, whether they are individuals or SMEs.

name: Petr MACH
text: – Commissioner, in your opinion, tax competition is evil, on the contrary, I consider high taxes to be evil, and tax competition protects taxpayers from endlessly high taxes. In Switzerland, for example, taxpayers are protected by a constitution that does not allow taxes to be raised above a certain limit, but the only protection for the European taxpayer is precisely tax competition. You're talking about aggressive tax practices, but I think your efforts to curb tax competition are aggressive. You say, Commissioner Moscovici, that you want to bring about a revolution in taxation, but you have no right to that revolution, the Treaties do not give the Right to harmonise direct taxes to the European Union, and you refer to Article 115 of the Treaty, but it is about the internal market and not about taxes. I think your only goal is to drag some of the taxes from countries that have lower taxes into your treasury with various tricks, and I would rather recommend to you in France if you are concerned that companies are leaving you because of high taxes, cut taxes and start running economy economically and not force us to pay high taxes.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The harmful phenomenon of tax avoidance by companies using aggressive instruments reduces budget revenues in the Member States of the European Union and creates unfair competition between companies. I agree that attempts by individual countries to solve this problem individually do not produce results.  I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal to drastically reduce the scale of this phenomenon by adopting a legislative package including a draft anti-tax avoidance directive and a proposal to amend the Directive on administrative cooperation. The draft anti-tax avoidance directive, in which the Commission proposes six specific instruments to reduce aggressive planning, is crucial. These include limiting the possibility of deducting financial costs from tax, eliminating the phenomenon of double tax avoidance, controlling foreign subsidiaries created to transfer profits and controlling the transfer of assets abroad, prohibiting the deduction from the tax base of certain flows within corporations. These lines of action deserve support, especially as they are consistent with the guidelines prepared by the G20 and the OECD under the BEPS programme.  However, I would like to make it clear that they must comply with the Treaties and, in particular, with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. In particular, there can be no question of harmonising tax rates. The arrangements adopted must not in any way affect the sovereign right of The Member States to determine the level of taxation. Nor should they unduly restrict the freedom of action of undertakings and impose additional administrative burdens on them.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Commissioner so much for presenting the Corporate Tax package. This is a very important step to a fair tax system in Europe, with the four pillars you presented. There is no doubt that multinational companies’ tax avoidance is a major threat to our welfare state and to fair competition in Europe: EUR 2 000 per capita per year. This is what it costs us in tax fraud and tax avoidance: EUR 1 trillion a year. It is outrageous how much it costs our societies. Imagine what this money could be used for – schools for our kids, education for our young people, investing in jobs and welfare. Furthermore, I think there is a very important principle at stake here. When citizens see that multinationals pay almost zero per cent in tax, they question the fundamental function of the state and our institutions. When citizens see that Belgium has given 35 multinational companies illegal tax deals, they see that multinationals appear more powerful than the state itself. Citizens see that the tax system is unfair. They see injustice. Countries and companies violate the law. They need, of course, to be punished. So what can we do to fix a broken system? I think first of all we have to bring transparency and light. Why? Because multinational companies operate in the shadow of the economy. They use the loopholes they can. As rapporteur for the report on the EU—Switzerland Agreement on the automatic exchange of information, I know that transparency is the way forward. Transparency and information are the building blocks for cooperation between tax authorities in our countries. Therefore, as you rightly say, Commissioner, we need public country-by-country reporting, and we need to see that so that multinationals pay their taxes and we need to see that they all pay their taxes. I ask you, Commissioner – I hope and I beg– that you fight for public country-by-country reporting. This is to ensure tax justice; it is to ensure and protect our welfare state and also our tax base.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, the powers of corporate taxation are currently in the hands of the nation states. This is problematic because aggressive tax planning is multinational in nature. I therefore agree with the recommendations of Parliament's resolution of December and hope that they will also be reflected in the Commission's work. It is clear that better coordination of national tax policies is the only way to eradicate tax arrangements that favour multinationals over small and medium-sized enterprises. And popular is Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg, who shrugged in December when he announced he was handing over 99 percent of his fortune to charity. That's a great thing to do. Of course, Mr. Zuckerberg could have paid his taxes, too. Let us help him with this work.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, I would like to say that we all agree on the need to tackle tax fraud and unfair tax competition. However, I would be pleased if the one who is mainly called upon here as an institution or as a Member State would also be represented here. It is surprising that the Council Bench is empty. And the fact that one of the main culprits, the Presidency-in-Office of the Council, is not present today is also an eloquent sign. In this respect, I am disappointed that those who are the sinners are escaping this debate here, whereas we in Parliament and – I would like to make it clear, Commissioner – you, as the Commission, are making proposals here that go in exactly the right direction, namely to have fair competition in the tax system – fair competition, not unfair ones. In this respect, I very much welcome the proposals, and I hope that the Member States, which have agreed at OECD level to at least implement and support the BEPS initiative, will actually do so. I myself was the rapporteur on tax rulings, and the Member States did not show much commitment when it came to bringing even a little transparency to tax rulings. So, my hope here is that the Council will now take a more courageous approach to things. I would like to expressly encourage the Commission to work closely with us here, to increase the pressure on the Member States to ensure that we find a good solution in their interests in the interests of taxpayers, namely those who cannot evade tax liability – small and medium-sized enterprises, ordinary employees.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, Commissioner Moscovici said that we must act quickly and clearly. I think we all share that objective and, from that point of view, the measures he has presented this morning are undeniably a positive signal.  I hear colleagues saying: "Finally, these measures are not up to the healthy and legitimate revolt of Europeans following the revelations of the LuxLeaks affair". Finally, ladies and gentlemen, let us also measure how far we have come! Some of the proposals that are on the table today were unimaginable until a few years ago. Let us also identify the resistance, Mr Lamberts, because the problem is not so much the Commission, at least not Commissioner Moscovici, it is the Council which obviously does not want this to progress. And let's finally recognize that this is only one step. Yes, only one step, because we need to make progress on harmonizing corporate taxes. I think we can do it. Progress must also be made in the publication of country-by-country financial information, including transparency. I want to reply to right-wing colleagues that transparency does not go against competitiveness, quite the contrary, especially today. We have to go further, there are some steps to be taken, not least because we need to extend certain measures to more multinationals, Commissioner. Today, the publication of financial information by country affects only 10-15% of multinationals. Colleagues, let us acknowledge that we are moving in the right direction. We have to move faster, we have to be sharper, but I believe we can put in place a fruitful partnership with the Commission. What matters is also the balance of power with the Council. (The speaker agrees to answer a question "blue card" (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, Mr Maurel, since you have challenged me, I would still like to be misinterpreted... When I say that foreplay is important, it is because the foreplay has substance. It is not just the act that has substance. I therefore do not deny that the preliminaries that the Commission has initiated in recent months have substance. I'm just saying that at some point you have to consume the act...

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, Mr Lamberts, I am not sure I am following you on your metaphor, which may lead us to a few slip-ups, but what is certain, and you will recognise it as I do, is that when we hear Commissioner Moscovici, we have the same objective. Even Mr Moscovici assumes - and that is good, because the Commission is a little more political than before - that he, personally, is in favour of publishing financial information country by country. Are you in a hurry to take action? I, too, want us to act quickly, but let us recognize our allies and those we are going to have to convince in this matter.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: – The Commission's plans are going ahead. They go much further than agreed in an international context. The scope for countries to maintain healthy competition between them, including in the area of taxation, is being reduced too far and the business climate in Europe is really getting a big tick from the Commission's plans.  The Commission says it is committed to a level Playing Field in Europe. That is wonderful, of course, but it really has to be done. A ban on corporate tax exemption for ports, as Mr Vestager recently imposed on the Netherlands, will not be affected as long as other European countries can continue to grant state aid to their ports. Finally, the Commission continues to reiterate its intention to come up with a common consolidated corporate tax base. I am sceptical about this, because that is the start of European taxation and will eliminate healthy tax competition between countries. This, like the above mentioned proposals, makes Europe a European single sausage. There is no support for this and it does not do justice to our pluralism. So don't!

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The implementation of our demands against tax evasion, against tax avoidance, against tax injustices between young and old is gaining momentum. That is a good thing. The proposals, with their six binding measures by the Commission, are not only the implementation of the OECD decision, but go beyond them and are right and necessary and therefore welcome by us. We want these six proposals to be implemented as quickly as possible, for nails to be done, even though we know that much remains to be done. The common consolidated corporate tax base is open – the proposal must come. Public country-specific reporting for multinationals is open – proposals from Parliament are on the table. It is open to full compliance with the VAT Directive – my colleague Mr Langen constantly points this out.
