And it is open that sinners are punished and not rewarded for their sins – the penalty contributions must be entered in the EU budget and must not be returned to the coffers of sinners. We still have a lot of work to do, but today we are taking the right step.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to tell you quite frankly that the lines contained in the package that you have presented to us are acceptable, but the content of the package is not. They're not consistent with those lines. They are far from the need, which you yourselves have put forward and which you want to resolve, that of having a tax behaviour that is respectful of the rules on the part of citizens and, in particular, on the part of companies. What is lacking is the heart, it is not only the proposal for detail that will have to come, but the idea that there should be no transparency on some of the most sensitive issues, I am thinking mainly of country by country. The OECD guidelines close and imprison this information in the context of tax administrations, they do not make it known to the citizens, and that is not good. Transparency has an extraordinary deterrence effect. I understand the Commission's concerns and it is right that the work on the impact assessment should be completed. However – you know this very well, and I remember it for everyone – when the same work was done for the banks, it was concluded that transparency did not create problems for competitiveness, but rather made it stronger. The same must be done for businesses. We need to broaden the area of application and then we need transparency as a basis. Finally, since you said – and I agree – that the package is timely, if the issue is timeliness, when you have finished work on the impact assessment, do not make an ad hoc directive, but place the conclusions of the proposal within the shareholders' rights directive, which is already under discussion, and we will have recovered months and months. And in this case we would have given substance to the idea of early intervention.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission for the package. I think it is important that taxation is fair, in order to fight illegal tax avoidance, and transparent regarding the differences, but also – something which I think we tend to forget in this discussion – it needs to be competitive. Europe needs to be a competitive economy. To be fair, the European Union is the most highly-taxed region in the global economy, and we certainly do not have the best growth and the most innovative development of companies. This is one of the problems we are discussing, and I think it is important to take this perspective into consideration in our discussions. The US is not going to go as far as the Commission now proposes for the European Union. The European Union is going beyond what the OECD is proposing. This means that there will be problems with competitiveness. But I would also like to underline one thing, namely that in the digital economy it is not that easy to say where an activity of a company is. It is not like in the old industrial economy. I think it is extremely important to have a focus on transparency and fairness, but also competitiveness. I think there we need – in Parliament and with the Commission – to do much more work, because Europe is not the competitive economy we need it to be.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, we are facing an historic moment when it comes to our tax system. Either we take the bull by its horns, or we continue with the system established in 1928 that fails to reflect the globalised and digital world we live in. We need to have a level playing field for European tech companies to grow, to become global leaders. The EU has to lead the action on tax evasion. The absence of the Dutch Presidency is most disappointing, given that it is the Member States which hold the blame for this. Commissioner, I welcome your proposals. They underscore the need to share tax information across EU countries, making it harder for multinationals to shift profits to low tax jurisdictions or to avoid paying tax completely anywhere in the European Union. We do have to face the fact that it is the legislative framework that allows multinationals to circumvent paying tax legally. So we have to close the loopholes and ensure that it is implemented consistently across the EU, and having an agreed list of tax havens is a significant step forward in the fight against tax avoidance. The Times yesterday reported that sweetheart deals like the one for Google are not unusual in the UK for the FTSE 100 largest companies: BP, Royal Dutch Shell and AstraZeneca all failed to pay any corporation tax in the UK in 2014. They have not broken any law, but we need to change this, and we need to do it soon for justice for all our citizens.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, you are being very generous with our speaking time this morning. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I also welcome the decision of the Commission on the Corporate Tax package, which was of course long overdue. In this regard I also welcome the relaunch of the common consolidated corporate tax base, which was introduced in 2011, but too little has been done to enforce it across Member States. More progress has to be made here, and much faster. Until now, big multinationals had considerable tax benefits to the disadvantage of SMEs, as has already been said. The Commission has a strong role to play in paving the way for a level playing field between SMEs and big multinationals. This is a crucial factor for supporting a better business environment for every company active in the single market, be it small or large. SMEs are a major job creator in Europe, therefore making corporate taxation fairer for all companies also safeguards employment here in Europe. Moreover, entrepreneurship and start—up creation are essential for innovation and the creation of the jobs of the future. Only then will a competitive advantage of European companies in the long term be ensured. The establishment of cross-border business is facilitated by making conditions equal for all companies and by improving coordination across Europe. Europe can catch up considerably in the areas just mentioned. So far, cross border e-commerce in Europe can still be expanded and facilitated. Only then will we create the foundations for a truly integrated single market in the coming years.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, there is indeed a promising historic opportunity to end the industry of tax avoidance. This industry does not lead to fair competition among countries, as some in this House may suggest. No, indeed: this industry makes use of the jungle of national tax laws in which the fittest survive. That means that the largest companies do not end up paying their fair share but pay hardly any taxes at all. So I welcome this initiative by the Commission. I am, to say the least, surprised by the absence of the Dutch Presidency, and I ask myself whether this opportunity is being exploited to the maximum. I will make two critical remarks. First, there is still the incentive for each Member State under these proposals to bring into effect lower taxes. My specific question for the Commission is: what happened to the idea of a minimum effective tax rate that was put forward by a coalition of large Member States? Second, even if this proposal blocks some ways of avoiding tax, there will be new ways developed by the industry of tax avoidance. It is clear that we need public, country—by—country reporting to end this industry once and for all.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! From the PPE-DE point of view, it is good and important that the Commission should be closely aligned with the OECD recommendations. Europe is not an island in terms of tax coordination.  Joint progress at international level is important in order to ensure the competitiveness of European businesses. We must certainly work to ensure that not only Europe is leading the way, but that third countries are also on board. To help the OECD process to achieve resounding success together.  We welcome the fact that the Commission has now presented further legislative proposals against tax avoidance. The announcements in recent months to combat tax avoidance can now be followed by action. We are counting on your vigour, Commissioner, to be able to help you achieve the necessary unanimity in the Council of the Member States. The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs will certainly take a hard look at the anti-tax avoidance directive. In the case of country-specific reporting, it certainly makes sense to start with a non-public exchange among tax administrations. The information is thus available where it can be used most effectively and efficiently. And we think it is right that the scope should be concentrated on multinationals. A reporting bureaucracy for all European companies would not be justified. All-encompassing reporting would not comply with the principles of improved regulation and proportionality imposed by the Commission itself. All-encompassing reporting would make tax-paying small and medium-sized enterprises stand for what some large corporations have triggered with their aggressive tax practices. That is why we are calling for clear differentiation here. Google's tax deals have recently shown us once again the importance of rapid progress in European tax coordination. We therefore expect the Commission, with a proposal on the common corporate tax base, to pave the way for such cases to be a thing of the past in the future.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr President; I believe that most of this House, Mr Moscovici, is in favour of your project, in favour of combating this tax avoidance, which causes economic inefficiency and social injustice, as you rightly said. But it's going to be a long march. Surely, it will be long and difficult. There are two obstacles I'd like to highlight. The first is in this same House: not only in many groups in that part of the House; also in many political groups that claim fiscal competition between States as an economicly correct competition. I don't understand that tax competition is good, legal and fair. I find it very difficult to find loyalty in tax competition in a single market between States of the same common currency, as we have. I just don't understand, in that unit, that fair competition.  And secondly, the problem will be in the States, because many do not allow the Commission to play a monitoring and coordinating role in creating a kind of tax agency to pursu this matter. These two obstacles are serious, Mr. Moscovici.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The tax reform package is undoubtedly an important contribution to greater tax justice. Tax rules must apply equally to everyone, both businesses and individuals. To achieve this, we need a single European system of taxation and the principle that multinational companies such as McDonald's should be regarded as a company and not as a multitude. A merger of franchisees, for example, must be anchored in the European Union. However, I am also missing a lot. What I miss, and what previous speakers have said and which is particularly important, is more courage to increase transparency through public country-by-country reporting. I have just had a conversation with the Dutch ambassador, who has assured me that when the Commission's impact assessment is available, the Dutch Presidency is prepared to take up this issue and not just stick to the OECD rules, as they have so far in the Presidency. What I also miss are proposals for intellectual property, in other words patent boxes. Here, too, I would like to see more ambition on the part of the Commission.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – I think that we can all say that the package of measures put forward by the Commission is, on the whole, heading in the right direction, and I would also like to congratulate the Commission's competent authorities on this matter. Mainly because we can now say more and more frequently that our main ambition is for all companies in Europe to pay tax where their profits were generated. I see this principle as a very successful transfer and, of course, it helps a lot in the matter of transparency. At the same time, the wording or definition, definition and problems with intellectual property rights in tax havens have now been left out of this package, and I would like them to be included later. Finally, we cannot talk about European competitiveness as long as multinationals pay 30 times as much tax, or you could say that small and medium-sized enterprises pay 30 times as much tax as multinationals. I believe that the distinguished title of being a European taxpayer can only be given to those who pay at least as much tax as a small and medium-sized enterprise.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Mr. President, we certainly need a new package of tax measures, and even more necessary is its implementation and the willingness of Member States to comply with tax rules and leave no room for interpretation and adjustment in individual cases. This package has three key parts that are necessary if we are to make a significant breakthrough in preventing tax avoidance. First, coordination of activities between Member States. Second, tax transparency. And third, the elimination of double taxation. We don't want multinationals to create an additional tax burden on companies that pay taxes fairly by tax avoidance. In the end, I have a question for Commissioner Moscovici. Given that you have announced the introduction of the CCCTB, I would like to know what additional measures you are trying to ensure that this time you are successfully introduced and what obstacles do you encounter?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Commission, in the context of the corporate tax package, has placed particular emphasis on the automatic exchange of information between Member States. The aim of this decision is to combat tax evasion affecting many Member States of the Union as well as tax rulings. The protagonists, of course, in tax evasion and avoidance are multinational companies, thus eroding the national tax base.  Moreover, the practice of intra-group transactions used by multinationals adversely affects countries' budgets and affects their economy, while multinationals save billions of euros in taxes. In order to combat these practices, of course, mandatory exchange of information is not enough. All the Member States of the Union should take measures to ensure that multinational companies are taxed in the country where their profits are made and to stop resorting to tax havens, such as in the Netherlands or Luxembourg, where we also had the LuxLeaks scandal, dear Mr President of the Commission, that you are present.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, we can be critical, but, we must admit, this package is a step forward in the need for fiscal fairness. It is very important, however, how we apply it. Member States have a very important role and believe in the subsidiarity of states in the area of taxation, but they also believe in the need to fight tax injustice and the dominance of the internal market by multinationals, which simply crush SMEs, decapitalising them and diminishing their capacity for development, even though SMEs share in number and number of employees. Commissioner, you have presented the four pillars very well and I hope that they will also be implemented, because we must be careful that what we regulate in theory works. It would have been nice if the Commissioner would listen to me.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I suppose the Commission is aware of the anger generated by the fact that the Commission applies with an iron hand the budgetary rules which force cuts and that everything to do with the fight with tax evasion is so and so slow, with so many doubts.  And there are things that seem right to us about what you've proposed. The fact that you want to tax at least once the profits you want to leave the European Union is good for us.  But you, in this package, basically, do what you do is develop the BEPS framework of the G—20 very timidly. In addition, we know that this framework leaves some things out, like patent pits, that are essential.  It therefore seems to us, Commissioner, that we need more ambition. We need companies to explain, country by country, exactly where they generate their profits, to prevent them from moving profits back and forth; a consolidated minimum base; a minimum corporate tax rate.  And we know of the resistance of the Member States. It is therefore very important that the Commission and Parliament make an alliance in order to be able to bend that resistance of the Member States. But for this, Commissioner, we need much more ambition on your part.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the Commission communication on combating the planned tax avoidance of large multinational companies contains well-timed findings on the scale of the problem and grandiose announcements to tackle it in the future. In practice, however, nothing has been done to ensure that the projected tax is paid where the value is generated or there is consumption.  The Communication mentions a package of legislative proposals including a proposal for a directive to combat tax avoidance by autumn 2016. Bearing in mind that the transposition of the directive into national law will take another two or three years, we realise that all this is an unacceptable delay at a time when citizens' social rights are being flattened in the name of so-called fiscal consolidation.  If the Commission is serious about what it says, it must prove it by taking action now and not in the future.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to welcome you for this high-year debate, close to 50 speeches which have made it possible to address in depth a large number of points, and what I see, of course, in respect of the various sensitivities, is a consensus on the need to continue our joint action against tax fraud and evasion. , which is a major topic.  The package adopted by the college last Thursday, under the leadership of Jean-Claude Juncker, whom I welcome, provides us with additional tools to shape a fairer and more efficient tax system within the Union and internationally. We must continue to work together for taxation that is responsive to the realities and challenges of the 21st century, which also facilitates growth and jobs. There have been so many interventions that I cannot respond to each, but I just want to make three points: the first, for those who are concerned and whom I want to reassure, concerns the impact of this package on the competitiveness of European businesses. No, tax justice and transparency in tax matters do not stand in the way of economic efficiency. Today we are witnessing a real global movement against tax evasion and I want to tell you that the European Union is not alone in this fight against aggressive tax planning. More than 100 states and territories have already committed to implementing the OECD's recommendations quickly last October at the G20 summit in Antalya.  I am convinced that a coordinated approach to the implementation of these recommendations at European level will, on the contrary, guarantee our companies more legal certainty, less administrative burdens and, I would like to stress once again, fairer tax competition.  This package that is good for justice is therefore also good for investment. As many of you have said, and this is my second point, the ball is now in the Member States' court. For my part, I am confident in their good will, not out of naivety, but because I think that this is a very consensual subject with strong pressure from European and international public opinion. This goodwill was demonstrated by the rapid adoption in seven months of the Directive on the Automatic Exchange of Information on Tax Rulings. Nevertheless, as you know, and I cannot hide it from you, unanimity at 28 is always a huge challenge.  As far as I am concerned, you will be able to count on my full and determined commitment, particularly in the Ecofin Council, but I will surely need your support, I would even say your constant political pressure and your reformist momentum, so that the fine statements made by some national governments are followed up. So I'm counting on your active support to make rapid progress. Third thought: many interventions have focused on the publication of country-by-country information and many have called for publicity. I told you what my wish was, and that is not rhetoric. I told you what my personal position was, she's sincere. At the same time, let us be aware that we must respond with pragmatism. Yes to transparency up to advertising, provided it does not penalize investment and competitiveness. We must therefore, once again, be very realistic on the subject and that is what the Commission will do. From tomorrow, we must move towards an exchange between administrations. That is what the OECD is suggesting. We will have the opportunity to return to the debate later this year, but Parliament is of course understood and the positions that are expressed on all the benches will be heard as well. I want to end by referring to an interesting and important debate that Mr Lamberts humorously raised about how the French approach love. I do not want to be scabrous and go too far into this metaphor, but it is true that foreplay is often a necessary condition for a successful act and I would add that the French sometimes take action, since the fertility rate in France is among the highest in Europe, but I do not want to push this metaphor any further, because - as I said - there are risks. Besides, love and politics are not exactly the same thing. So in political matters, we have to move quickly, and I have spoken to you today about the common act. That's what we want to do together.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. – We agree with the fight against tax evasion and tax fraud, to achieve transparency, but this is not linked and has nothing to do with the ability of countries to freely define their tax policy. The setting of free tax rates by member countries is an element of the free economy, is the basis of healthy competition and helps countries develop their own economic policies. Ultimately, with these policies you will drive foreign companies out of the EU, destroy SMEs and lead countries with developed financial services to lose significant incomes as well as jobs.  It does not mean that any country that implements, for its own reasons, its own tax policy with competitive taxes, affects transparency issues and there is nothing reprehensible since everything is done transparently and publicly. On the contrary, the free definition of tax rates helps as a tool for the development of economic and social policy.''

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – The measures against tax avoidance proposed by Socialist Commissioner Pierre Moscovici are positive. It is commendable that a specific Directive should be proposed in this area to prevent the parent company from transferring its profits to tax havens. It is very important that the threshold for defining a low-tax jurisdiction, determined relatively and not absolutely, does not provide incentives for Member States to reduce the corporate tax rate.  However, it is not understood why country-by-country reports will be exchanged only between tax administrations, even if it is a breakthrough, while the public will still not know in a transparent and disaggregated way where profits are generated and where taxes are paid. In addition, the minimum threshold of EUR 750 million in annual turnover seems too high. Finally, we must not forget the need to approve the common consolidated basis for corporation tax, which would reduce the scope of so-called tax competition, as well as the establishment of a European Tax Agency to centralize information on opaque tax rulings and cross-border elusors and evasors, as well as maintain and update the European list of tax havens.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – I support the European Commission for finally adopting this Tax Avoidance Package by multinationals in the EU - and I call for surveillance and research of large companies and families with privileged access to power, which continue to benefit from tax agreements and other opaque schemes to dodge their tax responsibilities.  In particular, the European Commission must take an active role in investigating decisions that could involve illegal state aid, in cases such as that of Sonangol, which received tax benefits from the Portuguese of more than EUR 1 billion in 2014 alone! The Commission also has to require states to ensure fiscal fairness in State Budgets in order to mitigate cuts in essential public services and reduce the tax burden on the poor and the middle classes, ensuring that more income is collected from those who can pay the most - which is not the case in Portugal, where the richest families in the country , which should contribute 25% of state revenues under IRS only contribute 0.5% thanks to benefits and tax exemptions granted in total opacity.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. – The current situation is completely unacceptable. The tax system in many of the countries of the European Union is unfair. Billions are lost every year because of tax evasion. President Juncker has promised to develop a comprehensive anti-tax evasion agenda to ensure a fairer single market and promote job creation. The European Parliament's report was designed to change the terms of the game, to end the current unacceptable tax evasion of multinationals and, at the same time, to ensure a fairer tax system. The anti-tax evasion package is an important step forward. It has three pillars (ensuring effective taxation in the EU, increasing tax transparency, ensuring a level playing field) and I am pleased to see that the recommendations of the TAXE Commission have been taken into account. I hope that these measures will prevent aggressive tax planning, promote transparency and ensure fairer competition for all businesses. Whoever breaks the law must answer to justice.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – The measures against tax avoidance proposed by Socialist Commissioner Pierre Moscovici are positive. It is commendable that a specific Directive should be proposed in this area to prevent the parent company from transferring its profits to tax havens. It is very important that the threshold for defining a low-tax jurisdiction, determined relatively and not absolutely, does not provide incentives for Member States to reduce the corporate tax rate.  However, it is not understood why country-by-country reports will be exchanged only between tax administrations, even if it is a breakthrough, while the public will still not know in a transparent and disaggregated way where profits are generated and where taxes are paid. In addition, the minimum threshold of EUR 750 million in annual turnover seems too high. Finally, we must not forget the need to approve the common consolidated basis for corporation tax, which would reduce the scope of so-called tax competition, as well as the establishment of a European Tax Agency to centralize information on opaque tax rulings and cross-border elusors and evasors, as well as maintain and update the European list of tax havens.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – So long as it introduces better transparency in tax matters in the European Union, the Commission decision on the Corporate Tax package is welcome. However, where it serves as part of a wider programme to introduce harmonisation of taxation across Member States, the package must be critically scrutinised. Member States, especially in the Eurozone, are implementing uniform rules in financial and economic decision-making. This is working to the advantage of Members having better economic endowments. One cannot deny to those who have less endowments, especially smaller and peripheral countries, the remaining flexibility in tax policies. Current accounting systems to measure profits and expenses date from when manufacturing was the main sector of economies. As services and digital activities, accompanied with a globalised mode of production and marketing, become increasingly predominant, the task of determining profits and expenses is now much more complex. In the circumstances the easiest way by which to claim to be curbing tax evasion by MNCs is by imposing tax harmonisation, using existing accounting methods. This is unfair. Indeed, the characteristic of any corporate tax package should be flexibility, equally applicable to all, not only to the bigger economies, as has happened with SGP rules.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – I welcome the whole package presented by the European Commission. I am pleased with the fact that the proposal is based on the recommendations of the OECD, which were supported by the leaders of the most economically powerful countries at the G20 summit last November.  I support the rule that tax should be paid where profits are made, which should be respected by all Member States in their tax policy. Greater transparency in business is a key factor in combating aggressive tax planning used by large companies.  We lose €170 billion a year as a result of tax evasion. Can you imagine how much each country could do with a hundred of that money? I wish the Commission as much success as possible in my work in combating tax evasion, and I hope for a good response from the Member States. We all know the competition is healthy. But not that competition that avoids the rules.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which It is an extraordinary pleasure for me to welcome our long-standing former colleague Toomas Ilves to the European Parliament. Mr Ilves has returned to the place where he worked for many years as a Member of the European Parliament. But today, for the second time, he is with us in his capacity as President of Estonia. Mr Ilves, Mr President- I would like to thank mr Ilves for his excellent work. It is an extraordinary pleasure for us to welcome you here. I will give you the floor immediately. I call the President of Estonia.

name: Toomas Hendrik ILVES
text: President of the Republic of Estonia. – Ladies and gentlemen, I begin by apologising for my voice, but I brought something with me from Estonia. Ten years ago I left these chambers to take a new post in my country. There was no euro or migration crisis, no idea that European borders could be changed by force, no talk that the European project might fail. Also, there were no smart phones, no revelations of internet surveillance. There was no Uber, or as we call it, ‘Über’. Ladies and gentlemen, for nearly three quarters of a century we have repeated the mantra of Europe as a project for peace. For the first three quarters of a century, Europe – half of Europe to be precise – thrived and grew, with our security in large part outsourced, even under the shadow of an aggressive, totalitarian Soviet Union. For the past quarter century, in the absence of any external threats, we have pursued the reintegration of Europe – also to bring back to the fold those nations forced against their will to live under totalitarian rule. Today, however, we are confronted with new existential, external – and, as we were reminded in Paris last November, internal – threats. We are at a loss, we are fearful, and Europe for so many is no longer the answer. I hear ringing in my ears William Butler Yeats: ʻTurning and turning in the widening gyre/ The falcon cannot hear the falconer; /Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold;/ Mere anarchy is loosed upon the worldʼ. So let us face this new reality. Europe is amidst a transformational crisis. Do we pull together or do we let others deal with it? A transformational crisis where we shall put to the test all that Europe has achieved, step by step, since Monnet and Schuman. We are approaching a tipping point where either we become stronger or we let fissiparous forces prevail. It is crucial to admit that in this transformational crisis much was foreseeable. We knew there were serious problems but we put off dealing with the internal European crisis of the euro until it was almost unmanageable. We thought, at least until recently, that was the greatest threat to the European project. We were wrong. We knew too, and for a long time, that huge income and democracy differentials between Europe and its immediate neighbourhood to the south and east were a time-bomb, ticking away, stayed more by the restraining influence of authoritarian regimes to the south, across the Mediterranean and the Middle East. Today massive migration in the form of flight from the horrific slaughter of civil war and the systematic brutality of Daesh, mixed with economic migration from poverty and lack of economic opportunity, threatens Europe like never before. Schengen is under threat. Some countries refuse to take refugees, others are overwhelmed by the numbers flooding into their countries. Solidarity is crumbling. Some refuse to help, others justly say that solidarity is a two-way street. Structural and cohesion funds are also expensive manifestations of solidarity. Ladies and gentlemen, we are aghast when we hear of the numbers. A million refugees and migrants to Europe this year, predictions of another two million in the next two. Yes, these are truly large numbers. Yes, they will strain social cohesion and our budgets. And yet we have seen far worse and we have prevailed. In the Europe of 1946, Germany alone had 12 million internal refugees and another 12 million displaced persons of 20 different nationalities. To resolve this, in three years UNRRA, the UN Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, spent, in today’s money, some EUR 50 billion. I mention this number, illustratively, to give us all a sense of perspective to understand what a daunting task our grandparents faced when Europe had no institutions, sometimes not even sovereign governments. And all of this before the Marshall Plan even started. So, ladies and gentlemen, let us now gather our wits and strengths, leave behind the indecision, finger-pointing and ducking of responsibility. We will handle this migration crisis if we show the resolve of our forebears. We must act in solidarity with those Member States that bear the brunt of the crisis, and we must accept a functional form of burden-sharing. (Applause) We also must take full control over the EU’s external border; we cannot be borderless both inside and outside the Union. (Applause) We must also have a functioning common asylum policy, especially when it comes to rejecting spurious claims and returning illegal immigrants. Is this so difficult when we look back to what Europe faced in the years after the Second World War? Ladies and gentlemen, after the horrors of the Paris attacks, I fear the refugee crisis will only further fuel the rise of populist and extremist politics. We will see the argument – indeed we already have – that we cannot accept refugees because they are terrorists, forgetting conveniently that the refugees streaming into Europe today have fled the same regime, the same brutality and murder witnessed in Paris, but writ large. Political speech today sometimes adopts language that a few years ago was found only in anonymous on-line fora. Democratic, centrist leaders advocating calm and responsible policies are increasingly under pressure, if not attack. Extremist parties and politicians exploit the current refugee crisis like they exploited the economic crisis; they exploit the dissatisfaction of voters with the often anodyne and milquetoast resolve of European leaders. Citizens expect decisive responses to crises. When traditional parties do not provide them, they look toward those whose rhetoric sounds decisive yet carries within it the ‘decisiveness’, so-called, of reaction: of simple, often un-European solutions the Union was created to rid Europe of forever. I say this all, inter alia, as the son of refugees, who fled terror in their homeland in Estonia in World War II, which is why I have this American accent. My parents did not always feel welcome when they reached Sweden, but they were given a chance. My hope is that a few decades from now there will be a president of a democratic Syria speaking Arabic with a German accent. (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen, while we should have foreseen the euro crisis and the migration crisis, one crisis we did not foresee – indeed to this day it beggars belief – was the invasion and Anschluss of Crimea, followed by the invasion of the Donbas. I shall not dwell on this today, but I must state that in doing what it did two years ago this month, Russia violated every foundational  European security treaty, beginning with the UN Charter… (Applause) … the 1975 Helsinki Final Act, and the 1990 Charter of Paris. And it violated as well the 1994 Budapest Memorandum that granted Ukrainians territorial integrity in return for eliminating what was then the world’s third largest nuclear weapons arsenal. In other words, we in Europe can no longer assume that the treaties that have underpinned European – I underline European – security since World War II still hold. The EU has been swift and united in its response to Russian aggression, and this has had a deterring effect. The sanctions have proved to be effective. But EU relations with Russia will remain strained for some time. Strategic patience is the keyword. Some call for dialogue, yes, but dialogue itself is not a policy, at least not a policy to counter aggression. That much we should have learned from Munich in 1938. (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen, I have spoken of European crises: some we should have foreseen, others we could not. I would turn now and for the rest of my talk, look at our future and a long-term crisis we can avoid, if we take it seriously before we discover ourselves in its midst: Europe’s decreasing competitiveness and productivity in a rapidly-changing, interconnected digital world. Together with Kaushik Basu, the Chief Economist of the World Bank, I have just finished co-chairing the preparation of the Bank’s first longer study of the economic potential of information technology and for improving society and governance. The report also outlines the pitfalls of falling behind. In general, Europe does well in this long, extensively-researched study, a year and a half in the making. But make no mistake, Europe stands to become a second-tier player, with not only the US but also India and China taking leading positions, if we do not keep up. The digital revolution could be a blessing for the Single Market: today, we can see nascent pan-European markets in sectors like health care, banking and transport that only a few years ago seemed inherently local. Yet, sector-by-sector, our legislation remains fractured between Member States and unprepared for the digital age. We are losing out to the absence of a single market and losing our best and brightest to where the opportunities for them are greater. I saw this with my own eyes when a 23-year-old who had gotten a little start-up money and I invited him to visit me, said: ‘I am sorry, Mr President, I am moving to the United States’. I said: ‘Why?’ He said: ‘That’s where the opportunities are’. Six months later he had USD 4.6 million invested in his company and three years later he sold it for USD 100 million. He could have stayed in Estonia if we had had a single market and the financing. (Applause) And I would argue that story is repeated over and over again in every single Member State of the Union. Sixty years ago, when the Treaty of Rome laid the basis for what we now call the four freedoms of the movement of people, goods, capital and services, there was no digital anything. Computing was in its infancy. Today we live in a completely different world. Unless we recognise how profound a change has occurred, especially in the last 10 to15 years, Europe will fall behind and so too will our citizens. Meeting the challenge of the digital revolution requires the ingenuity of Europe’s entrepreneurs, its businesses, civil society and all levels of government. Market forces and business models will be the primary drivers of change and our response, but legislation, all European legislation, must support them. To reflect the magnitude of this change, I propose we add to the four fundamental freedoms a fifth freedom: free movement of data. This fifth freedom could be folded into the existing four freedoms, but today it is distinct enough and all-encompassing enough that I think it should be given a separate status. Data is neither a person, a physical good, capital nor a service, but to help all those move data, data must also be able to cross borders. The Commission’s proposal for a Digital Single Market will shore up the foundations of the free movement of data, but it must become an abiding value of the internal market, not simply a target to be met by a certain date.   But from the citizen’s point of view, what would that fifth freedom mean? For one thing, the free movement of data would mean that we can access services we have paid for throughout the EU. It would mean that online commerce would not be restricted by the country of our bank account, and that national boundaries would no longer determine – arbitrarily in the digital world – which European citizens can purchase digital goods and services and who cannot. Today, however, it is easier to ship a bottle of olive oil from Sicily to sell north of the Arctic Circle than to send an iTunes song across the border. (Applause) And personally,  as I am blowing my nose, I can tell you that in my country we have digital prescriptions, which means that I can go to any pharmacy without a prescription written by my doctor and take it out. But I cannot do that as soon as I leave my country, whereas I see no reason why I could not go to a pharmacy in Strasbourg and get, when I desperately need it, a prescription that my doctor has written out for me in Estonia. It is all possible: technologically there is no problem; it is in our laws. (Applause) Yet the free movement of data is not just about commerce. Like every EU fundamental freedom, the free movement of data comes with rights and responsibilities, chief among these the right to and responsibility for data protection. Indeed, ownership of one’s own data and the freedom to decide over its use are essential preconditions for unlocking the value of these data. The new Data Protection Regulation – and I congratulate you on concluding negotiations – recognises this principle in title and substance. It will give individuals real ownership of their data – the right to control its use and pass it on to third parties. This should create new markets and, applied to the public sector, reduce the burdens of paperwork and reporting that now cost European citizens and businesses frustration, time and money. It should also dramatically increase transparency. We must strive to create a data economy where the free movement of data also works for non-personal data. There is tremendous value hidden in the big data generated by our cars, our homes, our refrigerators, increasingly connected devices and industry: what in Germany is already called today Industrie 4.0.   Europe must invest in the underlying technologies that create confidence in the security of data flows, especially encryption and block-chain technology, which really would give us genuine security, and we must promote their use. Finally, just as the free movement of goods needs ports and roads, we do need modern digital infrastructure to make the fifth freedom possible. 5G and fibre connections need to be truly ubiquitous in Europe. This applies especially to the last mile connection, to our homes and businesses. Our rural communities that have benefited so immensely from the common agricultural policy require in this new world the same access to the internet as everyone else, those in the cities. Inclusiveness is vital. It is vital that the benefits of this digital dividend are shared by all. Estonia’s experience at least makes me optimistic. Since 2005, we have allowed online voting in nine national, regional and European elections. You might think that this would benefit the young urban elite, the ones who are accustomed to using modern technology, yet extensive sociological research has shown over and over that there is no demographic or urban-rural divide. The pensioner living in a small village is just as likely to vote online, Skype with her family and stay in touch with her doctor remotely as are her grandchildren. I mention Skype, by the way, because it was invented in Estonia, but like so many other good things it now resides in Renton, Washington, in the United States. At the same time, Ladies and Gentlemen, we must ask: where is the digital revolution taking us? What is the future of work in a digital era? What will happen to the taxi driver’s and the factory worker’s job? And tomorrow, with developing technologies, to the doctor and to the accountant?   Each previous industrial revolution has increased employment, replacing old jobs with new ones that are higher-skilled, better paying and more challenging. But we do not know yet if history will repeat. We are still at the beginning of the digital revolution, and I have the humility to admit that there are no certain answers. But I do know this: the digital revolution, like the crises of the Eurozone, Crimea and refugees, call upon us to put forward the best in us at a time when politics play to the basest of our instincts.  Yet let us not suppose that these challenges will be insurmountable. This is a time to step humbly in the courageous steps of our predecessors, in 1957, in 1989, in 1991, and in 2004. They faced uncertainty, and they stepped forward. If we cede to the populists who say that Europe cannot be trusted with its citizens’ interests, Ladies and Gentlemen, then no crisis, foreseeable or not, will find an adequate solution. Be they migration, the euro or even military aggression, not to mention the challenge of technological change, solutions that revert to the nation state will bring us back to a pre-World War II era. An era where short-termism, beggaring-thy-neighbour, leads inevitably to a tit-for-tat and a loss for all. Back to an era where, once again, might makes right. Where that leads we have seen too many times in Europe’s history. Let us hold no illusions of what faces us if we hesitate or stumble, if – to quote Yeats again from the same poem, ʻthe best lack all conviction, while the worst/ Are full of passionate intensityʼ. The choice is ours. (Sustained applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for your applause. Thank you, Mr Ilves. Mr President, thank you very much for your inspiring speech. I do not think I need to add anything to that. Both in terms of applause and protest, I believe that your speech was a very landmark, for which we would like to express our thanks. Thank you very much!

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Mr President, it is actually a legal point that happened to me in my country, that the House will want to hear. I was exonerated of any allegations that were charged against me and I would just like to explain that and to thank my colleagues for supporting me. Across this House I have had tremendous support from different individual nations and also colleagues: ‘There but for the grace of God go I’, is what most of you said to me. I would like to thank certain colleagues: Stuart Agnew, who has been an absolute rock and who never doubted me. I would like to thank Paul Nuttall and Nigel Farage for keeping in touch. Also my ENF colleagues. You know what, you people believed in me. I cannot say thank you to you all, but there are two people I would like to single out:  Edouard Ferrand, an outstanding politician, and Marine Le Pen, magnificent Marine. Thank you friends, it has been really supportive. (Applause from the ENF Group)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Your thanks are not on the record, please do not abuse the Bureau's tolerance and do not violate the Rules of Procedure. You could have sent him flowers, but not right now.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Voting time is up.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report, because it creates legislation. UKIP is against the EU having any power to legislate so as to make the laws of the United Kingdom. UKIP opposes the operation of the Schengen Agreement which is causing so much long-term harm to the peoples of the Member States. This is permitting and causing the current crisis in respect of largely economic migrants from Africa and the Middle East and thereby exacerbating the problems of migration from the EU into the United Kingdom.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU attaches great value to the simplification and clear formulation of European law, so that it becomes increasingly comprehensible and accessible to all citizens. That is why it is expected that, if a European act is amended on several occasions, it must be codified in order to ensure its immediate understanding and clarity. Codification consists of merely meeting the various amendments made in this field, without therefore making any substantial changes. This includes the proposal for a regulation establishing a Union code on the crossing of borders by persons. I voted in favour because I believe it is essential to ensure clarity and coherence of European law, ensuring not only the correct application of European law but also greater clarity for citizens.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report, because it creates legislation. UKIP is against the EU having any power to legislate so as to make the laws of the United Kingdom. UKIP opposes the operation of the Schengen Agreement which is causing so much long-term harm to the peoples of the Member States. This is permitting and causing the current crisis in respect of largely economic migrants from Africa and the Middle East and thereby exacerbating the problems of migration from the EU into the United Kingdom.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report is related to Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Community Code of Rules for the Crossing of Persons across borders. The report is the codification of the different versions and amendments introduced to this Regulation since 15 March 2006. Since it is a coding report which preserves in its entirety the content of the acts being codified – given the technical nature of the coding – I voted in favour.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this proposed regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on an EU code on the regime for people crossing borders (Schengen border code). Indeed, this text aims to codify the corpus of rules gathered around the Schengen status quo. However, such codification has the ambition to ensure the posterity of the Schengen rules.  Deeply opposed to the maintenance of the Schengen area, which is the game of mass immigration and terrorism, I could not support such a text.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this text. By way of background information, codification is a bringing together of all the legal text when a Regulation or Directive (in this case Regulation (EC) No 562/2006) has been amended by other legal acts for 10 or more times. This is to clarify the text and make it easier to read. A codification exercise can only make formal modifications; no substantive changes or deletions may be made. The EP always has to check whether a codification only makes formal changes to the legal text. Moreover, codification serves to simplify complicated legal texts and, as a result, prevents unnecessary legal challenges in the future.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it is a simple codification of existing texts, without any substantive amendment.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The report in question is intended to codify the body of rules gathered around the Schengen status quo. Whereas historically, from the Roman emperor Justinian to the French emperor Napoleon, any codification undertaking was part of a desire to ensure the posterity of rules and to enshrine great legal principles, it is rather a question of bringing our stone to a building that we wish to deconstruct because of its obvious weaknesses. The Schengen area has in fact greatly worsened the migration crisis that we are currently experiencing. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This was a legislative proposal to consolidate the rules on Schengen. This provides for the absence of border control of persons crossing the internal borders between Member States of the European Union. It lays down the rules governing border control and establishes the list of persons to which the absence of internal border control applies. I voted against this proposal because I do not believe in such harmonisation.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Europe has been paralysed with regard to the migrant crisis. While we keep discussing possible solutions to the grave problem we face, it hardly ever comes to common action. However, even when we do decide on joint measures, we do not follow through on them. The Dublin Agreement and the relocation system have failed utterly, as the Member States have not committed to apply them.  We must either effectively enforce the current measures, or introduce new ones. Either way, it is not a problem that can be solved by any Member State alone. It is a dilemma that must be dealt with by the European Union as a whole. It cannot be fixed by closing national borders, but only by guarding our common ones; those defined by Schengen. What we need to do is form a common border guard and coast guard and put a collective reception and relocation system in place. Furthermore, we must prompt Turkey to crack down on the criminals smuggling refugees to Europe under harsh circumstances and we must speak with African governments about returning economic migrants. However, what is most important is that Member States keep to it.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which is intended solely to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to codify Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 March 2006 establishing a Community code of rules governing the crossing of persons' borders (Schengen Borders Code). The new Regulation replaces the acts it includes. This proposal preserves the content of the codified acts in their entirety and, accordingly, merely merges them by making the formal amendments necessary for the codification. Since there is no substantive change in the schengen rules so far and from a Hungarian point of view we have a strong interest in the interoperability of internal borders (commuter workers, closure of internal Hungarian borders to Slovakia and Slovenia) and the possibility of temporarily reintroducing internal border controls is set out in the Regulation, so I supported the adoption of a re-codified Schengen regulation.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report, because it creates legislation. UKIP is against the EU having any power to legislate so as to make the laws of the United Kingdom. UKIP opposes the operation of the Schengen Agreement which is causing so much long-term harm to the peoples of the Member States. This is permitting and causing the current crisis in respect of largely economic migrants from Africa and the Middle East and thereby exacerbating the problems of migration from the EU into the United Kingdom.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This new codification aims to save the Schengen area, so I logically voted against it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The aim here is to codify - for clarity - the 2006 regulation establishing the "Schengen Border Code" which has been the subject of numerous changes since its adoption. Even if it is a text of major importance (the regime of crossing external borders) the proposed new regulation would replace the various acts incorporated in it while fully preserving the substance. I approved this codification.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time of greatest crisis in the Union, with Member States divided on the issue of managing migratory flows and controls at their borders, it seems increasingly necessary to facilitate direct access for citizens to European legislation on border crossings. The Hautala report on the proposal for a regulation establishing a Union code on the system of crossing borders is a further step in this direction. The resolution, which is of an eminently technical nature, confirms the validity of the codification of existing texts, promoting the establishment of a system that will make access to the legislation produced by the Union simpler and clearer. In view of the absence of any changes to existing legislation and in agreement with the intention of the proposal, I have therefore decided to support this report.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this change in the Borders Code, in so far as it does not represent a change in the political content of the existing Code and is merely a simplification and reduction of duplications in overlapping codifications.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on the adoption of the Regulation establishing a Union Code of Rules for the crossing of persons across borders. The advisory group, following the meetings of 9 and 26 February and 15 April 2015, found certain amendments referred to in points 1 to 6. This has made it possible to determine by common agreement that the proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantial modification of them.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. By launching Schengen cooperation, Member States have agreed to abolish internal border controls in the Schengen area, based on confidence that Member States are securing their external borders and implementing the necessary measures in this regard.  This report aims to codify the rules of the Schengen area. Europe makes us vulnerable and, it is clear, that the Schengen area is a giant sieve today. However, I am against the Schengen area that this codification is trying to save. We need to regain control of our national borders to stop the wave of migration and apply a strict migration policy in the image of Australia.  Finally, we must engage in a genuine policy of co-development with the countries of origin of the "migrants" and condition the aid granted to these countries according to agreements in this area.  I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Schengen Agreements are now outdated and have proved to be completely unsuitable for dealing with the current situation in Europe, which is facing an unprecedented migration crisis. These agreements need to be completely revised. That is why I voted against this report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without any substantial amendment to the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Union Code of Rules for the crossing of persons across borders.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the Commission's technical proposal to codify the legislation constituting the Schengen Borders Code as soon as possible. The aim of this proposal is only to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In the light of the ongoing migrant and refugee crisis, I consider the need to protect the European Union's external borders and the enforceability of the rules on it to be of paramount importance. The current codified text is forward-looking in this area and I therefore voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. Although it sounds like a very important topic around the Schengen regime, which could be discussed quite a lot in the current migrant situation, the above proposal for a regulation is merely a codification of the text without any substantial substantive changes. Therefore, there were also no complications in supporting technical corrections in the text prepared by the consultative groups of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. For the reasons set out above, I supported the proposed regulation.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This proposed regulation proposes to establish an EU code on people crossing borders (Schengen Border Code). I have been opposed to Schengen for years and, therefore, I voted against the text.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the changes made to the border crossing regime by people respect the spirit of the Schengen Agreement and therefore move in the direction of greater integration.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Schengen Convention represents a major milestone in the process of European integration, enabling national border management and the free movement of persons within the European Union to be overcome. A Europe without internal borders also brings considerable economic benefits, which shows how tangible, popular and effective the creation of the Schengen area is, as well as the importance it has in our societies. The codification of Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 March 2006 establishing a Community code on the border crossing regime has nothing to do with the current proposals for reform or suspensions of Schengen. It is a technical procedure (governed by an interinstitutional agreement providing for accelerated approval) on which the Legal Service of the Commission, Parliament and the Council gave a favourable opinion and on which the JURI Committee then voted by a very large majority. The Committee on European Free Trade did not wish to give its opinion, precisely because it shows that the new text does not in any way affect the political content of the Schengen Agreement.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report calls for the codification of the body of rules relating to the regime of border crossings by persons. This codification undertaking is part of the European institutions' desire to ensure the posterity of the rules that govern the functioning of the Schengen area.  As an opponent of the European Soviet Union, it is our duty to vote against this text, which consists of engraving in stone the main principles of the Schengen area, unable to protect the Member States from the current migration flood and the potential arrival of jihadists. The increase in attacks and the attempted attacks, particularly in France, demonstrate the extent to which the European Union has not taken the measure of the risks that the peoples of Europe currently face. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of simplifying and clarity of European Union legislation aims to increase the degree of coherence and easy access for European citizens, while providing the possibility to make use of certain legislative procedures.  I welcome the recommendations of the Consultative Working Party on Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on the Union Code on the Regime for Crossing Borders by Persons (Schengen Borders Code). In the context of the migrant crisis and the crossing of borders by many refugees, well-structured documents are needed to provide an appropriate legal framework, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 A simple codification procedure without any substantial changes to the approval of the Schengen Agreement Code. However, I am openly opposed to the same and I prefer to vote against the codification work, which is purely 'political'.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the first reading position of the proposal because, according to the conclusions of the Advisory Working Group, this proposal is a simple codification of the existing texts and does not make any significant changes to the text. The European Union is a global pioneer in ensuring the free movement of people within the internal market in a borderless area, in accordance with Article 26(2) TFEU. In order to ensure this area without internal borders, the EU has committed to the adoption of measures, such as the common external border crossing policy. It must also reflect the Schengen acquis. It should be pointed out that this external border control is not only a matter for the Member State concerned, but for the whole Of Romania. It should be mentioned the only situation in which a Member State may reintroduce control at its internal borders for a maximum period of ten days, i.e. in the event of a serious threat to public policy or internal security. I stress that migration and the crossing of external borders by a large number of third-country nationals should not in themselves be considered a threat and that any extension of that period should be monitored at Union level.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report, because it creates legislation. UKIP is against the EU having any power to legislate so as to make the laws of the United Kingdom. UKIP opposes the operation of the Schengen Agreement which is causing so much long-term harm to the peoples of the Member States. This is permitting and causing the current crisis in respect of largely economic migrants from Africa and the Middle East and thereby exacerbating the problems of migration from the EU into the United Kingdom.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report expresses the European Parliament's position on the proposal for a regulation establishing a Union code on the arrangements for the crossing of borders by persons (so-called Schengen Borders Code). This codification work is necessary because of the numerous amendments made to Regulation (EC) No 562/2006. I voted in favour of the position of the legislative text at first reading because the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission have noted that the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts without making any substantial changes.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that the establishment of rules for the crossing of persons across borders cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States, but can be better achieved at European Union level.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Union Code on the status of persons crossing borders (Schengen Borders Code) is a particularly important issue for the time being, as we are witnessing an unprecedented crisis testing Europe's resistance. I think it is a good thing that any effort contributes to the modernisation and the correction of regulations for the benefit of the citizens. That is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Union code on the arrangements for the crossing of borders by persons, as I am convinced that border control is in the interests not only of the Member State at whose external borders it is carried out, but of all Member States that have abolished internal border control. Border control will contribute to the fight against illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, as well as to the prevention of any threat to internal security, public order, public health and the international relations of the Member States, without the rights of free movement enjoyed by citizens of the Union.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a regulation merely codifies existing rules, and I voted in favour. However, I believe that we must raise our voice to what is happening with regard to the Schengen Agreement: the Dublin Regulation is clearly inadequate to deal with the situation we are experiencing, and in Europe at the moment we need statesmen who know how to look beyond contingency and draw up a framework for the future, so that we have new rules that are able to resist any eventuality. In this Parliament we are working for an entity that the Member States seem to be prepared to sacrifice for their electoral needs: we are not here to plug a hole, but to write rules that our citizens are asking of us and that will simplify our lives and those who will face similar problems in the coming decades.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report, because it creates legislation. UKIP is against the EU having any power to legislate so as to make the laws of the United Kingdom. UKIP opposes the operation of the Schengen Agreement which is causing so much long-term harm to the peoples of the Member States. This is permitting and causing the current crisis in respect of largely economic migrants from Africa and the Middle East and thereby exacerbating the problems of migration from the EU into the United Kingdom.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation, commonly referred to as the "Schengen Borders Code", was adopted in 2006 and consolidates and develops the legislative policy component of integrated border management of the European Union. Over the years it has undergone six changes. Among the most common is the establishment of common rules on the temporary reintroduction of internal border control in exceptional circumstances under the so-called "Schengen Governance Package". The amendments that are being made, which I support, only consolidate the text which resulted from the amendments to the original regulation, so as to allow its better application and interpretation.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report, because it creates legislation. UKIP is against the EU having any power to legislate so as to make the laws of the United Kingdom. UKIP opposes the operation of the Schengen Agreement which is causing so much long-term harm to the peoples of the Member States. This is permitting and causing the current crisis in respect of largely economic migrants from Africa and the Middle East and thereby exacerbating the problems of migration from the EU into the United Kingdom.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the motion for a resolution because it is a simple procedure for codifying the existing text establishing a Union code on the arrangements for people crossing borders (Schengen Borders Code), without making any substantial changes.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The Schengen Borders Code allows Member States to give effect to the freedom of movement principle which is of fundamental value to European citizens. The report presents a codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.  I have voted in favour as codification provides better access to legislation for the citizen.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report is related to Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Community Code of Rules for the Crossing of Persons across borders. The report is the codification of the different versions and amendments introduced to this Regulation since 15 March 2006. Since it is a coding report which preserves in its entirety the content of the acts being codified – given the technical nature of the coding – I voted in favour.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The new provisions of the Regulation appear to be the next step in implementing the idea of establishing a common border guard to protect the EU's borders in order to stop m.in. wave of illegal immigration into Community countries. The new formation is expected to replace the current Frontex agency based in Warsaw in the long term. In view of frontex's experience so far and further unconvincing proposals for action in the area, I abstained.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is a straightforward codification procedure of existing texts. There are no substantial changes to the text in question and therefore I voted in favour of the adoption of this position at first reading.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully agree with the idea that, at the Schengen borders, control must be carried out in a professional and respectful manner and proportionate to the objectives pursued, so that human dignity is fully respected.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to consolidate the legal regime of the EU Code on the regime of border crossings by persons (Schengen border code - EC Regulation 562/2006) without changing its substance. This is the sixth time that Parliament has proposed an amendment to the text since the adoption of this regulation in 2006. Considering that this technical report does not raise a fundamental problem and that we need to strengthen our legislative arsenal in this area in light of the current crises, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of codifying the regulation establishing a Community code on the regime of border crossing by people, the Schengen border code. While preserving its substance, it is indeed important to work for greater clarity of European legislation.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report to codify the regulation establishing a Community code on the regime of border crossing by persons (Schengen border code).  In view of the many amendments to this Code, I believe it is justified, in the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, to proceed with this codification. The opinion of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission confirms that the proposal is indeed limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without any change in substance.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report aims to codify all the rules relating to the Schengen area, a construction which is questionable in many respects. The very principle of codification is aimed at perpetuating a legal framework by compiling positive rules of law. Being coherent and not wishing to strengthen this space, the dramatic consequences of which are seen every day, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the codified text of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union Code on the rules governing the movement of persons across borders. The new regulation will replace the various acts incorporated therein. It shall fully preserve the content of the codified acts and shall be limited to merging them, making only formal amendments necessary for the codification itself. I abstained as this is a codification of legislation, but overall I believe that some of the texts violate the sovereignty of the Member States and bring the EU closer to a centralised federal state.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote against the report as it only attempts to codify the existing legislation and not to amend it. In view of the high turnout of illegal immigrants, it is necessary to amend the legislative texts relating to the cross-border movement of persons.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. The purpose of this proposal is the codification of Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 March 2006 establishing a Community Code of Rules for the Crossing of Persons across borders (Schengen Borders Code), with a view to providing greater clarity and accessibility to EU law. The conclusions of the Legal Services of the three institutions confirm that the codifications are correct and that, therefore, this coding proposal will give greater clarity and effectiveness to the provisions contained.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Having taken into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working method for the official codification of legislative texts, the Advisory Group composed of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission held meetings to examine the proposal resulting from this report. The analysis thus allowed the Advisory Group to conclude, by common agreement, that the proposal under consideration is effectively based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive changes. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I do not want such rules to be sustainable.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 When discussing amendments to the Community Code on the regime for the passage of persons at borders (Schengen Borders Code) in 2013, we said: "It is intended with this report to introduce amendments to the 2006 Regulation, taking into account legal developments and practical experience, and also due to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. The changes are mainly in clarifying the definition of the conditions for entry for third-country nationals and in the duration of the validity of some travel documents. They also introduce amendments to the extension of exemption from stamping travel documents for international lye and train crew crews, as is already the case with airline crew members. Measures to train border guards are included in order to detect situations of unaccompanied minors and victims of trafficking. We do not follow up on amendments aimed at increasing harmonisation of immigration and border policies, which oblige Member States to report on bilateral agreements they establish under the Schengen Borders Code. Nor the obligation for Member States to be required to report when "legal" citizens of third countries enter another Member State."
