Although it is a codification, which is an eminently technical procedure, we voted against it, taking into account our bottom line on this matter.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not support the report as there are no substantial changes to the EU code. Schengen needs to be completely reviewed.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report as it attempts only to codify the legislation in force and not to amend it. In view of the high turnout of illegal immigrants, it is necessary to amend the legislative texts relating to the cross-border movement of persons.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal in question contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the amendment of the EU code on the regime of border crossing by people. This reform of the Schengen border code should allow for mandatory and systematic checks at the EU's external borders on all persons entering the Schengen area, including EU nationals. It is important, however, that this reform is accompanied by better information sharing between Member States and real-time feeding of European databases.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In the opinion of the Advisory Working Party composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a simple consolidated text without any substantive amendment, and I therefore accept its position at first reading, agreeing with the Commission's proposal, as amended by the recommendations of the Advisory Working Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. Furthermore, in line with the rapporteur, I instruct its President to forward Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the national parliaments.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour, considering that the proposal in question is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without any substantial modification of them. The EU must continue to work for greater coordination and legislative unity in this important area and ensure border control to ensure the proper functioning of Schengen.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I abstained today in the vote on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a Community code for the crossing of borders by persons (Schengen Border Code), because I support the approach of the document in principle, but I see in its details difficulties in its practical implementation, which unfortunately could not be rectified in the course of the negotiations.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. In view of the current refugee situation, it is important that we effectively protect Europe's external borders. This is where a solution is needed at Union level, and that is why I support today's proposal.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ This codification report contains no new provisions, rather it is just an update of the Union code, and represents a simple, effective action by the European Parliament allowing the language in this legislation to be standardised.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this change in the Borders Code, in so far as it does not represent a change in the political content of the existing Code and is merely a simplification and reduction of duplications in overlapping codifications.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is a straightforward codification procedure of existing texts. There are no substantial changes to the text in question and therefore I voted in favour of the adoption of this position at first reading.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour on the technical Commission proposal to codify legislation of the Schengen Borders Code as soon as possible. Since Europe has been struggling in regard to the migrant crisis, it is not a problem that can be solved by any Member State alone. That must be dealt with by the European Union as a whole. It cannot be fixed by closing national borders, but only by guarding our common ones – those defined by Schengen.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This report relates to Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Community code on rules on the cross-border movement of persons. The report is a simple codification of the various versions and amendments to the Regulation from 15 March 2006 onwards. The codification fully preserves the content of the legal acts codified and simply brings together in one text all the amendments adopted since the last codification. For these reasons, we voted in favour of the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the technical codification proposed by the Commission which will not impact on the substance of the Schengen Border Code, only simplify and clarify the text, making it clearer and more accessible to citizens.  On 20 January 2015 the Commission adopted a proposal for the technical codification of the Schengen Border Code (i.e. the rules governing movement of persons across Schengen borders). The Schengen Borders Code regulation is intended to improve the legislative part of the integrated border management European Union policy by setting out the rules on the border control of persons crossing EU external borders and on the temporary reintroduction of border control at internal borders. This regulation applies to any person crossing the external borders of all EU countries, except those of the United Kingdom and Ireland, and the internal borders of the Schengen area (a border-free area comprising 22 EU countries, along with Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland). Ireland is not a member of Schengen and so we do not fall under the remit of the Schengen Border Code.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The European Commission has submitted a codification proposal for the Schengen Borders Code to the European Parliament. No material-content changes may be made in a codification. The specific process is based, inter alia, on the interinstitutional agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working procedure for the official codification of legal texts. The aim is to combine existing EU legislation in the spirit of simplification. In the present case, this concerns the Community Code on the crossing of borders by persons, or Schengen Borders Code for short. The new regulation replaces the various acts which are the subject of codification.  As I am in favour of simplifying EU law and reducing red tape in the EU institutions, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, the Schengen area is one of the most tangible achievements of the European project. We see that restrictions on its functioning lead to delays in transport, huge losses for the European economy. They have negative consequences for the overall state of the European single market, of monetary union, of the value of the euro.  Europe must therefore make every effort to protect it, especially by strengthening the Union's external borders. In doing so, it is highly unfair that countries such as Bulgaria and Romania, tasked with protecting 3 349 km of the Union's external borders, should be kept outside Schengen, despite the accepted criteria met.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report in accordance with the recommendations of the Advisory Working Group on Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on the Union Code on rules governing the movement of persons across borders (Schengen Borders Code), as the proposal in question is limited to codification without substantive change.  In one very important area, such as the movement of persons, it is essential that EU law is clearer and more accessible and that it is certain. The European Union must guarantee a simpler and more efficient finding and understanding of its legal acts, and codification is heading in this direction. In this context, I also support an interinstitutional agreement allowing for an accelerated process for the swift adoption of codified acts.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The report in question is intended to codify the body of rules gathered around the Schengen status quo. Whereas historically, from the Roman emperor Justinian to the French emperor Napoleon, any codification undertaking was part of a desire to ensure the posterity of rules and to enshrine great legal principles, this is to bring our stone to a building that we wish to deconstruct because of its obvious weaknesses. The Schengen area has in fact greatly worsened the migration crisis that we are currently experiencing. So I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I in UKIP voted against this report, because it creates legislation. UKIP is against the EU having any power to legislate so as to make the laws of the United Kingdom. UKIP opposes the operation of the Schengen Agreement which is causing so much long-term harm to the peoples of the Member States. This is permitting and causing the current crisis in respect of largely economic migrants from Africa and the Middle East and thereby exacerbating the problems of migration from the EU into the United Kingdom.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution on the rules governing the movement of persons across borders. The Commission’s proposal in question consists in a mere codification of the already existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Heidi Hautala's report on the European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on an EU code on the regime of people crossing borders. The purpose of this text is to incorporate into the same legal text the various amendments that have been made to the Schengen border code in the interest of clarification and simplification.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical report, which aims to adopt an outright codification of the existing texts on the Schengen border code, without any substantive changes.  In the interest of consolidating and simplifying the various legal standards relating to Schengen, it was necessary to endorse this Commission proposal.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I do not agree with this report. It includes rules relating to the Schengen Agreement, which I am critical of.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I support the establishment of a Community Code for the rules governing movement of persons across borders. The proposal does not involve any change in the substance of these rules; it is a simple codification that would aid interpretation and strengthen the law, and thus I agree with the rapporteur that this regulation of Parliament and Council on a Union Code should be implemented.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as the proposal fully preserves the content of the act being codified.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The European Commission has submitted a codification proposal for the Schengen Borders Code to the European Parliament. No material-content changes may be made in a codification. The specific process is based, inter alia, on the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working procedure for the official codification of legal texts. The aim is to combine existing EU legislation in the spirit of simplification. In the present case, this concerns the Community Code on the crossing of borders by persons, or Schengen Borders Code for short. The new regulation replaces the various acts which are the subject of codification.  As I am in favour of simplifying EU law and reducing red tape in the EU institutions, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The establishment of a Community code on the arrangements for the crossing of borders by persons (Schengen Borders Code) is limited to a codification of existing texts. This does not involve any substantial changes and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour. As we all know, the European Union is going through an unprecedented historical moment and Community legislation on immigration needs more clarity. The latter, combined with legal certainty and the immediate application of Community rules, is closely linked to the establishment of the code we are to discuss.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on a European Union code on people's border crossings (Schengen border code). The proposal in question is limited to codifying existing texts, without altering their substance. However, the Schengen system has proved to be a failure. It is therefore not a question of modifying or codifying it, it must be abolished and given the possibility for Member States to regain control of their borders.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it approves the codification of the rules of the Schengen area. However, I am against the Schengen area that this codification is trying to save. We must regain control of our national borders to stop the wave of migration.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This report calls for the codified body of rules gathered around the Schengen status quo. Codification has significance since historically, from the Roman emperor Justinian to the Emperor Napoleon, it was part of a desire to ensure the posterity of the rules and to enshrine great legal and societal principles.  I therefore refuse to allow the construction of the Schengen area as a principle, which is also in its part of free movement of people without any borders or controls. This artificial, unstable and inept construction that is the Schengen area being deconstructed in my opinion, I logically voted against this report.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The European Commission has submitted a codification proposal for the Schengen Borders Code to the European Parliament. No material-content changes may be made in a codification. The specific process is based, inter alia, on the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working procedure for the official codification of legal texts. The aim is to combine existing EU legislation in the spirit of simplification. In the present case, this concerns the Community Code on the crossing of borders by persons, or Schengen Borders Code for short. The new regulation replaces the various acts which are the subject of codification.  As I am in favour of simplifying EU law and reducing red tape in the EU institutions, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation Codification (EC) No. 562/2006 sets conditions, criteria and detailed rules on border checks changes taking into account human rights and dignity. Border control will check individually as before, but will also introduce additional checks to secure the EU's internal borders. People in the so-called SIS system will be additionally checked. Since only a person can be truly identified through a fingerprint, consolidation with the so-called VIS system will be in place, and every time the border is crossed, it will be mandatory to stamp the passport. Under the proposal for a resolution, the possibility of reintroducing the EU's internal borders will be an exception and will be treated as a last resort. It is also necessary to ensure a common response to threats that may cause borders to be closed. The maximum time period for closing borders is 10 days, after that period of time, if an extension is required, it is necessary to obtain approval at EU level.  I supported the proposal to change the rules, as eu internal security needs to be ensured. The purpose of the change in regulation is to better manage border crossings to enhance security within the EU where there are no national borders. Given previous developments and terrorist attacks, there is a need for additional security and for this reason I support the proposal.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council was adopted about 10 years ago, in March 2006, aimed at introducing a Community Code on the rules governing the movement of persons across borders. On the other hand, a year ago in February and April, the Working Party of Legal Staff of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission came to the conclusion that the Commission's original proposal to install the Schengen Borders Code was fully acceptable, since in no case does any amendments to the existing texts, but only legally combine them and thus codify them. In other words, today there was a vote aimed at raising, to a certain point, the legal force of existing legislation through further integrative codification through the new regulation. Hopefully this will make it possible to increase the efficiency of the Schengen area, which has become a more fundamental challenge over the last year than ever before.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Union Code on the status of persons crossing borders (Schengen Borders Code), because in indirect terms it has the competence of the Member States in the field of rules on the transit of persons across borders. These competences belong to the Member States and the Shengen Borders Code in this respect infringes the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The aim of this report is to put in place a code for people crossing borders. In other words, it is a matter of codifying rules around Schengen to strengthen it. We are opposed to the very existence of this Schengen area, so there is no question for us of supporting a text that strengthens it.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Report. However, I do not believe the main problem with Schengen is the rules but the failure of political will in a number of Member States.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Union code on the arrangements for the crossing of borders by persons. Control at the external borders is one of the main protection measures, carried out in the interests of all Member States with the aim of preventing any threat to the internal security and public order of the Member States, regardless of the origin of the threat. It is therefore of great importance that there should be simple and clear European legislation so that all European citizens can have access to it and enforce the rights enshrined in that legislation.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, this proposal is based on the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments. I voted for it.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. A further cementing of the current legal situation, which does not provide the right answers for the current crisis situation, is certainly the wrong way to go. Nation states must be free to decide whether and how to protect their borders. I am therefore voting against the codification of the Schengen laws and therefore against this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report is purely technical and aims to aggregate the changes made to the Schengen coder in the EU. It does, however, open the door to abuses such as the last Danish law to confiscate migrants' property. This regulation explains for many the disasters of the management of the current migration crisis. I'm voting against codifying it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report aims to codify the corpus of rules gathered around the Schengen status quo.  Codification is an operation that aims to affirm great legal principles, to be asserted in the long term. This is about supporting a building that I want to deconstruct because of its essential infirmities. The Schengen area has played a serious role in worsening the migration crisis we are currently experiencing. As a result I voted against this text

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This report involves the codification of texts regarding the movement of persons across European borders, as provided by the Schengen Borders Code. I voted in favour of this report as codification of the rules regulating movement of persons will help make for a safer Europe.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Since the proposal for a regulation of the EP and the Council on an EU code on the regime of border crossing by persons is limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without altering the substance, and taking into account the inter-institutional agreement of 20 December 1994 on the method of accelerated work for the formal codification of legislation , I agreed that this position should be decided at first reading.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The European Union is now facing historical events when more refugees arrive on its territory than at any time in its history. The difficult situation in the Middle East and Africa is forcing many people to flee their homes and seek safety in other countries. Many of them seek refuge in the countries of the European Union. The Schengen area, which is of great benefit to facilitating the lives of ordinary people and entrepreneurs in Europe, must be sufficiently protected by precise rules and their observance, both with regard to the safety of both residents and refugees crossing its borders. For these reasons, I welcome all the changes that the draft legislative resolution brings about, which positively regulate legislation in this area.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the Rules governing the movement of persons across borders (Schengen Borders Code) as the proposal fully preserves the content of the act being codified.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft regulation submitted by the European Commission contains, in the opinion of the Advisory Working Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, a simple consolidated set of existing texts without any substantive amendment. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs therefore recommended to Parliament that it adopt the draft with the amendments proposed by the Advisory Working Party. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded in its opinion that this proposal is to be combed to the pure and simple codification of existing texts without substantive amendments. I would like to vote in favour of this report, which stresses the fact that the establishment of rules for the crossing of persons at borders cannot be sufficiently carried out by the Member States and may be better achieved at Union level.  To this end, the Union must take the necessary measures in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity enshrined in Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union. In accordance with the principle of proportionality enshrined in that Article, that Regulation and its successive amendments do not go beyond what is necessary to achieve that objective.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report calls for the codification of the corpus of rules gathered around the Schengen status quo. Historically, from Emperor Justinian to Emperor Napoleon, any codification undertaking has been part of a desire to ensure the posterity of rules, to enshrine great principles. It is therefore not a question of making a contribution to a building that we wish to deconstruct. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the regime of border crossings by people. Purely technical, this codification text aims to consolidate the regulation of the Schengen border code, to which six legislative amendments have been made since its adoption in 2006.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The initial regulation of the border code has been amended by six different legislative tools since its adoption in 2006. I therefore voted in favour of the report on the Eu Code on the regime of border crossings by people to allow a consolidation of the text, which nevertheless does not alter its substance.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Union code on the arrangements for the crossing of borders by persons (Schengen Borders Code) is limited to the codification of existing texts and does not involve any substantial changes and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour. Border control will contribute to the fight against illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings and terrorism, priority issues that the European Union is called upon to address.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on the rules governing the movement of persons across borders that alters existing texts on the Schengen Borders Code, without any change in their substance.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the issue of crossing borders is all the subject of it, and it is legislated by the Schengen Borders Code. Today's report does not, in substance, amend this Schengen Borders Code, but refers only to a codification of existing texts, entrusting the President with the task of sending our position, the European Law-Making Forum, to the Council, the Commission and national parliaments. In this respect, I believe that these changes are beneficial for all Member States, at this time when the rules on crossing borders in the Schengen area must be extremely clear.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. \u2012 The Schengen system is one of the European Union's most important achievements, with great practical benefits and symbolic value. In order to maintain the system in the circumstances of the large number of asylum seekers and the terrorist threat, it is necessary to clarify the rules of the system. Parliament's position is to make sure that the development of the system does not affect the most important benefits of Schengen, and I therefore support it.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I would have opposed this report because the Schengen Borders Code, which contains the rules for the Schengen area, obliges the EU Commission and the Member States concerned to inform the European Parliament and the Council of the EU if there are grounds for a temporary reintroduction of border controls. It is precisely in these times that border controls are particularly important. Short-term regulations and border controls are unacceptable to me.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is a codification of existing legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report, because it creates legislation. UKIP is against the EU having any power to legislate so as to make the laws of the United Kingdom. UKIP opposes the operation of the Schengen Agreement which is causing so much long-term harm to the peoples of the Member States. This is permitting and causing the current crisis in respect of largely economic migrants from Africa and the Middle East and thereby exacerbating the problems of migration from the EU into the United Kingdom.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Schengen Borders Code regulation applies to anyone crossing the external borders of all EU countries except the UK and Ireland, and the internal borders of the Schengen area. This regulation, as you know, has achieved an excellent result by implementing different decisions for the two borders. I therefore welcome a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes. I am voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Free movement within the Schengen area is one of the most important freedoms of the European Union. National borders undermine one of the main achievements of the EU – the internal market. Initial estimates indicate that the economic loss from reinstating some national borders is equivalent to the imposition of a 3% tax in the EU. The only solution is strengthening the security of external borders and the Commission proposal to establish a European Border and Coast Guard. Actions need to be undertaken within the shortest delay possible and I welcome the report on the proposal for a regulation on the rules governing the Schengen Borders Code.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ Different events have proved that the cross-border movement of persons could not be sufficiently achieved by the Member States but could rather be better achieved at Union level. Given the current state of play in which the Schengen area is confronted with extreme realities, a solution from the Union is what is needed.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report governing the rules of movement of persons across borders, because I believe that the regulation of the Schengen Borders Code will help better control movement. I believe it is important to clearly define parameters in which internal border checkpoints can be reintroduced and that any border control should be approached with complete professionalism, while respecting human dignity in particular.  It is important to have clearly regulated rules so that every situation, whether it is a terrorist incident, a threat, suspicion of organised crime or something else, has a quick and clear response on the ground. Such a reaction is possible only with the approach provided by this rule proposal, from which, without wasting time on the interpretation of the rules, one can immediately see which reaction is appropriate in accordance with the regulations of the European Union.  Considering that this proposal has a positive impact on very important issues of security of citizens of the European Union, as well as those outside it, and more clearly defines some parts of the related Regulations with which efficiency in emergency situations will be at a higher level, I fully support it.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report calls for the codification of the corpus of rules gathered around the Schengen status quo. Historically, from Emperor Justinian to Emperor Napoleon, any codification undertaking has been part of a desire to ensure the posterity of rules, to enshrine great principles. It is therefore not a question of making my stone to a building which I hope will be dismantled and returned to the oblivion of history. I am obviously voting against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the codification report, that is, the codification report. the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the Union Code of Rules governing the movement of persons across borders (Schengen Borders Code), since the proposal fully preserves the content of the act being codified, in particular with regard to the agreement on the accelerated method of work for the formal codification of legislative texts.  In situations where Member States cannot sufficiently exercise and enforce the rules applicable to the movement of persons across borders, it is the right and power of the Union to be able to adopt measures in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity laid down in Article 5(1) of the Regulation. Treaty on European Union without exceeding what is necessary to achieve the objective in accordance with the principle of proportionality. What is important is that this proposal is limited to codifying existing texts and does not enter into substantive changes.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Regulation will replace the various acts integrated therein by simply encoding existing texts without substantive changes. The amendments focus primarily on clarifying the definition, the conditions of entry for third-country nationals and the duration of the validity of some travel documents. Changes are also made to extend the exemption to stamp travel documents for crew members of international trains and buses, as is already the case with airline crew members. Measures to train border guards are included in order to detect situations of unaccompanied minors and victims of trafficking. Regardless of the assessment made of these minor changes, we have not changed the previous reflection on Schengen. We do not monitor the increasing harmonisation of immigration and border policies, which oblige Member States to report on bilateral agreements they establish under the Schengen Borders Code. Nor is the obligation of Member States to be required to report when "legal" citizens of third countries enter another Member State.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I support my colleague Heidi Hautal's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the Union Code of Rules governing the movement of persons across borders. Joint measures on crossing persons across internal borders and border control at the external borders should reflect the acquis of the European Union incorporated within the framework of the European Union, in particular the relevant commissions of the 1985 Convention on the Implementation of the Schengen Agreement.  Border control is in the interest not only of the Member States at whose external borders it is carried out, but of all Member States which have abolished internal border control. Borders should help combat illegal immigration and human trafficking and prevent any threat to internal security, public policy, public health and international relations between Member States. It is also necessary to provide rules on calculating the authorized duration of short-term stays in the EU.  Clear, simple and harmonised rules for all legal actions related to this matter would contribute to travellers and both border and visa authorities. Finally, Member States should ensure that external border control procedures do not create significant barriers to trade and social and cultural exchange. Therefore, Member States should set the right number of staff and resources. For these reasons, I agree with the report.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 The document received was only of a technical nature, but I would like to use this space to explain my position and support the maintenance of the Schengen area as we know it, or at least until recently. The Schengen area represents one of the greatest achievements of European integration, a symbol of a united Europe, a privilege that we take for granted. However, this is now at risk if European states do not find a common solution and the closure of the Union's internal borders continues, as has already happened with several states. We are facing urgent questions that we need to address together. How to set up a system for accepting refugees from war-torn countries? How to help the countries most affected by the refugee crisis? How to protect the external borders of the Schengen area more effectively so that we do not have to close internal borders? Managing the migration crisis and Schengen are connected vessels. They have a profound social and financial impact. If we want to finance our asylum policy, which is very expensive, we cannot afford to lose billions of euros, which we will lose by restricting traffic at internal borders. I expect European leaders to make their decisions after careful consideration of all aspects, and that more attention will be paid to the comprehensive functioning of Schengen and its impact than has been the case so far.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Following several meetings in 2015 between the legal services of the European Parliament and those of the Council and the European Commission, a codification of Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 March 2006 was concluded. This codification establishes a Community code on the arrangements for the crossing of frontiers by persons (Schengen Borders Code) without any substantial changes. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the codification of the various provisions is essential in order to make the existing legislation on the crossing of borders more comprehensible and transparent.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a codified version of the European Union Code on rules that provide for the cross-border movement of persons. The Advisory Group, composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, did not propose a fundamental transformation of the Code and, as mentioned in the relevant opinion, the Advisory Group came to the unanimous conclusion that this proposal is merely codification of the existing texts without any change in their content in kind.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 After examining the Commission's proposal for Regulation No 562/2006, it should be noted that this is an important change aimed at giving the EU another power that has hitherto belonged to individual countries of the community, namely the protection of its own borders. This can be indirectly inferred from the amendment of recital 19, which reads as follows: "Since the objective of Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 and subsequent acts amending it, namely the establishment of rules applicable to the movement of persons across borders, could not be sufficiently achieved by the Member States and could have been better achieved at Union level, the Union could have adopted measures in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity as set out in Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union. In accordance with the principle of proportionality, as set out in the same Article, that Regulation and subsequent acts amending it did not go beyond what was necessary in order to achieve that objective.'  The new provision of recital 19 in the form of a regulation appears to be another step in the idea of establishing a common border guard to protect the EU's borders, which aims to stop m.in. wave of illegal immigration into Community countries. The new formation is expected to replace the current Frontex agency based in Warsaw in the long term. France, as well as Germany, have been in favour of the establishment of a joint EU border guard for years. I do not agree with the change introduced, which gives rise in the long term to giving the EU control over the protection of its borders, which in practice means giving the EU a significant amount of sovereignty over the Member States.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 The Schengen area is still alive. This is also demonstrated by the fact that today we are deciding on this report. It is, of course, more or less technical, but it is still a signal that most of us want to maintain the Schengen system, because it is economically and politically advantageous for our citizens.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it simplifies the reading of this legal document. I would also like to point out that codification is a well-known and recognized technique in our country, and that this type of initiative allows citizens to find themselves more easily in the texts in application, whose reading is sometimes complicated.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report, because it creates legislation. UKIP is against the EU having any power to legislate so as to make the laws of the United Kingdom. UKIP opposes the operation of the Schengen Agreement which is causing so much long-term harm to the peoples of the Member States. This is permitting and causing the current crisis in respect of largely economic migrants from Africa and the Middle East and thereby exacerbating the problems of migration from the EU into the United Kingdom.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation lays down the rules applicable to the control of persons crossing the external borders of the Member States of the Union. This report, which I voted in favour of, was made in such a way as to ensure full respect for human dignity and to ensure that border control is not exclusively done in the interests of the Member State at whose external borders it is exercised, but in the interests of all Member States which have abolished control at its internal borders. These measures should continue to contribute to the fight against illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, as well as to the prevention of any threat to internal security, public order and health, and the international relations of the Member States.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without any substantial amendment to the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Union Code of Rules for the crossing of persons across borders.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted today in favour of this report. Indeed, in view of the inter-institutional agreement of 20 December 1994 on the accelerated working method for the formal codification of legislation and considering that, in the opinion of the European Parliament' Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance. , the hemicyle endorsed the Commission's proposal as adapted to the recommendations of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this opinion. Although the document is more technical, as the amendments do not change the substance of the original text, it nevertheless reproduces an important provision here. It submits that the Member States cannot properly lay down rules on the movement of persons across borders and that objective would therefore be better achieved at Union level. I agree that the rules should be the same for everyone, but it is also important that member states have sufficient flexibility to implement them; adopt additional rules where necessary.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a proposal for a Regulation of Parliament and the Council on the compilation of a set of scattered legislation on the regime for the passage of persons at borders with a view to establishing a Community code (Schengen Borders Code).  In view of the growing terrorist threat scenario that is taking on Europe and the international measures taken against this escalation of violence, this proposal to codify the Regulation is departing, through a prior analysis of the risks to internal security and threats that may affect the security of external borders, the codification of existing rules on the passage of persons through border controls.  In an area without internal border controls such as the EU, it is necessary to have a common response to situations that could seriously affect public policy or internal security, thereby allowing the temporary introduction of internal border control in exceptional circumstances, without jeopardising the principle of the free movement of persons.  In view of the exceptional nature inherent in this measure (of a markedly technical nature) I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which supports the Commission's proposal to codify the regulation establishing a Community code on the regime of border crossings by people.  It is therefore in the interests of transparency and clarity of law that this new regulation would replace the various acts that are incorporated into the Schengen border code. The content of the code is preserved; it is a simple coding operation. Thus, the conditions of application related to the lack of control at the EU's internal borders, the types of controls, the particular circumstances, the modalities of exceptional reintroduction of controls and the response to serious threats are being re-codified. This codification operation allows for the legal clarification necessary for the implementation of the Schengen border code.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this change in the Borders Code, in so far as it does not represent a change in the political content of the existing Code and is merely a simplification and reduction of duplications in overlapping codifications.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. As agreed in the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994, it is important that we make EU legislation easier to understand for European citizens. That is why I support this codification.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report is related to Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Community Code of Rules for the Crossing of Persons across borders.  The report is the codification of the different versions and amendments introduced to this Regulation since 15 March 2006. Since it is a coding report which preserves in its entirety the content of the acts being codified – given the technical nature of the coding – I voted in favour.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report, because it creates legislation. UKIP is against the EU having any power to legislate so as to make the laws of the United Kingdom. UKIP opposes the operation of the Schengen Agreement which is causing so much long-term harm to the peoples of the Member States. This is permitting and causing the current crisis in respect of largely economic migrants from Africa and the Middle East and thereby exacerbating the problems of migration from the EU into the United Kingdom.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ There are actually no new provisions in this codification file; just a simple update to the Union code. This is just an example of the European Parliament effectively making EU legislation simpler and allowing for the language to be standardised.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing \u2012 In the current crisis, concrete steps must be taken. Large rescue plans and quotas do not work in practice. I therefore support the specific definition of the practical way of checks at the external borders. However, the rules of this system should be defined more clearly and comprehensiblely, accepting the sovereignty of the Member States. For this reason, I abstained from voting on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a codified version of the Schengen Borders Code.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the Schengen borders have been under immense pressure in recent months. On the one hand, they are external borders that require stronger protection. In addition, it is necessary to ensure that effective protection of member states' internal borders can be carried out in crisis situations. To this end, the Commission has come up with a proposal for codification of the Schengen Code Directive. I welcome and support the Commission's efforts to clarify and rationalise the rules governing the conditions for the introduction of border controls, although it should be noted that this is mainly about harmonising the existing rules.  I believe that controls at the external borders of the Member States should only be introduced in extreme cases, so that we do not hinder free movement in the Schengen area in the long term. But national authorities must be able to ensure their internal security. In addition to border control, the Schengen Code also includes risk analysis, border patrols and the use of the Schengen information system. Citizens of third countries must move within the EU in such a way that it is clear from the visa information system and their travel documents when they joined the EU and which borders they crossed. If border controls also need to be introduced for EU citizens in some places, they should be carried out in accordance with human dignity and in such a way as to reduce as much as possible the waiting time for crossing the border.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ the Code fully respects the right to move and reside freely within the territory of EU Member States. The issue of asylum, the movement of foreigners, border control, the protection of the rights of third-country nationals, as well as the rights of Union citizens and their family members, is one of the primary tasks of a democratic society based on the principles of freedom, security and justice.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒2012 Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on the accelerated method of work for the formal codification of legislative texts, in particular its point 4, the advisory group consisting of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission met on 9 and 26 February and 15 April 2015 to, inter alia, consider that proposal submitted by the Commission.  Since, according to the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes, I supported the proposal.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which is a purely technical file. It merely updates the Union code on this issue.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union Code on rules governing the movement of persons across borders (Schengen Borders Code). I support the 2016 Commission proposal, which has been adapted in line with the recommendations of the Consultative Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. It is not a question of substantive corrections, but only a codification of an existing text.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down a Union code on rules governing the cross-border movement of persons (Schengen Borders Code). These are not new rules, only the codification of the current text of the Schengen Borders Code, which was created back in 2006 and has been amended several times in that time. In particular, the evaluation mechanism of individual Member States in the implementation of external border protection or the rules for the introduction of temporary internal border controls have recently been modified.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Given the high turnout of illegal immigrants, it is necessary not to codify the legislation in force, but to amend the legislative texts concerning the cross-border movement of persons.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of the decision, given that the Commission's proposal, which received support during interinstitutional Commission discussions, is intended to maintain the functioning of the Schengen system and to adapt it to practical requirements. Although the proposed amendments are essentially of a legal-technical nature, they are based on the recognition that the implementation of the Schengen standards governing the movement of persons across national borders has shown that the role of Community, Union legislation and enforcement should be strengthened in the face of specific implementation at Member State level. As a Member attaching great importance to interoperable European borders, I will continue to support similar corrective efforts to strengthen the Community method in the EP's procedures.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Considering that, in the opinion of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without any change in substance, Parliament could only vote on this text.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on the rules governing the movement of persons across borders: the changes proposed by the Commission were studied by the European Parliament’s Legal Service; they purely consist in a codification of existing texts and do not foresee any change of the content. A new recital is inserted, based on already existing provisions, recalling the importance of managing movement of persons at EU level, in accordance with the principles of necessity and proportionality.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, determined to maintain the Schengen agreements and borders. Without the free movement of citizens, union would be a big market. I'm not going to compromise. Nationalism and identity rhetoric lead to deadlock. To solve the migration crisis, as well as to combat terrorist risks, European countries must unite and strengthen their common border policy, not break it up. Returning to national borders would only exacerbate isolation and condemn everyone to impotence. Those who tried to pull Greece out of the eurozone are now proposing to take it out of the Schengen area. This is unacceptable. Greece is not responsible for its geographical location, which makes it a privileged point of arrival for refugees from the Middle East. Is there a need for a border management policy? Yes. But it must be done at the EU's external borders and with European border guards!   The European Union is now in a crucial phase: if Schengen falls, it will also fall. Together we will be stronger, without cooperation, we will remain powerless.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Although, according to the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the Union Code on rules governing the movement of persons across borders is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes, it is evident that the amendment in the recital is an important change aimed at giving the European Union powers over border management.  As I support respect for the sovereignty and integrity of each Member State of the European Union, I cannot support another step in realising the idea of establishing a common border police of the European Union, i.e. a step towards a federal Union. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union Code of the Union on rules governing the movement of persons across borders (Schengen Borders Code) as I believe that the need to weigh up the necessity and proportionality of the reintroduction of internal border controls should be weighed against the threat to public policy or internal security that has created the need for such the introduction of controls.  However, alternative measures that could be taken at national, Union or both levels and the impact of such controls on the free movement of persons in the area without internal border control should also be considered. The reintroduction of internal border controls should continue to apply only exceptionally in an area where persons can move freely. First and foremost, we must strive for the safety of all Citizens of the Union.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this change in the Borders Code, in so far as it does not represent a change in the political content of the existing Code and is merely a simplification and reduction of duplications in overlapping codifications.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The European Commission has submitted a codification proposal for the Schengen Borders Code to the European Parliament. No material-content changes may be made in a codification. The specific process is based, inter alia, on the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working procedure for the official codification of legal texts. The aim is to combine existing EU legislation in the spirit of simplification. In the present case, this concerns the Community Code on the crossing of borders by persons, or Schengen Borders Code for short. The new regulation replaces the various acts which are the subject of codification.  As I am in favour of simplifying EU law and reducing red tape in the EU institutions, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this, as it is crucial that Europe and its institutions make sure the rules regarding Schengen are clear but most of all implemented. In these difficult times with serious threats, it is crucial to secure our external borders if we want Schengen to live! The free movement of persons is one of Europe’s fundamental achievements; let us make sure it does not collapse!

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report calls for the codification of the corpus of rules gathered around the Schengen status quo. Historically, from Emperor Justinian to Emperor Napoleon, any codification undertaking has been part of a desire to ensure the posterity of rules, to enshrine great principles. It is therefore not a question of making a contribution to a building that we wish to deconstruct. So I logically voted against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In the opinion of the Advisory Working Party composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a simple coding of existing texts without any substantive amendment, so I agreed with the position of the S&D Group and supported the act.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this change in the Borders Code, in so far as it does not represent a change in the political content of the existing Code and is merely a simplification and reduction of duplications in overlapping codifications.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is mainly a technical codification of existing rules that have been amended several times. Specifically, the purpose of this proposal is to undertake a codification of Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 March 2006 establishing a Community Code on the rules governing the movement of persons across borders (Schengen Borders Code). The new Regulation will replace the various acts incorporated in it; this proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified and does nothing more than bring them together with the only exception of formal amendments that are required by the codification exercise itself. The reason for such codifications is that the Commission attaches great importance to simplifying and clarifying the law of the Union so as to make it clearer and more accessible to citizens. This aim cannot be achieved so long as numerous provisions that have been amended several times, often quite substantially, remain scattered, so that they must be sought partly in the original instrument and partly in later amending ones.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a proposal which, according to the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without any substantial amendment thereof, so that the Eurochamber proceeds to its approval at first reading. Given the nature of that rule, I think it is appropriate to vote in its favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report. In Europe, we have not been able to provide a collective response to the refugee crisis. Time and time again we discuss possible solutions, but almost never does it lead to joint action by the European Union. Even in the cases where we do come to a joint action, we do not succeed in bringing this to a successful conclusion.  However, it goes without saying that the problem of the refugee crisis cannot be solved by one Member State alone. This is a European crisis and so there must be a European response. Closing the internal borders of the Schengen zone cannot be a solution, but it is the monitoring of our common external borders. I therefore call, on the one hand, for a common European border and coastguard to guard our external borders and, on the other hand, for a European set of migration rules that apply to the whole of the Union.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 15 March 2006 establishes the Community code on the regime for the passage of persons at borders (Schengen Borders Code), which has already been amended several times. The new regulation voted on today will replace the various acts contained therein, with a simple and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. A further cementing of the current legal situation, which does not provide the right answers for the current crisis situation, is certainly the wrong way to go. Nation states must be free to decide whether and how to protect their borders. I am therefore voting against the codification of the Schengen laws and therefore against this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a Community code for the crossing of borders by persons (Schengen Border Code). It is claimed that the above-mentioned proposal is limited to a mere codification of the existing legal texts without any substantive changes, so that the simplified legislative procedure can take place. In fact, however, recital 19 now stipulates that 'operational cooperation and mutual assistance to Member States in border controls ... the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States ("Frontex") established by Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004". This goes beyond the existing powers of Frontex, which has helped the Member States. The new text is a sovereignty levy, albeit a small one. It is therefore not a mere codification of existing rules.  I believe that Parliament should in no way relinquish its already limited powers in favour of the Commission. That is why I have already refused for formal reasons.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution establishing the Union Code on the status of persons crossing borders (Schengen Borders Code), as the relevant advisory group of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission decided that this proposal is limited simply to codifying existing texts.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. We are facing a critical and unknown situation for the EU. More and more refugees are crossing our borders, trying to escape the war and find a better future. I certainly strongly support that we must help those who come in search of refuge; not doing so would go against our values. What I do believe is that these borders should be controlled, to ensure that anyone with a visa enters and avoids those who have no reason to enter the EU.  Without a doubt, I believe that we must be aware that those refugees who settle in the EU have to enjoy our rights, but they must also respect our duties and values; otherwise action should be taken. Nevertheless, I believe that the solution to the refugee problem lies not so much in improving the management of EU borders as in ending the Syria war.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report because I consider it important that European Union law be clear and comprehensible. The different provisions relating to the Schengen area have changed considerably over time and new documents have been produced. I therefore very much welcome the codification that will create a comprehensive document of a holistic nature. In the current refugee crisis, it is of the utmost importance that The Member States know clearly what powers and instruments the Schengen documents offer them and which they can use.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the draft regulation on the movement of people across borders within the European Union. It should be emphasised, however, that this document does not bring any new substantive solutions, but merely unifies – often amended in recent years – the provisions on the so-called Schengen area.  The functioning of the Schengen area is one of the pillars of the European Union. These rules allow eu citizens to move freely in Europe. Border control by a single Union country shall be carried out in the interest of all Member States. This gives a specific obligation to the EU country which issues the travel documents. Border control should therefore always be carried out professionally and with respect for the persons inspected. There is no doubt that the harmonisation of the text will facilitate the work of the border services of the Member States of the European Union.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I abstained in the vote on this report. The report on the proposal for a regulation establishing the Schengen Borders Code should only have been a codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance. However, despite this assurance, in my opinion, the report is on one point moving powers from the Member States to the European Union, which goes beyond the definition of codification without any change in substance. The report states that, since the objective of the regulation cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States and could be better achieved at Union level, the European Union should be able to adopt measures the adoption of which before that codification was a competence of the Member States. And while this particular article may not mean any substantial change in the long term, I believe that it should not be inserted into the regulation without due attention.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. Schengen is one of the European Union's greatest achievements. Today it is being tested and the EU is also on the test. The migrant wave must be stopped or angry, which requires coordinated action by all Member States in controlling the external borders. I therefore supported the proposal for a regulation, which brings about a set of common measures and rules on the movement of persons across borders.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 In 1979, the EU ratified the Convention on Transfrontier Air Pollution of Heavy Metals, consoting the first binding instrument in this area. By regulating the control and subsequent reduction of pollution from industrial sources or waste incineration, the Convention was subsequently extended by eight protocols, the last of which was in 1998. The Aarhus Protocol tightened up the rules on the emission of certain metals, such as lead, cadmium and mercury, forcing Member States to reduce their emissions sharply. I voted in favour because I consider the latest changes introduced to be appropriate, which will ensure greater protection of the environment, as well as human health.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report deals with the acceptance of procedural amendments updating the scope of international conventions already approved by Parties at international level and now being incorporated into the framework of EU law. I voted in favour because I believe that the ratification of the amendments is a step forward towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from long-range cross-border air pollution caused by heavy metals.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this recommendation on amendments to the 1998 protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution on Heavy Metals. Indeed, if heavy metals are extremely harmful, both to humans and to nature, and these amendments are in line with EU legislation, Member States are already signatories to this protocol. I therefore believe that it is not necessary for the EU to sign these amendments; it would not add value. Moreover, it would be wise to have the Aarhus Protocol ratified by major industrial powers in third countries such as the United States or China.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this recommendation. The vote was procedural and technical. The recommendation accepted amendments to the 1998 Protocol of the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution. The protocol has been updated at international level and some of the updating amendments need to be ratified by the parties to the Convention. Therefore, we voted in favour of this dossier.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the specific amendments to the 1998 Heavy Metals Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution, as these provide, inter alia, for stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain large fixed sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements that will benefit the parties to it before the end of 2019. This amendment is fully in line with existing EU legislation.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Supporting the amendment on heavy metal pollution would be a mistake. I note that, with the exception of Malta, the EU Member States are already signatories to the Aarhus Protocol on this subject.  The commission's recommendation does not bring added value or legal significance. It would make more sense for the EU to approach the major industrial powers in order to invite them to join this protocol under the leadership of the Un. So I voted against this amendment.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in the importance of improving the air quality not just in Europe but across the globe. However I do not believe that the Commission’s proposal to expand legislation in this area is the correct way to achieve this. The European Union’s policies on energy and climate have already caused irreparable damage to the United Kingdom’s industry and economy.  I abstained on this proposal, as I agree with the aim to improve air quality in Europe but I believe that this legislation will not achieve this.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of these amendments because they represent an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. Winds do not know the borders, so it is necessary to tackle the problems caused by air pollution at European and international level.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Amendments to the 1998 Protocol on Heavy Metals to the Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution. The purpose of this Convention is to protect human health and the environment from air pollution. Studies carried out between 1972 and 1977 have shown that air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometres before they settle, and this problem needs to be addressed at international level. The Convention, signed in 1979, was the first legally binding international instrument in this field. It has created a system to control and reduce the damage to human health and the environment caused by transboundary air pollution. In 1998, i supplemented the Convention. The Aarhus Protocol on Heavy Metals aims to reduce and control emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury into ambient air due to anthropogenic activity. It requires the Parties to reduce the total annual emissions of these three metals to a lower level than their emissions in 1990. The aim is also to reduce emissions from industrial sources, combustion processes and waste incineration. I support the amendments contained in the proposal aimed at ensuring a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against transboundary air pollution.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution is to protect the human environment from air pollution. Several studies have shown that air pollutants can travel thousands of kilometres before they are deposited. Therefore, the problems caused by air pollution need to be addressed at international level. In 1979, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe signed the Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution, which aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. This Treaty has been extended to several protocols over time and is currently amending the 1998 Protocol. The proposal in question amends the Protocol on heavy metals emitted into the air by tightening up the limit values. On the basis of the explanatory memorandum annexed to this document, the existing EU standards contain a large part of these limits. The new standards will be introduced into EU law by the creation of a directive. On this basis, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The Aarhus Protocol, named after Denmark's second largest city, where a first convention was signed in June 1998, five years before the protocol of the same name, concerns long-distance cross-border pollution. The amendments in question are intended to set limits on the emission limits of dust containing heavy metals or persistent organic pollutants (such as PCBs).  The Aarhus Protocol is under the aegis of the United Nations, the signatory parties are essentially European states as well as the European Union. But not all EU states are at the same stage of engagement and Malta has not signed or ratified the Aarhus Protocol. Heavy metals and POPs - persistent organic pollutants - are real poisons for humans and nature. For example, nearly half of migratory birds have already disappeared because of the effects of POPs on their sense of direction.  However, the amendments in question are already widely covered by our legislation and the EU should start by asking third countries such as the United States or China to sign and/or ratify this protocol, before imposing new constraints on us.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution was signed in 1979 and came into force in 1983. It has since been expanded through eight protocols specifically identifying measures for parties to reduce their emissions of air pollutants, including the Aarhus Protocol, which in 1998 aimed to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of lead, mercury and cadmium. I have endorsed this decision to accept amendments to this protocol in order to set a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution is one of the greatest threats to people's health and environmental protection. Since the 1970s, the international community has decided to tackle the problem by creating, in 1979, the Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution, which was then extended by several protocols. In 1998, the Heavy Metals Protocol, which saw the accession of the Community in 2001, specified the measures needed to limit and control emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury. The amendments made to the Protocol in 2012 need to be ratified by the EU in order to enter into force, which is why I voted in favour of the La Via report. The new measures will ensure not only a more efficient use of the best available techniques but will set stricter emission limit values.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report as the inclusion of these amendments implies acceptance of an improvement in heavy metals legislation adopted in international conventions and now transposed into European Union law.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this report on the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution in Heavy Metals. The Convention aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. To date, the Convention has been expanded with eight protocols identifying specific measures to be taken by Parties to reduce their air pollution emissions.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This amendment relates to the Aarhus Protocol on cross-border heavy metal pollution (pcBs, for example). The signatories of this protocol are for most European states as well as the European Union.  The amendments are already widely covered by EU legislation. The Commission's recommendation has no added value or legal significance, especially since the Member States are already parties to the protocol. It is of no use to support this recommendation. On the other hand, we can only invite the European Union to get closer to the major industrial powers in order to invite them to sign and/or ratify the Aarhus Protocol as the United States (not ratified) or China (not ratified and non-signatory countries).  So I decided to vote against that recommendation.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr La Via's report is well thought out and I support it. The proposed amendments to the 1998 Aarhus Protocol aim to reduce and control more both emissions of 'heavy metals' and emissions of 'persistent organic pollutants'. I believe that it is essential to strengthen the current legislation, which will certainly lead to greater protection both for the environment and for the health of our citizens. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval to the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution in Heavy Metals.
