Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 had shown that air pollutants could travel several thousand kilometres before depositing, so problems arising from air pollution on an international scale need to be addressed. The Convention, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, was the first legally binding international instrument in this area and has been expanded with eight protocols establishing specific measures, including heavy metals. This amended Protocol sets stricter limit values for particulate emissions from certain large stationary sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements that will benefit Parties that accede to the amended Protocol by the end of 2019, including eastern and south-eastern European countries. The ratification of the amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it endorses Parliament's opinion in 1979. Amendments to the 1998 Protocol on Heavy Metals to the Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution. The Convention on Long-range transboundary air pollution aims to protect human health and the environment from air pollution. Several studies carried out between 1972 and 1977 showed that air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometres before they settle. The problem of air pollution must therefore be tackled at international level. The Convention, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, was the first legally binding international instrument in this field. That Convention was a framework that allowed the control and reduction of damage to human health and the environment caused by transboundary transboundary air pollution. The amended Protocol lays down, in particular, stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major stationary sources and a more flexible transitional arrangements. This amendment to the Protocol has already been implemented by existing EU legislation and will be further transposed by the adoption of a new directive setting updated national emission ceilings for certain atmospheric pollutants and providing for annual national emission lists (among others, lead, cadmium and mercury).

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. -u2012 Similar to the Protocol on persistent organic pollutants, the proposal for an amendment to the Protocol on heavy metals to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Trans-Border Air Pollution lays down in particular stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major stationary sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements that will benefit those Parties that will accede to the amended Protocol before the end of 2019 , including the countries of Eastern and South-Eastern Europe. These protocols are important because air pollution does not know national borders, so proper cooperation and unification of protocols is the only possible choice and, for this reason, my support for these solutions is also my support.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against air pollution knows no national boundaries and therefore needs to be addressed globally. To this end, the 1979 Convention, which was subsequently extended by eight protocols, established a legally binding framework to reduce the risks to the environment and human health caused by air pollution. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol, transposed by the European Union, regulates emissions from industrial sources, combustion processes and waste incineration. The protocol has recently been reviewed and updated, setting tighter limits for emissions of certain dusts and establishing annual national emission registers including substances such as lead, cadmium and mercury. I therefore welcome the inclusion of the amendments to the protocol, since its updating is fully in line with the strategy put in place by the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Amendments to the Aarhus Protocol on long-distance cross-border pollution provide for setting limits on the emission limits of dust containing heavy metals. Member States are already signatories and it is therefore not necessary for the EU to ratify these amendments. On the other hand, the latter should approach the major industrial powers of third countries to invite them to sign and/or ratify the protocol such as the United States or China.  Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution concerning Heavy Metals and their Protocols are fundamental documents for the protection of the environment and the health of individuals and that, therefore, it is the Union's task to ensure its full application.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. It has been known since 1972 that air pollutants can be transported thousands of kilometres before depositing, which highlighted the need to tackle the problems caused by air pollution at international level as early as 1979, with the signing of the Convention on Transboundary Air Pollution which came into force in 1983. It establishes a common framework for the control and reduction of damage caused by cross-border air pollution to human health and the environment. Today, the European Parliament must support the Commission's proposal to update the 1998 Protocol to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of lead (Pb), cadmium (Cd) and mercury (Hg) into the atmosphere. , in addition to the imposition on States to apply the best available production techniques (BAT). It is important to support all efforts to curb air pollution and to protect the health of our citizens.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Aarhus Protocol, under the auspices of the United Nations, aims to limit cross-border air pollution over long distances. Almost all of the signatory parties are Member States of the European Union, although they are not all at the same stage of engagement. These amendments are intended to set the emission limits for dust containing heavy metals.  On the merits, the health hazards of heavy metals are no longer to be demonstrated. From a legal point of view, we believe that the objectives of these amendments are in perfect harmony with European Union legislation. Nevertheless, we do not consider it necessary for the European Parliament to ratify these amendments as the Member States are already signatories. If the objective for the European institutions, always with good intentions, is indeed to reduce the emission of these dusts, then the real challenge is to convince the federal authorities of the United States as well as those of emerging countries such as China and India to ratify the Aarhus Protocol. That is why I voted against these amendments.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution harms human health and the environment. In Europe, emissions from many air pollutants have decreased substantially in recent decades, resulting in an improvement in air quality in the region. However, concentrations of air pollutants continue to be very high and air quality problems persist.  The most important thing is that the problems caused by air pollution are solved internationally.  In this context, I welcome the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the acceptance of amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution on Heavy Metals. This draft decision is one of the beneficial measures contributing to the identification of specific measures to reduce emissions of air pollutants.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants aims to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and spills of persistent organic pollutants (dichlorodiphenyl trichloroethane (DDT), hexachlorocyclohexane (HCH), polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (IPA), dioxins/furans (PCDD/PCDF) and hexachlorobenzene (HCB)). In December 2009, the Protocol was amended by Decisions 2009/1, 2009/2, 2009/3 and 2009/4, the latter two of which refer to the best available techniques (BAT). Decisions 2009/1 and 2009/2 include seven new substances, update implementation requirements for many substances, update the limitations of PCDD/PCDF emissions from different sources and add PCBs to the list of substances subject to annual emission restrictions and reporting requirements. The amendments to the Protocol, which are already largely covered by EU legislation, will be further transposed by the revision of the Directive setting national emission limits (NECs) for certain air pollutants and establishing annual national emission inventories, which are currently under way. I am voting in favour.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Recommendation concerning the draft Council Decision accepting the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution of Heavy Metals. The Convention on Air Pollution is the first legally binding international instrument in this area, as it has established a framework for the control and reduction of damage caused to the human environment by the spread of pollutants. Over the years, the Convention has been extended by eight protocols, which have ensured a more effective approach, focusing mainly on the phasing out of leaded petrol and the reduction of mercury concentration levels in alkaline batteries and other products, such as measuring devices. The Accession of the European Community to the last Protocol was approved in April 2001, but the text was reviewed from the point of view of the adequacy and effectiveness of the obligations laid down, in particular by establishing stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major fixed sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements for the benefit of the parties to join by the end of 2019. The recommendation accepts these amendments and that is why I voted for its acceptance.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the ratification of the amendments to the Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals, which I believe will lead to a higher level of protection of health and the environment. The aim of these changes is to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of many heavy metals into the atmosphere, with particular reference to emissions from industrial sources, combustion processes and waste incineration. Furthermore, these amendments provide for this protocol to set stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major fixed sources.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. We support the report and believe that the problems caused by air pollution should be addressed at international level.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The recommendation on the draft Council Decision accepting the amendment to the 1998 Heavy Metals Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution is part of a wider effort to improve existing regulations and agreements. As it directly concerns all European citizens affected by air pollution, I think it should be welcomed by all of us and that is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure because I believe that its ratification will be a decisive step towards the ever-increasing protection of public health and the environment from the possible damage caused by cross-border pollution. The Commission proposes that the Council approve the amendment to the Aarhus Protocol to the 1979 Convention. This Protocol regulates the reduction and control of emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury, heavy metals which are easily suited to cross-border air pollution. The Protocol requires the Parties to reduce the total annual amount of emissions of these heavy metals.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because it incorporates principles already enshrined and confirmed by this Parliament in other regulatory contexts. President La Via has done an excellent job in coordinating the parliamentary process of this measure.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on long-range transboundary air pollution on heavy metals. The Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution aims to protect the environment against air pollutants. Air pollutants have the potential to travel several thousand kilometres before being deposited. Stricter limit values for dust emissions and flexible transitional arrangements will directly benefit those following the amended protocol. A new directive setting updated national emission ceilings for certain atmospheric pollutants and annual national emission inventories will deal with emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury. Ratifying this amendment aims to provide a higher level of protection of human health and preserve the environment against transboundary air pollution.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mr La Via's report on strengthening the fight against heavy metal pollution. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals aims to reduce and control emissions into the atmosphere of man-made lead, cadmium and mercury. It aims to reduce the annual emissions of the three metals to levels below those recorded in 1990. As the Rapporteur rightly points out, the Protocol aims to reduce emissions from industrial sources (iron and steel industry, non-ferrous metals), combustion processes (industry, electricity generation, road transport) and waste incineration.  It is in this context that we want to phase out leaded petrol, reduce mercury concentration levels in alkaline batteries and include other products containing mercury as measuring devices. The amended Protocol sets stricter limit values for dust emissions that need to be transposed through a new directive. I agree with the Rapporteur that the ratification of the amendment will be an important step towards better protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution, especially in view of the fact that it is heavy metals.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. In view of the fact that the 1998 Protocol to the Convention in question responds to the need to tackle the problem of air pollution, I have decided to vote in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council resolution amending the protocol. Indeed, the amendments that have been made have not only been judged to be perfectly consistent with the legal competences of the European Union, but also create a positive development in regulation, particularly with regard to limiting the presence of heavy metals in the atmosphere. This progress will benefit all European citizens by ensuring a higher level of health.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Air pollution is harmful to the human environment, yet pollution does not contain itself to one state and so cannot be addressed through single individual state action but only through joint international action. I have voted in favour of this report which supports the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long Range Transboundary Air Pollution on Persistent Organic Pollutants. Action that deals with pollution and environmental issues needs to be kept under continuous review.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention aims to reduce and control emissions of seven new substances, including emissions of lead (Pb), cadmium (Cd) and mercury (Hg) into the atmosphere. The Parties are required to reduce their total annual emissions of these three metals to levels below those of 1990. Studies carried out during the 1970s on air pollutants already highlighted the need to address the problems caused by air pollution. I believe that the ratification of the amendments to the 1998 Protocol is not only useful but also necessary. The WHO revealed in a 2010 study that in large Italian centers, due to the high concentration of thin particulate matter, more than 8 thousand people die every year. That is why I am voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report deals with the acceptance of procedural amendments updating the scope of international conventions already approved by the parties at international level and which are now incorporated into the framework of EU legislation. I voted in favour because I believe that the ratification of the amendments is a step forward towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from long-range cross-border air pollution caused by heavy metals.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution for which I voted in favour approves the amendments to the Protocol to the Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution of Heavy Metals. The proposed amendments set stricter limits on cross-border emissions than those set out in the Convention Protocol in order to improve the prevention of air pollution and its effects on human health.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution is to protect the human environment from air pollution. As air pollutants do not respect borders and travel thousands of kilometres before they are deposited, the problems caused by air pollution must be addressed at international level. The Convention, which entered into force in 1983 and was later annexed to eight Protocols, was the first international instrument with binding legal force in this area. The accession of the Community to the Protocol was approved on behalf of the Community by Council Decision 2001/379/EC of 4 April 2001. The Protocol entered into force in December 2003 and has been transposed into EU law through a number of different acts. The Protocol was amended in December 2012 by Decisions 2012/5 and 2012/6 and 2012/7 respectively. Decision 2012/5 must be ratified by the Parties. The ratification of the amendment will be a significant step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. Parliament has given its consent to this today.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Emissions of heavy metals and persistent organic pollutants affect human health and the environment around us. Effective emission control requires international cooperation. Both protocols list the best available emission reduction techniques and reporting requirements, national emission limits and emission limits for each type of project. The 1979 Heavy Metals Protocol aims to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury in order to reduce respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, as well as losses in biodiversity and agricultural production resulting from heavy metals. The second protocol aims to reduce and eliminate the ejection and emissions of persistent organic pollutants, which includes chemicals such as DDT and pollutants such as dioxins. The amendments to the Metals Protocol, agreed in 2012, introduce stricter limits on dust emissions from certain stationary emission sources, as well as flexible provisions for the entry into force of these changes. The amendments to the Second Protocol, established in 2009, add new substances and supplement the provisions on existing substances. Current EU legislation is in line with these amendments. In view of the fact that the ratification of the amendments by the EU will be a step forward towards their entry into force and will encourage other states parties to the UN Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) to sign them, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this amendment to the Aarhus Protocol on Heavy Metals, as the amended protocol sets out, in particular, stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major stationary sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements that shall benefit those parties that will accede to the amended protocol before the end of 2019. The amendment is fully consistent with existing EU legislation.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This non-legislative report proposes the European Parliament's support for amendments to the protocol on long-range cross-border air pollution with regard to heavy metals. The Convention, which came into force in 1983, created a framework to control and reduce damage to human health and the environment caused by air pollution in cross-border areas.  In 2012, amendments were adopted to set stricter limits on metal dust emissions, and to establish a flexible transitional regime for new parties to the convention, including eastern and south-eastern European countries.  Considering that these amendments are already covered by European legislation under the revised Directive on National Emission Limits (NEC) recently adopted by Parliament and currently being negotiated with the Council, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported the amendment to the protocol to the Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution on Heavy Metals. By controlling emissions of air pollutants such as anthropogenic emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury, we are helping to improve the protection of human health and the environment.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution was an important step forward in protecting health and the human environment, particularly as regards threats from air pollution. Numerous studies have shown that pollutants can reach areas thousands of kilometres away, thus becoming an international problem. Once again, this problem must necessarily be tackled at European level and it is therefore essential to consider the well-being of European society as a whole and not to fall into the defence of national self-interest linked to particular production processes or economic interests in heavy metals. Through these amendments it will be possible to raise the level of protection of human health and reduce the risk of the incidence of dangerous diseases. I am therefore voting in favour of this measure in order to relaunch once again the European Union's commitment to environmental issues.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's Resolution calling on the Council to accept, on behalf of the European Union, the amendment to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Distance Transverse Air Pollution on Heavy Metals. The protocol aims to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of heavy metals transported into the atmosphere, across borders over long distances. It provides that the parties reduce their total annual emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury from 1990 levels (or any other year between 1985 and 1995).  The proposed amendment to the protocol aims to establish stricter emission limits for dust emissions from certain major fixed sources, as well as adaptable transitional provisions that will benefit future parties who adhere to the protocol, as amended, between 1 January 2014 and 31 December 2019.  This amendment should be implemented, notably through a directive setting new national emission limits for certain air pollutants and providing for an inventory of annual national emissions covering, among other things, the emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The objectives of these amendments, relating to the Aarhus Protocol on cross-border heavy metal pollution, are laudable. Nevertheless, they do not contribute anything to the current European legislation. It would be more useful to promote the extension of the protocol to the major industrial powers that have not signed it or have not ratified it. Being opposed to unnecessary normative inflation, I voted against it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague La Via's report as fumes from heavy metals have a very negative effect on the environment. The 1998 Protocol outlines the best available techniques for reducing harmful emissions.  The purpose of this protocol is to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions into the air, which can lead to a high content of cadium and mercury and cause respiratory and heart problems and diseases. The ratification of this Protocol represents a step forward in the fight against pollution.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. The Convention, signed in 1979 and in force since 1983, was the first legally binding international instrument in this area. To date, the scope of the Convention has been extended by eight protocols identifying specific measures to be taken by the Parties to reduce their emissions of air pollutants. In December 2012, the Protocol was amended by Decisions 2012/5, 2012/6 and 2012/7, the latter two on THE EDMs having to be ratified by the Parties. In particular, the amended Protocol sets stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain large fixed sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements which should benefit future Parties to the amended Protocol before the end of 2019, including countries in eastern and south-eastern Europe. Ratification of the amendment will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. I therefore welcome the Council's draft decision.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I consider it not the role of the European Union to ratify amendments to an international treaty.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals aims to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of lead (Pb), cadmium (Cd) and mercury (Hg) into the atmosphere. It requires the Parties to reduce the total annual emissions of the three metals indicated to levels below those recorded in 1990 or in an alternative year between 1985 and 1995. The Protocol aims to reduce emissions from industrial sources (iron and steel industry, non-ferrous metals), combustion processes (industry, electricity production, road transport) and waste incineration.  The Protocol also suggests the inclusion of management measures for other mercury-containing products, including measuring apparatus. In particular, the amended Protocol sets stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain large fixed sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements which should benefit future Parties to the amended Protocol before the end of 2019, including countries in eastern and south-eastern Europe. The amendment to the Protocol is already covered by EU legislation, but should still be transposed through a new directive that will update national emission limit values for certain air pollutants and provide for national inventories of annual emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury, among others. We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ We need to address the problems caused by air pollution globally at international level, as several studies have shown that air pollutants can overcome even a few thousand kilometres before they are established. The 1979 Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution was the first instrument in this area. To date, eight protocols have been annexed to the Convention, the most significant of which was the 1998 Aarhus Protocol, which mainly concerned emissions, lead and mercury into the air. The proposal for a Council Decision is an important step for a higher level of protection of human health and the environment.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the proposal to revise the national emission limits for certain air pollutants.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation as the amendments to the 1998 Heavy Metals Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Trans-Border Air Pollution are a necessary step towards environmental protection, an issue that concerns us all, regardless of political positioning.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Single consent vote. I fully support the amendment to the Aarhus Protocol on Heavy Metals. The amended Protocol sets out, in particular, stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major stationary sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements that will benefit those Parties that accede the amended Protocol before the end of 2019. The amendment is fully consistent with existing EU legislation.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the convention on long-range, cross-border air pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. Between 1972 and 1977, several studies showed that air pollutants travel thousands of kilometres before they are deposited. Therefore, the problems caused by air pollution need to be addressed at international level. The Convention, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, was the first international instrument of binding legal force in this area.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Convention with the desire to protect the human environment from air pollution, as several studies have shown that air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometres before their deposition. It is therefore essential to address this problem at the international level. The amended Protocol sets stricter limit values for particulate emissions from certain large stationary sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the adoption of the amendment to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution on Heavy Metals, as I warmly welcome an increase in environmental and consumer protection in this area.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Studies show that air pollutants can be transported over several thousand kilometres. That is why a European solution is needed here too. With today's vote, we are making an important contribution to protecting people's health in the future.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I fully supported the ratification of this recommendation, which is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. The Aarhus Protocol is an international convention under the aegis of the United Nations. Its aim is to address environmental issues, including cross-border heavy metal pollution. These pollutants have serious effects not only on health but also on biodiversity. For example, migratory birds lose their sense of direction, which explains the rapid decline of their populations on the American and Asian continents. The Member States of the European Union are already signatories to this protocol and apply very strict standards. They are almost the only ones and the major polluting powers do not take this into account.  This recommendation by Parliament does not oblige the Member States in any way. On the other hand, it will enable the Commission to justify future directives to limit polluting emissions, without putting pressure on third countries that are far more polluting than European countries.  On the contrary, every free trade agreement between the EU and third countries, such as the transatlantic treaty, is intended only to increase transport flows and pollution without environmental preconditions.  Member States are already signatories to this protocol and do not need the recommendation that is proposed to us. So I voted against this unnecessary recommendation.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. All Member States are parties to the International Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution and its various protocols.  The two reports before us today concern amendments to these protocols, amendments strengthening the provisions on heavy metals and persistent organic pollutants. They are asking the Council to approve these amendments on behalf of the European Union. I do not understand how the european Union's participation as such in this convention and its aftermath represents any added value. Moreover, EU legislation is largely in line with the proposed new provisions: whether or not the EU is a party to the Convention, it must take due account of the international commitments of its members. The initial mistake was to allow Europe from Brussels, fifteen years ago, to accede to this convention. This was neither necessary nor useful. It would be much more useful in these matters to push the two biggest polluters on the planet, the United States and China, to sign and ratify these provisions as well.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as the inclusion of these amendments implies acceptance of an improvement in heavy metals legislation adopted in international conventions and now transposed into European Union law.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution concerning Heavy Metals, Persistent Organic Pollutants.  Heavy metal pollution is one of the most important threats to human health and the environment. Respiratory or cardiovascular diseases are common in Europe today, and current scientific studies have confirmed the important relationship between concentrations of heavy metals in food or inhaled air and cancer mortality, which is far too fast to become the next civilization disease of our time.  The same factors cause huge losses in agricultural production and biodiversity. I am therefore convinced that increasing the limits on emissions of heavy metals and persistent organic pollutants into the atmosphere, as well as updating the list of harmful metals, will significantly improve the quality of the environment and allow for the reconstruction and development of agriculture, thereby positively impacting the health and life of Europeans.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the amendment, as it is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the EU’s ratification of an update to the international agreement on controlling transboundary air pollution, specifically concerning heavy metal emissions, because these amendments will contribute to a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The two amendments to the 1979 Conventions are the acceptance of the procedural amendments that upgrade these Conventions and which have already been adopted at international level and now need to be transposed into the EU legal framework.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution on Heavy Metals because they seek to update the sufficiency and effectiveness of transboundary air pollution. More importantly, the Protocol aims to cut emissions from industrial sources (iron and steel industry, non-ferrous metal industry), combustion processes (power generation, road transport), and waste incineration. It sets limit values for emissions from specific major stationary sources and requires the use of best available techniques (BAT). Parties must also develop and maintain emission inventories for Pb, Cd and Hg, phase out leaded petrol, and reduce Hg concentration levels in alkaline batteries, all of which will benefit the health of EU citizens and the environment. The amended Protocol sets out, in particular, stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major stationary sources, as well as transitional arrangements for acceding countries. The amendments are fully consistent with existing EU legislation and will be further transposed via the ongoing revision of the National Emission Ceilings Directive. The ratification of the amendments will contribute to a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The 1998 protocol on Heavy Metals, which aims to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions into the air of lead, cadmium and mercury, was amended in 2012 with stricter emission limit values for dust emissions from some major stationary sources and flexible  transitional arrangements. The POPs Protocol, which aims to control, reduce or  eliminate discharges, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants, was amended in 2009, when new substances were added to its scope and provisions for existing substances  were updated. While EU legislation is already in place to cover these amendments, the ratification by the EU is important for their entry into force and to give a signal to other UNECE signatories. Given the widespread impact of these substances on human health and on biodiversity and the need for international collaboration on this particular topic, I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this report, because the Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution protects the human environment from air pollution. The Heavy Metals Protocol aims to reduce and control anthropogenic lead emissions into the atmosphere.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision to accept amendments to the 1998 Heavy Metals Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution, as this gives consent for the acceptance of amendments to the Protocol. Reducing and controlling anthropogenic emissions of lead, kadmi and mercury can largely help improve air quality and, accordingly, reduce the adverse impact they have on the environment and human health.  In this context, it is necessary to reduce emissions from industrial sources, in the incineration of waste and during the combustion process. Therefore, I believe that a coordinated approach at international level is needed, and I believe that the ratification of the amendments in question will improve the level of protection and strengthen EU legislation in the area concerned.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I do not think it makes sense to support the amendment on heavy metal pollution. I note that, with the exception of Malta, the EU Member States are already signatories to the Aarhus Protocol on this subject.  The commission's recommendation does not bring added value or legal significance. It seems to me more useful for the EU to get closer to the major industrial powers in order to invite them to join this protocol under the leadership of the United Nations. Therefore I vote against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Giovanni La Via's recommendation on the recommendation on long-range cross-border air pollution for heavy metals. The Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution has created a framework to reduce pollution damage to health and the environment. The heavy metals protocol aims to reduce emissions of these metals into the atmosphere. I therefore approved the Council's decision to ratify this protocol and its amendments.  This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. ‒ The Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution (signed 1979, entering into force 1983) is intended to protect the human environment against air pollution. The Convention was the first international legally binding instrument in this area. To date, the Convention has been extended by eight protocols, which identify specific measures to reduce their air pollutant emissions. The Aarhus Protocol on Heavy Metals is one of these amending protocols. It aims to cut emissions from industrial sources (iron and steel industry, non-ferrous metal industry), combustion processes (power generation, road transport), and waste incineration.  The accession of the EU to the Protocol was approved on behalf of the Community by Council Decision 2001/379/EC of 04/04/2001. The Protocol, which entered into force on 29/12/2003, has been transposed into EU law through several instruments. The Protocol put to the vote today sets out stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major stationary sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements that will benefit those Parties that accede to the amended Protocol before the end of 2019.  In view of this positive amended protocol, which not only tightens up values for dust emissions but also reaffirms that waste incineration plants damage human health and the environment, EH Bildu has voted in favour of this La Via Report.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation from the European Parliament on the Convention on Cross-Border Air Pollution and more specifically on amendments to its Heavy Metals Protocol.  The adoption of these amendments will add a number of types of heavy metals to the list of affected products, thereby strengthening the fight against air pollution.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report deals with the adoption of a supplementary protocol on an international agreement to which the Member States and the EU have already acceded. I am abstaining on this report.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I support the amendments proposed for the 1998 Protocol. Particularly important amendments include the more flexible arrangements to be allowed for Parties that adopt the amended Protocol before 2020, which will encourage a swifter widespread implementation of it. Stricter restrictions on dust emissions from particular dominant stationary sources would also be an important step in preventing air pollution across the borders. Transboundary air pollution significantly affects countries across Europe – in recent years Ireland has fallen below the World Health Organisation guidelines on air pollution, with airflow coming from the Sahara desert to Ireland and polluting our air with dust. I agree with the rapporteur that the proposed amendments, if ratified, would be a triumph for each EU country’s environmental protection and public health levels.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the amendment, as it is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. – The UNECE Convention on Transfrontier Air Pollution aims to limit and prevent air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment. The Aarhus Protocol (1998) and its subsequent amendments further broadened the scope of the Convention; it has the function of reducing and controlling emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury into the atmosphere. I would like to stress that the Council's decisions on the amendment of the Protocol are closely linked to bat (Best Available Techniques). In this respect, there is an obligation on the part of companies to apply the best available techniques in order to reduce emissions into air, water, soil, as well as waste production. EU legislation already covers almost all legislative instruments relating to matters covered by the Aarhus Protocol and its subsequent amendments, which we are debating today. I have therefore called on my fellow Members to give their consent to the Council's decision, in order to officially adopt the amendments to the protocol on behalf of the Union.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. Heavy metals are poisons for man and nature. Their health effects are no longer to be mentioned. The objectives of the amendments are in full compliance with EU legislation. However, since the Member States are already signatories, it does not seem to me to be necessary for the EU to ratify these amendments. On the other hand, it could be recommended that certain major industrial powers, such as the United States or China, be invited to sign and/or ratify the Aarhus Protocol.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it does not bring anything new to the fight against cross-border heavy metal pollution. On the other hand, and above all, the Member States are already parties to the protocol concerned.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The protocol in question relates to long-distance cross-border pollution. These amendments are intended to set limits on the emission limits of dust containing heavy metals or persistent organic pollutants (POPs). The effects of these pollutants and POPs are disastrous for human health, but also for flora and fauna. The migratory bird population has been drastically reduced due to these toxic pollutants.  Nevertheless, European states are already signatories to this undying protocol. The EU therefore has no need to ratify these amendments, and should instead consider inviting industrial powers outside the European Union (United States, China) to sign this treaty. In order to make this point, and this vote being superfluous, I voted against this text.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I was delayed. I believe in the need to protect the air from toxic emissions. However, there is already agreement between the Member States in the Council and individual countries can set their own emission limits. It is therefore not necessary to have another directive to do so.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported Representative Giovanni La Via's recommendation to protect human health and ecosystems from the harmful effects of air pollution. These problems must be addressed internationally, as air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometres before deposition. The Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution is the first international legally binding instrument in this area. It was signed in 1979, entered into force in 1983 and is intended to protect the environment from air pollution. To date, the Convention has been expanded with eight protocols identifying concrete measures to be taken by the parties to reduce their emissions of pollutants. The amendment to the 1998 Protocol is largely covered by EU legislation and will set national emission ceilings for substances through the new directive.  The amended Protocol sets stricter emission limits for certain substances and will carry out an annual national inventory including emissions for individual atmospheric pollutants, covering, inter alia, POP-owl emissions, including PAH, PCDD/PCDF, HCB and PCB.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution, which entered into force in 1983, became the first international agreement of its kind. In particular, the 1998 Aarhus Protocol noted in particular the need to reduce and more closely control levels of lead, cadmium and mercury. Today's vote focused on adopting the amendments in 2012, which set stricter emission limit values for dust emissions from certain major stationary sources. This also applies to flexible transitional measures which will to some extent assist the Parties to accede to the amended Protocol by the end of 2019, including the countries of Eastern and South-Eastern Europe. The new amendments also provide, by the way, for an annual national emissions report, which will allow for more effective control of ejp levels in each country. It should be noted, however, that, while the adoption of these amendments is undoubtedly an important step, it is absolutely necessary that as many countries as possible not only join in the practice of implementing these principles, but also in the fairest possible manner. Otherwise, there will be no real positive environmental impact.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Economic development negatively affects the state of the air. This is an international problem, the effective solution of which requires the active involvement of all the countries of the world. The decision to adopt amendments to the 1998 Heavy Metals Protocol, which has been transposed into EU law by a number of acts, tightens the limits on dust emissions from large stationary sources, in line with already adopted EU legislation. I believe that ratification of the decision and its application will contribute to effective air protection.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision accepting the amendment to the 1998 Heavy Metals Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. These are amendments to set the limits on the emission limits of dust containing heavy metals. This protocol is under the aegis of the UN, and EU member states, and the EU as an organisation, are signatories. The negative health effects of heavy metals are no longer to be explained, which is why it is important to deal with them. However, we oppose this text because the Member States have already signed these amendments, so we do not think it is necessary for the EU to ratify them in turn.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ The Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution is intended to protect the human environment against air pollution. Several studies performed between 1972 and 1977 had shown that air pollutants could travel several thousand kilometres before deposition. Problems caused by air pollution therefore need to be addressed on the international level. Signed in 1979 and entering into force in 1983, the Convention was the first international legally binding instrument in this area. It has created the framework for controlling and reducing the damage to human health and to the environment caused by transboundary air pollution. The Convention identifies the Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) as its secretariat.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision accepting the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution of Heavy Metals. The 1979 Convention on Transfrontier Air Pollution is one of the first legally binding international instruments with the aim of limiting, gradually reducing and preventing air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment. This Convention on Air Pollution was extended by eight protocols, including the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals. By ratifying the amendments to this protocol, it will be possible to ensure greater protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it intends to transpose into the framework of European legislation the acceptance of the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution, on Heavy Metals, which has already been previously agreed by the parties at international level. Ratification of the amendment will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to accept the changes set out in the last Protocol on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution in Heavy Metals. As the rapporteur points out, it is a question of establishing stricter limit values for particulate emissions from certain large stationary sources, which is entirely consistent with existing EU legislation in this area. We will therefore be taking a step further towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This is a proposal to adopt a supplementary protocol to an international agreement to which the Member States and the EU have already acceded and are already taking into account. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which supports amendments to the Convention on The Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution. I believe that these amendments will control and reduce the damage to human health and the environment caused by transboundary air pollution. The amended Protocol to the Convention lays down, in particular, stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major stationary sources and a more flexible transitional arrangements in the interest of Parties wishing to accede to the Protocol as amended by the end of 2019, including the countries of Eastern and South-Eastern Europe. The ratification of this amendment will be an important step towards ensuring a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against transboundary air pollution.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 showed that air pollutants could be transported several thousand kilometres before being precipitated.  The Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, and was the first legally binding international instrument in this area.  To date, the convention has been expanded through eight protocols specifically identifying the measures to be taken by the parties to reduce their air pollutant emissions. The report proposes that the Council approve, on behalf of the European Union, an amendment to the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on persistent organic pollutants.  This amendment sets stricter emission limits for dust emissions from certain major fixed sources. I vote for this text and I hope that it will be quickly opposed to the criminal emissions of lignite in Germany.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I do not think it makes sense to support the amendment on heavy metal pollution. I note that, with the exception of Malta, the EU Member States are already signatories to the Aarhus Protocol on this subject.  The commission's recommendation does not bring added value or legal significance. It seems to me more useful for the EU to get closer to the major industrial powers in order to invite them to join this protocol under the leadership of the United Nations. Therefore I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council decision on the acceptance of the amendment to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution on Heavy Metals. Given that several studies have shown that air pollutants can travel thousands of kilometres before deposition, it is important to address the problems caused by air pollution at international level. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals aims to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury into the atmosphere. This Protocol entered into force on 29 December 2003 and was transposed into EU law through various instruments. A new EU directive needs to be able to update the national emission limit values for certain air pollutants.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of ratifying the amendment because I believe it is important to take a proactive role concerning the health of our environment. Specifically, this amendment aims to limit dust emissions from fixed sources, and to lower transboundary air pollution.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution for Heavy Metals aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. So-called pollution can be characterized by the emission of heavy metals such as lead (Pb), cadmium (Cd) and mercury (Hg) into the atmosphere. The aim of the protocol is therefore to reduce emissions from industrial origin, from combustion or from the incineration of waste.  However, given the environmental problems that these heavy metals may cause, it is appropriate (as the amendments made) to reduce on the one hand the mercury contained in alkaline batteries and in measuring devices and on the other hand to maintain an updated national inventory on Pb, CD and Hg emissions.  The ratification of the amendments is an essential step towards a high level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – Air pollution is an unpleasant and dangerous phenomenon because it is not visible to the free eye and its extent cannot be determined immediately after the pollution has occurred. At the same time, pollution can spread through the air hundreds, even thousands of kilometres, and can have a negative impact on human health. For these reasons, it is important and appropriate that environmental legislation in the field of air pollution be continuously improved. In the present proposal, I welcome the linking of the revised Aarhus Protocol to a new directive setting updated emission ceilings for specific substances that threaten clean air. I also see the prioritising of the best technologies that have been developed to date from an economic and technical point of view, the so.BAT, as an inseparable condition for any new legislation relating to environmental protection. For these reasons, I also support the motion for a resolution.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my full support to the Report on amending the Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution on Heavy Metals. The amended Protocol sets out, in particular, stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major stationary sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements that will benefit those Parties that accede to the amended Protocol before the end of 2019.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, established a framework for monitoring and reducing the harmful effects of cross-border air pollution on human health and the environment. One of the two Aarhus Protocols of 1998 supplementing the Convention aims at reducing and controlling emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury into the air of human origin. The accession of the Community to the Protocol was approved by Council Decision 2001/379/EC of 4 April 2001. The Protocol entered into force on 29 December 2003. The Protocol was amended by three Decisions of the Parties in December 2012. Of these, Decision 2012/5 introducing more stringent limits for dust emissions from significant fixed sources and introducing transitional measures favourable to the Parties which acceded to the amended Protocol before the end of 2019 should be ratified by the Parties. The draft decision submitted by the Council proposes this. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety notes in its report that the amendment is fully in line with existing EU legislation and therefore recommends that Parliament give its consent to the draft decision. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This report proposes to set limits on the emission of dust containing heavy metals or persistent organic pollutants. The Aarhus Protocol is under the aegis of the United Nations, the signatory parties are essentially European states as well as the European Union.  These heavy metals are real poisons for man and nature. For example, nearly half of migratory birds have already disappeared due to the effects of POPs on direction. The health effects of heavy metals are known. The objectives of the amendments are in full compliance with EU legislation.  However, since the Member States are already signatories, we do not think it is necessary for the EU to ratify them. On the other hand, it could be recommended to approach the major industrial powers to invite them to sign and/or ratify the Aarhus Protocol, notably the United States or China, which have not ratified them.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution, signed in 1979 and in force since 1983, was the first legally binding international instrument on the protection of the human environment from air pollution. This Convention has created the framework for controlling and reducing damage to human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution.  The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals aims to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury into the atmosphere. This Protocol was amended by Decisions 2012/5, 2012/6 and 2012/7. The amendment to the Protocol is already covered by EU legislation, but should still be transposed by means of a new Directive which will update the national emission limit values for certain air pollutants and provide for national inventories of annual emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury, among others. I believe that ratification will make it possible to protect human health and the environment more and more against cross-border air pollution.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. As Member States are already signatories to this text, it does not seem necessary for the EU to ratify these amendments. On the other hand, it might be interesting to approach the major industrial powers of third countries to invite them to sign and/or ratify the Aarhus Protocol as the United States (not ratified) or China (neither).

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I approved this text which authorises the EU's ratification of amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Cross-Border Air Pollution on Heavy Metals. These amendments are in full coherence with current EU legislation. Their ratification will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The report on long-range cross-border air pollution on heavy metals follows international agreements in compliance with and consistency of EU legislation. Their ratification is an important step towards better protection of health and the environment, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The UNECE Convention on Transfrontier Air Pollution aims to limit and prevent air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment. The Aarhus Protocol and its subsequent amendments have further broadened the scope of the Convention by reducing and controlling emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury into the atmosphere. I have chosen to vote in favour of the Council's decision because I consider it to be a decisive step towards increasing the protection of public health and the environment against possible pollution damage.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The 1979 Convention on long-range transboundary air pollution has as its purpose the protection of the human environment from air pollution. I have voted for this recommendation that will set out stricter limit values for dust emission from certain major stationary sources.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This is a supplemental protocol to an international agreement to which the Member States and the European Union have already acceded. I would have abstained from voting.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Ratification of the Protocol is essential to better protect human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution. The Protocol lays down stricter limits for dust emissions from certain major stationary sources and for more flexible transitional arrangements.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution was already being studied in 1972. Several studies showed that atmospheric pollution could be transported thousands of kilometres before settling, which highlighted the need to tackle this problem internationally. For heavy metals, the Aarhus Protocol was established with the aim of reducing and controlling anthropogenic emissions. In this regard, a convention was established to monitor, through a monitoring programme and a transport evaluation programme. Over the years, the Convention has been extended by defining specific measures to be taken by the parties to reduce emissions of air pollution. As a member of the ENVI Parliamentary Committee and as a sensitive member of environmental issues, I am voting in favour of ratification of this convention, which will certainly be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Long-range transport of air pollution has been recognized as an important factor affecting ecosystems and the human population. The heavy metals cadmium, lead and mercury are common air pollutants, being emitted mainly as a result of various industrial activities. The amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution. I therefore welcome the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the acceptance of the amendments.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. – I supported the ratification of the amendments to the 1998 Protocol on heavy metals to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Air Pollution across Borders, because this document confirms member states' commitments and gives them enhanced responsibilities in their efforts towards cleaner air. The convention under consideration is the first agreement of an international nature on the prevention of the negative effects of heavy metals on air and provides a framework for further limiting the use of cadmium, mercury and lead.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposed amendment to the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Heavy Metals to the Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution intended to protect the environment from air pollution.  In its acquis, the European Union already has this area governed by the Ambient Air Quality and Cleaner Air Directive for Europe and the Directive concerning arsenic, kadmium, mercury, nickel and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in the external air and together with the Industrial Emissions Directive and a package of other related regulations constitutes a coherent package that strictly monitors environmental pollution by heavy metals in the European Union.  I am pleased that conventions and protocols as mechanisms of international law follow EU policy and allow further progress in the fight for a cleaner and healthier planet globally. The adoption of amendments to the Protocol is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. In this context, I welcome once again this just adopted legislative resolution.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Heavy metals and POPs are poisons for man and nature. This has been proven by multiple studies. The objectives of the amendments are in full compliance with EU legislation. However, Member States are already signatories to the protocol and the fact that the EU ratifies them therefore has no added value.  It would be more effective to stop negotiating TTIP with the United States, which signed it without ratifying this protocol, and to refuse to go further in our trade relations with China, which has not even signed it. As is often the case, the EU is re-fighting symbols but continuing to take concrete and harmful actions. I therefore vote against this text, which cannot have any real effect on anything.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposed amendments to the 1998 Heavy Metals Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution. The Convention and the Protocol set a good example of increasingly close joint cooperation between states in solving problems that are by their nature cross-border and require transnational solutions.  The amendment itself is largely already covered by EU legislation and aims to ensure stricter limits for certain emissions and more flexible transitional conditions for those who will accept this amendment by the end of 2019. Croatia ratified the Protocol on Heavy Metals back in 2007 and has since adopted all key regulations in accordance with Union regulations setting limits for emissions of pollutants into the air from stationary sources, the quality of liquid petroleum fuels, air quality, waste battery and battery management and chemical management.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals aims to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of lead (Pb), cadmium (Cd) and mercury (Hg) into the atmosphere. It requires the Parties to reduce the total annual emissions of those metals to levels below those recorded in 1990 or in an alternative year between 1985 and 1995. The Protocol aims to reduce emissions from industrial sources, combustion processes and waste incineration. The Protocol also suggests the inclusion of management measures for other mercury-containing products. The amendment to the Protocol, already covered by EU legislation, should also be transposed through a new Directive updating national emission limit values for certain air pollutants, providing for national inventories of annual emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury, among others. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I support fellow MEP Giovanni La Via's recommendation on the Council's draft decision to accept amendments to the 1998 Heavy Metals Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution. The convention, which is the first legally binding in this area, was signed in 1979, entered into force in 1983 and is intended to protect the environment from air pollution.  Problems caused by air pollution must be addressed internationally, as air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometres before deposition. The amendment to the 1998 protocol is already largely covered by EU laws and will be further transposed through a new directive that will set updated national emission ceilings for certain pollutant things in the atmosphere and provide annual national emissions lists that should include, inter alia, lead, kadmium and mercury emissions.  Ratification of the amendment to the Protocol will be a very important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from cross-border atmospheric pollution.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of amending the Protocol on Heavy Metals of 1998 to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Air Pollution crossing national borders, because there is a serious danger in the form of hazardous air pollutants that can carry up to several thousand kilometres before being stored. This has been confirmed by several studies and once again supports the thesis that we must combat pollution at global level. If we do not start tinging this problem as soon as possible, we will soon have very serious consequences. As the amendment is fully in line with existing EU legislation, I find no reason not to support it. Ratification of the change will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution was created to protect the environment and public health. Signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, the Convention was the first legally binding international instrument adopted in this field. It establishes a framework for the control and reduction of damage caused by cross-border air pollution, human health and the environment. Over the years, the Convention has been extended by eight protocols defining specific measures to be taken by the Parties to reduce emissions of air pollutants. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals aims to reduce emissions from industrial sources, combustion processes and waste incineration. I voted in favour of all this. As the Union has already adopted legislative instruments on matters covered by the Aarhus Protocol, these amendments must now be officially adopted on behalf of the Union. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of adopting this recommendation.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Emissions of heavy metals and persistent organic pollutants affect human health and the environment. These substances do not respect national borders and therefore effective control of their emissions requires international cooperation. Two 1998 protocols list best available techniques (BAT) for emission reductions and reporting requirements, national emission limits and emission limits for each type of project. In other words, they establish tools to enable emission reductions and track progress.  The Heavy Metals Protocol aims to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury in order to reduce respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, as well as losses in biodiversity and agricultural production resulting from the impact of heavy metals. In view of the importance of the provisions for citizens' health, I supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Cross-border heavy metal pollution is a phenomenon that we must take with great consideration. This report has the advantage of developing a much broader and more extensive protection for the environment and the health of our citizens in this area. That is why I voted in favour of him.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. Several studies carried out between 1972 and 1977 have shown that air pollutants can travel many thousands of kilometres before their deposition. It is therefore necessary to address the problems caused by air pollution at international level.   This report approves the amendment of the Protocol on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution on heavy metals under the Convention signed in 1979. This has now been extended by eight protocols identifying specific measures to be taken by the Parties involved to reduce their emissions of air pollutants. It sets, inter alia, stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain large fixed sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements which should benefit future Parties to the amended Protocol before the end of 2019, including the countries of eastern and south-eastern Europe.  For all this, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. In Europe, air pollution is responsible for almost half a million premature deaths each year, so Parliament has rightly updated its legislation on long-distance cross-border air pollution enshrined in a Convention of the same name. This includes reducing and controlling heavy metal emissions, which pose a hazard to significant or prolonged exposure that can cause disease and accelerated aging. Naturally present in our environment and used industrially, heavy metals are emitted into the air in the form of very fine particles and eventually fall back to the ground, contaminating the animals and plants we consume, eventually accumulating in our tissues.  Cadmium, found in pesticides and TV screens, causes thousands of kidney cancers. Lead, emitted by the metallurgical sector and causing psychological disturbances, including lead poisoning. Mercury, also derived from electricity generation and which is part of the composition of dental fillings, is considered by the WHO to be one of the ten chemicals of great public health concern.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation to revise the Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution related to heavy metals, as I have done with regard to persistent organic pollutants. This Convention is important in that it aims to reduce the risks to human health and the environment caused by cross-border air pollution. Since its adoption in 1979, this text has been amended and extended through eight protocols. The one we are amending here is the reduction and control of anthropogenic emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury, which are dangerous heavy metals transported by the atmosphere over very long distances. The proposed changes set stricter limits for dust emissions from large fixed sources and provide transitional provisions for future parties to join the protocol by the end of 2019, including Central and South-Eastern European countries. The proposed elements are in line with current EU legislation or will be consistent with the revision of the Directive on national emission caps for certain air pollutants, and should take a new step in the protection of human health and the environment.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval to the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution in Heavy Metals. Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 had shown that air pollutants could travel several thousand kilometres before depositing, so problems arising from air pollution on an international scale need to be addressed. The Convention, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, was the first legally binding international instrument in this area and has been expanded with eight protocols establishing specific measures, including heavy metals. This amended Protocol sets stricter limit values for particulate emissions from certain large stationary sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements that will benefit Parties that accede to the amended Protocol by the end of 2019, including eastern and south-eastern European countries. The ratification of the amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 have shown that air pollutants can be transported several thousand kilometres before being precipitated. The problems caused by air pollution at the international level must therefore be addressed. This convention established the framework for controlling and reducing the damage to human health and the environment caused by cross-border air pollution. To date, the convention has been expanded through eight protocols specifically identifying the measures to be taken by the parties to reduce their air pollutant emissions.
