In December 2012, the protocol was amended by the 2012/5, 2012/6 and 2012/7 decisions. The 2012/5 decision still needed to be ratified by the parties, as the amended protocol in particular establishes stricter emission limits for dust emissions from certain major fixed sources, as well as flexible transitional provisions that will benefit future parties to join the protocol, as amended, by the end of 2019, including the countries of Eastern and South-Eastern Europe. Parliament approved this recommendation today.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it endorses the European Parliament in 1979. Amendments to the 1998 Protocol on Heavy Metals to the Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution. The Convention on Long-range transboundary air pollution aims to protect human health and the environment from air pollution. All the more so because the consequences of air pollution are not local – pollution is constantly travelling by the wind. To date, the Convention has been supplemented by eight protocols, which include: a european monitoring and evaluation scheme for monitoring and evaluation actions, sulphur emissions, nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds, cross-border pollutant flows, heavy metals and persistent organic pollutants, specific national emission ceilings and reduction targets for different substances. The protocols set stricter emission limit values, as well as management measures, and encourages a gradual change in production to prevent the use of environmentally harmful substances such as mercury.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of this proposal for a recommendation which aims to amend the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution on Heavy Metals. This Convention was the first legally binding international instrument to create the framework for monitoring and minimising data for health and the environment from air pollution. Meanwhile, the scope of the Convention has been extended by a set of eight protocols identifying specific measures to be taken by the parties to reduce emissions of air pollutants.  The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals was revised and amended by Decisions 2012/5, 2012/6 and 2012/7. The review, which is based on these decisions, sets, inter alia, stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain fixed sources, as well as other provisions that should benefit future parties to the amended protocol before the end of 2019, including countries in eastern and southwestern Europe. The amendment in question is fully in line with existing European legislation and will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the approval of the amendment to the 1998 protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution for Heavy Metals.  The 1979 Convention on Cross-Border Air Pollution came into force in 1983 and is the first legally binding international instrument to protect the human environment from air pollution.  In 2001, the EU adhered to the 1998 Protocol, which aims to reduce and control emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury into the atmosphere.  In December 2012, this protocol was amended to establish stricter emission limits for dust emissions from certain major fixed sources.  The limits set by this amendment to the 1998 protocol are already largely foreseen by current European legislation. The ratification of these amendments by the EU represents a step towards a higher level of protection of the environment and the health of European citizens against air pollution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as the inclusion of these amendments implies acceptance of an improvement in heavy metals legislation adopted in international conventions and now transposed into European Union law.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. \u2012 The approval of the amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. That is why I support the changes.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the revised convention because it is important to always adjust the limit values. This will create a higher level of cross-border health protection. It is crucial that south-eastern Europe is now included in this convention. In addition to the existing NEC Directive, the revision was a logical step.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report deals with the acceptance of procedural amendments updating the scope of international conventions already approved by the parties at international level and which are now incorporated into the framework of EU legislation. I voted in favour because I believe that the ratification of the amendments is a step forward towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from long-range cross-border air pollution caused by heavy metals.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, Parliament transposes into EU legislation the amendments to the 1998 Aarhus Protocol to the Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution concerning Lead, Cadmium and Mercury. The Convention, signed in 1979, establishes a framework for the control and reduction of damage caused by transfrontier air pollution to human health and the environment. The amendments to the 1998 Protocol set stricter limit values for dust emissions from industrial sources, combustion processes and waste incineration. I voted in favour of the recommendation because the ratification of these amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the amendment on heavy metals to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution, because I see it as an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ the Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution is intended to ensure the protection of the human environment against air pollution. I support the development and conduct of emission inventories for Pb, Cd and Hg and the reduction of Hg concentration levels in alkaline batteries. It was also necessary to introduce measures for the handling of other products containing Hg, including measuring instruments. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ In 1979, a convention was concluded on far-reaching cross-border air pollution with the aim of limiting and preventing air pollution in order to prevent negative consequences on people and the environment. It was already proven that air pollutants can pass up to several thousand kilometers before deposition. In 1998, the convention was extended to the Protocol on Heavy Metals and the Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants.  The Heavy Metals Protocol obliges signatory states to monitor lead, kadmium and mercury emissions, eliminate leaded petrol and reduce mercury levels in alkaline batteries. The protocol on persistent organic pollutants enables the reduction or elimination of persistent pollutants and the regulation of pesticides, polychlorinated binephiles (PCBs), dioxins, furanes and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. The amendment to the heavy metals protocol explicitly imposes stricter emission limits for dust (particles dispersed in the gaseous phase) and monitoring the value of lead, kadmium and mercury emissions on an annual basis. I supported the European Parliament's resolution amending the Heavy Metals Protocol. I therefore also supported the amendment of the Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants, as it reports annual emissions of polychlorinated binephiles (PCBs), which confirms that emissions are lower than the reference year and create new limits for dioxins and furans.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: In writing ‒ the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals aims to reduce and control discharges into the air of anthropogenic emissions such as lead, cadmium and mercury. It requires the Contracting Parties to reduce their total annual emissions of the three metals below their 1990 levels or below any of the 1985 to 1995 levels. The Protocol aims at reducing emissions from industrial sources, combustion processes and waste incineration. It sets limit values for emissions from certain large stationary sources and requires the use of best available techniques. The Contracting Parties shall also draw up and maintain emission inventors for lead, cadmium and mercury, phase out leaded petrol and reduce lead concentration levels in alkaline batteries. The Protocol proposes the introduction of measures for the management of other lead-containing products, including measuring instruments.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ Given the nature of this theme, there is a need to strengthen consistency and certainty under the Convention and to set stricter emission ceilings for certain air pollutants as well as annual national emission inventories.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒the Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution is intended to protect the environment from air pollution. Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 have shown that air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometers before deposition. Therefore, problems caused by air pollution should be addressed internationally. The Convention is the first international legally binding instrument in this field.  The Convention has created a framework to control and reduce the adverse impact on health and the environment caused by cross-border air pollution. The amendment to the Protocol is already largely covered by EU legislation, but the new directive will establish updated caps on the values for national emissions for certain atmospheric pollutants and provide conditions for annual national emissions inventory covering, lead, kadmium and mercury emissions.  As stated, the amendment is fully in line with existing EU legislation and the ratification of the amendments will be a step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ My Labour colleagues and I support the ratification of the amendment, which is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision adopting an amendment to the 1998 Protocol on heavy metals to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Air Pollution across borders. A lot of ink has already been spilled on air pollution, and many studies have already been carried out.  I support the changes to the protocol that have resulted from a review of adequacy and effectiveness by the contracting partners. The amended Protocol brings stricter limit values for dust emissions from some major stationary sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution aims to protect the environment from air pollution. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals aims to reduce and control emissions into the atmosphere. It requires the Contracting Parties to reduce their total annual emissions for these three metals. The amended Protocol lays down in particular stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain main fixed sources, as well as flexible transitional arrangements applicable to the benefit of the Contracting Parties to join the amended Protocol before the end of 2019. The ratification of the amendment will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1998 Protocol, as well as its subsequent amendments and additions, namely those relating to obsessive organic pollutants, are a necessary step in the protection of the environment.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The ratification of the amendments to the Recommendation represents a significant step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. Citing several studies (1972-1977), the justification points out that air pollutants can travel thousands of kilometres before they are deposited. I agree that the problems caused by air pollution must be addressed at international level. In the form of an agreement, an international instrument of binding legal force came into force in 1983, creating a framework for monitoring and reducing adverse effects. The further Protocol on heavy metals of 1998 aims at reducing and controlling emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury into the air of human origin. It requires the Parties to reduce their annual aggregate emissions below 1990 levels. The purpose of the Protocol is to reduce emissions from industrial sources (iron, steel and non-ferrous metals), combustion processes (energy production, road transport) and incineration. The Protocol establishes limit values and provides for the use of best available techniques. The Parties shall produce and maintain a cadastre of emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury, eliminate the use of leaded petrol and reduce the amount of mercury in alkaline batteries. The amendments are fully in line with existing EU legislation, which is why I supported the recommendation.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution aims to protect the environment and human life. Research indicates that air pollutants can travel up to several thousand kilometres before they fall to the ground, which is why these issues need to be addressed at international level.  Signed in 1979, the Convention was the first legally binding international instrument in this field. It has created a framework for controlling and reducing damage to human health and the environment caused by cross-border air pollution. However, almost 40 years after its signature, it is necessary to adapt to both economic and, above all, environmental changes.  The last amendment to the 1998 Protocol, agreed in 2012, is the first to cover both many pollutants and their multiple effects and contains specific national emission ceilings and emission reduction commitments for various pollutants. These actions should contribute to the protection of health and the environment.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of approving Decision 2012/5 amending the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals. We recognize that this protocol has made a substantial contribution to the elimination of three harmful metals such as lead, cadmium and mercury. It has severely limited emissions to the atmosphere from industry, energy production, transport and waste incineration, thanks to the use of Best Available Technologies and the reduction of leaded petrol and mercury present in alkaline batteries and measuring instruments. We believe that the adaptation of the protocol made by the amendment can strengthen its action and effectiveness. In particular, stricter limits are imposed on dust emissions from certain major fixed sources and new parts are encouraged to be accession to the amended protocol by 2019, especially in Eastern and South-Eastern Europe. We hope that the parties will ratify Decision 2012/5 as soon as possible and commit themselves to promoting the technological improvement necessary to protect the health of citizens and the environment from cross-border air pollution. We will also ensure that adaptation to the Protocol, both in Eastern and Western Europe, is accompanied by transitional measures for industrial and energy production, transport and waste incineration towards greater sustainability.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text and its amendments. The Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 have shown that air pollutants can be transported several thousand kilometres before being precipitated. The problems caused by air pollution at the international level must therefore be addressed. Signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, the Convention was the first legally binding international instrument in this area. It has established the framework to control and reduce the damage to human health and the environment caused by cross-border air pollution. It provides that the Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe will provide its secretariat. The Convention is implemented and monitored through the concerted programme to monitor and assess the long-distance transport of air pollutants in Europe.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on long-range transboundary air pollution on heavy metals. The Convention aims at reducing air pollutant emissions and was amended by eight protocols. The 1998 Protocol on Heavy Metals has an implication for the steel and non-ferrous metal industries. The EU legislation is already fully compliant with the amendments to the 1998 Protocol which, in particular, set stricter values for dust emissions and foresee transitional arrangements.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I supported the amendment of the Heavy Metals Protocol to the Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution. In fact, studies have shown that air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometers before deposition, and I believe that the problem caused by air pollution should be solved internationally.  Increased emissions of heavy metals into the atmosphere have a detrimental effect on human health, wildlife, and some metals have been proven or suspected of being carcinogenic. I believe that the amendment to the Heavy Metals Protocol will establish stricter limits on dust emissions from large stationary sources, reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of lead, kadmi and mercury in the air, and reduce emissions from industrial sources in waste combustion and incineration processes. In my view, this is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health against cross-border air pollution.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the recommendation on the draft Council Decision adopting an amendment to the 1998 Protocol on heavy metals to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Air Pollution across borders, as I believe that it represents an important step towards a greater level of protection of the environment and air in the Union.  Air pollutants can travel more than 1000 km before they settle, so we need to tackle the issue in a coordinated manner internationally. The new directive, which sets updated national emission ceilings for certain air pollutants and allows the introduction of annual national emission inventories, will thus further upgrade the existing protocol, unify emissions in all Member States and, consequently, have an impact on a better quality of life for EU residents.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as the inclusion of these amendments implies acceptance of an improvement in heavy metals legislation adopted in international conventions and now transposed into European Union law.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this convention. The Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution is intended to protect the human environment against air pollution. Several studies performed between 1972 and 1977 had shown that air pollutants could travel several thousand kilometres before deposition. Problems caused by air pollution therefore need to be addressed on the international level. Signed in 1979 and entering into force in 1983, the Convention was the first international legally binding instrument in this area. It has created the framework for controlling and reducing the damage to human health and to the environment caused by transboundary air pollution. The EU should play its full role in this sense and I support this fully.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Aarhus Protocol covers long-distance cross-border pollution. It is under the aegis of the United Nations, the signatory parties are essentially European states as well as the European Union. Not all EU states are at the same stage of engagement. Only Malta has neither signed nor ratified it.  Heavy metals and POPs are real poisons for man and nature. The objectives of the amendments are in full compliance with EU legislation. However, since the Member States are already signatories, we do not think it is necessary for the EU to ratify these amendments. On the other hand, it could be recommended to approach the major industrial powers third countries to invite them to sign and/or ratify the Aarhus Protocol as the United States (which has not ratified) or China (neither). I voted against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution is to protect the human environment from air pollution. Between 1972 and 1977, several studies showed that air pollutants travel thousands of kilometres before they are deposited. The Convention, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, was the first international instrument of binding legal force in this area. Eight protocols have been added to the Convention so far, which set out specific measures taken by the Parties to reduce emissions of air pollutants. In particular, the amended Protocol provides for stricter than before limit values for dust emissions from significant stationary sources and introduces transitional measures in favour of the Parties acceding to the Amended Protocol before the end of 2019, including eastern and south-eastern European countries. I voted in favour of the document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as the inclusion of these amendments implies acceptance of an improvement in heavy metals legislation adopted in international conventions and now transposed into European Union law.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear colleagues, research shows that air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometers before being defer. The problems must therefore be addressed at international level. The Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution, which entered into force in 1983, is the first international legally binding instrument in this field.  To date, the Convention has been extended by eight protocols laying down specific measures to reduce emissions of air pollutants, such as sulphur and nitrogen oxides, volatile and persistent organic compounds, heavy metals, combating acidification, eutrophication and ground-level ozone, introducing national ceilings and reducing emissions for different substances below 1990 levels.  In December 2009, the Protocol was amended to update the parties' obligations and reflect the best available techniques. Amending decisions must be ratified by the Parties. Amendments to the Protocol are largely covered by EU legislation and will be further transposed by a new Directive setting updated national ceilings for emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants.  Ratification of the amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution. I therefore voted for Parliament to give its consent.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – The Convention on Long-range transboundary air pollution aims to protect human health and the environment from air pollution. The problem of air pollution must therefore be tackled at international level. The aim is to reduce emissions from industrial sources (iron and steel industry, non-ferrous metal manufacturing industry), combustion processes (energy production, road transport) and waste incineration. It sets emission limit values for specific major stationary sources and requires the Parties to apply the best available techniques (BAT). The Parties must also draw up and maintain lists of Pb, Cd and Hg emissions into ambient air, phase out ethyled petrol and reduce mercury levels in alkaline batteries.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which contains a recommendation from the European Parliament to accept  a series of amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution on Heavy Metals. The objective of this Protocol is to control emissions of heavy metals caused by anthropogenic activities that are subject to long-range transboundary atmospheric transport and are likely to have significant adverse effects on human health or the environment. The parties to the protocol agreed, among other things, to reduce their total annual emissions into the atmosphere of each of the heavy metals listed in its annex, to facilitate the exchange of technologies and techniques designed to reduce emissions of heavy metals and to encourage research, development, monitoring and cooperation, primarily focusing on heavy metals.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about an amendment to the Protocol which introduces, in particular, stricter limits on dust emissions, as well as flexible transitional provisions from which Parties accessing the amended Protocol would benefit before the end of 2019, including the countries of eastern and south-eastern Europe. The ratification of these amendments is a step forward in certifying a higher level of protection of human health and the environment, so I consider it necessary to vote in their favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of amending the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on long-range transboundary air pollution on heavy metals. This change is important in order to improve the protection of the environment and public health in the face of cross-border air pollution. This change provides, among other things, for stricter limit values and thus stricter regulation than before.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals aims to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of lead (Pb), cadmium (Cd) and mercury (Hg) into the atmosphere. It requires the Parties to reduce the total annual emissions of the three metals indicated to levels below those recorded in 1990 or in an alternative year between 1985 and 1995.  The Protocol aims to reduce emissions from industrial sources (iron and steel industry, non-ferrous metals), combustion processes (industry, electricity production, road transport) and waste incineration. The Protocol establishes limit values for emissions from certain large fixed sources and requires the use of the best available techniques (ATM).  The amendment to the Protocol is already covered by EU legislation, but should still be transposed through a new directive that will update national emission limit values for certain air pollutants and provide for national inventories of annual emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury, among others.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This is a proposal to adopt a supplementary protocol to an international agreement to which the Member States and the EU have already acceded and are already taking into account. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on 'Adoption of the amendment to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution on Heavy Metals'. These substances do not border on them, which is why international cooperation is required to introduce effective measures to protect our health and environment. The protocols established in 1998 try to achieve just that, for example by clarifying, for example, national emission limits. In other words, the protocols are tools to help Europe control emissions.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this recommendation by Mr La Via on the acceptance of the amendment to the 1998 Heavy Metals Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution. This amendment will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment, while being fully in line with current EU legislation.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to control and reduce the damage caused by cross-border air pollution to human health and the environment. This report refers to one of the eight protocols of the Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution. Specifically, it refers to the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Heavy Metals, which focuses on reducing and controlling emissions into the atmosphere of lead, cadmium and mercury. This Protocol obliges the parties concerned to reduce emissions of industrial origin, combustion processes and incineration of waste. To do this, set limit values. As I fully defend social welfare and environmental care, I fully support this report, which aims to establish stricter limit values for particulate emissions from certain large stationary sources.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. Several studies carried out between 1972 and 1977 had shown that air pollutants could be transported thousands of kilometres before depositing, which highlighted the need to tackle the problems caused by air pollution at international level. Signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, the Convention was the first legally binding international instrument adopted in this field: it establishes a framework for the control and reduction of damage caused by transboundary air pollution to human health and the environment. To date, the Convention has been extended by eight protocols. The eighth protocol for the first time covers various pollutants and multiple effects and provides for specific national emission limits, as well as reduction commitments for various substances. The amended Protocol lays down, in particular, stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major fixed sources. The amendments are fully consistent with eu legislation and their ratification will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ in the framework of this legislative resolution, the European Parliament gave its consent to the amendment of the Heavy Metal Protocol to the Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution, which dates back to 1979. The objective of this Protocol is to reduce and control discharges of heavy metal emissions such as lead or mercury, in particular in relation to industrial sources, combustion processes and waste incineration. It also obliges the Contracting Parties to phasing out leaded petrol or to reduce the level of mercury in alkaline batteries and measuring instruments. Of course, all these changes and limitations will require the introduction of appropriate measures at the level of the Contracting Parties, which may also affect Slovakia, but I think that, given the negative health and environmental impacts of heavy metal emissions, as well as the impossibility of controlling emissions at national level, which is due to rapid and uncontrollable spread across national borders, such international adjustment is very important. That is why I supported this and The Second La Via proposal on the protocol on persistent organic pollutants.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision adopting amendments to the 1998 Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Air Pollution, which will set updated national emission ceilings for certain air pollutants and allow the introduction of annual national emission inventories covering, inter alia, emissions of lead, cadmium and mercury. Ratification of measures and commitments will make an important contribution to reducing damage to human health and the environment and limit cross-border air pollution.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Studies carried out in the 1970s have shown that air pollutants can be transported thousands of kilometres, causing enormous damage to human health and the environment. The Convention concluded in 1979 on transfrontier air pollution sought to combat this phenomenon by drawing up a framework for the reduction and control of pollution. The adoption of eight successive protocols amended the original text, updating the catalogue of prohibited substances and raising emission limits, especially for those substances, referred to as "dioxins", produced by human and natural activities. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the amendments which strengthen prevention policies and which lay down additional parameters and obligations, which will efficiently protect not only the environment but the health of all citizens.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report deals with the acceptance of procedural amendments updating the scope of international conventions already approved by Parties at international level and which are now incorporated into the framework of EU law. I voted in favour because I believe that the ratification of the amendments is a step forward towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from long-range cross-border air pollution caused by persistent organic pollutants.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this recommendation on amendments to the 1998 protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution on Persistent Organic Pollutants. Indeed, if persistent organic pollutants are extremely harmful, both to humans and to nature, and these amendments are in line with EU legislation, Member States are already signatories to this protocol. I therefore believe that it is not necessary for the EU to sign these amendments; it would not add value. Moreover, it would be wise to have the Aarhus Protocol ratified by major industrial powers in third countries such as the United States or China.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this amended protocol as this includes seven new substances, updated application requirements for various substances, updated restrictions on PCDD/PCDF emissions from various sources, and adds PCBs to the list of substances affected by total annual emission restrictions and reporting obligations. The amendments are fully in line with existing European legislation

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Supporting the POP amendment is not necessary. Indeed, with the exception of Malta, EU states are already signatories to the Aarhus Protocol on this issue.  The commission's recommendation does not bring added value or legal significance. It would be more useful for the EU to approach the major industrial powers to invite them to join this protocol under the leadership of the United Nations. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in the importance of improving air pollution not just in Europe but across the world.  However I do not believe that the Commission’s proposal to expand legislation in this area is the correct way to achieve this. The European Union’s policies on energy and climate have already caused irreparable damage to the United Kingdom’s industry and economy.  I abstained on this proposal as I agree with the aim to improve air pollution in Europe but I believe that this legislation will not achieve this.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of these amendments because they represent an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. Winds do not know the borders, so it is necessary to tackle the problems caused by air pollution at European and international level.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Amendments to the 1998 Protocol on Heavy Metals to the Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution. The purpose of this Convention is to protect human health and the environment from air pollution. Studies carried out between 1972 and 1977 have shown that air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometres before they settle, and this problem needs to be addressed at international level. The Convention, signed in 1979, was the first legally binding international instrument in this field. It has created a system to control and reduce the damage to human health and the environment caused by transboundary air pollution. In 1998, i supplemented the Convention. The Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants aims to limit, reduce or discontinue POPs emissions, their introduction and release into the environment. The Parties shall ensure that operators of major stationary emission sources apply the best available techniques, that the emission limit values set, etc. are complied with in certain waste incineration plants. I support the amendments contained in the proposal aimed at ensuring a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against transboundary air pollution.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The Aarhus Protocol, named after Denmark's second largest city, where a first convention was signed in June 1998, five years before the protocol of the same name, concerns long-distance cross-border pollution. The amendments in question are intended to set limits on the emission limits of dust containing heavy metals or persistent organic pollutants (such as PCBs).  The Aarhus Protocol is under the aegis of the United Nations, the signatory parties are essentially European states as well as the European Union. But not all EU states are at the same stage of engagement and Malta has not signed or ratified the Aarhus Protocol. Heavy metals and POPs - persistent organic pollutants - are real poisons for humans and nature. For example, nearly half of migratory birds have already disappeared because of the effects of POPs on their sense of direction.  However, the amendments in question are already widely covered by our legislation and the EU should start by asking third countries such as the United States or China to sign and/or ratify this protocol, before imposing new constraints on us.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution was signed in 1979 and came into force in 1983. It has since been expanded through eight protocols specifically identifying measures for parties to reduce their emissions of air pollutants, including the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants. Its objective was to combat the release, emissions and leakage of these organic pollutants. I have endorsed this decision to accept amendments to this protocol in order to set a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants was an important step forward in protecting the environment and citizens' health. The restrictions imposed on the use of dichlorodiphenyl trichloroethane (DDT), hexachlorocyclohexane (HCH) and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) have been linked to the obligation to use the best available techniques and the correct disposal and transport of pollutants that have become waste. I have today voted in favour of the La Via report on amendments to the 1998 Protocol, which links to the ratification by the contracting parties of the 2009 decisions amending certain aspects of the Protocol. The amendments are fully consistent with current EU legislation and represent an improvement in international standards in this area, which is why I have decided to support the report.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report as the inclusion of these amendments implies acceptance of an improvement in persistent organic pollutant legislation adopted in international conventions and now transposed into European Union law.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this report on the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution caused by Persistent Organic Pollutants. The Convention aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. To date, the Convention has been expanded with eight protocols establishing specific measures to be taken by Parties to reduce their emissions of air pollutants. I consider the new addition positive.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This amendment relates to the Aarhus Protocol on cross-border heavy metal pollution (pcBs, for example). The signatories of this protocol are for most European states as well as the European Union.  The amendments are already widely covered by EU legislation. The Commission's recommendation has no added value or legal significance, especially since the Member States are already parties to the protocol.  It is of no use to support this recommendation. On the other hand, we can only invite the European Union to get closer to the major industrial powers in order to invite them to sign and/or ratify the Aarhus Protocol as the United States (not ratified) or China (not ratified and non-signatory countries).  So I decided to vote against that recommendation.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr La Via's report is well thought out and I support it. The proposed amendments to the 1998 Aarhus Protocol aim to reduce and control more both emissions of 'heavy metals' and emissions of 'persistent organic pollutants'. I believe that it is essential to strengthen the current legislation, which will certainly lead to greater protection both for the environment and for the health of our citizens. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval to the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution caused by Persistent Organic Pollutants.  Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 had shown that air pollutants could travel several thousand kilometres before depositing, so problems arising from air pollution on an international scale need to be addressed. The Convention, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, was the first legally binding international instrument in this area and has been expanded with eight protocols establishing specific measures, including persistent organic pollutants. This amended Protocol includes seven new substances, updates implementation requirements for various substances, updates restrictions on DDPC/PCDF emissions from various sources, and adds PCBs to the list of substances to which total annual emission restrictions and reporting obligations apply.  The ratification of the amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it endorses Parliament's opinion in 1979. Convention on Long-range transboundary air pollution 1998 adoption of the Protocol on amendments to persistent organic pollutants. I voted on this report because it is approved by Parliament in 1979. Convention on Long-range transboundary air pollution 1998 Amendments to the Protocol on heavy metals. The Convention on Long-range transboundary air pollution aims to protect human health and the environment from air pollution. Several studies carried out between 1972 and 1977 showed that air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometres before they settle. The problem of air pollution must therefore be tackled at international level. The Convention, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, was the first legally binding international instrument in this field. That Convention was a framework that allowed the control and reduction of damage to human health and the environment caused by transboundary transboundary air pollution.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \ u2012 The EPP Members voted in uniform to amend the agreement, that is to say, the 1998 Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Air Pollution across Borders. The 1998 targets following the control, reduction or elimination of emissions, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants are upgraded by updating the Protocol, which includes seven new substances, updating the multiple substance requirements and limits on emissions of dioxins and furans, etc. The ratification of these amendments represents significant progress towards greater protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1998 Aarhus Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution has as one of its objectives to control emissions, spills and discharges of persistent organic pollutants, with planned actions to reduce the use of DDT and other harmful substances. In addition to updating emission limitation obligations and adding other harmful substances subject to reduction obligations, the amendment to the Protocol also provides for specific exemptions and flexible time limits for economies in transition, so as to facilitate ratification by all. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which approves the amendments and advocates more vigorous protection of human health and the environment.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Amendments to the Aarhus Protocol on long-distance cross-border pollution provide for setting limits on the emission limits of dust containing persistent organic pollutants.  Member States are already signatories, so it is not necessary for the EU to ratify these amendments. On the other hand, the latter should approach the major industrial powers of third countries to invite them to sign and/or ratify the protocol such as the United States or China.  Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution of Persistent Organic Pollutants and its protocols are fundamental documents for the protection of the environment and the health of individuals and that, therefore, it is the Union's task to ensure its full application.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. Since 1972 we have known that air pollutants are transported thousands of kilometres before they settle, which highlighted the need to tackle the problems caused by air pollution at international level as early as 1979, with the signing of the Convention on Transboundary Air Pollution which came into force in 1983. It establishes a common framework for the control and reduction of damage caused by cross-border air pollution to human health and the environment. Today, the European Parliament must support the Commission's proposal to update the 1998 Protocol to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions of dichlorodiphenyl trichloroethane (DDT), hexachlorocyclohexane (HCH) and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), as well as reduce total annual emissions of polycyclic hydrocarbons aromatic (IPA), dioxins/furans (PCDD/PCDF) and hexachlorobenzene (HCB) in the atmosphere: the parties must be required to reduce their total annual emissions of these three metals to levels below those of 1990 and emission limit values applicable to certain large fixed sources are defined, in addition to forcing states to apply the best available production techniques (BAT). It is important to support all efforts to curb air pollution and to protect the health of our citizens.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Aarhus Protocol, under the auspices of the United Nations, aims to limit cross-border air pollution over long distances. Almost all of the signatory parties are Member States of the European Union, although they are not all at the same stage of engagement. These amendments are intended to set limits on the emission of dust containing persistent organic pollutants.  Basically, we know full well that persistent organic pollutants pose a real danger to humans and nature. From a legal point of view, we believe that the objectives of these amendments are in perfect harmony with European Union legislation. Nevertheless, we do not consider it necessary for the European Parliament to ratify these amendments as the Member States are already signatories. If the objective for the European institutions, always with good intentions, is indeed to reduce the emission of these dusts, then the real challenge is to convince the federal authorities of the United States as well as those of emerging countries such as China and India to ratify the Aarhus Protocol.  So I voted against these amendments.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution is harmful to human health and ecosystems. A large part of the population does not live in a healthy environment, by current standards. This leads us to act through the mechanisms we have at our fingertips. One of these is the Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution and the Protocols to that Convention. In view of the year-on-year changes in the degree of pollution, the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the abovementioned Convention constitute a necessary adaptation to the new realities of the environment.  I was in favour of this report because ratification of the amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants aims to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and spills of persistent organic pollutants (dichlorodiphenyl trichloroethane (DDT), hexachlorocyclohexane (HCH), polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (IPA), dioxins/furans (PCDD/PCDF) and hexachlorobenzene (HCB)). In December 2009, the Protocol was amended by Decisions 2009/1, 2009/2, 2009/3 and 2009/4, the latter two of which refer to the best available techniques (BAT). Decisions 2009/1 and 2009/2 include seven new substances, update implementation requirements for many substances, update the limitations of PCDD/PCDF emissions from different sources and add PCBs to the list of substances subject to annual emission restrictions and reporting requirements. The amendments to the Protocol, which are already largely covered by EU legislation, will be further transposed by the revision of the Directive setting national emission limits (NECs) for certain air pollutants and establishing annual national emission inventories, which are currently under way. I am voting in favour.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the acceptance of the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution of Persistent Organic Pollutants. The problem of long-distance transboundary air pollution was addressed at international level by the Convention signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983. Over the years, it has been extended by eight protocols, such as the 1998 protocol on persistent organic pollutants, established with the aim of controlling, reducing or eliminating discharges, emissions and spills of persistent organic pollutants, limiting the use of many substances compared with the period before 1990. The amendments to the protocol, which are already largely covered by EU legislation, will be further transposed thanks to a new directive updating national emission limits for certain air pollutants and establishing annual national emission inventories.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Amendments to the Protocol to the Convention on Long-Range Air Pollution include the inclusion of as many as seven new persistent pollutants, update the implementation obligations and limitations of total annual dioxin/furran (PCDD/PCDF) emissions from different sources, and provide for the addition of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) to the list of substances subject to annual emission restrictions. This is therefore an important step towards international management of the problems caused by air pollution and I voted in favour of ratifying these amendments with great conviction.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report which stresses that air pollutants can travel many thousands of kilometres before they are placed and therefore the problems caused by air pollution should be addressed at international level.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Recommendation on the draft Council Decision accepting the amendments to the Protocol on Obsessive Organic Pollutants of 1998 to the 1979 Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution is part of all the discussions we are having with a view to reducing environmentally aggravating elements. I therefore think it is particularly important to support such initiatives in order to improve the living conditions of citizens but also to protect the environment itself. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amendments because I believe that we need to tackle the problems caused by air pollution at European level. The Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants aims to control and reduce discharges and emissions of these substances. This vote is taking important steps in the direction of environmental protection and the fight against pollution, fundamental objectives that the European Union must pursue at supranational and state level.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because, in addition to confirming principles with which I agree and which are already part of other legislative measures, it goes in the direction of improving air quality and improving the protection of citizens' health. Given the obvious advantages, I easily took this voting decision.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution aims to protect the environment against air pollutants. Air pollutants have the potential to travel several thousand kilometres before being deposited. The amended Protocol updates implementation requirements for several substances, including PCDD/PCDF emissions from several sources. PCBs will be added to the list of substances affected by the total annual emission restrictions. Flexible timeframes will be provided for parties with an economy in transition regarding the application of emission limit values and for the choice of the reference year for the total annual emissions. A new directive setting updated national emission ceilings for certain atmospheric pollutants and annual national emission inventories will deal with emissions of POPs, including PAHs, PCDD/PCDF, HCB and PCBs. Ratifying this amendment aims to provide a higher level of protection of human health and preserve the environment against transboundary air pollution.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mr La Via's report on persistent organic pollutants. It has already been scientifically proven that air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometres before deposition. All the more reason for an international approach.  The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on persistent organic pollutants aims to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants. In December 2009, the Protocol was amended by Decisions 2009/1, 2009/2, 2009/3 and 2009/4, the latter two of which were on the best available techniques. Decisions 2009/1 and 2009/2 must be ratified by the parties. The amended Protocol includes seven new substances, updates of application requirements for various substances, restrictions on updates on various emissions and extends the list of substances affected by total annual emission restrictions subject to reporting obligations.  A new Directive will be needed to update national emission limit values for air pollutants and to provide for national inventories of annual emissions covering persistent organic pollutants. Specific derogations and flexible transition timetables for economies in transition should enable all parties to comply with the Essential Protocol for a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. Since the 1970s there have been studies on the harmfulness to the environment and human health caused by the emission of persistent organic pollutants into the atmosphere. Since then, the subject has continued to evolve in conjunction with the emergence of new issues and problems. The ratification of the amendments to the protocol on this area, to which the Union acceded in 2004, is important in order not to hinder the path taken which allows for a continuous improvement in regulations on persistent organic pollutants. The amendments that have been tabled will enable EU citizens to live in an increasingly healthy environment, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The Protocol in question aims at reducing emissions from industrial sources (iron and steel industry, non-ferrous metal industry), combustion processes (power generation, road transport), and waste incineration. I have voted in favour of the EU accepting amendments to the Protocol so as to ensure continued relevance of the aims of the Protocol itself.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report deals with the acceptance of procedural amendments updating the scope of international conventions already approved by Parties at international level and which are now incorporated into the framework of EU law. I voted in favour because I believe that the ratification of the amendments is a step forward towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from long-range cross-border air pollution caused by persistent organic pollutants.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution that I voted in favour approves the amendments to the Protocol to the Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution concerning Persistent Organic Pollutants. The proposed amendments set stricter limits on cross-border emissions than those set out in the Convention Protocol in order to improve the prevention of air pollution and its effects on human health.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. – The Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. Air pollutants can travel thousands of kilometres before they are deposited, so the problems caused by air pollution need to be addressed internationally. The Convention, which entered into force in 1983, is the first international instrument with binding legal force to set up a framework for monitoring and reducing the harmful effects of cross-border air pollution. Eight protocols have been added to the Convention. The purpose of the 1998 Aarhus Protocol is to control, reduce or eliminate the release, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants. The accession of the Community to the Protocol was approved by Council Decision 2004/259/EC of 19 February 2004. Decision 2009/1 should be ratified by the Parties. The revised Protocol contains seven new substances, updates implementation requirements, restrictions and expands the range of substances subject to annual emission restrictions and reporting obligations. The amendments to the Protocol will be governed by EU law and will be further implemented through a new directive. The ratification of the amendments will be a significant step towards achieving a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. I voted in favour of granting the parliamentary consent required for the draft Council decision.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this amendment to the Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants, as the amended protocol includes seven new substances, updates implementation requirements for several substances, updates restrictions for PCDD/PCDF emissions from several sources and adds PCBs to the list of substances affected by the total annual emission restrictions and reporting obligations. The amendments are fully consistent with existing EU legislation.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This non-legislative report proposes the European Parliament's support for amendments to the protocol on long-range cross-border air pollution with regard to heavy metals.  The Convention, which came into force in 1983, created a framework to control and reduce damage to human health and the environment caused by air pollution in cross-border areas. In 2012, amendments were adopted to set stricter limits on emissions of organic pollutants, and to establish a flexible transitional regime for new parties to the convention, including eastern and south-eastern European countries.  Considering that these amendments are already covered by European legislation under the revised Directive on National Emission Caps (NEC) recently adopted by Parliament and currently being negotiated with the Council, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. By this vote, the European Parliament approved amendments to the 1998 protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution on Persistent Organic Pollutants. I obviously support any measures towards better protection of the health of European citizens, but also of their environment.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's Resolution calling on the Council to accept, on behalf of the European Union, the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Distance Transverse Air Pollution on Persistent Organic Pollutants.  Approved in 1981, the Convention is the main international legal framework for cooperation and measures to limit and gradually reduce air pollution and avoid its harmful effects on human health and the environment in the UN EEC region.  The text of the proposed amendments to the 1998 Protocol includes new substances, an update of the enforcement regime for certain emissions, and limit values (VLE) applicable to dioxin/furan emissions (PCDD/PCDF) from certain waste incinerators, establishing new limits for PCDD/PCDF emissions from conurbation and arc electric furnaces, and adding PCBs to the list of substances whose annual emissions must remain below the baseline year level and be reported. I support and welcome this news to better protect human health and the environment.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. As well as on the issue of heavy metals, the objectives of these amendments are laudable, but they do not add value to the current European legislation. Being opposed to a counterproductive multiplication of norms and texts, I objected to this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague La Via's report on amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution. Its purpose is to control or eliminate emissions or losses of persistent organic pollutants. The ratification of this Protocol represents a step forward in the fight against pollution.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. The Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. Signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, the Convention was the first legally binding international instrument in this field. It establishes a framework for the control and reduction of damage caused by cross-border air pollution to human health and the environment. The Convention entrusts the Executive Secretariat of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) with the functions of secretariat. To date, the Convention has been extended by eight protocols. This instrument, which entered into force on 23 October 2003, has been transposed into EU law through various instruments and has been amended by Decisions 2009/1, 2009/2, 2009/3 and 2009/4, the last two of which relate to BAT. The amended Protocol includes seven new substances, updates the implementing requirements for many substances, updates the limitations of PCDD/PCDF emissions from different sources and adds PCBs to the list of substances subject to annual emission restrictions and reporting obligations, ensuring a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on long-range transboundary air pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. The Convention, signed in 1979 and in force since 1983, was the first legally binding international instrument in this area and established the context for controlling and reducing damage to human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution. To date, the scope of the Convention has been extended by eight protocols identifying specific measures to be taken by the signatory parties in order to reduce their emissions of air pollutants. These amendments are already largely covered by EU law and will be further transposed by a new Directive updating national emission limit values for certain air pollutants. Ratification of the amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation, because I do not consider it the role of the European Union to ratify amendments to an international treaty.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. Air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometres before deposition. The problems caused by air pollution must therefore be addressed internationally. The Convention on long-range transboundary air pollution was the first legally binding international instrument in this area, creating a framework for controlling and reducing damage to human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on persistent organic pollutants aims to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants (POP). It requires the parties to suppress the production and use of relevant substances, restrict the use of dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT), hexachlorocyclohexane (HCH) and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and to reduce the total annual emissions of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH), dioxins/furans (PCDD/PCDF) and hexachlorobenzene (HCB) to levels below 1990 or an alternative year between 1985 and 1995. The parties shall ensure that operators of the main fixed emission sources use the best available techniques (EDM). The Community's amendment to the Protocol was adopted by Council Decision 2004/259/EC. The Protocol has been transposed into EU law through various instruments and has since been amended successively. We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: In writing ‒ the Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution aims to ensure the protection of human health and the environment from air pollution. This Convention established a cooperation programme for monitoring and measuring the large-scale transmission of air pollutants. Subsequently, eight protocols identifying specific measures aimed at reducing air pollutants were annexed to the Convention. The proposal for a Council Decision includes amendments to the Protocol, which are an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment and concern persistent organic pollutants.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the proposal to revise the national emission limits for certain persistent organic pollutants.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation as the amendments to the Protocol on Obsessive Organic Pollutants of 1998 to the 1979 Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution are a necessary step towards environmental protection, an issue that concerns us all, regardless of political positioning.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Single consent vote. I fully support the amendment to the Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants. The amended protocol includes seven new substances, updates implementation requirements for several substances, updates restrictions for PCDD/PCDF emissions from several sources, and adds PCBs to the list of substances affected by the total annual emission restrictions and reporting obligations. The amendments are fully consistent with existing EU legislation.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I think it is important to draw attention to the report, as the convention in question has so far been completed with eight protocols specifying specific measures by the Parties to reduce emissions of air pollutants. The first Protocol to the Convention was signed in 1984 and provided for a financing system for activities under EMEP. The Second Protocol on Sulpin Emissions was the first major measure to reduce air pollution. The third, fourth and fifth protocols dealt with nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds and, once again, sulphur emissions and their cross-border flows. The 1991 Protocol on Volatile Organic Compounds moved towards a more effective group approach to regulating individual substances. This continued under the two 1998 Protocols on heavy metals and persistent organic pollutants. The Eighth Protocol to combat acidification, eutrophication and ground-level ozone is the first multi-pollutant and multi-impact protocol and includes specific national emission limits and emission reduction commitments for different substances.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the draft Council Decision considering that the amendments to the Protocol are already largely covered by EU legislation, and that their transposition will continue with the adoption of a new Directive on updated national emission ceilings for certain air pollutants. Similarly, the amendments are fully consistent with existing EU legislation. There is no doubt that ratification of the amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution on Persistent Organic Pollutants, as I warmly welcome an increase in environmental and consumer protection in this area.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Studies show that air pollutants can be transported over several thousand kilometres. That is why a Community solution is needed here too. With today's vote, we are making an important contribution to protecting people's health in the future.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this recommendation, which is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. The Aarhus Protocol is an international convention under the aegis of the United Nations. Its aim is to address environmental issues, including cross-border pollution with persistent organic pollutants. These pollutants have serious effects not only on health but also on biodiversity. For example, migratory birds lose their sense of direction, which explains the rapid decline of their populations on the American and Asian continents. The Member States of the European Union are already signatories to this protocol and apply very strict standards. They are almost the only ones and the major polluting powers do not take this into account.  This recommendation by Parliament does not oblige the Member States in any way. On the other hand, it will enable the Commission to justify future directives to limit polluting emissions, without putting pressure on third countries that are far more polluting than European countries.  On the contrary, every free trade agreement between the EU and third countries, such as the transatlantic treaty, is intended only to increase transport flows and pollution without environmental preconditions.  Member States are already signatories to this protocol and do not need the recommendation that is proposed to us. So I voted against this unnecessary recommendation.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as the inclusion of these amendments implies acceptance of an improvement in persistent organic pollutant legislation adopted in international conventions and now transposed into European Union law.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution concerning Heavy Metals, Persistent Organic Pollutants.   Heavy metal pollution is one of the most important threats to human health and the environment. Respiratory and cardiovascular diseases are common in Europe today, and current scientific studies have confirmed the important relationship between heavy metal concentrations in food intake or inhaled air and cancer mortality, which is far too fast to become the next civilization disease of our time.  The same factors cause huge losses in agricultural production and biodiversity. I am therefore convinced that increasing the limits on emissions of heavy metals and persistent organic pollutants into the atmosphere, as well as updating the list of harmful metals, will significantly improve the quality of the environment and allow for the reconstruction and development of agriculture, thereby positively impacting the health and life of Europeans.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒  I supported the ratification of the amendment, as it is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the EU’s ratification of the 1998 update to the international agreement on controlling transboundary air pollution, specifically concerning persistent organic pollutants. Thanks to the updated implementation requirements for several substances and restrictions for dioxin and furan emissions from several sources, as well as the addition of PCBs to the substances affected by emission restrictions, these amendments will contribute to a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The two amendments to the 1979 Conventions are the acceptance of the procedural amendments that upgrade these Conventions and which have already been adopted at international level and now need to be transposed into the EU legal framework.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the of the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution on Persistent Organic Pollutants because they seek to update the list of persistent organic pollutants covered by the protocol, to make the protocol more adaptable to future developments on the best available techniques and to facilitate accession to the amended protocol by parties with an economy in transition.  In addition to that, the amendments aim to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants and require parties, of which the EU is one, to eliminate the production and use of the substances which are considered a persistent organic pollutant, to reduce the use of certain pollutants which are considered carcinogenic from the level of the emission in 1990 , update the implementation requirements applicable to emissions from certain waste incinerators all of which benefit European citizens and the environment. The amendments to the Protocol are already largely covered by EU legislation, and will be further transposed via a new directive setting updated national emission ceilings for certain atmospheric pollutants. In view of this, I believe the amendments should be supported.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The 1998 Protocol on heavy metals, which aims to reduce and control anthropogenic emissions into the air of lead, cadmium and mercury, was amended in 2012 with stricter emission limit values for dust emissions from some major stationary sources and flexible  transitional arrangements. The POPs Protocol, which aims to control, reduce or  eliminate discharges, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants, was amended in 2009, when new substances were added to its scope and provisions for existing substances were updated. While EU legislation is already in place to cover these amendments, the ratification by the EU is important for their entry into force and to give a signal to other UNECE signatories. Given the widespread impact of these substances on human health and on biodiversity and the need for international collaboration on this particular topic, I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, with this Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution, a framework has been created to combat and reduce damage to human health and the environment.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision to accept amendments to the 1998 Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants with the 1979 Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution. 2016, as this gives consent to amend the Protocol. I think it is essential to pay more attention to rising air pollution to protect human health and the environment.  However, this major challenge needs to be addressed by coordinated forces and internationally, as it has been established that pollutants can be carried by air for thousands of kilometres before their deposition. In this context, cross-border pollution requires specific measures and effective action in the form of controlling and reducing harm to human health and the environment.
