Therefore, the ratification of the amendments in question will improve the level of protection and strengthen EU legislation in the area concerned.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I do not think it is necessary to support the POP amendment. I note that, with the exception of Malta, the EU states are already signatories to the Aarhus Protocol on this subject.  The commission's recommendation does not bring added value or legal significance. I would therefore find it more useful for the EU to approach the major industrial powers to invite them to join this protocol under the leadership of the United Nations. Therefore I vote against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Giovanni La Via's recommendation on the recommendation on long-range cross-border air pollution for persistent organic pollutants. The Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution has created a framework to reduce pollution damage to health and the environment. The persistent organic pollutants protocol has been revised to improve its effectiveness and has introduced seven new toxic substances. I therefore approved the Council's decision to ratify this protocol and its amendments.  This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation from the European Parliament on the Convention on Cross-Border Air Pollution and more specifically on amendments to its Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants.  The adoption of these amendments will allow the introduction of seven new toxic substances that will be included in this Protocol.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report deals with the adoption of a supplementary protocol on an international agreement to which the Member States and the EU have already acceded. I am abstaining on this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the amendments, as they constitute an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the procedural improvement of the scope of the International Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution, already endorsed by Parties at International level and now to be transposed in the EU legislation framework through several legal instruments. The acceptance of these procedural arms is necessary, given the damage to human health and to the environment caused by transboundary air pollution. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol further extends the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution of Persistent Organic Pollutants. It therefore aims to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and spills of persistent organic pollutants. The amended protocol includes seven new substances, updating the limitations of PCDD/PCDF emissions and adding PCBs to the list of substances subject to annual emission restrictions and reporting requirements. Here, too, I have called on my fellow Members to give their consent to the Council's decision, in order to officially adopt the amendments to the protocol, which are largely already covered by European legislation.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. Persistent organic pollutants are real poisons for humans and nature. For example, nearly half of migratory birds have already disappeared due to the effects of POPs on direction. The objectives of the amendments are in full compliance with EU legislation. However, since the Member States are already signatories, it does not seem to me to be necessary for the EU to ratify these amendments. On the other hand, it could be recommended that certain major industrial powers, such as the United States or China, be invited to sign and/or ratify the Aarhus Protocol.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it brings nothing new to the fight against persistent organic pollutants. On the other hand and above all the Member States are already parties to the protocol concerned.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The protocol in question relates to long-distance cross-border pollution. These amendments are intended to set limits on the emission limits of dust containing heavy metals or persistent organic pollutants (POPs). The effects of these pollutants and POPs are disastrous for human health, but also for flora and fauna. The migratory bird population has been drastically reduced due to these toxic pollutants.  Nevertheless, European states are already signatories to this undying protocol. The EU therefore has no need to ratify these amendments, and should instead consider inviting industrial powers outside the European Union (United States, China) to sign this treaty. In order to make this point, and this vote being superfluous, I voted against this text.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported La Via's recommendation to amend the 1998 Heavy Metals Protocol to the Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution, which was the first international legally binding instrument in the area when it was signed in 1979. Since it entered into force in 1983, the Convention has to date been expanded with eight protocols identifying concrete measures to be taken by the parties to reduce their pollutant emissions. The amendment to the 1998 Protocol is largely covered by EU law. The new directive sets national emission ceilings for individual atmospheric pollutants and provides annual national emission lists that should include, inter alia, lead, kadmium and mercury emissions.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 While the previous vote concerned heavy metals as environmental pollutants, this was the case for persistent organic pollutants, which are often still used in agriculture (such as pesticides, insecticides), electrotechnical production (as insulators), road transport, chemical industry, oil processing and much more. All these elements, while being able to serve and also serve to achieve different types of necessary outcomes, are generally highly polluting and harmful to health. As in the case of metals, there is an agreement to reduce ejem levels to or from 1990 to 1990 levels. The adoption of the amendments is clearly an important step towards a more efficient functioning of the field of ecology and, of course, the success of public health, especially in view of the very widespread respiratory diseases in the world – not just in Europe).

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision accepting the amendments to the Protocol on Obsessive Organic Pollutants of 1998 to the 1979 Convention on Long-range Cross-Border Air Pollution, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. These are amendments to set limits on the emission limits of dust containing persistent organic pollutants. This protocol is under the aegis of the UN, and EU member states, and the EU as an organisation, are signatories. Persistent organic pollutants are poisons for humans and nature, and are particularly responsible for disrupting the direction of migratory birds. We oppose this text, despite its interest, because the Member States have already signed these amendments, so we do not think it is necessary for the EU to ratify them in turn.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ The Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution is intended to protect the human environment against air pollution. Several studies performed between 1972 and 1977 had shown that air pollutants could travel several thousand kilometres before deposition. Problems caused by air pollution therefore need to be addressed on the international level. Signed in 1979 and entering into force in 1983, the Convention was the first international legally binding instrument in this area. It has created the framework for controlling and reducing the damage to human health and to the environment caused by transboundary air pollution. The Convention identifies the Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) as its secretariat.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the amendments to the Protocol are already in line with current EU legislation and will be transposed by means of a new directive that will update the national emission limit values for certain air pollutants. The ratification of the amendments will be an important step towards greater protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. "U2012 Again my vote in favour of the proposal on the draft Council Decision on the acceptance of amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution, in this case caused by persistent organic pollutants. Limits already provided for in European law are established and, as could not otherwise be the case, this amendment to the Protocol is supported.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This is a proposal to adopt a supplementary protocol to an international agreement to which the Member States and the EU have already acceded and are already taking into account. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which supports amendments to the Convention on The Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution. I believe that these amendments will control and reduce the damage to human health and the environment caused by transboundary air pollution. The amended Protocol to the Convention lays down, in particular, stricter limit values for dust emissions from certain major stationary sources and a more flexible transitional arrangements in the interest of Parties wishing to accede to the Protocol as amended by the end of 2019, including the countries of Eastern and South-Eastern Europe. The ratification of this amendment will be an important step towards ensuring a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against transboundary air pollution.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 showed that air pollutants could be transported several thousand kilometres before being precipitated. The Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, and was the first legally binding international instrument in this area.  To date, the convention has been expanded through eight protocols specifically identifying the measures to be taken by the parties to reduce their air pollutant emissions. The report proposes that the Council approve, on behalf of the European Union, an amendment to the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on persistent organic pollutants.  The amended protocol includes seven new substances, an update of the application regime for several substances, and an update of restrictions for certain emissions.  I want him to be opposed to the criminal pollution of German lignite mines that create pollution peaks in France, I voted for.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I do not think it is necessary to support the POP amendment. I note that, with the exception of Malta, the EU states are already signatories to the Aarhus Protocol on this subject.  The commission's recommendation does not bring added value or legal significance. It therefore seems to me more useful for the EU to approach the major industrial powers to invite them to join this protocol under the leadership of the United Nations. Therefore I vote against it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amendment because it is an important step to further curb and lower air pollution. The new amendments place new restrictions upon dioxin and furan emissions, as well as add PCBs to the list of substances affected by overall emissions limits and reporting obligations.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – Unfortunately, air pollution does not stop at the border. Often this pollution takes many kilometres before it crashes somewhere far away. It is therefore necessary to tackle the problems caused by air pollution internationally and across borders. In 1983, a treaty with a legally binding instrument was first put into force to limit the environmental and health effects of cross-border air pollution. In recent years, a number of protocols have been added to the existing Convention to enable a more efficient approach to environmental problems. The latest amendment includes the addition of a series of harmful substances to which implementing rules, emission limit values and reporting obligations will apply. I hope that, with the ratification of these amendments, we will take another step towards better protecting air quality and public health against cross-border air pollution.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing – Persistent organic pollutants are not normally found in nature but enter the air through human activity, in particular as by-products in industry. They are able to persist in the environment for a long time and are transmitted over long distances. In this way, they can also reach areas whose air is not negatively affected by industrial production and can therefore deteriorate undetectively. Better and more recent regulation of legislation is therefore in place. The changes brought about by the new text of the Protocol will contribute to the protection of the environment by better regulating dangerous emissions. I certainly welcome and support the proposal for a legislative resolution tabled and agree with the rapporteur that the European Parliament approve it, thus contributing to environmental protection, air protection and the health of millions of people.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my full support to the Report on amending the Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution on Persistent Organic Pollutants. The amended Protocol includes seven new substances, updates implementation requirements for several substances, updates restrictions for PCDD/PCDF emissions from several sources, and adds PCBs to the list of substances affected by the total annual emission restrictions and reporting obligations. The amendments are fully consistent with existing EU legislation.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The other Aarhus Protocol of 1998, supplementing the 1998 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution referred to in point 2, aims to control, reduce or eliminate emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants. The accession of the Community to the Protocol was approved by Council Decision 2004/259/EC of 19 February 2004. The Protocol entered into force on 23 October 2003. The Protocol was amended by four decisions by the Parties in December 2012. Of these, Decision 2012/1, which contains seven new substances, updates the implementing requirements for a number of substances and the restrictions on dioxins/furans from multiple sources, and the range of substances subject to annual emission restrictions and reporting obligations is extended by polychlorinated biphenyls and should be ratified by the Parties. The draft decision submitted by the Council proposes this. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety notes in its report that the amendment is fully in line with existing EU legislation and therefore recommends that Parliament give its consent to the draft decision. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution, signed in 1979 and in force since 1983, was the first legally binding international instrument on the protection of the human environment from air pollution. This Convention has created the framework for controlling and reducing damage to human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution.  The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on persistent organic pollutants aims to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants (POP). The Protocol was amended by Decisions 2009/1, 2009/2, 2009/3 and 2009/4. Amendments to the Protocol are already largely covered by EU legislation and will then be transposed by means of a new Directive which will update the national emission limit values for certain air pollutants and provide for national inventories of annual emissions covering MPs. I believe that ratification will make it possible to protect human health and the environment more and more against cross-border air pollution.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. As Member States are already signatories, it does not seem necessary for the EU to ratify these amendments. On the other hand, it might be useful to recommend that it approach the major industrial powers of third countries to invite them to sign and/or ratify the Aarhus Protocol as the United States (not ratified) or China (neither).

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I approved this text which authorises the EU's ratification of amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Cross-Border Air Pollution on Persistent Organic Pollutants. These amendments are in full coherence with current EU legislation. Their ratification will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The report on long-range cross-border air pollution of persistent organic pollutants is in line with its counterpart on heavy metals. I therefore also voted in favour of this report.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1998 Aarhus Protocol further extends the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution of Persistent Organic Pollutants and aims to control and reduce discharges and emissions of these substances. I voted in favour so that we can move in the direction of environmental protection and the fight against pollution, fundamental objectives that the European Union must pursue.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The 1979 Convention on long-range transboundary air pollution has as is purpose the protection of the human environment from air pollution. I have voted for this recommendation that updates restrictions on dioxin and furan emissions from several sources and updates implementation requirements for several substances.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The above recommendation contains a measure that should provide better protection for people's health. As this is only a transfer of a supplementary protocol to an international agreement to which the Member States and the European Union have already acceded, I abstained from voting on this recommendation.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Ratification of amendments to the Protocol is essential to better protect human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution. The amended Protocol contains seven new substances, updated the requirements for a number of substances and the emission limits for polychlorodibenzodione and polychlorodibenzofuran (PCDD/PCDF) caused by different sources, and the addition of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) to the list of substances subject to annual emission limits and notification obligations. In order to facilitate the ratification of the Protocol by parties with a transitional economy, the Protocol shall set flexible deadlines for them to apply emission limit values, to introduce best available techniques and to select the reference year for total annual emissions.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Air Pollution came into force in 1983, the first legally binding international instrument in this area. Subsequently, in 1998, the Aarhus Protocol on persistent organic pollutants was established, with the aim of controlling, reducing or eliminating discharges, emissions and spills of these pollutants. This convention has noted its results and I therefore vote in favour, confident of this draft.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The objective of the Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants to the Convention is to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emission and losses of persistent organic pollutants (POPs). It is recognised that POPs resist degradation under natural conditions and are associated with adverse effects on human health and the environment. The amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution. That is why I welcome the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the acceptance of the amendments.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of ratifying the amendments to the 1998 Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Air Pollution across Borders, as this document is the first protocol that takes into account several effects and an additional seven pollutants. We already have enough knowledge and technology in the EE In the EZ to bind waste incineration plants to limit the release of organic pollutants in a way that is less harmful to the environment.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposed amendment to the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants with the Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution intended to protect the environment from air pollution.  In its acquis, the European Union already has this area governed by the Ambient Air Quality and Cleaner Air Directive for Europe, as well as the Industrial Emissions Directive and a package of other related rules, which constitutes a coherent package that strictly monitors environmental pollution through persistent organic pollutants in the European Union.  It is these rules that ensure that operators of large immutial emission sources use the best available techniques (BAT), waste incinerators operate in accordance with the prescribed emission limits and take effective measures to control these emissions from mobile sources, and that persistent organic pollutants are transported and disposed of in the prescribed manner once they become waste. I am pleased that conventions and protocols as mechanisms of international law follow EU policy and allow further progress in the fight for a cleaner and healthier planet globally.  The adoption of the amendments to the Protocol is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution by persistent organic pollutants. In this regard, I welcome once again this just adopted legislative resolution.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. POPs, like heavy metals, are poisons for man and nature. This has been proven by multiple studies. The objectives of the amendments are in full compliance with EU legislation. However, Member States are already signatories to the protocol and the fact that the EU ratifies them therefore has no added value. It would be more effective to stop negotiating TTIP with the United States, which signed it without ratifying this protocol, and to refuse to go further in our trade relations with China, which has not even signed it.  As is often the case, the EU is re-fighting symbols but continuing to take concrete and harmful actions. As with the previous vote, I am therefore speaking out against this text, which cannot have any real effect on anything.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support amendments to the 1998 Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants to the 1998 Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution. It is a protocol to an important Convention which was once the first internationally binding instrument in this area of protection. Amendments to the Protocol include seven new substances, amended rules in implementation and in the restriction of individual emissions, as well as the inclusion of polychlorinated biphenyr.  Ratifying these amendments will ensure a higher level of protection of the environment and human health against organic pollutants. Law on the Implementation of Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013 850/2004 direct application of these rules is possible on persistent organic pollutants in Croatia. I hope that its application will ensure the protection of human health and the environment in the Croatian border regions around Slavonski Brod, which are exposed to cross-border pollution.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. Air pollutants can be transported thousands of kilometres before they are depositioned. For this reason, the consequences of air pollution must be addressed at international level. The Convention on long-range transboundary air pollution was the first legally binding international instrument in this area, creating a framework for controlling and reducing damage to human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants (POP) aims to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and losses of those pollutants. It requires the parties to suppress the production and use of relevant substances, restrict the use of DDT's, HCH's and PCB's, and to reduce their total annual emissions of HAP's, PCDD/PCDF's and HCB to levels below 1990 or an alternative year between 1985 and 1995. The Parties shall ensure that operators of the main fixed emission sources use the best available techniques. The Community's amendment to the Protocol was adopted by Council Decision 2004/259/EC. The Protocol has been transposed into EU law through various instruments and has since been amended successively. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I agree with my colleague Giovanni La Via's recommendation on the council's draft decision to accept amendments to the 1998 Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants with the 1979 Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution. This Convention is the first legally binding convention of this type and entered into force in 1983.  It is intended to protect the environment from air pollution and has created a framework to control and reduce damage to human health and the environment caused by far-reaching cross-border air pollution. The amended 1998 Protocol is already largely covered by EU laws and will be further transposed through the revision of the directive on national emission ceilings for certain pollutants.  Likewise, the amended Protocol sets 1) stricter limits on dust emissions from certain major stationary sources and 2) flexible transitional arrangements that will be useful for those Member States that will access the amended Protocol before the end of 2019, including the countries of Eastern and South East Europe.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, aims to protect the human environment from air pollution and is the first legally binding international instrument adopted in this area. It establishes a framework for the control and reduction of damage caused by cross-border air pollution, human health and the environment. Over the years, the Convention has been extended by eight protocols defining specific measures to be taken by the Parties to reduce emissions of air pollutants. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants aims to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and spills of persistent organic pollutants. The protocol, which is being amended, includes seven new substances, updates the implementation requirements for many substances, updates the limitations of dioxin/furrani emissions from different sources and adds polychlorinated biphenyls to the list of substances subject to annual emission restrictions and reporting requirements. I believe that the amendments to the amendments to the Protocol (08648/2015 ADD 1) are fully consistent with existing EU legislation and constitute an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. I voted in favour of all this.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Emissions of heavy metals and persistent organic pollutants affect human health and the environment. These substances do not respect national borders and therefore effective control of their emissions requires international cooperation. Two 1998 protocols list best available techniques (BAT) for emission reductions and reporting requirements, national emission limits and emission limits for each type of project. In other words, they establish tools to enable emission reductions and track progress. The protocol aims to reduce and eliminate the ejection and emissions of persistent organic pollutants (POP), which includes chemicals such as DDT and pollutants such as dioxins. In view of the importance of the provisions for citizens' health, I supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Cross-border pollution with persistent organic pollutants is a phenomenon that we must take with great consideration. This report has the advantage of developing a much broader and more extensive protection for the environment and the health of our citizens in this area. That is why I voted in favour of him.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it to be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.   This ratification of the 1998 Protocol on long-range cross-border pollution on persistent organic pollutants (EPs) aims at operators of the main fixed emission sources to use the best available techniques; whereas certain waste incineration plants comply with emission limit values; effective measures are taken to control POP emissions from mobile sources; and that PSPs be transported and disposed of in a way that respects the environment once processed into waste.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. On Tuesday, the European Parliament approved a tightening of its air quality legislation. Specifically, it is an amendment to the Geneva Convention on Long-range Cross-Border Air Pollution that strengthens the fight against persistent organic pollutants such as aldrine, chlordane, heptachlor, mirex and toxaphene. Beneath these barbaric titles are the infamous "POP", these dangerous chemical compounds that have in common toxicity, persistence in the environment, long-distance transport and bio-amplification is the fact that concentration increases within the food chain. They are found in pesticides, in PCBs added to paints and plastics, and in the burning of wood and household waste, especially in the form of dioxin.  This legislative amendment is intended to add seven new substances to the list that limits the use of persistent organic pollutants and to update some existing regimes. I welcome this adjustment, especially since at the same time a similar vote has been considered on the limitation of heavy metals.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation to approve the revision of the Convention on Long-Distance Air Pollution related to persistent organic pollutants. The Convention, adopted in 1979, which came into force in 1983, and has been revised and extended several times through several protocols since then, was at the time the first legally binding instrument to control and reduce the risks to human health and the environment caused by cross-border air pollution. It is a text of reference and importance, since it aims to better cooperate and limit and reduce this pollution, an importance all the more obvious when we remember that air pollutants can be transported over several thousand kilometers before being rushed. The amendments proposed to us, which must now be ratified by the parties, are consistent with EU legislation when they are already covered, or are in the process of being covered through the new directive on national emission limits for certain air pollutants. They should take the next step in protecting human health and the environment, including the addition of new substances, updating the application regime for others, and setting new limits.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval to the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution caused by Persistent Organic Pollutants.  Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 had shown that air pollutants could travel several thousand kilometres before depositing, so problems arising from air pollution on an international scale need to be addressed. The Convention, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, was the first legally binding international instrument in this area and has been expanded with eight protocols establishing specific measures, including persistent organic pollutants. This amended Protocol includes seven new substances, updates implementation requirements for various substances, updates restrictions on DDPC/PCDF emissions from various sources, and adds PCBs to the list of substances to which total annual emission restrictions and reporting obligations apply.  The ratification of the amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 have shown that air pollutants can be transported several thousand kilometres before being precipitated. The problems caused by air pollution at the international level must therefore be addressed. Signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, the Convention was the first legally binding international instrument in this area. To date, the convention has been expanded through eight protocols specifically identifying the measures to be taken by the parties to reduce their air pollutant emissions. The first protocol under the convention was signed in 1984 and contained a funding plan for activities under the EMEP (the concerted programme for monitoring and evaluating long-distance transport of air pollutants in Europe). In December 2009, the protocol was amended by the 2009/1 and 2009/2 decisions, which had yet to be ratified by the parties. The Draft Council Decision includes in its annexes the text of the amendments made to the protocol by the 2009/1 and 2009/2 decisions. Parliament approved it today.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it is approved by the European Parliament in 1979. Convention on Long-range transboundary air pollution 1998 amendments to the Protocol on persistent organic pollutants. 1998 The Aarhus Protocol aimed to limit, reduce or stop persistent organic emissions. The Parties to the Protocol are hereby charged to discontinue the production and use of substances harmful to the environment, to limit the use of dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane, hexachlorocyclohexanes and polychlorinated biphenyls, and to reduce their total annual emissions of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, dioxins and hexachlorobenzene. December 2009 The text of the Protocol has been amended to include seven new substances. Most of these amendments to the Protocol have already been implemented by existing EU legislation and will be further transposed by the adoption of a new directive which will set limits on emissions from these substances. In this context, this document is an important step in reducing pollution.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. We all know that air pollutants can travel thousands of kilometres before their deposition, so the approach to air problems must be carried out within an international framework. The scope of the Convention on long-range cross-border air pollution has been extended by eight protocols identifying specific measures to be adopted by the signatory parties with the aim of reducing their emissions of air pollutants. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on persistent organic pollutants aims to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants. This Protocol was amended by Decisions 2009/1, 2009/2, 2009/3 and 2009/4, the first two of which must be ratified by the Parties. Since the amendments are fully in line with the current European legislation and that their ratification will be a step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution, I have voted in favour of this proposal for a recommendation.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the approval of the amendment to the 1998 protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution on Persistent Organic Pollutants.  The 1979 Convention on Cross-Border Air Pollution came into force in 1983 and is the first legally binding international instrument to protect the human environment from air pollution.  The EU, which came into force in 2003, adheres to the 1998 Protocol, which aims to combat the release of persistent organic pollutants by banning certain substances and setting emission thresholds for others.  In 2009, the protocol was amended to add seven new substances to the list and update the diets of certain substances. These amendments are largely covered by EU legislation. This amendment provides for additional exemptions and time limits for transposition in order to comply with the protocol.  The ratification of these amendments by the EU represents a step towards a higher level of protection of the environment and the health of European citizens against air pollution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as the inclusion of these amendments implies acceptance of an improvement in persistent organic pollutant legislation adopted in international conventions and now transposed into European Union law.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. \u2012 Approval of the changes will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. That is why I support the changes.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the revised Convention, because it is important to always adjust the limit values for organic pollution. This will create a higher level of cross-border health protection.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report deals with the acceptance of procedural amendments updating the scope of international conventions already approved by Parties at international level and which are now incorporated into the framework of EU law. I voted in favour because I believe that the ratification of the amendments is a step forward towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from long-range cross-border air pollution caused by persistent organic pollutants.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, Parliament transposes into EU legislation the amendments to the 1998 Aarhus Protocol to the Convention on Long-Range Transfrontier Air Pollution of Persistent Organic Pollutants. The Convention, signed in 1979, establishes a framework for the control and reduction of damage caused by transfrontier air pollution to human health and the environment. The amendments to the 1998 Protocol include seven new pollutants, update implementing requirements for many substances, update the limits on dioxin/furran emissions from different sources and add polychlorinated biphenyls to the list of substances subject to annual emission restrictions and reporting requirements. I voted in favour of the recommendation because the ratification of these amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This vote represented the second amendment to this Protocol that we voted through today. This amendment pertaining to long-range transboundary air pollution on persistent organic pollutants represents an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the envrionment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ the Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution is intended to ensure the protection of the human environment against air pollution. I voted in favour of this amended protocol, which includes seven new substances, updates the implementing requirements for several substances, updates restrictions on emissions of PCDDs/PCDFs (dioxins/furans) from several sources, and adds PCBs (polychlorinated biphenyls) to the list of substances concerned by the limitation of total annual emissions and the notification obligation.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the EP motion for a resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the adoption of amendments to the 1998 Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants to the 1979 Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution. The Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution is intended to ensure the protection of the human environment against air pollution. Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 have shown that air pollutants can fly several thousand kilometres before ingesting. The problems caused by air pollution therefore need to be addressed at international level. The Convention, which was signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, was the first legally binding international instrument in this field. It has created a framework to control and reduce the damage to human health and the environment caused by transboundary air pollution. The EP's support for the proposal for a Council decision is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment as a result of cross-border air pollution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 I unequivocally support stricter settings for limiting total annual air pollutant emissions.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒The Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution is intended to protect the environment from air pollution. Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 have shown that air pollutants can travel several thousand kilometers before deposition. Therefore, problems caused by air pollution should be addressed internationally.  The Convention is the first international legally binding instrument in this field. The Convention has created a framework to control and reduce the adverse impact on health and the environment caused by cross-border air pollution. The amendment to the Protocol is already largely covered by EU legislation, but the new directive will establish updated ceilings for national emissions for individual atmospheric pollutants and provide conditions for annual national emissions inventory covering POP emissions, including PAH, PCDD/PCDF, HCB and PCB.  As stated, the amendment is fully in line with existing EU legislation and the ratification of the amendments will be a step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support the ratification of the amendment, which is an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from transboundary air pollution.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision adopting amendments to the 1998 Protocol on persistent organic pollutants to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Air Pollution across borders.  I support amendments to the 1998 Protocol, which requires the Parties to abandon the production and use of substances causing emissions, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants. The proposal for an amendment to the Protocol updates the requirements for several substances, updates the limits for emissions of dioxins and furans and expands the list of substances subject to total annual emission limits and to be reported.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution aims to protect the environment from air pollution. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol aims to control and reduce emissions. The amended Protocol updates the implementation requirements for different substances, updates emission restrictions from different sources, and adds to the list new substances affected by the limitations of total annual emissions and reporting obligations. Ratification of the amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment from cross-border air pollution. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The 1998 Protocol, as well as its subsequent amendments and additions, namely those relating to obsessive organic pollutants, are a necessary step in the protection of the environment.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation, as the ratification of the amendments will be a significant step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution and is fully in line with existing EU legislation. It is important to note that between 1972 and 1977 several studies showed that air pollutants can travel thousands of kilometres before they are deposited. Therefore, the problems caused by air pollution need to be addressed at international level. The Convention, signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, was the first international instrument of binding legal force in this area, creating a framework for monitoring and reducing adverse effects. Furthermore, the purpose of the 1998 Protocol is to control, reduce or eliminate the release, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants (POP). The latter requires the Parties to limit the use of dichlorphenyl trichloroethane (DDT), hexachlorocycloexane (HCH) and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and a reduction in total annual emissions of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), dioxins/furans (PCDD/PCDF) and hexachloro benzene (HCB) compared to emissions levels in 1990. I agree with the reasoning given in the Recommendation that special exemptions and flexible transition timetables for economies in transition will enable the Parties to comply with the provisions of the Protocol.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of approving Decisions 2009/1 and 2009/1 amending the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants. We recognise that this protocol has been an important tool to combat acidification, eutrophication and tropospheric ozone, providing for the first time national emission limits for DDT, HCH and PCB and commitments to reduce IPA, PCDD/PCDF and HCP thanks to Best Available Technologies (BAT). We believe that updating the Protocol and extending its scope can strengthen its effectiveness. In particular, seven new substances are covered, implementation obligations are adapted and emission limits and stricter controls are put in place for PCBs and PCDDs/PCDDs. This is as important a step forward as it is due to protecting the health of citizens and the environment from cross-border air pollution. We will ensure that the flexibility on the emission benchmarks and the terms of application of the emission limit values and BAT given to those economies in transition that are part of the protocol does not undermine its effectiveness. On the contrary, we hope that the parties will ratify Decisions 2009/1 and 2009/2 as soon as possible and will commit themselves to promoting the technological improvement necessary to protect the health of citizens and the environment.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text and its amendments. The Convention on Long-Distance Cross-Border Air Pollution aims to protect the human environment from air pollution. Several studies conducted between 1972 and 1977 have shown that air pollutants can be transported several thousand kilometres before being precipitated. The problems caused by air pollution at the international level must therefore be addressed. Signed in 1979 and entered into force in 1983, the Convention was the first legally binding international instrument in this area. It has established the framework to control and reduce the damage to human health and the environment caused by cross-border air pollution. It provides that the Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe will provide its secretariat. The Convention is implemented and monitored through the concerted programme to monitor and assess the long-distance transport of air pollutants in Europe.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on long-range transboundary air pollution on persistent organic pollutants. The Convention aims at reducing air pollutant emissions and was amended by eight protocols. The 1998 Protocol on persistent organic pollutants (POPs) aims at reducing those emissions and collecting information on their production and sales. EU legislation already largely covers the provisions of these amendments, which provide flexibilities for countries with an economy in transition for the application of the new limit values.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the amendment to the protocol on persistent organic pollutants, as the amendments are fully in line with EUROPEAN Union legislation and updated emission limits for certain atmospheric pollutants will provide tools to address and monitor progress in emission control.  Amending the Protocol will improve surveillance and help reduce or eliminate the release, emission and waste of persistent organic pollutants. In my view, these changes will ultimately lead to a reduction in air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment, with a particular focus on far-reaching cross-border air pollution.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the recommendation on the draft Council Decision adopting amendments to the 1998 Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Trans-Border Air Pollution, as I believe that ratifying the amendments will be an important step towards a greater level of protection of human health and the environment against air pollution.  Pollution, which is an international problem, will thus be reduced and more controlled throughout the Union as a result of the introduction of annual national emission inventories in EU countries, covering, inter alia, emissions of persistent organic pollutants (including PAH, PCDD and PCDFs, HCB and PCBs). This will, in turn, have an impact on the better quality of life of the EU people. This will also have beneficial consequences for human health.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as the inclusion of these amendments implies acceptance of an improvement in persistent organic pollutant legislation adopted in international conventions and now transposed into European Union law.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Aarhus Protocol covers long-distance cross-border pollution. It is under the aegis of the United Nations, the signatory parties are essentially European states as well as the European Union. Not all EU states are at the same stage of engagement. Only Malta has neither signed nor ratified it.  Heavy metals and POPs are real poisons for man and nature. The objectives of the amendments are in full compliance with EU legislation. However, since the Member States are already signatories, we do not think it is necessary for the EU to ratify these amendments. On the other hand, it could be recommended to approach the major industrial powers third countries to invite them to sign and/or ratify the Aarhus Protocol as the United States (which has not ratified) or China (neither). I voted against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution is to protect the human environment from air pollution. Between 1972 and 1977, several studies showed that air pollutants travel thousands of kilometres before they are deposited. Therefore, the problems caused by air pollution need to be addressed at international level. The current amendments are fully in line with existing EU legislation. Special exemptions and flexible transition timetables for economies in transition shall enable the Parties to comply with the provisions of this Protocol. The ratification of the amendments will be a significant step towards a higher level of protection of human health and the environment against cross-border air pollution. I voted in favour of the document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as the inclusion of these amendments implies acceptance of an improvement in persistent organic pollutant legislation adopted in international conventions and now transposed into European Union law.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – The problem of air pollution needs to be tackled at international level. The Parties to the Protocol are hereby authorised to cease the production and use of the substances concerned, to limit the use of dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane, hexachlorocyclohexanes and polychlorinated biphenyls and to reduce their total annual emissions of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, dioxins/furans and hexachlorobenzene (HCB). The Parties must also establish and maintain inventories of certain POPs and collect information on the production and sale of other POPs covered by the Protocol.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which contains a recommendation from the European Parliament to accept a series of amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution on Persistent Organic Pollutants. The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants aims to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and losses of POPs. It requires parties to eliminate the production and use of a series of relevant substances, as well as to restrict the use of other substances such as dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT), hexachlorocyclohexanes (HCH) and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs). The protocol entered into force on 23 October 2003 and was transposed into EU law through several legal instruments.  The amended protocol includes seven new substances, updates implementation requirements for several substances, updates restrictions for PCDD/PCDF emissions from several sources, and adds PCBs to the list of substances affected by the total annual emission restrictions and reporting obligations. The amendments to the Protocol are already largely covered by EU legislation, and will be further transposed via a new directive setting updated national emission ceilings for certain atmospheric pollutants.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about an amendment to the Protocol which introduces seven new substances and updates the implementation requirements for certain substances affected by total annual emission restrictions. The ratification of these amendments is a step forward in certifying a higher level of protection of human health and the environment, so I consider it necessary to vote in their favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the proposed amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on long-range transboundary air pollution in respect of persistent organic pollutants. The adoption of these amendments will be an important step towards a higher level of protection of public health and the environment. That is why I supported these changes.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1998 Aarhus Protocol on persistent organic pollutants aims to control, reduce or eliminate discharges, emissions and losses of persistent organic pollutants (POP). It requires the parties to suppress the production and use of relevant substances, restrict the use of dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT), hexachlorocyclohexane (HCH) and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and to reduce the total annual emissions of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH), dioxins/furans (PCDD/PCDF) and hexachlorobenzene (HCB) to levels below 1990 or an alternative year between 1985 and 1995.  These amendments to the Protocol are already largely covered by EU legislation and will be further transposed by means of a new Directive which will update national emission limit values for certain air pollutants and provide for national inventories of annual emissions. The draft Council decision lists the texts of the amendments to the Protocol through Decisions 2009/1 and 2009/2 in its annexes. Specific derogations and flexible transition timetablefor economies in transition should allow all Parties to comply with the Protocol

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This is a proposal to adopt a supplementary protocol to an international agreement to which the Member States and the EU have already acceded and are already taking into account. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on 'Adoption of the amendments to the 1998 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution on Persistent Organic Pollutants'. Heavy metal and pollutant emissions have a permanent negative impact on human health and the environment. These substances do not border on them, which is why international cooperation is required to introduce effective measures to protect our health and environment. The protocols established in 1998 try to achieve just that, for example by clarifying, for example, national emission limits. In other words, the protocols are tools to help Europe control emissions.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Similarly, I supported Mr La Via's recommendation to accept the amendments to the Protocol on Obsessive Organic Pollutants of 1998 to the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution. As in the case of cross-border air pollution, this amendment is moving in the right direction.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to control and reduce the damage caused by cross-border air pollution to human health and the environment. This report refers to one of the eight protocols of the Convention on Long-Range Cross-Border Air Pollution. Specifically, it refers to the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on Persistent Organic Pollutants and proposes an amendment based mainly on the application of stricter limits on particulate emissions from major stationary sources and greater flexibility in transitional arrangements. I support this report, as I believe that the amendments to the Convention it proposes serve to further defend social welfare and the environment, while its objective lies in reducing pollution caused by persistent organic pollutants.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the amendments to the Protocol, which will be further transposed by the new Directive, which will set updated national emission ceilings for certain air pollutants and allow the introduction of annual national emission inventories covering, inter alia, emissions of certain persistent organic pollutants. The measures will make an important contribution to the protection of the human environment and health.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Ukraine.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time like the one europe is currently going through, cooperating in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, is indeed a necessity. The security of European citizens must be one of the European Union's priorities, so the agreements between Eurojust and third countries are perfectly part of today's changed geopolitical order. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the proposal to approve an agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Ukraine.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report would ratify an agreement between the Eurojust agency, which specializes in the fight against organized crime and terrorism, and Ukraine through police collaboration and data exchange. It should be remembered that Ukraine is a state where the human rights of the population are systematically violated and whose current government has passed measures that violate the rights of the Russophone population, and has even outarmed left-wing symbols and political parties. We have opposed its approval by being radically opposed to strengthening our relations with Ukraine at a time like the current one where there is a conflict in the country following the 2014 coup d'am with European and American support. This agreement responds to a geopolitical interest of the European Union in strengthening its ties with the Ukrainian authorities and trying to isolate Russia that we will not support.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the draft Council implementation decision, which approved Eurojust's conclusion of the Eurojust cooperation agreement with Ukraine. While this text aims to approve an agreement on judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, it also provides for the exchange of information including personal data.  This last provision is unacceptable to me.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We abstained on this report. Ukraine currently possesses a poor human rights record, which includes questions over access to fair trials and other procedural rights, and now is therefore not the time to enhance judicial cooperation. If the rights of defence are absent, decent prison conditions lacking and basic rights not respected or implemented in national law, why should we then conclude agreements in the judicial sphere with this country?  Furthermore, the Commission proposed a Eurojust Regulation giving the European Parliament a bigger role in drafting cooperation agreements; however, this agreement was just presented for consultation. These factors combined made it impossible for us to support this report. We therefore abstained.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this agreement, as I think it is important to support Eurojust's work in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. This Agreement launches cooperation between Ukraine and Eurojust as part of judicial cooperation between European countries

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we oppose a cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine that would require greater judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime.  We are particularly opposed to the cooperation arrangements between Eurojust and Ukraine, including the exchange of personal data. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I do not believe that the European Union should be negotiating agreements on behalf of the elected government of the United Kingdom. This report is essentially allowing the expansion of the European Union’s power by beginning the accession process for Ukraine.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this cooperation agreement, as it aims to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and judicial cooperation in Europe. Eurojust's operational cooperation with Ukraine is necessary: it facilitates the fight against serious forms of crime and helps to strengthen judicial cooperation, particularly with regard to terrorism.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to support the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, which aims to improve judicial cooperation to combat serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, for example by seconding a liaison officer to Eurojust and exchanging information containing personal data. I agree that, in order to strengthen the fight against cross-border crime and to improve judicial cooperation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for Eurojust to cooperate with Ukraine. I support the conclusion of this cooperation agreement with Ukraine, which would help to combat serious crime and also contribute to improving judicial cooperation, in particular in the fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Ukraine

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The draft agreement includes provisions for cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data.  This last point did not seem acceptable to me and believing that the conditions were not there to further strengthen our cooperation with Ukraine, I voted against this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Parliament is here consulted by the Council on the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime and corruption. This agreement includes detailed provisions for operational cooperation between partners, such as the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information. I have endorsed this positive opinion proposed by the rapporteur because the cooperation agreement must enable judicial cooperation to be intensified in the fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Broadening EU action in the fight against terrorism and organised crime must be a priority, which is why I have today voted in favour of the Kauffman report on the draft Council decision approving the conclusion of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. The text of the agreement, which is of a technical nature, provides for a strengthening of the process of exchange of information and various operational provisions such as the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer. In general, this text represents an opportunity to strengthen the Union's action, which is why I supported the report.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We abstained on the recommendation of the rapporteur of the GUE/NGL Group, who considers it risky to support a judicial cooperation agreement with countries with serious violations of human rights and procedural rights, taking into account, moreover, that the European Parliament has had no option to participate in the drafting of the agreements.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this report on the draft Council Implementation Decision approving Eurojust's conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine with a view to strengthening organised crime and terrorism. This draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation, for example the sending by Ukraine of a liaison officer on commission of services to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, particularly organised crime and terrorism, is a laudable intention.  Interesting avenues are envisaged such as the posting of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust. However, the exchange of information, including personal data, seems unacceptable to me. The protection of personal data and the respect of the privacy of individuals are fundamental major rights. There is a need to maintain a balanced approach between strengthening the security of European citizens and safeguarding human rights, particularly with regard to the protection of personal data.  So I decided to vote against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While I believe that it is essential to conclude agreements between Eurojust and third countries aimed at strengthening the fight against transnational crime, I do not share the positions held in this text, which is addressed to Ukraine. In view of the delicate geopolitical situation that is taking place and the fact that the EU has been in a territorial dispute between third countries, even going so far as to decide on economic sanctions against Russia, which have caused enormous damage to our businesses and to the production of our territories, I did not intend to support this text and abstained.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have chosen to abstain. Eurojust is an EU body whose aim is to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, and in this case it is a question of changing personal data. The Left Party is against Eurojust as such, but votes for cooperation when countries themselves want to enter. However, the situation in Ukraine is tense and it has repeatedly violated human rights, including with regard to the right to judicial proceedings, and that is why we are choosing to abstain in this vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal to give the green light to the conclusion of a Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organized crime and terrorism. Among other aspects, this agreement provides for the sending by Ukraine of a liaison officer on commission of services to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. The conclusion of the agreement has also received the approval of the Eurojust Joint Supervisory Authority, which pointed out that all Eurojust's amendments to the draft agreement have been taken into account, further stressing that all issues relating to the independence of the competent supervisory authority have been satisfactorily resolved by transferring the tasks to the Ombudsman , which enjoys full independence in accordance with the Constitution of Ukraine.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. The aim of this agreement is to improve judicial cooperation to combat serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, for example by seconding a liaison officer to Eurojust and exchanging information containing personal data. Ukraine has acceded to the Council of Europe Convention for the Protection of Individuals with regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data and to the Protocol to this Convention on data flows crossing the borders of supervisors and states. In this respect, the Joint Supervisory Body pointed out that the issue of the independence of the competent supervisory authority in Ukraine had been adequately addressed by entrusting these tasks to the Ombudsman, who is guaranteed full operational independence under the Ukrainian constitution.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 This report concerns the proposal to approve the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, which aims to enhance judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine. In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and enhance judicial cooperation within Europe, eurojust's cooperation with Ukraine is clearly needed from a practical point of view. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. Members have majorityly supported the approval of the Eurojust-Ukraine agreement. Especially in this politically unstable country, the assistance of the European authorities in prosecuting serious crime and terrorism is more than welcome. The exchange of information, the deployment of a liaison officer from Ukraine to Eurojust and the greater independence of the competent supervisory authority are key advantages of this cooperation. This also strengthens judicial cooperation throughout Europe in the area of serious criminality and terrorism.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I am of course always in favour of any measure to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism, but I am vehemently opposed to the exchange of information involving personal data. That is what this report provides. Therefore I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine has many positive aspects in many respects. Indeed, this agreement, on the one hand, provides support to Ukraine by bringing it even closer to the EU and, on the other, it is an important tool in the fight against terrorism.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to strengthen the fight against international crime and to improve judicial cooperation in Europe, it is useful to activate the cooperation agreement between the Joint Supervisory Authority Eurojust and the Ukrainian Republic. The European Parliament must be in favour of concluding this cooperation agreement with Ukraine because – because of the seriousness with which the bilateral dialogue has been conducted and because of the implications, including political implications, it entails – it is an aid and support for the fight against the serious forms of crime that characterise many territories in Eastern Europe and would help to strengthen judicial cooperation between the Two. , in particular in the field of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This proposal concerns the approval of an agreement between Europol and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against criminal networks as well as terrorism. This report includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of a liaison officer to Eurojust but above all the exchange of information, including personal data.  We strongly oppose the European Union's desire to permanently strengthen its influence with third countries. It is therefore our duty to protect these countries from the interference of the European institutions in their national affairs. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crimes and strengthen judicial cooperation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for Eurojust to cooperate with Ukraine. In this context, the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and that country is an important step in combating serious forms of crime and corruption. In view of the need for this agreement, I was in favour of the report on the draft decision implementing the Council approving Eurojust's conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. It contains detailed provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment by Ukraine of a liaison officer to Eurojust and exchanges of information.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 This series of agreements between Eurojust and third countries is mainly aimed at strengthening the fight against transnational crime. However, as far as Ukraine is involved and in view of the delicate geopolitical situation and in order to avoid exploitation towards a state that is not really democratic or respectful of the agreements made on gas, I am abstaining.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 Ukraine is one of the european Union's main eastern partners. What deeply links this state to the EU is its pro-Western vision, which is also at the root of the armed conflict between Ukraine and the pro-Russian rebels. With the entry into force of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area on 1 January 2016, the Ukrainian Government continues its European course, but relations with Russia and the creation of peace in the area remain complicated. In this regard, I am convinced that Ukraine will follow its pro-Western path, as there is a political will in this regard supported by a pro-European public opinion. The signing of the Memorandum of Understanding between the European Parliament and the Supreme Rada of Ukraine of 3 July 2015 creates the common framework for parliamentary support and capacity-building of Rada.  However, the relationship between the EU and Ukraine is not just about support, characterised by close collaboration. In this respect, the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine aims to strengthen judicial cooperation in order to combat serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. I believe that the implementation of this agreement is timely for both parties.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving eurojust's conclusion of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. The aim of this project is to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of organised crime, in particular criminal and terrorist associations, including through ukraine's secondment of a liaison officer to Eurojust and the automatic exchange of information, including personal data. The cooperation agreement with Ukraine is an aid and support to the fight against serious crime and helps to strengthen judicial cooperation, particularly in the field of organised crime and terrorism. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the text.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Ukraine.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
