text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament was consulted on the conclusion of the agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine which aims to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The text of the agreement, if signed, will cover not only the exchange of information but also very operational aspects, such as the secondment by Ukraine of a liaison prosecutor to Eurojust. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report aimed at strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and corruption. There is a clear operational need for Eurojust to cooperate with Ukraine in order to combat transnational crime and strengthen judicial cooperation in Europe.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine has particular implications for the lives and freedoms of millions of citizens. Although the extension of cooperation between States is positive in nature and can bring very important results in the field of crime, we cannot support any initiative without ensuring the protection of citizens' individual rights. I therefore think we need to deepen the debate and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine because I am convinced that there is an operational need to improve judicial cooperation in combating serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The measure establishes cooperation between the Ukrainian National Authority and Eurojust, which takes the form of a number of measures, including the secondment of national experts to the European institutions and the exchange of data.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 If the legal systems reason in compartments, there are people who commit crimes, the damaged people report, provided they have confidence in the system, the investigators investigate and, in case they manage to accumulate evidence, we move on to punishment. In order to defuse this chain, care must be taken to prevent the consumption of crime and one of the mandatory steps is to try to stop people inclined to commit crimes within the borders of the state. In other words, we must avoid importing crime. An agreement with neighbouring countries to improve their legal systems, which is included in this perspective, is a good way to cooperate and, on the basis of these considerations, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ A cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine would reinforce judicial cooperation in the combat against serious crime and corruption. The agreement would see operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the temporary transfer of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust. The exchange of information would also be encouraged. This cooperation mechanism would aid in the combat against serious crime whilst also enhancing judicial coordination on organised crime and terrorism.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Ukraine.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Eurojust is an essential part of European judicial cooperation, developing its work mainly in the field of cross-border organised crime and terrorism. Its support for Member States lies, inter among others, in the ability to collect and analyse information, as well as in the articulation of cross-border investigations. In this context, Eurojust also cooperates with third countries. Such cooperation is generally the result of its geographical proximity to the Union or of the importance for the agency's material scope of action. It is in this context that this cooperation agreement with Ukraine has been signed. After the protection of data by the Joint Control Body and its usefulness and legality by the College of Eurojust, Parliament, as a co-legislator, gives its political assent to the conclusion of the Agreement.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because the cooperation agreement promotes cross-border crime and judicial cooperation in Europe as well. Crimes do not stop at borders, so I believe that the agreement is an effective means of combating serious crime and corruption.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Ukraine.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft concerns the proposal to approve a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine with the aim of improving judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. There are provisions concerning operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine such as: the exchange of information (including personal data) or the secondment by Ukraine of a liaison officer to Eurojust. This type of judicial cooperation between the European Union and third countries supports and helps the difficult fight against the various forms of transnational crime, so I felt I had to vote in favour.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and corruption, is important to ensure citizens’ safety. I agree with the provisions concerning the operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of a liaison officer by Ukraine to Eurojust.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the draft Council implementing decision on the proposal to approve an agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, with the aim of improving judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions concerning operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as ukraine's secondment of a liaison prosecutor to Eurojust and the exchange of information. Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland shall participate in the adoption and application of the Decision. I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report would ratify an agreement between the Eurojust agency, which specializes in the fight against organized crime and terrorism, and Ukraine through police collaboration and data exchange. It should be remembered that Ukraine is a state where the human rights of the population are systematically violated and whose current government has passed measures that violate the rights of the Russophone population, and has even outarmed left-wing symbols and political parties. We have opposed its approval by being radically opposed to strengthening our relations with Ukraine at a time like the current one where there is a conflict in the country following the 2014 coup d'am with European and American support. This agreement responds to a geopolitical interest of the European Union in strengthening its ties with the Ukrainian authorities and trying to isolate Russia that we will not support.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal to approve the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine aims to enhance judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of the liaison officer delegated by Ukraine to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. Eurojust's cooperation with Ukraine is clearly necessary from an operational point of view in order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and to enhance judicial cooperation within Europe. Eurojust may conclude agreements with third countries or international organisations after approval by a qualified majority of the Council, after parliament has given its approval. Today, Parliament approved the Council's draft cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, as it helps and strengthens the fight against serious crime and contributes to enhancing judicial cooperation, particularly in the areas of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of the cooperation agreements under consideration between Eurojust and Ukraine and Montenegro is to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The Agreements contain provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine and Montenegro, such as the posting by Ukraine and Montenegro of a liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. These cooperation agreements with Ukraine and Montenegro will support and strengthen the fight against serious crime and contribute to improving judicial cooperation, in particular in the area of organised crime and terrorism. With this in mind, I voted in favour of the agreements.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal in question concerns the approval of an agreement of cooperation between Ukraine and Eurojust in order to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime in various aspects. Changes were made with regards to the exchange of information which could include personal data, as Ukraine is a party to the Council of Europe Convention of 28 January 1981 on the Protection of Individuals with regards to the Automatic Processing of Personal Data and additional protocols. The agreement seeks to strengthen the European Union’s fight against organised and cross-border crime, specifically the fight against terrorism. For this reason I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, which allows for the mutual exchange of information and the secondment of liaison officers or liaison magistrates to Eurojust. Cooperation of this kind is vital to tackle cross-border serious crime both within and outside the European Union. I am also satisfied with Eurojust’s Joint Supervisory Body’s positive opinion on the data protection provisions in this agreement. In order for international cooperation in the fight against crime to be successful it is imperative that law-abiding citizens have confidence in the safety of their own personal data under these agreements.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. In this consultation report, the European Parliament approves the eurojust-Ukraine cooperation agreement, with the aim of strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism.  The agreement provides for operational measures to facilitate cooperation on the ground, such as the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the sharing of information. The exchange of personal data will be authorized after consultation with the joint data protection supervisory authority and the Approval of the Council. Considering that strengthening the Union's external borders in the fight against terrorism requires better cooperation with third border countries, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The conclusion of the agreement on cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine allows for a strengthening of essential relations in the fight against terrorism and organised crime.  That is why I support this text. Such an agreement allows the exchange of information between Eurojust and Ukraine, but also the detachment of officers or liaison magistrates to Eurojust.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 This decision approved a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine in order to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and corruption. I voted in favour of this agreement because I believe it is essential to prevent and combat criminal realities that only the exchange of information between security systems can guarantee.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution to strengthen judicial cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine. It is necessary, in fact, to intensify the fight against serious forms of crime, particularly in the area of organised crime and terrorism. In particular, I support the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the increased exchange of information, including personal data.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. In order to better combat organised crime and terrorism, it is proposed to approve cooperation between Europol and Ukraine, including exchanges of information, some of which are personal. This is a further step backwards in terms of the guarantee of civil liberties, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 In this world where transnational crime is already becoming a daily occurrence, I cannot help but support this report. Any agreement that is driven by a desire to fight serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, will always meet my approval. Moreover, when talking about countries where there are Bulgarians, such as Ukraine.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Operational cooperation in matters of a judicial nature between EUROJUST and the respective Ukrainian authorities cannot be implemented because of the continued interference of the illegal Ukrainian Government in the judiciary. The ombudsman to whom the duties of the competent supervisory authority have been transferred is not a guarantee of compliance with legality, cessation of interference and, in particular, protection of personal information.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 This document concerns the proposal for the adoption of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, including organised crime and terrorism.  In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and judicial cooperation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for collaboration between Eurojust and Ukraine. I am in favour of concluding this cooperation agreement with Ukraine, as it supports and intensifies the fight against serious forms of crime, and also contributes to strengthening judicial cooperation, in particular in the fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because certain provisions, such as the transfer of personal data, have nothing to do with the fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims at the adoption of the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, under the pretext of intensifying judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, including organised crime and terrorism. The Agreement provides for provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the posting by Ukraine of a liaison officer for Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. Entities such as Eurojust, which escapes democratic and judicial control, are centralised, structured and reinforced, beyond guarantees as to the rights and freedoms provided for in national legislative and constitutional frameworks. Among other things, these initiatives are part of a security drift that increasingly puts fundamental rights, freedoms and guarantees at risk. It should also be noted the worsening situation in Ukraine and the profound hypocrisy and complicity of the US, the EU and NATO, in the face of the wave of provocations, instigation of violence, violations of freedoms and rights and crimes perpetrated by the ultranationalist and fascist forces in this country, of which citizens who oppose forces and coup power have been victims. There is an urgent need for denunciation and vehement repudiation which is not consistent with this proposal. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft implementing decision for a cooperation agreement between Eurojust, Ukraine and Montenegro, in order to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and corruption. I believe that effective and operational cooperation between European agencies and states is the right way to deal with the terrorist threat to all actors on the international stage. The European Union must make its voice heard and take concrete action in this direction.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the European Union has taken a number of crucial decisions with regard to Ukraine in the past. This proposal concerns the strengthening of judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. It also contains provisions on operational cooperation between Ukraine and Eurojust, including the secondment of a liaison officer from Ukraine to Eurojust or the exchange of information, including personal data. Cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine aims to strengthen the fight against transnational crime.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the vote as the EU should review its foreign policy in the area between Ukraine and Russia before concluding new agreements.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Operational cooperation in matters of a judicial nature between EUROJUST and the respective Ukrainian authorities cannot be implemented because of the continued interference of the illegal Ukrainian Government in the judiciary. The ombudsman to whom the duties of the competent supervisory authority have been transferred is not a guarantee of compliance with legality, cessation of interference and, in particular, protection of personal information. For these reasons I am voting against the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The draft agreement limits the transfer of personal data between the parties and includes a number of specific safeguard provisions. Onward transmission of such personal data is not possible without the written consent of the other party.  It is important that we continue to support the work of Eurojust, as it will play a key role if the EU wants to enhance its judicial cooperation to tackle organised crime and terrorism.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report in support of the cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine, which will strengthen and intensify judicial cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. While the work of the Eurojust agency is mainly based on coordination between the various Member States and the other European institutions, the scope and scale of the current threats make international cooperation with our partners, including Ukraine, more indispensable than ever.  This agreement includes provisions on the exchange of information, including the exchange of personal data, and on the posting of officers and liaison magistrates to the agency, for a more coordinated response. Finally, this agreement is more broadly in the strengthening of our partnership with Ukraine and remains an additional means of supporting Ukraine on the path of reform.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we approve the conclusion of the operational cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. This agreement has the objective of enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, through the exchange of information, including personal data.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns the proposal to approve the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, which aims to enhance judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of the liaison officer delegated by Ukraine to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. I welcome this initiative because, in my view, eurojust's cooperation with Ukraine is clearly necessary from an operational point of view in order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and enhance judicial cooperation within Europe.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal with the intention of strengthening judicial cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organized crime and terrorism. There is no doubt that, in order to achieve the objective of strengthening the fight against transnational crime and strengthening judicial cooperation in Europe, Eurojust needs to cooperate with Ukraine.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, as I consider strengthening judicial cooperation beyond the EU's borders to be an important and useful instrument.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I welcome greater judicial cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine. Serious crime and the dangers of terrorism can now be combated even more effectively.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which concerns the proposed approval of cooperation agreements between Eurojust and Ukraine, with the aim of enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Errare humanum est, perseverare diabolicum. Just over a year ago, the EU signed an association agreement with Ukraine covering very broad economic and political areas, including visa liberalisation for workers, or substantial financial assistance. Less for the good of Ukraine, that the march towards ultra-liberalism in Brussels will end up disorganizing, than to provoke Russia. This agreement is still not ratified by all Member States, including the Netherlands, under popular pressure, being obliged to hold a referendum on the subject in April. According to the polls, 75% of the Dutch population is hostile to this association. The IMF, the country's main donor, is threatening to cut off food supplies, as corruption is endemic and the fight against it is anemic. We are now being offered a judicial cooperation agreement that includes data exchanges, including personal data, with this country. Without any guarantee, of course, that the Ukrainian authorities are in a way to ensure that it is used in accordance with European criteria. I voted against this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained on the recommendation of the rapporteur of the GUE/NGL Group, who considers it risky to support a judicial cooperation agreement with countries with serious violations of human rights and procedural rights, taking into account, moreover, that the European Parliament has had no option to participate in the drafting of the agreements.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On the draft Implementing Decision of the Council approving the conclusion by EUROJUST of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine and Montenegro.  Organised crime and terrorism are topical and important topics for europe as a whole. We are constantly learning about the growing number of criminal organisations and attacks that are destroying and intimidating European society.   These phenomena must be strongly opposed.  The strengthening of operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine and Montenegro, and in particular the appointment by both countries of a liaison officer to Eurojust, therefore deserves support. I am convinced that the steps taken under the agreement will strengthen Europe in the fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The role of Eurojust is important for the EU to enhance its judicial cooperation role and to tackle organised crime and terrorism, something which does not respect borders and something which we need to find transnational solutions to. Hence I think it is important to continue to support the work of Eurojust and this is why I voted in favour of the report today.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and the Ukraine, because it is imperative that Eurojust and the Ukraine work together in the fight against serious transnational crime, particularly organised crime and terrorism. This agreement would also enhance judicial co-operation, which is similarly necessary in this battle.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The agreement for which Parliament's approval is sought concerns judicial cooperation between the EU and Ukraine. In Ukraine there is a regime that condemns and makes illegal political parties, among them the KK Ukraine, leads people to prison purely for their political beliefs, and the EU wants to strengthen relations with it in the judicial field.  The agreement provides for the exchange of information including personal data that may be used by Ukraine to serve targets as recorded above. A regulation on Eurojust is also currently being promoted by the European Commission, proposing more powers to the EP in drafting these cooperation agreements. In this particular case, the EP simply asks for approval. That is why we are voting against this agreement and consider it, unfortunately, to be part of the wider geopolitical game being played in the region in an attempt to serve other purposes.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ The passing of the draft agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine would lead to increased judicial cooperation in combatting organised crime and terrorism. The benefits of such an agreement are many as it enhances European judicial collaboration and fulfils the operational need to fight transnational crime as mentioned by Rapporteur Jiří Maštálka. Given that the cooperation would only extend as far as the secondment of a liaison officer by Ukraine to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data, and, given that the Council will be required to consult Parliament when adopting implementing measures pursuant to Article 39(1) of the pre-Lisbon Treaty on European Union and in accordance with Article 9 of Protocol 36 , I have decided to vote in favour of the draft implementing decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of the Agreement on Cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the cooperation decision between Eurojust and Ukraine. Such an agreement is necessary for judicial consolidation in the fight against serious forms of crime and corruption.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on a draft Council decision authorising Eurojust to conclude the Eurojust-Ukraine Cooperation Agreement (11592/2015 - C8-0300/2015 - 2015/081 (CNS)), as I support the proposal for a Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and corruption, and given that there is a clear operational need for Eurojust's cooperation with Ukraine to combat transnational crime and strengthen judicial cooperation in Europe.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I refuse to approve a cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine that would be for greater judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime. I particularly reject the cooperation arrangements between Eurojust and Ukraine, including the exchange of personal data. Furthermore, I do not accept the possibility of having a Liaison Officer from Ukraine with Eurojust. As a result I vote against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Ukraine.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement between Eurojust, the European Union’s Judicial Cooperation Unit, and Ukraine aims at strengthening their cooperation in criminal matters, especially in fighting organised crime and terrorism.  Given the current terrorism threat looming over Europe, it is of great importance to me to enhance exchange of operational information with third countries. This agreement will help, for example, to accelerate or facilitate the execution of extradition and mutual legal assistance requests, to clarify legal requirements and relevant legislation. I am convinced this will enable us to fight organised crime more effectively within Europe, this is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann's report on the draft Council implementation decision approving Eurojust's conclusion of the Eurojust cooperation agreement. This is an approval procedure for operational and judicial cooperation between the Eurojust agency and the Ukrainian authorities.  The aim is to facilitate the exchange of data, since the independence of the agency responsible for processing this data in Ukraine has been validated. In addition, a Ukrainian liaison officer would be dispatched to Eurojust. Today, judicial cooperation is more important than ever. I therefore approved the effective establishment of closer cooperation between Ukraine and the European Union.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to approve the decision of operational and judicial cooperation between the euroJUST agency and the Ukrainian authorities. This cooperation will result in the exchange of personal information between Ukraine and the EU to combat the most serious forms of crime and corruption.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from this report, which deals with the fight against international crime, as I do not believe that there is currently a serious discussion with the Ukrainian Government in this regard.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I find the proposed cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine to be most important if we are to effectively set an example in fighting serious crime, particularly organised crime and terrorism. The agreement would also act as a catalyst for enhancement of judicial cooperation in the area of serious crime. I recognise how important such progress is for the safety of European citizens and states, and thus I support this report and its approval of a cooperation agreement.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the conclusion of the cooperation agreement, as it would aid and reinforce the fight against serious crime and would contribute to enhancing judicial co-operation in particular in the field of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The European Union is committed on a daily basis to combating organised crime and terrorism. I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal to approve the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, as it further strengthens judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and corruption. I welcome any bilateral or multilateral agreement aimed at preventing further strengthening of organised crime activities.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime. This proposed agreement includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. This last aspect above all is unacceptable to me. I am opposed to the systematic and widespread use of personal data of French citizens.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this proposed agreement because it includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the exchange of information, including personal data. I am opposed to this kind of exchange.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against it. The report sought to approve a judicial cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine, particularly in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. The operational provisions of this agreement are, for example, the posting of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust, the exchange of information, but above all also the exchange of personal data. This crucial point is unacceptable to me and to all the Members of our group, who are fighting every day to push back against this european Union objective.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Eurojust-Ukraine Cooperation Agreement as it aims to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism with measures such as Ukraine's admission of a liaison officer (fiscal) to Eurojust or the exchange of information , including data.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 Eurojust is a abolition office, a tax-eater for EUR 32 million per year. Combating international crime was also possible before and after the European Union, without unnecessary euro office. There is no need to add more states to this inefficient cooperation.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Agreement on Cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine is of utmost importance, in particular with regard to the fight against crime and corruption. This draft agreement contains provisions relating to operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the deployment of liaison officers by Ukraine to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. I supported Mp Kaufmann's report, because transnational cooperation between security-caring bodies today, when we witness the daily rise in crime and terrorism, is much needed.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement on cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine aims to promote judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement also contains the principles of operational information exchange and close cooperation, as well as gives Ukraine the opportunity to send its liaison officer to Eurojust. The new agreement is just one of a series of various agreements that have recently been adopted and whose primary objective is to intensive EU-Ukraine cooperation in the widest possible number of sectors. Consequently, given, in particular, the nature of the bilateral cooperation principles contained in this draft agreement, it should become another factor which, hopefully, will have a positive impact on the overall cooperation between the EU and Ukraine, as well as on Ukraine's internal reforms in the respective areas, thanks to some form of transfusion effect.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ I support the conclusion of this agreement between Ukraine and Eurojust. The agreement will help to detect serious transnational crime, corruption and the fight against terrorism. Cooperation between ukrainian investigative bodies and Eurojust will increase the efficiency of national investigative and judicial authorities and help combat international crime more effectively.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, because it is not complete and substantiated.  Furthermore, it enhances Ukraine's role and paves the way for Ukraine's possible future accession to the EU, a prospect with which I strongly disagree, as, among other things, a possible accession of Ukraine to the EU would be harmful to the Greek agricultural economy.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against this text. The aim here is to approve a cooperation agreement between Eurojust (Europe's justice cooperation agency) and Ukraine. The aim of this agreement is to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, especially in the context of the fight against terrorism. This agreement includes the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. It is this last point that prevents us from supporting this project: Europe should not have access to this information.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this proposal on cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine with the aim of enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. The aim of the proposal is to improve and strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious transnational crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The agreement would also help and support the fight against serious crime and would help to strengthen judicial cooperation in Europe, particularly in the field of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the rapporteur on stepping up the fight against organised crime and terrorism. Judicial cooperation between the EU and Ukraine will allow a new step in this direction. Nowadays, the exchange of information between competent authorities is fundamental in the fight against organised crime and terrorism which, as we know, has no geographical boundaries.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the Eurojust-Ukraine Cooperation Agreement in order to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organized crime and terrorism.  The EU and Ukraine have in recent years established important partnership agreements and these relations need to be strengthened every day, also, in this case, in judicial matters.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I take a critical view of the Eurojust agency. However, the report is positive about the fight against international crime. Unfortunately, there is no critical confrontation with the current Ukrainian government. I am abstaining from my voice.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I support the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. This agreement will help the officers responsible to combat serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. In addition, the agreement will facilitate cooperation between the courts of EU Member States and Ukraine.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This agreement authorizes cooperation between Eurojust, the European Agency for Judicial Cooperation, and Ukraine. It provides for the exchange of data between states in order to combat organised crime and terrorism in particular and facilitates the coordination of investigations and prosecutions in states. When it takes years for some third countries to negotiate cooperation agreements, for Ukraine everything goes much faster. Everything is good to reinforce an inept anti-Russian game, including with a country whose judicial system is particularly fallible, corrupt and in the service of a well-established oligarchy supported by neo-Nazis. Moreover, Parliament is simply consulted here and the decision will be applied anyway, the umpteenth proof of the semblance of European democracy. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I refuse to approve a cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine that would be for greater judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime. I particularly reject the cooperation arrangements between Eurojust and Ukraine, including the exchange of personal data. Furthermore, I do not accept the possibility of having a Liaison Officer from Ukraine with Eurojust. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because judicial cooperation between Ukraine and Eurojust helps the fight against organised crime and terrorism. An important facet of this resolution is enhancing the operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, including the exchange of information.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In the face of organised crime, terrorism, trafficking and corruption, it is essential that the Union register its action in an international framework with particular attention to its neighbouring countries. By adopting the eurojust-Ukraine cooperation agreement, the EU is strengthening its judicial mechanism. The new liaison officer within Eurojust will make it possible to smooth the exchange of information and thus the effectiveness of our cooperation. The aim is common: to end impunity and to strengthen the security of European territory. I therefore encourage the Union and Eurojust to multiply this type of agreement with other third countries.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – Cooperation with Ukraine in the fight against serious crimes is very important. Ukraine borders the European Union, and we must work with neighbouring countries in many areas in the interests of our citizens. Especially today, when terrorist attacks in Europe are a harsh reality, I consider the eurojust-Ukraine agreement to be another crucial step towards reducing organised crime on the European continent. I welcome the proposal for a legislative resolution tabled and share the rapporteur's assertion that concluding this agreement would help and strengthen the fight against serious crime. Agreements and contracts of a similar nature must be concluded as far as possible.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my approval to a draft Cooperation Agreement to be entered into between Eurojust and Ukraine, in particular to the draft Council decision approving the draft agreement. It is important that we continue to support the work of Eurojust, as it will play a key role if the EU wants to enhance its judicial cooperation to tackle organised crime and terrorism.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council adopted a draft implementing decision approving the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. The agreement aims to enhance judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. Eurojust's joint supervisory body approved the draft agreement. The Council is obliged to consult Parliament on the draft. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs notes in its report that, in order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and enhance judicial cooperation within Europe, there is a clear operational need for eurojust-Ukraine cooperation, and therefore recommends that Parliament approve the Council's draft. I supported the proposal accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The proposal is for the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. Proposals include the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. This last aspect above all is unacceptable to us.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with the proposal for the adoption of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, including organised crime and terrorism.  I support closer and more effective cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine with the aim of strengthening the fight against transnational crime and judicial cooperation in Europe. This report is in my favour in combating serious forms of crime, and it also contributes to strengthening judicial cooperation, in particular in the field of combating organised crime and terrorism.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The proposal under consideration is for the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. This proposed agreement includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. This last aspect above all is unacceptable, so I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the agreement on operational and judicial cooperation between the Eurojust agency and the Ukrainian authorities. The aim is to better combat crime by promoting the exchange of information and by authorising the secondment of Ukrainian liaison officers to Eurojust. Eurojust's mission is to strengthen the effectiveness of national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases of serious cross-border crime and organised crime and to bring criminals to justice quickly and effectively.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the decision to implement the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine to enable greater judicial cooperation between the parties. The agreement will include the exchange of information, as well as the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the proposal for approval, concerning the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, as it further strengthens judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and corruption. The measure establishes cooperation between the Ukrainian National Authority and Eurojust, which takes the form of a number of measures, including the secondment of national experts to the European institutions and the exchange of data.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine with the aim of enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. I have voted for this report that will reinforce the fight against transnational crime and enhance judicial cooperation in Europe.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the approval of the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, which aims to deepen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and corruption. I believe that this agreement can make a major contribution to tackling the problem of corruption that Ukraine has been facing for a long time and which is a burden both from an internal political point of view and from the point of view of its approach to the EU. This is a much-needed helping hand given to Ukraine and a testament to the strength of the link between Ukraine and the EU.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. In principle, I am opposed to the Eurojust agency, but the report calls for a stronger fight against international crime. Moreover, there is no critical confrontation with the current Ukrainian government. That is why I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine is necessary in order to strengthen the fight against international crime, in particular in the field of terrorism and organised crime, and to enhance judicial cooperation in Europe.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. Organised crime and terrorism do not stop the EU's external borders and are increasingly becoming international.  In this context, it is essential to develop opportunities for cooperation and to implement adequate measures at regional level. The operational efficiency of the competent authorities of the Member States in the fight against serious transnational and organised crime needs to be strengthened.  More cooperation with other important third countries, in particular those with borders with the EU, and other actors and international organisations in the region, is therefore necessary. It is necessary to enable the fight against organised crime to be combated more effectively and to ensure adequate protection of people against international crime and terrorism and to prevent the potential harm to the social and economic life of European society.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Ukraine.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, is a key issue for the European Union. I am confident that the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine will improve legal cooperation in the fight against these forms of crime.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The Agreement on Ukraine-Eurojust cooperation is aimed at developing partnership in the judicial area, especially in fighting organised crime and terrorism. I firmly believe that tackling these issues is essential for building a stronger European community. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ With current geostrategic trends, security and neighbourhood development is of key importance. In this way, the EU should continue its efforts to provide Ukraine with means to accelerate its reform process and convergence towards the EU. Eurojust, an agency of the European Union dealing with judicial co-operation in criminal matters, will add more stability for both Ukraine and the EU in those matters.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report on the Council's draft implementing decision authorising Eurojust to conclude a Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, as it aims to increase legislative cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised and terrorism. Ukraine is an important partner here because of its geostrategical position with which the European Union will better coordinate investigations and prosecutions in the future when it comes to cross-border and organised crime.  I believe that cooperation between Ukraine and Eurojust will improve the effectiveness of investigative and judicial authorities in both Ukraine and all Member States of the European Union in cases of terrorism, trafficking in human beings, illicit drug trafficking, fraud and money laundering, in order to bring perpetrators of organised cross-border crime to justice quickly and effectively. The security of people, both citizens of the European Union and those outside it, must come first, as must the protection and existence of democratic principles and fundamental freedoms and human rights that the existence of organised crime, and in particular terrorism, greatly undermines.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The proposal under consideration is for the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. This proposed agreement includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, including in particular the exchange of information, including personal data. This last aspect above all is unacceptable to me. I therefore speak out against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. In particular, this is an operational judicial cooperation between the two parties, in particular in the form of an exchange between prosecutors and information including personal data, which was also green-lighted by the Joint Supervisory Authority.  Furthermore, the problems relating to the independence of the competent authorities in Ukraine have been satisfactorily addressed by transferring these tasks to the Ombudsman as a fully independent body. This agreement strengthens the fight against organised crime and terrorism, but also judicial cooperation in Europe in general, which is particularly important in the case of Ukraine given the complex political situation in this country.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft agreement provides for provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine under the pretext of intensifying judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, including organised crime and terrorism. Entities such as Eurojust, which escapedemocratic and judicial control, are centralised, structured and strengthened, overcoming guarantees as to the rights and freedoms provided for in national legislative and constitutional frameworks. This goes beyond free and sovereign cooperation between national states, and progress is made with the creation of supranational control mechanisms, initiatives that fall into a security drift that increasingly puts fundamental rights, freedoms and guarantees at risk. An agreement concluded in the event of aggravation of the situation in Ukraine, in the face of the wave of provocations, instigation of violence, violations of freedoms and rights and crimes perpetrated by ultranationalist and fascist forces in this country, of which citizens who oppose forces and coup power have been victims, in the face of the posture of deep hypocrisy and complicity of the UNITED STATES , the EU and NATO. There is an urgent need for denunciation and vehement repudiation of that reality, which is not consistent with this proposal. By the above vote against.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I fully support Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann's report on the council's draft implementing decision authorising Eurojust to conclude the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. Cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine is of significant importance, in particular with regard to broba against serious crime and corruption.  The cooperation agreement precisely encourages this type of cooperation and contains detailed commissions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the transfer of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of data. Article 26a (2) Eurojust decisions dictate that the Council must approve such agreements with third countries or international organisations. Article 39(1) of the Lisbon version of the Agreement on European Union states that Parliament must be consulted on such approval.  Eurojust's operational need to work with Ukraine to combat transnational crime and strengthen judicial cooperation in Europe is clear. Consequently, I agree with the aforementioned report.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of concluding the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. This agreement is an aid and support aimed at improving judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The joint text provides for the secondment by Ukraine of a liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of wars and instability, events in Eastern Europe have ceased to be at the heart of the interests of many European political elites. However, it is Ukraine that, on the one hand, is still struggling with Russian aggression and separatist tendencies, but on the other hand it is going through a very difficult and complex period of reform and transformation. It is the European Union's duty to assist the Ukrainian Government and the people in the democratic and free direction of their country. One possibility is the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, which has significant positive potential for both the Ukrainian judiciary and Pan-European cooperation. One of the cornerstones of democracy is a functioning, fair and independent rule of law and judiciary. I therefore support the agreement's efforts to deepen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, particularly organised crime and terrorism, as these threats do not only concern Ukraine, but nevertheless have a Pan-European impact. I believe that the agreement will help cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine and will prevent as much transnational crime as possible, which unfortunately also applies to the States of the European Union. I also acknowledge with gratitude the sending of the Ukrainian representative to Eurojust and the future exchange of information. I support this proposal by the rapporteur, Sylvie-Yvonne Kaufmann, and I join the call on the Council to support this proposal.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report concerns the proposed approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine in order to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. This draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the posting by Ukraine of a liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data.  In accordance with Article 26a(2) of the Council Decision of 28 February 2002 establishing Eurojust, as last amended by Council Decision 2009/426/YSSW of 16 December 2008, it is for the Council to approve by qualified majority the agreements concluded by Eurojust with third countries or international organisations.  I support the conclusion of this cooperation agreement with Ukraine, as it will support and strengthen the fight against serious crime and will contribute to improving judicial cooperation, in particular in the area of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the cooperation agreement between Ukraine and the European agency Eurojust. Strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime is very beneficial, given that Ukraine is an important neighbour of the European Union and coordination of action can help detect crimes. The report therefore has my support.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. For us, it is a question of validating the principle of rapprochement between the Eurojust agency and its Ukrainian equivalent. This is an important step towards enhanced judicial cooperation, both in remote relations and on the ground.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Ukraine.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and judicial cooperation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for collaboration between Eurojust and Ukraine. This document concerns the proposal for the adoption of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, including organised crime and terrorism. This agreement provides for detailed provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the deployment by Ukraine of a liaison officer for Eurojust and the exchange of information, so I voted in favour of it.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The European Parliament today backed the Kaufmann report on the Eurojust-Ukraine cooperation agreement.  In the aftermath of the Paris attacks, the EU pointed to the lack of judicial cooperation between states.  The murder of pro-Russian journalist Oles Buzyna in Kiev in April 2015 helps to reinforce Ukraine's poor image on crime. According to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, 1,390 homicides were committed in the country in 2015, while Belgium had 125. The latest report from the Organized Crime Observatory found that drug trafficking and human trafficking remained frequent.  New challenges such as the increase in counterfeiting and cybercrime are becoming international and directly affecting the EU. Crime in all its forms is an attack on the fundamental principles on which the Union is based. There is an urgent need to strengthen judicial cooperation between states, which is essential to improve the fight against crime and terrorism that plague our present society.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal to give the green light to the conclusion of a Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organized crime and terrorism. Among other aspects, this agreement provides for the sending by Ukraine of a liaison officer on commission of services to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. The conclusion of the agreement has also received the approval of the Eurojust Joint Supervisory Authority, which pointed out that all Eurojust's amendments to the draft agreement have been taken into account, further stressing that all issues relating to the independence of the competent supervisory authority have been satisfactorily resolved by transferring the tasks to the Ombudsman , which enjoys full independence in accordance with the Constitution of Ukraine.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Today's vote was on the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime and corruption. This agreement includes detailed provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information. In accordance with Article 26 bis, paragraph 2, of the Eurojust decision, it is up to the Council to approve Eurojust's agreements with third countries or international organisations. In accordance with Article 39, paragraph 1, of the former Treaty on the European Union, the European Parliament must also be consulted on this approval. I voted in favour of this text because it seems clear to me that Eurojust's operational cooperation with Ukraine is necessary in order to combat transnational crime and to strengthen judicial cooperation in Europe.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine because I believe that this will help Ukraine to strengthen and better fight organised crime and terrorism. This is another step in which Ukraine is moving towards membership of the European Union. This cooperation will help Ukraine to improve its legal framework and exchange good practices. At the same time, this will allow us to see the fundamental differences between the European Union and Ukraine's systems and help them get closer together.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine is essential to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and promote greater judicial cooperation in Europe. With the aim of strengthening and cooperating in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular in the field of combating organised crime and terrorism, this agreement includes detailed provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, in particular as regards the control of border data flows and the exchange of various types of information. In view of the content of the premises contained in this Cooperation Agreement, I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives the European Parliament the approval of the Council's draft on the Eurojust-Ukraine cooperation agreement. The aim of this agreement is to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime and corruption. The aim is to deepen this operational cooperation with, for example, the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information. This agreement will facilitate and intensify the fight against serious forms of crime and help strengthen judicial cooperation, particularly in the area of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote is even more interesting in light of the government crisis that broke out in Kiev on Wednesday due to the resignation of the economy minister who he accused of no longer being able to continue working due to corruption and the predominated personal interests over those of the country. Thanks to the agreement, Eurojust will be able to cooperate with Ukraine on serious crimes and terrorism.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained on the recommendation of the rapporteur of the GUE/NGL Group, who considers it risky to support a judicial cooperation agreement with countries with serious violations of human rights and procedural rights, taking into account, moreover, that the European Parliament has had no option to participate in the drafting of the agreements.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. This cooperation agreement with Ukraine will support and strengthen the fight against serious crime and will contribute to improving judicial cooperation, in particular in the context of organised crime and terrorism. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the cooperation agreement between the EU agency Eurojust, which coordinates judicial cooperation in the EU, and Ukraine, as everything must be done to support this important neighbouring country in its fight against organised crime. The exchange of data and information is important, because this is the only way to cooperate effectively. It is also true that Ukraine is sending a liaison to Eurojust.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Written. Cooperation agreements between Eurojust and Ukraine are a welcome step towards making the fight against organised crime more effective. However, the ongoing occupation of Crimea and the war in eastern Ukraine complicate both opportunities for cooperation and the situation. The fight against trafficking in human beings for slave labour or sexual purposes has weakened and crimes have worsened with the conflict and occupation. This is particularly serious because Ukraine has long been one of the most common countries of origin, where the International Organisation for Migration has considered that more than 160 000 people have been victims of trafficking since 1991. This situation has now worsened as a result of the conflict in the eastern part of the country and the occupation of Crimea. I am convinced that the European Commission must do more and support Ukraine more precisely during the current conflict, if the fight against cross-border criminality is not to experience a backlash.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report would ratify an agreement between the Eurojust agency, which specializes in the fight against organized crime and terrorism, and Ukraine through police collaboration and data exchange. It should be remembered that Ukraine is a state where the human rights of the population are systematically violated and whose current government has passed measures that violate the rights of the Russophone population, and has even outarmed left-wing symbols and political parties. We have opposed its approval by being radically opposed to strengthening our relations with Ukraine at a time like the current one where there is a conflict in the country following the 2014 coup d'am with European and American support. This agreement responds to a geopolitical interest of the European Union in strengthening its ties with the Ukrainian authorities and trying to isolate Russia that we will not support.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text voted on today concerns the approval of the proposal for a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation, as well as the exchange of information and personal data. I have chosen to vote in favour of this report in order to increase the effectiveness in preventing and combating the most serious forms of international crime in Europe and Ukraine.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Ukraine.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The role of Eurojust is important for the EU to enhance its judicial cooperation role and to tackle organised crime and terrorism, something which does not respect borders and something which we need to find transnational solutions to. Hence I think it is important to continue to support the work of Eurojust and this is why I voted in favour of the report today.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ Eurojust must work with Ukraine to combat transnational crime and strengthen judicial cooperation in Europe. I therefore support the conclusion of the cooperation treaty between Eurojust and Ukraine and voted in favour. This will help and strengthen the fight against serious crime and contribute to improving judicial cooperation, in particular in the field of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ in support of national investigative bodies in serious crimes, Eurojust was created 14 years ago as a unit of the European Council. Initially, it was only an initiative of several countries, but the deterioration of the global situation linked to the terrorist attacks in the US in 2001 led member states to consolidate eurojust's position, which was gradually moved to The Hague. Eurojust is currently aiming to coordinate the cooperation of investigators and prosecutors in transnational crime cases. Its scope of action includes, in particular, terrorism, drug and human smuggling, money laundering, corruption, fraud or cybercrime. In addition to EU Member States, the Agency also seeks to cooperate with other countries in Europe. I therefore support Ukraine's accession to the cooperation agreement with Eurojust. This will strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular as regards organised crime and terrorism. Cooperation shall also include the agreement to send a liaison prosecutor from Ukraine to Eurojust to participate in the mutual exchange of information. Not only the EU, but also Ukraine must have a particular interest in investigating serious crime. Corruption in particular is a problem in today's situation of destabilised Ukraine, which the country will struggle with for a long time to come. Strengthening the fight against transnational crime and strengthening judicial cooperation across Europe is one of the tools to build mutual trust.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Eurojust is an organisation tasked with improving the effectiveness of national authorities responsible for investigation and law enforcement in dealing with serious forms of cross-border and organised crime and ensuring the swift and effective judicial treatment of criminals.  The report concerns the proposed approval of the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. The agreement would strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine.  For example, the Agreement provides for the secondment of a liaison officer from Ukraine to Eurojust and the exchange of information (e.g. exchange of personal data). The latter is the subject of controversy, but in my opinion they are not fully justified. Ukraine is a signatory to the Council of Europe Convention on the Protection of Individuals with regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data and its Protocol on Supervisory Authorities and Cross-border Data Transmission.  I believe that the agreement reached would help and strengthen the fight against serious crime, while also contributing to strengthening judicial cooperation. For the sake of this, I voted in plenary in favour of the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: In writing ‒ the agreement aims to promote and improve cooperation between member states' judicial authorities and Ukraine in the fight against serious terrorist activity. As Ukraine is also a strategically important neighbour for us, I am of the opinion that all steps must be taken towards political association and the gradual economic integration of Ukraine.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very happy to support the approval of the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. This agreement is a key step in the area of judicial cooperation in criminal matters. This is judicial cooperation in the fight against serious cross-border crime, particularly in the area of organised crime and terrorism. As shadow rapporteur for this agreement, I consider this new partnership to be very important. Ukraine is having a very difficult time, it is at war. It has long faced widespread corruption. In this situation, Ukraine undoubtedly needs a stable partner to help it stay on the path of progress and reform it has embarked on. Cooperation with Eurojust as an agency that increases the effectiveness of the authorities charged with investigating serious international and organised crime is, in my view, a very positive step forward. Both for Ukraine and for the EU.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ This decision proposes the approval of the Eurojust-Ukraine Cooperation Agreement to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and corruption. The agreement contains detailed provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the deployment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information. There is a clear operational need for Eurojust cooperation with Ukraine to combat transnational crime and strengthen judicial cooperation in Europe, and I have therefore supported the Cooperation Agreement.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which concerns the proposed approval of cooperation agreements between Eurojust and Ukraine, with the aim of enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime. I believe that these measures will aid in the fight against both serious organised crime and terrorism.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of a Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. In view of the increasing international crime that we are witnessing, the fight against organised crime must be intensified and therefore enhanced judicial cooperation between countries in Europe is urgently needed.  The Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine will strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and corruption. We need enhanced cooperation as many actors as possible if we are to achieve good results.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution approving the Council implementing decision approving Eurojust's conclusion of the Eurojust-Ukraine Cooperation Agreement, as this cooperation will further deepen cooperation between the EU and Ukraine in the field of combating organised crime or terrorism. Deepening judicial cooperation in these areas should also be encouraged in relations with non-EU countries. I also supported the conclusion of similar cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted against this report as it provided for Parliament's approval in judicial cooperation between the EU and Ukraine, which we are opposed to, as there is a regime of repression and violence in Ukraine at the moment. Political parties have been banned, including the KK, people are imprisoned and tortured every day, the historical rehabilitation and vindication of Ukrainian Nazis is sought, while at the same time they have entrusted the education of youth to members of fascist organisations.  The EU's stance on ukraine is yet another demonstration of its hypocritical behaviour in applying its values and ideals as they see fit. At the same time, the effort to further link up and cooperate with Ukraine is a continuation of their interventionist policy in the region in the interests of their geopolitical interests, which was launched with the support of the illegal coup d'état of right-wing and far-right circles. This agreement provides for the exchange of information, including personal data, which will lead to the targeting of hundreds of people who oppose the Ukrainian government's plans.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Operational cooperation in matters of a judicial nature between EUROJUST and the respective Ukrainian authorities cannot be implemented because of the continued interference of the illegal Ukrainian Government in the judiciary. The ombudsman to whom the duties of the competent supervisory authority have been transferred is not a guarantee of compliance with legality, cessation of interference and, in particular, protection of personal information.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the parliamentary approval of the agreement between Eurojust and the Ukrainian authorities allowing closer operational cooperation, convinced that this represents a significant Pan-European interest, in particular in the fight against cross-border organised crime. The intensive exchange of information envisaged in the Agreement and the deployment of a Ukrainian liaison officer alongside Eurojust can serve this well.
