As Vice-Chairman of the EP Association Committee on Ukraine, I specifically welcomed the fact that the agreement was based in part on legislative and administrative changes in the area of justice and data protection introduced by the Ukrainian Government on the basis of Eurojust's proposals. I am convinced that this agreement and the cooperation that is emerging on its basis are an important contribution to our joint efforts to democratise Ukraine and cooperate closely with the EU.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for this report. The proposal under consideration is the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. This proposed agreement includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement to reinforce the cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine. The agreement aims at increasing operational cooperation between the two, for instance through the exchange of information on organised crime and terrorism. Considering the international situation there is a clear operational need to fight transnational crime jointly with Ukraine and increase our judicial cooperation.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to intensify and improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, the conclusion of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine is crucial. Of the utmost importance is the secondment by Ukraine of a liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information and data.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted to conclude a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, as I believe there is a clear need for operational cooperation between Ukraine and Eurojust to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and improve judicial cooperation in Europe.  I believe that cooperation with each other will improve the effectiveness of national, investigative and judicial authorities in the face of cases of serious forms of cross-border and organised crime, such as terrorism, trafficking in human beings, illicit drug trafficking, fraud and money laundering. In addition, Eurojust will support competent authorities to improve the effectiveness of investigations and prosecutions.  Since I believe that the conclusion of the Eurojust cooperation agreement with Ukraine will enhance cooperation between the competent authorities, in particular by facilitating the implementation of international mutual legal assistance and the execution of the European arrest warrant, I supported the agreement.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of the Eurojust-Ukraine Cooperation Agreement. An agreement containing provisions on the exchange of personal information defining, in particular, the operational level of cooperation is necessary to strengthen the fight against international crime.  The agreement will also strengthen judicial cooperation between all Member States, which will mean a more effective fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, which today is a pressing problem throughout the Union.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ Cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine shall reinforce the fight against organised crime, terrorism, and transnational crime.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained on the recommendation of the rapporteur of the GUE/NGL Group, who considers it risky to support a judicial cooperation agreement with countries with serious violations of human rights and procedural rights, taking into account, moreover, that the European Parliament has had no option to participate in the drafting of the agreements.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I will support any measure that fights against violence and crime, that is why I agree to enhance judicial cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The proposal under consideration is for the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. This proposed agreement includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of a Ukrainian liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. This last aspect above all is unacceptable to us.  I voted against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns the proposal to approve the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, which aims to enhance judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of the liaison officer delegated by Ukraine to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. I voted in favour of the document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained on the recommendation of the rapporteur of the GUE/NGL Group, who considers it risky to support a judicial cooperation agreement with countries with serious violations of human rights and procedural rights, taking into account, moreover, that the European Parliament has had no option to participate in the drafting of the agreements.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – This proposal concerns the proposal to approve the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, which aims to improve judicial cooperation to combat serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, for example by seconding a liaison officer to Eurojust and exchanging information containing personal data.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the draft Council decision to formally approve the cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine. More specifically, this proposal concerns the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine with the aim to enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. This draft agreement contains provisions concerning the operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the secondment of a liaison officer by Ukraine to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. I voted in favour of the conclusion of this agreement because in order to reinforce the fight against transnational crime and to enhance judicial co-operation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for Eurojust to cooperate with Ukraine.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The agreement itself aims to increase judicial cooperation in the fight against organized crime and terrorism. We are therefore talking about an important issue for the fight against human trafficking networks and mafias operating in the European Union, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this agreement because better cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine will lead to a more efficient fight against cross-border crime, terrorism and organised crime.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft agreement provides for provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine, such as the deployment by Ukraine of a liaison officer for Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. Entities such as Eurojust, which escapes democratic and judicial control, are centralised, structured and reinforced, beyond guarantees as to the rights and freedoms provided for in national legislative and constitutional frameworks. This goes beyond free and sovereign cooperation between national states, and progress is made with the establishment of supranational control mechanisms over them. Among other things, these initiatives are part of a security drift that increasingly puts fundamental rights, freedoms and guarantees at risk. Moreover, as far as the worsening situation in Ukraine is concerned and the deep hypocrisy and complicity of the US, the EU and NATO in the face of the wave of provocations, instigation of violence, violations of freedoms and rights and crimes perpetrated by the ultranationalist and fascist forces in this country, of which citizens who oppose forces and coup power have been victims , denunciation and vehement repudiation which is not consistent with this proposal is urgently urgent.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I take a critical view of the Eurojust agency. However, the report is positive about the fight against international crime. Unfortunately, there is no critical confrontation with the current Ukrainian government. I am abstaining from my voice.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on Eurojust's agreement to conclude a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. I am opposed to the enlargement of the EU at this stage, because the EU must first solve its own deep problems before it can meaningfully accept other members. A cooperation agreement with a non-EU country is also a step towards membership. I also reject preparatory actions for accession. In particular, the EU should exercise foreign policy caution with regard to the conflict in Ukraine and refrain from any further interference.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. This draft agreement aims to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. It contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine. There is a clear operational need for Eurojust to cooperate with Ukraine in order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and judicial cooperation in Europe.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report on the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. I fully agree that it is essential that Eurojust cooperates with Ukraine in order to combat transnational crime, terrorism and improve judicial cooperation. I very much welcome the detailed provisions concerning, for example, the secondment of a liaent public prosecutor from Ukraine and the exchange of information. Only a genuinely high-quality and mutual exchange of information can make the fight against organised crime and terrorism more effective.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to approve the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine. The European Parliament has consultative power in these agreements and, in my opinion, the fulfilment by Ukraine of the conditions for concluding the agreement has been sufficiently demonstrated. These conditions included, in particular, the independence of the competent supervisory authority as well as ensuring the protection of individuals with regard to the automated processing of personal data. Once these conditions have been met, I consider that the conclusion of the agreement will be of particular benefit to the fight against serious crime and will contribute to improving judicial cooperation.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The fight against cross-border crime and terrorism requires close international cooperation. Cooperation with Ukraine is of particular importance here, especially in the context of the difficult internal and international situation in which our eastern neighbour has found itself.  Eurojust, as an agency of the European Union, aims to strengthen cooperation between Member States in the fight against international crime and needs effective tools to operate more widely and also outside the EU. We must bear in mind that many criminal groups are of a cross-border nature and operate on the territory of several countries, only some of which are EU Member States.  There is no doubt that Ukraine is currently a weak country that cannot properly monitor all threats to public policy and security. The conflict with Russia and Kiev's de facto lack of control over ukraine's eastern border pose a danger of increasing the activity of organised crime groups or smugglers. The threat of terrorism, which is heading to Europe with successive waves of illegal immigrants from the Middle East and Africa, remains relevant.  This agreement responds to these challenges and formalises cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine. The secondment of the liaison officer and the possibility of exchanging information, including personal data, will speed up the decision-making process and identify risks. This cooperation can also prove extremely valuable in the context of Ukraine's European ambitions

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the draft Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine as it will contribute to the operational strengthening of judicial cooperation in the fight against international crime.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Montenegro.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Improving judicial cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism is now more than ever a priority for the European Union. The only way to counter these threats is to establish collaborations with anyone who can help us in this fight. The draft agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, among other provisions, provides for montenegro to second a liaison prosecutor to Eurojust and, of course, to exchange information. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the report, in the hope that this cooperation will produce results both in the short term and in the long term.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Montenegro.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report would ratify an agreement between the Eurojust agency, which specializes in the fight against organized crime and terrorism, and Montenegro through police collaboration and data exchange. We abstained in the vote because, according to international organisations such as Fair Trials International, montenegro systematically violates the rights of persons accused of a crime, in addition to numerous allegations of torture and police violence and, therefore, we understand that we cannot reach judicial agreements with States that do not respect the standards of democratic rights and guarantees in justice that we claim.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the draft Council implementation decision, which approved Eurojust's conclusion of the eurojust cooperation agreement with Montenegro. While this text aims to approve an agreement on judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, it also provides for the exchange of information including personal data.  This last provision is unacceptable to me.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – On the Griesbeck report, we abstained. This report is similar to the Kaufmann report except that it concerns Montenegro. While Montenegro may not as be corrupt as Ukraine (listed at place 61, the same as Italy in the corruption index), to say that it has a well-functioning legal system that has full respect for human rights would be to give it too much credit. Montenegro is an official EU membership candidate country, but it has still some way to go.  Furthermore, the Commission proposed a Eurojust Regulation giving the European Parliament a bigger role in drafting cooperation agreements; however, this agreement was just presented for consultation. These factors combined made it impossible for us to support this report. We therefore abstained.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this agreement, as I think it is important to support Eurojust's work in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. This Agreement opens Montenegro and Eurojust cooperation as part of judicial cooperation between European countries

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I am opposed to the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Montenegro which would be to cooperate more judicially in the fight against serious forms of crime. In particular, I reject the cooperation arrangements between Eurojust and Montenegro, including the exchange of personal data. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I do not believe that the European Union should be negotiating agreements on behalf of the elected government of the United Kingdom. This report is essentially allowing the expansion of the European Union’s power by beginning the accession process for Montenegro.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. Crime and terrorism have no borders, which is why I voted in favour of this agreement, the result of a long work by my colleague Nathalie Griesbeck, which strengthens the fight against international crime and judicial cooperation in Europe. It is essential that Eurojust engages in cooperation with Montenegro to support and strengthen the fight against serious forms of crime and that it contributes to improving judicial cooperation, particularly with regard to organised crime and terrorism.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to support the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, which aims to improve judicial cooperation to combat serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, for example by posting a liaison officer to Eurojust and exchanging information containing personal data. I agree that, in order to strengthen the fight against cross-border crime and to improve judicial cooperation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for Eurojust to cooperate with Montenegro. I welcome the conclusion of this cooperation agreement with Montenegro, which would help to combat serious crime and also contribute to improving judicial cooperation, in particular in the fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report concerns the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro aimed at enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the secondment of a liaison prosecutor delegated to Eurojust by Montenegro and the exchange of information, including personal data. Eurojust contributes to re solving conflicts of jurisdiction where several Member States are in a position to prosecute a particular case. It facilitates the implementation of international judicial measures such as the European Arrest Warrant. It provides funding for the setting up and operational needs of joint investigation teams. In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and to enhance judicial cooperation within Europe, the reporter clearly considers eurojust's cooperation with Montenegro to be operationally necessary. This is indeed necessary, as there is a strong base for organised crime in Montenegro.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Montenegro.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The draft agreement includes provisions for cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the secondment of a Montenegro liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. This last point did not seem acceptable to me and believing that the conditions were not there to further strengthen our cooperation with Montenegro, I voted against this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Parliament is here consulted by the Council on the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime and corruption. The agreement includes detailed provisions for operational cooperation between partners, including information exchange. I have endorsed this positive opinion proposed by the rapporteur because the cooperation agreement must enable judicial cooperation to be intensified in the fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I supported the report on the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. The text largely contains operational measures aimed at strengthening cooperation between the Eu ropean Union and the Balkan country in judicial matters. Particular attention is paid to the issue of combating corruption and serious crime. Considering the agreement to be very positive and agreeing with its objectives, I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the Griesbeck report.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We abstained on the recommendation of the rapporteur of the GUE/NGL Group, who considers it risky to support a judicial cooperation agreement with countries with serious violations of human rights and procedural rights, taking into account, moreover, that the European Parliament has had no option to participate in the drafting of the agreements.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this report on the draft Council Implementation Decision approving Eurojust's conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro with a view to strengthening organised crime and terrorism. This draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation, for example the sending by Montenegro of a liaison prosecutor on commission of services to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, particularly organised crime and terrorism, is a laudable intention.  Interesting avenues are envisaged such as the secondment of a Montenegro liaison officer to Eurojust. However, the exchange of information, including personal data, seems unacceptable to me. The protection of personal data and the respect of the privacy of individuals are fundamental major rights. There is a need to maintain a balanced approach between strengthening the security of European citizens and safeguarding human rights, particularly with regard to the protection of personal data.  So I decided to vote against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because I believe that an operational agreement for the exchange of data and information between Eurojust and Montenegro will strengthen the fight against transnational crime.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have chosen to abstain. Eurojust is an EU body whose aim is to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, and in this case it is a question of changing personal data. The Left Party is against Eurojust as such, but votes for cooperation when countries themselves want to enter. However, the country has repeatedly violated human rights, including with regard to the right to judicial proceedings, and that is why we are choosing to abstain in this vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal to give the green light to the conclusion of a Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. Among other aspects, this agreement provides for the sending by Montenegro of a liaison prosecutor on commission of services to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. The conclusion of the agreement has also received the approval of the Eurojust Joint Supervisory Authority, which stressed that all Eurojust's amendments to the draft agreement have been taken into account and that the provisions on the exchange of personal data included therein are relevant.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. The aim of this agreement is to improve judicial cooperation to combat serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, for example by posting a liaison prosecutor to Eurojust and exchanging information containing personal data. Montenegro has acceded to the Council of Europe Convention for the Protection of Individuals with regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data and to the Protocol to this Convention on data flows crossing the borders of supervisors and states. The Joint Supervisory Body has indicated that the provisions on the exchange of personal data included in the draft agreement are appropriate.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to strengthen the fight against cross-border crime and to enhance judicial cooperation within Europe, eurojust's cooperation with Montenegro is clearly needed from a practical point of view. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. Last week, I also voted in plenary to conclude the Eurojust-Montenegro Cooperation Agreement by Eurojust. Montenegro will also provide more assistance to Montenegro in prosecuting serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. Montenegro fulfils the conditions from an operational point of view, so strengthening the exchange of information and judicial cooperation is more than welcome. Montenegro thus continues to successfully continue its path towards reforms and to fulfilling the conditions for membership of the European Union, which is why I was also happy to support such a proposal.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support the Eurojust-Montenegro Draft Cooperation Treaty.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I am of course always in favour of any measure to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism, but I am vehemently opposed to the exchange of information involving personal data. That is what this report provides. Therefore I voted against this project.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro has many positive aspects in many respects. In fact, this agreement, on the one hand, represents a further step in Montenegro's accession process and, on the other, it is an important instrument in the fight against terrorism.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament must be in favour of concluding this cooperation agreement with the Republic of Montenegro, since the contracting parties have responded positively to all the requests of the relevant committees and for the particular role that Montenegro can play in the management of the migration flows of south-eastern Europe, as well as for the active contribution that the agreement can make in the fight against the serious forms of crime that characterise many territories in Eastern Europe and the Balkans. Strengthening the fight against international crime and improving judicial cooperation in Europe is important for the security of our citizens, and that is why we must activate the cooperation agreement between the joint supervisory authority Eurojust and the Republic of Montenegro.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This proposal concerns the approval of an agreement between Europol and Montenegro to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against criminal networks as well as terrorism. This report includes provisions in terms of operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the secondment of a liaison officer to Eurojust but above all the exchange of information, including personal data. We strongly oppose the European Union's desire to permanently strengthen its influence with Member States as well as third countries. It is therefore our duty to protect these countries from the interference of the European institutions in their national affairs. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and to enhance judicial cooperation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro.  This agreement is an important element in terms of creating a stronger link between the EU and Montenegro, a candidate country for EU Member State status. I voted in favour of this report because the conclusion of the agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro is an important step towards combating serious forms of crime and corruption.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 This series of agreements between Eurojust and third countries is mainly aimed at strengthening the fight against transnational crime. I am voting in favour of an operational agreement which results in an exchange of information and data.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and this Montenegro.Il project aims to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular criminal, subversive and terrorist organisations, through the creation and strengthening of mechanisms to make the exchange of personal data and information between institutions involved in the fight against and repression of the various criminal associations. Given that there is a clear operational need to establish effective cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro and that the cooperation agreement introduces all the provisions in support of this process, I have chosen to vote for its acceptance.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Montenegro.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report gives Parliament's opinion on the criminal judicial cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. The same is important to include this country in its efforts to combat serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. I voted without any doubt in favour of the report recommending that the agreement be signed.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime and in particular against organised crime and terrorism.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro has particular implications for the lives and freedoms of millions of citizens. Although the extension of cooperation between States is positive in nature and can bring very important results in the field of crime, we cannot support any initiative without ensuring the protection of citizens' individual rights. I therefore think we need to deepen the debate and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the draft Council implementing decision in which the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro is approved. The basis of my choice is the firm conviction that there is an urgent need to improve the efficiency of judicial cooperation between the contracting parties in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The measure establishes cooperation between the Montenegrin National Authority and Eurojust, which is implemented in a number of measures. One of the main provisions contained in the agreement is the secondment of national experts to the European institutions and the exchange of information between the competent authorities.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Montenegro is a state that for years has unwittingly served arms, illicit substances and people traffickers (including former war criminals) as a logistical base for reaching Italy and with it Europe. If we want to stop this trafficking, it is appropriate to help montenegrin justice to be more efficient, and that is exactly the spirit of this agreement. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ A cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro would reinforce judicial cooperation in the combat against serious crime and corruption, with a particular emphasis on organised crime and terrorism. The agreement would see operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the temporary transfer of a liaison prosecutor by Montenegro to Eurojust. It would also encourage the exchange of information including personal data. Article 26a(2) of the Council Decision of 28 February 2002 provides that it is for the Council to approve the agreements concluded by Eurojust with third countries. The Council is required to consult Parliament when adopting implementing measures. This cooperation mechanism is crucial to strengthen the combat against transnational crime whilst also enhancing judicial coordination in Europe.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Montenegro.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Eurojust is an essential part of European judicial cooperation, developing its work mainly in the field of cross-border organised crime and terrorism. Its support for Member States lies, inter among others, in the ability to collect and analyse information, as well as in the articulation of cross-border investigations. In this context, Eurojust also cooperates with third countries. Such cooperation is generally the result of its geographical proximity to the Union or of the importance for the agency's material scope of action. It is in this context that this cooperation agreement with Montenegro has been signed. After the protection of data by the Joint Control Body and its usefulness and legality by the College of Eurojust, Parliament, as a co-legislator, gives its political assent to the conclusion of the Agreement.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Montenegro.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision because it will make it possible to achieve the objective of improving judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. In addition, the agreement contains provisions that will facilitate the exchange of data between the European justice system and the Montenegrin authorities and organises montenegro's secondment of a liaison prosecutor to Eurojust.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime in particular organised crime and corruption is important to ensure citizens’ safety. I agree with the provisions concerning the operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the secondment of a liaison officer by Montenegro to Eurojust.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the draft Council implementing decision on the proposal to approve an agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, with the aim of improving judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions concerning operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as montenegro's secondment of a liaison prosecutor to Eurojust and the exchange of information. Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland shall participate in the adoption and application of the Decision. I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report would ratify an agreement between the Eurojust agency, which specializes in the fight against organized crime and terrorism, and Montenegro through police collaboration and data exchange. We abstained in the vote because, according to international organisations such as Fair Trials International, montenegro systematically violates the rights of persons accused of a crime, in addition to numerous allegations of torture and police violence and, therefore, we understand that we cannot reach judicial agreements with States that do not respect the standards of democratic rights and guarantees in justice that we claim.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal to approve the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro aims to enhance judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the secondment of a liaison prosecutor delegated to Eurojust by Montenegro and the exchange of information, including personal data. In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and enhance judicial cooperation within Europe, eurojust's cooperation with Montenegro is clearly necessary from an operational point of view.  According to the Council Decision establishing Eurojust, Eurojust may conclude agreements with third countries or international organisations after approval by a qualified majority of the Council, after Parliament has agreed to do so. Today, Parliament approved the Council's draft cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, as it helps and strengthens the fight against serious crime and contributes to enhancing judicial cooperation, particularly in the areas of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the approval of Council draft 11592/2015 as I support the conclusion of this cooperation agreement between the European Union and Montenegro as it aims to strengthen the EU’s fight against organised and cross border crime, particularly within the field of organised crime and terrorism. The agreement aims to enhance judicial cooperation between the EU and Montenegro and contains provisions concerning the operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the secondment of a liaison prosecutor by Montenegro to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. Because it is essential that the EU equips itself with the necessary tools for the fight against terrorism and organised crime, I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro which allows for the mutual exchange of information and the secondment of liaison officers or liaison magistrates to Eurojust. Cooperation of this kind is vital to tackle cross-border serious crime both within and outside the European Union. I am also satisfied with Eurojust’s Joint Supervisory Body’s positive opinion on the data protection provisions in this agreement. In order for international cooperation in the fight against crime to be successful it is imperative that law-abiding citizens have confidence in the safety of their own personal data under these agreements.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. In this consultation report, the European Parliament approves the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, with the aim of strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. The agreement provides for operational measures to facilitate cooperation on the ground, such as the secondment of a Montenegro liaison officer to Eurojust and the sharing of information. The exchange of personal data will be authorized after consultation with the Joint Data Protection Supervisory Authority and the approval of the Council. Considering that the third countries around the external borders of the European Union are preferred places of passage for terrorists, I voted in favour of this report which aims to improve the cooperation of the Montenegrin authorities with the European agency Eurojust.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the agreement on cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro. It is indeed important to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. This includes the exchange of information and the secondment of officers or liaison magistrates to Eurojust.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro because, in a situation such as the one we are experiencing of extreme mobility at Europe's borders, we must set ourselves the objective of improving judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime. The exchange of information, including personal data, with Montenegro will allow a synergy that until now had not been possible to counter even the most odious forms of trafficking such as that of human beings.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution to strengthen cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, including the secondment of a Montenegro liaison prosecutor to Eurojust as well as the exchange of information, including personal data.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. As well as the proposal for cooperation with Ukraine to combat organised crime and terrorism, the exchange of personal data is not desirable with Montenegro. These processes are not the cure for all the ills mentioned, made possible by the desired porosity of our borders and by the uncontrolled mass immigration.  That is why, consistent with my political positioning, I voted against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Montenegro is one of the countries in Europe which, for one reason or another, is perhaps closest to being adopted in the Union. Therefore, any document signed between it and the Union is another step towards that objective.  It is good that Montenegro will sign this treaty because it has been repeatedly accused of joining Islamic State. Their signature under this treaty will allow Europe to fight even harder with the spread of radical Islamism within its borders. These are the reasons why I support this report.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 This document concerns the proposal for the adoption of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, including organised crime and terrorism. In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and judicial cooperation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for collaboration between Eurojust and Montenegro. I am in favour of concluding this cooperation agreement with Montenegro, as it supports and intensifies the fight against serious forms of crime, and also contributes to strengthening judicial cooperation, in particular in the field of the fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to the transfer of personal data, which has nothing to do with the fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims at the adoption of the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, under the pretext of intensifying judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, including organised crime and terrorism. This draft agreement provides for provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the deployment by Montenegro of a liaison officer for Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. Entities such as Eurojust, which escapedemocratic and judicial control, are centralised, structured and strengthened, overcoming guarantees as to the rights and freedoms provided for in national legislative and constitutional frameworks. Instead of free and sovereign cooperation between States, progress is made with the establishment of supranational control mechanisms. Among other things, these initiatives are part of a security drift that increasingly puts fundamental rights, freedoms and guarantees at risk. It is recalled that Montenegro's possible accession to NATO – the accession proposal was submitted in December 2015 – an inseparable process for the militarisation of the EU and the extension of the organisation's influence in the Balkan region. For the above, our vote against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro aims to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular in organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains, inter alia, provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro and, with respect to the Council of Europe Convention on the Protection of Individuals with regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data, the Joint Supervisory Body has reached a conclusion on the exchange of personal data in the draft agreement.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the agreement which aims to increase security and the exchange of information and data with third countries.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 There is a clear operational need for EUROJUST to cooperate with the respective Montenegrin judicial authorities in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The opinion of the relevant Joint Supervisory Authority (JSB) on the draft agreement took into account the provisions of the Council of Europe Convention on the Automated Processing of Personal Information, supervisory authorities and the cross-border flow of data. For these reasons I am voting in favour of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The draft agreement limits the transfer of personal data between the parties and includes a number of specific safeguard provisions. Onward transmission of such personal data is not possible without the written consent of the other party. It is important that we continue to support the work of Eurojust, as it will play a key role if the EU wants to enhance its judicial cooperation to tackle organised crime and terrorism.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report in support of the cooperation agreement between Europol and Montenegro, which will strengthen and intensify judicial cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. While the work of the Eurojust agency is mainly based on coordination between the various Member States and the other European institutions, the scope and scale of the current threats make international cooperation with our partners, including Montenegro, more indispensable than ever.  This agreement includes provisions on the exchange of information, including the exchange of personal data, and on the posting of officers and liaison magistrates to the agency, for a more coordinated response. Finally, this agreement is more broadly in line with the strengthening of our partnership with Montenegro, which has been a candidate country since 2010, and is an additional way to support that country in its reforms to stay on the path to accession.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we approve the conclusion of the operational cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. This agreement has the objective of enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, through the exchange of information, including personal data.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and enhance judicial cooperation within Europe, eurojust's cooperation with Montenegro is clearly needed from an operational point of view. The report concerns the proposal to approve the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, which aims to enhance judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the secondment of a liaison prosecutor delegated to Eurojust by Montenegro and the exchange of information, including personal data.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal with the intention of strengthening judicial cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. In an increasingly globalized world, where criminal practices and terrorism have international reach, the EU must cooperate with neighbouring states to improve the fight against these execrable scourges until their complete elimination.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the eurojust-Montenegro cooperation agreement, as I believe that strengthening judicial cooperation beyond the EU's borders is an important and useful instrument.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I welcome greater judicial cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro. Serious crime and the dangers of terrorism can now be combated even more effectively.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which concerns the proposed approval of cooperation agreements between Eurojust and Montenegro, with the aim of enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained on the recommendation of the rapporteur of the GUE/NGL Group, who considers it risky to support a judicial cooperation agreement with countries with serious violations of human rights and procedural rights, taking into account, moreover, that the European Parliament has had no option to participate in the drafting of the agreements.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On the draft Implementing Decision of the Council approving the conclusion by EUROJUST of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine and Montenegro.  Organised crime and terrorism are topical and important topics for europe as a whole. We are constantly learning about the growing number of criminal organisations and attacks that are destroying and intimidating European society. These phenomena must be strongly opposed.  The strengthening of operational cooperation between Eurojust and Ukraine and Montenegro, and in particular the appointment by both countries of a liaison officer to Eurojust, therefore deserves support.  I am convinced that the steps taken under the agreement will strengthen Europe in the fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒  As with the vote before this relating to the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, this agreement also enhances the judicial cooperation role that the EU has to tackle organised crime and terrorism.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. On Tuesday 2 February, I voted in favour of the agreement on cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro. Founded in 2002, Eurojust's mission is to promote and strengthen coordination and cooperation between national authorities in the fight against serious cross-border crime in the European Union.  This report aims to endorse Eurojust's conclusion of the Eurojust-Montenegro cooperation agreement with the aim of strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. These cooperation agreements may include the exchange of information, including personal data, and the posting of officers or liaison magistrates to Eurojust.  In order to strengthen the fight against international crime and judicial cooperation in Europe, it is clearly essential, from an operational point of view, that Eurojust begin cooperation with Montenegro. .

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro because it is necessary that Eurojust work with Montenegro in aiding and reinforcing the fight against serious crime, as well as enhancing judicial co-operation, particularly in the field of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The agreement for which Parliament's approval is sought concerns judicial cooperation between the EU and Montenegro. The agreement provides for the exchange of information including personal data, which raises reasonable questions. A regulation is currently being promoted by the European Commission on Eurojust proposing more powers to the EP in drafting these cooperation agreements. In this case, the EP is simply seeking approval. For these reasons, we consider the abstention attitude to be more appropriate.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ The passing of the draft agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro would lead to increased judicial cooperation in combating organised crime and terrorism. This argument should enhance European judicial collaboration. Given that the cooperation would only extend as far as the secondment of a liaison officer by Montenegro to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data, and given that the Council will be required to consult Parliament when adopting implementing measures pursuant to Article 39(1) of the pre-Lisbon Treaty on European Union and in accordance with Article 9 of Protocol 36 , I have decided to vote in favour of this draft implementing decision.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the proposal for a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. This initiative would facilitate and intensify the fight against serious forms of crime and would contribute to strengthening judicial cooperation, in particular in the area of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on a draft Council decision authorising Eurojust to conclude the Eurojust-Montenegro Cooperation Agreement (11596/2015 - C8-0299/2015 - 2015/081 (CNS)), as I support the proposal for a Eurojust-Montenegro Cooperation Agreement with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime and corruption, and given that there is a clear operational need for Eurojust's cooperation with Montenegro to combat transnational crime and strengthen judicial cooperation in Europe.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I refuse to approve a cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine that would be for greater judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime. I particularly reject the cooperation arrangements between Eurojust and Montenegro, including the exchange of personal data.  Furthermore, I do not accept the possibility of having a Montenegro liaison officer with Eurojust. As a result I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. My colleagues and I have therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Montenegro.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement between Eurojust, the European Union’s Judicial Cooperation Unit, and Montenegro aims at strengthening their cooperation in criminal matters, especially in fighting organised crime and terrorism.  Given the current terrorism threat looming over Europe, it is of great importance to me to enhance exchange of operational information with third countries. This agreement will help, for example, to accelerate or facilitate the execution of extradition and mutual legal assistance requests, to clarify legal requirements and relevant legislation. I am convinced this will enable us to fight organised crime more effectively within Europe; this is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Nathalie Griesbeck's report on the Council's enforcement decision approving Eurojust's conclusion of the Eurojust cooperation agreement with Montenegro. The agreement aims to strengthen judicial cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro. It thus addresses the exchange of information and provides for the secondment of liaison officers to Eurojust. I supported the effective establishment of closer cooperation between Montenegro and the European Union to improve the effectiveness of the fight against terrorism and organised crime. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves the decision of operational and judicial cooperation between the Eurojust agency and the authorities of Montenegro. This cooperation will result in exchanges of information between Montenegro and the European Union to combat crime and corruption.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from this report, which deals with the fight against international crime, as I do not believe that there is currently a serious discussion with the Montenegrin Government in this regard.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the conclusion of the cooperation agreement, as it would aid and reinforce the fight against serious crime and would contribute to enhancing judicial co-operation in particular in the field of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The report concerns the proposed approval of a cooperation agreement between the Ukraine and Montenegro with Eurojust. Eurojust is an EU body to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime. It is important to underline the role of Eurojust in building mutual trust and bridging the EU’s wide variety of legal systems. The report stresses the clear operational need for Eurojust to cooperate with Montenegro, in order to reinforce the fight against transnational crime and to enhance judicial co-operation in Europe. However, I decided to abstain. I believe that this position makes it possible to express my doubts on the necessity to conclude agreements in the judicial sphere with countries like Montenegro, given the continual infringement of defence rights and prison conditions at national level.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The draft we are debating today concerns the proposal to approve a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. The main aim is to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. Specifically, the CSR (eurojust's Joint Supervisory Authority) is satisfied with the provisions on the exchange of personal data provided for in the draft agreement. I have therefore decided to vote in favour because the EU needs, now more than ever, more support from other countries, in order to combat all forms of transnational crime.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Montenegro to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime.  This proposal for an agreement includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the secondment of a Montenegro liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. This last aspect above all is unacceptable to me. I am opposed to the systematic and widespread use of personal data of French citizens.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this proposed agreement because it includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the exchange of information, including personal data. I am opposed to this kind of exchange.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against it. The report sought to approve a judicial cooperation agreement between Europol and Montenegro, particularly in the fight against organised crime and terrorism.  The operational provisions of this agreement are, for example, the posting of a Montenegrin liaison officer to Eurojust, the exchange of information, but above all also the exchange of personal data. This crucial point is unacceptable to me and to all the Members of our group, who are fighting every day to push back against this european Union objective.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Eurojust-Montenegro Cooperation Agreement as it aims to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism with measures such as Montenegro's admission of a liaison officer (fiscal) to Eurojust or the exchange of information , including data.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 Eurojust is a abolition office, a tax-eater for EUR 32 million per year. Combating international crime was also possible before and after the European Union, without unnecessary euro office. There is no need to add more states to this inefficient cooperation.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This agreement concerns co-operation between Eurojust and Montenegro with the aim of strengthening judicial co-operation in the fight against serious, organised crime and terrorism. The draft co-operation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro contains provisions concerning operational co-operation, including the transfer of montenegro's liaison prosecutor to Eurojust and the exchange of information including personal data.  In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and improve judicial cooperation in Europe, there is a clear operational need to achieve cooperation. For these reasons, I supported Mp Griesbeck's report on the council's draft implementing decision authorising the conclusion of the Eurojust-Montenegro Cooperation Agreement.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Since agreements of this kind between Eurojust and third countries are typical, the nature of the Agreement on cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro is very close to the one between Eurojust and Ukraine, which has also been voted on here today. So there will be closer judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. There will be principles of regular operational exchange of information and close cooperation, as well as the possibility for Montenegro to send its liaison officer to Eurojust. Given the very intensive cooperation between the EU and Montenegro over the last decade, as well as Montenegro's clear desire to integrate more closely with the European Union – even by unilaterally adopting the euro as its national currency almost a decade ago – the entry into force of this agreement will allow for another strong and rather positive springboard for the development of our relations.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ the Agreement will strengthen cooperation between Eurojust and montenegro's criminal and investigative bodies. It will help to make the detection of serious cross-border crime and organised crime more effective, improve cooperation between competent authorities, in particular in the field of international mutual legal assistance and the application of European arrest warrants. It is important to maintain the protection of personal data within and within the scope of the adopted legislation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, because it is not complete.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. As before, the aim here is to approve a cooperation agreement between Eurojust (Europe's justice cooperation agency) and Montenegro. The aim of this agreement is to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, especially in the context of the fight against terrorism. This agreement includes the secondment of a Montenegro liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. It is this last point that prevents us from supporting this project, as before: Europe should not have access to this information.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro with the aim of enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the draft Council implementing decision approving eurojust's conclusion of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. Council Decision 2002/187/JHA establishes Eurojust as a body of the European Union, with legal personality, with the aim of stimulating and improving coordination and cooperation between the competent judicial authorities of the Member States. The agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro is crucial as it provides help and support for European judicial cooperation and for the fight against serious crime, such as organised crime and terrorism.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro by renewing my desire for a more effective and efficient fight against organised crime and terrorism. The exchange of information with neighbouring countries the Union is becoming increasingly important in order to achieve a safer Europe free from any criminal organisation.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The European Union and Montenegro are in a process of strengthening relations and, for that reason, I welcome the possibility of the agreement between Eurojust and the Authorities of this country with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I reject Eurojust as an agency. On the positive side, I am pleased that the report mentions the fight against international crime. I am abstaining from my voice.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I support the Agreement on Judicial Cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro. This agreement will help the officials responsible to combat serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, and facilitate cooperation between the courts of the EU Member States and Montenegro.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This agreement authorizes cooperation between Eurojust, the European Agency for Judicial Cooperation and Montenegro. It provides for the exchange of data between states in order to combat organised crime and terrorism and to facilitate the coordination of investigations and prosecutions in states. I am opposed to such collaboration, which serves as a showcase for Montenegro to join the European Union, in a country where the judicial system is still particularly fallible. Moreover, Parliament is simply consulted here and the decision will be applied anyway, the umpteenth proof of the semblance of European democracy. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I refuse to approve a cooperation agreement between Europol and Ukraine that would be for greater judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime.  I particularly reject the cooperation arrangements between Eurojust and Montenegro, including the exchange of personal data. Furthermore, I do not accept the possibility of having a Montenegro liaison officer with Eurojust. As a result I vote against it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it is important to further the judicial cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro. This resolution, like the one between Eurojust and Ukraine, seeks to advance operational cooperation and the exchange of information.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Parliament was consulted on the future operational cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. I welcome the positive signal to the conclusion of this agreement sent by Parliament.  In the current climate particularly marked by the fight against terrorism, trafficking and organised crime, it is imperative to take into account the transnational nature of these scourges and to strengthen judicial cooperation. It must be effective between Member States on the one hand and between Member States and third countries on the other. Indeed, with crime increasingly playing at the borders, judicial cooperation is a necessity if we are to be able to effectively prosecute those involved and avoid the impunity they still too often enjoy because of the lack of cross-border cooperation.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing – Following the brutal Paris attacks in November 2015, not only concerns but also efforts to achieve a higher level of security in Europe have generally increased. The activities of terrorist organisations, and the activities of any organised crime actors at all, are a cancer of society and an undesirable element that must be combated by all appropriate procedures and options. I consider it one excellent opportunity to eliminate terrorism and organised crime by extending the European Union's cooperation with third countries. The agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro on their cooperation with each other is a step towards reducing the terrorist threat. I support similar proposals because they contribute to the security and general easing of the climate of fear that engulfed Europe at the end of 2015.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my approval to the Cooperation Agreement to be entered into between Eurojust and Montenegro, in particular to the draft Council decision approving the draft agreement. It is important that we continue to support the work of Eurojust, as it will play a key role if the EU wants to enhance its judicial cooperation to tackle organised crime and terrorism.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council adopted a draft implementing decision approving the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. The agreement aims to enhance judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. Eurojust's joint supervisory body approved the draft agreement, noting, inter alia, that the provisions of the draft agreement on the exchange of personal data are appropriate. The Council is obliged to consult Parliament on the draft. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs notes in its report that, in order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and enhance judicial cooperation within Europe, there is a clear operational need for cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, and therefore recommends that Parliament approve the Council's draft. I supported the proposal accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The proposal is for the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Montenegro to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism.  Proposals include the secondment of a Montenegro liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. This last aspect above all is unacceptable to us.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with the proposal for the adoption of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, including organised crime and terrorism.  I advocate that closer and more effective cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro is essential, with the aim of strengthening the fight against transnational crime and judicial cooperation in Europe. This report is in my favour in combating serious forms of crime, and it also contributes to strengthening judicial cooperation, in particular in the field of combating organised crime and terrorism.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The proposal under consideration is for the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Montenegro to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. This proposal for an agreement includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the secondment of a Montenegro liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. This last aspect is unacceptable, so I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which authorises the judicial cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. The aim is to strengthen the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, by promoting the exchange of information and the secondment of officers or liaison magistrates to Eurojust. Eurojust's mission is to strengthen the effectiveness of national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases of serious cross-border crime and organised crime and to bring criminals to justice quickly and effectively.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro includes provisions similar to those contained in the Eurojust-Ukraine cooperation agreement. This agreement will result in better cooperation between the parties, notably through the secondment of a Montenegro liaison prosecutor to Eurojust.  I therefore also voted in favour of this report.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council implementing decision in which the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro is approved. The main objective is to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, including through the secondment of national experts to the European institutions and the exchange of information between the competent authorities.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro with the aim of enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. I have voted for this report that will reinforce the fight against transnational crime and enhance judicial cooperation in Europe.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I am also critical of Eurojust as an agency in this report. However, the report is also about combating international crime. That is why I have also abstained from this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro is necessary in order to strengthen the fight against international crime, in particular in the field of terrorism and organised crime, and to enhance judicial cooperation in Europe.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I welcome the conclusion of this agreement. The Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro is a necessary tool for strengthening the fight against organised crime. Only close and effective international cooperation and coordination can contribute to the fight against cross-border crime and to improving judicial cooperation in Europe.  It should be noted that the provisions on operational cooperation between the two parties provided for in the agreement will facilitate international cooperation in cases involving serious and organised crime, in particular terrorism, trafficking in human beings and large-scale fraud.  In view of the damage caused by organised crime to public security and the economic stability of the country, further efforts are needed to promote and improve the coordination of pre-trial investigations and prosecutions, as well as by providing legal assistance to Member States to make their investigations and prosecutions more effective.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Montenegro.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and improve judicial cooperation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro. That is why I am in favour of it.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The Eurojust Cooperation Agreement with Montenegro is a very important step to more effectively tackle issues such as organised crime and terrorism in Montenegro and across the EU. I welcome this agreement which will deliver better cooperation and coordination between the EU Member States and Montenegro in the field of justice and law enforcement when dealing with cross-border crime and help make Europe safer.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ With current geostrategic trends, security and neighbourhood development is of key importance.
