Eurojust, an agency of the European Union dealing with judicial co-operation in criminal matters, will add stability in those matters to Montenegro and the EU, and increased EU convergence to the whole region of the Western Balkans.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Council's decision authorising Eurojust to conclude a Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, as it aims to increase legislative cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised and terrorism. This draft agreement contains parts concerning operational co-operation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the exchange of liaison officers and the exchange of information, including personal data, which I consider very important in the prevention of serious crime.  I believe that this kind of co-operation plays a key role in security, not only of european union citizens, but also of those outside it. By building good-social interstate relations, there is also the possibility of creating new forms of cooperation, be they on the security, economic or some third plan. Therefore, I welcome this form of cooperation because it brings only positive changes in the daily lives of citizens, especially in the plan of security and freedom, which I consider one of the fundamental rights of every person.  For all these reasons, this report on the draft Council decision authorising Eurojust to conclude the Eurojust-Montenegro Cooperation Agreement enjoys my full support.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The proposal under consideration is for the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Montenegro to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. This proposed agreement includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, in particular the exchange of information, including personal data. This last aspect above all is unacceptable to me. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ In light of the progress of integration and cooperation between Montenegro and the European Union, which I actively support through my political activities, but also from supporting a more assertive fight against serious crime and terrorism, I support the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. In particular, this is an operational cooperation between the two parties, in particular in the form of an exchange between the applicants and information including personal data, which was also green-lighted by the Joint Supervisory Authority.  While the focus is on cooperation in the field of terrorism, it should be stressed that Eurojust can also operate in a number of other areas such as drug trafficking, money laundering, people smuggling, etc., as a result of which this cooperation will become more comprehensive and deserve our support.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, under the pretext of intensifying judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, provides for provisions on operational cooperation such as the deployment by Montenegro of a liaison officer for Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. Entities such as Eurojust, which escapedemocratic and judicial control, are centralised, structured and strengthened, overcoming guarantees as to the rights and freedoms provided for in national legislative and constitutional frameworks. Among other things, these initiatives are part of a security drift based on supranational control mechanisms, which increasingly undermine fundamental rights, freedoms and guarantees. Under the scope of combating crime and terrorism, this proposal is part of the framework of interference with this process of European capitalist integration in the political, economic and judicial systems, as well as in foreign and security policy. The country's predictable membership of NATO, which is part of the EU militarisation and the extension of influence in the Balkan region, will not be unrelated to this process. By the above vote against.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – The most important objective of the Eurojust-Montenegro Co-operation Agreement is to increase judicial co-operation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. Co-operation between Eurojust and Montenegro is of significant importance, especially in the fight against serious crime and corruption.  The draft Implementation Decision of the Council granting Eurojust the conclusion of the Eurojust-Montenegro Cooperation Agreement contains detailed commissions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, including the exchange of personal data. The operational need for Eurojust-Montenegro cooperation is clear in order to step up the fight against transnational crime and increase judicial co-operation in Europe.  For these reasons, I fully support fellow MEP Nathalia Griesbeck's report on the council's draft implementing decision authorising Eurojust to conclude a Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of approving this cooperation agreement because there is a clear operational need for cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro in order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and improve judicial cooperation in Europe. The agreement provides for montenegro to second a liaison officer to Eurojust and exchange information, including personal data.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report concerns the proposed approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. This draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the posting by Montenegro of a liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data.  In accordance with Article 26a(2) of the Council Decision of 28 February 2002 establishing Eurojust, as last amended by Council Decision 2009/426/YSSW of 16 December 2008, it is for the Council to approve by qualified majority the agreements concluded by Eurojust with third countries or international organisations.  I support the conclusion of this cooperation agreement with Montenegro, as it will support and strengthen the fight against serious crime and will contribute to improving judicial cooperation, in particular in the area of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 As in the case of Ukraine, I consider the cooperation agreement under way between Montenegro and the European agency Eurojust to be beneficial. Strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime is essential in view of the fact that Montenegro is also one of the European Union's important neighbours, and coordination of action can help detect a number of crimes. The report therefore received my support.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The aim is to validate the principle of rapprochement between the Eurojust agency and the Montenegrin authorities, particularly in relation to crime and terrorism. These rapprochements are always positive as long as they affect the safety of our citizens.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Montenegro.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 This document is nothing more than the proposal for the adoption of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, such as organised crime and terrorism. I voted in favour, because with this agreement it is intended, among other positive aspects, to ensure the protection of individuals from the automated processing of personal data when it is collected and processed.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I would like to congratulate my colleague Nathalie Griesbeck on her report, which was adopted by a large majority in this House. This text, which I supported, gives a positive opinion on the Council's draft on the cooperation agreement between the European agency Eurojust and Montenegro. The agreement aims to strengthen judicial cooperation in Europe and to better combat serious forms of crime, including organised crime and terrorism. Cooperation with Montenegro is necessary in this regard on an operational level. In concrete terms, a montenegro liaison prosecutor will be seconded to Eurojust and information exchanges will take place, among other things. The tragic events that have affected our country in recent months are a reminder of the imperative to strengthen the fight against these scourges of organized crime and terrorism. We also ask that the Council inform this House if it intends to amend the agreement, and that it consults with us again if it intends to change it substantially.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal to give the green light to the conclusion of a Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. Among other aspects, this agreement provides for the sending by Montenegro of a liaison prosecutor on commission of services to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. The conclusion of the agreement has also received the approval of the Eurojust Joint Supervisory Authority, which stressed that all Eurojust's amendments to the draft agreement have been taken into account and that the provisions on the exchange of personal data included therein are relevant.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Today's vote was on the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, including the secondment of a Montenegro liaison prosecutor to Eurojust and exchanges of information, including personal data. In order to strengthen the fight against international crime and judicial cooperation in Europe, it clearly seems to me to be essential, from an operational point of view, for Eurojust to enter into cooperation with Montenegro. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it will support and strengthen the fight against serious forms of crime and will help to improve judicial cooperation, particularly with regard to organised crime and terrorism between the European Union and Montenegro.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution because Montenegro has made huge progress in recent years in strengthening the legal framework, increasing the professionalism and independence of the work of the judiciary. Nevertheless, there remains a high risk of legal corruption in Montenegro, detention conditions are deplorable, and other human rights violations are reported. Cooperation with Montenegro is therefore essential to ensure reforms.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, such as organised crime and terrorism. The rapporteur's proposals provide for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, with the secondment by Montenegro of a liaison officer to Eurojust, as well as the exchange of information, including personal data. Montenegro is a party to the Council of Europe Convention dated 28 January 1981 for the protection of persons in relation to the automated processing of personal data when collecting and processing data and its protocol on supervisory authorities and cross-border data flows. In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and judicial cooperation in Europe, it seems clear to me that there is an operational need for collaboration between Eurojust and Montenegro. In view of the content of the clause summing up the conclusion of this Agreement and its objective of stepping up support and the fight against serious forms of crime, helping to strengthen judicial cooperation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives the European Parliament the approval of the draft Council agreement on cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro with the aim of strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The aim of this agreement is to deepen this operational cooperation with, for example, the secondment of a liaison prosecutor by Montenegro to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. This agreement will facilitate and intensify the fight against serious forms of crime and help strengthen judicial cooperation, particularly in the area of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague's legislative motion for a resolution to kick-start the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro aimed at improving the fight against serious crimes and, above all, terrorism. This cooperation can also take place thanks to the possibility of seconding officials from Montenegro to Eurojust in order to ensure that there is a real exchange of information between the two realities. In order for this text to have an effect, we look forward to the council, which co-legislator will also approve this report together with the European Parliament.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained on the recommendation of the rapporteur of the GUE/NGL Group, who considers it risky to support a judicial cooperation agreement with countries with serious violations of human rights and procedural rights, taking into account, moreover, that the European Parliament has had no option to participate in the drafting of the agreements.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. This cooperation agreement with Montenegro will support and strengthen the fight against serious crime and will contribute to improving judicial cooperation, in particular in the field of organised crime and terrorism. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the cooperation agreement between the EU agency Eurojust, which coordinates judicial cooperation in the EU, and Montenegro, as Montenegro is a candidate for EU membership and its judicial apparatus needs to be strengthened to fight organised crime and terrorism. The exchange of data and information and the creation of a liaison point at Eurojust is important, because that is the only way to work together effectively.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Written. Cooperation agreements between Eurojust and Montenegro are a welcome step towards a more effective fight against organised crime. However, that is not enough. In its 2014 Progress Report, the European Commission has pointed out that success depends on reducing corruption and improving judicial deficiencies. Montenegro has taken measures in the field of anti-corruption measures following its application for membership to the EU. These efforts should be supported by the EU. Cooperation with Eurojust will not produce sufficient results if the aid is limited to that alone. Nevertheless, I choose to support the report because cooperation is a necessary, but not sufficient, measure.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report would ratify an agreement between the Eurojust agency, which specializes in the fight against organized crime and terrorism, and Montenegro through police collaboration and data exchange. We abstained in the vote because, according to international organisations such as Fair Trials International, montenegro systematically violates the rights of persons accused of a crime, in addition to numerous allegations of torture and police violence and, therefore, we understand that we cannot reach judicial agreements with States that do not respect the standards of democratic rights and guarantees in justice that we claim.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text voted on today concerns the approval of the proposal for a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation, as well as the exchange of information and personal data. I have chosen to vote in favour of this report in order to increase the effectiveness in preventing and combating the most serious forms of international crime in Europe and Montenegro.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of any EU judicial forces and we believe this agreement expands the power and influence of Eurojust. UKIP has therefore voted against this Eurojust agreement with Montenegro.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ As with the vote before this relating to the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Ukraine, this agreement also enhances the judicial cooperation role that the EU has to tackle organised crime and terrorism.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I support the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, as this will help and strengthen the fight against serious crimes and contribute to improving judicial cooperation, especially in the field of organised crime and terrorism. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Eurojust was created 14 years ago as a unit of the European Council to support national investigative bodies in serious crimes. Initially, it was only an initiative of several countries, but the deterioration of the global situation linked to the terrorist attacks in the US in 2001 led member states to consolidate eurojust's position, which was gradually moved to The Hague. Eurojust is currently aiming to coordinate the cooperation of investigators and prosecutors in transnational crime cases. Its scope of action includes, in particular, terrorism, drug and human smuggling, money laundering, corruption, fraud or cybercrime. In addition to EU Member States, the Agency also seeks to cooperate with other countries in Europe. I therefore agree with Montenegro's accession to the cooperation agreement with Eurojust. This will strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular as regards organised crime and terrorism. Cooperation shall also include the agreement that Montenegro will send a liaison prosecutor to Eurojust to participate in the mutual exchange of information. In order for Montenegro to fully join the EU in the future, it is essential that it participates in strengthening the fight against transnational crime. Strengthening judicial cooperation across Europe is one of the tools to build mutual trust between countries.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. -u2012 Eurojust is an organisation established in 2002. Its main task is to promote and strengthen coordination and cooperation between national authorities in the fight against serious cross-border crime affecting EU Member States.  These tasks shall be carried out by cooperating with each other in coordinating the work of national authorities at all stages of investigations and law enforcement. They also solve issues and practical problems arising from differences between member states' legal systems.  The report concerns the proposed approval of the Eurojust-Montenegro agreement with a view to strengthening judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. I agree that the cooperation of Eurojust and Montenegro is necessary from an operational point of view.  This would strengthen the fight against international crime and judicial cooperation in Europe. That operational cooperation includes, inter alia, the referral of a liaison prosecutor from Montenegro to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data.  In this respect, the competent Joint Supervisory Body has determined that the provisions of the draft agreement on the exchange of personal data are appropriate. I agree that the conclusion of this agreement would help to combat serious crime and would contribute to strengthening judicial cooperation, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ In order to successfully integrate this association country into the EU, I consider it important to establish a political framework that can achieve the country's political association and gradual economic integration into the EU.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the approval of the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, which I dealt intensively with as shadow rapporteur. I consider any new partnership in the field of judicial cooperation in the fight against serious cross-border crime to be extremely important. The conclusion of this agreement is of great benefit to Montenegro as an EU candidate country, montenegro's new and deepened contractual relations with the EU strengthen the country's integration into the EU's institutional structure, and in the future they also facilitate the country's preparation for EU membership itself.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. This decision proposes the approval of the Eurojust-Montenegro Cooperation Agreement to strengthen judicial co-operation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism.  This draft agreement contains provisions relating to operational co-operation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the link between the Prosecutors of Montenegro and Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. In order to strengthen the fight against crime and improve judicial cooperation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for Eurojust's cooperation with Montenegro, and I therefore supported the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which concerns the proposed approval of cooperation agreements between Eurojust and Montenegro, with the aim of enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime. I believe that these measures will aid in the fight against both serious organised crime and terrorism.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of the Eurojust-Montenegro Cooperation Agreement by Eurojust. The Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro will strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism.  Like the agreement with Ukraine, the agreement with Montenegro will contribute both to better preventive action and to a more effective detection of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We support the need to combat organised crime and terrorism. However, we cannot support the promotion of measures that jeopardise the right to safeguard personal data as well as other human rights and freedoms. A regulation on Eurojust is also currently being promoted by the European Commission proposing more powers to the EP in the drafting of these cooperation agreements. This one simply requires EP approval. That is why we have abstained on this agreement.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 There is a clear operational need for EUROJUST to cooperate with the respective Montenegrin judicial authorities in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The opinion of the relevant Joint Supervisory Authority (JSB) on the draft agreement took into account the provisions of the Council of Europe Convention on the Automated Processing of Personal Information, supervisory authorities and the cross-border flow of data.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of parliament's approval of the agreement between Eurojust and the Montenegrin authorities allowing closer operational cooperation, convinced that this represents a significant Pan-European interest, in particular in terms of cross-border organised crime and the fight against international terrorism. When considering this issue, I have been mindful of the important role that Montenegro has to play in stabilising the Western Balkans region and, more recently, in managing the migration flow to Europe. The intensive exchange of information envisaged in the Agreement and the deployment of a Montenegrin liaison prosecutor alongside Eurojust can serve this purpose well. I am also convinced that this agreement and the cooperation that is emerging on its basis are an important contribution to Montenegro's process of democratisation and accession to the EU, and thus to our joint efforts within the framework of the European Union's enlargement policy.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text and its amendments. The proposal under consideration is the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, including the secondment of a Montenegro liaison prosecutor to Eurojust and exchanges of information, including personal data.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement to reinforce the cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro. The objective is to strengthen our operational cooperation, especially in fighting organised crime and terrorism. The international situation is such that it is of utmost importance to increase judicial cooperation with our neighbours.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 Combating all serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, is a primary interest of the European Union and all Member States, which is why I welcome the conclusion of the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. Any action to improve judicial cooperation and in particular, as provided for in the agreement, montenegro's secondment of a liaison prosecutor to Eurojust is of fundamental importance for the security of all European citizens.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. I strongly supported the report on the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. The objective of cooperation has been clearly defined and aims to improve cooperation between the judicial authorities of the EU Member States, at the level of investigations and prosecutions of crimes, taking into account transnational and organised crime. The draft agreement contains provisions relating to operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, which provides, inter alia, for the secondment of a liaison prosecutor to Montenegro to Eurojust and the exchange of information covering personal data, in particular when it comes to the fight against terrorism in Europe.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report authorising Eurojust to conclude a cooperation agreement with Montenegro. As Eurojust's objectives are to foster and enhance cooperation between Member States' authorities in the field of investigation and prosecution, to improve cooperation between Member States' authorities in the area of mutual legal assistance and the implementation of extradition requests, and to investigate and conduct processes effectively, I believe that this agreement will be an incentive in the fight against serious forms of cross-border organised crime and terrorism.  As Eurojust provides logistical support, I believe it can organise or assist coordination meetings between judicial authorities of different countries in order to address some legal or practical problems. I also support the call for the swift and effective detection and prosecution of perpetrators of cross-border organised crime.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of the Eurojust-Montenegro Cooperation Agreement. An agreement containing provisions on the exchange of personal information defining, in particular, the operational level of cooperation is necessary to strengthen the fight against international crime.  The agreement will also strengthen the judicial cooperation of the entire Union, which will mean a more effective fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism, which today poses a pressing problem throughout the Union

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ Cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro shall reinforce the fight against organised crime, terrorism, and transnational crime.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained on the recommendation of the rapporteur of the GUE/NGL Group, who considers it risky to support a judicial cooperation agreement with countries with serious violations of human rights and procedural rights, taking into account, moreover, that the European Parliament has had no option to participate in the drafting of the agreements.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this motion because I agree that, to reinforce the fight against transnational crime and to enhance judicial co-operation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for Eurojust to cooperate with Montenegro.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The proposal is for the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Montenegro to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism.  This proposal for an agreement includes provisions for operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the secondment of a Montenegro liaison officer to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data.  This last aspect above all is unacceptable to us. I voted against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns a proposal for the approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro aimed at enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. In order to strengthen the fight against transnational crime and enhance judicial cooperation within Europe, eurojust's cooperation with Montenegro is clearly necessary from an operational point of view. I voted in favour of the document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained on the recommendation of the rapporteur of the GUE/NGL Group, who considers it risky to support a judicial cooperation agreement with countries with serious violations of human rights and procedural rights, taking into account, moreover, that the European Parliament has had no option to participate in the drafting of the agreements.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the draft Council decision to formally approve the cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro. More specifically, this proposal concerns the proposed approval of a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro with the aim of enhancing judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. This draft agreement contains provisions concerning the operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the secondment of a liaison Prosecutor by Montenegro to Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data.  I voted in favour of the conclusion of this agreement because in order to reinforce the fight against transnational crime and to enhance judicial co-operation in Europe, there is a clear operational need for Eurojust to cooperate with Montenegro.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The agreement itself aims to increase judicial cooperation in the fight against organized crime and terrorism. We are therefore talking about an important issue for the fight against human trafficking networks and mafias operating in the European Union, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this agreement because better cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro will lead to a more efficient fight against cross-border crime, terrorism and organised crime.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft agreement provides for provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as the deployment by Montenegro of a liaison officer for Eurojust and the exchange of information, including personal data. Entities such as Eurojust, which escapedemocratic and judicial control, are centralised, structured and strengthened, overcoming guarantees as to the rights and freedoms provided for in national legislative and constitutional frameworks. This goes beyond free and sovereign cooperation between national states, and progress is made with the establishment of supranational control mechanisms on them. Among other things, these initiatives are part of a security drift that increasingly puts fundamental rights, freedoms and guarantees at risk. Moreover, the supposed pretext for combating crime and terrorism, this proposal is part of a pressure framework, in the so-called "Process of European Integration", thus constituting another act of meddling in the political, economic and judicial system, as well as in the field of foreign and security policy. It is also recalled that the country's possible membership of NATO – the proposal for membership was submitted in December 2015 – as part of the EU's militarisation, and the extension of influence in the Balkan region.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I reject Eurojust as an agency. On the positive side, I am pleased that the report mentions the fight against international crime. I am abstaining from my voice.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on Eurojust's agreement to conclude a cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro. I am opposed to the enlargement of the EU at this stage, because the EU must first solve its own deep problems before it can meaningfully accept other members. A cooperation agreement with a non-EU country is also a step towards membership. I also reject preparatory actions for accession.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the Cooperation Agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, which aims to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The proposals in the draft agreement are intended to facilitate and intensify the fight against serious forms of crime and would contribute to strengthening judicial cooperation, in particular in the area of organised crime and terrorism.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to approve the cooperation agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, which aims to strengthen judicial cooperation in the fight against serious forms of crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report we have voted on today concerns the draft Council implementing decision on the proposal to approve an agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro, with the aim of improving judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime and terrorism. The draft agreement contains provisions concerning operational cooperation between Eurojust and Montenegro, such as montenegro's secondment of a liaison prosecutor to Eurojust and the exchange of information. The LIBE Commission has recommended that Parliament approve the draft Council decision. It is up to eurojust to approve by qualified majority the international cooperation agreements concluded by Eurojust with third countries. However, the Council is obliged to consult Parliament on approval but is not bound by the position expressed.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report because I see the cooperation of Eurojust and Montenegro as very important. The agreement will enable a much better fight against international organised crime and also provides the possibility of better judicial cooperation. As in the case of a similar agreement with Ukraine, I very much welcome the detailed provisions concerning, for example, the secondment of a Liaent Prosecutor from Montenegro and the exchange of information, including provisions on the exchange of personal data that are proportionate. Personally, I believe that we can only succeed in the fight against organised crime if the strategy is comprehensive and involves as many European states as possible.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the conclusion of an agreement between Eurojust and Montenegro aimed at closer judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, such as organised crime and terrorism.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, is accused of violating the highway code and administrative code of the Republic of Poland by exceeding the speed limit in an inhabited area. This type of violation does not cover diplomatic immunity because it is not inherent in any way in the parliamentary activity of the Member. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of waiving his immunity.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to suspend the parliamentary immunity of Mr Robert Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz so that he can deal with the cause for which he has been brought to justice, since the acts for which he has been accused have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on the request to lift the immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz. This proposal followed two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic which had been submitted by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland. This is an alleged violation of the Polish traffic code.  In this case, it is necessary that the immunity of a Polish Member of Parliament be lifted in order for him to pay his fines in Poland. Moreover, there is no indication of any desire to harm the Polish Member of Parliament. Out of respect for Polish law, which calls for this waiver of immunity, I support this text.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – MEP Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz has been charged with exceeding the speed limit in a built-up area. He had requested an annulment of the fine on the ground that the offence took place while he was performing parliamentary work – going to Brussels to attend a meeting of the European Parliament. Exceeding the speed limit does not constitute part of an MEPs duties, therefore I voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This request does not appear to be driven by a desire to undermine the political action of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz. Therefore, I am in favour of his immunity being waived so that he can pay his fine. Therefore I voted for it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should be a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I voted to waive the Parliamentary immunity. I do wish to note, however, my annoyance at the amount of public time spent dealing with a minor speeding offence. However, ultimately that is a matter for the people of Poland rather than the United Kingdom.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic calling for the lifting of the immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland, in relation to two alleged offences. In this case, Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious presumption, and specifies that the application was submitted with the intention of interfering with the political activity of the Member concerned. For a Polish MP to pay his fines in Poland, his immunity must be waived. That is why I did not object.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Following the unanimous vote of Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I voted in favour of the request to lift Mr Iwaszkiewicz's parliamentary immunity.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the pleading to suspend immunity in both versions as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This is an alleged violation of the Polish traffic code. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz's political activity. Polish law requires that his immunity be waived so that he can pay his fine.  I have therefore decided to vote for the lifting of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz's parliamentary immunity.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. As the report of the JURI Commission finds, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland sent last August to the European Parliament an injunction to suspend the immunity of European Mp. Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz in the face of the alleged commission of a traffic offence in September 2014. In so far as there is no connection between the infringement identified and its activity as a Member of the European Parliament and there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, Parliament voted in favour of the suspension of immunity, for which it voted in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has led Parliament to waive the immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, a Polish MEMBER. On 13 August 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland referred the President of Parliament to the High Inspectorate for Road Transport for the prosecution of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, a Member of the European Parliament, for an infringement of speeding at 29 km/h in Shklari, Poland. The facts on which Mr Iwaszkiewicz is accused constitute an infringement under the Polish Code of Administrative Offences. In order to rule on the waiver or waiver of a Member's immunity, the European Parliament applies its well-established principles, one of the following principles: immunity is normally waived if there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, i.e. sufficiently serious and clear suspicions that the court has been seised in order to damage the political reputation of the Member concerned. It is apparent from the circumstances of the case that the suspicion of an administrative offence and further administrative prosecution have nothing to do with mr Iwaszkiewicz's duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that, therefore, there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported the proposed decision to waive my fellow immunity of my colleague Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz. Whatever the circumstances, Members must also accept responsibility for their actions in road transport. It is therefore right that a colleague should be punished for speeding.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the infringement committed by Mr Syderman is a very serious one. Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz does not fall within the typology and modalities covered by the rules on parliamentary immunity and that, therefore, Mr Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz's parliamentary immunity is not covered by the rules of parliamentary immunity. Iwaszkiewicz must be revoked.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the General Inspectorate of Road Safety calling for the lifting of the immunity of MEP Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz for two alleged offences. In order for this MEMBER of the European Parliament to be able to avoid his fines, it is necessary to withdraw his parliamentary immunity. Since this request was clearly not submitted with the intention of harming the political activity of this Member of the European Parliament, I have spoken in favour of the lifting of his parliamentary immunity.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Infringement of the Polish Highway Code. There is no basis for the protection provided by Parliament.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The request for authorisation to proceed by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland against Mr Syderman is not a good one. Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz concerns a procedure relating to speeding offences. I therefore voted in favour because these are matters which go completely beyond the scope of the guarantee of parliamentary immunity.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the request for the waiver of my colleague's parliamentary immunity

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the application for waiver of the immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz. As the request concerns acts which are in no way related to the political activities and freedoms of the Member, I believe that we cannot and should not stand in the way of justice, and I therefore voted in favour of the waiver of the Member's immunity.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's proposal to revoke Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz's parliamentary immunity because I believe that the alleged infringement has no direct and obvious connection with the exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that Parliament has found no evidence of fumus persecutionis.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Mr Iwaszkiewicz is accused of an offence under Article 92a of the Polish Code of Administrative Offences in conjunction with Article 20(1) of the Polish Road Traffic Act of 20 June 1997. This case falls under Article 9 of Protocol (No 7) on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. This provides that Members, in the territory of their own state, are protected with the same immunities accorded to Members of the Parliament of that State. It is for the European Parliament to decide whether criminal proceedings against Mr Iwaszkiewicz are authorised. Immunity will generally be waived if the offence is within the remit of Article 9 of Protocol No 7, once there is no fumus persecutionis. It is clear that the facts of this case and the prosecution do not interfere with the position of Mr Iwaszkiewicz as a Member of the European Parliament thus there is no fumus persecutionis. Pursuant to Rule 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure the parliamentary immunity of Mr Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz should be waived.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament has correctly followed the procedures for verifying the conditions for invoking immunity by Mr Iwaszkiewicz and whereas this verification has shown that immunity has no legal basis for being invoked in this specific case, I agree with the assessment of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market and I am in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Parliamentary immunity is not a Member’s personal privilege but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament as a whole and of its Members. The case in question does not have a direct and obvious connection with the Member’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7. I have thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to suspend the parliamentary immunity of Mr Robert Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz so that he can deal with the cause for which he has been brought to justice, since the acts for which he has been accused have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report requests the removal of the parliamentary immunity for an MEP. As I have always done in these cases, I agree to the removal of immunity so that an MEP can prove his innocence or otherwise according to the judicial system of the relevant Member States.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. With regard to the lifting of the immunity of this Polish Mp, the alleged author of a traffic violation, there is no indication that there is a desire to interfere with the political activity of this elected official. In this case, and in order to allow the application of Polish law, I voted in favour of the lifting of The parliamentary immunity of Mr Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Immunity of the MEP is requested to be waived as it was recorded by a speed measurement camera moving at 79km/h in an area with a speed limit of 50km/h.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. 'I regularly vote in accordance with the committee responsible in immunity proceedings, where it is reasonable and in accordance with the Rules of Procedure that cases be referred to the national judiciary unless there are political motives.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of the European Parliament a request from the Polish Road Traffic Inspectorate to withdraw the immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz in connection with a traffic offence, since it did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations. From the circumstances of the present case it is inferred that the alleged offence and subsequent criminal proceedings clearly have nothing to do with Mr Iwaszkiewicz's position as a Member of the European Parliament and, therefore, I agree with the request for waiver of immunity made by the rapporteur.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it does not concern the activity of a Member of the European Parliament in the performance of his duties.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz. These are the facts: the General Inspectorate of Road Traffic in Poland claims that, On 7 September 2014, while driving a vehicle, Mr Iwaszkiewicz did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban.M agglomerations – which is 50 km/h – when driving the vehicle referred to at a speed of 79 km/h. The facts of which he is accused constitute an infringement of Article 92(a) of the Polish Code of Contratomes, together with Article 20(1) of the Road Traffic Act of 20 June 1997. Regardless of other considerations that may be made, the alleged infringement does not have a direct and obvious link with the performance of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member. Hence the vote in favour.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the waiver of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz's immunity, as parliamentary privileges must in no way lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Following the unanimous adoption of the decision by the JURI Committee of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of MEP Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the request on the basis that, on 13 August 2015, the Chief Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament the request of the Polish Inspector General for Transport Police to allow him to prosecute Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz MEP in connection with a speeding offence. According to the Polish Transport Police Inspectorate, on 31 December 2014, the polish transport police inspectorate had been in a state of shock. At 12.34pm on 7 September 2014, Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz did not respect the 50 km/h speed limit for a given residential area while driving an Opel car with the registration number DW404NA in the town of Szklary, but instead used the aforementioned vehicle at 79 km/h and exceeded this speed limit by 29 km/h.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading to suspend immunity in both versions as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive the immunity.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the decision to waive the immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, due to the fact that in similar cases involving Article 9 of Protocol No. 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, parliamentary immunity is usually waived. This is especially the case when there is no evidence of political motivation behind the prosecution, which there does not seem to be here. As a result, I am in favour of the conclusion made by the Committee of Legal Affairs to waive parliamentary immunity for Mr Iwaszkiewicz, and have the criminal proceedings begin.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 This colleague twice violated the speed limit with his car. Since these accusations have nothing to do with the parliamentary activities of this Member and that there is no suspicion of bias or political persecution (fulmus persecutionis), we voted in favour of the report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report in accordance with the position adopted by my political group after the Legal Affairs Committee’s evaluation.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift the immunity of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, on the basis that it was a violation of a restricted speed in a populated area unrelated to the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament. Moreover, there is no doubt that the application was made in order to cause political damage to Mr Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, and this is in accordance with Article 9 of the Regulation. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. It does not seem to me that this request is driven by a desire to undermine the political action of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz. Therefore, I am in favour of his immunity being waived so that he can pay his fine. Therefore I vote for.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the decision on the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz. This procedure is a formality which, without deciding on the merits of the case, is intended to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work. This decision was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am following the decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs to waive Mr Iwaszkiewicz's immunity. The incident described occurred before his time as an EU mandater and is unrelated to the exercise of the mandate.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive the immunity.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted to lift the parliamentary immunity of Mr Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz, because this is not a political matter, but an alleged breach of the Polish traffic code, for speeding. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with Mr. Siekierski's political activity.  Polish law requires that his immunity be waived so that he can pay his fine.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes to lift the parliamentary immunity of a Member of Parliament prosecuted for a traffic violation.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 This specific request for waiver of the immunity of a Member of the European Parliament stems from the fact that By Polish MEP Robert Jaroslav Ivaškevičs on 7 September 2014, driving in the city at a speed of 79 km/h, while the speed of the inner city in Poland is only 50 km/h. On 13 August 2015, a decision was taken to waive the immunity of Mr Ivaškevičs, acting as President of the European Parliament, at the request of the Polish Road Traffic Headquarters and the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament. I agree with this decision because it is necessary that all the principles mentioned in the legislation of the Republic of Poland and relevant to this type of situation be respected, and Mr Ivaškevičs would not have any contradiction with his homeland law.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 The request for waiver of immunity concerns a traffic offence committed on the territory of the Republic of Poland. In accordance with EU law and the law of the Republic of Poland, the waiver of immunity is necessary in order to hold them criminally liable. I respect the law and have confidence in a fair investigation and resolution of the offence, so I agree with the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of the immunity of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this waiver of immunity. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the Polish Traffic Inspectorate for two alleged offences by Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz. It was felt that this first request was not made to interfere with the Member's activity, which is why we believe that it is necessary to lift his immunity so that he can pay his fines in Poland.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the waiving of the immunity of Mr Iwaszkiewicz. In this case, the request for waiver of the immunity of Mr Iwaszkiewicz has been submitted as a result of an alleged offence consisting of exceeding the speed limit in a built-up area. It appears from the file that Mr Iwaszkiewicz admitted on 5 June 2015 that he was driving the vehicle at the relevant time, although he had requested earlier, on 8 February 2015, the annulment of the fine on the ground that the offence took place while performing parliamentary work – going to Brussels to attend a meeting of the European Parliament. From the circumstances of the case it appears that the alleged offence and the ensuing prosecution clearly have nothing to do with the position of Mr Iwaszkiewicz as a Member of the European Parliament and that there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have expressed my opposition to the request for waiver of Mr Sley's immunity. Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, because I believe that parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege of a Member but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament and its Members as a super partes institution. I remain convinced that a guarantee line must be followed in these cases and i will therefore continue to vote against this type of report in defence of the institutional role conferred by this Parliament.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. There are no politically motivated reasons for this extradition request. These are traffic offences. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The request concerns the lifting of the immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland.  The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted a request from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic for an offence of speeding in an agglomeration. Indeed, the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic claims that on 7 September 2014, at 12:34 p.m., in the town of Szklary, Mr. Iwaszkiewicz was photographed by a radar while driving a vehicle travelling at a speed of 79 km/h on a road with an authorized speed of 50 km/h. Since the offence is unrelated to his parliamentary activity and Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz does not oppose the lifting of immunity, I voted in favour.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. It does not seem to me that this request is driven by a desire to undermine the political action of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz. Therefore, I am in favour of his immunity being waived so that he can pay his fine. Therefore I vote for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz. The application fulfils the requirements for the application of Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union: the waiver of the Member's immunity is lifted where the offence is not related to the performance of the duties of a Member and provided that there is no suspicion of fumus persecutionis, i.e. a serious and reasoned suspicion that the criminal proceedings are intended to harm the Member politically.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I voted to lift the parliamentary immunity of Mr Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, because speeding in an agglomeration cannot be justified as an act committed in the context of parliamentary duties. Parliamentary immunity goes hand in hand with the freedom and independence of the legislative branch. Parliamentary immunity is an immunity from office that aims above all to protect women or politicians from pressure, wherever they come from, to ensure the independence of their vote. The act of Mr. Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz does not fit into this situation.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Polish Transport Police Inspectorate intends to prosecute Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz MEP for exceeding the speed limit for that residential area by his car at 12.34pm on 7 September 2014. On 13 August 2015, the Chief Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland forwarded the Request of the President of the European Parliament for authorisation of the Chief Inspectorate to prosecute. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs states that the alleged infringement is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of the duties of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz MEP and that there are no serious and well-founded suspicions that the request was made with a view to causing political damage to the Member, and therefore recommends that Parliament suspend the Member's immunity in the context of the case in question. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, once all the legal procedures required have elapsed and because the offence in question is not in any way related to the performance of the duties of a Member and that there is no evidence or suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, the intention to harm the Member concerned is politically impaired.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic calling for the lifting of the immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland, in relation to two alleged offences. In this case, Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious presumption, and specifies that the application was submitted with the intention of interfering with the political activity of the Member concerned. In order for a Polish Member of Parliament to pay his fines in Poland, it is necessary for his immunity to be lifted, so I vote for this lifting.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee.  I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. Mr. Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz's request to waive his immunity was part of a normal procedure for traffic violations. I therefore voted in favour of lifting parliamentary immunity.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to Parliament's proposal to waive the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, I voted in favour because I believe that the alleged infringement has no direct connection with the exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report in accordance with the evaluation made by the JURI Committee.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Robert Jaroslaw is accused of having committed an administrative offence within the meaning of Article 92a of the Polish Law on Administrative Offences in connection with Article 20(1) of the Polish Road Traffic Code of 20 June 1997 on 21 August 2014. I voted in favour of the deprivation of liberty at the expense of Robert Jaoslaw and Am in favour of waiving parliamentary immunity until this case is resolved and no more accusations are made.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the action taken by Member Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, I vote in favour of the request for waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The report calls for the MP to be waived for immunity so that he can pay a fine for traffic offences. Since this has nothing to do with his political activity as a Member of Parliament, I have no reason to oppose this lifting of immunity and I therefore vote in favour of the text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation to lift the immunity of my colleague Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, as the prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or to vote in the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8(1) of the EIA. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunisms of the European Union and the alleged offence is clearly in no relation to the performance of my colleague Iwaszkiewicz's duties as a Member of the European Parliament.  It is a traffic offence of speeding in a populated area and there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis). At issue is compliance with the regulations of the member state from which fellow Siekierski comes, as stipulated in Article 9 of the European Union. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz. The alleged infringement which motivates the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity does not have a direct and obvious link with the exercise of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member. In the express, we voted in favour of the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 On 13 August 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament the request made by the head of the municipal police to grant permission to initiate legal proceedings against Mr Syoderman. Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz. The reason for this request is a high speeding of driving a car dating back to 7 September 2014. Pursuant to Rule 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament waive the parliamentary immunity of Mr Sleyn. Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz. I voted in favour of waiving immunity so that the Polish authorities can proceed with the verification of whether or not the traffic code has been breached.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the withdrawal of mr. Iwaszkiewicz's immunity. Immunity is not intended to protect against penalties for traffic offences, but to protect against possible penalties for political expression of opinion. The case of my colleague Iwaszkiewicz is clear in this respect, and so is my position.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of these requests to waive parliamentary immunity because in this case it is a common procedure.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 On 13 August 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of the European Parliament a request from the Polish Road Traffic Inspectorate to withdraw the immunity of Member of the European Parliament Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz in connection with a traffic offence. The Polish General Road Traffic Inspectorate alleges that at 11.46 pm on 21 August 2014 in the town of Rawicz, Mr Iwaszkiewicz was registered by a traffic control camera while travelling at a speed of 94 km/h in an area with a speed limit of 60 km/h. This report approves the decision to withdraw the immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz and instructs its President to transmit this Decision immediately, as well as the report of his competent committee, to the relevant authorities of the Republic of Poland and to Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. As the report of the JURI Commission finds, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland sent last August to the European Parliament an injunction to suspend the immunity of European Mp. Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz in the face of the alleged commission of a traffic offence in September 2014. In so far as there is no connection between the infringement identified and its activity as a Member of the European Parliament and there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, Parliament voted in favour of the suspension of immunity, for which it voted in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr. So that the Polish judiciary can carry out its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, in the same respect for the alleged facts - non-compliance with the speed limit in agglomerations - are clearly unrelated to the office of Member of Parliament of Mr Robert Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz and are not motivated by the desire to harm the political action of the Member.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz. This is a request made by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland, concerning a case relating to a traffic offence where, allegedly, on 7 September 2014, the Member did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations – which is 50 km/h – when driving the vehicle at a speed of 79 km/h. There is no reason to doubt the legitimate intention underlying this legal action, and in view of the fulfilment of the conditions set out in Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, I consider the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity to be appropriate and, to that end, I voted in favour.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading to suspend immunity in both versions as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. In order to be a member of the European Union, you have to have a rule of law. We must therefore have confidence that the Member State's judiciary can judge when an indictment against a Member of the European Parliament is strong enough to waive immunity so that the case can be tried in court. That is why I support the repeal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to suspend the parliamentary immunity of Mr Robert Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz so that he can deal with the cause for which he has been brought to justice, since the acts for which he has been accused have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of removing the immunity: the law should be allowed to run its course.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The Polish Constitution grants immunity to parliamentarians for speeding when driving, which is why a vote must be performed in order to allow Mr Iwaszkeiwicz to be brought to justice over a traffic infraction that he made in September 2014. Mr Iwaszkiewicz had admitted that he was driving the vehicle in June 2015, but argued for the annulment of the fine on the ground that the offence took place while performing parliamentary work – going to Brussels to attend a meeting of the European Parliament. From the circumstances of the case it appears that the alleged offence and the ensuing prosecution clearly have nothing to do with the position of Mr Iwaszkiewicz as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, because it is important that, in the Republic of Poland, where the named Member has committed an offence, his offence should also be investigated by inferred appropriate sanctions. The request for waiver of immunity was made by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland in connection with criminal proceedings to be initiated by the Chief Transport Inspectorate. Poland's chief transport inspectorate says that back in September 2014, an MEP violated traffic regulations by exceeding it by 29 km while driving in a stopped area where a maximum speed of 50 km/hour was prescribed. In order for the whole case to be investigated with subsequent punishment under the applicable road traffic laws in the Republic of Poland, it was necessary to waive the parliamentary immunity of my fellow Member Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz is accused of exceeding the speed limit in a populated area. As the alleged infringement is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and in this case Parliament found no evidence of sufficiently serious and reasonable suspicion that the application was made with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis), I supported the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted to lift this Member's immunity so that he could have the free rein to defend himself in the courts of his country.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic accuses Mr Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz of failing to respect the speed limit. This accusation does not impact Mr. Iwaszkiewicz’s capacity to perform his duty as an MEP nor it is with intent to cause him political damage, therefore I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of the MEP Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to lift the immunity of Polish MEP Robert Jarsolaw Iwaszkiewicz.  According to the Polish Inspectorate General of Road Transport, the representative committed the offence of speeding in a populated area on 7 September 2014. Since the alleged offence is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament, I consider that there is no reason to assume that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the Member concerned.  Given that the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has forwarded to the President parliament a request by the Polish Inspectorate General of Road Transport to lift the immunity of Representative Robert Jarsolaw Iwaszkiewicz, I consider it correct that the Member be waived his immunity and given a fair trial.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity from Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, as I agree that the violation (too fast), which is legislatively defined, gives a negative example to a Member in a Member State and potentially casts a bad light on all Members. Nor can immunity be invoked if a Member is caught in an offence. A bad example for European citizens would say so.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading to suspend immunity in both versions as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic calling for the lifting of the immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland, in relation to two alleged offences.
