In this case, Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious presumption, and specifies that the application was submitted with the intention of interfering with the political activity of the Member concerned.  For a Polish MP to pay his fines in Poland, his immunity must be waived. So I voted for it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 On 13 August 2015, the Chief Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request from the Polish Inspector General for Transport Police to authorise the prosecution of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz MEP in connection with a speeding offence. Iwaszkiewicz admitted driving the car at the time. I followed the S&D group's position on the matter and supported the motion.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading to suspend immunity in both versions as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for waiver of the immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz. On 13 August 2015 the Prosecutor-General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request made by the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic to grant authorisation to take legal action against a Member of the European Parliament, Mr Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, in connection with a speeding offence. In this case, the request for waiver of the immunity of Mr Iwaszkiewicz has been submitted as a result of an alleged offence consisting of exceeding the speed limit in a built-up area. It appears from the file that Mr Iwaszkiewicz has not admitted that he was driving the vehicle at the relevant time, nor that he accepts the fine. From the circumstances of the case it appears that the alleged offence and the ensuing prosecution clearly have nothing to do with the position of Mr Iwaszkiewicz as a Member of the European Parliament and that there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis. The Committee on Legal Affairs recommended that the European Parliament should waive the parliamentary immunity and this is why I voted in favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of the lifting of parliamentary immunity so that one can defend itself before the national courts.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The alleged infringement does not have a direct and obvious link with the performance of Czesław Adam Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. There are no politically motivated reasons for this extradition request. These are traffic offences. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, is accused of violating the highway code and administrative code of the Republic of Poland by exceeding the speed limit in an inhabited area. This type of violation does not cover diplomatic immunity because it is not inherent in any way in the parliamentary activity of the Member. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to suspend the parliamentary immunity of Mr Robert Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz so that he can deal with the cause for which he has been brought to justice, since the acts for which he has been accused have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – MEP Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz has been charged with exceeding the speed limit in a built-up area. He had requested an annulment of the fine on the ground that the offence took place while he was performing parliamentary work – going to Brussels to attend a meeting of the European Parliament. Exceeding the speed limit does not constitute part of an MEPs duties, therefore we voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This request does not appear to be driven by a desire to undermine the political action of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz. Therefore, I am in favour of his immunity being waived so that he can pay his fine. So I voted in favour of it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should be a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I voted to waive the Parliamentary immunity. I do wish to note, however, my annoyance at the amount of public time spent dealing with a minor speeding offence. However, ultimately that is a matter for the people of Poland rather than the United Kingdom.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic calling for the lifting of the immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland, in relation to two alleged offences. In this case, Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious presumption, and specifies that the application was submitted with the intention of interfering with the political activity of the Member concerned.  For a Polish MP to pay his fines in Poland, his immunity must be waived. That is why I did not object.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Following the unanimous vote of Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I voted in favour of mr Iwaszkiewicz's request to lift his parliamentary immunity.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the pleading to suspend immunity in both versions as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This is an alleged violation of the Polish traffic code. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz's political activity. Polish law requires that his immunity be waived so that he can pay his fine.  I have therefore decided to vote for the lifting of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz's parliamentary immunity.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. As the report of the JURI Commission finds, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland sent last August to the European Parliament an injunction to suspend the immunity of European Mp. Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz in the face of the alleged commission of a traffic offence in August 2014. In so far as there is no connection between the infringement identified and its activity as a Member of the European Parliament and there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, Parliament voted in favour of the suspension of immunity, for which it voted in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has led Parliament to waive the immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, a Polish MEMBER. On 13 August 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland referred the President of Parliament to the High Inspectorate for Road Transport for the prosecution of R.J. Iwaszkiewicz for the offence of speeding in the city of 34 km/h in Ravičiau, Poland. The facts on which Mr Iwaszkiewicz is accused constitute an infringement under the Polish Code of Administrative Offences. In order to rule on the waiver or waiver of a Member's immunity, the European Parliament applies its well-established principles, one of the following principles: immunity is normally waived if there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, i.e. sufficiently serious and clear suspicions that the court has been seised in order to damage the political reputation of the Member concerned. It is apparent from the circumstances of the case that the suspicion of an administrative offence and further administrative prosecution have nothing to do with mr Iwaszkiewicz's duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that, therefore, there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported the proposed decision to waive my fellow immunity of my colleague Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz. Whatever the circumstances, Members must also accept responsibility for their actions in road transport. Given that a colleague in the car has a heavy leg several times, it is absolutely right that he should be properly sanctioned.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the infringement committed by Mr Syderman is a very serious one. Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz does not fall within the typology and modalities covered by the rules on parliamentary immunity and that, therefore, Mr Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz's parliamentary immunity is not covered by the rules of parliamentary immunity. Iwaszkiewicz must be revoked.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the General Inspectorate of Road Safety calling for the lifting of the immunity of MEP Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz for two alleged offences. In order for this MEMBER of the European Parliament to be able to avoid his fines, it is necessary to withdraw his parliamentary immunity. Since this request was clearly not submitted with the intention of harming the political activity of this Member of the European Parliament, I have spoken in favour of the lifting of his parliamentary immunity.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Infringement of the Polish Highway Code. There is no basis for the protection provided by Parliament.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliamentary immunity is a safeguard for the freedom and independence of Members of Parliament and not a personal benefit. The events in which the Polish Attorney-General intends to proceed against my colleague Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz are not about the latter's exercise of his duties as a Member of Parliament, but about certain violations of the highway code.  I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the request for waiver of immunity.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the request for the waiver of my colleague's parliamentary immunity

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the application for waiver of the immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz. As the request concerns acts which are in no way related to the political activities and freedoms of the Member, I believe that we cannot and should not stand in the way of justice and therefore voted in favour of the waiver of the Member's immunity.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the European Parliament's proposal to waive the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz. As in the previous case, I believe that the infringement in question does not have a direct and obvious causal link with the exercise of its duties as a Member of the European Parliament. Furthermore, I do not think that Parliament can find any evidence of fumus persecutionis in the circumstances of the case.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Mr Iwaszkiewicz is accused of an offence under Article 92a of the Polish Code of Administrative Offences in conjunction with Article 20(1) of the Polish Road Traffic Act of 20 June 1997. This case falls under Article 9 of Protocol (No 7) on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. This provides that Members, in the territory of their own state, are protected with the same immunities accorded to Members of the Parliament of that state. It is for the European Parliament to decide whether criminal proceedings against Mr Iwaszkiewicz are authorised. Immunity will generally be waived if the offence is within the remit of Article 9 of Protocol No 7, once there is no fumus persecutionis. It is clear that the facts of this case and the prosecution do not interfere with the position of Mr Iwaszkiewicz as a Member of the European Parliament, thus there is no fumus persecutionis. Pursuant to Rule 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure the parliamentary immunity of Mr Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz should be waived.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament has correctly followed the procedures for verifying the conditions for invoking immunity by Mr Iwaszkiewicz and whereas this verification has shown that immunity has no legal basis for being invoked in this specific case, I agree with the assessment of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market and I am in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒  Parliamentary immunity is not a Member’s personal privilege but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament as a whole and of its Members. The case in question does not have a direct and obvious connection with the Member’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7. I have thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, deputy member of the EFDD Group, is accused of violating on two separate occasions (Ref. proc. n. CAN-PST-SCW.7421.1158450.2014.5.A.0475 and n. CAN-PST-SCW.7421.1209083.2014.9.A.0475) the highway code and administrative code of the Polish Republic exceeding the speed limit in an inhabited area. For the rapporteur, this type of violation is not covered by diplomatic immunity because it is in no way inherent in the parliamentary activity of the Member. On the other hand, Mr Iwaszkiewicz did not come to the JURI Commission for his own defence but (as reported by the Pres. Svoboda) sent a message in which he basically referred the matter to the committee. The JURI Committee voted in favour of the rapporteur's request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz for both procedures in question. I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to suspend the parliamentary immunity of Mr Robert Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz so that he can deal with the cause for which he has been brought to justice, since the acts for which he has been accused have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report requests the removal of the parliamentary immunity for an MEP. As I have always done in these cases, I agree to the removal of immunity so that an MEP can prove his innocence or otherwise according to the judicial system of the relevant Member States.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. With regard to the lifting of the immunity of this Polish Mp, the alleged author of a traffic violation, there is no indication that there is a desire to interfere with the political activity of this elected official. In this case, and in order to allow the application of Polish law, I voted in favour of the lifting of The parliamentary immunity of Mr Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. 'I regularly vote in accordance with the committee responsible in immunity proceedings, where it is reasonable and in accordance with the Rules of Procedure that cases be referred to the national judiciary unless there are political motives.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 In this case, Mr Iwaszkiewicz's application for waiver was lodged because of an alleged infringement which consisted of exceeding the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations, since the vehicle he was following was registered by a traffic control camera when travelling at a speed of 94 km/h in an area with a speed limit of 60 km/h. From the circumstances of the present case it is inferred that the alleged offence and subsequent criminal proceedings clearly have nothing to do with Mr Iwaszkiewicz's position as a Member of the European Parliament and, therefore, I agree with the request for waiver of immunity made by the rapporteur.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it does not concern the activity of a Member of the European Parliament in his or her position.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, like others previously voted, focuses on the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity by Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz. These are the facts: the General Inspectorate of Road Traffic in Poland claims that, On 7 September 2014, while driving a vehicle, Mr Iwaszkiewicz did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban.M agglomerations – which is 50 km/h – when driving the vehicle referred to at a speed of 79 km/h. The facts of which he is accused constitute an infringement of Article 92(a) of the Polish Code of Contratomes, together with Article 20(1) of the Road Traffic Act of 20 June 1997. Regardless of other considerations that may be made, the alleged infringement does not have a direct and obvious link with the performance of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the waiver of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz's immunity, as parliamentary privileges must in no way lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Following the unanimous adoption of the decision by the JURI Committee of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of MEP Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the request on the basis that, on 13 August 2015, the Chief Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament the request of the Polish Inspector General for Transport Police to allow him to prosecute Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz MEP in connection with a speeding offence. According to the Polish Transport Police Inspectorate, on 31 December 2014, the polish transport police inspectorate had been in a state of shock. At 12.34pm on 7 September 2014, Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz did not respect the 50 km/h speed limit for a given residential area while driving an Opel car with the registration number DW404NA in the town of Szklary, but instead used the aforementioned vehicle at 79 km/h and exceeded this speed limit by 29 km/h.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading to suspend immunity in both versions as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the decision to waive the immunity of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, due to the fact that in similar cases involving Article 9 of Protocol No. 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, parliamentary immunity is usually waived. This is especially the case when there is no evidence of political motivation behind the prosecution, which there does not seem to be here. As a result, I am in favour of the conclusion made by the Committee of Legal Affairs to waive parliamentary immunity for Mr Iwaszkiewicz, and have the criminal proceedings begin.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 This colleague twice violated the speed limit with his car. Since these accusations have nothing to do with the parliamentary activities of this Member and that there is no suspicion of bias or political persecution ( fulmus persecutionis), we voted in favour of the report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report in accordance with the position adopted by my political group after the Legal Affairs Committee’s evaluation.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on the application to lift the immunity of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, as this is in line with Article 9 of the European Union. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and for the sake of the established fact that there is no reasonable doubt that immunity is lifted with a view to causing political harm, but is an infringement of exceeding the permitted speed in a populated area. Such a vote is also the position of the ALDE Group.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. It does not seem to me that this request is driven by a desire to undermine the political action of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz. Therefore, I am in favour of his immunity being waived so that he can pay his fine. Therefore, I vote for it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the decision on the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz. This procedure is a formality which, without deciding on the merits of the case, is intended to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work. This decision was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am following the decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs to waive Mr Iwaszkiewicz's immunity. The incident described occurred before his time as an EU mandater and is unrelated to the exercise of the mandate.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive the immunity.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted to lift the parliamentary immunity of Mr Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz, because this is not a political matter, but an alleged breach of the Polish traffic code, for speeding. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with Mr. Siekierski's political activity. Polish law requires that his immunity be waived so that he can pay his fine.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes to lift the parliamentary immunity of a Member of Parliament prosecuted for a traffic violation.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. In August 2015, poland's main prosecutor's office applied for the authorisation of legal acts against MEP Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz for a traffic offence for exceeding the permitted driving speed.  In particular, Representative Iwaszkiewicz was driving at 29 km/h faster than the permitted speed in a populated area where speeds of 50 km/h are allowed. Since the MP admitted being the driver of the car at the time of the offence, he is held responsible for the offence.  The MEP invoked immunity and the Chief Prosecutor of Poland forwarded an inquiry to the European Parliament to have his immunity lifted. I supported the request for the waiver of immunity since the Member did not perform official parliamentary duties at the time of the offence.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Similar to the previous vote on the waiver of the immunity of Robert Jarosław Ivaškevics, this case also concerns speeding. Unlike the first case, however, Mr Ivaškevičs did not in any way confirm that he was driving a car at a speed of 94 km/h in an area with a limit of 60 km/h, even though his face is clearly visible in the photograph taken during the overspeed. On the same basis as in the first case, namely the conclusion of the Polish Central Administration of the Republic of Poland sent to the President of the European Parliament on 13 August 2015 and by the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament, a decision was taken to waive the immunity of Mr Ivaškevičs. I agree with the decision, as no Member of the European Parliament can have any unregulated contradiction with any national judicial system.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of the immunity of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted to waive his immunity. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the Polish Traffic Inspectorate for two alleged offences by Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz. It was felt that this second request was not made to interfere with the Member's activity, which is why we believe that it is necessary to lift his immunity so that he can pay his fines in Poland.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support the waiving of Mr Iwaszkiewicz’s immunity. In this case, the request for waiver of the immunity of Mr Iwaszkiewicz has been submitted as a result of an alleged offence consisting of exceeding the speed limit in a built-up area. It appears from the file that Mr Iwaszkiewicz has not admitted that he was driving the vehicle at the relevant time, nor that he accepts the fine. From the circumstances of the case it appears that the alleged offence and the ensuing prosecution clearly have nothing to do with the position of Mr Iwaszkiewicz as a Member of the European Parliament and that there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have expressed my opposition to the request for waiver of Mr Sley's immunity. Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, because I believe that parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege of a Member but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament and its Members as a super partes institution. I remain convinced that a guarantee line must be followed in these cases and i will therefore continue to vote against this type of report in defence of the institutional role conferred by this Parliament.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. There are no politically motivated reasons for this extradition request. These are traffic offences. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The request concerns the lifting of the immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted a request from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic for an offence of speeding in an agglomeration.  The Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic claims that on 21 August 2014, at 2346 hours in the town of Rawicz, Mr. Iwaszkiewicz was photographed by a radar while driving a vehicle travelling at a speed of 94 km/h on a road with an authorized speed of 60 km/h.  Since the offence is unrelated to his parliamentary activity and That Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz does not object to the lifting of immunity, I vote For and urge Mr. Iwaszkiewicz to exercise caution while driving.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. It does not seem to me that this request is driven by a desire to undermine the political action of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz. I am therefore in favour of his immunity being waived so that he can pay his fine. Therefore I vote for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz. The application fulfils the requirements for the application of Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union: the waiver of the Member's immunity is lifted where the offence is not related to the performance of the duties of a Member and provided that there is no suspicion of fumus persecutionis, i.e. a serious and reasoned suspicion that the criminal proceedings are intended to harm the Member politically.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Polish Transport Police Inspectorate intends to prosecute Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz MEP for exceeding the speed limit in rawicz at 23.46 on 21 August 2014. On 13 August 2015, the Chief Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland forwarded the Request of the President of the European Parliament for authorisation of the Chief Inspectorate to prosecute. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs states that the alleged infringement is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of the duties of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, a Member of the European Parliament, nor does it constitute a vote or an opinion expressed in the exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament under Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. Furthermore, there is no serious and substantiated suspicion that the request was made for the purpose of causing political damage to the Member, and therefore proposes that Parliament suspend the Member's immunity in the context of the matter in question. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, once all the legal procedures required have elapsed and because the offence in question is not in any way related to the performance of the duties of a Member and that there is no evidence or suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, the intention to harm the Member concerned is politically impaired.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic calling for the lifting of the immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland, in relation to two alleged offences. In this case, Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious presumption, and specifies that the application was submitted with the intention of interfering with the political activity of the Member concerned. In order for a Polish Member of Parliament to pay his fines in Poland, it is necessary for his immunity to be lifted, so I vote for this lifting.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to Parliament's proposal to revoke the parliamentary immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, I voted in favour because I believe that the alleged infringement has no obvious connection with the exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report in accordance with the evaluation made by the JURI Committee.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Robert Jaroslaw is accused of having committed an administrative offence within the meaning of Article 92a of the Polish Law on Administrative Offences in connection with Article 20(1) of the Polish Road Traffic Code of 20 June 1997 on 21 August 2014. I voted in favour of the deprivation of liberty at the expense of Robert Yaroslav and Am in favour of waiving parliamentary immunity until this case is resolved and no more accusations are made.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the action taken by Member Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, I vote in favour of the request for waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The report calls for the MP to be waived for immunity so that he can pay a fine for traffic offences. Since this has nothing to do with his political activity as a Member of Parliament, I have no reason to oppose this lifting of immunity and I therefore vote in favour of the text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation to lift the immunity of my colleague Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, as the prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or to vote in the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8(1) of the EIA. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunisms of the European Union and the alleged offence is clearly in no relation to the performance of my colleague Iwaszkiewicz's duties as a Member of the European Parliament.  It is a traffic offence of speeding in a populated area and there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis). At issue is compliance with the regulations of the Member State from which my colleague Iwaszkiewic comes, as required by Article 9 of the EEA. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity to Mr Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz. The alleged infringement which motivates the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity does not have a direct and obvious link with the exercise of Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member. In the express, we voted in favour of the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Pursuant to Rule 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament waive The honourable Member's parliamentary immunity. Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz. I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Member of the European Parliament Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, because I believe that the Polish Attorney-General should be allowed to carry out the appropriate investigations.  Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz is accused of speeding in his country. The indictment relates to August 21, 2014. In any case, I would like to stress that my vote in favour of such a revocation does not involve a judgment as to the guilt or innocence of the Member.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of these requests to waive parliamentary immunity because in this case it is a common procedure.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 Still on the case of The Member of the European Parliament Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, I approved the report which, in addition to stating that the alleged infringement does not have a direct or obvious link with the exercise of the duties of a Member, it also does not concern opinions or votes expressed in the performance of his duties within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. This report therefore approves the decision to lift the immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. As the report of the JURI Commission finds, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland sent last August to the European Parliament an injunction to suspend the immunity of European Mp. Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz in the face of the alleged commission of a traffic offence in August 2014. In so far as there is no connection between the infringement identified and its activity as a Member of the European Parliament and there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, Parliament voted in favour of the suspension of immunity, for which it voted in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of the immunity of Mr Robert Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz, so that the Polish justice system could carry out its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the alleged facts - non-compliance with the speed limit in the agglomeration - are clearly not related to the office of Member of Parliament of Mr Robert Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz , and are not motivated by the desire to interfere with the MP's political action.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 As in the previous application, here too we are facing a request by the Polish Attorney General to apply for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Iwaszkiewicz in relation to an alleged road traffic offence committed on 21 August 2014 for driving at an excessive speed of 94km/h when the limit in the area was 60km/h. Since this is conduct allegedly carried out outside your mandate as an MEP and there is no reason to doubt the legitimate intention underlying this road infringement procedure, I voted in favour of this request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity, as aresult of the verification of the conditions listed in Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunity of the European Union.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading to suspend immunity in both versions as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. In order to be a member of the European Union, you have to have a rule of law. We must therefore have confidence that the Member State's judiciary can judge when an indictment against a Member of the European Parliament is strong enough to waive immunity so that the case can be tried in court. That is why I support the repeal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to suspend the parliamentary immunity of Mr Robert Jaros-aw Iwaszkiewicz so that he can deal with the cause for which he has been brought to justice, since the acts for which he has been accused have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of removing the immunity: the law should be allowed to run its course.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ As with the previous vote, the Polish Constitution grants immunity to parliamentarians for traffic offences, such as speeding, when performing their parliamentary duties. Similarly, I do not wish to stand in the way of the course of justice and I supported the vote to have Mr. Iwaszkiewicz tried for this offence. This case has a slight difference from the previous one, as Mr. Iwaszkiewicz does not accept that he was driving the vehicle at the time of the allegation and does not accept the fine; if the Member desires to clear his name of this accusation, I believe that it should be taken through the judicial system.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ poland's Chief Traffic Inspectorate recorded a traffic offence by MEP Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz when he was recorded speeding at 94 km/h in August 2014 in a speed limitation zone of 60 km/h. As an MEP is covered by the Polish Parliamentary Immunity Act, Members and senators cannot be held criminally liable without the consent of the Sejm or the Senate. In this case, it is for the EP to waive its immunity, therefore the request of the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland was submitted to the President of the EP. After discussion in the relevant committee, the request was forwarded to the EP for a vote. In the interests of justice, we waived the parliamentary immunity of my fellow Member Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz in the vote so that he could be held accountable for the offence he committed in his country, even if he was protected by parliamentary immunity.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz is accused of exceeding the speed limit in a populated area. As the alleged infringement is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and in this case Parliament found no evidence of sufficiently serious and reasonable suspicion that the application was made with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis), I supported the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted to lift this Member's immunity so that he could have the free rein to defend himself in the courts of his country.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic accuses Mr Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz of failing to respect the speed limit. This accusation does not intend to cause political damage to Mr Iwaszkiewicz. Without prejudging on his guilt, I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of the MEP Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported a request to lift the immunity of Polish MEP Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, who is accused of committing a speeding offence in a populated area on 21 August 2014. As in the last report, I consider that there is not a sufficiently serious and reasonable suspicion that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the Member concerned, since the alleged offence is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament.  Since the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has forwarded a request by the Polish Inspectorate General of Road Transport to authorise legal action against Representative Robert Jaroslaw Iwaszkiewicz, as in the previous case, I consider it right that the Member be waived his or her immunity and given a fair and impartial trial.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity from Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, as I agree that the infringement, which is leash, gives a negative example to a Member in a Member State and potentially casts a bad light on all Members.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading to suspend immunity in both versions as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic calling for the lifting of the immunity of Robert Jarosaw Iwaszkiewicz, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland, in relation to two alleged offences. In this case, Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious presumption, and specifies that the application was submitted with the intention of interfering with the political activity of the Member concerned. For a Polish MP to pay his fines in Poland, his immunity must be waived.  So I voted for it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 On 13 August 2015, the Chief Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request from the Polish Inspector General for Transport Police to authorise the prosecution of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz MEP in connection with a speeding offence. According to the Polish Transport Police Inspectorate, the photo of the trafipax clearly shows the face of the person driving the vehicle, Robert Iwaszkiewicz MEP, at the time of the offence. I followed the S&D group's position on the matter and supported the motion.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading to suspend immunity in both versions as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for waiver of the immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz. On 13 August 2015 the Prosecutor-General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request made by the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic to grant authorisation to take legal action against a Member of the European Parliament, Mr Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, in connection with a speeding offence. In this case, the request for waiver of the immunity of Mr Iwaszkiewicz has been submitted as a result of an alleged offence consisting of exceeding the speed limit in a built-up area. It appears from the file that Mr Iwaszkiewicz has not admitted that he was driving the vehicle at the relevant time, nor that he accepts the fine. From the circumstances of the case it appears that the alleged offence and the ensuing prosecution clearly have nothing to do with the position of Mr Iwaszkiewicz as a Member of the European Parliament and that there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis. The Committee on Legal Affairs recommended that the European Parliament should waive the parliamentary immunity and this is why I voted in favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of the lifting of parliamentary immunity so that one can defend itself before the national courts.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The alleged infringement does not have a direct and obvious link with the performance of Czesław Adam Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. There are no politically motivated reasons for this extradition request. These are traffic offences. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I support the proposal for a European Parliament decision requesting the waiver of the immunity of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, because the report concluded that the alleged offence and the resulting criminal prosecution were clearly unrelated to the situation of Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz as a Member of the European Parliament and that there was no evidence of the existence of a serious and reasonable suspicion that the case was raised with intent to cause political harm to a Member.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 MEP Florian Philippot has been accused of defamation by the state of Qatar. My colleague Philippot, during a radio program that aired on January 9, 2015 and in a television program that aired on January 9, 2015, insinuated that Qatar was funding terrorism. I have chosen to vote in favour because I believe that these statements fall within the freedom of expression covered by parliamentary immunity, which is guaranteed for what has been said at official meetings of Parliament but also in other forums, for example during interviews with the media.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which calls for the withdrawal of parliamentary immunity from Mr Florian Philippot since the facts for which he has been sued are directly related to his work as an MEP. Parliamentary immunity can under no circumstances be used as a political weapon. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text to support the opinion against the lifting of Florian Philippot's immunity from the Committee on Legal Affairs.  This text followed the defamation proceedings brought by the State of Qatar against him. Like the Committee on Legal Affairs, I consider respect for freedom of expression and opinion to be a sacred value.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted against the waiver of the immunity of Florian Philippot on the grounds of the fundamental right to freedom of expression and, moreover, on the right to express opinion in the course of an elected representative’s parliamentary duties.  It would be a serious limitation of one’s functioning as a Member of the European Parliament if one could not express matters of concern for fear of being sued for defamation. It is important to remember that according to Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union it is prohibited to bring any form of civil or criminal proceedings against Members of Parliament in respect of opinions expressed in the performance of their duties. Moreover, in the Judgment of the Court of Justice in the Patriciello case (C-163/10), it was found that this absolute immunity implies that opinions cannot be challenged, whether they are expressed during official meetings of Parliament or elsewhere, for example in the media, when there is a link between the opinion expressed and parliamentary duties.  To allow for the waiver of parliamentary immunity in this case would set in place a dangerous precedent and would ultimately undermine fundamental freedoms for all, regardless of political persuasion.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. In Qatar's defamation proceedings against Florian Philippot, I have spoken out against the lifting of his parliamentary immunity, as proposed by the committee's report in the name of freedom of expression. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should be a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I voted for the Committee of Legal Affairs’ recommendation not to lift Mr Philippot’s immunity as he was carrying out his mandate as an MEP.  I believe that defamation should be a case for the civil courts not the criminal.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. On 28 January 2016, members of the Legal Affairs Committee unanimously gave an opinion against the lifting of his parliamentary immunity in connection with Qatar's scandalous defamation proceedings against my colleague Florian Philippot. However, it is worth recalling in particular the staggering words that this procedure has provoked on the part of Anne Hidalgo in particular. Asked in June about Qatar's complaint, the mayor of Paris dared to say that the emirate had "reason" to go to court if it felt "insulted". And it was all shame that she went so far as to congratulate the emirate on its "fight against homophobia, racism in stadiums". This speaks volumes about the compromise of our so-called "leadership elites".

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Following the unanimous vote of Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I voted in favour of rejecting Mr Philippot's request to lift his parliamentary immunity.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of Florian Philippot's pleading for suspension of immunity, considering that the purpose of immunity is, as the report proposed by the JURI Commission cited, 'to allow the legislature to carry out its constitutional tasks without undue interference from abroad, in particular from the executive branch'. In this case there is no political persecution or anything under the criminal proceedings in order to prejudice the political activity of the Member. Therefore, there is no problem in casting a vote in favour of the pleading for investigations to run their course in the spaces competent to do so.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. I would like to point out here that Qatar's defamation complaint against an MEP, in this case Florian Philippot, was filed with the constitution of a civil party and that, as such, France, through its seal guard, was under a legal obligation to request the lifting of its parliamentary immunity in order to follow up on the criminal proceedings against it. It is not, as I have heard here or there, a biased will of the French government to prosecute this elected official. The French government was simply bound to this type of procedure. We should also recall and congratulate ourselves that the European Parliament has adopted this system of protection for its members for their words or opinions in the performance of their duties.  This freedom of opinion must be subject to absolute immunity when the conditions of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union are met. That has been the case here, and I welcome that.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In accordance with Article 26 of the Constitution of the French Republic, which states that "no Member of Parliament may be prosecuted, sought, arrested, detained or tried on the occasion of the opinions or votes cast by him in the performance of his duties", and that "no Member of Parliament may be subject, in criminal or correctional matters, to an arrest or any other restrictive or restrictive measure of liberty" without any parliamentary authorisation. , the European Parliament refused to lift parliamentary immunity in the case between Florian Philippot and Qatar.  This case will have brought to light the compromise of the French government and in particular the former guard of the Seals, Madame Taubira, who signed with her hand the request to waive immunity. I welcome the failure to lift Florian Philippot's parliamentary immunity. It is regrettable that a foreign country can take the French justice to attack a French parliamentarian for the sole purpose of intimidating him as a result of comments relating to his freedom of expression.  I have therefore decided to vote against the lifting of Florian Philippot's parliamentary immunity.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I supported the JURI Commission proposal, the report finds that the French judicial authorities have requested the suspension of Florian Philippot's immunity in connection with criminal proceedings brought by a third State, Qatar, which accuses him of defaming Florian Philippot in the course of a radio programme on 9 January 2015 and a television programme on 19 January 2015 , insinuating that that State would have financed terrorism. The JURI Commission has considered, however, that parliamentary immunity covers not only the views expressed by the Member at official meetings of Parliament, but also those expressed in other for a, such as the media, when there is 'a relationship between the opinion expressed and the parliamentary functions', and has therefore decided not to suspend Florian Philippot's parliamentary immunity.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has led Parliament to decide not to waive the immunity of a French MEMBER of the European Parliament, Florian Philippot. Florian Philippot is a non-EU country, i.e. Qatar is accused of defamation of the country during radio broadcasts on 9 January 2015 and television broadcasts on 19 January 2015, claiming that the state was funding terrorism. Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union and Article 26 of the Constitution of the French Republic provide that members of parliament may not be held civil or criminal for the opinion expressed in the performance of their duties. The provisions of the French system, which protect the representatives of the people in the performance of their duties, have been in force since 1789 and have arisen from respect for the expression of the will of the people and the need for representatives elected in a democratic state to be free and without fear of being sued or prevented by the executive or judicial exercise of their powers. This absolute immunity of a Member of the European Parliament includes not only the opinion expressed by a member at formal parliamentary sittings, but also elsewhere, for example in the media, where there is a link between the opinion expressed and the duties of a Member, and the expression of the opinion on the foreign policy of the EU and non-member countries in the public ity is one of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament. The Parliament therefore considered that, for this reason, there was no satisfactory conditions for the waiver of the immunity of Florian Philippot.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. The expression of political views is one of the fundamental rights of a Member of any Parliament, whether we agree with them or not. I therefore support not deprive my colleague Philippot of immunity for his words about the financing of terrorism.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the facts attributed to Mr De Clercq are not the same as those attributed to Mr De Clercq. Philippot immunity and that, therefore, it cannot be waived in these circumstances.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. As a reminder, in March 2015, the State of Qatar filed a defamation complaint against MEP Florian Philippot, for comments he had made two months earlier.  The request to waive his parliamentary immunity was unquestionably submitted with the intention of harming his political activity. It would be absolutely scandalous and terrifying if a Member of the European Parliament were prosecuted and condemned for an opinion he expressed in the performance of his duties, since freedom of expression is one of the essential values of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. This complaint is all the more scandalous because it comes from an Islamist dictatorship in which human rights are regularly violated and the dignity of women violated.  That is why I voted in favour of this report which opposes the lifting of Florian Philippot's parliamentary immunity.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Philippot is accused by the government of a third state, qatar, of defaming this state during a radio broadcast on 9 January 2015 and a television broadcast on 19 January 2015, implying that that state would finance terrorism. According to the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs itself has also recognized that there are grounds for maintaining immunity. I am voting in favour of granting immunity.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of our rapporteur's proposal in the Committee on Legal Affairs not to waive the parliamentary immunity of Member Florian Philippot. The statements in which my fellow MEMBER of the European Parliament has suggested that the State of Qatar should finance terrorism are in fact fully covered by the freedom of expression covered by parliamentary immunity, which must be considered guaranteed not only at official meetings of Parliament, but at any other public occasion, including interviews with the media.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the request for the waiver of my colleague's parliamentary immunity

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on Florian Philippot's application for waiver of immunity. This request arose from the political activities of the Member, in particular because of his position on specific political and economic issues of a third State. Although we are divided by an ideological abyss and I do not embrace any of the views of this Member and the place from which he comes, I have decided to vote against the waiver of immunity, as the opposite would be a major blow to the right to free expression, not only of MEPs, but also of society as a whole. I therefore believe that the Member's immunity should not be waived.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because I do not believe that the necessary legal and substantive conditions are in place to proceed with the withdrawal of the parliamentary immunity of the MEP Florian Philippot.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Qatar, a non-Member State, accuses Mr Philippot of defaming the country during both radio and television broadcasts. Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the on the Privileges and Immunities provides that legal proceedings against Members of the European Parliament for expressing their opinion in the performance of their duties is not permitted. Article 26 of the French Constitution also stipulates laws to the same effect. Consequently, this absolute immunity for Members of the European Parliament provides that there is a link between the expression of opinions and parliamentary duties. Accordingly the public expression of opinions on foreign policy of both the European Union or non-Member States is within the scope of Members’ official duties. There is no need to consider the matter of fumus persecutionis. As a result, the immunity of Florian Philippot should not be waived.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with my fellow rapporteur, Laura Ferrara, on the request for the waiver of Mr Philippot's immunity, since the statements in the political field on the foreign policy of the European Union and third countries made by the Latter fall within the re functions of a Member of the European Parliament.  As the conditions for revocation do not exist, I am in favour of the decision not to waive the honourable Member's parliamentary immunity.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Members of the European Parliament are acting within the scope of their official duties whilst expressing opinions publicly on the foreign policy of the EU or of non-Member States. Parliamentary immunity is an absolute immunity which implies that opinions cannot be challenged, whether they are expressed during official meetings of Parliament or elsewhere, for example in the media. I agree that the conditions for the waiver of Mr Philippot’s immunity are not met, thus I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Florian Philippot has been accused of defamation by the state of Qatar for allegedly implying, during a radio program that aired on January 9, 2015 and on a television program that aired on January 9, 2015, that Qatar was funding terrorism. During the juri committee meeting, with a very brief debate, it was decided that mr Florian's statements should fall within the freedom of expression covered by parliamentary immunity, which is guaranteed for what has been said at official meetings of Parliament but also in other forums, for example during interviews with the media. [Court of Justice of 6/9/2011, Patriciello, C-163/10, ECLI: EU:C:2011:543] The JURI Committee did not even vote in favour of the rapporteur's proposal not to waive the parliamentary immunity of Member Florian Philippot. I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which calls for the withdrawal of parliamentary immunity from Mr Florian Philippot since the facts for which he has been sued are directly related to his work as an MEP. Parliamentary immunity can under no circumstances be used as a political weapon. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report not to waive the Parliamentary immunity of Florian Philippot because I believe that an MEP can publicly express an opinion on the foreign policy of the European Union or of non-Member States as this is within the scope of their official duties.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Florian Philippot, MEP, is currently the subject of defamation proceedings brought by the State of Qatar, which does not accept criticism of him. The role of European parliamentarians is of course to support this elected official and to defend his freedom of expression and opinion. As well as the Members of the Committee on Legal Affairs, who voted unanimously in favour of the report which opposes the lifting of his parliamentary immunity, I have opposed the lifting of this immunity.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. – The MEP is accused of slander by the State of Qatar, as in a radio broadcast he claimed that Qatar is financing terrorism. It is proposed that the EP's proposal should not waive its immunity on the basis of this accusation.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. 'I regularly vote in accordance with the committee responsible in immunity proceedings, where it is reasonable and in accordance with the Rules of Procedure that cases be referred to the national judiciary unless there are political motives.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Mr Florian Philippot is accused by the government of a third country, namely Qatar, of defaming qatar during a radio broadcast by suggesting that Qatar was financing terrorism. For a Member of the European Parliament, immunity covers not only the views expressed by the Member at official meetings of Parliament, but also the manifestation of his views elsewhere, for example in the media. The expression in the public sphere of opinions on the foreign policy of the European Union and third countries falls within the functions of a Member of the European Parliament, and I agree that there are no conditions for the waiver of Mr Philippot's immunity.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it opposes the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of an MEP who has defended a political opinion within the framework of his mandate.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Florian Philippot, deputy of the National Front. Here are the facts: the deputy is accused by the Qatari government of defaming qatar by suggesting, on a radio show and on a television show (both in January 2015), that Qatar finances terrorism. The French authorities have requested the waiver of immunity following the prosecution brought by a third country. In accordance with Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union and Article 26 of the Constitution of the French Republic, it is prohibited to bring any civil or criminal proceedings against a member of parliament arising from opinions expressed in the performance of his duties. Article 8 of Protocol No 7 provides that "members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties". It is clear that that principle also applies in the case of the initiation by a third country of criminal defamation proceedings against a Member. It is understood that the intention behind the prosecution is to undermine the political activity of this Member. We voted in favour of the report refusing the request for waiver of immunity.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The MEP is accused of slander by the State of Qatar, as in a radio broadcast he claimed that Qatar is financing terrorism. I am voting in favour of the EP's proposal not to waive its immunity on the basis of this accusation.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Following the unanimous adoption of the decision by the JURI Committee of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Mr Florian Philippot.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of a Member of the European Parliament, the immunity from impeachment applies not only to the opinion of the Member expressed at official meetings of Parliament, but also to his opinions expressed elsewhere, such as in the media, where there is a link between the opinion expressed and the duties of parliament. Thus, when MEPs express their views publicly on the foreign policy of the European Union and third countries, it falls within their res responsible. For these reasons, it decides not to suspend Florian Philippot's immunity.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. I am delighted that, for once, the European Parliament will decide to maintain the parliamentary immunity of a member of the National Front. Unfortunately, I fear that it is not in the name of the strict freedom of expression of parliamentarians, nor in the name of justice and fairness. Above all, I believe that the European Parliamentarians wanted to protect themselves, who spend their time, inside and outside the Chamber, judging all the countries of the world. Indeed, unheard of, Florian Philippot is being sued for defamation by a state, Qatar. Florian Philippot suggested that Qatar was funding the most radical Islamist groups. He is not the only one in France and Europe to question the murky relations of some Gulf countries with terrorism. Parliament invokes the separation of powers against the interference of the executive branch in the exercise of parliamentary mandate in defence of immunity, and the fact that the Member, commenting on the Union's foreign policy, was in the exercise of his mandate. I hope that by analogy and logically, any comment on the disastrous consequences of the arrival and the massive presence of immigration encouraged by Schengen will now also be judged in this regard, which has never been the case.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Florian Philippot's pleading to suspend immunity, considering that the purpose of immunity is, as the report proposed by the JURI Commission cited, 'to allow the legislature to carry out its constitutional tasks without undue interference from abroad, in particular the executive branch'. In this case there is no political persecution or anything under the criminal proceedings in order to prejudice the political activity of the Member. Therefore, there is no problem in casting a vote in favour of the pleading for investigations to run their course in the spaces competent to do so.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union stipulates that Members of the European Parliament may not be subject to any form of inquiry, detention or legal proceedings in respect of opinions expressed or votes cast by them in the performance of their duties. I therefore voted not to waive Mr Philippot's immunity.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the Committee's decision to uphold Mr. Philippot's parliamentary immunity. This is because his alleged offence is an opinion he stated regarding a non-member state, and according to both the European Parliament and French law, opinions and expressions cannot be challenged or face the threat of legal action.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the report concerns an ENF MEP, we voted in favour so as not to waive his immunity, as complaints from Qatar are not spoken of and concern a basic political right, that of freedom of expression. The report argues that qatar's case against the MEP will set a bad precedent against the basic right to freedom of expression.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report in accordance with the position adopted by my political group after the Legal Affairs Committee’s evaluation.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Florian Philippot's immunity, which decides not to lift immunity, as one of the duties of MEPs is to express opinions on EU and third country foreign policy.  Members' immunity also applies to opinions expressed by a Member, e.g. in the media, relating to his parliamentary activities. Therefore, I consider that this decision is also appropriate in accordance with the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunies of the European Union.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. In Qatar's defamation proceedings against Florian Philippot, I have spoken out against the lifting of his parliamentary immunity, as proposed in the committee's report in the name of freedom of expression. I therefore vote in favour of this report.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against the decision on Florian Philippot's request to waive parliamentary immunity. The facts alleged against Mr Philippot relate to remarks made in the context of a broadcast and television debate which was part of his duties as an elected member of the European Parliament. Therefore, I found that the lifting of parliamentary immunity was not justified.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The Committee on Legal Affairs has not established any reason to justify the lifting of Mr Philippot's immunity. I therefore agree with the committee's decision.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive the immunity.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the possible lifting of my colleague Florian Philippot's parliamentary immunity. The request comes in the context of a defamation lawsuit brought by the State of Qatar.  I was pleased to note that on 28 January, in the name of defending freedom of expression and opinion, members of the Committee on Legal Affairs gave an unfavourable opinion to the lifting of his parliamentary immunity. They therefore rightly voted unanimously in favour of the report, which opposed the lifting of its parliamentary immunity.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it refuses to lift the parliamentary immunity of Florian Philippot, who is being sued by the State of Qatar for daring to publicly criticize him. I am proud to have successfully defended Florian Philippot in the Legal Affairs Committee. The plenary of the European Parliament has saved the honour of European civilisation by unanimously refusing to lift its immunity. She slapped Qatar and the French justice system, which relayed its defamation complaint.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The French court requested the waiver of Philippot's immunity for the purposes of criminal proceedings brought in a country outside the European Union. Mp Philippot has been accused by the Katra government of slandering the country by suggesting they fund terrorism.  Article 8 Protocol Number 7 on the privileges and immunity of the European Union stipulates that members of the European Parliament may not be subject to any form of investigation, detention or legal proceedings in relation to the opinions expressed in the performance of their duties. I did not support the lifting of Philippot's parliamentary immunity, because when publicly expressing opinions on the foreign policy of the European Union or non-member states, members of the European Parliament act within their official duties.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The request for waiver of the immunity of Member of the European Parliament Florian Filippo stems from the desire of the High Court in the French city of Nantere to open a court case against him based on qatar's allegation of defamation on the part of a Member on 9 January 2015 on radio - Mr Filippo accused Qatar of sponsoring terrorism. Given at least the nature of the case itself, the principle of freedom of expression and the fact that the request came from a third non-EU country, the COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AFFAIRS of the EP decided not to waive mr Filippo's parliamentary immunity. I fully agree with the decision taken in the Committee on Legal Affairs and voted in favour. In parallel, Qatar itself would very much like to do everything to avoid being treated with this kind of insult from the out pre-out, which, unfortunately, contains a large list of well-proven financing cases, and whose geographical directions include both the Middle East, the North Caucasus and other regions of the world.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of Florian Philippot's immunity, following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. This request to waive Florian Philippot's parliamentary immunity comes in the context of a defamation proceeding brought by Qatar.  Parliamentary immunity guarantees Members the "defence of freedom of expression and opinion", which is why all members of the Parliamentary Committee on Legal Affairs have unanimously opposed the lifting of this immunity. The rapporteur herself here asks not to lift Florian Philippot's immunity, a position we support.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union stipulates that Members of the European Parliament may not be subject to any form of inquiry, detention or legal proceedings in respect of opinions expressed or votes cast by them in the performance of their duties. I therefore voted not to waive Mr Philippot's immunity.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have expressed my opposition to the request for waiver of Mr Sley's immunity. Florian Philippot, because I believe that parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege of a Member but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament and its Members as a super partes institution. I remain convinced that a guarantee line must be followed in these cases and i will therefore continue to vote against this type of report in defence of the institutional role conferred by this Parliament.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The motion for annulment refers to a political expression of the Member within the framework of his mandate. The purpose of parliamentary immunity in general is to ensure that the legislature can carry out its constitutional mandate without undisprud interference from third parties, and in particular the executive. I therefore agree with this request.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report defends The immunity of Mr Florian Philippot. Florian Philippot is being sued for defamation by the Qatari state for having stated on several occasions, including on the set of RTL, that Qatar supports terrorism.  Until then, no state had ever asked for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of an elected member of the European Parliament. Of course, Qatar paid Mr. Plantu 10,000 euros as a prize for press freedom. However, he gave no evidence of respect for freedom of expression. It is a shame that he is suing a parliamentarian with the aim of intimidating Parliament, which guarantees his immunity. Although Mr Philippot was a Member of Parliament at the time of the events, accepting such a lift would undermine the essential freedoms of MEPs. I am voting for this report which opposes the lifting of immunity.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. In Qatar's defamation proceedings against Florian Philippot, I have ruled against the lifting of his parliamentary immunity, as proposed in the committee's report in the name of freedom of expression. I therefore vote in favour of this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Florian Philippot, who decides not to withdraw the immunity. The application does not meet the requirements for the application of Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union: the facts relate to the performance of the duties of a Member, since there is a link between the statements made and the parliamentary functions.

name: Louis MICHEL
