text: In writing. Freedom of expression is one of the foundations of any democratic society. Guaranteed, in particular by the European Convention on Human Rights, it testifies to the maturity of a democracy. Mr. Philippot has the right to express his sensibilities, his opinions.  As a strong defender of freedom of expression, I can only oppose the request to waive parliamentary immunity In addition, I would stress that according to Article 26 of the French Constitution, "no Member of Parliament may be prosecuted, sought, arrested or tried on the occasion of the opinions or votes cast by the latter in the performance of his duties".

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Florian Philippot.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. The Government of Qatar has opened proceedings against Florian Philippot, a French MEP, in a nanterre court, accusing him of slandering the aforementioned state during a radio broadcast on 9 January 2015 and a television broadcast on 19 January 2015, suggesting that this state was funding terrorism. On 2 September 2015, the Minister of Justice of the French Republic sent a request to the European Parliament to suspend Mr Philippot's immunity in the context of the ongoing proceedings.  In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs states that both Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union and Article 26 of the French Constitution prohibit civil proceedings or prosecutions against a Member for his opinion in the performance of his duties, and that when MEPs give their opinions publicly on the foreign policy of the European Union and third States, it falls within their remnants. It also notes that that exemption from the Member of the European Parliament relates not only to the Member's opinion expressed at official meetings of Parliament, but also to his opinions expressed elsewhere, such as in the media, where there is a link between the opinion expressed and the duties of Parliament. In view of all this, it proposes that Parliament should not suspend the immunity of Florian Philippot. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The report seeks to deny the lifting of immunity of Florian Philippot, who has merely used his freedom of expression as part of his mandate as an MEP by criticising the policy of the State of Qatar. We therefore follow the advice of the JURI committee.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of the requirements of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, as well as Article 26 of the French Constitution, which prohibits any civil or criminal action against a Member for opinions expressed in the performance of his duties, and whereas the immunity of a Member of the European Parliament covers not only the views expressed by the Member of parliament at official meetings of Parliament , but also the expression of her views in any other part – for example, in the media, when there is "a link between the opinion expressed and the parliamentary functions" – and that the rapporteur considers that there are no preconditions for the waiver of Mr Philippot's immunity, this report deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. It is completely unprecedented for a parliamentarian to be prosecuted by a state for comments he has made against him. It is a matter of respect for parliamentary democracy that of being able to ensure the free expression of the representatives of the citizens.  In addition, and in this case, Qatar has, in all the morewise proven, participated in the financing of terrorist groups. The National Front being a party whose silence cannot be bought, anxious to carry a vision of balanced diplomacy in a multipolar world, fully supports the righteous words of Florian Philippot. I voted in favour of this report concluding that Mr Philippot's immunity should not be lifted.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the lifting of Florian Philippot's parliamentary immunity. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee.  The commission unanimously considered that the defamation complaint filed by the State of Qatar against Mr. Philippot could not justify a waiver of his immunity. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of refusing to lift Mr Florian Philippot's immunity. The Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI), which has jurisdiction over the substance, unanimously considers that the Comments made by the Member were part of the exercise of his parliamentary foncions. I have therefore followed the proposal of the JURI Committee in order to defend the idea of the freedom of expression of any parliamentarian.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report in accordance with the evaluation made by the JURI Committee.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this motion. The repeal motion refers to the political expression of the Member within the scope of his mandate. The purpose of parliamentary immunity in general is to ensure that the legislature can carry out its constitutional mandate without undisprud interference from third parties, and in particular the executive.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the action taken by Member Florian Philippot, I am voting in favour of the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report concerns my own parliamentary immunity. Madam Ferrara recalls how Qatar's complaint against me was the archetype of the prosecution for which immunity was provided.  Indeed, within the framework of his mandate, every parliamentarian must be able to enjoy total freedom of expression to defend his compatriots, among others against the maneuvers of foreign dictatorships like Qatar. It is scandalous that the French justice system has agreed to receive this complaint, which clearly goes against the main principles underlying the status of parliamentarian since at least 1789 in France, as the members of the Committee on Legal Affairs unanimously acknowledged.  I welcome the fact that the most basic law and justice have for once triumphed over sectarianism and blindness, and I have therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒I support the recommendation not to grant immunity to fellow MP Florian Philippot for his televised statement.  Public expression of opinions on the foreign policy of the European Union and third countries is part of the official duties of members of the European Parliament. In addition, the Judgment of the European Court of Human Rights cites provisions that protect people's representatives in the French system when carrying out their duties dating back to 1789 and derive from respect for the expression of the will of the people and the need for elected representatives in a democratic state to serve a free term without fear of legal action or interference by executive or judicial authorities, and such absolute immunity of Members of the European Parliament does not apply only to opinions expressed by a Member of Parliament at official meetings of Parliament than and those expressed elsewhere, for example in the media. Therefore, there is no legal basis for lifting my colleague Philippot's immunity.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Florian Philippot. The deputy is accused by the Qatari government of defaming qatar by suggesting on a radio show broadcast on 9 January 2015 and on a television programme broadcast on 19 January 2015 that Qatar finances terrorism. The French authorities have requested the waiver of immunity following the prosecution brought by a third country. In accordance with Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union and Article 26 of the Constitution of the French Republic, it is prohibited to bring any civil or criminal proceedings against a member of parliament arising from opinions expressed in the performance of his duties. In general terms, the aim of parliamentary immunity is to allow the legislative power to exercise its constitutional functions without undue external interference, especially by the executive branch. In view of the foregoing, the request for waiver of parliamentary immunity should not be granted.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Philippot is accused by the government of a third country, qatar, of defaming that state during a radio broadcast on 9 January 2015 and a television broadcast on 19 January 2015, implying that that state would finance terrorism.  Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union and Article 26 of the Constitution of the Republic French prohibit any civil or criminal proceedings against a Member concerning opinions expressed in the performance of his duties.  Furthermore, for a Member of the European Parliament, this unquestionable covers not only the views expressed by the Member at official meetings of Parliament, but also opinions expressed elsewhere, for example in the media, when there is a link between the opinion expressed and the parliamentary functions. I therefore believe that there is no basis for waiving Mr Syrendt's immunity. Philippot and that is why I am voting in favour of this decision today.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the withdrawal of Mr Phillipot's immunity, in accordance with the unanimous proposal of the committee responsible. Immunity is intended to protect against possible sanctions for political expression of views. If Mr Philippot has been accused in France by Qatar of publicly saying that this Arab country finances terrorism, he has a right to such a political opinion, whether we agree with him on this point or not. We rarely encounter a case in immune matters that is so clear in this regard, and so does my position.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. The French judicial authorities have requested the waiver of the immunity of Florian Philippot, a Member of the European Parliament, following criminal proceedings brought by a third country. Florian Philippot is accused by the Qatari government of defaming qatar during a radio broadcast of 9 January 2015 and a television broadcast of January 19, 2015, in suggesting that Qatar was financing terrorism. The immunity of a Member of the European Parliament covers not only the views expressed by the Member at official meetings of Parliament, but also the expression of his views, for example in the media, when there is "a link between the expressed opinion and the parliamentary functions".  For that reason, this report, in which I voted in favour, decides not to lift Florian Philippot's immunity.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I supported the JURI Commission proposal, the report finds that the French judicial authorities have requested the suspension of Florian Philippot's immunity in connection with criminal proceedings brought by a third State, Qatar, which accuses him of defaming Florian Philippot in the course of a radio programme on 9 January 2015 and a television programme on 19 January 2015 , insinuating that that State would have financed terrorism. The JURI Commission has considered, however, that parliamentary immunity covers not only the views expressed by the Member at official meetings of Parliament, but also those expressed in other for a, such as the media, when there is 'a relationship between the opinion expressed and the parliamentary functions', and has therefore decided not to suspend Florian Philippot's parliamentary immunity.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr. Florian Philippot, so that the French justice system can carry out his work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the alleged facts - Florian Philippot is accused by the Government of Qatar of defaming the said state during a radio and TV show, during which he suggested that Qatar would finance terrorism - have no connection with the office of Deputy Mr Philippot, and are not motivated by the desire to interfere with the political action of the Member.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The French Ministry of Justice requested a request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Florian Philippot on 2 September 2015 as part of a defamation proceedings pending before the Court of Grand Instance in Nanterre. The request follows a criminal action brought by a third state – Qatar – which accuses the Member of defaming the country during a radio broadcast on 9 January 2015, by mentioning that qatar was financing terrorism. However, the French Fundamental Law states that "no member of Parliament may be prosecuted, investigated, arrested, detained or judged by the opinions or votes cast by him in the performance of his duties". And Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union prohibits any civil or criminal action against a Member for opinions expressed in the performance of his duties. In view of the above, the conditions for maintaining the parliamentary immunity status of Mr Florian Philippot are met, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Florian Philippot's pleading for suspension of immunity, considering that the purpose of immunity is, as the report proposed by the JURI Commission cited, 'to allow the legislature to carry out its constitutional tasks without undue interference from abroad, in particular the executive branch'. In this case there is no political persecution or anything under the criminal proceedings in order to prejudice the political activity of the Member. Therefore, there is no problem in casting a vote in favour of the pleading for investigations to run their course in the spaces competent to do so.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. In order to be a member of the European Union, you have to have a rule of law. We must therefore have confidence that the Member State's judiciary can judge when an indictment against a Member of the European Parliament is strong enough to waive immunity so that the case can be tried in court. That is why I support the repeal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which calls for the withdrawal of parliamentary immunity from Mr Florian Philippot since the facts for which he has been sued are directly related to his work as an MEP. Parliamentary immunity can under no circumstances be used as a political weapon. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of keeping the immunity of Florian Philppot as he was acting within his work as an MEP.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ As far as I understand, a French court has asked for the immunity of Florian Philippot MEP to be waived for the purposes of criminal proceedings instituted by a country outside the EU, namely Qatar, which accuses the politician of having defamed the country, claiming that Qatar finances terrorism. While I may not agree with a lot of what Mr Philippot and his party believe, it is important that MEPs be allowed to express their opinions. Both from a moral and legal stand point, the conditions for the waiver are not met.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ when I drafted the European Parliament's decision on the request for waiver of the immunity of Florian Philippot, a Member of the European Parliament, I voted in line with the position of my EKR faction in favour of adopting this resolution, by which the European Parliament decided not to waive Mr Philippot's immunity. The Philippot MP was accused by the Government of Qatar of de-edsing the state when he suggested during a television broadcast that Qatar was funding terrorism. I agree with the position of the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament, which considered the request by the French judicial authorities to waive immunity in connection with criminal proceedings initiated in a third country to be unjustified, since in the case of a Member of the European Parliament, immunity concerns not only the views expressed by a Member in official part-sessions of Parliament, but also his views expressed in other places, such as in the media, if there is a link between the opinion expressed and his parliamentary functions. The objective of immunity is generally to enable the legislative authorities to perform their constitutional function without any undesirable external interference, and the principle also applies to legal proceedings initiated by a third country.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the Ministry of Justice of the French Republic has requested that MEP Florian Philippot be waived of his immunity in connection with defamation proceedings pending before the Court of First Instance in Nanterre, since Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union provides that MEPs shall enjoy, in the territory of their own State, the immunities granted to members of the Parliament of that State. Mr Philippot was accused by the government of a third country, namely Qatar, of deniing the state during radio broadcasts on 9 January 2015 and television broadcasts on 19 January 2015, when he indicated that Qatar was funding terrorism. Given that expressing opinions on EU and third country foreign policy in public is part of the mep's duties, we have decided not to waive the parliamentary immunity of Mep Florian Philippot.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The government of a third country, namely Katra, accused MP Florian Philippot of insinuating in a radio broadcast on 9 January 2015 and in a televised broadcast on 19 January 2015 qatar by insinuating that Qatar was financing terrorism. French judicial authorities have requested the lifting of the immunity of MEP Florian Philippot in relation to this criminal proceedings. As public expression of opinion on the foreign policy of the European Union and third countries is part of the official duties of members of the European Parliament, I supported the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. It is normal to vote for the lifting of an MP's immunity so that he can explain himself in court in his country. However, in this particular case, we European parliamentarians are forced to take part in a charade which aims only to make a little more publicity not only to the FN in its sensationalist outings, but also to Qatar, which needs to restore its image: a circus of which the European Parliament and the French justice must be in spite of themselves the actors in this matter.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ A French court has asked for the immunity of Florian Philippot to be waived for the purposes of criminal proceedings instituted by a country outside the European Union. Indeed Florian Philippot is accused by the government of a non-member state, namely Qatar, of having defamed that country by suggesting, in a radio programme broadcast on 9 January 2015 and in a television programme broadcast on 19 January 2015 that Qatar finances terrorism. While I oppose Mr Philippot’s political views and ideology, it is prohibited, under Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union and under Article 26 of the French Constitution, to bring any form of civil or criminal proceedings against members of parliament in respect of opinions expressed in the performance of their duties. This is the reason why I decided to vote in favour of this report and thus not to waive the immunity of Florian Philippot.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The french authorities forwarded to the European Parliament a request to lift the parliamentary immunity of Florian Philippot, whom the State of Qatar accuses of public defamation during the broadcast of a radio show on 9 January 2015 and a television programme on 19 January 2015, when it insinuated that the country in charge was financing terrorism.  Given that Philippot has been charged with expressing his opinion, I consider that there is reason to assume, i.e. sufficiently reasonable and serious doubt, that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the Member concerned. Since the absolute immunity of Members of the European Parliament applies not only to the opinions expressed by a Member at official meetings of Parliament, but also to those expressed elsewhere, for example in the media, where there is a link between the opinion expressed and parliamentary duty, I supported the report which does not lift Philippot's immunity.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Florian Philippot, as I believe that the alleged infringement was committed as part of the parliamentary work. Expressing a personal position in your work is an act which is not subject to detention, questioning or judicial proceedings. It is only through protection that Members are free to exercise our mandate without fear of action, so I support mr Philippot's immunity not to be waived.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Florian Philippot's pleading for suspension of immunity, considering that the purpose of immunity is, as the report proposed by the JURI Commission cited, 'to allow the legislature to carry out its constitutional tasks without undue interference from abroad, in particular the executive branch'. In this case there is no political persecution or anything under the criminal proceedings in order to prejudice the political activity of the Member. Therefore, there is no problem in casting a vote in favour of the pleading for investigations to run their course in the spaces competent to do so.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Florian Philippot's hearing took place on 11 January in the Committee on Legal Affairs. It intervenes in a defamation proceeding brought by the State of Qatar.  On 28 January 2016, in the name of "defending freedom of expression and opinion", MEPs on the Legal Affairs Committee gave an unfavourable opinion to the lifting of his parliamentary immunity (they voted unanimously in favour of the report, which opposed the lifting of his parliamentary immunity). So I voted for this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Florian Philippot is accused by a third state, namely the Government of Qatar, of slandering the aforementioned state during a radio broadcast on 9 January 2015 and a television broadcast on 19 January 2015, suggesting that this state was financing terrorism. I followed the S&D group's position on the matter and supported the motion.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Florian Philippot's pleading for suspension of immunity, considering that the purpose of immunity is, as the report proposed by the JURI Commission cited, 'to allow the legislature to carry out its constitutional tasks without undue interference from abroad, in particular the executive branch'. In this case there is no political persecution or anything under the criminal proceedings in order to prejudice the political activity of the Member. Therefore, there is no problem in casting a vote in favour of the pleading for investigations to run their course in the spaces competent to do so.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the request for waiver of the immunity of Florian Philippot. In this specific case, a French court has asked for the immunity of Mr Philippot to be waived for the purposes of criminal proceedings instituted by a country outside the European Union; more specifically, Mr Philippot is accused by the government of a non-member State, namely Qatar, of having defamed that country by suggesting, in a radio programme broadcast on 9 January 2015 and in a television programme broadcast on 19 January 2015, that Qatar finances terrorism. Considering that when they publicly express opinions on the foreign policy of the European Union or of non-Member States, Members of the European Parliament are acting within the scope of their official duties, in this particular case the conditions for the waiver of Mr Philippot’s immunity are not met. The Legal Affairs Committee thus decided not to waive the immunity of Mr Philippot and this is why I voted against.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of the lifting of parliamentary immunity so that one can defend itself before the national courts.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. A request to lift Florian Philippot's parliamentary immunity was put to a vote by the European Parliament on 2 February. It was addressed to the European Parliament by the French authorities following Qatar's defamation complaint against statements by Florian Philippot, when he was already an MEP, alleging that Qatar supported terrorism. This request for the lifting of parliamentary immunity is based on a specificity of the French penal code allowing legal entities to sue a person for defamatory statements; the French authorities therefore had to legally submit to the European Parliament the request to waive the immunity since a defamation complaint had been filed against an MEP. The question put to the European Parliament was therefore also purely legal. Can a legal entity, and in this case a foreign state, criminally prosecute a Member of the European Parliament for comments made in the course of his mandate. Logically, the European Parliament rejected this request to waive immunity in the name of protecting the freedom of expression of any MEP within its mandate. I voted in favour of this report rejecting this request to waive immunity on policy grounds.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. 'Florian Philippot' is accused by the government of a third country, namely Qatar, of defaming qatar during a radio broadcast of 9 January 2015 and a television broadcast of 19 January 2015, in suggesting that Qatar was financing terrorism. For a Member of the European Parliament, immunity covers not only the views expressed by the Member at official meetings of Parliament, but also the manifestation of his views elsewhere, for example in the media, when there is "a link between the expressed opinion and parliamentary functions".

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The motion for annulment refers to a political expression of the Member within the framework of his mandate. The purpose of parliamentary immunity in general is to ensure that the legislature can carry out its constitutional mandate without undisprud interference from third parties, and in particular the executive. I therefore agree with this request.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I rejected the proposal for a European Parliament decision on the request for the waiver of the immunity of Florian Philippot, because I agree with the report's findings that there is no valid reason to waive the immunity of that Member in connection with criminal proceedings for alleged defamation, which was brought before a national court in France at the request of Qatar on the grounds of opinions, since he expressed them in the performance of his duties in office.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: A 2014 Eurobarometer survey shows that at least one in ten European citizens have purchased goods or services from undeclared work. But the fact I want to emphasize today is that no country can give lessons in morality and balance. If the European country with the highest percentage of uneathed work is Greece, then immediately after in the ranking there are unsuspected countries such as the Netherlands, Denmark, Luxembourg and Sweden. The very lives of workers are at risk, given that the sector in which the incidence of unead work is highest is construction.  The new European platform to discourage undeclared work is an excellent first step towards a Europe of citizens and workers. However, the data tells us that 60% of those who agree to pay in the black do so because they spend less. Then the platform will necessarily have to be accompanied by concrete measures with a real impact on the labour market. I will mention two in particular: a strong simplification of the rules, without this, however, having disturbed the guarantees, and above all a significant reduction in the tax wedge, which is then the first real cause of undeclared work.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, it is difficult to quantify undeclared work, but it is estimated that in some Member States, as in Spain, it is around 20% of gross domestic product. It is a scourge with significant negative effects on workers, the state and society as a whole.  However, the increase in undeclared work has not happened by chance, but has been on the rise with the economic crisis and austerity policies that have increased employment precariousness. A precariousness that particularly strikes the most vulnerable workers, such as women, migrants, young people and so-called "false self-employed people".  The platform is a positive first step and that is why we voted in favour. It is important to know the phenomenon, to address it in a coordinated way, and it contains very interesting aspects. However, the roots of the problem remain intact and the threat of further labour reforms to countries like Spain go counterceding to its solution.  Our commitment is to continue working to end the economic policies that have helped to deregulate the labour market and to precarious the working conditions of European workers.

name: István UJHELYI
text: – I have risen to speak because I would like to confirm that what we have just voted on is a very important issue. It affects millions of workers in Europe and in several countries, such as, unfortunately, a typical situation in my country, Hungary. If you look around, there are tens of thousands of workers in almost every sector who are not properly reported. Therefore, their own social security, the revenue from the state budget, the income from social security, competition neutrality in these sectors are all being undermined. In fact, I am rising to the point of being able to indicate that there must be a common platform for member states' responsibility, in addition to the policies of the Member States supporting such tax avoidance behaviours, in Europe, where Member States coordinate with the EU institutions and organisations representing social dialogue. That is why I supported today's proposal.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, yet again we are attacking the symptom rather than the underlying disease. Why it is that people are pushed into the black economy? Because the regulated economy is over—regulated: taxes are too high, working conditions are uncongenial, and it therefore pays people to take their work elsewhere. The solution is not yet more of the medicine that caused the disease in the first place. If we have a problem caused by excessive state intervention, we are not going to solve it with yet more state intervention. We could have more and more inspectors and licensers and clerks trying to police a system with dwindling tax revenue caused by the black economy, but we are simply going to be exacerbating the problem. What is the real answer? Lower, flatter, simpler taxes so that people are not driven into the black economy in the first place.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by During the vote, I supported the creation of a European Platform to improve cooperation on the prevention of undeclared work. On average, 8% and in some countries up to 20% of Europeans receive unsaid salaries for their work, according to available data. Another 10% or more work without the required contracts. This shows that working in the grey economy in Europe is still too common. Many people are unaware of the long-term consequences of such a practice. Low official wages and illegal employment not only mean lower revenues to the state budget and local government units, but above all, it radically reduces the amount of the old-age pension and causes a lack of health care. The prevalence of this phenomenon may cause the Union to struggle in the future with more elderly people living in poverty. We must not forget that problems related to illegal employment or remuneration vary, very often dependent on local specificities. Concrete measures to combat the grey area must therefore be taken at the lowest possible level and adapted to local requirements.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! Denmark has one of the best functioning labour markets, a high level of labour market participation, a very low level of undeclared work. Indeed, I would go so far as to say that had it not been for the problems created by the European Union with freedom of movement and labour and the freedom to move as a service provider across borders, well, then our problems with the black economy would be minimal.  Unfortunately, however, because of what has happened over the last ten years, when we have insisted that more and more rules be regulated by the European Union, indeed, this problem has become increasingly important because it is becoming increasingly difficult for national authorities to pursue those who break the rules. What we need, therefore, is no more regulation here from the EU institutions. No, what we need is for our Member States to be able to pursue the people who work in the black economy. We need to strengthen the trade union movement, not as the EUROPEAN Union fails and weakens the trade union movement. We need it to be the Member States themselves who control welfare payments, etc. Therefore, this is basically going in completely the wrong direction.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur One of the most fundamental preconditions for the building of the rule of law and society is, of course, the consent of citizens to implement and also to active follow-up to the provisions of the existing legal system, which relates in particular to the payment of taxes and, in general, to the execution of legal work in general.  Consequently, the creation of a common European Union-wide platform, the functioning of which is aimed at preventing undeclared work, is very important, because the prospect of an increasingly effective fight against the shadow economy, illegal financial money laundering and other national economies and also the negative consequences for the population as a whole will be tackled more effectively.  This platform will bring together both the executive bodies of each Member State of the European Union and experts from the sectors involved; the interests of both national, business and employees will be respected. As long as the Platform does not have specific decision-making rights, it will have the opportunity to actively inform the relevant bodies and provide them with specialised advice and recommendations.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I voted for this report because I believe that cooperation between Member States, in relation to sharing information and best practice, is vital. We can develop tools which will allow us to share this information and to enforce shared practices; we can develop databases and establish rapid reaction exchange. I think all of these actions can contribute significantly to tackling undeclared work, both at national level and cross-border. It is important because Member States themselves lose revenue; but equally, and crucially, it is very important for workers themselves. Many workers find themselves without social security contributions, without any kind of protection, and they are open to exploitation. The truth is, the more marginalised the worker, the more likely they are to be exploited. I did not support Amendment 63, which asked for a Member State opt-out, because it is  very clear that participation is mandatory but that any recommendations for action are purely voluntary. Finally, I did not support the amendment which asked that Members would not be reimbursed for their travel; they give their time free, their work is free, but it would be unreasonable to suggest that their airfares would not be paid.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I am of the opinion that labour costs are one of the competitive advantages of how states can differ from one another. These advantages come in tax matters, in social matters, and that is why I stand up for the right of the Member States of the European Union to assess this matter primarily in my own legislation. However, working illegally, undeclared work is a real evil and brings a number of problems not only in the tax, pension part of the state budget, but also brings a number of social problems, which my colleagues have already mentioned here. For this reason, I supported the proposed report, and I think it is important that EU Member States work together and share information so that the labour market actually meets the minimum requirements and standards in force in the Union.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, d’fhreastail mé ar an díospóireacht anseo ar maidin ach níor éirigh liom labhairt ann agus dá bhrí sin, buíochas as ucht an seans a thabhairt dom cúpla focal a rá anois. I was amazed this morning to see the extent of the black economy – or undeclared work as we call it here – right across Europe, varying from 1% to 30% in different Member States. We obviously have a major problem and, while my good friend Daniel Hannan referred to people being driven into the black economy in the first place, that is only part of the problem – or a small part of it maybe – because the emphasis has to be particularly on employers exploiting workers, as my colleague Marian Harkin said. I think there is a need for an exchange of best practice and incentives for people to pay their taxes and to declare their work.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, we have just had a debate on undeclared work, better known as the black economy. The irony of the debate was rich. We had the EU discussing why people choose to work outside of the normal rules and regulations when many of the rules and regulations, the anti-competitive things that cause problems, have come from the EU. We have the British Conservatives, and one of my local colleagues from the British Conservatives, saying: ‘what a great thing this is, this shows how good the EU is, because it is not enforceable.’ So you might as well not be in it anyway. We have got the British Labour Party, another one from the West Midlands where I am from, saying: ‘this is what we should be talking about: competitiveness. We will teach you all a lesson in competitiveness.’ The British Labour Party that virtually destroyed our country’s economy, discussing competitiveness. The irony of it is so rich; just as with so many other things in this place, you just could not make it up.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation because it will create a taxpayer-funded junket for civil servants, national agencies and social partners to wine and dine in Brussels. The platform will produce advice and non-binding guidelines on how to tackle undeclared work. An article in the legislation specifically says that the Commission will reimburse travel and, where appropriate, subsistence expenses for members, alternates, observers and invited experts. In the original Commission proposal it states: ‘Up to EUR 224 000 per year will be used to reimburse the costs related to participation in the Platform meetings.’ UKIP has no problem with individual countries working together to share best practices and deal with this issue. However only the elected and accountable national governments should be able to take such decisions – unelected EU bureaucrats have no right to waste taxpayer’s money on such vanity projects.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 About one in ten European citizens admits to having purchased goods or services obtained from undeclared work in the previous year, while 4% admit to having personally received undeclared payments in return for work carried out. The European Commission has described undeclared work as any lawful activity of a nature but not declared to public authorities. Parliament's proposal for the creation of a European platform is aimed at preventing and discouraging undeclared work, through the sharing of good practices and assessments by the Member States. Establishing cooperation between national governments, encouraging alternative forms of dialogue between institutions, workers and employers, will certainly play a key role in the fight against such illegal practices. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. Today, the EU has taken a very important step in addressing the many challenges of undeclared work. This seriously harms the European economy, accounting for around 18% of GDP, although in some states it can reach 35% (20% for Spain).  But it not only affects the economy, but poses a serious risk to affected workers as they are often exploited, suffer more dangerous conditions and worse wages, and their labour rights are violated.  The Socialists have led the creation of this platform which aims to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. The platform will deal with all forms of undeclared employment, from false self-employed people to fictitious enterprises, combining the efforts of a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States and social actors.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this initiative which I hope will be the first step in creating more incisive measures to combat this scourge of our economy and our society.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislation because it will create a taxpayer-funded junket for civil servants, national agencies and social partners to wine and dine in Brussels. The platform will produce advice and non-binding guidelines on how to tackle undeclared work. An article in the legislation specifically says that the Commission will reimburse travel and, where appropriate, subsistence expenses for members, alternates, observers and invited experts. In the original Commission proposal it states: ‘Up to EUR 224 000 per year will be used to reimburse the costs related to participation in the Platform meetings.’ UKIP has no problem with individual countries working together to share best practices and deal with this issue. However only the elected and accountable national governments should be able to take such decisions – unelected EU bureaucrats have no right to waste taxpayer’s money on such vanity projects.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The proposal for a platform to strengthen cooperation on the prevention and disincentivation of undeclared work by the Commission in order to provide a stable framework for cooperation and exchange of good practices between States, open to the participation of social actors. I welcome the widening of the definition of 'undeclared work' through negotiations with Parliament to include falsely declared work and false self-employed persons, and the participation of trade unions, competent European agencies (Eurofound and OSHA) and the ILO has been strengthened. Although the proposal is far from establishing a coordinated and binding framework for combating employers' abuses (a problem of undoubted magnitude in Europe after integration into the single market), it is an important first step, so I voted in favour.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a European platform aimed at strengthening cooperation to prevent and discourage undeclared work. Indeed, while it is clear that un-reported work needs to be the subject of new measures, it is shown that they would be relevant at national and non-European level as proposed in this text. Moreover, this cooperation represents a new EU interference in the internal affairs of member countries.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report, which improved a Commission proposal to establish a European Platform to fight against undeclared work by ensuring that bogus self-employment is included. Undeclared work deprives workers of social protection; it lowers labour standards and increases health and safety risks. It undermines public finances and social security systems, and it creates a race to the bottom based on unfair competition.  This Platform aims to bring together the various enforcement bodies in each Member State involved in the fight against undeclared work such as labour and social security inspectorates, and tax and migration authorities.  It is an important step forward. Until now, undeclared work, falsely declared work and bogus self-employment have been dealt with sporadically and in an uncoordinated way. The Platform will provide a framework for more effective cooperation. We particularly welcome the inclusion of bogus self-employment in the Platform, as this is a major problem across Ireland, especially in the construction industry. Big contractors deliberately label workers as being self-employed rather than direct labour to cut costs on social insurance payments. The workers miss out on their entitlements and the state misses out on tax revenue.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This European Parliament report aims to create a European platform to strengthen cooperation in the field of the prevention of undeclared work. Undeclared work accounts for 18% of the EU's GDP and ranges from 8% to 30% depending on each state.  Undeclared work is a phenomenon found in many areas of employment and is associated with negative consequences for workers (lower wages, unfair competition, social dumping, lower tax revenues and social security contributions, violations of their labour rights).  I believe that the creation of this platform will be a useful first step forward in order to have better cooperation between the Member States and the social partners of the Union, so as to combat the phenomenon of undeclared work and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Not only does unannounced employment cause financial damage to public budgets and social systems, but it also often leads to highly questionable employment relationships for workers. I therefore welcome the introduction today by the European Parliament of an EU-wide platform to combat the informal economy, which aims to network national authorities such as tax offices, employment agencies or even social partners to better exchange information and successful measures to combat the informal economy. This is the next right step, but for the informal economy to be effectively combated, it needs more than this platform. EU Member States must legislate at national level or adopt initiatives that make black entrepreneurship unattractive. Belgium, for example, has had good experience with the introduction of so-called service cheques.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report aims to combat unreported work in all its forms by establishing better cooperation between Member States. There are laudable intentions in this report. But it is clear that they will have only a limited effect and represent a further breach of the sovereignty of States. In the fight against social fraud and declining tax revenues, the national scale remains the most appropriate. Amendment 63 tabled by the EFDD was not voted on - it would have left the Member States free not to participate - I voted against it.  Therefore I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The report proposed the creation of a ‘Platform’ in Brussels to produce analysis on tackling undeclared work. Undeclared work is defined as ‘any paid activities that are lawful as regards their nature but not declared to public authorities, taking into account the difference in regulatory systems of the Member States’. It proposes that EUR 244 000 be used to reimburse the costs of the Platform meetings. The report would allow for an all-expenses-paid junket for civil servants and national agencies in Brussels. I do not believe that British taxpayers’ money should be used to fund junkets for bureaucrats. I believe that this issue would be best handled by Member States and not the European Parliament.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. Undclared work is one of the most complex and worrying problems facing Europe. I voted in favour of establishing this platform because it will enable enhanced cooperation to combat labour law violations, tax evasion and non-compliance with social security obligations. This platform is the first step towards developing a work programme that will respond to the urgency of today's undeclared activity situation, while contributing to fair market competition and sustainable fiscal stabilization.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to address the problem of undeclared work. This proposal would allow eu national ministries, trade unions and employers' associations to cooperate more closely in the fight against undeclared work. Undeclared work is any gainful activity which, by its very nature, is legal but not declared to the relevant public authorities. It accounts for as much as 18% of the EU's gross domestic product. Such activities have very negative consequences: exploitation of millions of workers across the Union, precarious work, unfair competition, as well as losses to Member States' budget and social security systems. I agree that, in order to successfully address the multifaceted problem of undeclared work, it is first of all necessary to give an objective consideration of its true nature. I support the obligation to set up a cooperation platform at EU level that will allow representatives of all the Countries of the Union, the European Commission and social partners– trade unions and employers – to meet twice a year. They will be able to share information and offer ways to overcome undeclared work. Working groups will also be set up to address specific problems related to such work.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. At the beginning of its current mandate, the European Parliament undertook to combat one of the most calming and complex socio-economic problems, undeclared work. The complexity of the challenge arises from the nature of the problem, i.e. the fact that they are paid activities which are by their very nature legitimate but remain hidden from the relevant administrative authorities. This is a tax avoidance that increases the size of the black economy, goes against the principle of joint burden-sharing, places a disproportionate burden on decent, declared workers and thus on taxpayers. Implementation should be paired with proactive, incentive policies and measures aimed at regularisation of undeclared jobs. Such measures may be the introduction of income tax allowances, tax reductions and aid schemes. The fact that there is no reduction in the practice of undeclared work in the Member States shows that there is demand for the jobs in question, as well as supply. Undeclared work and its various forms of work cannot be tolerated in a strong, work-based and order-based society. The EP's proposal strengthens and improves the functioning of the undeclared work platform, so I supported the adoption of the report.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation because it will create a taxpayer—funded junket for civil servants, national agencies and social partners to wine and dine in Brussels. The platform will produce advice and non-binding guidelines on how to tackle undeclared work. An article in the legislation specifically says that the Commission will reimburse travel and, where appropriate, subsistence expenses for Members, alternates, observers and invited experts. In the original Commission proposal it states: ‘Up to €224 000 per year will be used to reimburse the costs related to participation in the Platform meetings.’ UKIP has no problem with individual countries working together to share best practises and deal with this issue. However, only the elected and accountable national governments should be able to take such decisions – unelected EU bureaucrats have no right to waste taxpayers’ money on such vanity projects.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Despite the good reasons put forward, namely the fight against social fraud and the decline in tax revenues, this form of imposed cooperation represents a new interference in the internal affairs of States. Moreover, it is accepted that it is at the national level that the actions to be taken are most relevant, so that cooperation at European level will have only a very marginal impact on this phenomenon, which is constantly increasing in a context of crisis, and with a very variable scale from one Member State to another. I would have been prepared to vote for this text if the amendment tabled by the EFDD group had been adopted: it was called for the addition of a derogation clause allowing Member States not to participate in this platform. The Eurocrats did not want it, so I voted against it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The primary objective of the platform is to add value at EU level to the efforts of Member States and EU institutions to effectively combat the complex problem of undported work and to deal with its multiple implications and consequences, including encouraging and promoting the work declared through appropriate policies. These policies are all the more necessary in view of the recent conclusions of the Eurofound study, which highlight a strong correlation between, on the one hand, the size and growth of the underground economy and, on the other hand, austerity policies which result in drastic budget cuts, increased deregulation and a significant reduction in the role of the State. The urgency of the measures to be taken cannot be underestimated, given the multiple and very negative consequences of undclared work: serious situations of exploitation, precarious living and working conditions of millions of workers throughout the Union, manifest unfair competition which seriously disrupts the single market and heavy losses to the budgets and social security systems of the Member States.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because I believe that a European platform to combat undeclared work can be a good tool to help reduce current figures: Undeclared work averages 18% of GDP in the EU. Spain is close to average, at 18.6%, which translates to more than 190 billion euros. Undeclared work undermines countries' social and economic progress and is a problem for all citizens, not just governments and businesses. Combating undeclared work is improving access to health care, ensuring labour rights or pensions. This platform would add value to the work already done by different Member States, which need a supranational structure like this to facilitate coordination and exchange of information between all countries.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. 12012 Undeclared work is one of the most serious problems in the european employment situation, a condition which affects millions of workers in all Member States and which seems to be suffering a worrying increase as a result of the crisis.  Recent research has shown a strong correlation between the growth of the black economy and austerity policies, opening up complex scenarios on the overall assessment of the impact of austerity policies. These figures oblige the Union to find a rapid and effective response to the problem. The Pirinski report moves in this direction, identifying the fight against undeclared work, tax evasion and breaches of safety at work rules as priorities for the near future.  The definition of a European platform is the first factor in a more general strategy which, by involving Member States, unions and civil society, cannot simply require the application of the rules but must engage in the development of proactive policies. Only through a system of incentives will it be possible to bring within the framework of formal work the millions of jobs currently hidden in the black economy.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – With regard to the creation of a platform to combat undeclared work, we voted in favour of the report submitted by the EMPL Commission with the aim of getting ahead as an amendment to the Commission document. As positive aspects of the report we highlight the following: - the platform must not only prevent and prevent undeclared work, but also address proactive policies and measures aimed at regularizing undeclared jobs; - we want to explore EU and national tools to address common problems, such as the phenomenon of false self-employed and undeclared work in outsourcing chains; - seeks to include among the tasks the identification of gaps and/or deficiencies of Union legislation;  - seeks to strengthen the operational aspects of the platform: strengthen operational cooperation with joint training sessions, staff exchange and joint inspections, as well as improve data exchange between national administrations;  - common principles and guidelines for inspections addressing undeclared work are to be developed;  - European campaigns and comprehensive regional or European strategies are to be carried out.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This proposal, of course, offers good reasons, whether in terms of fraud or taxation. However, let's not get it wrong. This problem varies enormously from state to state, as each country has to manage this scourge according to the context within its own territory. If the amendment including the opt-out clause allowing Member States not to participate in this European platform had passed, I would have voted for this resolution, although the impact on this phenomenon at European level remains marginal due to the divergences of the problems encountered in the different countries.  The amendment was refused, once again depriving the Member States of their freedom and sovereignty in the name of the great European diktat, I decided to vote against this proposal.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the formation of a European platform to strengthen cooperation to prevent and discourage undeclared work. Given that the principle of the free movement of workers and services and the phenomenon of 'posting of workers' have created the problem of cross-border unemployed work, with enormous damage to our territories, I believe that it is the EU's task to find an effective and shared solution, which is why I wanted to support this report with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Today, the EU has taken a very important step in addressing the many challenges of undeclared work. This seriously harms the European economy, accounting for around 18% of GDP, although in some states it can reach 35% (20% for Spain).  But it not only affects the economy, but poses a serious risk to affected workers as they are often exploited, suffer more dangerous conditions and worse wages, and their labour rights are violated.  The Socialists have led the creation of this platform which aims to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. The platform will deal with all forms of undeclared employment, from false self-employed people to fictitious enterprises, combining the efforts of a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States and social actors.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this initiative which I hope will be the first step in creating more incisive measures to combat this scourge of our economy and our society.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supported the creation of a European platform to combat unemployment. This Platform will strengthen cooperation between member states' labour ministries, trade unions and employers' organisations in identifying best practices in the fight against undeclared work in the EU. Undeclared work damages the economy of the EU as a whole, distorts the labour market and accounts for as much as 18% of the EU's total GDP. In the light of the latest findings of the Eurofound surveys, the scale and growth of the undeclared economy and, secondly, austerity policies, with drastic budget cuts, increasing deregulation and the role of the state, are closely linked. The same studies show that an alternative approach to promoting public expenditure on the labour market and social assistance measures is closely linked to a much smaller undeclared economy. The Platform will be the place where reliable information on best practices and protracted issues is collected and shared, as well as cooperation in defining and implementing effective enforcement and enabling measures.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has already acknowledged in previous debates that 'black work' is a common problem in Europe, which not only has a negative impact on workers, but also causes serious deficits and imbalances in public tax revenues and social contributions. Black employment of 15-20% is not uncommon in the Member States, and a so-called platform could therefore be set up, on the basis of a proposal from the European Commission, to exchange good practices in the Member States and to strengthen professional and advocacy work, as this could facilitate reported employment, job security and decision-makers' work in employment policy and economic policy. As you know, one of the most difficult tasks when examining unannounced employment is to establish black work, because in most cases it remains hidden. The fight against black work is a common cause, but everyone has to do their homework at home and the most effective way to do this is on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. - By supporting a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European platform to strengthen cooperation in preventing and discouraging black work, MEPs have sent as many as 61 amendments to their text, with the aim of improving, in particular, the text in the area of proactive policies enabling and guiding measures to regulate work that is still carried out in the black, for example through tax breaks , tax reductions and subsidy schemes. For tighter controls alone will not be enough, and incentives should also be given to eliminate it in a way that make black recruiters less likely to choose an illegal solution, especially in sectors where such practices are most common.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The text voted on today is in line with the Union's social and labour policy objectives, with the aim of making cooperation between Member States in the fight against undeclared work more effective. Un declared work, in addition to worse working conditions and depriving workers of the fundamental protections that would apply to them automatically, both in terms of social and health benefits and pension rights, has distorting effects on competition and extremely harmful consequences in terms of taxation, which affect the whole of society and the entire economic and social system. As this form of work corresponds to a significant part of the Union's economy, although to varying degrees from one Member State to another, I welcome the establishment of a platform to discourage this practice through better cooperation between the supervisory authorities of the Member States, the constant exchange of information and best practices, in the awareness and respect of the principle of subsidiarity and therefore of the competences of the Member States.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support the report establishing a European platform on preventing and deterring undeclared work. This European platform is the first step in cooperation between member states in the fight against black labour. Undeclared work is often synonymous with disloyal competition, while undocumented workers often work in dangerous conditions and work for lower pay. Therefore, I think it is our obligation to tackle this problem, because working on the black market is one of the biggest problems in the economy and economy of the member states.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I strongly condemn unreported work in all its forms. Nevertheless, this is a matter for each state's policy in its design and application. The Pirinski report underlines this point. In these circumstances I do not see what a European platform for the exchange of good practices would bring to the solution of this problem. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I firmly believe that undeclared work is an extremely pressing and topical problem affecting our economic system and that the establishment of a European platform for strengthening cooperation to prevent and discourage undeclared work is an important first step in the fight against this phenomenon that limits the growth of our economies.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Undeclared work is a precarious job, without protection. A job that escapes the control of the institutions and that often puts the worker in positions of serious precariousness, subordination and danger, also leading to a significant shortness of public office, with consequent negative impact on public services and on the taxation of the population.  The Union and the Member States need to cooperate more in the fight against labour law violations, tax avoidance and breaches of social security provisions, which have reached worrying dimensions in certain areas. Combating undeclared work means protecting the health and safety of workers and protecting tax justice and public services.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to combat undclared work that thrives in times of economic crisis at the expense of the Member States of the European Union. The tool required in this text is the creation of a European platform that would strengthen cooperation between Member States, national bodies and European institutions. Funded by the "Progress" component of the EaSI programme, this platform is intended to promote the exchange of information and good practices, but should also improve the training of the staff concerned.  Whatever the reasons given, we consider that the fight against social and tax fraud remains the responsibility of the Member States and we believe that these exchanges of data will have only a marginal impact on achieving this objective. Furthermore, we oppose the European Commission's willingness to interfere in national affairs through often misappropriated means.  I therefore objected to this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Undeclared work has extremely serious budgetary implications through low tax revenues and social security. This has a negative impact on employment, but also on productivity. It undermines the financial sustainability of social protection systems, deprives workers of adequate social benefits and generates lower pension rights and limited access to healthcare. In view of the negative effects of this type of activity, as well as the lack of sufficient cooperation at EU level, since there is no formal mechanism for cross-border cooperation between the competent authorities of the Member States, I believe that the European platform for enhancing cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work will be real support at European Union level. I am in favour of this report, because through the platform there will be an EU-wide framework to develop expertise and analysis and will improve the operational coordination of actions between the different national law enforcement authorities in the Member States.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. This platform works along the lines of a committee. While there is a risk that it will propose 'more Europe' in a matter of shared competence between the EU and the Member States, it must be recognised that, since the principle of free movement of workers and services (e.g. the 'posting of workers') has created the problem of cross-border untaxed work, there is a need to find solutions to it at Union level. It would be ideal if the accession of the Member States were made optional.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 Undeclared work is constantly used in the Member States, which demonstrates both the existence of a demand and an offer for those jobs, thus making it necessary to integrate them into the official set of rules and regulations of the social market economy and not to eliminate them.  I support the EP draft resolution on the proposal for an EP and Council decision on the establishment of a European platform to enhance cooperation on the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work, with the aim of providing clear EU added value both to efforts to prevent and deter undeclared work and to efforts to regularise the jobs concerned. I believe that there is a need to develop a clear and precise proactive policy that encourages production in order to counter low levels of economic growth and deflation.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. Today, the EU has taken a very important step in addressing the many challenges of undeclared work. This seriously harms the European economy, accounting for around 18% of GDP, although in some states it can reach 35% (20% for Spain).  But it not only affects the economy, but poses a serious risk to affected workers as they are often exploited, suffer more dangerous conditions and worse wages, and their labour rights are violated.  The Socialists have led the creation of this platform which aims to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. The platform will deal with all forms of undeclared employment, from false self-employed people to fictitious enterprises, combining the efforts of a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States and social actors.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this initiative which I hope will be the first step in creating more incisive measures to combat this scourge of our economy and our society.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted to set up a European platform to combat undclared work. Undeclared work is a scourge that deprives workers of protection, maintains unfair competition between companies and constitutes a shortfall for states in terms of tax revenues. The platform will be made up of representatives from Member States, the Commission and social partners. Funding will be provided by the European Union's Employment and Social Innovation Programme and the European Social Fund. Such a measure will facilitate the exchange of information and best practices in the field of work, which will strengthen the single market.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a European Commission decision on the establishment of a European platform for strengthening cooperation to prevent and discourage undeclared work. Undeclared work has many negative consequences: serious exploitation and precarious living and working conditions for millions of workers, unfair competition with distorting effects on the single market and serious losses for member states' budgets and social security systems. I therefore welcome the new European platform, which should guarantee added value to prevent and discourage undeclared work but also, and perhaps even more so, to regularise the jobs concerned.  In its proposal, the Commission envisages an approach based on enforcement. This approach is certainly heading in the right direction. However, in line with what the report says, I believe that the application of the rules should be combined with proactive incentive-based measures and policies aimed at promoting the regularisation of jobs that are not declared. We are talking, for example, about income tax relief, tax breaks and subsidy schemes.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation because it will create a taxpayer—funded junket for civil servants, national agencies and social partners to wine and dine in Brussels. The platform will produce advice and non-binding guidelines on how to tackle undeclared work. An article in the legislation specifically says that the Commission will reimburse travel and, where appropriate, subsistence expenses for Members, alternates, observers and invited experts. In the original Commission proposal it states: ‘Up to €224 000 per year will be used to reimburse the costs related to participation in the Platform meetings.’ UKIP has no problem with individual countries working together to share best practises and deal with this issue. However, only the elected and accountable national governments should be able to take such decisions – unelected EU bureaucrats have no right to waste taxpayers’ money on such vanity projects.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the European platform to combat undeclared work. The main objective of this initiative is to strengthen cooperation between the competent bodies in the Member States by bringing about the sharing of best practices. The platform will consist of one representative per Member State, a maximum of four representatives at EU level of the cross-industry social partners – equally distributed among workers and employers' organisations – and the Commission. The overall objective is to help improve working conditions and social inclusion, and I have therefore certainly voted in favour.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Undeclared work is now a major challenge for the European Union. This is a very complex issue, linked to the very nature of the phenomenon and the serious repercussions it has on working conditions, fair competition, business investment and public budgets. In this regard, it is necessary to highlight the close link between undeclared work and organised crime, which in different regions of the Union operates a dense network of activities – many of them transnational in nature – which are damaging to the financial interests of the Union, by taking care of the correct and effective use of public funds and, more generally, by damaging the entire economic system as a whole.  The establishment of a European platform, through the exchange of information and the sharing of good practices, can help discourage the occurrence of undeclared work, regularise the situation of millions of European workers, guarantee them access to the necessary services, and define sustainable fiscal stabilisation. Only where there are legality and respect for the rules are there fairness and transparency and job opportunities are created for everyone.  For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and welcome the creation of this platform. However, we stress that this measure alone is not sufficient to monitor the various proposals, including legislative proposals, contained in the European Parliament resolution of January 2014 on 'effective labour inspections'. The European Parliament's amendments aim to make the platform more effective in carrying out its tasks and objectives. In particular, it is considered necessary to include falsely declared work in the scope of the decision. Submitting false information about working hours or pay is a form of falsely declared work that cannot be left out of the platform's mission. We also support the close involvement of the social partners in the activities of the platform, as well as the national single contact points.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We discussed today the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the creation of a European platform to strengthen cooperation to prevent and prevent undeclared work.  Undeclared work is obviously one of the biggest thorns in Europe's economy and any initiative to combat it seems to the benefit of citizens, as the formal and legal registration of workers ensures a range of rights that protect and support them. In fact, it should be stressed that the creation of a platform is a rather innovative move that will allow us to listen better to the existing problems and needs of the European economy. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt it was right to vote in favour of the measure because I am convinced of the importance of providing clear added value at Union level to efforts not only to prevent and discourage undeclared work but also to regularise the jobs concerned. These policies are all the more necessary in the light of recent research by the European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions (Eurofound), the results of which indicate a strong correlation between the size and growth of the undeclared economy, on the one hand, and austerity policies characterised by drastic budget cuts, increased deregulation and a role of the state reduced to a minimum. , on the other hand.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because I believe it is appropriate that undeclared work should not become an additional instrument of trade policy for states less inclined to comply with the rules, while we, who are already not squealing, continue to harm us both alone and through the infringements that are raised to us. In particular, I hope that the platform will define common tolerance criteria, because I firmly believe that undeclared work must, to a certain extent, be tolerated: in the face, for example, of a sudden spike in work, given the labour legislation that is at least in Italy, we must not expect companies to hire immediately indefinitely because then the game may not be worth the candle and there would be a disincentive to accept orders. However, this tolerance must not be abused and I would be pleased to see this consideration applied uniformly throughout Europe.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
