text: in writing. ‒ With regard to the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on establishing a European Platform to enhance cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work, European citizens, most often migrants, frequently find themselves trapped in situations of undeclared work. They are particularly vulnerable to the effects of unemployment, without access to any form of social protection. Many of these employees may have worked under the pretext of legal employment only to find that they are not entitled to the benefits generally available to citizens in such situations. The consequences of undeclared work can lead to financial hardship and in some cases, homelessness. The European Platform for prevention and deterrence of undeclared work is necessary to aid Member States in understanding and reducing practices which contribute to homelessness. The Platform will help to reduce the exploitation of such workers. It also enables national and local authorities to provide information to workers who have been negatively affected by such practices. Easily accessible information and advice can help endangered families avoid homelessness.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation because it will create a taxpayer—funded junket for civil servants, national agencies and social partners to wine and dine in Brussels. The platform will produce advice and non-binding guidelines on how to tackle undeclared work. An article in the legislation specifically says that the Commission will reimburse travel and, where appropriate, subsistence expenses for Members, alternates, observers and invited experts. In the original Commission proposal it states: ‘Up to €224 000 per year will be used to reimburse the costs related to participation in the Platform meetings.’ UKIP has no problem with individual countries working together to share best practises and deal with this issue. However, only the elected and accountable national governments should be able to take such decisions – unelected EU bureaucrats have no right to waste taxpayers’ money on such vanity projects.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Undeclared Work is a phenomenon that seriously undermines the working conditions, fair competition and public budgets of the Member States. The Commission has proposed establishing a European Platform that should improve cooperation on the prevention and decommissioning of undeclared work at EU level, bringing together a number of national law enforcement bodies involved in the fight against undeclared work. Although the main responsibility for solving this problem lies with the Member States, however, there are cases where cooperation between the different entities at national level is not sufficiently structured or does not reveal the necessary effectiveness, and this new Platform should be an asset—it should be an asset not only to prevent and deter undeclared work, but also to regularise it. I support the Pirinski Report, as I believe that EU-wide action can help Member States combat undeclared work more effectively, and also contribute to tackling the challenges associated with professional mobility in a positive and constructive way at EU level, while preserving the free movement of workers as one of the EU's fundamental freedoms.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislation because it will create a taxpayer funded junket for civil servants, national agencies and social partners to wine and dine in Brussels. The platform will produce advice and non-binding guidelines on how to tackle undeclared work. An article in the legislation specifically says that the Commission will reimburse travel and, where appropriate, subsistence expenses for Members, alternates, observers and invited experts. In the original Commission proposal it states: ‘Up to €224 000 per year will be used to reimburse the costs related to participation in the Platform meetings.’ UKIP has no problem with individual countries working together to share best practises and deal with this issue. However, only the elected and accountable national governments should be able to take such decisions – unelected EU bureaucrats have no right to waste taxpayers’ money on such vanity projects.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Undeclared work is one of the most complex and worrying problems that the European Parliament is called upon to deal with. In its proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment of a European platform, the Commission gave priority to the enforcement approach aimed at preventing and discouraging undeclared work.  In this way, the strategy is based on enhanced cooperation in the fight against violations of labour law, tax avoidance and breaches of social security provisions, but also on proactive incentive-based measures and policies, in order to promote the regularisation of jobs that are not declared, such as income tax relief , tax breaks and subsidy schemes.  Having said that, I voted in favour of establishing a European platform that will make it possible to provide clear added value at EU level to efforts not only to prevent and discourage undeclared work but also to regularise the jobs concerned.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Workers who are in undeclared work often face hazardous working conditions, much lower wages, severe infringements of labour rights, and find greatly reduced protection under labour and social protection law. As legislators it is of concern that people are forced to choose undeclared work as this deprives them of adequate social benefits, pension rights and access to healthcare, as well as skills development and life-long learning opportunities.  From a cross-border element point of view this Platform should contribute to the strengthening of the cooperation between Member States, including adopting innovative approaches of cross-border cooperation and enforcement as well as by evaluating experiences of such cooperation to draw conclusions for future policy action.  Finally, by voting in favour I am expressing my concern about the lack of targeted policies for workers in the informal sector who are young, elderly or female, and, in particular women with disabilities and female immigrants. We need to integrate these realities into the formal range of rules and regulations of the social market economy.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objective of the platform is to encourage closer cooperation between the relevant bodies in the Member States dealing with the problem of undeclared work. The scope and regulations vary between Member States. The platform will meet at least twice a year, in plenary session, and there will be working groups to address specific issues related to undeclared work. The aim is to encourage cooperation (essentially through the sharing of best practices and the development of evaluations) between Member States, without having any operational power. Member States will decide the level of their participation in this platform. Each Member State may appoint only one representative (and one substitute); the participation of social actors (4 Permanent Representatives and 14 observers) is also planned. More high-level representatives appointed by all Member States, a maximum of four representatives at EU level of cross-industry social partners. The overall objective is to help improve working conditions, promote integration into the labour market and promote social inclusion. The platform covers all forms of unead work, including bogus self-employment. I regard this as a good proposal, so I can only vote in favour of it.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The proposal for a platform to strengthen cooperation on the prevention and disincentivation of undeclared work by the Commission in order to provide a stable framework for cooperation and exchange of good practices between States, open to the participation of social actors. I welcome the widening of the definition of 'undeclared work' through negotiations with Parliament to include falsely declared work and false self-employed persons, and the participation of trade unions, competent European agencies (Eurofound and OSHA) and the ILO has been strengthened. Although the proposal is far from establishing a coordinated and binding framework for combating employers' abuses (a problem of undoubted magnitude in Europe after integration into the single market), it is an important first step, so I voted in favour.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the initiative on undeclared work and I am convinced of the need for strong cooperation between European states, in order to combat their causes and limit their scope. According to recent surveys, the impact of the "black" on the European economy is estimated at around 18% of GDP, with a range that varies widely between Member States (from a minimum of 8% to a maximum of 30%). To date, the fight against this phenomenon has been left to national bodies, which have little to do with a highly cross-border phenomenon.  That is why the platform for cooperation between the Commission and the Member States must be implemented quickly and, with the cooperation of the social partners, able to better prevent the phenomenon, verify its extent and disseminate the best practices that allow it to emerge. Tax evasion and unfair competition entail costs for public finances; inadequate working conditions, minimum safety standards, exploitation of the most vulnerable social groups are social costs that we can no longer afford.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 At the beginning of his term, the 8th President of the European Parliament and the European Parliament, Commissioned by the European Parliament to combat undeclared work. The complexity of the challenge arises from the nature of the problem, i.e. that they are paid activities which are by their very nature legitimate but remain hidden from the relevant administrative authorities or are misrepresented in the event of s faking self-employment.  The proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Platform has set out the challenge of having a platform where reliable information on best practices and existing problems is collected and shared and where cooperation can be pursued in the development and application of effective enforcement and incentive measures. The aim is, inter alia, to create a work programme that takes full account of the need for targeted action that reverses the current trend of the spread of undeclared work and increases the number of regular jobs that provide a decent livelihood and provide useful services to customers, while contributing to fair competition in the market and sustainable financial stability. The outcome of the interinstitutional negotiation was acceptable to the European People's Party, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal aims to create a platform that will facilitate the exchange of best practices and information and the development of a common approach to undeclared work. I support the creation of this type of platform, which I consider to facilitate cross-border cooperation and knowledge exchange between law enforcement authorities. I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the first reading of this agreement as I believe that the EU must make greater efforts in combatting undeclared work and precarious employment throughout the EU. Undeclared work detriments the wellbeing of workers and subjects them to a black market with no financial, or social safeguards. The proposal seeks to establish a platform that helps, not only by preventing undeclared work but also by transforming undeclared work into declared work. Furthermore, I supported the proposal as it gives Member States the necessary tools to combat undeclared work within their Member States and through cross border collaboration and helps the EU give one unified response to the phenomenon.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that undeclared work at national and cross-border level represents two distinct forms of undeclared work and that this can contribute to the emergence of the phenomenon known as 'social dumping', including through wage reductions in the Member States where services are provided, I believe that close and effective cooperation is needed both across border and Union level , because the identification, analysis and resolution of practical problems relating to the implementation of Union law with regard to undeclared working conditions and social protection at work fall within the competence of the Member States and their national labour protection systems.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Undeclared work is a scourge afflicting the European market and forms a significant part of it, estimated at over 18% of the European Union's GDP. This phenomenon continues to be widespread and undermines our social protection systems, deprives our governments of tax revenue and exposes workers to working conditions of contractual weakness, with negative consequences for the competitiveness of the entire European market.  I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council because it has the merit of establishing a European platform to prevent and discourage this practice. A new instrument that will provide the legal framework to combat the phenomenon of unse declared work more effectively, through the strengthening and improvement of operational cooperation between Member States and the easier sharing of information and good practices.  This first step, which I welcome, will have to be followed in the coming months by targeted actions at European level aimed in particular at the weakest groups, such as immigrants or younger workers, who are often forced to accept precarious working conditions, with lower earnings, without any protection of their fundamental rights.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to set up a European platform to promote the fight against unreported work. This platform will improve cooperation between national authorities for the prevention and detection of unreported work and strengthen their technical capacity. One of the main objectives of this scheme will be to increase public awareness through the sharing of best practices and analysis.  In addition, in order to ensure the added value of this European platform, the European Commission will have to submit an evaluation of this scheme four years after its introduction. Considering that this project respects the principle of subsidiarity on the one hand, and that undclared work which accounts for 18.4% of EU GDP has negative effects on both workers who do not enjoy the right rights and on businesses, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of establishing a European platform to strengthen cooperation to prevent and discourage undeclared work. It is indeed essential that the European Union commits itself even more to the Member States to combat unreported work and promote employment and growth. In particular, it is then relevant to improve cooperation between the various national authorities responsible for this matter.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because undeclared work can lay a heavy burden on tax incomes and social security revenues. It creates unfair competition between those that abide by the rules and those that do not. I believe that for a free and single European market to function we need to ensure that workers have an adequate level of protection wherever they are employed. A European Platform can be a good instrument for this problem since undeclared work has become a cross-border problem with undeclared workers moving back and forth between Member States, ultimately even undermining the fundamental right of free movement.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 Undeclared work, undeclared work, employment falsely declared as self-employed are very serious realities in the lives of workers; workers who often have lower wages and lack their rights and safety at work.  That is why I voted in favour of the creation of this platform, which aims to combat these phenomena, not only by combating misconduct, but also by disseminating best practices and preventive and proactive policies to promote the regularisation of jobs and to avoid unwork.  The platform will fill a gap at European level and allow for more effective cooperation between those in everyday life who are faced with undeclared work. An important step towards the Europe of solidarity and growth that we want to build

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The undeclared economy accounts for an average of 18% of the EU's GDP, and reaches 30% of GDP for Bulgaria, the most exposed Member State. It thus represents a significant shortfall for the public authorities, but also exposes workers "in the dark" to precarious and dangerous working conditions.  The European Union must therefore work to curb this phenomenon and seek to reintegrate these workers into the legal labour market. The creation of a platform for the exchange of information between states and cross-border actions is a first step towards a more effective fight against black-and-trade.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. The consequences of unreported work are very negative: serious situations of exploitation, precarious living and working conditions for millions of workers throughout the Union, manifest unfair competition disrupting the single market, heavy losses to Member States' budgets and social security systems...  That is why I voted in favour of the PIRINSKI report on the establishment of a European platform with the aim of cooperation to prevent and discourage undeclared work. I welcome the forthcoming implementation of this platform, which will add value to efforts to prevent and discourage undeclared work and to efforts to regularise the jobs concerned.  The European platform is defined as a place to collect and share reliable information on good practices and persistent problems and to cooperate in the definition and implementation of effective enforcement of legislation and incentives.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has already acknowledged in previous debates that 'black work' is a common problem in Europe, which not only has a negative impact on workers, but also causes serious deficits and imbalances in public tax revenues and social contributions. Black employment of 15-20% is not uncommon in the Member States either, so a so-called platform could be set up on a proposal from the European Commission to exchange good practices in the Member States and strengthen professional and advocacy work, as this could facilitate reported employment, job security and decision-makers' work in employment policy and economic policy. As you know, one of the most difficult tasks when examining unannounced employment is to establish black work, because in most cases it remains hidden. On the basis of good practice so Hungary has done much in recent years to whiten the economy, e.g. by introducing online cash registers. In addition, the introduction of job protection programmes for hundreds of thousands of people, employment tax incentives and the introduction of new atypical forms of employment (simplified employment, multi-employer employment, etc.) have contributed significantly to the domestic reduction of black employment. The fight against black work is a common cause, but everyone has to do their homework at home and the most effective way to do this is on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution establishing a 'European platform' to strengthen cooperation between labour ministries, trade unions and employers' associations in The Member States' countries to combat undclared work.  Currently, unreported work accounts for an average of 18% of EU GDP. For workers, undercover work too often means unsafe working conditions and squalor wages, which encourages social dumping, especially in cases of cross-border work.  This platform should, first, aim to prevent, discourage and combat undeclared work, but also to promote the transformation of such activities into declared work, secondly to encourage practical, effective and efficient cross-border actions, and to develop a reliable and effective system for rapid exchange of information between national bodies.  However, this should not interfere with Member States' own measures or seek to harmonize the regulatory systems of individual EU countries.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ The shadow economy can have a serious impact on tax and social security systems in the Member States. Furthermore, it can affect, inter alia, citizens’ access to health care, parental leave or pension rights. I am supportive of and voted for the newly adopted proposal to create a platform for the EU Member States and EU institutions to share best practices and to enhance cooperation to prevent and deter undeclared work. Member States should fully participate in the platform which will help us to unite forces in Europe to fight against undeclared work, create more formal jobs and secure higher tax revenues.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The fight against all forms of undclared work must be carried out by States, which are best able to provide relevant and effective responses on this subject, with the help of social partners. This is an area in which European countries must remain sovereign. I am not in favour of the creation of a platform whose secretariat would be entrusted to the Commission. I was opposed to any forced interference in the internal affairs of States and voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, although I have some concerns because I believe that facilitating the exchange of best practices and information is important. However, I would like to express my concerns when it comes to the flexibility that Member States must have when participating in the proposed platform. I support mandatory participation in the platform itself, but I am against any suggestion that Member States should be obliged to participate in the activities.  This should remain on a voluntary basis, given that not all Member States are fit and able to participate permanently. More important than undermining obligations is voluntary participation, which will stimulate better quality and positive engagement.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against, undeclared work and in general the exploitation of the working class are not treated with "platforms" especially when they are created by active large capital, who from the outset exploit the masses. In addition, the report includes provisions for illegal immigrants, as well as various benefits for the so-called experts who will staff this platform.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has already acknowledged in previous debates that 'black work' is a common problem in Europe, which not only has a negative impact on workers, but also causes serious deficits and imbalances in public tax revenues and social contributions. Black employment of 15-20% is not uncommon in the Member States either, so a so-called platform could be set up on a proposal from the European Commission to exchange good practices in the Member States and strengthen professional and advocacy work, as this could facilitate reported employment, job security and decision-makers' work in employment policy and economic policy. As you know, one of the most difficult tasks when examining unannounced employment is to establish black work, because in most cases it remains hidden. On the basis of good practice so Hungary has done much in recent years to whiten the economy, e.g. by introducing online cash registers. In addition, the introduction of job protection programmes for hundreds of thousands of people, employment tax incentives and the introduction of new atypical forms of employment (simplified employment, multi-employer employment, etc.) have contributed significantly to the domestic reduction of black employment. The fight against black work is a common cause, but everyone has to do their homework at home and the most effective way to do this is on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. With the creation of this European platform, the aim is to improve cooperation in the prevention and disincentive of undeclared work in the EU. The exchange of good practices and cooperation between the police authorities of the Member States is intended to prevent and discourage undeclared work and to increase public awareness of this issue. The aim is to improve the technical capacity of Member States to be able to deal cross-border with undeclared work, and to achieve an exchange at European level of analyses, opinions and good practices. It is a great EU agreement on employment, which will have an impact on future benefits and which fully respects the principle of subsidiarity and the competences of the Member States.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Undeclared work is a serious problem in Europe. In 2012, it will have accounted for 18.4% of EU GDP and the negative effects are felt on workers, businesses and governments. Undeclared work 'is a legal work that is not adequately declared before the competent authorities'. From unfair competition to loss of tax revenues and social security contributions, there are several negative consequences of undeclared work, and workers are left with their fundamental social and labour rights reduced.  I therefore agree that the platform is an opportunity to analyse data and share best practices, especially in a context of undeclared cross-border work.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation, because I believe that the fight against illegal labour must remain the responsibility of the States.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 Work not only has an economic and profit purpose but is the main tool by which a person realizes himself and secures the widest right to dignity. The fight against undeclared work is first and foremost a battle of civilisations to improve social and individual living conditions. It also means combating criminal phenomena such as illegal intermediation, tax and tax evasion, the 'foreign arms' market and all forms of labour exploitation.  A platform to improve European cooperation to combat undeclared work must aim not only at preventing and discouraging it, but also at regularising the positions that lead to a lack of social and employment protection for workers.  It would make it easier to improve knowledge and mutual understanding of the different national systems of inspections at work, to know all forms and causes of undeclared work, to exchange experience and good practice, and to provide up-to-date, reliable and comparative information that will also help to improve legislation in this area.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the creation of an EU-wide Platform for combating undeclared work, while any paid activity of a lawful nature but not declared to the public authorities. This Platform aims at greater cooperation between Member States – their structures and authorities for labour surveillance, hygiene and safety conditions, financial taxation, foreign services, etc. – by sharing information and best practices, developing a common database and principles and methodologies, as well as training actions. Undeclared work (which is associated with false self-work and other forms of precarious labour relations) has repercussions for the financial and ethical structure of states, corresponding on average to 18% of GDP in the EU. The workers involved in these schemes are more fragile in their rights – such as protection against accidents, unemployment or guaranteed reform – so the establishment of strategies to combat the phenomenon is essential and is understood as positive. However, there are aspects in the architecture of this Platform that deserve our disagreement, particularly involving the use of data and that may jeopardise the freedoms of individuals. The importance of a formal structure with these objectives is also questioned, despite the importance of cooperation in this context as in other contexts.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which will lead to the creation of a European platform to prevent and discourage undeclared work, which includes paid activities not declared to the relevant public authorities. I believe it is essential to specify that the establishment of this platform will be without prejudice to the obligations and competences of the Member States in the fight against undeclared work. This will be ensured in two ways: each State will have flexibility in deciding whether or not to participate in each activity of the platform; the social partners on the platform will not have the same weight as the Member States in terms of voting and managing the agenda.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the European Parliament has long highlighted one of the European Union's worst and most complex problems, undeclared work. This also results from the fact that public administrations often do not act. The main cause of many negative consequences related to undeclared work is the avoidance of registration. It is precisely the establishment of a European platform that will allow enhanced cooperation to be established to combat labour law violations, tax evasion or social security violations. However, it must be linked to support policies aimed at legalising currently illegal jobs. The aim of the new European platform must therefore be to provide added value at European Union level by supporting targeted proactive policy measures by increasing production in order to combat low growth and deflation.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the establishment of the European platform to find new responses at EU level aimed at discouraging cross-border uneen work.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the creation of a European platform to strengthen cooperation to prevent and prevent undeclared work. Undeclared work and, more generally, the exploitation of the working class are not treated with "platforms" especially when they are created by workers of large capital, who from the outset exploit the masses. In addition, the report includes provisions for illegal immigrants, as well as various benefits for the so-called experts who will staff this platform.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the fact that the undeclared economy is equivalent to over 18% of the European Union’s GDP, ranging from below 8% to over 30% of GDP in the different Member States, I believe we need to ensure the adoption of the agreement reached with Council and Commission by a large majority. The construction sector is over-proportionately affected by undeclared work; the phenomenon is also wide-spread with regard to household and care services, private security, industrial cleaning, and agriculture as well as in the hotel, restaurant and catering sector. Undeclared work is often associated with unfair competition and social dumping as well as lower tax revenues and social security contributions. Undeclared workers are often subject to hazardous working conditions, lower wages, lacking social security and violations of their labour rights. I strongly support the call for the involvement of European Social Partners as members of the Platform, and the mandatory participation of all Member States in the Platform.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has already acknowledged in previous debates that 'black work' is a common problem in Europe, which not only has a negative impact on workers, but also causes serious deficits and imbalances in public tax revenues and social contributions. Black employment of 15-20% is not uncommon in the Member States either, so a so-called platform could be set up on a proposal from the European Commission to exchange good practices in the Member States and strengthen professional and advocacy work, as this could facilitate reported employment, job security and decision-makers' work in employment policy and economic policy. As you know, one of the most difficult tasks when examining unannounced employment is to establish black work, because in most cases it remains hidden. On the basis of good practice so Hungary has done much in recent years to whiten the economy, e.g. by introducing online cash registers. In addition, the introduction of job protection programmes for hundreds of thousands of people, employment tax incentives and the introduction of new atypical forms of employment (simplified employment, multi-employer employment, etc.) have contributed significantly to the domestic reduction of black employment. The fight against black work is a common cause, but everyone has to do their homework at home and the most effective way to do this is on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I am convinced that the first step to successfully address the multifaceted problem of undeclared work is to examine its nature objectively. This investigation shows that, in fact, avoiding an appropriate notification can be considered as a direct cause of the many and extremely adverse consequences and effects associated with the problem. By agreeing on the true nature of undeclared work and the proposed responsibilities of the Platform, it will be possible to reach agreement on a number of issues affecting membership, participation, procedures and decision-making. It also serves as a basis for the establishment of a work programme that takes full account of the need for targeted action to reverse the current trend of the spread of undeclared work and to increase the number of regular jobs that provide a decent livelihood and provide useful services to customers, while contributing to fair competition in the market and sustainable financial stability.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the view that closer cooperation and increased labour inspections are essential to combat undeclared work at EU level. I therefore consider the Commission's decision to create a European platform to improve eu-wide cooperation in this area an important step in this direction, especially in view of the view that undeclared work causes serious harm to working conditions, fair competition and public finances, and we must therefore be taxative in their eradication.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – Today, the EU has taken a very important step in addressing the many challenges of undeclared work. This seriously harms the European economy, accounting for around 18% of GDP, although in some states it can reach 35% (20% for Spain).  But it not only affects the economy, but poses a serious risk to affected workers as they are often exploited, suffer more dangerous conditions and worse wages, and their labour rights are violated.  The Socialists have led the creation of this platform which aims to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. The platform will deal with all forms of undeclared employment, from false self-employed people to fictitious enterprises, combining the efforts of a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States and social actors.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this initiative which I hope will be the first step in creating more incisive measures to combat this scourge of our economy and our society.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. Today, the EU has taken a very important step in addressing the many challenges of undeclared work. This seriously harms the European economy, accounting for around 18% of GDP, although in some states it can reach 35% (20% for Spain).  But it not only affects the economy, but poses a serious risk to affected workers as they are often exploited, suffer more dangerous conditions and worse wages, and their labour rights are violated.  The Socialists have led the creation of this platform which aims to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. The platform will deal with all forms of undeclared employment, from false self-employed people to fictitious enterprises, combining the efforts of a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States and social actors.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this initiative which I hope will be the first step in creating more incisive measures to combat this scourge of our economy and our society.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Global geopolitics is going through a period of great fragility and the repercussions of the economic crisis spare no one, from China, America, the main European countries and markets.  In this climate, in which the labour market sector is probably affected more than any other, the data tell us of an undeclared labour economy in Europe above 18%, which is often associated with other worrying phenomena which make the situation of our workers even more worrying, such as social dumping, the complete absence of guarantees and rights , as well as unlikely working conditions.  To oppose all this is our duty and responsibility. For this reason, I vote and support the Commission's proposal to establish a European platform to promote the regularisation of undeclared jobs and to promote the sharing of information and good practices between national administrations in such a way as to prevent and discourage undeclared work, as well as for the protection of the dignity and rights of workers.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the creation of a European platform to strengthen cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work, as I consider it to be an instrument that can counter undeclared work across borders. At the same time, I realize that this will not be a miracle weapon, even if some people like to sell it that way. For me, it will be important to analyse the work on an annual basis and to consider together whether the platform makes sense in this way.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Worthy working conditions should be a matter of course for every worker. Unfortunately, this is not the case. The problem of undeclared work in particular has become increasingly explosive recently. We can only solve this problem together. That is why I have today advocated better coordinated cooperation at EU level.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the EU’s decision to establish a Platform to tackle the problem of undeclared work in the EU. Given the freedom of movement in the EU, it is pertinent that Member States are encouraged to cooperate in this area and tackle employers who impose undeclared work and yet hide behind borders. There are many negative consequences of undeclared work, which in the UK is estimated to be 10 % of GDP.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to combat unreported work in all its forms: clandestine work, false statements, false self-employed work. To this end, the report calls for the establishment of a European platform that would bring together, under the aegis of the European Commission, the Member States and their national bodies responsible for combating undclared work. A focal point for information from states and their agencies, this platform would have a function of coordinating and exchanging best practices among its members. The problem with this platform is that it will also have a function of monitoring the action of the Member States, without any guarantee of a real fight against undclared work.  We know, for example, that Europe has encouraged detached work, which is itself a way of circumventing social legislation. We also know that covert work, since it involves illegal immigrants, is tolerated by both European leaders and some national leaders who are in favour of illegal immigration, as demonstrated by the migrant crisis. Therefore, the creation of this platform will at most enable the creation of a new European budget-eating agency.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Brussels has decided to focus on the problem of unreported work. And for this, it creates a "platform", a gimmick halfway between the Theodule committee and the officiine responsible for proposing standards. If the platform turns to the Theodule committee, it will be content to lay unnecessary reports at great expense. It will serve as an alibi for the Commission to show that it is concerned about workers who are constantly unemployed or insecure by its laws, such as the 'detachment' directive. If it turns to the officiine, it will become the birthplace of ultra-liberal reforms of our labour codes, our social protection systems, which are considered too expensive, and our wage policies, which are considered too generous. Reforms are all the more illegitimate because all these areas are by no means the competence of Brussels. So yes, we have to fight against black work, we have to recreate the conditions so that no one is forced to be a fake self-employed person to find work and that companies do not judge a hiring as a potential trap that can put them at risk. But the solutions cannot come from this Europe.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report which combats labour law violations and tax evasion, with the aim of increasing the number of jobs in a market characterised by fair competition, social security and sustainable fiscal stability. Undeclared work distorts the market, particularly affecting SMEs, but also workers. I believe that it is only through collaboration between Member States and a platform that operates according to well-established rules that undeclared work can be reduced.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Undeclared work has serious implications for the economy and deprives workers of their basic rights and often puts them in hazardous working conditions. I welcome this decision of the EU to establish a Platform to tackle the problems of undeclared work in the EU. It is right that Member States work with each other to tackle those employers who perpetrate undeclared work and attempt to hide behind borders. In the context of the UK, undeclared work is estimated to be equivalent to 10% of the GDP. Hence, I believe that this package provides a much needed format for such cooperation and addresses the new challenges that the EU faces, such as the labour market integrating the recent influx of refugees.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. On Tuesday 9 February, I voted in favour of a report aimed at establishing a European platform to combat undclared work. This would strengthen cooperation between the labour ministries, trade unions and employers' associations of the Member States on how best to manage a scourge that is damaging the EU economy and disrupting the labour market.  Behind these terms "undclared work" lie serious situations such as the exploitation of workers, precariousness, unfair competition and heavy losses for states and their social security systems. The long-term goal is to help improve working conditions and integrate unreported workers into the labour market.  I expect Member States to implement labour laws, carry out inspections and punish abuses. Too many European laws fail in their transposition, application or control by states, including the directive on the secondment of workers which suffers from the shortcomings of national systems.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. Today, the EU has taken a very important step in addressing the many challenges of undeclared work. This seriously harms the European economy, accounting for around 18% of GDP, although in some states it can reach 35% (20% for Spain).  But it not only affects the economy, but poses a serious risk to affected workers as they are often exploited, suffer more dangerous conditions and worse wages, and their labour rights are violated.  The Socialists have led the creation of this platform which aims to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. The platform will deal with all forms of undeclared employment, from false self-employed to fictitious enterprises, combining the efforts of a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States and social actors.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this initiative which I hope will be the first step in creating more incisive measures to combat this scourge of our economy and our society.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. 18% of eu's GDP. According to Eurofund figures, this is what undclared work in the European Union represents. This is a real threat, not only to workers, to governments, but also to the European economy.  This distorts the labour market, hurting the European Union's economy. It exacerbates the phenomena of social dumping. Unreported work also threatens workers who are often in precarious or even exploitable situations. Unreported workers are often forced to accept unsafe working conditions and low wages. They lack social security coverage, their pension rights are non-existent and they have less access to care.  In order to discourage this phenomenon, I have therefore spoken out in favour of the creation of a European cooperation platform that will facilitate the exchange of information and good practices by proposing new solutions for the fight against undeclared work. The European Union has just taken a major first step in the fight against undclared work, but it still has a long way to go.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the trilogue agreement because EU action on the issue of tackling undeclared work can help create jobs by legalising them, securing workers’ access to social security and pensions and saving Member States’ tax revenues, among other things. In addition, the trilogue agreement will get the Platform operational as soon as possible, will not conflict with national legislation, and will harmonize cooperation between Member States.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. Today, the EU has taken a very important step in addressing the many challenges of undeclared work. This seriously harms the European economy, accounting for around 18% of GDP, although in some states it can reach 35% (20% for Spain).  But it not only affects the economy, but poses a serious risk to affected workers as they are often exploited, suffer more dangerous conditions and worse wages, and their labour rights are violated.  The Socialists have led the creation of this platform which aims to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. The platform will deal with all forms of undeclared employment, from false self-employed to fictitious enterprises, combining the efforts of a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States and social actors.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this initiative which I hope will be the first step in creating more incisive measures to combat this scourge of our economy and our society.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has already acknowledged in previous debates that 'black work' is a common problem in Europe, which not only has a negative impact on workers, but also causes serious deficits and imbalances in public tax revenues and social contributions. Black employment of 15-20% is not uncommon in the Member States either, so a so-called platform could be set up on a proposal from the European Commission to exchange good practices in the Member States and strengthen professional and advocacy work, as this could facilitate reported employment, job security and decision-makers' work in employment policy and economic policy. As is known, one of the most difficult tasks when examining unannounced employment is to establish black work, because in most cases it remains hidden. On the basis of good practice so Hungary has done much in recent years to whiten the economy, e.g. by introducing online cash registers. In addition, the introduction of job protection programmes for hundreds of thousands of people, employment tax incentives and the introduction of new atypical forms of employment (simplified employment, multi-employer employment, etc.) have contributed significantly to the domestic reduction of black employment. The fight against black work is a common cause, but everyone has to do their homework at home and this is most effectively done on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 In January 2014 the EP adopted a resolution on more cooperation and strengthening of national labour inspection services with the aim of combating undeclared work. In April 2014 the Commission presented a proposal to create a European Platform aimed at strengthening cooperation at EU level. The Pirinski report welcomes the creation of the Platform and proposes a number of amendments. Our group has proposed 26 amendments to the committee. The majority of them have been incorporated into the report, and despite some weaknesses, we consider this to be a good first step, hence we voted in favour of the report.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The platform put forward by the Commission, composed of enforcement agencies nominated by each Member State, would simplify the exchange of best practices and information and develop a common understanding of undeclared work. The final trilogue agreement, which was reached in December, ensured flexibility to Member States in regards to participation in the activities of the platform and limited the number of social partners while ensuring they would have no voting rights or influence over the agenda of the platform. My Group and I believe this initiative would be useful, and since it has been ensured that national competence will not be infringed upon I have voted in favour of this proposal.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has already acknowledged in previous debates that 'black work' is a common problem in Europe. This not only has a negative impact on workers, but also causes serious deficits and imbalances in public tax revenues and social contributions. Black employment of 15-20% is not uncommon in the Member States. Therefore, on the basis of a proposal from the European Commission, a so-called platform could be set up to exchange good practices in the Member States and strengthen professional and advocacy work. This can greatly facilitate reported employment, job security and decision-makers' work in employment policy and economic policy. As you know, one of the most difficult tasks when examining unannounced employment is to establish black work, because in most cases it remains hidden. On the basis of the good practices so Hungary has done much in recent years to whiten the economy, e.g. by introducing online cash registers. In addition, the introduction of job protection programmes for hundreds of thousands of people, employment tax incentives and the introduction of new atypical forms of employment (simplified employment, multi-employer employment, etc.) have contributed significantly to the domestic reduction of black employment. The fight against black work is a common cause, but everyone has to do their homework at home. This is most effectively possible on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ Along with other Labour MEPs, I welcome the decision to establish a Platform to tackle the problem of undeclared work in the EU. Member States should be working together to take on those employers who utilise undeclared, cash-in-hand work. Many workers are being forced to sign contracts that class them as self-employed purely to circumvent the employers’ obligations. This means many are missing out on sick pay, holiday pay and are denied access to employment tribunals. We also need to tackle this problem at source, reducing levels of poverty and inequality.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ Undeclared work leaves workers vulnerable to exploitation, tax payers short changed and responsible employers undermined. 600 000 undeclared workers in Britain need today’s recommendations for European action to bring them in to the formal economy, to prevent and deter undeclared work, now and in the future. A British Government study described the difference between the average ‘value added’ in national statistics and the local calculation as one measure of the ‘shadow economy’ and thus the incidence of undeclared work. In my own constituency it estimates this to be 15% in Lowestoft, 17% in Clacton, 20% in Southend and 23% in Great Yarmouth. People here are left unprotected, can be fired without warning, do not receive holiday or sick pay, and have reduced benefit entitlements. The root causes of this undeclared work derive from economic failure, low social protection and higher poverty levels. The communities I represent in the East of England deserve better. European action to promote worker protection will mean fewer undeclared workers. But it also means better protection for all those who suffer low pay and job insecurity. Let’s provide a hand-up to protect  those forced to rely on cash-in-hand.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report, which should establish a European Platform with the goal of reducing undeclared work. In addition, the aim is to take action and reduce labour law infringements, tax avoidance and breaches of social security requirements.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to establish a European Platform to Improve Cooperation on Preventing and Deterring Undeclared Work, as it mitigates the negative consequences of undeclared work such as exploitation and poor working and living conditions for millions of workers across the European Union.  Accordingly, the disloyal competition resulting from this significantly harms the single market and weakens Member States' budgets and social protection systems. In this context, coordinated action is needed by social partners, Member States, EU institutions and stakeholders to effectively overcome challenges and shortcomings.  In addition to the fact that it is necessary to prevent and deter undeclared work, it is necessary to regulate this type of work. Therefore, the platform in question should become a place for collecting and sharing information and good practices and a tool for implementing and launching concrete measures in this sector.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The proposed cooperation, while its intentions are laudable, will have only a limited effect. It represents a further breach of the sovereignty of states. I believe that the actions to be taken in the fight against social fraud and the decrease in tax revenues it generates are more relevant at the national level. If EFDD Amendment 63 had passed I could have supported the text, because it would have left the Member States free not to participate. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My fellow UKIP MEP’s voted against this legislation because it will create a taxpayer funded junket for civil servants, national agencies and social partners to wine and dine in Brussels. The platform will produce advice and non-binding guidelines on how to tackle undeclared work. An article in the legislation specifically says that the Commission will reimburse travel and, where appropriate, subsistence expenses for members, alternates, observers and invited experts. In the original Commission proposal it states: ‘Up to EUR 224 000 per year will be used to reimburse the costs related to participation in the Platform meetings.’ UKIP has no problem with individual countries working together to share best practises and deal with this issue. However only the elected and accountable national governments should be able to take such decisions – unelected EU bureaucrats have no right to waste taxpayers’ money on such vanity projects.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. U2012 I welcome the EU's progress in its fight against undeclared work, which seriously harms the European economy as it accounts for around 18% of GDP, although in some States it can reach 35% (20% for Spain).  But it not only affects the economy, but poses a serious risk to affected workers as they are often exploited, suffer more dangerous conditions and worse wages, and their labour rights are violated.  The Socialists have led the creation of this platform which aims to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. The platform will deal with all forms of undeclared employment, from false self-employed to fictitious enterprises, combining the efforts of a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States and social actors.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this initiative which I hope will be the first step in creating more incisive measures to combat this scourge of our economy and our society.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Georgi Pirinski's report on the proposed decision establishing a European platform to strengthen cooperation to prevent and discourage undeclared work.  The consequences of unreported work are indeed very harmful and lead to situations of exploitation and precariousness for millions of workers throughout the Union. Added to this are the very large losses to budgets and social security systems in the Member States, which penalises all citizens who follow the rules. This would represent between 15% and 20% of eu GDP. That is why I support the establishment of this European platform, which should enable us to better combat undclared work. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. The fight against undclared work is an important battle for the public accounts of the Member States. The aim of this important report on the fight against undclared work is to create a platform at European level to exchange best practices between Member States, improve cross-border cooperation and keep a register of companies that take advantage of the flaws in the system. This will strengthen cooperation between labour ministries, trade unions and employers' associations in member states. I have obviously voted in favour of this very good initiative which will help to improve working conditions in Europe and promote the integration of unreported workers into the labour market.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The problem of undeclared work is an extremely complex problem. The mere definition of this issue creates some difficulties, since it may concern both profit-making activities which have not been notified to the competent authorities and self-employment which has been notified but does not actually function (i.e. the declared activity is not carried out). Avoiding proper registration usually results from a desire to avoid taxation. To counteract this phenomenon, the EU legislative institutions propose the creation of a European platform to facilitate cooperation to prevent undeclared work. This platform is primarily intended to collect and exchange reliable information, joint planning and implementation of procedures. Active action is necessary, especially given that the level of undeclared work in the Member States is not decreasing – and therefore many citizens are still highly motivated to practe and disseminate this practice. The proactive policy mentioned by the rapporteur seems to be the right approach, aimed at reaching out to those Europeans who are moving in the so-called grey economy and encouraging them to register their activities or change the industry. A proper understanding of the problem, understanding the causes and motivations of citizens avoiding registration, and then proposing solutions and encouraging fairness, is the best way to deal with it.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The creation of such a European Platform will undoubtedly mean that workers would have to be subject to permanent control for no reason whatsoever. For reasons of data protection law, this report also has gross flaws. For this reason, I do not agree with the report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the EU’s decision to establish a Platform to tackle the problem of undeclared work in the EU. With the freedom of movement across the EU, it is right that Member States work with one another to tackle those employers perpetrating undeclared work who attempt to hide behind borders. Undeclared work has multiple highly negative consequences: severe exploitation and precarious working and living conditions for millions of workers throughout the Union, grossly unfair competition that is deeply disruptive to the single market, as well as serious losses to the budgets and social security systems of the Member States.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has already acknowledged in previous debates that 'black work' is a common problem in Europe, which not only has a negative impact on workers, but also causes serious deficits and imbalances in public tax revenues and social contributions. Black employment of 15-20% is not uncommon in the Member States either, so a so-called platform could be set up on a proposal from the European Commission to exchange good practices in the Member States and strengthen professional and advocacy work, as this could facilitate reported employment, job security and decision-makers' work in employment policy and economic policy. As you know, one of the most difficult tasks when examining unannounced employment is to establish black work, because in most cases it remains hidden. On the basis of good practice so Hungary has done much in recent years to whiten the economy, e.g. by introducing online cash registers. In addition, the introduction of job protection programmes for hundreds of thousands of people, employment tax incentives and the introduction of new atypical forms of employment (simplified employment, multi-employer employment, etc.) have contributed significantly to the domestic reduction of black employment. The fight against black work is a common cause, but everyone has to do their homework at home and the most effective way to do this is on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the efforts of the EU in order to tackle one of the most complex problems, that of undeclared work. The consequences of undeclared work are highly negative: deprivation of workers of social protection, several health and safety risks, weakening of labour standards. It is important also to underline that the problem of undeclared economy has grown during the economic crisis. The report welcomes the establishment of a European Platform in order to prevent and deter undeclared work more effectively. However, the rapporteur stresses the need to further improve the functioning of the Platform by making wider its scope, by reinforcing its legal instruments and enhancing a better cooperation with all Member States. This is why I voted in favour of this report

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I support the idea of establishing a Platform for Undeclared Work as well as the methods of action contained in the report. Although the debate on the report was dominated by voices on more effective control, I believe that not control and the prevention of undeclared work will be at the heart of the Platform. This is particularly important for the intensively developing domestic work sector, where women, often migrant women, work in the first place and which is difficult to control, as the work takes place on private premises and the employee is also a private individual.  The experience of Belgium and France shows that it could be effective to disseminate and universalise cheque systems to include care, education and care services. Care services are particularly important because they cannot be postponed or abandoned: This is a key barrier to women's access to the labour market and the first reason for driving them into the grey area, as workers and employers.  Finding the right solutions in the form of clear rules, tax facilitations and incentives will not only lead thousands of women out of the grey economy, giving them social protection and a contribution to their pension, but will also help reconcile professional and family roles. This will strengthen the institution of the family and the economic independence of women.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The establishment of a European platform aims to strengthen cooperation between EU countries by bringing together all the police, labour and social security inspectorates involved in the fight against unclaimed work. The platform will provide the legal framework within which to cooperate through the development of effective measures based on enforcement. Another important aspect is the promotion of production in order to counter low levels of growth and deflation.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The European platform proposed to us by the Commission aims to strengthen cooperation to prevent and discourage undeclared work. In practical terms, it must enable information and practices to be shared, to combat illegal work and to have a better grip on its cross-border aspects by facilitating cooperation between administrations of different countries. In the Employment Committee, we have amended this text so that it addresses the problems of the false self-employed, European laws and also non-cooperative national administrations, but also that it works on ways to regularise unreported jobs. I have therefore supported this text. Undercover work is not only a loss of income for states, but it also represents a lack of protection for unreported workers. In addition to the increase in these practices, there are new legal models of exploitation of workers who organize the avoidance of labour law and its taxation. These are all problems against which we need strong measures and the establishment of new European social rights. I have therefore supported this text.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on unreported work. Whatever the good reasons given, namely the fight against social fraud and the decline in tax revenues, the form of cooperation imposed through a "European platform" represents a new interference in the internal affairs of States.  Moreover, it is accepted that it is at national level that the actions to be taken are most relevant, so that cooperation at European level will have only a very marginal impact on this phenomenon, which is constantly increasing in a context of crisis, and of very variable magnitude from one Member State to another.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I believe that the fight against black work is the responsibility of the Member States and not the European Union.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This report is paved with good intentions, namely the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work, the fight against social fraud and the decline in tax revenues. Nevertheless, it marks once again a certain interference in the internal affairs of States.  In times of high unemployment, it is clear that the relevant actions to be taken for employment are being carried out at national level, while coordinated action at European level will have only a marginal impact on this phenomenon. For political reasons (refusal of EU interference in the internal policy of states) and pragmatic (lack of significant impact of such measures), I voted against this report.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I believe that the Commission's proposal to create a European platform against undeclared work is a positive step in the fight against this social and economic problem, which will help to combat one of the economic phenomena of our society which, in the case of Spain, accounts for 20% of GDP, but which in other States can reach 35%. The main victims of this phenomenon are the workers themselves, without security or rights. But it is also a problem for our economy because it distorts the labour market, and a very big problem for public coffers in many of our countries. Among the most relevant elements of this platform, which will bring together the Commission, the social partners and the EU national authorities responsible for combating undeclared work, such as labour inspections and social security authorities, is the inclusion of law enforcement in recruitment, the fact that all States will be part of it and that all social actors will play a leading role in this cooperation. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. Today, the EU has taken a very important step in addressing the many challenges of undeclared work. This seriously harms the European economy, accounting for around 18% of GDP, although in some states it can reach 35% (20% for Spain).  But it not only affects the economy, but poses a serious risk to affected workers as they are often exploited, suffer more dangerous conditions and worse wages, and their labour rights are violated.  The Socialists have led the creation of this platform which aims to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. The platform will deal with all forms of undeclared employment, from false self-employed to fictitious enterprises, combining the efforts of a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States and social actors.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this initiative which I hope will be the first step in creating more incisive measures to combat this scourge of our economy and our society.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 States should fight black labor by cutting taxes and liberalizing the labor market, not by setting up additional offices paid out of taxpayers' pockets.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. In its Resolution of 14 January 2014 on Effective Labour Inspection as a strategy to improve working conditions in Europe, the European Parliament supported the Commission's initiative to establish a platform and called for enhanced cooperation at Union level to address undeclared work.  The grey economy is largely present, representing more than 18 % of the Union's GDP, and its presence among Member States varies considerably, ranging from less than 8% to more than 30 % of GDP. The main objective of the platform is to contribute to the efforts of The Member States and the Union institutions to successfully address the complex problem of undeclared work and the regulation of jobs and their many impacts and consequences, and to encourage and promote the reported work.  I supported Representative Pirinski's report on the fact that undeclared work has serious consequences for workers who have to accept unsafe and sometimes dangerous working conditions, much lower wages and significantly reduced protections provided for in labour and social protection legislation, thereby denying these workers adequate social benefits, pension rights and access to healthcare.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 Through the resolution adopted today by 619 votes to 619, the European Parliament has given its support to the establishment of a European platform in order to strengthen cooperation to prevent and deter undeclared work. It is estimated that undeclared work is causing enormous damage to the Union economy by depriving tax and social security systems of income and payments due. As a result of undeclared work, there is a grey sector of unfair competition that leaves workers without rights and protection. The platform is intended to extend measures to counter undeclared work through enhanced cooperation. The proposed platform option is in line with the principle of subsidiarity and is without prejudice to the competence of Member States to establish national rules. Among the measures envisaged are: improving member states' technical capacity, exchanging good practices and raising public awareness. I am convinced that the new European platform will improve cooperation between public authorities to combat undeclared work.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ Undeclared work damages not only the economy and economy of EU countries, but also, in the form of precarious and unfavourable working conditions, the people themselves who carry out undeclared work.  I support the motion for a resolution and agree that, with regard to the free movement of persons and capital, this problem must be tackled by the joint forces of all the Member States.  A common European platform and coordinated control of undeclared work can contribute more effectively to its detection. They will also help to find and implement targeted proactive measures that eliminate or eliminate interest in such a method of employment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the creation of a European platform to strengthen cooperation to prevent and prevent undeclared work, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 2/2/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. We appreciate finding some good ideas in this text, such as support for learning, alternating training, and tutoring, which we have always supported. But, as usual, the EU is not responding properly to the problem.  If it is clear that policies for the integration of young people into the labour market must be carried out, it is at the regional and local level that we must bet! Public service networks are able to support young people in the transition to employment, in partnership with associations or private organizations, and especially in connection with companies, PMIs/SMEs. As for youth entrepreneurship, it is a recurring idea with limited scope in a particularly difficult economic context, and it is often only an instrument used to "occupy" young people and get them out of the unemployment figures. This is proof of the total failure of Europe's education and training systems, and rather than admitting its limitations, Europe is increasingly demanding from states already weakened by the crisis.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ In its proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on establishing a European Platform, the Commission has given precedence to the enforcement approach aimed at preventing and deterring undeclared work. This envisages enhanced cooperation for ‘combating’ labour law infringements, tax avoidance and breaches of social security requirements – doubtless issues of grave concern in themselves.  However, there is growing realisation that enforcement must be coupled with pro-active enabling policies and measures targeted towards the regularization of jobs that remain undeclared, such as income tax relief, tax reduction and subsidy schemes. The undiminishing practices of undeclared work throughout Member States demonstrate that there is both demand and supply for the jobs involved – hence the need not to suppress, but rather to integrate them into the formal range of rules and regulations of the social market economy.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the report on the establishment of a European platform for strengthening cooperation to prevent and discourage undeclared work. The phenomenon of undeclared work is still a brake on European employment and growth, undermining the financing of social security, reducing tax revenues and also causing social dumping. It is therefore a priority to work as hard as possible to reduce this harmful phenomenon and to commit ourselves to widespread and constant control to combat it.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Undeclared work or false self-work has so far been treated sporadically and uncoordinatedly. In this sense, the creation of a European Platform will provide the necessary means for enhanced and more effective cooperation between States with regard to combating labour law violations, tax evasion and violations of social security requirements. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The undeclared economy accounts for 18% of EU GDP. We must therefore take immediate action on the matter and take measures to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. My support for the proposal to create a European platform to boost the fight against undeclared employment, in order to cooperate with social and economic institutions and actors in order to tackle a problem that harms everyone's economy and distorts the labour market.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The proposed platform is another EU agency that wants to further control European workers. I reject further harassment in the form of increased inspections. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has supported the creation of a European platform to combat undeclared work. This Platform will strengthen cooperation between member states' responsible authorities, trade unions and employers' organisations in the fight against undeclared work in the EU. Undeclared work is a sensitive problem because it distorts the labour market, encourages tax avoidance and puts the worker in a particularly risky situation where he does not have social guarantees. What is even more worrying is that workers often support this phenomenon, as undeclared work is their only chance of receiving higher wages but not necessarily sufficient wages.
