A coordinated approach at EU level to understand and combat the causes of informal work could help to ensure stronger workers' rights and protection, promote funding for social security and strengthen labour standards.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Undeclared work has been defined at EU level since 1998 as "any paid activity of a legal nature, but not reported to the government, [...] taking into account the differences between member states' regulatory systems, which therefore excludes all illegal activities. The report denounces unreported work as a factor of social dumping. He adds, of course, that this "harms the Union's economy, creates unfair competition and distorts the market, endangers the financial viability of the Union's social models". The European Parliament's amendments propose to add the "falsely" declared work, which refers to any paid activity of a legal nature that is not properly declared to the public authorities.  They also propose to focus on a particular form of unreported work: the abuse of self-employment status, at the national level or in cross-border situations. Thus, "self-employment" is false when a person, although meeting the conditions characteristic of a working relationship, is declared as self-employed in order to avoid certain legal or tax obligations. I vote for this text which tackles, albeit timidly, the scam of the status of 'self-employed entrepreneurs'.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The proposed cooperation, while its intentions are laudable, will have only a limited effect. It represents a further breach of the sovereignty of states. I believe that the actions to be taken in the fight against social fraud and the decrease in tax revenues it generates are more relevant at the national level.  If EFDD Amendment 63 had passed I could have supported the text, because it would have left the Member States free not to participate. Therefore I voted against it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution because I believe that all Member States should work together to crack down on undeclared work, which exposes workers to exploitation and undermines the financing of social services.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Undeclared work can be defined as paid activities of a legal nature but not reported to the government. It is still a scourge for European economies today. Indeed, the underground economy within the Union is very present and can reach up to 18% of the Union's GDP. In view of the unfair competition it generates, I think it is essential to point out the negative consequences that can be summed up by losses of jobs, productivity and income for states.  In addition, it hinders compliance with standards of working conditions and I find that women are often the most affected by unreported work. This once again widens the gender gap. Creating a platform to combat undclared work is a first step in the right direction. Cooperation between Member States must be strengthened, and reliable and up-to-date information must be provided. This cooperative work would contribute to a level playing field and would benefit economic actors.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing – Undeclared work carries many risks. I consider poor working conditions, too low earnings and poor social status of illegally employed people to be the most dangerous. Last but not least, widespread undeclared work is signed up to a reduction in expected revenues to the Treasury. In the motion for a resolution tabled, I appreciate well-defined concepts such as 'undeclared work', 'falsely reported work', 'false self-employment', etc., because without a clear definition of the meanings of the concepts, legislation remains toothless and it is not possible to fully implement pre-amended changes. I also consider it positive that this area has been left to the remit of individual Member States. In order to improve the position of thousands of people in illegal employment and also in the interests of the European economy, I support the wording of the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to the establishment of a European Platform to enhance cooperation at EU level for both prevention and deterrence of undeclared work as well as encouraging its transformation into declared work. This report is an important first step towards dealing with the multiple challenges of undeclared work in Europe. The European Platform will operate on the basis of experience and best practice exchange, bringing together a wide range of stakeholders, including representatives of Member States and cross-industry social partners.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has submitted a proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the subject referred to in the title. In its proposal, the Commission voted in favour of an implementation-based approach, proposing increased cooperation in the fight against labour law violations, tax avoidance and social security breaches. However, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs argues in its report that implementation should be paired with proactive, incentive policies and measures aimed at regularisation of undeclared jobs. Such measures may be the introduction of income tax allowances, tax reductions and aid schemes. The fact that the practice of undeclared work in the Member States is not weakening shows that there is a demand for the jobs in question, as well as supply. They should therefore be introduced into the official rules and regulatory framework of the social market economy rather than banning these works, all the more so as production needs to be boosted in order to counter the slow pace of growth and deflation that is currently being experienced. Accordingly, the report proposes that Parliament support the Commission's proposal by adopting more than 60 amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This text proposes strengthening collaboration between Member States in order to promote the transition from unreported work to regularised employment. Whatever the good reasons put forward by this report, namely the fight against social fraud and the decline in tax revenues, this form of imposed cooperation represents a new interference in the internal affairs of States.  Moreover, it is accepted that it is at national level that the actions to be taken are most relevant, so that cooperation at European level will have only a very marginal impact on this phenomenon, which is constantly increasing in a context of crisis.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the establishment of the European Platform to strengthen cooperation in the fight against undeclared work, bearing in view of the impact on the Union economy, creates unfair competition, undermines the financial sustainability of the Union's social models and results in a growing lack of social and labour protection for workers. The "Platform", in addition to combating undeclared work, will also deal with falsely stated work, including false independent work. I support that undeclared work has serious implications for affected workers, who are forced to accept precarious and dangerous working conditions, very low wages, serious violations of their labour rights and considerably reduced protection under labour law and social protection, which deprives them of adequate social benefits, pension rights and access to health care , as well as opportunities for skills development and lifelong learning. I believe that the "Platform" will provide better working conditions, promote integration into the labour market and foster social inclusion. Close and effective cooperation between Member States is essential to combat undeclared work.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Whatever the good reasons given, namely the fight against social fraud and the decline in tax revenues, this form of imposed cooperation represents a new interference in the internal affairs of States.  Moreover, it is accepted that it is at national level that the actions to be taken are most relevant, so that cooperation at European level will have only a very marginal impact on this phenomenon, which is constantly increasing in a context of crisis, and of very variable magnitude from one Member State to another. I am voting against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the EU’s decision to establish a Platform to tackle the problem of undeclared work in the EU. With the freedom of movement across the EU, it is right that Member States work with one another to tackle employers who perpetrate undeclared work and attempt to hide behind borders. Undeclared work has multiple highly negative consequences: severe exploitation and precarious working and living conditions for millions of workers throughout the Union, grossly unfair competition that is deeply disruptive to the single market, as well as serious losses to the budgets and social security systems of Member States. In the UK, undeclared work is estimated to be equivalent to 10 % of GDP.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the fight against undclared work. The aim was to approve the strengthening of the means of cooperation between national authorities against this scourge which seriously harms EU economies and workers. Behind this term of undclared work lie serious situations such as the exploitation of workers, precariousness, unfair competition and heavy losses for states and their social security system.  I am particularly sensitive to the sense of injustice expressed in the face of the progress of this type of work by the vast majority of European citizens who respect the rules. According to a Eurobarometer study in 2013 for the European Commission, unreported work would account for between 15 and 20% of the P.I.B. of the Member States. 50% of respondents consider unreported work to be beneficial to both parties, 40% cite the burden of tax burden and almost 50% cite the difficulty of finding stable employment. I think it is essential to act upstream as well: Member States must relax administrative rules and reduce the burden on businesses to promote declared employment.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. Prevention and combating undeclared work is a priority issue: "undeclared" work has a negative impact not only on competition and public budgets, on employment, productivity, working conditions, but also on combating social exclusion, integrating people excluded from the labour market and developing skills throughout life. That is why I supported the proposal to establish a European platform to prevent and effectively discourage undeclared work and all related cases, such as false self-employment and undeclared work in the context of subcontracting.  Given the cross-border dimension of the challenge we face, it is therefore essential to recognise the need to work towards closer cooperation between EU countries bringing together all police, labour and social security inspectorates, tax authorities and those involved in the field of migration, as well as representatives of employers and workers at European level. The move to a formal mechanism is an important and necessary step in building the legal framework for sharing information and good practice, just as it is important to promote initiatives that raise awareness of the problem at European and national level.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Undeclared work is a problem facing European economies with negative repercussions on the production system and on the sustainability of member countries' social security systems. The employment of employed persons without prior notification of the establishment of an employment relationship by the employer fuels unfair competition between undertakings by not promoting a climate of free and equal competition. For this reason, European states must continue along the path of legalising undeclared work, which today accounts for more than 18% of Europe's GDP. We therefore welcome this report, which aims to create a European platform to combat undeclared work. The platform demonstrates Europe's commitment to citizens' rights by encouraging contractual forms that protect health, safety and compliance with appropriate labour standards. The project provides for more effective cooperation between bodies to combat the black economy and representatives of employers and workers at European level, fill a gap that persists in terms of cooperation and coordination, in order to ensure uniform application of the rules in all countries of the Union.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. Undeclared work must be discouraged and combated. The establishment of a European platform for the cooperation of the competent authorities of the Member States is an important step forward in this area. As such, I voted in favour of an important report that respects the competences of States and the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of a European platform aims to strengthen cooperation between EU Member States by bringing together all the bodies involved in the fight against unclaimed work, tax avoidance and breaches of social security provisions. I believe that undeclared work must be prevented and discouraged, and I therefore voted in favour of the measure.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ In order to successfully tackle the complex issue of undeclared work, we need first to objectively consider its true nature. This consideration reveals that the avoidance of proper registration constitutes the direct cause of a broad range of extremely negative implications and consequences. I have voted for this report that will set out the establishment of a European Platform that will gather and share trustworthy information on best practices and persisting problems and will cooperate in outlining and implementing effective enforcement and enabling measures.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted to step up cooperation in preventing and discouraging undeclared work. The decision adopted in the plenary of the European Parliament aims to establish a European platform to encourage cooperation between Member States at Union level. Since the situation of undeclared work differs greatly from one Member State to another, the needs of the relevant authorities and other actors of the Member States in terms of cooperation also differ.  Close and effective cooperation between Member States should be encouraged at EU level so that they can support each other and complement their activities related to combating undeclared work. The measures adopted at national level depend on the specific context existing in each individual Member State and the activities carried out under the Platform cannot be substituted for a national assessment of the appropriate measures to be taken.  Member States and their relevant authorities shall retain competence in identifying, analysing and addressing practical problems relating to the enforcement of applicable Union legislation on working conditions and social protection at work and in determining the measures to be taken at national level in order to implement the results of the activities carried out within the Platform.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour for establishing a European Platform to directly tackle the multiplex problem of undeclared work by strict prevention and deterrence. Avoiding proper registration comprises the direct cause of the various exceedingly negative implications as well as the consequences associated with it. There must be enforcement accompanied by pro-active enabling policies and certain measures directed towards the regularisation of jobs that remain undeclared. This undeclared work highlights that there is both supply and demand for the jobs involved, which further demonstrates the need to integrate them into the formal range of rules and regulations of the social market economy. Overall, the new European Platform should provide value-added at the Union level to efforts to prevent and deter undeclared work as well as regularize the jobs involved. These pro-active policies come at a time when it is necessary to increase production to counter low growth and deflation. Increased regularisation, as a result, will provide for decent livelihoods and the needed services to customers, all while fairly contributing to market competition and sustainable fiscal stabilisation.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the establishment of a European platform to strengthen cooperation in preventing and deterrence from undeclared work. The proposal for a Council and EP decision is based on a coercive approach foreseeing enhanced cooperation to combat labour law violations, tax avoidance and breaches of social protection requirements. The purpose of the Platform is, in particular, to develop a reliable and effective system for the rapid exchange of information in order to address undeclared work and to improve the ability of national labour inspection systems to carry out checks and address cross-border aspects of undeclared work through measures such as joint operations, the relevant database and the exchange of staff. It is therefore a support instrument complementing existing national instruments, as the fight against illegal employment and entrepreneurship is the primary responsibility of the Member States.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because the European Union wants to commission an additional platform or institution to control the exchange of information between national authorities more effectively. Everyone should be able to intervene as quickly as possible when there is a risk of undeclared work. Since it is not clearly defined how effective this project will be, I am clearly opposed to a waste of further money.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Undeclared work has a number of negative consequences, including reduced taxes, unfair competition between companies, worse working conditions, lower pension rights and poorer access to health care. Although the problems arising from undeclared work are mainly due to the problems of undeclared work, it also has a cross-border impact. In order to enhance cooperation between the authorities dealing with this issue in the Member States, but also at EU level, it is considered necessary to create a platform at EU level, the mechanism that will address this problem. Among other things, I consider it important that the search for solutions also means that women are still underemployed on the European labour market and that efforts must be made to reduce the differences between women and men in terms of participation in employment.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. – Undeclared work is one of the main brakes on growth and employment in Europe, has a negative impact on the financing of social security and is a factor of social dumping that wastes security and rights workers. The creation of this European platform is a fundamental weapon in advancing the end of all of the above and combating illegal practices which, as I said, harm our public coffers and, above all, the weakest link in the chain, workers. I voted in favour of this report in the hope that, through this platform and with the cooperation of this European Parliament, we can help prevent and discourage undeclared work.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. It should be noted that undeclared work is often a cross-border and constantly widening phenomenon with significant negative budgetary implications, employment, as well as distorting social protection systems. Therefore, a common approach to tackling and deterring undeclared work is needed in order to combat and deter undeclared work more effectively and effectively. Eu-wide targeted active policies need to be implemented to prevent the spread of this phenomenon and to increase the effectiveness of controls on illegal work. In particular, joint coordinated action at EU level requires improved cooperation and exchange of best practices between Member States. Measures need to be put in place to help the relevant authorities of the Member States to address cross-border aspects of undeclared work. Particular attention must be paid to the validation of relevant jobs through responsible economic and social policies that reduce incentives for employers and workers to engage in illegal employment.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's proposal on combating undeclared work. Undeclared work tends to be a major problem for the social cohesion of the European Union and any legislative initiative aimed at harmonising controls between the Member States and the Union can only be supported. According to Eurofound data, undeclared work accounts for more than 18% of the Union's Gross Domestic Product. Its area varies considerably between Member States and ranges from less than 8% to over 30% of GDP, while there is a clear gap within the Union between North and South and between East and West. I am certainly also aware of the serious consequences that such a practice can cause to the citizens of the Union, since it is most often linked to the absence of agreements and working conditions.  All of the above indicate that support for legislative initiatives aimed at combating the phenomenon of undeclared work is essential.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation because it will create a taxpayer funded junket for civil servants, national agencies and social partners to wine and dine in Brussels. The platform will produce advice and non-binding guidelines on how to tackle undeclared work. An article in the legislation specifically says that the Commission will reimburse travel and, where appropriate, subsistence expenses for Members, alternates, observers and invited experts. In the original Commission proposal it states: ‘Up to €224 000 per year will be used to reimburse the costs related to participation in the Platform meetings.’ UKIP has no problem with individual countries working together to share best practises and deal with this issue. However, only the elected and accountable national governments should be able to take such decisions – unelected EU bureaucrats have no right to waste taxpayers’ money on such vanity projects.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, unfortunately, undeclared work escapes observation and registration and is defined differently in national law. It is therefore difficult to obtain reliable estimates of the spread of the phenomenon in the Member States. In view of the latest survey, where only 4% of respondents admitted to having done undeclared work, I welcome the establishment of a European platform.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Undeclared work lead to countries missing out on taxes and social security contributions and to distortions in the labour market as it gives people who do not declare their services and goods an unfair advantage. Far from being a minor issue, undeclared work amounted to 18.4 % of the EU’s GDP in 2012. I believe the European platform will improve cooperation and technical capacity between Member States’ enforcement authorities to prevent and deter undeclared work and increase public awareness. Hence, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ Undeclared work is a major problem in all EU Member States that affects at least 10 % of employment capital. Members of the EPP Group, as a solution, support cooperation between Member States and the exchange of best practices in the fight against undeclared work, but not the granting of executive power at EU level to this platform, on a domain which I believe should be kept at Member State level.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒The report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a European platform to improve cooperation on preventing and deterring undeclared work is an important step in the final reckoning with undeclared work in the European Union. In Croatia, in 2014, the grey economy took a toll of €13 billion, or about 28 percent of total GDP (30.4% in 2015), roughly at the level of the average of eastern European countries and well above the 18.5 percent that average in Europe.  About two-thirds of these amounts relate to undeclared work. So the problem is serious and I am happy that its resolution is beginning to be more seriously thought about. The establishment of a platform made up of the most important stakeholders involved in tackling undeclared work or regulating jobs will certainly contribute to better enforcement of Union law and national law. I believe that the platform will improve the exchange of experience and good practices in preventing illegality.  In doing so, account will need to be taken of national specificities and specific situations and dedicated to improving mutual understanding of different national labour inspection systems. I welcome the adoption of this report on the proposal for a decision establishing a European platform and have been happy to support it.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Whatever the good reasons given for the creation of this platform, namely the fight against social fraud and the decline in tax revenues, this form of imposed cooperation represents a new interference in the internal affairs of States. Moreover, it is accepted that it is at national level that the actions to be taken are most relevant, so that cooperation at European level will have only a very marginal impact on this phenomenon, which is constantly increasing in a context of crisis, and of very variable magnitude from one Member State to another.  A European platform would at best be yet another useless structure financed by taxpayers' money, which would be more useful elsewhere, at worst another harmful bureaucracy. I therefore vote against this proposal.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that undeclared work, if not properly combated, profoundly hinders the Union's ability to achieve its objectives of employment, growth and equal opportunities in the labour market. In addition, a common platform can facilitate the transition from informal to formal work, which is an essential condition for re-establishing decent jobs.  Undeclared work in Europe is a worrying reality that is inherently difficult to measure. It is therefore important to address this phenomenon as a common challenge to step up inspections at work and to call for the sharing of good practice. Furthermore, it is a priority to redefine the concept of undeclared work at European level. Many Member States do not have a formal definition of undeclared work in their own legislation, others provide for it in their labour code, in others the meaning of undeclared work takes on various forms depending on the different agencies referred to.  With a view to creating a European platform, the raison d'ion of which is cooperation between states, it is therefore crucial to reformulate this concept and also to ensure that the challenges posed by vulnerable groups, especially women, are integrated into it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒I support this proposal to establish a European platform against undeclared work as a first step in preventing undeclared work that is the cause of multiple losses. For workers, undeclared work includes: lower pension entitlements, limited access to healthcare, poor working conditions and possible violation of employment rights. For companies, it leads to unfair competition because companies that do not report their workers have an unfair advantage. For governments, it represents lost revenue from taxes and social contributions. It is estimated that undeclared work accounts for almost 20% of GDP at EU level, while this number is higher in Croatia. While the fight against undeclared work falls within the competence of Member States, this platform will help exchange information, especially in cross-border cases where it is difficult to identify and sanction undeclared work. As there is currently no EU-wide cooperation between national authorities fighting cross-border undeclared work, the platform will fill this gap.  Equally, I hope that the system of realisation of the rights of registered workers in another Member State will be corrected, which is not always the case until now. For example, Croatian workers, daily migrants working in Slovenia have faced difficulties in realising their rights for years. I hope this question will be on the agenda as soon as possible.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. Undeclared work has repercussions for the financial and ethical structure of states and the workers involved in these schemes are more fragile in their rights. The establishment of strategies to combat the phenomenon is essential and positive. The report neglects to be right-wing policies implemented at national level under the guidance of EU policies, which have contributed to the deregulation of labour legislation, the attack on collective bargaining and the deepening of mechanisms for devaluation and precarious work. Omit that austerity policies have contributed to the increase in situations of work in whole or in part, the false provision of services, false paid internships or false voluntary situations.  There is in the architecture of this Platform a tendency to standardize methodologies and legislation, which makes anticipating greater prevalence of decision at supranational level, compromising national sovereignty.  Combating precariousness and undeclared work can only pass, within the framework of the sovereignty of the Member States, through links that guarantee security and stability, the valorization of collective bargaining, wages and work with rights, that is, the opposite way to what the European Union has been imposing. For the reasons set out above, we abstained.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 Undeclared work accounts for up to 30% of gross domestic product in some Member States of the European Union. Thus, the consequences for state budgets, which subsequently finance the necessary policies, such as education, infrastructure building or employment, cannot be downplayed. Similarly, the consequences of undeclared work for their executors cannot be downplayed. They are often exposed to disproportionate conditions, lower wages and a total lack of social security. I voted in favour of the report on the establishment of a European platform to strengthen cooperation in preventing and deterrence from undeclared work, as these shadow and grey economy activities are unacceptable to both parties. I also supported the european social partners becoming equal partners within the platform and for all The Member States of the European Union to participate, because this problem does not concern only a select few countries. It affects everyone and therefore requires a coordinated approach at European, national and regional level. In this respect, the Platform should act as an optimal place to exchange information and share appropriate national practices. Not only to increase the relatively low economic growth to date, but also to combat deflation, undeclared work needs to be reported as soon as possible, preferably through the introduction of both restrictive and proactive measures.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 When we talk about undeclared work, we are generally talking about paid activities which in themselves would be lawful, but which are not declared to the relevant public authorities or, in the case of fictitious self-employment, are falsely declared. Therefore, the establishment of a European platform providing for enhanced cooperation in the fight against labour law violations, tax avoidance and breaches of social security provisions is undoubtedly the first step towards resolving the multiple implications of undeclared work.  I support the establishment of such a platform and hope that it will be combined with proactive incentive-based measures and policies aimed at promoting the regularisation of jobs that are not declared, such as income tax relief, tax breaks and subsidy schemes. For all these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the creation of a European platform to strengthen cooperation to prevent and discourage undeclared work. Beyond being illegal, unreported work undermines the proper functioning of our society, as it does not contribute to our health and social redistribution systems.  The amount of expenses or administrative complexity is often cited as a justification for moving to unreported work. I myself am fighting against the excessive taxation of work and against the administrative overload that our country unfortunately suffers from, in order to revive growth. But this is another debate, which should not make us forget the figures: undclared work accounts for about 20% of European GDP, sometimes even more in some countries that are not known to break tax records.  Therefore, we must fight against unreported work for the good of our businesses and their law-ad living employees, for the good of our lives—together.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation because it will create a taxpayer funded junket for civil servants, national agencies and social partners to wine and dine in Brussels. The platform will produce advice and non-binding guidelines on how to tackle undeclared work. An article in the legislation specifically says that the Commission will reimburse travel and, where appropriate, subsistence expenses for Members, alternates, observers and invited experts. In the original Commission proposal it states: ‘Up to €224 000 per year will be used to reimburse the costs related to participation in the Platform meetings.’ UKIP has no problem with individual countries working together to share best practises and deal with this issue. However, only the elected and accountable national governments should be able to take such decisions – unelected EU bureaucrats have no right to waste taxpayers’ money on such vanity projects.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Today, the EU has taken a very important step in addressing the many challenges of undeclared work. This seriously harms the European economy, accounting for around 18% of GDP, although in some states it can reach 35% (20% for Spain).  But it not only affects the economy, but poses a serious risk to affected workers as they are often exploited, suffer more dangerous conditions and worse wages, and their labour rights are violated.  The Socialists have led the creation of this platform which aims to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. The platform will deal with all forms of undeclared employment, from false self-employed to fictitious enterprises, combining the efforts of a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States and social actors.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this initiative which I hope will be the first step in creating more incisive measures to combat this scourge of our economy and our society.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Undclared work is a critical issue. Crucial because we are talking about an underground economy that accounts for 18% of European GDP. While the fight against this form of work remains a prerogative of the Member States, it is essential to establish synergies at European level. It was therefore with enthusiasm that I voted in favour of the creation of a platform to contribute to the fight against undclared work. This platform will also have to tackle mailbox companies and fake independents, which we must actively combat to counter social dumping in Europe. It's a first step. It will then be necessary to continue with the establishment of a genuine social Europol which networks the social inspection services of the Member States to exchange their information.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the European platform for cooperation in preventing and deterrence of undeclared work will become a tool to combat undeclared work. It must be stressed that the success of this platform can only depend on EU Member States. Their willingness to share good practices and their willingness to take concrete action together will determine whether this tool will benefit Europe or become another broken system.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. Unreported work and dummy self-employment have serious budgetary implications, as well as serious consequences for employment, productivity, skills development, the right to pensions and adequate social benefits, and the stability of social security systems.  The existence of a cross-border dimension of this type of fraud requires action by the European Union, while no formal structure exists to enable the Member States, in charge of combating undclared work, to cooperate at European level.  Thus, by this resolution Parliament supports and reinforces the Commission's proposal to establish a European platform for cooperation to prevent and discourage undeclared work. This tool, by pooling resources and resources, will enable this problem to be tackled more effectively, while promoting the regularization of the jobs concerned. That is why I supported Georgi Pirinski's report.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the establishment of a European platform to strengthen cooperation in the prevention and decommissioning of undeclared work. Undeclared work is one of the most worrying and complex problems facing the EU today, and urgent action must therefore be taken to mitigate the extremely negative consequences of this, as well as the serious losses to member states' budgets and social security systems. This platform aims to improve cooperation between Member States' authorities to prevent and prevent undeclared work and alert citizens by exchanging best practices, analyses and opinions. As I consider joint action by member states and the social partners, together with other stakeholders (including regional level), to be essential and essential in interaction with the EU institutions and capacities, I voted in favour of this report, as only through a joint and concerted position can a whole dense set of challenges facing the EU in this area be successfully overcome.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this report which calls for the establishment of a European platform to combat undeclared work, i.e. paid activities that are not reported to the public authorities. This type of work has negative consequences such as serious exploitable situations, unfair competition disrupting the internal market or significant losses to Member States' social security systems. A European platform would collect and share reliable information on good practices and persistent problems; it would also develop cooperation in the definition and implementation of effective enforcement of the legislation.  It is essential that actions also take place upstream, including the reduction of administrative and tax rules for our companies in order to boost employment and growth.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has been living in a serious economic crisis for several years: the lack of money, investment and foresight on the part of the main European players has led thousands of people to remain out of work and many other people to have to settle for working in the black economy, in order to earn something. With the report that we have adopted today, the European Parliament has sent a clear message to all those who exploit the work and despair of others: we have launched the establishment of a platform that helps the various realities concerned to be able to work together so that the scourge of unlea good work can be eliminated.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. As regards the creation of a platform to combat undeclared work, we voted in favour of the report submitted by the EMPL Commission with the aim of getting ahead as an amendment to the Commission document.  As positive aspects of the report we highlight the following: - the platform must not only prevent and prevent undeclared work, but also address proactive policies and measures aimed at regularizing undeclared jobs; - we want to explore EU and national tools to address common problems, such as the phenomenon of false self-employed and undeclared work in outsourcing chains; - seeks to include among the tasks the identification of gaps and/or deficiencies of Union legislation; - seeks to strengthen the operational aspects of the platform: strengthen operational cooperation with joint training sessions, staff exchange and joint inspections, as well as improve data exchange between national administrations; - common principles and guidelines for inspections addressing undeclared work are to be developed; - European campaigns and comprehensive regional or European strategies are to be carried out.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. Today, the EU has taken an important first step in addressing the many challenges of undeclared work. With today's law, we are creating a European platform that will operate on the basis of experience and the exchange of best practices. It will bring together a wide range of stakeholders, including representatives of Member States and multidisciplinary social partners.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the introduction of a European platform to combat undeclared work, as it is important to have a body to discuss proven and effective methods of combating undeclared work, thereby creating a constant flow of information between the competent authorities. What is important to me is that we have not agreed on harmonisation of control methods, which might have led to a weakening of best practice. The exchange of control methods is a priority, not the adoption of binding requirements by the Platform.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a decision establishing a European platform to strengthen cooperation in preventing and deterrenting undeclared work, as this is an important step towards addressing the many undeclared labour problems affecting millions of workers in the EU – undignified, even dangerous working conditions, lower wages, the loss of social insurance or social rights in general. I consider the strength of the platform to be that it will involve a wide range of stakeholders, in particular representatives of the Member States and the social partners, and will operate on the basis of an exchange of experience and best practices. I expect the platform to also become a place of enhanced cooperation in order to prepare and implement effective coercive and supportive measures in the field of undeclared work.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The proposal for a platform to strengthen cooperation on the prevention and disincentivation of undeclared work by the Commission in order to provide a stable framework for cooperation and exchange of good practices between States, open to the participation of social actors. We support that work must be all declared and with rights, but the fight against undeclared work should not penalize workers. We believe that a European minimum wage or universal basic income are essential instruments in this fight. But since the proposal is far from establishing a coordinated and binding framework for combating abuses by employers (a problem of undoubted magnitude in Europe after integration into the single market), I abstained.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the establishment of a European platform against undeclared work to prevent, discourage and combat this phenomenon with serious repercussions on working conditions, fair competition, public budgets and social security systems. This new instrument aims to bring together all the police, labour and social security inspectorates and tax authorities involved.  I therefore hope that it will improve knowledge and the exchange of information and practices on combating undeclared work, as well as facilitate its transformation into legal work by promoting the regularisation of undeclared jobs and integrating those excluded from the labour market.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation because it will create a taxpayer funded junket for civil servants, national agencies and social partners to wine and dine in Brussels. The platform will produce advice and non-binding guidelines on how to tackle undeclared work. An article in the legislation specifically says that the Commission will reimburse travel and, where appropriate, subsistence expenses for Members, alternates, observers and invited experts. In the original Commission proposal it states: ‘Up to €224 000 per year will be used to reimburse the costs related to participation in the Platform meetings.’ UKIP has no problem with individual countries working together to share best practises and deal with this issue. However, only the elected and accountable national governments should be able to take such decisions – unelected EU bureaucrats have no right to waste taxpayers’ money on such vanity projects.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Undeclared work has serious implications for the economy of the West Midlands and deprives workers of their basic rights and often puts them in hazardous working conditions. I welcome this decision of the EU to establish a Platform to tackle the problems of undeclared work in the EU. It is right that Member States work with each other to tackle those employers who perpetrate undeclared work and attempt to hide behind borders. In the context of the UK, undeclared work is estimated to be equivalent to 10% of the GDP. Hence, I believe that this package provides a much needed format for such cooperation and addresses the new challenges that the EU faces, such as the labour market integrating the recent influx of refugees.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing \ u2012 In the case of the European Parliament resolution on the establishment of a European platform to strengthen cooperation in the field of preventing and discouraging undeclared work, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution. I welcome this proposal, as the illegal economy and work unfortunately represent a widespread problem for the EU, which we are also facing to a large extent in Slovakia. Undeclared work damages the Union's economy, leads to unfair competition and ultimately harms the very people who are in this form of 'employment'. The platform will aim not only to combat undeclared work, but also to combat the creation of letterbox companies, which I consider to be a key part of the solutions to tax fraud and the fight against corruption.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ undeclared work and illegal employment from my point of view has been a serious economic and societal problem for the EU and its Member States for some time, which is why I supported the resolution for the establishment of a European platform to strengthen cooperation on preventing and discouraging undeclared work. I am glad that the Commission is coming up with measures which, in view of the negative consequences of undeclared work, can help to improve precarious working and living conditions for millions of workers within the Union, unfair competition and serious losses for member states' budgets and social security systems. However, I am convinced that without the joint efforts of the Member States and the social partners, as well as other stakeholders, including at regional level, together with the EU institutions and options, we will not be able to overcome these serious problems and shortcomings. I expect that, on the basis of the platform adopted, the exchange of best practice experience between Member States will be improved, the possibility of providing up-to-date, objective, reliable and comparative data will be strengthened, and cross-border cooperation will also be improved.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the establishment of a European platform to strengthen cooperation in preventing undeclared work. With this resolution, the European Parliament proposes an amendment to the Commission's proposal at first reading. This is the creation of a coordination platform composed of representatives of the national authorities of the Member States, representatives of the Commission and also of the social partners. The European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions (Eurofound), the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work (EU-OSHA) and a representative of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) will also participate. I consider it necessary to strengthen cooperation between Member States at EU level in order to allow Member States to prevent undeclared work more effectively. This should be served by exchanging best practices and information and providing expertise and analysis at EU level between the responsible persons and institutions. Mandatory participation for Member States is proposed for the platform to be effective. I consider it important to have the efficiency and minimum costs that will be incurred on this platform. Undeclared work is a growing phenomenon that has many causes and contexts and has negative effects on the labour market and the revenues of the state budget. Ultimately, it harms both employers and employees.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The report refers to the proposal for a decision establishing a European platform to strengthen cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of black working. It is one of the most worrying and complex problems, as it relates to activities which are, by their very nature, legal but are not registered with public authorities or are incorrectly reported in the case of apparent self-employment.  Working on the black has very serious negative consequences on many segments. It affects workers' rights and social rights, as well as the budget of the municipality, the state, and ultimately the EU budget. I welcome the proposed creation of the platform, but it still has concrete measures to follow.  I believe that there are still many frameworks in which we can properly combat working on the black. As such, I can mention an appropriate tax policy, which should be stimulating and which should not push workers and employers into the working-life relationship.  I also believe that it is necessary to support activities in the areas of active employment policy, social policy and, above all, the updating of data, which will allow access to accurate data on the number of people working on the black. I agree that the proposed platform could provide some basis for the creation of a work programme that fully meets the urgent need for targeted action, which is why I supported the report.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'Today the European Parliament voted on the creation of a European platform for better cooperation in preventing and preventing undeclared work. Undeclared work is a widespread phenomenon in Europe and leads to exploitation of workers and undermining of the economy. It deprives national governments of revenue. It is estimated that 18% of economic activities are involved. It was therefore time for EU Member States to work together to provide a coherent response to the problem. The platform serves to exchange information and good examples between national authorities working in the fields of employment, taxation and migration, but also with the social partners. The importance of labour inspection services and financial support is emphasised. Bogus self-employment is also known as undeclared work. In addition, the link was also made with the EU employment targets and the European semester. Since undeclared work knows no borders, European cooperation is very important. The platform must not become a talking club and must also propose concrete actions. At the urging of the Greens, there will be a specific focus on domestic work and women, who are particularly disadvantaged by working 'in the black'. There is no doubt that this is an important issue and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ We are all part of the labour market, which is why I welcome the strengthening of cooperation on preventing and discouraging undeclared work. It is important to combat unemployment properly, it is about the survival of the economy as a whole, because undeclared work is associated with very negative effects, for example, on workers' rights, their social rights, tax issues, it also has a negative impact on pensions and so on, which in turn has an impact on the budget of the Member States of the European Union. This is the way to promote employment and to better living conditions.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Undeclared work has serious budgeting implications due to reduced tax revenues and social contributions. Strengthening cooperation between Member States at EU level is necessary to help Member States prevent and discourage undeclared work in an effective and effective manner. The objectives of the platform will facilitate the exchange of best practices and information, provide an EU-wide framework for the development of expertise and analysis, improve operational coordination of actions between Member States' implementing authorities.  The Platform should make use of all relevant sources of information, in particular studies, bilateral agreements between Member States and multilateral cooperation projects and create synergies between existing instruments and structures at EU level in order to maximise the objective of deterring and preventing undeclared work, and therefore support the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the EU’s decision to establish a Platform to tackle the problem of undeclared work in the EU. With the freedom of movement across the EU, it is right that Member States work with one another to tackle employers who perpetrate undeclared work and attempt to hide behind borders. Undeclared work has multiple highly negative consequences: severe exploitation and precarious working and living conditions for millions of workers throughout the Union, grossly unfair competition that is deeply disruptive to the single market, as well as serious losses to the budgets and social security systems of Member States. In the UK, undeclared work is estimated to be equivalent to 10 % of GDP.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European platform to strengthen cooperation in preventing and discouraging black working. Working on the black is a major problem for the whole of the European Union: it threatens the economy, creates unfair competition, distorts the market and, last but not least, threatens the financial stability and social security of the European Union.  There are many differences between Member States as regards the definition of work on the black, quantity, patterns, work and nature of the work on the black, so we need measures that take all these differences into account. We need enhanced cooperation on measures against unasuth labour, which must benefit those economic operators who do business fairly and do not use work on the black.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the creation of a European information exchange platform and the strengthening of cooperation between Member States to prevent and prevent undeclared work.  It is the result of a trilogy between the Commission Parliament and the Council, in which it seems that even the Commission has tried to play a constructive role. We voted in favour of the report because, on the one hand, it stresses that the Member States have the first say in cooperation between them, and, on the other hand, the report is sensitive to the social issues of precarious work and social dumping. There are also reports of combating undeclared work, particularly for domestic workers, practices promoted by "postbox" businesses and support for social security.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Undeclared work and the exploitation of the working class in general is not treated with "platforms" especially when they are created by active large capital, who from the outset exploit the masses. In addition, the report includes provisions for illegal immigrants, as well as various benefits for the so-called experts who are planned to staff this platform.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has already acknowledged in previous debates that 'black work' is a common problem in Europe, which not only has a negative impact on workers, but also causes serious deficits and imbalances in public tax revenues and social contributions. Black employment of 15-20% is not uncommon in the Member States either, so a so-called platform could be set up on a proposal from the European Commission to exchange good practices in the Member States and strengthen professional and advocacy work, as this could facilitate reported employment, job security and decision-makers' work in employment policy and economic policy. As you know, one of the most difficult tasks when examining unannounced employment is to establish black work, because in most cases it remains hidden. On the basis of good practice so Hungary has done much in recent years to whiten the economy, e.g. by introducing online cash registers. In addition, the introduction of job protection programmes for hundreds of thousands of people, employment tax incentives and the introduction of new atypical forms of employment (simplified employment, multi-employer employment, etc.) have contributed significantly to the domestic reduction of black employment. The fight against black work is a common cause, but everyone has to do their homework at home and the most effective way to do this is on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the report to be an important and thoroughly structured material, which is why I supported it. I believe that the practice of undeclared work is causing enormous damage to the Member States and, ultimately, to the eu as a whole. This not only causes tax avoidance damage, but also raises personal and systemic social security issues. Unfortunately, there is a high number of undeclared workers in Hungary and the practice of announcing a lower wage on paper. I believe that workers are most vulnerable in this process, as in most cases it is an abuse of employers, made possible by legislative loopholes. During the debate in the European Parliament, I said that a single minimum wage system at EU level could be an effective tool to prevent and eradicate labour fraud! The report includes the "European Platform on Undeclared Work" initiated by the European Commission, in which member states determine the level of participation independently. In my opinion, results can only be achieved through a combination of the active involvement of the Member States and the joint European cooperation. I also believe that, of course, the role of trade unions in the fight against undeclared or announced employment on the paper minimum wage should also be increased.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Undeclared work is a very common phenomenon in Europe, leading to the exploitation of workers, the deprivation of national budgets of significant revenues, persistent market distortions and fair competition rules, thereby undermining the economy of the EU as a whole.  As undeclared work is not limited to the borders of a single country, cooperation within the European Union is all the more important. The establishment of a platform in which all EU Member States will participate can contribute to combating undeclared work and developing a coherent approach to combating undeclared work. The platform being created should therefore lead to the exchange of information and best practices between national institutions such as employment support agencies, tax or immigration authorities, while including economic and social partners.  However, there is no doubt that an in-depth assessment will be necessary of the extent to which such cooperation between the European Commission and the authorities of the Member States serves the objectives set out in the Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council and whether the benefits of such cooperation justify the costs associated with the operation of the Platform.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Undeclared work is a phenomenon that is threatening the European economy and exploiting a large part of the workforce.  Some one in ten European citizens admit to having purchased goods or services obtained from undeclared work, while 4% admit that they have personally received undeclared payments in return for work carried out. For governments, undeclared work threatens tax revenues by putting a strain on the sustainability of social protection systems. The impact on workers is also profound. Unleaded work deprives workers of social protection, puts their health and safety at risk and lowers labour standards.  The Aim of the European Platform is to step up cooperation between Member States and thus to be able to combat unead work more efficiently. That is why we voted in favour.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The phenomenon of undeclared work or so-called 'black work' significantly affects the ECONOMY and Member States' economy. More than 18 % of the Union's GDP and between 8 and 30 % of the Member States' GDP are diverted by this negative phenomenon, which can be seen mainly in the construction sector, but also in the areas of care and cleaning services, private security services, agriculture and tourism. The main effect is unfair competition through tax evasion and the widowing of public budgets of social security taxes. The workers involved are also deprived of social and workplace protection and are vulnerable to poor pay conditions.  In order to remedy the situation, the Commission has decided to set up a European platform to enhance cooperation between Member States and the main actors involved in combating this phenomenon. The Platform, having an advisory role, is to be a forum for discussing solutions to this problem, which is then proposed to the Member States. The major aim of this initiative is to further motivate us to declare the workforce "black" and to prevent the phenomenon. Cross-border cooperation is essential in order to achieve this goal. I therefore support this initiative and believe that this document is an important element in ensuring fairness in the work.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for this text. From the beginning of its eighth Parliament, the European Parliament is called upon to address one of the most complex and worrying problems, namely unreported work. The complexity of the problem arises from its very nature: these are paid activities of a legal nature, but they are not reported to the public authorities or which, in the case of dummy self-employment, are the subject of false statements. I would like to stress that this is a European problem and not just a Greek one, as some seem to believe in our institutions.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on establishing a European Platform to enhance cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work. This report recommended the establishment of a European Platform to enhance the cooperation at Union level in tackling undeclared work. This mean the prevention, deterrence and combating of undeclared work as well as encouraging and promoting declared work. If properly implemented, the overriding objective of the Platform shall be to provide value-added input at Union level to the efforts of Member States and Union institutions to successfully tackle the complex problem of undeclared work and its manifold implications and consequences including encouraging and promoting declared work. The Platform shall, to that end, contribute to an improvement in Union and national law, help to achieve the Union’s employment targets providing a more effective Union framework for employment and workplace health and safety.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. Unreported work is equivalent to 18% of the EU's GDP and affects 8% to 30% of economic activity according to Member States. The financing of our social security is a real scourge that deprives our employees of rights and pushes them to practice their profession in increasingly precarious and degraded conditions.  In order to build the European Union, we must instead converge towards high social standards and the guarantee of the rights of all European workers. Thus, the fight against unreported work is a priority.  I congratulate my Socialist colleague Pirinski on his report which foreshadows the creation of this European platform. Aimed at preventing and discouraging such practices, it will largely include social partners. This platform, which will be attended by all Member States, will have to "prevent, detect and combat unreported work". Its objective will also be an incentive, not just repressive, since it aims to regularize unreported workers.  This is a significant step forward that deserves to be welcomed, let us continue in this direction with a genuine European social agenda. Social Europe in action is what our citizens expect.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the proposal to establish a high-level European platform with the primary objective of combating undeclared work. Regularising undeclared work means improving the situation of thousands of workers in Europe, who are without rights, who are insecure, victims of all kinds of abuse. It is also a question of avoiding endangering social security systems by creating unfair competition between workers, a clear threat to our welfare system, as well as the cause of a reduction in the minimum protections to which every citizen is entitled. The fight against undeclared work must be a priority and it is good that the EU recognises a European dimension to the problem and intends to continue with an open dialogue with civil society, favouring meetings between trade unions and employers.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has already acknowledged in previous debates that 'black work' is a common problem in Europe, which not only has a negative impact on workers, but also causes serious deficits and imbalances in public tax revenues and social contributions. Black employment of 15-20% is not uncommon in the Member States either, so a so-called platform could be set up on a proposal from the European Commission to exchange good practices in the Member States and strengthen professional and advocacy work, as this could facilitate reported employment, job security and decision-makers' work in employment policy and economic policy. As you know, one of the most difficult tasks when examining unannounced employment is to establish black work, because in most cases it remains hidden. On the basis of good practice so Hungary has done much in recent years to whiten the economy, e.g. by introducing online cash registers. In addition, the introduction of job protection programmes for hundreds of thousands of people, employment tax incentives and the introduction of new atypical forms of employment (simplified employment, multi-employer employment, etc.) have contributed significantly to the domestic reduction of black employment. The fight against black work is a common cause, but everyone has to do their homework at home and the most effective way to do this is on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 Among the European Union's objectives in the field of social policy, the report mentioned the promotion of employment and the improvement of living and working conditions. This is a very important statement. Therefore, in order to achieve a comprehensive and effective solution to the problem, in particular with regard to undeclared work, Member States should introduce a specially designed set of actions based on cooperation between all relevant authorities. This cooperation should cover all national authorities and representatives of the social partners. Closer cooperation at EU level is necessary in order to prevent undeclared work that is damaging the EU economy, leads towards unfair competition and market distortions, threatens the financial stability of the EU social model and creates growing gaps in the protection of workers' social protection and employment. With this in mind, the tasks of the European Platform should include increasing the exchange of experience and good practice, providing timely, objective, reliable and comparable information, which will undoubtedly contribute to deepening cross-border cooperation in order to better protect workers. I voted in favour of the report for the following important reasons.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the establishment of a European Platform to Improve Cooperation on Preventing and Deterring Undeclared Work, as I think this is a strong political message as it demonstrates our commitment to combating undeclared work that harms workers, undermines the rule of law and undermines market relations. But I don't think establishing a platform alone will solve anything. We need to understand the causes of not reporting work so that we can approach this problem constructively. I believe that there are those who do not report work because they like to do business on the other side of the law and cheat people and the state, but Croatian experience says that most employers who do not report workers do so because of the intolerable tax burden on wages. We can only drastically reduce the grey economy if we achieve that cheating is no longer worth it. As long as taxes are so high that employers will prefer to pay a penalty instead, our fight for fully legal business across the Union will be unsuccessful.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European platform to strengthen cooperation in preventing and discouraging black work, as working on the black is a problem that member states each face within their own frameworks.  Working on the black is not only an impact on member states' budgets, it is even more so than it has a significant negative impact on the social security of individuals. The objectives of the establishment of the Platform are to improve cooperation between Member States' law enforcement authorities to prevent and deter black work, to improve the technical capacity of Member States to combat cross-border work and to increase public awareness through the exchange of best practices, analyses and opinions.  It is primarily the responsibility of the Member States to combat the work of the blacklist. That remains the case, despite the creation of a platform. It is governments that can mitigate the negative effects, both on the part of employers and on the part of the employees, through a more appropriate policy. Advocating for a reduction in the scale of it would have positive effects, both for the economy and on people's social security.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ According to reliable estimates, in 2015 the average size of the shadow economy of the 28 EU countries was about 18% of GDP. It was much higher in some Eastern and Southern-European countries. For instance, in my native Estonia it was equal to 26%. Importantly, no EU economy is absolutely or almost free from this phenomenon. In the EU undeclared work may have an important cross-border component and therefore it may even compromise the fundamental right to free movement. I believe that the new European Platform is capable to address these complex problems. However, efficiency of the Platform will depend on the Member States, on their ability to be proactively engaged. Participation in the work of the Platform should not depend on decision of national authorities. Therefore, this participation was made obligatory.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. As regards the creation of a platform to combat undeclared work, we voted in favour of the report submitted by the EMPL Commission with the aim of getting ahead as an amendment to the Commission document.  As positive aspects of the report we highlight the following: - the platform must not only prevent and prevent undeclared work, but also address proactive policies and measures aimed at regularizing undeclared jobs; - we want to explore EU and national tools to address common problems, such as the phenomenon of false self-employed and undeclared work in outsourcing chains; - seeks to include among the tasks the identification of gaps and/or deficiencies of Union legislation; - seeks to strengthen the operational aspects of the platform: strengthen operational cooperation with joint training sessions, staff exchange and joint inspections, as well as improve data exchange between national administrations; - common principles and guidelines for inspections addressing undeclared work are to be developed; - European campaigns and comprehensive regional or European strategies are to be carried out.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Taking into account Europe’s fiscal situation, it is clear that one of our challenges for the coming years is to prevent informal or undeclared work from growing, as its existence weakens our welfare systems.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. In principle, the fight against illegal labour remains the responsibility of States, and its effectiveness depends very much on the participation of social partners. The main actions of the platform will be to enable the exchange of information and best practices, monitor actions at the national level, and encourage the training of the staff concerned. Whatever the good reasons given, namely the fight against social fraud and the decline in tax revenues, this form of imposed cooperation represents a new interference in the internal affairs of States. Moreover, it is accepted that it is at national level that the actions to be taken are most relevant, so that cooperation at European level will have only a very marginal impact on this phenomenon, which is constantly increasing in a context of crisis, and of very variable magnitude from one Member State to another. So I voted AGAINST.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. As regards the creation of a platform to combat undeclared work, we voted in favour of the report submitted by the EMPL Commission with the aim of getting ahead as an amendment to the Commission document.  As positive aspects of the report we highlight the following: - the platform must not only prevent and prevent undeclared work, but also address proactive policies and measures aimed at regularizing undeclared jobs; - we want to explore EU and national tools to address common problems, such as the phenomenon of false self-employed and undeclared work in outsourcing chains; - seeks to include among the tasks the identification of gaps and/or deficiencies of Union legislation; - seeks to strengthen the operational aspects of the platform: strengthen operational cooperation with joint training sessions, staff exchange and joint inspections, as well as improve data exchange between national administrations; - common principles and guidelines for inspections addressing undeclared work are to be developed; - European campaigns and comprehensive regional or European strategies are to be carried out.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that undeclared work is a major problem in Europe which needs to be tackled effectively. Undeclared work, which accounted for 18.4 % of the EU’s GDP in 2012, is a problem not only because governments miss out on revenue, but also because workers are also less protected. It is conducive to unfair competition and makes countries miss out on taxes and social security contributions, and at the same time puts workers at a disadvantage. This is why I supported the report’s idea to create a European platform to address the issue: this platform could serve to share best practices and examine information, especially when it involves companies operating in more than one EU country.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. I welcome the establishment of a European platform to promote strengthening cooperation to prevent and prevent undeclared work. Any such initiative aimed at promoting cooperation so that national authorities can combat undeclared work across borders, as well as increase awareness and the need to combat such practices, is positive and necessary for Europe. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. Today, the EU has taken a very important step in addressing the many challenges of undeclared work. This seriously harms the European economy, accounting for around 18% of GDP, although in some states it can reach 35% (20% for Spain).  But it not only affects the economy, but poses a serious risk to affected workers as they are often exploited, suffer more dangerous conditions and worse wages, and their labour rights are violated.  The Socialists have led the creation of this platform which aims to improve working conditions, reduce social security fraud and integrate workers from the submerged economy into the labour market. The platform will deal with all forms of undeclared employment, from false self-employed to fictitious enterprises, combining the efforts of a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States and social actors.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this initiative which I hope will be the first step in creating more incisive measures to combat this scourge of our economy and our society.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of this report on the negotiations between the Council, Commission and Parliament on the issue of undeclared work.
