While freedom of movement has brought many great benefits, in employment, opportunities to travel and link with people all over Europe, one of those benefits should not be the ability to avoid the taxman through undeclared work in other Member States. We need to work at an EU level to tackle this problem. Undeclared work has multiple and highly negative consequences: severe exploitation and precarious working and living conditions for millions of workers throughout the Union, grossly unfair competition that is deeply disruptive to the single market, as well as serious losses to the budgets and social security systems of Member States. In the UK, undeclared work is estimated to be equivalent to 10% of GDP.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'Undeclared work in Europe is a problem because workers are less protected than in the legal circuit. That is why I voted in favour of the creation of a European platform for stepping up cooperation in preventing and preventing undeclared work. Member States should cooperate fully with this platform and thus share best practices and information with each other, especially when it comes to information about companies operating in several Member States at the same time.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Following the adoption in January 2014 of a European Parliament resolution calling for enhanced cooperation in national labour inspections against undclared work, the Commission proposed in April 2014 the creation of a European platform in this area. After several months of negotiations, the European Parliament and the Council have agreed to create this platform. In addition to measures to strengthen cooperation and operational measures between national labour inspections and joint investigations, the platform will also cover fictitious self-employment. However, after the negotiations between the Council and Parliament, States will no longer be obliged, contrary to the Commission's original proposal, to participate in all the activities of the platform and will be able to choose to implement its recommendations. Once again, the Member States refused to build a real social Europe. However, I voted for this report, considering that it was a first step in the fight, at European level, against undclared work which deprives many workers of the most basic social rights in terms of social protection and security.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This Platform aims at greater cooperation between Member States – their structures and authorities of labour supervision, hygiene and safety conditions, financial taxation, foreign services, etc. – sharing information and best practices, developing a common database, principles and methodologies, as well as training actions. This Platform will be coordinated by the Commission. It also provides for the participation of partners, including representatives of employers and workers. However, there is in the architecture of this Platform a tendency to standardize methodologies and legislation, to use data that could call into question the freedoms of individuals, or to prevail the importance of the supranational level decision on national sovereignties. We also question the relevance of a formal structure with these objectives, despite the importance of cooperation in this as in other contexts.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The proposed platform is another EU agency that wants to further control European workers. I reject further harassment in the form of increased inspections. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the European data on undeclared work are worrying, with an average of 18% at EU level. This has negative consequences in many sectors, from safety at work (in particular the construction sector, where there are many black workers) to the inability of these workers to access social shock absorbers. The platform will be a step towards better cooperation between Member States and social partners in the fight against undeclared work.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on the establishment of a European platform to strengthen cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work. I am opposed to the establishment of more European authorities and platforms. Undeclared work is best combated by lower taxes and levies. There is no need for European cooperation on reducing taxes and levies. The platform aims to enable more complete surveillance of citizens and financial flows, and thus fits into the big picture of an EU on its way to becoming a Big Brother that far surpasses the novel. I do not want to participate in any measures whose primary objective is the monitoring and control of citizens, and I have therefore voted against the legislative proposal.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – At EU level, undeclared work is one of the most worrying and complex problems. I voted on the report on the establishment of a European platform to enhance cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work. In its proposal for a decision, the Commission gave priority to a constraint approach aimed at preventing and discouraging undeclared work. This requires enhanced cooperation to 'combat' labour law violations, tax evasion and non-compliance with social security requirements. I welcome the rapporteur's vision, which also highlighted the need for efforts to regularise the jobs in question.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported the legislative decision to create a European platform to strengthen cooperation in preventing and combating undeclared work. Undeclared work, unfortunately, is a reality for millions of citizens in Europe. The long-term objective of this new platform is to improve working conditions and integrate undeclared workers into the labour market. We should all support with all our strength the efforts being made to combat undeclared work through enhanced cooperation.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The main objectives of the European platform for strengthening cooperation in the prevention and disincentive of undeclared work have as its main objectives to improve cooperation between Member States to solve the problem, improving the technical capacity to address undeclared cross-border work and increasing public awareness through exchanges of good practice, analysis and opinion. I support this report, as I am against screen jobs and false self-employed people, which harm the economy and society, which could be reduced by creating incentives for people to declare their jobs. In addition, I share the Commission's position in so far as it respects the principle of subsidiarity and the competences of the Member States.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of creating a European platform to prevent and combat undeclared work and to encourage the regularisation of workers. I think it is important to strengthen cooperation at EU level in order to tackle the many challenges of unlarfaced work as a whole. It goes without saying that this phenomenon is widespread in many sectors and affects millions of workers: people who endure dangerous working conditions and lower wages, often without insurance and the most basic social rights. I would remind you that this work leads to serious disruption of the market, with companies complying with the rules required to face dangerous unfair competition. I will conclude by emphasising the importance of creating a platform that promotes the exchange of experience and good practice. I hope that a wide range of actors will be involved in this process, including representatives of the Member States and multisectoral social partners.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 Undeclared work is currently a very worrying problem, which is why I have decided to support the report on the creation of a European platform to strengthen cooperation in preventing this phenomenon. Undeclared work is damaging the European Union economy, leading to unfair competition and market distortions. I consider it important that experience and best practices be exchanged between Member States in order to combat undeclared work. I fully agree with the need to involve representatives of different levels in the platform, as well as the need for proactive measures accompanying coercive measures.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the establishment of a European platform to strengthen cooperation on preventing and discouraging undeclared work. I believe that the establishment of such a platform will facilitate the exchange of best practices, information and opinions to combat undeclared work. Undeclared work has serious consequences for Member States' budgets, as well as a negative impact on employment, productivity and, in particular, the working conditions of persons employed illegally. Consequently, these persons also have smaller pensions and, unfortunately, often problems with health insurance and health care. Given that the phenomenon of undeclared work is emerging not only in relation to individual Member States, but also has a cross-border impact, a platform that brings together the competent authorities of the Member States within the European Union could make a significant contribution to identifying problems and finding solutions.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The functioning of the employment grey economy is detrimental to economic growth, the security of workers and the stability of the social benefits system. The high level of mobility in the European Union promotes the deepening of this phenomenon, especially in a cross-border context. Strengthening cooperation between national authorities and inspections responsible for monitoring the labour market in different Member States is a necessary and supportive step.  The creation of a platform to improve cooperation on preventing and discouraging undeclared work is intended to develop best practices and joint initiatives to combat this phenomenon more effectively. This form of action will guarantee the independence of national authorities whose competences will not be depleted and will combine the efforts of Member States and the social partners (including workers' and employers' organisations) and international institutions.  The most important tasks of this platform will be to define many phenomena that are perceived differently in different Member States, to ensure a rapid exchange of information on cases of violations of the law and to create a system of incentives for the registration of workers for employers who benefit from undeclared work.  We must bear in mind that the biggest victims of the grey economy are unregistered workers themselves, whose right to limited working time, social benefits or insurance against the consequences of accidents in the workplace cannot be enforced. It is their first and foremost that we must protect them.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council establishing a European Platform to strengthen cooperation in the prevention and decommissioning of undeclared work because it also considers this phenomenon, accentuated by the current crisis, particularly harmful, as austerity measures lead to the resurgence of parallel economies, and also to believe that a coordinated approach at EU level to understand the causes and combat informal work could contribute to strengthening rights and protection of workers, increase social security funding and strengthen labour standards. On the other hand, bearing in mind that underemployment continues to characterise the situation of women in European labour markets, any proposal to contribute to achieving the great target of 75% of employment by 2020 and, even more so, to the goal of full employment, naturally has my support.   Although the EU Platform is aimed at law enforcement authorities, I believe that the needs and consequences for the undeclared worker himself, whether male or female, cannot be ignored, and the authorities should pay particular attention to their working conditions and labour inclusion for all.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a decision establishing a European platform to strengthen cooperation in preventing and discouraging working on the black. I agree that measures are needed to strengthen cooperation at Union level to combat unactional work that threatens the Union economy and leads to unfair competition and market distortions and reduces social and employment protection for workers.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in 2015 the focus on environmental issues was really high. 2015 was the year of COP21, with the world facing the need for greater protection of the environment and nature. This debate must now be followed by a concrete commitment, because it seems that, unfortunately, the biodiversity strategy has failed to date. I welcome my colleague's report, which starts from the deep awareness that biodiversity is a resource, a resource that – I would add – is also economic wealth, but above all social wealth. I would particularly stress the need to protect marine biodiversity and to integrate the natural protection objectives into all Eu ropean Union policies. There can be no blue growth without protecting the biodiversity of our seas. Achieving these objectives also means stimulating growth through support for universities and the study of the conservation of ecosystems, without which the world will be poorer and our health will consequently be more compromised.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, as a Labour MEP I am committed to protecting the EU Nature Directives and will work to ensure that the fitness check is not used as an excuse to water down or weaken legislation. It is imperative that the idea of reducing red tape is not used to mask the cutting of vital environmental protection. The Birds Directive and the Habitat Directive are pieces of legislation which EU citizens care deeply about. As part of the fitness check, a public consultation on the benefits of the directives was launched and over 100 000 citizens from the UK alone spoke up in favour of environmental laws stemming from European cooperation. In Scotland the effect of these laws can be seen clearly by the designation of Natura sites, and these sites help to conserve and protect Scotland’s native wildlife, as well as migratory birds which visit from other Member States. There are an incredible 293 Special Areas of Conservation, and with regard to birds there are 153 Special Areas of Protection. The Habitats and Birds Directives have a large and visible impact in securing biodiversity in Scotland. I therefore support proposals to ensure that the legislation is being implemented correctly and as effectively as possible.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur What is the action of any normal and responsible landlord in his apartment? Regular cleaning, periodic repair, non-mowing of all sorts of cockroaches, rats, not to mention the need to eat food, wash the dishes immediately. While treating a man as earthowner would be too anthropocentric, it is nonetheless in its own way true, so it is very much dependent on us what is happening here and going on in the future, first of all, with the environment, nature and ecology.  In other words, we must not behave like enemies against ourselves, because we have no other home. The current trends unfortunately mean that by the 120th year it will not be possible to achieve effectively the objectives set for the EU biodiversity strategy, the real periodicity and the setting and implementation of intermediate targets, the more rational delivery and use of funding, the most active cooperation between transnational and relationship structures, and the more effective and rational implementation of the common fisheries policy.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I am delighted today that the European Parliament urged Member States not to authorise any new fracking operations in the EU. This call was made on the basis of the precautionary principle and also on the gaps that are identified in EU legislation. We said that we need to take account of the risks and of the negative climate and environmental and biodiversity impacts involved in hydraulic fracturing. Fifty-five percent of the Members of Parliament support that view. And indeed, I have to say I was a little bit surprised to find myself somewhat in conflict with my colleagues in Sligo County Council, which is my own local authority, because yesterday they voted not to ban fracking in their draft development plan, unlike my colleagues in Leitrim County Council. I know it is just a draft plan and perhaps it can be changed. Maybe today’s vote in the European Parliament might have some influence on that outcome.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Mr President! I have today supported the report, for which there was a great deal of support. I have noted that paragraph 68 supports the full examination of the role of large predators and the possible introduction of regulatory measures. Nature is not static, nor should our rules be in this area. The wolf was an endangered predator decades ago, but it's no longer. There is a need for us to allow for national regulation of the wolf here too.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I also supported this draft report because diversity is not only one of the central slogans of the European Union, but undoubtedly biodiversity is the fundamental value of our territory, our continent. It is clear that the strategy has not been very successful so far, and we must realise that biodiversity is not only an economic resource, undoubtedly an ecological one, but that the protection of the environment and the landscape is a fundamental and fundamental value. Biodiversity also unsuitably fulfils its social function. I am not in favour of the rule of law being dominated by a hunch of regulations, too many, we are even talking about a certain atrophy of the law. However, the environment is one of those areas that undoubtedly deserves good regulation, because what we leave to future generations is the legacy, and we can also fight cockroaches and rats, but it is important that they appreciate the legacy of the next generation.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I commend the rapporteur for highlighting that there is an increasing depletion of biodiversity, and this needs to be tackled as a matter of urgency, especially if we are to reach the 2020 targets and also, of course, as a result of the successful COP21 in Paris. It goes without saying that the better our environment is, the better it is for human beings; nevertheless this depletion takes place, some of it unwittingly, unfortunately more of it done perhaps even purposely. So there is a need to bring the public on board to help them to see what can be done and to see the benefits. I know in my own country that wildlife and nature are very important for attracting tourists, so there is an economic benefit. This is very important. I just want to finish by complimenting the Estonian President on his wonderful address here today. Normally such addresses are rather general. His was very specific and therefore very relevant to us.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe in the importance of preserving nature reserves and natural habitats for wildlife in Britain and in Europe. However, we believe that this task should be a national, not European, responsibility, and we will therefore oppose new EU legislation in this area. Nevertheless, we will support all amendments aimed at improving the existing legislation on this issue. We believe that the best people to decide on natural habitats in Britain are the British people. We do not trust the unelected EU Commission to decide on the protection of the environment and animal welfare. The EU has caused irreparable damage with its environmental policy. It has destroyed our fish stocks and caused widespread deforestation with its policy on bio-fuels.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on an input into the review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy. The report contains several important elements; the continuation of the prohibition of some toxic sprays, for example. However, the report also dismisses a revision of the Habitats and Birds Directive and requires common sustainability criteria for forestry. The Habitats Directive needs to be reviewed, not least because it too much governs game management (including wolf hunting). A stance we pressed during the election campaign.  The Birds Directive is from 1979 and the Habitats Directive is from 1992, and which species need protection need to be updated at regular intervals. Some species that need protection receive nothing, and some species that are protected no longer need it. In addition, the Report calls for common criteria for sustainable forestry. But the conditions for forestry in Sweden and Greece, for example, are very different. It does not benefit either the biodiversity of Greek or Swedish forests to transfer more power over forest policy to the EU.  I therefore chose to vote against the report.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Safeguarding biodiversity is a fundamental strategy of the European Union, but even before that it is our duty to future generations who will take our place. The Union's ecosystems are under threat, and to this end we need a more effective integration of biodiversity into other sectoral policies, accompanied by a more targeted use of existing financial instruments. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe in the importance of preserving nature reserves and natural habitats for wildlife in Britain and in Europe. However, we believe that this task should be a national, not European, responsibility, and we will therefore oppose new EU legislation in this area. Nevertheless, we will support all amendments aimed at improving the existing legislation on this issue. We believe that the best people to decide on natural habitats in Britain are the British people. We do not trust the unelected EU Commission to decide on the protection of the environment and animal welfare. The EU has caused irreparable damage with its environmental policy. It has destroyed our fish stocks and caused widespread deforestation with its policy on bio-fuels.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it calls for better implementation of relevant legislation to halt biodiversity loss, mainly the Habitats and Birds Directives, while requiring improvement in the implementation of these policies and giving great attention to the agricultural and forestry sectors. The report also notes that Member States and the Commission should focus on curbing biodiversity loss in Europe, warning that the 2020 targets in this area cannot be achieved unless Member States and the EU actually make a serious bet in this regard.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the mid-term review of the European Union's biodiversity strategy. This consensual text is indeed lightened and does not impose heavy constraints on the Member States. It also encourages respect for the environment and economic development.  This report is therefore commendable, even if I regret that the defence of the vital aspect of the environment for man rooted in his space is absent.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report on the mid-term review of the 2020 biodiversity strategy. Given the very sorry state of biodiversity in Europe we were extremely pleased to see cross-party support for strong demands to protect nature. It is extremely important that the European Parliament has added its voice (with a very large majority) to support the half a million citizens  who have called on the European Commission to protect the Nature Directives – i.e. the Birds and Habitats Directives. It is disappointing that the Commission continues to allow doubt to surround the future of these effective and valuable pieces of legislation which do not need re-opened but require a stronger effort to better implement them. We were particularly pleased to see a call for no new authorisations for hydraulic fracturing operations across Europe given the risks and negative climate, environmental and biodiversity impacts involved in the fracking process.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, on the EU's biodiversity strategy, because its strategy is to check the adequacy of legislation on Nature (birds and habitats). The compromise amendments cover many key issues, including the importance of providing an urgent political priority to achieve the 2020 targets, as well as more information for the general public to raise awareness by adopting a multi-stakeholder approach to ensure the active participation of all stakeholders, including regional and local stakeholders.  We also agreed that farmers should play an important role in preserving biodiversity and we believe that the instruments of the Common Agricultural Policy should encourage farmers to address this issue. The compromises also cover fisheries and the marine environment, invasive alien species, pollinators, wildlife trafficking and deforestation, as well as the importance of research and innovation in this area.  In conclusion, the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats supports fruitful negotiations at Commission level, which has managed to incorporate important points of our group's proposals so that we have a comprehensive approach to biological diversity in agriculture and the environment, as well as the preservation of genetic diversity.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I support this text in favour of biodiversity. It indicates that efforts have been modest and expresses regret over the flexibilities granted to Member States, which have prevented the proper implementation of the biodiversity guidelines. For my part, I regret the argument made in the text of identifying the loss of biodiversity at a financial cost when we should first of all emphasise the importance of human roots and, therefore, the need to preserve their habitat and environment.  However, the whole text is consensual without imposing too heavy demands on Member States and reminds us of the importance of reconciling respect for the environment and economic development, a laudable approach... I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that it is important to protect our wildlife and its habitats. The United Kingdom and my own constituency in the North East is full of beautiful landscapes, unique wildlife and vegetation. I want to preserve it for future generations.  However, the EU environmental policies have caused irreparable damage to our fish stocks, caused great damage to our agriculture industry and caused widespread deforestation. This report uses the 'precautionary principle' to block progress and innovative technology that could possibly help maintain our environment.  I voted against this report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. Biodiversity in the European Union has declined at an alarming rate. That is why I voted in favour of this review. Our environmental protections are the highest in the world, we must defend EU legislation and ensure that it is properly implemented.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Biodiversity, a unique multitude of different ecosystems, habitats, species and families from which man is also an integral part, provides an extremely high net value. Biodiversity is under great pressure, both in Europe and around the world, and species are dying out at crazy speeds. Habitat changes, pollution, overfishing, invasive alien species and climate change are the main causes of biodiversity loss. In 2011, the EU developed a new strategy consisting of six challenges: full implementation of the Birds and Habitats Directives; the maintenance and restoration of ecosystems and their functions; increasing the contribution of agriculture and forestry to maintaining and improving biodiversity; ensuring the sustainable exploitation of fish stocks; combating invasive alien species and a greater EU contribution to changing the trend towards global biodiversity loss. However, the results are not encouraging. In the EU-28, the ecological impact is twice as high as the biological potential. Only 23% of species and 16% of habitats are in good condition. Progress is too limited to achieve the main objective. I agree with the need to show greater political will so that the problem of biodiversity loss is truly a policy priority. Better implementation and supervision of existing legislation are also prerequisites for progress, as are investment in nature and biodiversity.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The mid-term evaluation of the Biodiversity Strategy at Community level highlights a number of interesting and problems related to the application of the strategy and the achievement of its objectives. The reporter mentions that the objectives of the strategy should be met by the Member States by 2020 at the latest, but that in many Member States they have not yet started to incorporate these objectives into the various national policies, let alone achieve the real objectives. One of the main positives of the report is the critical tone not only towards the Member States and the Commission because of inaction and inconsistency, but also against the strategy, which it criticises in some cases for exaggerated expectations and objectives, and sometimes for unilateralism. An important element is that it expects member states, and in particular the Commission, to take greater account of the precautionary principle when authorize the cultivation or marketing of various GMOs. At the same time, there are parts of the report that would lead to the withdrawal of national competence in certain sub-areas, for example by creating a single EU-wide environmental control system, which could also be a pre-ethic for the introduction of a single EU-wide environmental fine. On balance, I considered the report to be eligible.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe in the importance of preserving nature reserves and natural habitats for wildlife in Britain and in Europe. However, we believe that this task should be a national, not European, responsibility, and we will therefore oppose new EU legislation in this area. Nevertheless, we will support all amendments aimed at improving the existing legislation on this issue. We believe that the best people to decide on natural habitats in Britain are the British people. We do not trust the unelected EU Commission to decide on the protection of the environment and animal welfare. The EU has caused irreparable damage with its environmental policy. It has destroyed our fish stocks and caused widespread deforestation with its policy on bio-fuels.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, whose pragmatic approach contrasts with the dogmatism to which eurocrats have become accustomed to us. Indeed, this text repeatedly reminds us of the importance of reconciling respect for the environment with economic development. I regret, however, that the amendments tabled by my group have not been adopted: they nevertheless recalled some of the evidence that eurocrats were highly aware of, in particular the disastrous effects that limitless free trade has on biodiversity.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The mid-term report of the biodiversity programme shows that if it does not redouble its efforts, the European Union will also miss its 2020 meeting. The figures speak for themselves: the ecological footprint of the twenty-eight is twice as large as the Union's biocapacity. Only 23% of species and 16% of habitats can be considered in good condition.  It should be noted, however, that the scientific evidence has shown that nature in Europe would be in much worse shape without the positive effects of the European Union's Birds and Habitats directives. However, the implementation of these directives by Member States is often too slow. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to urgently give priority to action to the achievement of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The rapporteur calls for a multilateral approach and stresses the essential role of national, regional and local actors. It also stresses that funding and increased public awareness of biodiversity protection, as well as increased support in this area, are also essential.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I supported this report because it takes another step towards achieving the objectives of the EU Biodiversity Strategy 2010-2020. The mid-term review shows that biodiversity commitments will hardly be achieved if we continue on the current path.  In this report we propose a number of improvements in order to achieve commitments through the implementation of ambitious legislative proposals rather than continuing with immobility and the decline of existing legislation.   At the same time, we must maintain the high standards of biodiversity and care of nature and the environment without falling into demagoguery and putting scientific and technical criteria before ideological arbitrariness.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of biological diversity is a key factor in maintaining individual well-being. Habitat destruction, changes in consumption and the impact of human activities on the environment pose serious threats to both life and the planet's economy.  In 2011, the European Union adopted a biodiversity strategy which has not yet achieved its expected results. Failure to meet the targets, with an estimated loss of EUR 50 billion per year, led the committee to propose a review. The Demesmaeker report, which I supported with my vote, has effectively highlighted the fact that full implementation and effective funding are the key prerequisites for the success of the Union's biodiversity strategy.  The development of a trans-European network for green infrastructure, the adoption of sustainable solutions for agriculture and the commitment to reducing marine pollution are some of the first measures that must be put into practice together with a commitment to halt the loss of biodiversity even outside protected natural areas.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy because its content reviews each and every six objectives of the Strategy, stressing the need to improve the implementation of all legislation aimed at stopping biodiversity loss, in particular the Habitats Directive and the Birds Directive. It also underlines the need for Member States to make an effort to better integrate environmental legislation into other areas, such as agriculture and forestry.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mr Demesmaeker for his work so that today we could approve this report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy. I supported this report as it stresses, inter alia, the strategic importance of the 'State of Nature' and SOER 2015 reports for the fulfilment of the EU biodiversity objectives.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the mid-term review of the EU's biodiversity strategy notes that efforts in this area have been modest. This reflects the failure of the proper application of the guidelines cross-referenced by this theme ("Habitats", "Birds").  Biodiversity issues are argued by a socio-economic integration of the issue, the loss of biodiversity is then identified at a financial cost.  I regret the fact that the vital aspect of the environment for man in his space is not defended in this text.  On the other hand, the whole text is consensual and is not part of an approach to impose excessive demands on Member States. So I decided to vote for this report

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While the Demesmaeker report proposes solutions that at first sight seem concrete in terms of protecting biodiversity, I do not agree with the basic approach of which it is pervasive. Calling for 'more Europe' in this area too is a nonsense, as EU policies themselves favour the loss of biodiversity, given that they are based on standardisation and 'free movement' on a larger scale, on a multinational scale rather than on the protection of local territories and biodiversity. That is why I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which expresses Parliament's concern about the continued loss of biodiversity and which shows that the targets set for 2020 will not be achieved unless further efforts are made.  The 2011-2020 Strategy sets out six main objectives: the full implementation of the Birds and Habitats Directives; the maintenance and restoration of ecosystems and their services; increasing the contribution of agriculture and forestry to the maintenance and improvement of biodiversity; sustainable use of fishery resources; combating invasive alien species, and strengthening the EU's contribution to preventing biodiversity loss globally.  The report estimates that only considerable progress has been made with respect to the objectives of fisheries and invasive alien species, while in others they are insufficient. It therefore calls on the Commission to submit to Parliament two annual reports explaining the situation, the reasons for non-compliance and the strategy to ensure its future compliance, and calls on both of them to urgently give greater priority to meeting the 2020 targets and greater financial support for biodiversity protection.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has made Parliament express its position on the mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy. Biodiversity, a unique multitude of different ecosystems, habitats, species and families from which man is also inseparable, provides an extremely high net value. Human life depends heavily on biodiversity due to the many valuable ecosystem services: clean air, fresh water, raw materials, plant pollinators and flood protection are just a few of them. Biodiversity is under considerable pressure both globally and in Europe. At crazy speed, species are dying out. It's all about human activity. Habitat changes, pollution, overfishing, invasive alien species and climate change are the main causes of biodiversity loss. In 2011, the EU developed a new strategy to halt the loss of biodiversity and ecosystem services, to restore it as much as possible by 2020 and to reverse the global trend of biodiversity loss. Today we can find that, unless special additional efforts are made, the EU will again fail to implement the agreement by 2020. The numbers are very obvious. In the EU-28, the ecological impact is twice as high as the biological potential. Only 23% of species and 16% of habitats are in good condition. Therefore, greater political will, better implementation and monitoring of existing legislation are prerequisites for progress.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. My colleague Demesmaeker has prepared a comprehensive and high-quality resolution to review the implementation of the EU Biodiversity Strategy. It warns that we are ahead of a major challenge and that there is a possibility that we will not achieve the targets by 2020. We have already failed once with the 2010 strategy, so the Commission has come up with a new strategy that is supposed to be more effective. Biodiversity is unfortunately under severe pressure around the world, including in Europe. Due to the human impact of the species, they are dying out at breakneck speed, habitat modification, pollution, overexploitation, invasive alien species and climate change are the main causes of biodiversity loss, and it is therefore necessary to support such ambitious targets, if we also want to ensure the sustainable functioning of key Earth ecosystems in the future.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The broad participation in the Commission's public consultation on the adequacy of the nature protection directives demonstrates the awareness of European citizens of the importance of biodiversity. The protection of biodiversity also depends on the well-being of the whole of humanity, and it also has an important socio-economic value. Its protection provides real opportunities for development and employment, while moving towards sustainable growth, in line with our objectives and commitments made at international level, in the interests of present and future generations. In line with this, I support this report which, in addition to highlighting the fundamental role of biodiversity and the need for its wider integration into other sectoral policies. As evidenced by the examples from some best practices, where implemented, the full implementation of the Habitats and Birds Directives has led to important results, demonstrating that effective implementation of existing directives can lead us to achieve the objectives set for 2020.  We must therefore continue along the path outlined in the existing directives and ensure that the instruments we have available today are actually deployed.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Biodiversity, which is a unique blend of ecosystems, habitats, species and genes on Earth, has enormous value in itself that needs to be protected for the benefit of future generations. This is why we need to be concerned about the continuing loss of biodiversity in Europe. Nevertheless, scientific evidence suggests that European nature would be in much worse shape if not for the positive impacts of eu bird and habitat directives. In conclusion, I support this report and the revision of the biodiversity strategy.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I regret that this report partly attributes the modest biodiversity performance to the flexibilities granted to Member States and that it attempts to reduce the issue of biodiversity to a financial matter. Nevertheless, I welcome the fact that he stresses the need to reconcile respect for the environment with the need for development, which is very important to me. So I voted for this report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the defence of biodiversity is one of the Eu ropean Union's priorities and that it is the task of the European institutions to ensure that the objectives set out in the EU Biodiversity Strategy for 2020 are met. The economic and social cost of biodiversity loss is too great for the Eu ropean Union and the Member States to overlook its effects.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report on the mid-term review of the European Union's biodiversity strategy finds that the efforts of Member States are relatively modest mainly because of the flexibilities granted to them. They have, in fact, limited the proper application of the European directives. While it is regrettable that the issue of biodiversity is being dealt with in a financial way, we appreciate the rapporteur's emphasis on reconciling respect for the environment and economic development. It is indeed essential not to impose excessive demands on Member States, as they are already suffering from environmental dumping by emerging countries and the United States. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Biodiversity is currently under enormous pressure, both globally and in Europe. Species are disappearing at an alarming rate, which is caused by numerous human activities. Habitat change, pollution, overexploitation, invasive alien species and climate change are the main causes of biodiversity decline. Unfortunately, only 23% of species and 16% of habitats are in good condition; thus, in a not too distant time frame, we may be in the presence of an unmanageable situation. In these circumstances, I believe that greater political will is needed to effectively address the current state of biodiversity as a political priority. We need multilateral involvement, in which local and regional actors play a special role. At the same time, the worrying situation of biodiversity generates devastating economic costs for society, which have so far not been sufficiently integrated into economic and other policies. In a smart, sustainable and inclusive Europe, nature must be central to the central position, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. Some of these proposals appear, rather than "concrete", dictated by an ideological approach or in the name of ecological alarmism that often and willingly resonates in politically correct living room discussions. It is contradictory to call for 'more Europe' in this area too, when EU policies themselves favour the loss of biodiversity, as they are based on standardisation and 'free movement' on a larger scale, on a multinational scale. Moreover, under austerity, even if the Member States do not want to be able to allocate sufficient financial resources to implement the necessary actions.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 Because the EU's efforts to halt the decline of biodiversity in 2010 failed, a new strategy was developed in 2011, developed around six objectives, each with its specific actions: (1) the full implementation of the Habitats and Birds Directives (nature directives); (2) the maintenance and restoration of ecosystems and ecosystem services; (3) increasing the contribution of agriculture and forestry to maintaining and improving biodiversity; (4) ensuring the sustainable use of fish stocks; (5) combating invasive alien species and (6) increasing the EU's contribution to avoiding the decline of biodiversity worldwide. The mid-term assessment (2015) makes it clear that we are still far from half the established route and that, without significant additional efforts, the EU will also miss the agreed targets in 2020. I support the EP resolution motion on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy, with the belief that biodiversity and nature must be central to an innovative, sustainable and inclusive Europe. At the same time, I consider it necessary for the elites to address the decline of biodiversity as a political priority, with the involvement of more stakeholders and the provision of a special role for local and regional actors important.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Parliament spoke following the mid-term review of the EU's biodiversity strategy.  I voted in favour of this balanced report, which aims to fully implement the nature guidelines and support the European Biodiversity Strategy for 2020.  It is important to remember that nature conservation and economic development are not mutually exclusive: the loss of biodiversity is detrimental to nature, man and the economy. To combat biodiversity loss, the European Union must be able to measure the state of biodiversity with scientific indicators.  This is one of the prerequisites for achieving the strategy's 2020 objectives. It is important that the agricultural and forestry sectors participate in achieving the objectives, which is why this report proposes a multilateral and participatory approach.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy, on the basis of the following considerations: – biodiversity is a threatened human resource and in a precarious balance, to the point that its compromise is estimated to be among the ten most serious global risks to ecosystems and to the resilience of the earth. , an inescapable "system" resource to address the necessary environmental sustainability challenges; - the planned strategy of the six objectives is complex and still a long way from being achieved. It must be noted, with regret, that only for two objectives are there visible positive aspects (for fishing and invasive alien species) and at this rate, unfortunately, no satisfactory results will be achieved by 2020, even if they are minimal, and in particular for two key sectors, agriculture and forestry. It follows that, in the final analysis, we need more political will and a multi-stakeholder approach, with the development of a greater ecological awareness on the part of regional and local actors, who together contribute to developing an ecological footprint twice that of sustainable.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe in the importance of preserving nature reserves and natural habitats for wildlife in Britain and in Europe. However, we believe that this task should be a national, not European, responsibility, and we will therefore oppose new EU legislation in this area. Nevertheless, we will support all amendments aimed at improving the existing legislation on this issue. We believe that the best people to decide on natural habitats in Britain are the British people. We do not trust the unelected EU Commission to decide on the protection of the environment and animal welfare. The EU has caused irreparable damage with its environmental policy. It has destroyed our fish stocks and caused widespread deforestation with its policy on bio-fuels.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report expresses Parliament's position on the intention expressed by the Commission and the Council to improve the implementation of biodiversity directives and to proceed with a more effective integration of biodiversity into other sectoral policies. I voted in favour of this report because it reiterates the need not to amend the directives on the protection of biodiversity, but rather to improve their implementation. In fact, I am of the opinion that the legislative instruments currently in force, if well implemented, can lead to much more positive results than those achieved since 2011.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ We need stronger, not weaker, Nature Directives and these should be better implemented, not revised. This is especially important as the European Commission are undertaking a ‘fitness test’ of the Birds and Habitats Directive. The assumption being that these directives are too restrictive. The European Parliament’s mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity strategy stated that the 2020 biodiversity targets will not be achieved without additional efforts, while existing EU Nature Directives should be better implemented instead of being revised; and that missing its biodiversity goals would cost the EU an estimated 50 billion a year. Food production and tourism are two major contributors to Ireland’s economy, and these are linked to nature and our clean green image. It would be unthinkable that we do not protect the very thing that makes our country so attractive.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Pollution, over-exploitation of natural resources, climate change, land use changes and deforestation are among the main factors causing the loss of biodiversity in Europe with harmful repercussions for the survival of species.  As early as 2010, Europe failed to achieve the agreed targets. Therefore, new and substantial efforts will be needed to restore ecosystems by 2020. Today, only 17% of habitats and species in the EU and 11% of the main ecosystems protected by European legislation enjoy a satisfactory conservation status. This means that the Natura 2000 network and the Habitats and Birds Directives, where implemented, have brought the desired results, but it is still too little compared to the speed with which we are witnessing the loss of biodiversity.  We need a change of pace and a greater commitment on the part of the Member States, especially to the application of existing legislation. However, if these efforts are not accompanied by a more resource-efficient economy that is more adaptable to climate change and low carbon emissions, the EU risks failing to achieve its 2020 target. I agree with the content of the report and call on all public and private actors to play an active role in safeguarding our planet.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that biodiversity loss is a loss for nature, for people and for the economy. We agree with the position of the rapporteur, who calls for a stronger political will to tackle biodiversity loss as a priority and considers it necessary to take a more comprehensive approach where regional and local actors play a particular role. Improved implementation and improved monitoring of the implementation of existing legislation are key words in achieving progress.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy is part of our discussion and activities on the environment. It is a common secret that we need to take immediate action and initiatives to protect the environment. Therefore, any such proposal is important and we must welcome it positively. I have therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Mid-Term Review of the Biodiversity Strategy as I believe that the enormous intrinsic value of biodiversity must be protected for the benefit of future generations. Biodiversity offers benefits for human health and makes a contribution of great social and economic value. In the vote on the amendments, however, I decided to depart from my group's position: in particular, I voted in favour of Amendment No 81, Part 2, in order to maintain the ban on the use of neonicotinoids; I voted in favour of Amendment No 82 in order to apply the precautionary principle in full when authorised the use and release into the environment of GMOs; finally, I voted in favour of Amendment No 88 because it is contrary to the use of the practice of fracking, which is a product of natural resources.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 We all agree that biodiversity is a value. However, being a value for all, like everything that is public, it risks not being a value for anyone: the farmer who has to cultivate one species and not another in one area in order to protect biodiversity must have a convenience or, most likely, only for the principle he could decide not to do so. It is a classic case of the public good that the public must pursue, including by putting in place appropriate financial instruments, which encourage people to go in the direction that is convenient for everyone rather than in the direction that is only convenient for a few. I congratulate the drafter of the report who has been able to highlight these aspects, on which I voted in favour.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe in the importance of preserving nature reserves and natural habitats for wildlife in Britain and in Europe. However, we believe that this task should be a national, not European, responsibility, and we will therefore oppose new EU legislation in this area. Nevertheless, we will support all amendments aimed at improving the existing legislation on this issue. We believe that the best people to decide on natural habitats in Britain are the British people. We do not trust the unelected EU Commission to decide on the protection of the environment and animal welfare. The EU has caused irreparable damage with its environmental policy. It has destroyed our fish stocks and caused widespread deforestation with its policy on bio-fuels.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The European objective of ending biodiversity loss was not met in 2010. The EU responded by drawing up a new strategy in 2011, with heads of state and government set as a central objective to end biodiversity loss and deterioration of ecosystem services, restore them as far as possible by 2020 and increase EU efforts to prevent global biodiversity degradation. According to the 2015 figures, we are far from achieving the proposed objectives, and political will is needed to put biodiversity as a priority on the agenda. I support the Demesmaeker Report, as It considers that further measures are needed to protect biodiversity by building a smart, sustainable Europe with environmental concerns, and Member States should be more effective in implementing European environmental legislation.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because, unfortunately, the mid-term review shows that we are still a long way from achieving the 2020 targets set. We must continue to make joint efforts to restore our ecosystems and also to protect biodiversity in the outermost regions and in the overseas countries and territories. I am convinced that we will only assume our responsibilities with strong commitment and sustained efforts. Words must be translated into action. The legal basis exists and does not need to be improved, but instead we must all pull together.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe in the importance of preserving nature reserves and natural habitats for wildlife in Britain and in Europe. However, we believe that this task should be a national, not European, responsibility, and we will therefore oppose new EU legislation in this area. Nevertheless, we will support all amendments aimed at improving the existing legislation on this issue. We believe that the best people to decide on natural habitats in Britain are the British people. We do not trust the unelected EU Commission to decide on the protection of the environment and animal welfare. The EU has caused irreparable damage with its environmental policy. It has destroyed our fish stocks and caused widespread deforestation with its policy on bio-fuels.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 On the report on the mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy, I voted in favour because I think it would be useful to draw attention to this issue and to pause for a moment to see, on the one hand, the progress made and, on the other, the objectives still to be achieved.  The protection of biodiversity is important for the maintenance of ecosystems, which are increasingly at risk, not to mention the fact that the projects already in place to ensure this protection have helped to create significant economic returns in the designated areas.  However, I would like to stress the need to maintain the ban on the use of neonicotinoid pesticides as their use is increasingly frequent, despite the fact that an increasing number of scientific studies reveal their possible negative effect on biodiversity, starting with the essential condition for the prosperity of natural habitats, such as pollination.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Biodiversity has an overwhelming intrinsic value that ensures a safe and healthy environment for future generations, benefiting also human health.  When we read scientific research which indicates the woes caused to our health because we have not cared enough for biodiversity and our environment, this in itself is sufficient reason to fully support this report.  For those who are somewhat reluctant to accept the benefits of having strong environmental laws, it is good to point out that the economic opportunity cost of missing the biodiversity headline target is estimated to be EUR 50 billion a year! Everyone is a stakeholder in environmental and biodiversity protection, be it private individuals, private enterprise or governments. I have thus voted in favour of the report.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. \u2012 Biodiversity is important. Today, however, we voted against the European Parliament's input into the review of the EU's biodiversity strategy. The reason is that a revision of the Habitats and Birds Directive is being rejected and common sustainability criteria for forestry are required. Nature is changing and therefore we must be prepared to revise our legislation in order to better reflect the current reality. Only then can we ensure biodiversity and sustainable management of the game population. The Birds Directive is from 1979 and the Habitats Directive is from 1992, and which species need protection need to be updated at regular intervals. Some species that need protection receive nothing, and some species that are protected no longer need it. The European Parliament also calls for common criteria for sustainable forestry. But the conditions for forestry in Sweden and Greece, for example, are very different. It does not benefit either the biodiversity of Greek or Swedish forests to transfer more power over forest policy to the EU.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has published (10/2015) a report on "The mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy up to 2020", which assesses the results achieved since 2011, the date of adoption of the Strategy, in the implementation of the actions and in the implementation of the planned targets. Overall, there is no significant progress on the key objective of 'halting biodiversity loss and ecosystem degradation in the European Union (EU) by 2020,' according to the report. Last December the Council agreed to improve the implementation of the sectoral directives (Habitats Directive and Birds Directive); a more effective integration of biodiversity into other sectoral policies, in particular the common agricultural policy (CAP), a more targeted use of existing financial instruments; greater attention to international strategies; the urgent need to raise awareness and involve all sectors of society and all levels of government; greater exploitation, including economic, of ecosystem services. The rapporteur has strongly emphasised the need not to amend the Habitats Directives and the others relating to protection for biodiversity, as these where well implemented give positive results. I regard it as a good report, so I am voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it calls for better implementation of relevant legislation to halt biodiversity loss, mainly the Habitats and Birds Directives, while requiring improvement in the implementation of these policies and giving great attention to the agricultural and forestry sectors. The report also notes that Member States and the Commission should focus on curbing biodiversity loss in Europe, warning that the 2020 targets in this area cannot be achieved unless Member States and the EU actually make a serious bet in this regard.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Biodiversity is an absolute value for our planet, but it is constantly at risk due to human activities and the low impact of the initiatives taken. This is certainly environmental, but also economic, if we calculate that failure to achieve the targets costs Europe around EUR 50 billion per year, while one in six jobs depends, in various ways, on the environment.  The implementation of the biodiversity strategy (drawn up in 2011) is proving to be a failure: according to the European Commission, no real progress has been made and the degradation of the system seems to be an unstoppable process. In particular, while results are being achieved in the fight against invasive alien species, the contribution of agriculture and forestry to the protection and restoration of biodiversity has so far been virtually nil.  We need to make up for it quickly; there is no need for revisions of the directives on the environment and nature, but efforts to achieve them must be supported. In particular, synergies with the Union's development policies must be strengthened, particularly in the field of agriculture, by removing the barriers that have prevented the CAP and other initiatives from better meeting environmental needs.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. – The loss of biodiversity has a negative impact on nature and man, undermining the earth's natural resilience. The main causes of the decline are habitat change, pollution, over-exploitation of resources, invasive alien species and climate change. Efforts to halt biodiversity loss failed in 2010. The EU developed a new strategy in 2011. In 2020, the EU will again not be able to meet its targets. The ecological footprint of the EU-28 is twice as large as Europe's biological capacity. I agree with the report that more political will and the management of biodiversity conservation as a political priority are needed in order to achieve concrete results. This issue affects us all and future generations even more, which is why it is important to involve as many stakeholders as possible, including regional and local actors. Full implementation of the existing nature directives, the Birds directive and the Habitats Directive is essential for the implementation of the whole biodiversity strategy. It is thanks to the directives that the EU has a unique network such as Natura 2000. In order to avoid a biodiversity-threatening amendment to the Directive, further innovative solutions are needed. A growing number of conscious European citizens see and consider it important to take steps to preserve diversity. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report notes with concern the general trend towards biodiversity loss and calls on the Commission and the Member States to give this issue political priority in order to achieve its 2020 targets. The proposed measures should include the integration of biodiversity into other policy areas such as agriculture and forestry, an increase in the number of Natura 2000 sites with management plans and an EU action plan on wildlife trade.  It should be noted here that environmental policy and economic development are not mutually exclusive, with the alternative socio-economic cost of not meeting the 2020 targets estimated at EUR 50 billion per year and one in six jobs in the EU being somewhat dependent on nature and biodiversity. With this in mind, I voted in favour of the relevant document.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Biological diversity is key to our well-being and economy, but indicators show that it is under threat, mainly as a result of human activity. Parliament’s report, which I supported, expresses concern about the continuing loss of biodiversity and underlines that the full implementation of the Nature Directives and adequate financing are vital prerequisites for the success of the strategy. It highlights the need for policy coherence, in particular between biodiversity protection and agriculture and forestry, and urges the Commission and Member States to redirect financial resources under the common agricultural policy from environmentally harmful activities to sustainable agricultural practices.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I support the push to halt the loss of biodiversity by 2020, especially the efforts to restore ecosystems in so far as is feasible, which both benefits the landscape and helps protect endangered species. I welcome the opposition in this report to any revision of the Nature Directives and its focus instead on better enforcement and improved guidelines. There were a number of elements introduced into this report at committee stage which I think are unwise, particularly on the budget and CAP policy, and my group has roll-called these to show our opposition to them, but overall I welcome the direction of this report.

name: Seb DANCE
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs are committed to protecting the EU nature directives and will work to ensure that the Commission’s fitness check is not used as an excuse to water down or weaken the legislation, and we call on the Commission not to reopen or revise the Birds and Habitats Directives, but to step up efforts to help Member States’ implementation. For this reason, Labour MEPs voted in favour of the Environment Committee’s report on the Mid-term Review of the EU’s Biodiversity Strategy.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully agree with the rapporteur's argument that biodiversity must be protected for its enormous intrinsic value and in order to keep our planet as intact as possible for future generations. I believe that investments in nature and biodiversity offer opportunities that are useful and necessary from a socio-economic point of view, and that is why I believe that we need to change our thinking about biodiversity.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This strategic initiative report provides Parliament's contribution to the European Commission's mid-term review of the EU's biodiversity strategy (habitat and bird directives). The report notes a general loss of biodiversity.  In unison, we opposed the reopening of the texts, which would lead to a weakening of legislation and damaging legal instability. Member States need to pay more attention to the implementation of existing rules to achieve the 2020 targets.  I am particularly committed to this issue so that the European Commission can adapt to large predators (e.g. wolves) in order to preserve livestock in mountainous areas. I also felt it was essential to call for better integration of local and regional actors, including farmers, to define a coherent biodiversity policy, which takes into account the activities of socio-economic actors and the particularities of the territories. Considering that this report sends a clear message to the European Commission with recommendations that go in the right direction, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this vote, the European Parliament wished to reiterate its commitment and support for a strong European Union strategy for biodiversity.  At a time when our biodiversity is highly threatened by pollution and climate change, the European Union and its Member States must show more political will by setting ambitious targets. In particular, it is relevant to stress the importance of innovation, research and development in achieving these goals.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – The EU Birds and Habitats Directives have contributed significantly to protecting nature in Europe. However, the mid—term review shows that the Union is about to seriously fail in achieving its biodiversity targets if no improvements are made. This resolution calls for a stepping up of efforts for the protection of biodiversity in the upcoming mid-term review, and for these reasons I support the general aim of this resolution.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Eurobarometer biodiversity survey, at least eight out of ten citizens in the EU consider the effects of biodiversity loss to be serious. The report on the mid-term review of the Eu ropean Union biodiversity strategy shows that much remains to be done to achieve the intermediate objectives in this field. My vote in favour is primarily intended to encourage this path to be speeded up and for the Commission and the competent authorities of the Member States to cooperate also through the exchange of best practices in safeguarding a fundamental asset.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Biodiversity is essential not only to the functioning of ecosystems but also to preserve air and water quality and promote pollination. The European Union has set itself the goal of halting biodiversity loss and restoring ecosystem-related services by 2020.  That is why it is important for Member States to better implement the European 'habitats' and 'birds' directives and for the EU to increase funding for biodiversity and to take action that strengthens the coherence between its agricultural, energy and environmental policies. Finally, effective and proportionate sanctions must be put in place in the event of non-compliance with EUROPEAN conservation directives.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the DEMESMAEKER report on the mid-term review of the European Union's biodiversity strategy. The report makes an urgent appeal to the European Commission and Member States to set priorities to slow the loss of Europe's biodiversity.  Through this vote I support the integration of local and regional actors in the definition of biodiversity protection policies. I also think it is important to take into account the particularities of the territories in order to respect local activities. I have also raised the issue of the protection of large predators who threaten livestock in mountainous areas.  With regard to neonicotinoid pesticides, the Report makes a fair observation: this type of pesticide is problematic and there is a moratorium on three pesticides of this type. However, a general ban on the use of neonicotinoids is problematic especially in the absence of an alternative for our farmers. In addition, I voted against the GMO paragraph, which is not consistent with the French positions. If we ban the cultivation of GMOs, we import them.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. This report sheds important light on how far we have come in protecting biodiversity and the work that still needs to be done to stop the extinction of plant and animal species. In this roadmap, agriculture and forestry have an important role to play.  At a time when biodiversity is under great pressure at the global level, extensive agriculture must be preserved. The diversity of plant species and varieties traditionally cultivated by small and medium-sized agriculture and family farming is crucial both to meet different needs and uses of rural communities, and to reduce the vulnerability of crops to adverse climatic conditions, pests and diseases.  On the global front, the report stresses that the 2020 targets will not be met without sustained and additional efforts on the part of Member States, while noting the positive impact of the bird and habitat directives on the degradation of nature.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported the recommendations to achieve the objectives set out in the EU Biodiversity Strategy 2010-2020. The EU has the strictest environmental protection legislation in the world. When properly implemented, this legislation has achieved excellent results, but the mid-term review nevertheless shows that the EU is on the verge of failing to achieve its biodiversity targets if no improvement is made.  Biodiversity losses have increased at an alarming rate: more than three-quarters of important natural habitats are in critical condition and a quarter of all species are threatened with extinction. It is our duty to work to protect our biodiversity in Europe for future generations. I therefore supported the system requiring a redoubling of efforts to protect our biodiversity.

name: Jørn DOHRMANN
text: Written. (u2012 Thank you to my good colleague, Sir. I would like to thank mr Demesmaeker for his work on the report on the safeguarding of biodiversity in the European Union, which I am voting for. The Commission's own assessment of the state of biodiversity in the EU is disheartening, which is why it is important that further attention be paid to this issue. However, it is also important that this is done in a balanced manner. I welcome the rapporteur's observation that agriculture contributes to biodiversity, which is a hugely important point to make. I am also pleased with the report's insistence that the Commission should take the lead in drawing up a detailed list of invasive species. At present, for example, the list does not include the dachshund, which is a species we struggle a lot with in Denmark and which does great damage to nature there. When we talk about biodiversity, the diversity of national challenges should also be reflected in such a list.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The protection of biodiversity naturally calls for vital, human and ethical considerations. It is regrettable that this text reflects more of an economic and financial approach to the subject. Nevertheless, it is consensual and based on a pragmatic vision.  This review reveals that efforts to promote biodiversity have been modest, but it is desirable to take economic development into account in all environmental issues. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 It is clear that we always set higher goals than those we are really capable of achieving. I also hope that in this important aspect, namely the protection of biodiversity, things will be like this.  Unfortunately, the EU is once again one of the leaders in this direction around the world. That is why we need to show the rest of the world a good example of how things should be done.  I support this report, although progress on the objectives set is going poorly, and I am aware that this is largely due to local governments, but we need to use the levers the Union gives us to get them to implement the measures at stake.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote in favour, environmental protection is a primary objective for us, our positions and ideology allow us to do nothing but assist every effort to protect Nature.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on 'The Mid-Term Review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy until 2020', as it assesses the results achieved since 2011, the date of adoption of the Strategy, in the implementation of actions and in the implementation of the targets set. I hope that all the objectives of the strategy will be achieved.  I am, however, well aware that the medium-term relationship is far from approaching the 6 targets targeted in 2020, especially with regard to the key objective of 'halting the loss of biodiversity and the degradation of ecosystems in the EU by 2020'. This is due to the failure to implement the Habitats Directive and the Birds Directive, which are not properly implemented by the Member States. The Member States must understand the importance of protecting biodiversity and must protect it, not by reviewing but simply by implementing the rules that already exist to protect it.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. "Overall, a good report dealing with ecosystem services and its role in nature, the economy and society. For example, antibiotic resistance is mentioned as a future challenge.  The Species and Habitats Directive regulates to some extent the wolf population, and it is deeply unfortunate that this report is opposed to a revision of the legislation. However, there are wordings that the Commission must review what should apply when adapting the Species and Habitats Directive to, for example, economic and regional conditions. We see that the need to control our wolf population is part of our special circumstances. I would have preferred other wordings in paragraphs 65 and 66 which would be more open to a review so that regional considerations can be secured.
