The report contains wordings on sustainability criteria for biomass and forest management. Its importance will depend entirely on its design and it is important that these do not disadvantage sustainable production from Scandinavia and respect the fact that forestry policy is Member State competence.  I voted against wordings on opening up the rules for environmental inspections on the problem of pesticide resistance, because I do not believe it is justified to change the framework for that reason.  All in all, the report contains important comments on the considerations that should be taken into account in the review of the EU biodiversity strategy. In the light of the above, I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the proposal.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Biodiversity is under enormous pressure, globally and in Europe.  The species are becoming extinct at a mind-blowing rate, because of human activity. Habitat changes, pollution, over-exploitation, invasive alien species and climate change are the main causes of biodiversity loss. Biodiversity loss is particularly harmful and entails losses for nature, humanity and the economy: it threatens necessary ecosystem services and compromises the Earth's natural capacity to meet new challenges. Biodiversity and nature must be central in a smart, sustainable and inclusive Europe, and I agree with the call for greater political will to genuinely end biodiversity loss.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted for this report because I defend any text in favour of biodiversity, despite the inadequacies it suffers from.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The goal of halting biodiversity loss failed in 2010.  The strategy developed in 2011 set a new global goal: halting biodiversity loss and the degradation of "ecosystem services", to restore them "as far as possible by 2020". In 2015, it became clear that without significant additional efforts, the EU will once again be able to achieve its objectives. This report calls for better implementation of the relevant legislation in order to halt biodiversity loss – especially the Habitats and Birds Directives (rejecting its revision, weakening them). A great deal of focus is given to the agricultural and forestry sectors. Additional measures are proposed to the Commission and the Member States to halt biodiversity loss. We have made more than 20 amendments to the report. Some have been accepted. But there is another approach and a background to the report. It remains to be assumed that only with the change of the production model, with the responsible use of natural resources and with the transformation of society, which respects all living beings as part of a whole, will we have a strategy that meets the objectives to which it proposes.  It is not enough to paint capitalism green, so that the world becomes better and livable for all living beings.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Written. \u2012 Biodiversity is important. Today, however, we voted against the European Parliament's input into the review of the EU's biodiversity strategy. The reason is that a revision of the Habitats and Birds Directive is being rejected and common sustainability criteria for forestry are required. Nature is changing and therefore we must be prepared to revise our legislation in order to better reflect the current reality. Only then can we ensure biodiversity and sustainable management of the game population. The Birds Directive is from 1979 and the Habitats Directive is from 1992, and which species need protection need to be updated at regular intervals. Some species that need protection receive nothing, and some species that are protected no longer need it. The European Parliament also calls for common criteria for sustainable forestry. But the conditions for forestry in Sweden and Greece, for example, are very different. It does not benefit either the biodiversity of Greek or Swedish forests to transfer more power over forest policy to the EU.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ according to the Eurobarometer survey on biodiversity, at least 80% of European Union citizens consider the impact of biodiversity loss to be serious. However, European efforts to halt the decline in biodiversity ended unsuccessfully in 2010, and a new strategy was set in 2011, containing six objectives to help halt global levels of biodiversity loss. Last year, however, according to the official report, alarming findings were confirmed which indicate that without additional efforts by the European Union, we will not meet the targets proposed by the Council by 2020. However, the protection of biodiversity and investment in nature are essential not only from a social point of view, but also from an economic point of view, and so biodiversity and its great intrinsial value must also be protected in order to keep the planet as good as possible for future generations.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from approving the mid-term review as some EU policies promote biodiversity loss and Member States would not be able to support such actions economically.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy, since environmental protection is a primary objective for me. My position and my ideology do nothing but help me in every effort to protect Nature.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The main aim of the strategic own-initiative report on ‘The Mid-term review of the EU’s Biodiversity Strategy’ is to respond to the State of Nature in Europe report, and the mid-term review of the EU’s Biodiversity Strategy. This strategic report will also be Parliament’s contribution to the on-going fitness check of the Nature legislation (Birds and Habitats Directives). In the fruitful negotiations at committee level, the S&D colleagues managed to integrate our important point to have a holistic approach to biological diversity in agriculture and the environment as well as the conservation of genetic diversity. Another important point for us was the awareness of citizens and the educational work of the Member State at local and regional level. The full implementation of the Nature directives is a necessary precondition to achieve the 2020 biodiversity target.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. – I voted for the adoption of this report because it represents the European Parliament's assessment of the mid-term review of the biodiversity strategy presented by the Commission at the end of 2015 and is of strategic importance for achieving the EU's biodiversity objectives. I support the guidelines given therein on the use of best practices as a catalyst for change. The successes achieved so far, although not outweighing the overall negative trend, show that the legislation in force is working. In this regard, the report provides recommendations for its better implementation and its integration into other policy areas in order to make progress.  A European initiative for pollinators will be key, which will take into account the resistance of plants to pests affecting bees and other pollinators. In addition, I welcome the multilateral approach taken with the involvement of all stakeholders. Investment in biodiversity is socially and economically necessary and brings great added value. The adoption of the report highlights the centrality of biodiversity in a smart, sustainable and inclusive Europe.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 It is of the utmost importance that biodiversity, the unparalleled diversity of the Earth's ecosystems, habitats, species and genomes, of which man is a part, is invaluable in itself. People are also extremely dependent on biodiversity because of a number of valuable ecosystem services, such as clean air, clean water, raw materials, pollinators and flood protection, to name a few. Biodiversity is therefore also a vital foundation for our health, wellbeing and economic well-being.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report considering that it contributes to the analysis of the situation of environmental legislation. The adoption of the amendment approving the list of localized and dangerous invasive species, in accordance with EFSA reports, is also of particular importance in order to ensure that they are eradicated before they are expanded around the EU. We are facing a very important challenge and must be prepared to be able to alleviate and contain the negative effects that may also have on European economies. There is no doubt that the threats to biodiversity today are many and worrying, such as the ever-dormant threat to the Ebro River, so we must enforce the law to protect more than 500 species and the economy of 60,000 people.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. The protection of nature and respect for the ecosystem of our planet are the basis of the health and well-being of the people who live there. That is why I agree with the need to intervene with an intermediate monitoring of the EU Biodiversity Strategy 2020, to urge the achievement of results that are still slow to acquire, but necessary for our future, in order to be able to count on new and greater resources that our ecosystem offers us and to face the challenges that threaten us most, from the economic crisis to climate change , promoting agricultural policies that preserve biodiversity and strategies to support greater awareness, thanks also to a stronger involvement of the main local and regional actors. Protecting the land to invest in growth and the future.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy, as I consider biodiversity to be an important cross-border issue. At the same time, I must stress that I would like the EU to be more involved in networking and the development of so-called 'ex situ' measures.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. It is our job to protect ecosystems. Last but not least, we depend on the services of functioning ecosystems. They guarantee clean drinking water and clear air. The richness of species, which is important for this purpose, must continue to be protected.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which calls on Member States to show more ambition in fully implementing the EU biodiversity strategy. Along with my Labour colleagues, I am committed to protecting the EU nature directives, and will ensure that this is not used as a subtext to weaken or dilute existing regulation in this area.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. – The UK Conservative Delegation supports EU aims to halt the loss of biodiversity by 2020 and fully supports the report’s calls for greater ambition and effort in the implementation and enforcement of the Nature Directives. However, the delegation believes that the report’s position on GMOs, the use of neonicotinoids and the practice of hydraulic fracking does not adequately reflect the science, and could result in restrictions on certain practices and products without adequate evidence of risk to the environment. In light of this, UK Conservative MEPs requested a series of roll call, separate and split votes on paragraphs 81, 82 and 88 of the report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy because its content reviews each and every one of the six objectives of the Strategy, stressing the need to improve the implementation of all legislation aimed at stopping biodiversity loss, in particular the Habitats Directive and the Birds Directive. It also underlines the need for Member States to make an effort to better integrate environmental legislation into other areas, such as agriculture and forestry.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The above-mentioned review published by the Commission can make a decisive contribution to halting biodiversity loss and, above all, to the European Union's greater involvement in the global biodiversity issue. I share the rapporteur's concern about the growing trend towards biodiversity loss. In addition, I would like to point out that, according to statistics, one in six jobs in the European Union depends on biodiversity and nature. Unfortunately, I cannot fully support the mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy and all the solutions it has proposed, as I strongly oppose the attempt to ban shale gas, which is why I was forced to abstain from voting on this text.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which ‘Emphasises that biodiversity loss has devastating economic costs for society, which until now have not been integrated sufficiently into economic and other policies; considers it vital to recognise that investing in biodiversity is essential from a socio-economic point of view; notes that one in six jobs in the EU depends to some extent on nature and biodiversity; stresses that biodiversity has significant potential to create new skills, jobs and business opportunities; welcomes methods for measuring the economic value of biodiversity; considers that these instruments can raise awareness, improve the use of available resources and result in better decision-making’.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. On Tuesday 2 February, I voted in favour of the report midway through the European Union's biodiversity strategy. The results point to progress in many areas, but highlight the fact that EU nature legislation needs to be better enforced by Member States to achieve the EU 2020 targets.  Indeed, more than three-quarters of the important natural habitats in the EU are currently in an unsatisfactory state, and many species are threatened with extinction.  It is also necessary to integrate all local and regional actors in order to define a coherent biodiversity policy, which takes into account the activities of socio-economic actors and the particularities of the territories. Specifically, it seemed essential to me to open the debate on the great predators for the European Commission to take adaptation measures, in order to preserve our farms in mountainous areas.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Birds and Habitats Directives have contributed significantly to protecting nature in Europe. The mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy nevertheless shows that biodiversity loss continues: more than three quarters of the important natural habitats in the EU are now in an unfavourable state, and a quarter of all species are threatened with extinction. Efforts must be stepped up, and EU legislation must be implemented in a more effective, equal and smart way across the EU. As a result, I support this Committee on the Environment’s report, and have voted in favour of it.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. – 'The own-initiative report is not legislation and is primarily about taking action against the serious impoverishment of Europe's biodiversity. Of course we stand up for the Swedish forest and the right for Sweden to decide for itself about the hunting of wolves. The EU has no competence in hunting matters – it is a national matter. When EU lawyers use the nature directives as an argument to stop Swedish hunting of wolves, they are wrong. A revision of the directives in that part is therefore welcome.  But the report is also good and the EU must do more to tackle the depletion of biodiversity in many EU countries. Sweden is at the forefront – not least through our forestry policy, which brings biodiversity and the use of forest raw materials. The protection of biodiversity is vital for the future of Europe, but current efforts are insufficient. The impoverishment of ecosystems also has social consequences, not least in rural areas. Countless jobs depend on biodiversity and nature. We take responsibility for ensuring that the EU works for sustainable, environmentally friendly and social development. That is why we support the report, although we do not share all its positions."

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The EU's goal of stopping biodiversity loss failed in 2010. The EU responded by setting a new strategy in 2011. In 2015 it was clear that without more effort, the EU would again fail in 2020 to meet its targets.  The report deals with the biodiversity strategy as an objective and proposes better implementation of all relevant legislation. The report also contains additional measures on which the Commission and the Member States should focus their efforts. We voted in favour of the report.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ This report is the Parliament’s response to the Commission’s EU Biodiversity Strategy mid-term review and its input to the ongoing fitness check of the Birds and Habitats Directives. The rapporteur calls for the Commission and the Member States to make achieving the 2020 targets an urgent political priority, noting the alarming trend in biodiversity loss. He suggests measures such as deeper integration of biodiversity in policy areas like agriculture and insists on the fact that nature policies can go hand in hand with economic development, while also stating that a full implementation of the Directive is necessary to achieve the 2020 targets. The rapporteur also points out that one in six EU jobs is dependent to some extent on nature and biodiversity and that the socio-economic opportunity costs of missing the targets amounts to EUR 50 billion per year. This repercussion of biodiversity loss are therefore numerous and widespread, and that is why I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ I am proud to be one of the massive 592 MEPs today to tell the European Commission you are wrong to threaten to re-open and potentially weaken the EU Birds and Habitats Directives. As the local Member of the European Parliament for Sandy, Bedfordshire, where the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds is based, I am proud to have joined their ‘Nature Alert’ campaign to protect these Nature Directives. The RSPB rightly insists the existing framework is absolutely vital for Europe to meet biodiversity targets and, rather than being weakened, should be fully enforced and implemented. Over half a million people – a record – backed the laws during the public consultation which ended last July – more even than the number which responded to the ‘TTIP’ consultation. 7 149 were in my own East of England constituency, and 100 000 from the United Kingdom overall. I am disappointed that the three UKIP MEPs from my region were amongst just 52 who opposed this resolution, and that one of our three Conservative MEPs also failed to support it. For those who accuse Europe of a ‘democratic deficit’, today is a victory for democracy. But above all, it is a victory for nature conservation.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report, which reiterates the need for additional, innovative solutions in order to halt biodiversity loss. Biodiversity and nature must be central in a smart, sustainable and inclusive Europe.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Written. \u2012 Biodiversity is deteriorating at a very worrying rate. The extinction of species and the collapse of ecosystems are the most serious threats facing mankind, along with climate change and unsustainable use of resources. The state of European nature is deteriorating. We are leaving future generations with even greater life chances. The objectives of the EU Biodiversity Strategy up to 2020 will not be achieved. The EU cannot stop development by its own actions alone. This requires a comprehensive change in consumption habits. For Finland, agriculture and forestry play a very important role. Their impact on biodiversity is absolutely crucial. All actors have already been aware of this and are increasingly taking diversity into account. Much more can still be done. Various economic incentives must be directed towards supporting sustainable development. Natural and sufficiently wide-ranging, conticreting areas are the best maintainers of biodiversity. There must be enough of them. Finland still lives in the forest. Finland is a forest. Our destiny is how we manage our forest resources. We have to balance between different cross-pressures: money must be made for the national economy, forests must be used and managed. At the same time, we must be able not to touch them in order to safeguard biodiversity.  Finland's oldest known tree is 800 years old. As it began to grow, Europe embarked on a fourth crusade, cambridge university was founded and Chechnya-Kini began its conquest. I want pine, which is now at the beginning of its growth, to see the next eight hundred years and I hope that they will be good for both Finns and our forests.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Voted only for the mid-term review report of the EU biodiversity strategy, as I believe that this unique blend of ecosystems, habitats, species and genes, called biodiversity, on which man is highly dependent, needs to be protected for the benefit of future generations. Agriculture plays a major role in this and the great goals that need to be achieved in order to be effective in producing food for the growing world population.  Sustainable and responsible farming, livestock farming, diversity of plant species and varieties, increased use of biomass as an energy source, the transition to a green economy are just some of the key contributions to biodiversity conservation. The fact is that around a quarter of wild species in Europe are at risk of extinction and that many ecosystems are being damaged, causing serious social and economic damage to the EU. Therefore, European legislation in this area must be implemented in a more efficient, equal and smart way across the Union.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I support this text in favour of biodiversity, which does not force the Member States too heavily. I also agree with the frequent reminder of combining respect for the environment with economic development.  I note only the fault of the approach of putting the issue of biodiversity on economic integration instead of considering it as a necessary good for man. As a result I vote for.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe in the importance of preserving nature reserves and natural habitats for wildlife in Britain and in Europe. However, we believe that this task should be a national, not European, responsibility, and we will therefore oppose new EU legislation in this area. Nevertheless, we will support all amendments aimed at improving the existing legislation on this issue. We believe that the best people to decide on natural habitats in Britain are the British people. We do not trust the unelected EU Commission to decide on the protection of the environment and animal welfare. The EU has caused irreparable damage with its environmental policy. It has destroyed our fish stocks and caused widespread deforestation with its policy on bio-fuels.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mark Demesmaeker's report on the mid-term review of the European Union's biodiversity strategy. Biodiversity is a wealth and a resource that we need to protect. The European Parliament has recognised the agricultural and forestry sectors as an important contribution to the preservation of this biodiversity. However, the implementation of the 2020 targets taken by the European Union is lagging behind. Member States must therefore make more efforts while integrating the particularities of local and regional socio-economic actors and territories. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Biodiversity in Europe is under threat. More than three quarters of important natural habitats in the Union are in very poor condition and many animal and plant species are threatened with extinction. That is why in 2011 the EU adopted a strategy aimed at halting biodiversity loss by 2020. Restoring natural ecosystems and protecting the environment are one of the most important faiths facing the EU today. Today, in carrying out a mid-term review of the adopted and implemented plan, it is important to emphasise the need to put into practice what has been established and accepted by the Member States. First of all, the aim should be to better apply environmental rights in specific areas. The European Commission is responsible for monitoring and evaluating the effectiveness of countries in achieving the objectives of the strategy and, as it says, although the current results of the implementation of the procedures indicate an improvement in the situation in many areas, the Eu countries must continue their efforts to fully implement their commitments. As the polls show, environmental issues are close to our citizens and the European Union remains a world leader in biodiversity conservation.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. A mid-term review of the 2011 strategy is being carried out to halt the loss of biodiversity and the decline of ecosystem services and to restore them as much as possible by 2020. The report shows that, without additional efforts, the target for 2020 would be missed if existing legislation is not better enforced and enforced. I agree with this report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I supported the report on the mid-term review of the European Union's biodiversity strategy. I believe that it is important to stick to the strategy for the preservation of the environment, as it is in the interests of our citizens in the long term. In addition, environmental conservation and biodiversity continue to be included in other policies. It is important that laws are implemented not only on paper, but also in practice, because systematic implementation of laws and the achievement of the objectives set will benefit people, nature and business.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Ensuring the sustainability of the European biodiversity is a promise we have to make for the future generations.  Preserving biodiversity in tensely populated area such as the EU requires efforts from all sides, from politicians on all levels, to companies, to agricultural and forestry sectors to individuals.  Current existing legislation, the Birds and Habitats directives, need to be better implemented. Achieving the 2020 targets of the EU biodiversity strategy should be one of the political priorities. It is important to underline that restoring, preserving and enhancing ecosystems related to agriculture and forestry, including in Natura 2000 areas, is highlighted as one of the six key priorities for rural development.  In order to generate synergies and engage all sectors in achieving those targets, one of the crucial issues is to boost innovation and especially invest into ecological engineering.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Labour MEPs are committed to protecting the EU nature directives and will work to ensure that the fitness check is not used as an excuse to water down or weaken the legislation.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the Biodiversity strategy of the EU. Biodiversity is therefore essential for people’s health and well—being, as well as for their economic prosperity. It is important to underline that nowadays biodiversity is under severe pressure due to human activity. Deplorably, the European aim to halt biodiversity loss failed in 2010 and the EU undertook a new strategy in 2011. It is clear that without additional reforms, the EU will in 2020 again fail to achieve its targets. For this reason, the report calls on a better implementation and enforcement of the existing legislation. Additionally, it considers that innovative nature-based solutions can significantly contribute to tackle those challenges. Consequently, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The loss of biodiversity is one of the ten most serious global risks. Biological resources are the foundations on which we build civilizations. Nature products are the basis of many industrial activities such as agriculture, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, the paper industry, horticulture, construction and residual treatment. The loss of biodiversity has a negative impact on our food supplies, recreation and tourism opportunities, timber, medicine and energy sources. It also interferes with essential ecological functions.  Unfortunately, the measures taken by the EU to stop this phenomenon by 2020 have not had the desired effect. Addressing this challenge certainly requires a mid-term review of the EU strategy accompanied by greater political will. I have therefore decided to support Mr Demesmaeker's report because, in protecting biodiversity, it is in the interests of the whole of Europe for the impact it may have, even for future generations.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted for the report on the Biodiversity Strategy. The whole text remains fairly consensual and does not impose excessive demands on Member States. The importance of reconciling respect for the environment and economic development is often recalled, a laudable pragmatic approach.  It is regrettable, however, that the issue of biodiversity is being argued by a socio-economic integration of the issue. The loss of biodiversity is then identified at a financial cost.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it works to protect biodiversity, especially against pesticides, GMOs and hydraulic fracturing. It also has the merit of giving Member States a great deal of leeway. It is regrettable, however, that the three amendments of the ENL group were rejected by anti-FN ideology when they were aimed at further restricting the use of certain products harmful to biodiversity.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 Nature conservation directives, such as NATURA 2000, go against the principle of subsidiarity. Nature conservation should be a matter for the Member States, I do not support the creation of a new EU soil directive.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ In Europe, around a quarter of wild species are at risk of extinction and many ecosystems have been destroyed causing serious social and economic damage to the European Union. Biodiversity loss is a huge cost to society and therefore investing in biodiversity is essential to preserve a favourable social economic situation. The EU must support developing countries in their efforts to preserve biodiversity. Awareness of the importance of biodiversity needs to be raised by eu populations, as people are dependent on all the good ecosystems such as drinking water, clean air and other natural goods. The Commission and the Member States must prioritise the achievement of the biodiversity targets by 2020, as the targets set will not be achieved without further and sustained efforts.   I supported MEP Demesmaeker's report because the unique diversity of ecosystems, habitats and species has great value for the EU. I believe that a better approach to biodiversity funding is needed, covering several funds, and it is very important to link different funding instruments. Sustainable management of the world's forests should be established by strengthening ecological processes, biodiversity and forest productivity and bearing in mind the rights of indigenous people in these areas.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \u2012 Preserving biodiversity for future generations is a challenging and sensitive process. Its decline is and will always be influenced by human activity, both direct and indirect. The loss of biodiversity will negatively affect all future life on Earth, affecting generations of humanity. It is therefore necessary to take effective measures on an ongoing basis to keep nature as balanced as possible with human economic activity. I will support all the proposals that, in the interests of biodiversity conservation, will integrate nature and landscape protection into all policies and will lead to a link between economic development and the protection of biodiversity.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. The vast majority of European citizens have recently expressed concern about the loss of biodiversity in Europe. In 2015, for example, more than half a million Europeans asked the European Commission to protect nature and ensure the implementation of existing directives.  Based on this observation, this report makes a clear diagnosis to achieve a containment of biodiversity loss, stressing that in order to achieve the objectives of the Union's biodiversity strategy, the current legislative framework will have to be fully implemented by the Member States, with additional monitoring and dedicated financial resources. This text deplores the fact that the UPRs are excluded from current EU legislation when they contain unique reserves of species and ecosystems and a substantial part of global and European biodiversity.  It calls on the Commission to define a legislative framework adapted to the specifics of these regions, as well as to create a sustainable mechanism to finance the protection of biodiversity in the UPRs and PTOMs.  Policies in favour of nature need strong political support. That is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy because it is not complete.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. This mid-term review, as its name suggests, takes stock of the Union's biodiversity strategy. It notes that efforts have been modest and regrets that the flexibilities granted to Member States have finally limited the proper application of the directives.  We regret, moreover, that the issue of biodiversity is seen only from the financial perspective of socio-economic integration. Nevertheless, this text remains consensual and has the immense advantage of not imposing too heavy demands on Member States, which we support.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which ‘Emphasises that biodiversity loss has devastating economic costs for society, which until now have not been integrated sufficiently into economic and other policies; considers it vital to recognise that investing in biodiversity is essential from a socio-economic point of view; notes that one in six jobs in the EU depends to some extent on nature and biodiversity; stresses that biodiversity has significant potential to create new skills, jobs and business opportunities; welcomes methods for measuring the economic value of biodiversity; considers that these instruments can raise awareness, improve the use of available resources and result in better decision-making’.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy highlights the need for greater implementation efforts by Member States to halt biodiversity loss and the prevention of degradation of ecosystem services. The EU has taken the first steps to reduce the indirect causes of biodiversity loss, in particular in the area of wildlife trade and illegal fishing, and to integrate the issue of biodiversity into its trade agreements. The aim of the mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy is to achieve the goal of halting biodiversity loss by 2020.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Nature Directives are important milestones with regard to nature policy, not only of the EU but also at international level.  This mid-term review of the Biodiversity Strategy aims not only for the measures and programmes implemented, in particular with regard to the Birds and Habitat Directive, to be strengthened, but also to be extended to other strategic areas of the environment.  I voted for it.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. From the European Parliament we are committed to the preservation of biodiversity in Europe and around the world and for this reason we call on the Community institutions to be persistent and act diligently to avoid irreversible losses of incalculable biological value. My support for the European Parliament's motion for a Resolution on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy, which also makes a particular defence of biodiversity in the EU's outermost regions and overseas territories, warning that action must be taken to ensure that this biological treasure is preserved.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I support this report, as nature conservation is a prime example of the issue that needs to be better dealt with at Community level, and because environmental protection is also a homeland protection.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy. In 2010, Europe's ambition to halt the loss of biodiversity failed. This is why the EU therefore developed a new strategy in 2011. In this strategy, EU Heads of State and Government has defined the main objective of halting the loss of biodiversity and ecosystem services, and restoring it as much as possible by 2020. It is stressed that the implementation, enforcement and financing of nature directives are prerequisites for ensuring the success of the strategy as a whole. The report therefore calls on the European Commission and the Member States to comply fairly with EU legislation, improve their enforcement and, where necessary, to impose proportionate, effective and dissuasive sanctions. Only in this way will the successful implementation of the strategy be achieved and the objectives set out therein are achieved.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The aim of this resolution is the full implementation of the Birds and Habitats Directives, as well as the preservation and restoration of ecosystems and ecosystem services. To this end, it proposes to promote the contributions of agriculture and forestry to the preservation and deepening of biodiversity.  The resolution also focuses on the sustainable exploitation of fish stocks and the control of invasive alien species. All this in order to stop the loss of biodiversity on a global scale. We are still far from the stated objectives and as such the report deplores 'the slow progress made by Member States in the implementation of European environmental legislation'. In fact, it notes that "no detailed data on the true funding of nature conservation by Member State" is available. I vote for this resolution without illusion as to its effects.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I support this text in favour of biodiversity, which does not force the Member States too heavily. I also agree with the frequent reminder of respecting the environment and economic development.  I note only the fault of the approach of putting the issue of biodiversity on economic integration instead of considering it as a necessary good for man. As a result I vote for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy.  Developed around six specific objectives, biodiversity loss is assumed as a political priority.  The role of the different national, local and regional actors in this process is crucial, so that the proposed targets are met through concrete actions.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the EU biodiversity strategy. We need to do more to protect our natural environment. This will deliver a strong political signal on the need to act urgently to protect Europe’s ecosystems.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – Nature in Europe, its ecosystems and its biodiversity are under severe pressure. We have come to this conclusion repeatedly, and equally many have been the noble efforts, action plans and strategies to prevent the risk of extinction of a growing number of endangered species. A new strategy was rolled out in 2011 to stop biodiversity loss in Europe. The ambition was to stop the loss and restore as many habitats and ecosystems as possible by 2020. Parliament's report now sets out the mid-term review of that EU biodiversity strategy. In 2015, the verdict is once again clear: without considerable efforts, the EU will once again be out of track for 2020 and the rich diversity of animals and plants will once again be a lot more skimpy. Human activities are at the root of the fact that species are becoming extinct and biotopes are disappearing. So the key to restoring nature and biodiversity lies with that same person. The report rightly calls on all stakeholders, i.e. everyone, to make additional efforts and to speed up the implementing and implementing of existing legislation and nature directives.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing – Biodiversity is an integral part of the natural environment. Even slight fluctuations in diversity in nature can cause problems of various kinds that affect humans sooner or later. We must approach the environment responsibly, which is of direct concern to us. The state of the environment has a direct impact on both human physical and mental health. The European Union's biodiversity strategy therefore has its merits and, all the more so, its mid-term review. Right now, with time to optimise and achieve the best possible results in the area of biodiversity, a period is right for concrete adjustments and changes in strategy. I believe that the result of today's vote will contribute to the protection of the environment.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ The main aim of the strategic own-initiative report on ‘The Mid-term review of the EU’s Biodiversity Strategy’ is to respond to the Commission proposal for the mid-term review of the EU’s Biodiversity Strategy. I gave my full support to the EP report which includes the importance of providing urgent political priority to the achievement of the 2020 targets, more information to the general public to increase awareness, adopting a multi-stakeholder approach to ensure the active participation of all stakeholders including regional and local actors. The report supports strong protection for the restoration of our natural environment and it sends out a strong political signal on the need to act urgently to protect Europe’s nature for the benefit of our citizens.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety presented a report on the mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy. The report states that biodiversity is a vital foundation for our health, well-being and economic well-being, but that it is also under heavy pressure worldwide and in Europe. However, European efforts to halt biodiversity loss failed in 2010 and the EU developed a new strategy in 2011 to halt biodiversity loss and degradation of ecosystem services, restore their status as far as possible by 2020 and help reverse biodiversity loss worldwide. The report states that, without further significant efforts, the EU will once again not be able to meet its targets in 2020. Demonstrating with a mystity of statistics that investment in nature and biodiversity is socially and economically necessary, it calls for a stronger political will to effectively halt the loss of biodiversity. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The report on the mid-term review of the EU's biodiversity strategy considers that efforts have been modest and regrets that the flexibilities granted to Member States have been able to limit the proper implementation of the directives on this subject. The question of biodiversity is more argued by its economic aspect, the loss of biodiversity is then identified at a financial cost. The vital aspect of the environment for man rooted in his space is obviously not defended in this text. However, the whole text remains consensual and does not impose excessive demands on Member States. Finally, the importance of reconciling respect for the environment and economic development is often recalled, a laudable pragmatic approach. We are therefore in favour of this text.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The loss of biodiversity has become alarming. The species are becoming extinct at a breakneck rate; habitat changes, pollution, over-exploitation, invasive alien species and climate change are the main foundations of biodiversity loss. I believe that biodiversity is paramount to our health and well-being, as well as to economic prosperity. I agree with the rapporteur in defending greater political will to genuinely address biodiversity loss as a political priority and on the need for a multilateral approach in which regional and local actors have a special role. I advocate better implementation and monitoring of compliance with existing legislation to put an end to biodiversity loss, which must be seen as an effective European objective. I also endorse the rapporteur's position that biodiversity and nature must be central in a smart, sustainable and inclusive Europe, and in the call for greater political will to genuinely end biodiversity loss. I would like to highlight the importance of this issue for EU citizens, expressed in the Nature Alert campaign, in which half a million citizens called for compliance and better implementation of nature protection legislation.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs are committed to protecting the EU nature directives and will work to ensure that the fitness check is not used as an excuse to water down or weaken the legislation. For this reason, Labour MEPs voted in favour of the Environment Committee’s report on the Mid-term Review of the EU’s Biodiversity Strategy.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the mid-term review of the EU's biodiversity strategy in Europe. Despite the interesting proposals in it, I could not support a text calling on Member States to ban the exploitation of unconventional hydrocarbons such as shale gas, in defiance of the principles of subsidiarity and sovereignty of national authorities in choosing their energy mix.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Biodiversity is a key element for our health, well-being and economic prosperity. Unfortunately, climate change in recent years, pollution and over-exploitation of land are a dangerous threat in Europe and around the world. Europe's efforts to halt biodiversity loss failed miserably in 2010, with important directives not being transposed. In 2011, the EU developed a new strategy, the progress of which is still too little. With the adoption of this report, we are calling for greater political will to make the loss of biodiversity a real strategic priority, in need of a multi-stakeholder approach, in which European actors, but also regional and local actors, play a special role. There is a need to increase public support for investment, but we believe it is essential to use the resources available in a more efficient and targeted way. We call on the Commission to draw up specific criteria to ensure that projects have adequate, positive and tangible scientific effects. Biodiversity and nature must continue to be seen as central to an intelligent, sustainable and inclusive Europe. This is essential for nature itself and for the health, well-being and prosperity of our children.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The report on the mid-term review of the European Union's biodiversity strategy presents encouraging solutions and objectives, which is why I voted in favour of it.  However, it also points to continued environmental degradation, and is pessimistic about the success of the 2020 targets in this area. The EU and the Member States must make the protection of biodiversity a political priority.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Biodiversity is under serious threat in Europe and around the world. Species are extinguishing at a very high rate, and this is due to human activities, habitat changes, pollution and climate change. Protecting biodiversity is in everyone's interest, especially for future generations, and that is why I supported Mr Demesmaeker's report.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Biodiversity represents the unique variety of ecosystems, habitats, species and genes on Earth, and its loss is a loss to nature, humanity and the economy. I have voted in favour of this report on the EU Biodiversity Strategy, which is essential for nature itself as well as for health, wellbeing and welfare of the generations to come.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the Commission's target to halt loss of biodiversity by 2020.  Biodiversity is critical to both our environmental and economic well-being. With only one out of the six specific targets on track to be achieved, the disappointing reality is that we are a long way off from achieving the Commission's goals.   The report calls for more ambitious means to achieve such vital targets. It calls for better implementation and further enforcement of existing polices such as the Nature Directives. Strengthening the existing mechanism will enable a more cohesive measurement of the economic value biodiversity can offer.   I acknowledge agriculture has an inherent role to play in conserving biodiversity. Yet we must be cautious to ensure that the targets set out establish a complementary relationship between biodiversity and agriculture rather than a conflicting one.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I support the position of like—minded colleagues in the European Parliament and voted in favour of the report. Taking into consideration that the loss of biodiversity and the disintegration of the ecosystem have been found by the World Economic Forum, in a 2014 ‘Global risk perception survey’, to be among one of the 10 biggest risks facing the global community, and that our existence is so closely intertwined with the sustainability of natural resources, it is paramount that we adopt an ambitious and consistent approach to secure a reversal of former bad trends. We need to focus more attention towards meeting the targets as set out in the EU Biodiversity Strategy to 2020 to avoid repeating the failure of 2010 where the targets were not met. The prevention of biodiversity loss therefore should be a top priority.  To arrive at the 2020 targets it is vital to implement and enforce already established EU legislation. Indeed, we know that not only does investing in biodiversity carry positive results for the natural environment it is also connected to socio-economic development. With great scope for improvement the EU therefore has an important task ahead if it is to meet the 2020 deadline.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 The review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy has resulted in the finding that meeting the agreed targets in 2020 is a long way off. Only 23% of natural species and 16% of natural habitats are in good condition. The EU's ecological footprint is double that of its biological capacity. Considerable additional efforts are therefore needed. I supported the points of the report that encourage these efforts and put together concrete steps that need to be taken. Finding the political will to make targeted investments in nature and biodiversity is key.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the report is a genuine promotion and funding of nature conservation. The report also calls for greater transparency in greening measures. Nature conservation is a prime example that needs to be better dealt with at Community level, and given that environmental protection is also a protection of the homeland, I also support this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Biodiversity is vital for human health, well-being and the economy, and it is under pressure all over the world and also in Europe. Due to human activity, different species are dying out too quickly. In order to preserve biodiversity, the EU has proposed a number of strategies. The targets for 2010 were not met, and the current interim report also shows that the 2020 targets are not even halfway. Serious efforts must therefore be made to achieve the agreed objectives. Stronger political will, better implementation and monitoring of legislation and new innovative solutions are needed. Nature needs to be more closely linked to society, sustainable growth and integrated into other policies to protect biodiversity.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. – There are many occasions when I have asked for the protection of our biodiversity, especially for those endangered species, such as the Iberian lynx, or denouncing bad environmental policies or the poor condition of our habitats.  This report is very critical of the results we are achieving with the current Strategy. The mid-term review gives us an opportunity to learn about our mistakes, which species or sectors are most vulnerable, and thus try to remedy a worrying situation that certainly requires greater efforts.  That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I welcome the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy. It is to be welcomed that progress has been made in many areas towards the 2020 target of halting biodiversity loss, but this is not enough and more efforts are needed. Particular attention must be paid to biodiversity policy, as biodiversity loss increases the risk of irreversible change and undermines economic development and resilience of society. In particular, better implementation and supervision of existing legislation is needed. In addition, additional innovative solutions and implementing measures need to be sought. I believe that the Commission should present a concrete proposal for a trans-European green infrastructure network as soon as possible. It is essential that the ban on the use of neonicotinoids continues to apply, taking into account their potential adverse effects. In addition, it is necessary to fully apply the precautionary principle when authorising the use and release into the environment of living modified organisms. Particular attention must be paid to new hydraulic fracturing operations in the European Union. Given the negative impact of these activities on the climate, the environment and biodiversity, I believe that Member States should not authorise such activities.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report recognising the need for urgent action to protect biodiversity in Europe, which is essential for our health and well-being and for our economic soundness. The report proposes European and national actions to achieve the objectives of the European Biodiversity Strategy by 2020 and proposes the full implementation, enforcement and financing of the Birds and Habitats Directives.  With the phenomenon of climate change we are seeing a reshaping of fauna and flora that directly affects the biodiversity of the planet. Finally, bearing in mind that the proportion of European eco-regions with at least 17% of their territory in protected areas is significantly reduced when areas protected exclusively by the Natura 2000 network are excluded, it is important to stress the role and involvement of sites in this network, where areas of Cyprus are also registered.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe in the importance of preserving nature reserves and natural habitats for wildlife in Britain and in Europe. However, we believe that this task should be a national, not European, responsibility, and we will therefore oppose new EU legislation in this area. Nevertheless, we will support all amendments aimed at improving the existing legislation on this issue. We believe that the best people to decide on natural habitats in Britain are the British people. We do not trust the unelected EU Commission to decide on the protection of the environment and animal welfare. The EU has caused irreparable damage with its environmental policy. It has destroyed our fish stocks and caused widespread deforestation with its policy on bio-fuels.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 As is well known, in 2010 the European commitment to halt biodiversity loss failed and the following year the EU developed a new strategy setting as its main objective this loss and degradation of ecosystem services by 2020. As we are still a long way from achieving these objectives, I am voting in favour of this mid-term review.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The overall trend in biodiversity loss is alarming and urgent political measures need to be undertaken in order for the 2020 targets to be attained. Of the total number of species assessed in Bulgaria, around 6 % are considered threatened and at least 7 % are near—threatened at the European level. Many of these species are endemic to Europe and are found nowhere else in the world. That is why I vote in favour of the report.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. – Efforts to preserve biodiversity must be among the priorities of the EZ. As many as a quarter of species are more seriously endangered, which not only directly affects the environment, but also harms the economy. I therefore voted in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy, as it further encourages Member States to take measures that would halt significant diversity reduction and address this in several segments: under the common agricultural policy, in rural support funds, continuous monitoring of the implementation of the Directives.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The european nature protection policy so far has proved successful, both from the point of view of achieving the conservation objectives of species and habitats, as well as from the point of view of benefits for society through measurable and undue benefits. The European Nature Protection System boasts the conservation of many species on the verge of extinction such as the Iberian lynx, the puppy eagle or the brown bear. Also, thanks to investments in protected areas, conditions for economic progress are ensured, primarily rural areas in addition to protected areas, which proves the high complementarity of different policies if the achievement of the desired goals is approached in a balanced way.  Nature protection must not be a burden and barrier for local people and farmers, but must become an added value. Consumers also value agricultural products originating in recognizable areas of the preserved environment. That is why I believe that such an approach, such as labelling the origin of products, represents what we want: synergies and coherence between different European policies.  Because of all this, I supported the resolution adopted today and I believe that the current legislative framework would not be good to change, but at the same time I expect it to be implemented more consistently at Member State level in order to achieve the desired goals by 2020.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The report on the mid-term review of the EU's biodiversity strategy considers that efforts have been modest. It is also regrettable that the issue of biodiversity is only argued by a socio-economic integration of the issue, the loss of biodiversity is then identified only at a financial cost. The vital aspect of the environment for humans or respect for nature and animals for themselves are not defended in this text.  However, the whole text remains consensual and, above all, does not impose excessive demands on Member States. Finally, the importance of reconciling respect for the environment and economic development is often recalled, a laudable pragmatic approach. I therefore vote in favour of this report.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 In Europe, as in the rest of the world, there is a daily inexorable and constant degradation of biodiversity, mostly linked to human activities. Despite the more effective use of raw materials, the European way of life remains among those most prone to the consumption of natural resources. The strategy that the European Union adopted in 2011 aimed to identify actions to be taken to integrate biodiversity challenges into the framework of different European policies such as the common agricultural policy or the common fisheries policy. This strategy aims to stop this degradation process by 2020 and yet, the European Environment Agency report of 3 March 2015 returns a very worrying reality by suggesting that the European target of halting the global loss of biodiversity is in danger of failing.  I voted in favour of this resolution because I am convinced that the strategy adopted by the Union demonstrates, first and foremost, great political awareness, but also that greater commitment, particularly on the part of the Member States, is necessary if the objectives are to be achieved within the time limits set.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒I support the Environment, Public Health and Safety Committee's mid-term audit report on the implementation of the EU Biodiversity Strategy, which clearly shows the current state of affairs with the application of the strategy and correctly points to areas where it is already becoming clear that the strategy will not be able to be met. We are currently halfway there since the strategy was adopted, and the figures are as follows: The EU's environmental footprint is twice that of the EU. Only 23% of species and 16% of habitats are in a favorable position. Significant progress has been made in the areas of fisheries and invasive alien species, but other objectives are insufficient, especially problematic agriculture and forestry. The most relevant legislation consists of environmental directives. The implementation of the birds and habitats directives is an absolute precondition for achieving the biodegradation strategy as a whole. These directives are milestones in European environmental policy, and they have established a single Natura 2000 network that protects over 26 000 areas.  However, the full potential of Nature 2000 has not yet been achieved, but is yet to be expected. Better cooperation between the Commission and member states on the implementation of the existing Nature Directive and improved guidelines, rigorous implementation and exchange of best practices are essential for successful implementation.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The goal of halting biodiversity loss failed in 2010. The strategy developed in 2011 set a new global goal: halting biodiversity loss and the degradation of "ecosystem services", to restore them "as far as possible by 2020". In 2015, it became quite clear that the EU in 2020 will not be able to achieve its objectives without significant additional efforts. This report calls for better implementation of the relevant legislation – in particular the Habitats and Birds Directives (rejecting its revision, weakening them) - proposing additional measures to the Commission and the Member States to halt biodiversity loss. A great focus is given to the agricultural and forestry sectors.  There were many proposals to amend the report, some considered. However, there remains another approach and a background to the report that takes on that only with the change of the production model, with the responsible use of natural resources and with the transformation of society, which respects all living beings as part of a whole, we will have a strategy that meets the objectives to which it proposes.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 Loss of biodiversity is one of the fundamental problems we, as humanity, are currently facing. At the same time, the disappearance of ecosystem diversity has huge effects on humans, which may not be so obvious today, but can nevertheless be fatal. We are talking, for example, about air purity, water purity, the availability of raw materials, and therefore health, well-being and economic prosperity. The European Union is a world leader in combating adverse climate change, a leader in promoting green energy and the economy, yet it is systematically failing to meet its own objectives in protecting and restoring biodiversity. In 2011, the EU approved a new strategy to preserve biodiversity. The strategy review has shown that without a fundamental change of approach at all levels of government, without greater political will not only at national level, but especially at regional and local level, the 2020 targets will not be achieved.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Biodiversity, a key element for our health, well-being and economic prosperity, is under serious threat in Europe and around the world. The loss of biodiversity is particularly harmful and leads to losses for nature, humanity and the economy. The World Economic Forum has placed biodiversity loss and ecosystem collapse among the ten most serious global risks. This loss is linked to issues related to climate change and the scarcity of raw materials.  In 2011, the European Union developed a new strategy with the main objective of halting biodiversity loss and degradation of ecosystem services in the EU by 2020. The 2015 mid-term review talks about too little progress to achieve the main objective and without further substantial efforts the EU will again miss the agreed target in 2020.  That is why I believe that, with greater political will, better implementation and enforcement of existing legislation and new financial commitments, the loss of biodiversity can be stopped. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Maurice PONGA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mid-term review of the European Union's biodiversity strategy.  The report stresses the need to continue efforts to stem biodiversity losses, but also repeatedly stresses the need to recognise the biodiversity specificities of ultramarine territories and provide adequate funding.  For example, the report calls on the Commission to set up a sustainable mechanism to finance biodiversity protection in the outermost regions and overseas countries and territories, in the wake of the BEST preparatory action. This is a very important point and it is an idea that I have been advocating for several years in the European Parliament: we need a specific instrument for the European overseas to protect our biodiversity.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In October 2015 The Commission has published a mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy, which examines progress towards halting the loss of biodiversity and ecosystem services by 2020, restoring, where possible, ecosystems and increasing the EU's commitment to preventing global biodiversity loss. The mid-term review concludes that this objective can only be achieved if implementation and enforcement efforts are much bolder and more ambitious. Parliament notes with concern the general trend towards biodiversity loss and calls on the Commission and the Member States to give this issue political priority in order to achieve its 2020 targets. The proposed measures include the integration of biodiversity into other policy areas such as agriculture and forestry, an increase in the number of Natura 2000 sites with development plans and an EU action plan on wildlife trade. Parliament also stresses that environmental policy and economic development are not mutually exclusive, with the alternative socio-economic cost of not meeting the 2020 targets estimated at EUR 50 billion per year and one in six jobs in the EU being somewhat dependent on nature and biodiversity. Since Par. 88 was adopted calling for an end to shale gas extraction, I abstained

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. This report on the mid-term review of the European Union's biodiversity strategy allows us to take stock of our recommendations. They are addressed to both the Commission and the Member States.  Specifically, it allows us to contribute to the current assessment of environmental legislation, including the Habitats Directive.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe in the importance of preserving nature reserves and natural habitats for wildlife in Britain and in Europe. However, we believe that this task should be a national, not European, responsibility, and we will therefore oppose new EU legislation in this area. Nevertheless, we will support all amendments aimed at improving the existing legislation on this issue. We believe that the best people to decide on natural habitats in Britain are the British people. We do not trust the unelected EU Commission to decide on the protection of the environment and animal welfare. The EU has caused irreparable damage with its environmental policy. It has destroyed our fish stocks and caused widespread deforestation with its policy on bio-fuels.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. Biodiversity, the unique variety of ecosystems, habitats, species and genes of the Earth, of which humanity is also a part, has an immeasurable intrinsic value, being under enormous pressure, globally and in Europe, as species are becoming extinct at a breakneck pace and largely because of human activity. Habitat changes, pollution, over-exploitation, invasive alien species and climate change are the main causes of biodiversity loss that is particularly harmful and entails losses to nature, humanity and the economy. The limits and capacity of the planet are being exceeded and this is necessarily triggering irreversible changes. The European objective of ending biodiversity loss was not met in 2010 and, as a whole, the EU responded by drawing up a new strategy in 2011. The Heads of State and Government have set the central objective of ending biodiversity loss and the deterioration of ecosystem services, re-establishing them as far as possible by 2020 and increasing the EU's efforts to prevent global biodiversity degradation, and I voted in favour of this mid-term review.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. At noon, the European Parliament adopted by a large majority of the recommendations to achieve the objectives set out in the EU's biodiversity strategy for 2010-2020.  This is not to say that biodiversity is at risk almost everywhere in Europe. In May 2015, the European Commission published an alarming report on the state of nature conservation in Europe. Nearly half of the bird species on the continent are at risk (48%), and more than half of the other species are in unfavourable conservation states (60%). It is regrettable to note that Belgium, and the Walloon region in particular, is doing even worse in terms of habitat conservation. I am in favour of a drastic repetition of efforts to protect our biodiversity by more implementing the Union's ambitious legislation rather than watering them down. I am thinking first of all of the "Birds" and "Habitats" directives. On the other hand, the Natura 2000 network, the largest network of protected areas in the world, is 18% of the Union's territory, will need to be strengthened. And build on the encouraging results achieved to better preserve nature and ecosystems.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: In writing. This report is a reminder of the importance of the European Union's protection of biodiversity in the face of multiple threats to biodiversity. Let us not forget that it is the living that has allowed us to develop many medicines and that biomimicry is a source of innovation as original as it is indispensable. Yet legislation is not being implemented equally across Europe. In some states, there is a great temptation to sacrifice environmental policies for economic considerations or for lack of courage. France, which has so delayed the adoption of a law on the protection of biodiversity, is one of the worst European pupils. The Notre-Dame-des-Landes airport project is a stark example of land use designed at the expense of the biological richness of the site and its endangered species. In April 2014, thanks to the work of environmentalists, the European Commission had not failed to put the French state on notice, concerned about the non-compliance with European legislation on the subject. With this report, MEPs therefore reiterate their vigilance: any new EU European strategy can only be more ambitious and coherent. We will not accept the Commission's proposal for a downward revision of European legislation.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the mid-term review of the European Union's biodiversity strategy. Progress in blocking the degradation of biodiversity around the world has so far been insufficient; only 23% of species and 16% of habitats can be considered in good condition. Positive results have been recorded for the common fisheries policy and for the control of invasive alien species, but the situation remains worrying particularly in the fields of agriculture and forestry.  The observation is clear: the current dynamics will not achieve the 2020 targets. That is why we need to redouble our efforts. Stronger political will is needed to make biodiversity a priority, involving as many actors as possible and giving an important role to local and regional actors. In particular, we call for improving the application of existing legislation, integrating biodiversity into the common agricultural policy, taking the necessary measures to protect pollinators or developing a trans-European green infrastructure network (TEN-G). Finally, adequate funding and political coherence are essential to the success of these objectives.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which expresses Parliament's concern about the continued loss of biodiversity and which shows that the targets set for 2020 will not be achieved unless further efforts are made.  The 2011-2020 Strategy sets out six main objectives: the full implementation of the Birds and Habitats Directives; the maintenance and restoration of ecosystems and their services; increasing the contribution of agriculture and forestry to the maintenance and improvement of biodiversity; sustainable use of fishery resources; combating invasive alien species, and strengthening the EU's contribution to preventing biodiversity loss globally.  The report estimates that only considerable progress has been made with respect to the objectives of fisheries and invasive alien species, while in others they are insufficient. It therefore calls on the Commission to submit to Parliament two annual reports explaining the situation, the reasons for non-compliance and the strategy to ensure its future compliance, and calls on both of them to urgently give greater priority to meeting the 2020 targets and greater financial support for biodiversity protection.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to phase out environmentally damaging subsidies by 2020. The text also calls on the Commission and Member States to approve without reservation and facilitate the transition to a circular economy. I also voted in favour of provisions that draw attention to the negative effects that neonicotinoid pesticides can have on pollination and therefore calls on the EU executive to maintain its ban on the use of these substances. With regard to shale gas, which was also discussed, I supported the paragraph which urges Member States not to authorise new hydraulic fracturing activities in the Union under the precautionary principle and the principle of taking preventive measures, taking into account the risks and negative impacts on climate, the environment and biodiversity and the shortcomings observed in the European regulatory framework in this area.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it is one of the best documents reflecting the realities of today. In Europe, almost a quarter of wild species are endangered and many ecosystems are in a deplorable state. In this context, the resolution calls for greater attention to be paid to soil conservation, encourages Member States not to grant authorisations for any new hydraulic fracturing operations in the European Union, and stresses that the CAP's financial resources must not be used to subsidise environmentally harmful activities and to channel funds to finance sustainable agricultural practices.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Biodiversity has an incalculable intrinsic value in itself and therefore must be protected for the benefit of current and future generations. The progressive trend towards biodiversity loss is alarming and urgent political priority needs to be given to environmental issues, without neglecting the crucial role of regional and local actors in the process with a view to meeting EU biodiversity targets. In Europe, close to a quarter of wild species are on the verge of extinction and many of our ecosystems are deeply degraded, causing enormous environmental, territorial, social and economic damage to the EU.  I therefore consider it essential to promote greater public awareness, as well as greater promotion of investment in these areas, in particular in terms of the preservation and conservation of biodiversity. Because it is a matter that deserves increased attention and particular care and because I agree with the measures put forward by the rapporteur, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mid-term review of the European Union's biodiversity strategy for 2020. This text provides an assessment calling for additional, substantial and ongoing efforts to achieve the 2020 targets.  It is true that the EU is lagging far behind in the implementation of its objectives, especially since habitat degradation and destruction, particularly due to climate change and unsustainable consumption patterns, are the main causes of biodiversity loss in Europe. To better address these challenges, the first step is to better integrate all local and regional actors to develop a coherent biodiversity policy that takes into account territories and socio-economic activities. The objectives are therefore to continue the full implementation and implementation of the nature directives, to develop a trans-European network of green infrastructure and above all to initiate the transition to a circular economy.  Finally, I would like to stress, as this report does, the contribution of the agricultural and forestry sector to improving biodiversity.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy because its content reviews each and every one of the six objectives of the Strategy, stressing the need to improve the implementation of all legislation aimed at stopping biodiversity loss, in particular the Habitats Directive and the Birds Directive. It also underlines the need for Member States to make an effort to better integrate environmental legislation into other areas, such as agriculture and forestry.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
