text: Written. Unfortunately, the mid-term review shows that there is still a long way to go before the EU has achieved the targets set in 2011 in the 2020 Biodiversity Strategy.  It is therefore important for the Commission to raise the level of implementation and cross-cutting coordination. The problem is neither funding nor lack of legislation, but control of member states' enforcement. The Commission must take on its task and ensure that we achieve the targets for 2020.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report, as agriculture and forestry are also sufficiently appreciated as important guardians of biodiversity. Both sectors play an important role in Germany in general and in my federal state of Saxony-Anhalt in particular and contribute to the preservation of our cultural landscape.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Written. \u2012 Modern nature conservation is based on the principle of adaptive management. The natural values we see today are the product of the management of the natural resources we have had. It is extremely important that the administration is adapted to actual changes and to reality. That flexibility is lacking today. We have rigid legislation which, in practice, means that we must invest time and resources on species that do not need greater protection, while there are species that are currently being hunted but which, from a scientific perspective, should not be hunted. It's serious. The possibility of amending the directives' annexes on endangered species must be introduced reasonably quickly and without having to amend the entire directive. Wordings that the European Commission must review what should apply when adapting the Species and Habitats Directive to, for example, economic and regional conditions are inadequate.  However, this is generally a good report, and although I would have preferred other wordings in paragraphs 65 and 66, which would be more open to a review so that regional considerations can be secured, I choose to vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it calls for better implementation of relevant legislation to halt biodiversity loss, mainly the Habitats and Birds Directives, while requiring improvement in the implementation of these policies and giving great attention to the agricultural and forestry sectors. The report also notes that Member States and the Commission should focus on curbing biodiversity loss in Europe, warning that the 2020 targets in this area cannot be achieved unless Member States and the EU actually make a serious bet in this regard.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report voted on today concerns the mid-term review of the European Biodiversity Strategy, adopted by the EU in 2011 to halt biodiversity loss and ecosystem degradation by 2020. Biological diversity is a pillar of our economy and well-being, so I supported Parliament's resolution expressing concern at the lack of progress towards achieving the objectives set, and calling for better implementation of the current law. I believe, in fact, that there is no need for a revision of the directives on the protection and conservation of nature, but for the more efficient application of this legislation, and a more productive use of existing funds.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – The preservation of biodiversity is a concern that must be present in all Union policies with a direct or indirect impact on the terrestrial and marine environment. To achieve this goal, we must ensure an approach that includes all relevant actors and sets clear goals. The preservation of dwellings or genetic conservation are examples of objectives that require strong collaboration between science, industry and citizens, and it is necessary to promote the ideal conditions for this to occur effectively. The evaluation of the European biodiversity strategy is an opportunity to correct the march where it is needed and to survey the needs of what is still to be done. Despite some positive developments, the data we have also show that we need to do more and more quickly to avoid losses to nature that may prove irreversible. It is necessary to strengthen the means available for better implementation, ensure that all sectoral policies incorporate biodiversity objectives and rethink new areas of activity to avoid fragmentation and enhance the achievement of these objectives.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe in the importance of preserving nature reserves and natural habitats for wildlife in Britain and in Europe. However, we believe that this task should be a national, not European, responsibility, and we will therefore oppose new EU legislation in this area. Nevertheless, we will support all amendments aimed at improving the existing legislation on this issue. We believe that the best people to decide on natural habitats in Britain are the British people. We do not trust the unelected EU Commission to decide on the protection of the environment and animal welfare. The EU has caused irreparable damage with its environmental policy. It has destroyed our fish stocks and caused widespread deforestation with its policy on bio-fuels.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Biodiversity conservation and promotion is reflected in EU legislation, which is continuously committed to further strengthening the Convention on Biological Diversity and its implementation. In this context, unflagging political engagement is particularly important not only at the level of EU legislation, but also at the regional and local level of the Member States, as they have the greatest potential and opportunities to inform and raise public awareness of biodiversity. The preservation of biodiversity, in addition to the obvious environmental benefits, is also of very clear economic importance, especially given that 1 in 6 jobs in the EU is to some extent dependent on nature and biodiversity, as reported in this report. It is worth noting that agriculture plays a very important role in this context, which can be both extremely beneficial and harmful, in the absence of compliance with certain standards. Appropriate, sustainable practices in agriculture can make a huge contribution to the conservation and protection of habitats, the containment of land degradation, the rational management of water resources, which can lead to an effective fight against climate change and the development of favourable consumption patterns while at the same time having important educational functions in relation to that part of society that does not come into contact with nature and agriculture or forestry on a daily basis.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the full implementation of the Nature Directives is a necessary precondition to achieve the 2020 biodiversity target. The protection of the Nature Directives should ensure that the fitness check is not used as an excuse to water down or weaken the legislation, something which I am committed to and which will safeguard the biodiversity of the greenspaces and rural areas of the West Midlands.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing \ u2012 Nature is vital for a person who is dependent on it and associated with it. The protection of nature and biodiversity must be part of EU policies. It is encouraging and motivating that targeted efforts and investments in nature and biodiversity are indeed a success. On the other hand, overall, the situation continues to develop particularly pessimistically and worryingly. Further measures are necessary. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ Biodiversity enables maintaining the biological balance of all living things on Earth. It is important to emphasize the fact that biodiversity has both great economic and social value. The consequences of climate change call on us to be vigilant and have a high dose of concern, as the balance in this area is irreversibly disturbed. As a Green/ESS MEP, I supported a European Parliament resolution calling for more decisive action and preventing possible serious consequences for biodiversity. I believe that the focus should be on solutions closely related to nature conservation with the aim of promoting the importance of the forestry and agricultural sectors, which would not only allow for the guarantee of security of supply of quality and diverse food, but also to positively affect the restoration of ecosystems and the mitigation of climate change and the prevention of a 2 degrees Celsius increase in global temperature.  Biodiversity loss also marks an economic cost to society, as 1/6 of jobs in the European Union are directly dependent on the state of biodiversity. Member States should invest more and step up efforts to encourage innovation by creating green jobs, which would contribute to reducing unemployment, increasing biodiversity and preventing major climate change.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ over the last 25 years, the EU has built up a network of 26 000 protected areas covering more than 850 000 km2 (Natura 2000) on its territory. I appreciate that the EU has a natural interest in addressing these protected areas and preventing the continued loss of biodiversity. I consider biodiversity to be crucial not only because it is important for human health, but also because it provides extremely important social and economic value. I believe that targeted and adequate funding for biodiversity will not only help us to halt the process of biodiversity loss, but will also make a significant contribution to the creation of new skills, jobs and business opportunities. I am convinced that, even with the resolution adopted, we will be able to create new opportunities and opportunities that will strengthen this important programme more effectively and effectively with further long-term measures. I supported the resolution, but I expect the Commission and the EU Member States to examine much more closely in the coming period the measures that should be implemented on an ongoing basis in the area of development cooperation in order to minimise potential adverse effects on biodiversity, and, if not met, will also impose sanctions on violators.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The report relates to the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy issued by the Commission in October 2015. The report welcomes this mid-term review and stresses its strategic importance for achieving the EU's biodiversity objectives.  Scientists have so far demonstrated that European nature has been in a much worse state without the positive impact of the EU Birds and Habitats Directives, and that planned and properly funded efforts are indeed delivering positive results. However, I believe that there is still a lot of potential for improvement and that the 2020 targets will not be achieved without significant additional and sustained efforts.  The report calls on the Commission and the Member States to give greater priority to achieving the 2020 targets as a matter of urgency. I agree that, in this context, funding, greater awareness and greater public understanding of the protection of biodiversity and support for biodiversity are also essential.  The report also calls on the EU to reduce its footprint on biodiversity worldwide, in line with the principle of PCD, so that it is within the ecological constraints of ecosystems. I believe that the report reflects well the current situation in the area of biodiversity in the EU and that it contains the necessary warnings and proposals, which is why I supported it in plenary.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Biodiversity itself has enormous value that needs to be protected for the benefit of future generations and biodiversity is also beneficial for human health and implies social and economic value.  The social and economic opportunistic cost of not meeting the main biodiversity target is estimated at EUR 50 billion per year. Biodiversity policies should fully comply with the principle of subsidiarity in order to fully respect regional differences in landscapes and habitats.  I therefore welcome the mid-term review of the biodiversity strategy and the 'State of Nature' and 'SOER 2015' reports, and would highlight the strategic importance of these reports to achieve the EU biodiversity targets.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy. I join the concerns raised in the report regarding the continued loss of biodiversity and the conclusion that the 2020 targets will not be achieved without significant additional and sustained efforts.  I think that we can all be concerned together about the fact that in Europe about a quarter of wildlife is at risk of extinction, and many ecosystems are damaged, causing serious damage to society and the EU economy. As we need to tackle the problem seriously as soon as possible, I welcome the call for a multi-stakeholder approach with an essential role and full involvement of national, regional and local actors in this process.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Environmental protection is a primary objective for us, our positions and ideology allow us to do nothing but assist every effort to protect Nature.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that biological diversity is key not only because of the narrowly understood environment, but also because of its welfare, health, job creation and economic impact. An important basis is the 2015 mid-term review, in which the European Commission concludes that the steps in this area are insufficient. During the plenary debate on this report, I explained that while we consider the relevant legal context to be good, there are errors in implementation. I have said that when we close the gap, we must pay particular attention to governments, because they always find economic and political reasons to feel exempt from obligations. In this case, however, unfortunately, the resources spent on biodiversity conservation can be considered a waste of money. I believe that desecration of nature should be seen as a desecration of human dignity. I believe that the investigation of such cases should be carried out at EU level, even if these areas concerned involve aid suspensions. I consider it important to put the EU's birds and habitats directives into effect immediately, and there can be no further delay in this! Furthermore, I believe that reasonable support and encouragement of environmentally friendly or organic farming methods is recommended, provided that we can ensure adequate food supply.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 In the mid-term review of the biodiversity package voted on today, it was easy to sign up to the concerns and threats raised in the evaluation. From a natural point of view, it is quite unambiguous. The state of biodiversity is extremely worrying both in the EU and worldwide. In the EU, three quarters of habitats are in poor condition and species loss persists. With some positive exceptions, the overall picture is bleak and the direction is deteriorating. However, we do not believe that there is a need for a new framework or legislation; This will best contribute to the implementation of the principles of biodiversity in the future as well. For these reasons, we could not accept this assessment in the final vote.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the Mid-Term Review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy. The report assesses the objectives achieved since 2011, which are unfortunately not positive. The results are not reassuring: we are continually losing biodiversity and degrading our ecosystems. The report does not imply any amendment to the Habitats and Birds Directives as they are directives that lead to positive results where well implemented. In view of the negative results, the report calls on the Member States to enforce the existing regulations more closely.   Two important points have been made in connection with this report. The first is the call for Member States not to authorise new hydraulic fracturing operations in the EU, on the basis of the precautionary principle and preventive action given the risks and negative impacts on climate, the environment and biodiversity. The second point calls on the Commission to maintain the ban on the use of neonicotinoids thanks to continuous scientific evidence showing that these pesticides are harmful to essential activities such as pollination and natural phytosanitary control.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Biodiversity conservation is one of the European Union's strategic objectives in the field of environmental protection. The European Parliament presents an own-initiative half-term report to assess the situation in this area and draw the necessary signals on the various problems that persist. Priorities identified by this year's report include prioritising the achievement of the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, as well as providing more information to the public with a view to raising awareness of the issues and including all decision-makers at European, national, regional and local level. Significant measures in this area include encouraging farmers through the common agricultural policy to respect biodiversity, as well as protecting the marine environment, avoiding the introduction of invasive species, protecting pollinators, combating deforestation and supporting research and innovation.  The main problem, however, remains the implementation of existing regulations. This is why there is a need for better coordination of national policies and better enforcement of European legislation through the use of proportionate penalties. An integrated approach to all these issues is needed through appropriate regulation in all related areas. In order to preserve genetic diversity, it is also important to introduce the basics into the educational systems of the Member States. The current strategy is just the first step in the right direction.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Sad observation. The constant loss of biodiversity is of great concern. The 2020 targets will not be met without additional, substantial and ongoing efforts. Certainly, the scientific evidence has shown that nature in Europe would be in much worse shape without the positive impacts of the European Union's Birds and Habitats directives, and that, therefore, efforts that receive sufficient funding produce concrete results. However, this is clearly insufficient and many improvements are possible.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the own—initiative on the midterm review of the EU’s biodiversity strategy. By doing so, I underlined together with my colleagues that unless it significantly steps up its efforts, the EU will not attain the objective it set itself to halt the loss of biodiversity and restore it as much as its services working on ecosystems can by 2020.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 Degradation and destruction of natural habitats due to changing land use, land grabbing, climate change, unsustainable consumption patterns and the exploitation of marine resources are among the most important factors causing biodiversity loss in the European Union and around the world. We need to identify certain elements that define the state of biodiversity in a given area or region and to support a rational and sustainable use of resources. It would be good to link international commitments on biodiversity to climate change strategies. We must make our economy more efficient and encourage a reduction in consumption so that we can reduce our dependence on natural resources, particularly those from third countries.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. I supported the Commissioner's Report because he draws attention to important issues relating to nature. According to him, the most important factors and causes of biodiversity loss within and outside the EU are land use change, which is linked to the dispersion, degradation and destruction of animal habitats, as well as marine use habits that are incompatible with the principle of marine development and exploitation. In this context, it is necessary to distinguish and establish indicators that unambiguously and scientifically assess the status of biodiversity in a given zone or area and maintain a wise and sustainable use of resources, as in the EU, as at global level. Reducing a more sustainable economy and over-consumption may in the future reduce the EU's dependence on natural resources, especially those from outside Europe. This is an important issue, because we must remember that almost a quarter of wild animals in Europe are threatened with extinction, and many ecosystems have been affected by degradation, which threatens serious social and economic losses in the EU.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the mid-term review of the biodiversity strategy. Since biodiversity constitutes a unique blend of ecosystems, habitats, species and genetic diversity on Earth on which man is extremely dependent and since itself has enormous value that needs to be protected for the benefit of future generations, I express serious concern about the continued loss of biodiversity.  Also, nature and economic development are not mutually exclusive and I believe that sustainable economic growth should be encouraged and proactive measures taken to protect and better manage the environment. In my view, the proposed urban planning initiatives can ensure a carefully designed use of space and adequate protection of the Natura 2000 network, as well as the preservation of open spaces, in particular by selecting livestock farming as an alternative to the abandonment of agricultural land.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy, as the fact that the loss of biodiversity and the disintegration of the ecosystem are among the 10 biggest risks we will face in the future is very worrying.  Given that the strategy so far has not yet shown an impact, I agree that it is necessary to step up the EU's efforts to prevent biodiversity loss. Only through better implementation and enforcement of existing legislation, greater integration, transfer of good practices and innovative solutions will we help and protect interventions in nature. As a result, they take care of the heritage, well-being and well-being of children and grandchildren.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy because its content reviews each and every one of the six objectives of the Strategy, stressing the need to improve the implementation of all legislation aimed at stopping biodiversity loss, in particular the Habitats Directive and the Birds Directive. It also underlines the need for Member States to make an effort to better integrate environmental legislation into other areas, such as agriculture and forestry.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, I could not support Mr Demesmaeker's report in the final vote because a passage prohibiting shale gas exploration was artificially implanted in it. I absolutely do not agree with the constantly repeated precautionary principle in this area. Only the future, research and demand are supposed to decide whether, what and under what conditions to benefit. As regards the protection of bee colonies , here I was very happy to support the sustainable development of this agricultural sector. If damage to the nervous system of bees resulting from the use of pesticides has been shown, these substances should be reduced as far as possible. If the point on hydraulic fracturing could be rejected, I would like to support the whole report, unfortunately paragraph 88 was adopted, so I abstained.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ 65 % of EU citizens live within 5 kilometres of a Natura 2000 site, and 98 % live within 20 kilometres. These numbers show the sheer importance of biodiversity for the lives of European citizens. There is no doubt that the protection of our natural habitats and species has to be a top priority both for national and regional governments and the European institutions.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The report on the mid-term review of the EU's biodiversity strategy considers that efforts have been modest and ultimately regrets that the flexibilities granted to Member States may have limited the proper application of the directives cross-referencing this theme ("habitats", "Birds", etc.).  It is also regrettable that the issue of biodiversity is argued by a socio-economic integration of the issue, the loss of biodiversity is then identified at a financial cost. The vital aspect of the environment for man rooted in his space is obviously not defended in this text. However, the whole text remains consensual and does not impose excessive demands on Member States.  Finally, the importance of reconciling respect for the environment and economic development is often recalled, a laudable pragmatic approach. So I voted for this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Biodiversity, the unparalleled diversity of the Earth's ecosystems, habitats, species and genomes, of which man is a part, is invaluable in itself. Biodiversity loss is particularly harmful and a loss to nature, people and the economy: it threatens the necessary ecosystem services and undermines the earth's natural resilience, which allows us to find solutions to emerging problems. In its 2014 global risk assessment survey, the World Economic Forum cited biodiversity loss and ecosystem collapse as among the top 10 risks. I voted in favour of the document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy because its content reviews each and every one of the six objectives of the Strategy, stressing the need to improve the implementation of all legislation aimed at stopping biodiversity loss, in particular the Habitats Directive and the Birds Directive. It also underlines the need for Member States to make an effort to better integrate environmental legislation into other areas, such as agriculture and forestry.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I stress that biodiversity loss leads to extremely high economic costs for society, which have so far not been sufficiently integrated into economic and other policies. I stress that political will at the highest level is essential for the conservation and loss of biodiversity; I believe that the implementation, enforcement and further integration of existing legislation into other policies is of paramount importance; in particular, I call on the regional and local authorities of the Member States to provide information and awareness of biodiversity.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: Writing. – Biodiversity is a serious threat both globally and in Europe. It is increasingly affected by climate change, consumption growth, increased use of transport and energy resources. Human activities result in increased environmental pollution, increases CO2 levels and species disappear. Surveys show that more than 80% of Europeans are concerned about biodiversity loss, which requires responsible environmental policies. The preservation of biodiversity is important for the health, well-being and well-being of both us and our children and grandchildren. Often, on a daily basis, we do not think about how dependent we are on valuable ecosystem services such as fresh air, clean water, raw materials that we use, for example, in the construction of our homes.  I believe that sustainable financing mechanisms for the protection of biodiversity should be provided in the future. Of course, investment in nature and biodiversity requires money, but if we do not act responsibly, the losses that will be caused in the future will be much greater. We must therefore do everything to prevent the primary causes of biodiversity loss and to integrate biodiversity into sectoral policies, including agriculture, forestry, fisheries, energy and transport.  In my opinion, the report adopted today will help to achieve the objectives of the EU Biodiversity Strategy and will protect against the loss of biodiversity, thus keeping the planet as unsailable as possible for future generations.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which contains recommendations in order to meet the objectives included in the EU's biodiversity strategy 2010-2020. I voted in favour because the mid-term review of this strategy shows that the Union is about to seriously fail in achieving its biodiversity targets if no improvements are made. Biodiversity losses have been increasing at an alarming pace, with more than three quarters of the important natural habitats being in an unfavourable state and a quarter of all species threatened with extinction. I think it is important to step up efforts in the protection of our biodiversity by strengthening and better implementing the ambitious EU legislations instead of watering them down. I am positive because in cases where these laws have been enforced they have had tremendous results: the EU Birds and Habitats Directives, for example, has brought back threatened birds and wildlife from the brink of extinction.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The report sets out the European Parliament's proposal for the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy by 2020. The report highlights the need to halt biodiversity loss and degradation of the European Union's ecosystem services by 2020, and to restore them as much as possible, so that the participation of local and regional actors is essential. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I am absolutely committed to protecting the biodiversity of Wales. To achieve this, I am also committed to protecting the EU Nature Directives and I will work to ensure that the fitness check is not used as an excuse to water down or weaken the legislation. Therefore I was happy to vote in favour of the Environment Committee’s report on the Mid-term Review of the EU’s Biodiversity Strategy. I believe this report upholds the integrity of the EU Nature Directives. The biodiversity of Wales is far too precious to the people of Wales to be risked.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I abstained on this report, not because I am against biodiversity, but because this report does not pay the least attention to farmers. Although the report calls for all actors to be brought around the table to promote biodiversity, I have the feeling that the farmer has been left behind. The European Natura 2000 programme has only been partially implemented in the Member States or a new European programme, the Trans-European Network for Green Infrastructure (TEN-G), will be implemented as early as 2017.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 In the mid-term review of the biodiversity package voted on today, it was easy to sign up to the concerns and threats raised in the evaluation. From a natural point of view, it is quite unambiguous. The state of biodiversity is extremely worrying both in the EU and worldwide. In the EU, three quarters of habitats are in poor condition and species loss persists. With some positive exceptions, the overall picture is bleak and the direction is deteriorating. However, we do not believe that there is a need for a new framework or legislation; This will best contribute to the implementation of the principles of biodiversity in the future as well. For these reasons, we could not accept this assessment in the final vote.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. After the failure of the EU's previous strategy against biodiversity loss by 2010, the Commission adopted a new strategy in 2012 which the European Parliament is assessing as implementing mid-term. We all know that species continue to disappear at a high rate, raising fears of mass extinction of species all over the world, including in the EU. Biodiversity is still highly threatened everywhere, especially by human activities. The report put to the vote of the European Parliament calls for opposition to the review of the various "Nature" directives, calls for the full integration of this biodiversity strategy into the CAP, the evaluation of the "greening" of the said CAP and the strengthening of the Natura 2000 network.  I am more than reserved about other measures such as the "natural capital financing mechanism", which is supposed to guarantee projects on biodiversity and which is mainly akin to green washing by which companies restore their reputation by financing which eco-friendly projects are profitable. Nevertheless, I voted in favour of this report, which is certainly lacking in ambition but nevertheless makes interesting and important proposals, the least of which is not the reaffirmation of the application by the Commission and the Member States of the precautionary principle for GMOs.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The European objective of halting biodiversity loss failed in 2010. So the Heads of State or Government, through the development of a new strategy in 2011, defined a new global target as halting biodiversity loss and the degradation of "ecosystem services", to restoring them "as far as possible by 2020", and intensifying EU efforts to prevent the degradation of global biodiversity. In 2015, it became clear that, without significant additional efforts, the EU will once again be able to achieve its agreed biodiversity targets by 2020. The report therefore focuses on the target biodiversity strategy, calling for better implementation of all relevant legislation in order to halt biodiversity loss, mainly through the Habitat and Birds Directives. The report opposes the possible revision of the Nature Directives because of the possibility of jeopardising the implementation of the Biodiversity Strategy and states that the ongoing REFIT verification of the Nature Directives should focus on improving their implementation and implementation, proposing additional measures that the Commission and the Member States should take into account to halt biodiversity loss.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I support this report, as nature conservation is a prime example of the issue that needs to be better dealt with at Community level, and because environmental protection is also a homeland protection.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy because it underlines the importance of a holistic approach to protecting biodiversity in the fields of agriculture and the environment. I also agree with the view that it is essential to raise the awareness of European citizens at local and regional level through awareness-raising initiatives.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the european Parliament's motion for a resolution on an EU biodiversity strategy. This strategy is an important element of the European Union's overall strategy for the environment, society and the economy. In order for the strategy to enter into force, the Heads of State or Government have set a basic objective to halt biodiversity loss and degradation of ecosystem services. I agree with the proposed strategy formula, which is based on six pillars, which are the different objectives: full implementation of the Birds and Habitats Directive, maintenance and restoration of ecosystems and their functions, increased contribution of agriculture and forestry to the maintenance and strengthening of biodiversity, ensuring the sustainable use of fish stocks, combating invasive alien species and increasing the EU's commitment to preventing the loss of biodiversity worldwide. The adopted report also envisages the implementation of additional innovative solutions, e.g. the ten-g trans-European GI network, which can bring mutual benefits to society, the environment and the economy.  According to the Eurobarometer on biodiversity, at least 8 out of 10 citizens stress that the impact on biodiversity loss is serious. Research also shows that citizens want to receive information on this issue systematically. As has rightly been pointed out, nature and biodiversity are of great importance to citizens. I agree with the argument that biodiversity and the environment must be at the heart of an intelligent, sustainable and integrated Europe.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has always promoted higher levels of environmental protections across Europe that Member States would have been unable to provide on their own. Part of the drive towards sustainability must run through guaranteeing the protection of our natural habitats both within Member States and across borders. The natural environment is part of our rich cultural heritage which is of concern to me as a member of the Committee on Culture.  As a representative for the north west of England I represent vast areas of national parks, Sites of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) and Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty (AONBs). I also work very closely with environmental organisations who I know will be pleased with our work on the strategy. Labour MEPs are committed to protecting the EU Nature Directives and will work to ensure that the fitness check is not used as an excuse to open up the Birds and Habitats Directives in order to water down or weaken the legislation. This is why I voted in favour of the Environment Committee’s report on the mid-term Review of the EU’s Biodiversity Strategy.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the own-initiative report on the mid-term evaluation of the EU Biodiversity Strategy. Biodiversity, today under enormous pressure, both globally and in Europe, is essential for our health and well-being, but also for our economic prosperity. European efforts to end the decline in biodiversity in 2010 have failed. For this reason, the EU developed a new strategy in 2011. The rapporteur advocates a greater political will to effectively address the decline of biodiversity as a political priority and considers that a multi-stakeholder approach is needed, in which local and regional actors play a special role.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 2 February 2016, a vote was held on mark Demesmaeker's report on the 'Mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy', a report by the European Commission on the implementation of the EU Strategy for 2020 on Biodiversity. The european biodiversity strategy for 2020 aims to halt the loss of biodiversity and the degradation of ecosystem services and restore them as much as possible by 2020 and contribute to preventing global biodiversity loss. There is no doubt that biodiversity must be protected, as it affects the sustainability of ecosystems of which man is an integral part. Mark Demesmaeker's motion for a resolution was sufficiently balanced and properly pointed to issues of concern in the EU biodiversity strategy. Unfortunately, in its final form there is a provision on the prohibition of shale gas extraction. I believe that there is no reason to believe that shale gas extraction carries a greater risk than other industrial activities. In the vote on the report as a whole, I did not support its content for the sake of this provision.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the EU Biodiversity Strategy, which realistically describes the situation at European level, while making substantial recommendations to the European Commission and the Council. Whether we like it or not, we must recognise that European commitments to protect biodiversity have repeatedly failed. Without significant efforts, but also political will, the EU will once again miss the 2020 target. The numbers, unfortunately, speak for themselves. The implementation of existing legislation and, above all, enforcement control, are essential conditions for achieving substantial progress.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. For Spain, biodiversity protection is a matter of great importance and significant efforts have been made; that is why we are the country that contributes the most to the EU's Natura 2000 Network. In addition, Spain's efforts to protect the marine environment are widely recognised and we also collaborate in the EU Biodiversity Strategy with the declaration of ZECs (special conservation zones) and in the policy on the protection of genetic resources (Nagoya Protocol). I believe that the implementation of the legal framework on biodiversity has been very positive in Spain and does not need any changes, as this would mean a reversal of the EU strategy for Spain. I therefore believe that the solution could be to make improvements in its implementation, as I defend that the EU Biodiversity Strategy is very good.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has published a report on "The mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy until 2020", which assesses the results achieved since 2011, in the implementation of actions and in the implementation of the planned targets. Overall, there is no significant progress on the key objective of 'halting biodiversity loss and ecosystem degradation in the Eu ropean Union by 2020', according to the report.  Last December, the Council agreed to improve the implementation of the sectoral directives (Habitats Directive and the Birds Directive), in particular: a more effective integration of biodiversity into other sectoral policies, in particular the common agricultural policy (CAP), a more targeted use of existing financial instruments, greater attention to international strategies, the urgent need to raise awareness and involve all sectors of society and all levels of government, and finally greater exploitation of the environment. , including economic services, ecosystem services.  This report strongly reiterates the need not to amend the Habitats Directives and others relating to the protection of biodiversity and supports the idea of better implementation of existing legislation.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 Biodiversity, i.e. the diversity of ecosystems, species and habitats, is extremely important for humans. It provides a number of ecosystem services, such as clean air or water, which we cannot do without. That is why I have decided to support this report. I agree with the challenges contained in the document. Biodiversity is under considerable pressure in today's globalised and technical world. I believe that it is more than necessary for Member States to make additional efforts to meet the objectives that the EU has committed itself to in 2020.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 Biodiversity, or diversity of life on earth, is a universally recognised value that is crucial for ensuring quality of life. At the same time, Eurobarometer surveys show that the population of the European Union is not indifferent to the deteriorating state of biodiversity. That is why Parliament has proceeded to assess the biodiversity situation in the mid-term of the European strategy. I think that this was the right step, which will hopefully be a sufficient reminder of the fact that what has been done and achieved so far is definitely not enough. The report therefore talks about a much greater effort to halt the overall trend of biodiversity losses, as well as better implementation of existing legislation and the inclusion of biodiversity among the main priorities. At the same time, the rapporteur rightly pointed out that economic development and nature conservation are not mutually exclusive; As I believe that nature should be preserved and improved for future generations, I supported the report in the final vote.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the vote on this report, which was the European Parliament's response to the EC's mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy in 2015, I abstained. While the overall direction of this report is correct and I agree with it on many points, the content of Article 88 calling for a total ban on the use of hydraulic fracturing by Member States is unacceptable. Biodiversity and ecosystem sustainability are not only an ecological issue, but also have an economic dimension, as the existence of one in six jobs in the EU depends on nature and the clean environment. These include, in particular, industries such as agriculture and tourism, which from the Polish point of view are key sectors of the economy. However, such far-reaching proposals as preventing shale gas extraction could jeopardise the energy security of Polish and many countries in our region in the future. This is all the more unacceptable as there is no convincing scientific evidence of the environmental harm of the hydraulic fracturing method. Economic development is largely dependent on its own and cheap energy. Poland has great potential for shale gas extraction and must be able to take advantage of these opportunities. In the face of the EU's decarbonisation policy, we cannot accept another reduction in our energy independence.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mid-term review of the Biodiversity Strategy because it agrees that biodiversity and nature must be central in a smart, sustainable and inclusive Europe, and because the document call for greater political will to genuinely end biodiversity loss as an essential measure for the very nature and health and well-being of our children and grandchildren. Also because he agrees with the rapporteur, when he points to the development of a trans-European green infrastructure network (TEN-V), which could create a win-win situation for nature and the economy; for advocating a European framework for the prevention of biodiversity loss and ecosystem services; calling for the Commission to draw up specific criteria for the "Natural Capital Financing Facility", which should ensure that projects produce positive and tangible results for biodiversity; because, by establishing the link between health and biodiversity, argue that the decline in the number of bees requires more research and action; for also believing, finally, that nature-based solutions can contribute significantly to addressing challenges such as climate change.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. – The European Commission, having carefully assessed the results achieved since 2011 on biodiversity, has published a report reviewing the actions necessary to achieve the objectives set with the adoption of the EU Biodiversity Strategy, in force until 2020. According to the document's data, there is no significant progress on the key objective of halting biodiversity loss and ecosystem degradation in the European Union by 2020.  The report pushes for the directives that are concerned with protecting biodiversity not to be amended, confirming that these rules, where well implemented and implemented, can produce significantly positive results. In addition, there is agreement on the urgent need to raise awareness and involve all sectors of civil society and all levels of government more closely, in order to promote and enhance an ecosystem-conscious economy. In the document, which I voted in favour of, Parliament expressed its opinion, in accordance with a recent Council ruling, promoting better implementation of the sectoral directives (with the Habitats Directive and the Birds Directive) and calling for the issue of biodiversity to be more effectively integrated with that of other sectoral policies, in particular that of the common agricultural policy (CAP).

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. The conservation of biodiversity plays an important role in the sustainable development goals. However, current indicators point to biodiversity loss. I therefore supported the report, which rightly concludes that better implementation and enforcement of existing legislation are essential for progress in this area. Policymakers at all levels must work constructively together. It is necessary to draw attention to the socio-economic value of biodiversity and to the consequences of its loss on health, well-being and well-being.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Explanations of vote shall be terminated.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The minutes of the previous session are approved.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Madam President, I would like to speak on a personal level, because some things have been heard here which are not true. In support of the proposal to add the issue of increasing racist hatred and violence to the agenda, Mrs Zimmer used as a justification that an anti-racist march was made in Athens last week by the Golden Dawn People's League. Either they didn't convey to her what happened in Athens, or she lied. Because in Athens it was an anniversary of honour and remembrance for three Greek hero officers, who died in 1996 in Imia, and this event of course the government of SYRIZA banned it.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Sir, we're recording this information.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for a joint discussion on: - the statements of the Council and the Commission on the emergency of refugees, external border control and the future of Schengen (2016/2259 (RSP)," - Council and Commission statements on compliance with the international principle of non-refoulement (2016/2535 (RSP)), - council and Commission statements on funding the mechanism (2016/2525 (RSP),) and - statements by the Council and commission on the resurgence of racist hatred and violence against refugees and migrants in Europe (2016/2563 (RSP)).

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank you for the possibility to discuss with you this afternoon what is I think the most pressing problem the European Union is faced with, namely to find effective operational and common answers and to build trust within and between our societies regarding the refugee crisis in the world, and the consequences for the European Union more specifically. 2015 saw the arrival of more than 1.8 million irregular migrants to the European Union, and more than 1.25 million applications for asylum were registered. The flow of refugees, the loss of life and the abuse by smugglers are a human tragedy which took the European Union and the Member States aback. We should continue to provide a safe haven for those in genuine need of international protection, and at the same time it cannot be denied that the large numbers of migrants place considerable strain on our societies and on European cooperation. I think this is specifically true of the sense among many in our populations that this issue is not under control and that it is not managed sufficiently. Frontline Member States – those along the Western Balkan route and the destination Member States – have been particularly affected by these events. It is clear that no single Member State is able to tackle this crisis on its own. Only with a combination of actions, executed in a coordinated way, can we manage the situation. We need common European solutions to tackle this crisis, and all Member States need to take their responsibility. We have said this before, and we know that time to address this crisis is running out. We have to manage the situation better before spring, when large numbers of migrants are expected to take to the seas to reach Europe and possibly be killed en route. The influx of migrants must be reduced, and our measures should not only aim at the short term but also at the longer term. The Council therefore insists that we continue our joint efforts aimed at reducing the influx, better managing the situation in our Member States, and implementing the decisions taken at the highest level. Yes, we need to strengthen our external borders work, work with Turkey to make sure the agreements we made with them are implemented, ensure that the hotspots function properly, including registration and return, and make credible progress in our cooperation with third countries on readmission and return. Some irregular migrants have no right to international protection and are unlawfully abusing our asylum systems. We should, furthermore, start implementing the relocation decisions properly and do further work on tackling the root causes of migration. There are some positive signs. At the moment, four hotspots are operational. Italy has declared two additional locations as operational, while a third one is ready for operations. Moreover, Italy has reported that all disembarkations are now running via hotspot locations, and registration and fingerprinting is at 100%. In Greece, despite continued high arrivals, work has been able to progress significantly on two additional locations. However, concerns remain on the timeline of the other locations. We commend the actions taken by Italy and Greece, yet efforts must continue unabated, not only by those frontline states but also by all the other Member States in supporting them, notably by responding swiftly and positively to the requests for assistance by the EU Civil Protection Mechanism and the calls for experts by agencies such as Frontex and EASO supporting these states , and by swiftly implementing the relocation decisions. On relocation: certain Member States are successfully relocating groups of migrants and experiencing growth and new spreads among the migrants. However, only 400 applications have been relocated, and the number of Member States which have not yet pledged any places is high. It is not acceptable that decisions adopted by the Council and Parliament are not implemented by all Member States. More should be done to relieve the pressure on Italy and Greece. All Member States must participate in the relocation. The Presidency started this week to have bilateral consultations with all Member States that have been lagging behind with pledges on relocation, resettlement and personnel towards EU agencies. As a final note on this topic, I would like to highlight the threat to the humanitarian situation along the Western Balkan route. As arrivals remain high and temperatures have dropped, efforts and coordination must increase further in order to prevent further loss of life, specifically the commitments to provide fully winterised reception. Capacity should be fulfilled as soon as possible, especially taking into account the increased controls along the different borders on the route and the partial or potentially complete closure for migrants wanting to continue north. At present we are discussing intensively with all these countries to avoid further humanitarian disasters. In line with the conclusions of the December European Council, the Presidency is fully committed to contributing to the implementation of all the necessary measures to safeguard and maintain control over the Schengen external borders. The Presidency is striving to address in particular the implementation of rules aimed at managing migration effectively and ensure European integrated border management of the EU’s external borders. Following up on the Council’s request to rapidly examine the recent Commission Border Package proposal, the Presidency immediately scheduled a series of meetings of the relevant Council preparatory bodies to carefully examine these proposals. Particular focus is put on the European Border and Coast Guard proposal and the amendments to the Schengen Border Code providing for systematic checks on persons enjoying the right of free movement at external borders. Given the scope of the proposals and their critical importance, work has been divided between several Council bodies in order to accelerate the examination. The Presidency can already confirm that the Member States are committed to a productive debate on the text of the proposals and a clear focus on achieving results. Substantial progress has already been made. EU Interior Ministers discussed these issues at their informal gathering in Amsterdam last week and the Council will come back to this issue at its forthcoming meetings on 25 February and 10 and 11 March. The Presidency is committed to ensuring the best and closest-possible cooperation with Parliament on these proposals, since it is convinced that these proposals must lead to tangible results as soon as possible in the light of the current crisis. On the future of Schengen, the scale of the migratory flows which have crossed the European external borders over the past months has seen several countries temporarily re-impose border controls: Germany, Austria, Denmark, Norway, France and Sweden. This temporary re-introduction of border controls is in line with the Schengen acquis, subject to conditions involving a serious threat to public policy or internal security and limited in time. The migration pressure has not decreased and the Presidency considers that the Schengen area without internal borders is only sustainable if the external borders are effectively controlled. A series of measures are being put in place to address the issues identified by the European Council in December. The Presidency is strongly committed to securing the integrity of the Schengen system, a system which is at the heart of the European project and one of the greatest achievements of European integration. The principle of non-refoulement is a cornerstone of international refugee law, and I appreciate your wish to raise this important issue. On this matter, particular reference should be made to Article 33 of the Geneva Convention of 28 July 1951: ‘No Contracting state shall expel or return a refugee in any manner whatsoever to the frontiers of territories where his life or freedom would be threatened on account of his race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion’. The same principle was fully integrated in the EU acquis. Let me recall in particular that the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights guarantees the right to asylum in Article 18 and the prohibition of refoulement in Article 19(2). Furthermore, Article 78 of the Treaty on the functioning of the European Union provides for the creation of a Common European Asylum System in accordance with the Geneva Convention and in compliance with the principle of non-refoulement. A number of legislative instruments adopted to implement that provision reflect the same concern. Therefore, EU Member States need to abide by the provisions of the asylum acquis and to respect the principle of non-refoulement in accordance with their international obligations. As far as the definition of a safe country of origin is concerned, it can only apply where the competent authorities are sure that the person seeking international protection will be treated in accordance with the principle of non-refoulement in the third country concerned. This principle should guide us when examining and negotiating the Commission proposals for a regulation on an EU common list of safe countries of origin. It should also be recalled that the Schengen Borders Code stipulates that the rights of refugees and persons requesting international protection, in particular as regards non-refoulement, should be respected when applying the code at the EU’s internal and external borders. One last word to mention is that an effective return policy is also an important feature in a balanced migration and asylum policy. The Council has recalled the importance of effective return and readmission policies, which should be implemented with the utmost urgency by all Member States and enforced in a manner consistent with the acquis. The Presidency will be very proactive, very concrete and very operational in taking this forward in full respect of the fundamental rights and dignity of the persons concerned and the principle of non-refoulement. With the above principles in mind, we will do everything necessary in order to improve the functioning of the Common European Asylum System. We look forward to starting the examination of new Commission proposals such as the revision of the Dublin Regulation, which should be presented shortly. We believe that such proposals, taking fully into account the cornerstone principles of our asylum policy such as the principle of non-refoulement and the current reality of migratory flows, should contribute to making Member States’ asylum systems more efficient. All EU Member States share the same fundamental values and have a shared responsibility to welcome asylum seekers in a dignified manner, ensuring that border surveillance is carried out without prejudice to the rights of persons requesting international protection. In that sense, we have a stress test, so to speak, when we talk about our European values. In particular the Council emphasised the importance of complying with these fundamental rights in EU asylum and migration policy at all stages, from the arrival of migrants and asylum seekers in the EU to migrant and refugee integration and the return of those with no right to remain. It stressed the need to ensure humane and dignified treatment and to reinforce the protection of fundamental rights. The fundamental rights of migrants and notably their protection from racist and other hate crime is very much our concern, and we strongly condemn all manifestations of hatred and violence against refugees and other migrants. However, we should also realise that small groups of individuals are responsible for these attacks. They do not represent the general European populace or European values – there are enough examples throughout Europe of refugees being welcomed and supported. We understand that the high influx of migrants raises concerns among parts of the European population. These concerns need to be taken seriously. However, violence is never the answer. The Ministers of Justice discussed this at a meeting last October and last December and agreed on a number of actions to improve the fight against hate crime, in particular hate crime against migrants. This includes specific attention for the reporting and recording of hate crime, as well as cooperation between civil society, law enforcement, the judiciary and assistance to victims. Action is generally needed in all these areas, but special attention should be given to migrants, as they might not so easily find the right bodies to help them if they are victims of racist or hate crime. This is also a topic of substance for the Dutch Presidency, and we have therefore today decided to organise a conference, together with the Council of Europe, on ‘EU fundamental values, immigration and integration: a shared responsibility’. It will also be the focus of the Council’s annual debate on the rule of law, and I would like to say here that when I listened to the debate this morning, that is a debate where everybody has their obligations – asylum seekers, migrants, populations of countries where people move to – in the same way. We have a stress test, as I said, at the moment on this issue because there are so many concerns raised in our societies. Finally, the Council concluded in October that one of the priority actions for the judicial authorities with regard to the migration crisis would be to ensure that, throughout the migration and asylum chain, including any administrative and judicial proceedings, the rights and best interests of children are protected. With you, I would like to express my concern about the reports by Europol’s Chief of Staff that at least 10 000 unaccompanied children have disappeared after arriving in Europe. The media indicated that many of them might have fallen into the hands of organised crime syndicates. This is shameful and we should be outraged and do something about it. It needs to be further investigated, obviously, and we need to get the facts and figures straight. This has not yet been discussed in the Council. However, if it is true, the thought obviously sickens us all. Unaccompanied children are among the most vulnerable groups, and it is deeply troubling that professional gangs might exploit them. In general it is important that EU Member States cooperate to prevent children falling into the hands of thugs. Finally, a word on the state of play regarding the Refugee Facility for Turkey and its financing. You will recall that European Union leaders in October and November 2015 committed to providing an initial EUR 3 billion of additional resources to support Syrians under temporary protection and host communities in Turkey. Following that commitment, the Commission adopted, at the end of November 2015, a decision setting up an instrument, the Refugee Facility for Turkey, in order to coordinate the provision of humanitarian development and other assistance to refugees and host communities. This facility would require a total amount of EUR 3 billion in 2016 and 2017. The annual amount foreseen in the EU budget for all external action programmes is around EUR 9 billion. Therefore, the full financing of the facility from the EU budget would put a strain on all other programmes and actions. In order to fulfill the Union’s commitments, and pending final agreement, Member States envisage contributing to the financing of the facility for up to two thirds of the required amount. Member States’ contributions would be calculated through a distribution formula based on their gross national income. The Commission has already identified the split between the years 2016 and 2017 for the remaining part from the EU budget and the sources for 2016. Member States are currently examining various aspects linked to the setting-up of the facility, including the governance of the facility and the conditionality framework to be respected. These aspects are of paramount importance in order to ensure that the financial efforts to be assumed by the EU and the Member States lead to really effective support for the refugees in host communities. The Presidency is committed to facilitating swift approval of the facility and will keep the European Parliament informed on the progress. You can count on us to make sure that on all these issues we are at the stage of making things happen. I think that is the most important task for the Presidency, with the Council and with the Commission. Decisions have been taken. It is now most important to make sure that they are put into practice.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I must start by thanking you for giving the Commission the opportunity once again to discuss the migration challenge with you in plenary. The sooner we deal with the situation on the basis of the twin principles of shared responsibility and solidarity, the better we, as the European Union, will do. As long as everyone is waiting for the others to move first, and as long as some continue to act as if it will all go away if they just close their eyes long enough, then things will only get worse. A consistent and coordinated European approach put into practice urgently is the only way ahead. Next week, ahead of the February European Council, the Commission will report on the implementation of the priority actions under the European Agenda on Migration. We will be frank and objective about the poor progress we see on the ground today and about what needs to be done in the next days or weeks. This concerns both the Member States on the front line and all the others, and both the external and internal policy dimension. On the external policy level, we need to gear up our cooperation with third countries on addressing root causes and on fighting smugglers, to establish safe passage for those in need, and to make sure return and readmission are the reality for those who have no right to stay in Europe. On the internal policy dimension, the to-do list is even longer: relocation, resettlement, hot spots, returns, joint operational measures taken by Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). We continue to provide substantial financial and operational support to our frontline Member States to that end, but the scale of the problem of irregular migrants flows reaching Greece and entering the Western Balkans continues unabated. The Commission is putting every effort into achieving normalisation of the Schengen functioning and, in parallel, is preparing for all options. But let me repeat clearly: this is not about the end of Schengen or cutting off a Member State. Today the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) has issued a press release. The numbers are dramatic. Thirteen times more people crossed the Mediterranean in January 2016 in comparison to January 2015. 368 people died during the first month alone, although many more were saved through our joint operations. But every life lost is one too many. The European humanitarian tradition, of which we should be proud, must be maintained even in times of crisis. Saving lives and the principle of non—refoulement are not negotiable. Today the Commission adopted a Schengen evaluation report on Greece, after receiving a positive opinion from the Schengen Evaluation Committee. The report, which is a classified document and will be shared with this House according to the usual rules, is based on unannounced site visits conducted in November 2015. Serious deficiencies were identified in this report in external border management by Greece. We are, however, taking note that Greece has already started undertaking efforts to remedy the deficiencies, and the Commission will continue its support for Greece. Greece will not be left alone to address the challenges that are related to the migratory pressure. In parallel, we are working closely with Turkey to bring order into migratory flows and help to stem irregular migration in the Aegean by implementing the EU—Turkey joint action plan. Recently the First Vice—President, Mr Timmermans, discussed with our Turkish counterparts how we can step up our cooperation to fight smugglers and address the growing numbers of non—Syrians irregularly crossing to the European Union. Our Turkish counterparts also informed us about opening up segments of the Turkish labour market to allow Syrian refugees to work. The Commission is working closely with both the Greek and Turkish authorities to scale up the returns to Turkey under the existing bilateral agreement, awaiting the full entry into force of the EU—Turkey agreement. We are exploring with Greece what further support it needs to be able to systematically return those migrants who do not have a right to stay in the European Union. Let me recall, as Commissioner Hahn will stress, that Turkey is making commendable efforts to host more than 2.75 million refugees at a cost of EUR 7 billion to date. To support Syrians in Turkey, the European Union has committed to providing financial assistance for an amount of EUR 3 billion over 2016 and 2017 to provide humanitarian, development and other assistance to refugees and host communities. Further down the stream, we have the Western Balkans route. This has been a key priority for the Commission and we are chairing weekly coordination meetings. Migrants should always be given the opportunity to apply for international protection, but if they choose not to do so or if it emerges that they are not in need of protection, they should be returned swiftly to their countries of origin or to transit countries. This will always be done subject to a prior non—refoulement and proportionate check in accordance with international law. Non—refoulement is an essential, basic safeguard and a legal obligation that we owe to each and every refugee. However, this principle is not incompatible with our efforts to ensure the much more effective return of illegal migrants throughout the European Union. We need to systematically and rapidly return those who are not in need of international protection if we are to build public trust and focus resources on the reception of genuine refugees. But we must also do more to promote legal channels of protection for those in need, such as resettlement measures. The more we can provide credible and effective support to those in need of international protection, the less they will feel the need to take the route of irregular migration. Let me conclude with a brief comment about the surge of racism and xenophobia towards migrants and refugees. It is my main worry and it did not come as a surprise to me. The Commission condemns without reservation what appear to have been mass sexual assaults on women in Cologne on New Year’s Eve, but it is too simplistic to conclude that all refugees and migrants are threats to our public order. They are not. And those fleeing from horror and war deserve our respect even more than anyone else. We therefore strongly condemn all forms and manifestations of intolerance, including public incitement to racist or xenophobic violence or hatred. It is clear that we will need to step up our efforts here too. The European Union is facing a crisis like no other before. Either we stand firm and find solutions in line with our values or we will see ourselves and our Europe change beyond recognition back to a past that no one wants to experience again.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioners, I would like to thank the Commissioners for their excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to thank the Commission because the issues on the table, the legislative proposals that are on the table, have been presented by the Commission at a very rapid pace. The agreements with Turkey, the reflections on safe third countries, the quota, the revision of Frontex, quota solutions – all the texts are available, and the Commission has worked very, very well on this. We have no problem with ideas, we have a blockade, especially in the European Council and also somewhat here in Parliament. We saw this at noon today, when the President of Estonia spoke and first pointed out the importance of solidarity in Europe – that everyone has to bear their burdens. There was applause, mainly, I have to say, from the left. When he then said that we must activate border protection, that we must protect Europe, there was applause from the right. And that is precisely our problem: we have a blockade. It must now be possible for us to overcome precisely this blockade towards the European Council, to simply take a step towards each other. If 250 000 people have now died in this war in Syria, 40 000 of them children, then this continent – east or west or north or south – must say: we must help. When a total of 60 million people in this world are on the run – 60 million people – then it is clear to everyone that a simple door-on policy – we welcome everyone – cannot work either. The two sides belong together. We must finally overcome this blockade, we must come together on this issue. The way is actually so short to understand these two things and bring them together. What is at stake? There is a lot at stake, namely the Schengen issue. Of course, if Europe does not agree on this issue, there will be more Swedish and Danish examples, there will be more border controls, there will be closures in this continent. And that is why it is a damn lot, which is why this step of overcoming the blockade must finally be taken. Once you consider what tasks have been solved in recent decades, our continent has been led from the confrontation between East and West to reunification. Today we live in an open Europe, we have overcome the euro crisis to some extent with two per cent growth, and we have set an example for the world on climate change in Paris. We can achieve a lot! And if, on the basis of these historical comparisons, we also look at what previous generations of politicians have done, we must tell the Heads of State and Government for the discussions in two weeks' time that it would be a historic failure for this group of current Heads of State or Government if they do not succeed in taking this joint step together now! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which For us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, there are three honest answers to these questions. Firstly, as I have already mentioned, border security. That is one of our expectations of the European Council, that borders must be guarded and that honesty also means that people at borders are also said no when people come without visas and without refugee backgrounds. Secondly, we must strengthen our authorities. If the head of Frontex says that if he has Frontex officials on duty there in Greece, he cannot currently consult the Schengen Information System, because we, as legislators, have stipulated that Frontex should not be allowed to use the Schengen Information System, then we have exaggerated it with data protection. That must be made quite clear. We need confidence in our authorities. Data protection is there to protect citizens, but not to protect criminals. Last but not least, to Cologne: all violence must be rejected. This also applies to violence against refugees – clear to the sun. But if people who are here as guests who have guest status because they claim protection during a period of civil war in their home country, the expectation that these people will not abuse the guest right, that they accept the culture and laws of a country, is not too much. That is why it must also be clear that if someone does not respect the culture and also the laws of a country, the host country, he must then leave that country again. These are principles that our citizens expect of us and which we must also clarify in the discussions. (Applause)

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we should say, with great realism and concern, that there is a bad wind in Europe. Neo-Nazi raids in Sweden and Germany in recent days, shameful calls by political leaders to shoot refugees and even children, all this tells us that a virus is infecting Europe, the virus of fear. Nor do I agree with the carrot-and-stick theory of refugees. Neither stick nor carrot! There is only one word and one duty for refugees: reception! Because they're not people who want to come and turn our lives upside down. They are people who are fleeing the same danger that attacks us, they are people fleeing war. Too many taboos have been broken in recent months: Schengen, the duty of humanitarian assistance, respect for human life. And in this House, therefore, we can no longer just discuss legislative matters, but we must re-discuss values, because we are here because we belong first and foremost to a community of values.
