If those values are no longer there, there is no longer this community and there is no point in keeping the European institutions alive either, because those institutions make sense if they are held on to the values of the European Union. That's why I make this speech.  Mr Koenders and Also Commissioner Avramopoulos mentioned the story of the 10 000 children. But is it possible that no one talks about this, that no one thinks about this? Let's think about the danger, but what? What are refugees, refugees, at risk of? About what? This must win, this cursed fear that is keeping its hands tied to those who have to decide, because the problems are on the table, the European Commission has put them. We agree, Mrs Weber, on strengthening control at the external borders. We agree on identification, we agree on relocation. What prevents this system from working? I say what prevents it, it prevents fear, fear that has been exaggerated, that has been fomented, that has been fuelled in recent months! This is our greatest danger, which is liquefying the European Union as a community of values. That's why my speech stops there. It stops at the theory of values, because this issue is fundamental, otherwise it will never work, Mrs Weber. If we do not come back here, if we do not tell our Heads of Government, our Heads of State: do not be afraid, you will not lose votes, you will not lose support if you show that the system works and the system can work. And be ware, it's not a phenomenon that's being governed in a few months. There are already flows affecting Eastern Europe, affecting Finland and other Eastern European countries. There will be more flows in the spring. So either we put this system in place or we fail. That is why my appeal is not so much an appeal to this dossier or this other dossier. All this is the result of a sharing that is either there or is not. The sharing of values for which we are Europeans and are members of the European Union.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, another Strasbourg, another debate about the migration and refugee crisis, another season beckons. As we look forward to spring, usually a season for optimism, it now becomes a season for concern. As the snow melts, as the Mediterranean becomes passable and as the crisis reaches an epic scale, are we really ready to find solutions that work? Some suggest letting everyone in from every country; others suggest the EU take over all border management; others again suggest sealing all borders and turning Europe into a fortress. We need to get away from this debate of polarisation and get to work on tackling the problems. I know that Mr Verhofstadt has warned the media that he is about to bring up comments made by a Member of my group. Let me be quite clear: we will look into those comments and we will discuss it with my group with due process this afternoon. But I am disappointed at this trying to put politics above trying to solve this crisis. My group has been consistent in our approach to this crisis since it began. We do not have months or years to rewrite the rule book; we have only a few weeks to help those in need and to regain the confidence of our citizens. Compassion can only be delivered when our rules are firm, fair and clear. Schengen rules say that the external border of the EU should be protected. If Member States cannot manage their borders, then we should offer them help through Frontex, but we should not force help on democratically—elected governments. Let us be clear: if you cannot play by the rules that you sign up to under Dublin and Schengen, do not be surprised if others want you out of the game. The rules only work if non-EU countries live up to their agreements too. What can we do to make sure that Turkey, already struggling to cope with refugees from Syria, is not merely seen as a transit country? What about countries such as Pakistan that have signed readmission agreements but are slow to take back their citizens? It is time to get tough with these countries to live up to their responsibilities. The Dublin Regulation is clear that, in most cases, the first safe country is where people apply for asylum, but Dublin has failed, because one leader opened her country to everyone, regardless of whether they were fleeing persecution or simply seeking a better life. It has failed because the first countries that refugees and migrants arrive at are unable to cope. Dublin does not need to be completely rewritten; it needs changes to make it work better and to make sure refugees remain in the countries offering them asylum. In order to stabilise the situation in the short term and focus help on genuine refugees, let us agree which countries can take refugees and how many, not impose it upon them. Let those countries that cannot take refugees help with money, equipment, boats and personnel to assist in border protection, processing and returns. But they should not simply wash their hands of the problem and expect others to pick up the bill. As the Mediterranean becomes a route for traffickers again this summer, let us not abandon Italy and Malta to fend for themselves. In the EU we are never short of grand plans and great schemes, but now we need pragmatism and action: action to deliver resources; action to implement legislation; action to generate political will. So let us not seek to completely rewrite the rules. Let us implement the rules we already have. Let us cooperate to stabilise the crisis and let us focus on helping those genuinely in need, genuinely fleeing persecution or war, in the short, the medium and the long term. (Applause)

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Madam President, first of all I want to thank Mr Koenders, because you have rectified what the leader of your party, Mr Samsom has said. He has proposed a plan, and I have to tell you, you have contradicted it, and I am pleased that you have contradicted it. Not by mentioning it, but by saying and defending the principle of non-refoulement and also by defending the fact that every refugee who comes has to have individual treatment, and there cannot be a collective push-out of these people. So thank you very much for that. Mr Kamall, you attacked me before I said anything – OK, fine. But you disappoint me, because what the chairwoman of AfD has said is outrageous and a disgrace for the European Union. She said that it is acceptable to shoot at people to stop refugees. And then you are saying: ‘Oh, we are going to look into this statement’. No, you have to condemn this statement of the AfD! That you have to do, I believe. (Applause) And then my third point, Mr Avramopoulos, and to Mr Koenders, is about the content. I think we are on the wrong track. We are not going to solve the problem in the way we are dealing with it, because it does not work. Commissioner, you are saying: ‘Yes, the Greeks are making improvements’, but you should look at the Commission’s own assessment. Two days ago, three days ago, last week, the Commission presented an analysis of the border controls between Greece and Turkey, and it does not work! People are not registered – that is one of the reasons that there are thousands of young refugees, and that is the reason for the Europol analysis and document. People are not kept in the right conditions. There is no distinction made on this border between economic migrants and refugees. It does not work. So our proposal is very simple: you have to use Article 78 of the Treaty, which gives you the possibility to take emergency measures and to take over the border, and to create a rapid response force – that is in fact what you want with the European Border and Coast Guard – and to send people there. It is Europe which has to do the task. It is a little bit too easy to say: ‘Yes, yes, they are going to make improvements. We are going to make recommendations to the Greek Government and within three months we are going to see’. Within three months there will again be 300 000 refugees coming to Greece. It is not working! You have to take your responsibility: use Article 78. Mr Koenders, that is a decision that can be taken by a qualified majority in the Council immediately, on 18 February. Instead of talking about all the requests by Mr Cameron, maybe take that decision. That is more important for the European Union than all the requests of the British Government. (Applause) And so you have to do it. If you do not do it, the mess is going to continue. It is Europe which has to organise these reception centres on the border with Greece, together with the Greek authorities. Greece cannot say: ‘Oh, it is a loss of sovereignty’. No, the outside borders are our common sovereignty, it not only Greek sovereignty. And the second thing to do – and that is also what do you need to do on 18 February, Commission and Council – is to decide to improve the conditions in these refugee camps. People are living there on USD 7 a month. How do you give food to your children, how do you pay your for housing, your clothing, with USD 7 a month! Instead of giving EUR 3 billion to Erdoğan, use that money to give direct assistance in the refugee camps. Organise it and help the United Nations to organise it, and I am pretty sure that if they receive not USD 7 a month but USD 70, 80, 200 a month for a family, they can organise themselves in an appropriate way. It is because the people do not have even the means, the money to buy food, housing and clothing that they are coming to Europe. That is the second thing to do. Use the EUR 3 billion, not to give to the Turkish Government, but to help inside the refugee camps in Turkey, and also in Lebanon and in Jordan if possible. Those are the two decisions, the game-changers. It is not by waiting months now, waiting for a new Council in March, that things are going to change. It is now on the 18th, now or never to make a change in this fundamental crisis and to show that Europe can manage it. Because do not look to the Member States – they will start a race to the bottom. Tomorrow they will close the borders, and the day after they will say: ‘OK, we are going to change this legislation on asylum seekers’. It is not the Member States, it is Europe which has to show that they can manage it, and you have to do it. (Applause)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, tackling the refugee crisis, Mr Koenders and Mr Avramopoule, requires stronger and more effective European cooperation, not an à la carte Europe that wants agricultural subsidies or the Structural Funds for infrastructure for Poland, Hungary, Slovakia, but does not want the implementation of the common European decisions to tackle the refugee crisis. And, of course, such a Europe, which respects its signature in the United Nations Geneva Convention, can have nothing to do with a return to the nationalisms, xenophobia, racism and disintegration of Europe pursued by far-right extremists.  Greece and Italy need more solidarity and European help to control European external borders rather than turning into easy scapegoats. Two days ago I read the following sentence: "Any country in the European Union that was in Greece's position would have the same problems. Greece has asked for help and we must support it," said Fabrice Leggeri, frontex's director general. Four months ago in this Chamber someone said 'Europe is the baker in Kos who distributes bread to refugees and European citizens who welcome refugees to Munich station', was Jean-Claude Juncker. This must be Europe and not the AFD president, Mr Kamall, who is calling for refugees to be shot at the border, and not the fascist far-right who are chasing black people at Copenhagen station.  And because several have discovered that the problem is Schengen and are calling for the abolition of Schengen or less Schengen. Less Schengen means no Schengen, and a collapse of Schengen would be a huge loss for both the Republic and refugees and the economy. The reintroduction of border controls will be a disaster for Europe and because many are talking about implementation – 'It's the implementation, stupid' – they decided in September to relocate 160 000 refugees, proportionately. What is the application? Four hundred, you told us today. Can Europe go ahead like this? Of course, Greece has already made significant progress – as we speak – in relation to the report at the beginning of November and we are confident that in March, when you evaluate, we will have completed the commitments made by the country. But you too must honour the commitments, ladies and gentlemen of the Council and gentlemen of the Commission, in order to have a more effective and democratic Europe that solves the problem of refugees, which is not a Greek or Italian problem, is a European problem. Otherwise, xenophobia, racism, the extreme right, a return to nationalism and the break-up of Europe will win.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Let me put a positive point against what has now been invoked here. Not only at my home in Germany and in my narrower home region, but also on Greek islands, Hungary, Stockholm or the United Kingdom and France, tens of thousands of citizens are volunteering to deal with this so-called refugee crisis. What began with Angela Merkel's decision last September, in my opinion, has led to the strengthening of the European civil society that has always been invoked. And they do their job in the knowledge – indeed, Mr Weber – of all the problems, all the contradictions that need to be addressed. But they do it because they want to solve this challenge. They don't push themselves, they move mountains!  And the phenomenon that I find increasingly serious from debate to debate is that this civil society does so much without any pathos, and that political debates are only so dripping about pathos, but the European Council in particular – and this is what these very citizens who are so committed to find so frightening – seems more and more like a body in which many are actually just seeking to escape from responsibility. It is important to talk about this before the next summit. This betrayal of civil society, which is more serious by the day.  The fact that we all found this decision by Angela Merkel last September surprising is one thing, but the other is that this decision has begun a period for the European Union in which we have stopped simply pushing ourselves away from the problems that have grown around us. The crisis outside the EU in the east and south will not pass quickly. The experience of the Minsk agreement is a foretaste of what is flourishing in these Syria negotiations and how long it will take. That is why, as Europeans, we must prepare ourselves to deal with these problems, which we always discuss only as acute problems, in the long term. Before the European Council, my group is calling for the Council to concentrate on four major steps and then to deliver on them. Words and deeds must be reconciled, because we must convince – on the one hand, the European citizens and, on the other, people fleeing the crisis outside the European Union. We believe that generous resettlement agreements with the UN are the most important European measure, which must no longer be talked about, but must actually take place. We are convinced that investments such as those that are now under discussion with regard to Turkey must be made even more generously and that what Mr Verhofstadt says is a move in the right direction. We cannot simply keep the refugees alive, but we must enable them to live where they first flee in their home regions. Those who do not follow this seriously fail in their approach to better management. We are certainly convinced that the distribution of refugees within the EU must finally be based on solidarity, and we expect the Council to make a difference, otherwise we will not be able to make progress. My fourth point concerns borders: we too are in favour of better managed borders. We too are in favour of European responsibility now being assumed in Greece together with the Greeks. But we know that these borders, these external borders, cannot be hermetic.  We are appalled that there are debates about shooting possibilities, shooting orders – especially in Germany! At this point, we are certainly looking for the challenge with those who, on the right wing of the European debate, are only using the refugee debate, the Schengen debate, to actually destroy the foundations of European integration. For overcoming borders has been the overcoming of war and detriment. Anyone who simply wants to upgrade borders– even within the EU – will return to the deconstructions of the last century, and the European Union should be strong against this.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, European governance of migratory flows is a complete failure. Faced with a vital challenge to its survival, the European Union shows its true face. Its inadequate response is made up of anti-solidarity and national self-interest. We continue to deal with the migration crisis blindly, starting from the effects without ever dealing with the causes. We never talk about the causes. What are the causes? The large European countries, on the one hand, help to create problems, with arms sales, support for warring factions, exploitation of the resources of the countries of origin of the flows, and then, on the other hand, they try to stop migratory flows by protecting themselves and raising all kinds of barriers to stop migratory flows.  Then it is good, as Pittella said, to start from values. So why not turn to the PD, which is in government in Italy, and propose to stop, to put a stop to the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia, which then uses them in the war-fighting factions in Syria, which causes the migratory flows, and then proposes to solve the problem that it itself causes, together with the other countries that also sell arms , and therefore proposes unlikely solutions. It is a perverse game in which incapacity and lack of will are combined. Unfortunately, the protection of the economic interests of multinationals takes precedence over the protection of life and fundamental rights. Then we have to give a semblance of humanity, we must show the citizens how much governments care about the fate of their citizens. So what do you do? Via Schengen, so we protect public safety. But then we have to take cover, because it would damage the single market, the single currency, and then there is a fear of a mini Schengen fort between the countries of Northern Europe. Or what do we do? Let us give EUR 3 billion to Turkey, even though we are aware of the violations of fundamental rights taking place on Turkish territory, so that we discharge responsibility outside Europe's borders.  The proposals of the 5-Star Movement continue to be those we have been presenting from the beginning: stop arms sales, review of energy and economic policies, amendment of the Dublin Regulation, compulsory relocation of migrants among all 28 Member States of the European Union. Let's start with the causes and then look at the effects.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Europe is overwhelmed by asylum seekers who are a danger to our society, our security, our culture and our freedom. At all costs, the European elite wants to stick to the dream of a European Union without borders where there is room for all. This is a terrible nightmare, because in 2016 the free movement of people and goods was transformed into the free movement of terrorists, asylum seekers and Kalashnikovs. A nightmare, because millions of fortune seekers make the crossing towards free home, free care and free money.  You are concerned about the demise of Schengen and other treaties of political prehistory, when you should be concerned about the demise of Europe. I'd say wake up! Schengen is bankrupt! The European Union is a fiasco! Listen to our people fed up with your policy of open borders. My appeal to the Dutch Presidency, to Mr Koenders sitting here today: close the Dutch borders! Protect the Dutch! Protect our freedom, our security and our future!

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Madam President, the causes of the influx of migrants are well known. First of all, it is the disorganization, with the help of the West and the United States of America, of countries like Iraq, Syria and Libya. It is then the air appeal that constitutes the rhetoric of the European Union and certain Member States or certain political forces which, precisely, constantly call, for ideological or political reasons, for more migration to Europe, and Mrs Merkel's call has been heard. But just now Mr Pittella and Mrs Harms gave us extremely moving speeches, except that if Mr Pittella and Mrs Harms go home and find migrants who have unwittingly entered their homes, I think they will call the police and close the locks on their doors twice, as well as the shutters of their windows.  It is also the laxity of the European Union, because it is always said - it is a purely verbal incantation - that those who do not have the right to be considered political refugees , and that is the vast majority of migrants, my dear colleagues, you know well, must return to their country of origin. Ah, how interesting! In my country, for example, France, it has been proven by one of our highest financial and judicial institutions, the Court of Auditors, that 95% of asylum seekers, whose applications have been carefully considered for months, years, with all kinds of levels of appeal, remain in France or, when they are taken back to the border , for example, at the Franco-Belgian border, they returned the next day to the country from which they had allegedly been deported.  The principle of non-refoulement is absurd when it applies to countries that are safe. Therefore, neither Article 33 of the Geneva Convention nor Article 19 of the European Charter prevents the return of people who come from safe countries and who come to us only for economic reasons.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, today I could repeat the same speech I said in December, or in November, or in October, or in September. We are a Parliament trapped in time. There would only be something that would be different. Today there are more dead than in December, more dead than in November, more than in October, more than in September. And another thing is different: they have also managed to cross more people, thirty thousand alone in the month of January. Worst of all, I think this debate today is not going to do any good either, which we are not going to solve today either. Citizens are beginning to think we can only talk. And even that is not true, because we repeat ourselves; we don't talk. And to repeat yourself is not to talk. We still have a lot of things to do, too much work we haven't finished. We have not yet launched the new European Border Agency. We still don't know how to finance the money we want to help Turkey with, and without Turkey we can't solve the problem. We don't have a common immigration policy yet. We remove the borders between our nations, but we still have twenty-four different immigration policies. We have not yet agreed that those who come to share our rights must also share our duties, also share our values, share our tolerance, and share the importance we place on gender equality. We have a lot to do. Addressing the consequences of the problem is useless if we don't attack the causes. Look, it's not true that Germany, France and Belgium no longer have borders. They have borders. They're in Greece. Germany's borders are guarded by Greek police. Either we are able to understand that everyone's politics have to be resolved among all, or in the end, nations will hide again behind their private borders. Look, it's not true that those who cross the sea do it by looking for our lifestyle. They do so by fleeing war and death. Either we are able to stop the war or millions of people will find death seeking salvation. Look, it's not true that Europe is failing with the refugee crisis. Some politicians are failing, who believe that it is European to receive aid but not to help. Either we are able, in the end, to deal with the problem as it is or Europe will get out of hand because of populist politicians. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Do you not think that European citizens are waiting for the European Union institutions to finally take decisions– not only talking, talking, talking – considering this migrant crisis? And do you not also think that our institutions should have to address the Arab countries, the Muslim countries, the Gulf countries, that should also have to take migrants because they belong to their world as well?

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: "blue card" response. – I believe, my dear colleague, that the European institutions are making decisions. It is the Member States that are not implementing them.  Being a refugee is not an election; is the salvation of those who no longer have a choice. This should be understood by some Governments of some Member States. I believe that the Commission understood this from the beginning of its mandate.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Dear Sirs. More and more Europeans are afraid of the migrant crisis. Up to 2,000 asylum seekers enter the Union every day. What happens when spring comes? What approach do we want to take towards a transit route through countries of the politically unstable and economically highly crippling Western Balkans, through Slovenia and beyond? Of the five hotspots in Greece, only one currently operates. They are working to move and return people, an action plan with Turkey. It is high time that these policies started working. Even if the Geneva conference brings a solution for Syria, we cannot expect peace tomorrow. The latest shocking report by Europol finds that it is not clear where tens of thousands of unaccompanied children have gone. The trail for half of them was lost in Italy, at least by tens of thousands in Sweden. Guesses about where and how many might end up are horrific. It is about children and action must be taken immediately. The Union is not in control of the migrant crisis. They're not a number problem. We are talking about a half-second million refugees in the Union, which has 500 million people. It is not true that this cannot be managed, but someone in the institutions must finally take political leadership. When Slovenia, my country, entered Schengen, it, like a number of other countries, saw a new face of Europe – a Europe that opened up in the most visible way possible. And now this Europe is closing in the most shameful, low-key way with national egoisms.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: – Madam President, my message is a simple one in a very complex situation: rules must be applied and implementation of those rules must be a priority. Current systems have been paralysed through inaction, unwillingness and ad hoc decision-making, and it is time for the EU to show our voters, and those seeking to come to the EU, that ours is a fair, but firm, system. We can only gain control if we start applying the rules on the basic principles we have long advocated. If we look for magic solutions which take years to implement, the situation will only further spiral out of control. We must fingerprint all those arriving; this cannot be optional, as it appears at the moment, but a compulsory requirement for anyone seeking to stay in Europe. Member States must come together to guard their external borders, and if a Member State cannot, or is unwilling to do this, then it must accept help from Frontex. Then we must return those who do not qualify for asylum. We must remove the administrative and practical obstacles which currently produce a pitifully low rate of returns. Member States need to stop pushing off the problem and understand that their contributions as well as assets are needed. Even though it needs review, Dublin must maintain its core principles and relocation should be the second-stage process. If countries cannot control the external border or its internal border or provide humane facilities and decent treatment, then participation in Schengen must be reviewed, and I believe that we have most of the tools we need. All we need now is for them to be used and enforced with courage and determination. May I just refer to the remarks of Mr Verhofstadt a few minutes ago? Mr Verhofstadt, really, you know, you must not be hypocritical. You can condemn another group and its leadership in relation to the remarks or behaviour of a Member, but you should not do so until you also condemn the behaviour of one of your own Members in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), when the EPP Vice-Chair was not only abused but also insulted at a meeting recently. Mr Verhofstadt, put your own house in order before you start lecturing others about theirs.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for We are facing a major crisis which requires a great deal of effort. The citizens want solutions, they want an end to Europe's flight from responsibility. And what this escape from responsibility looks like, the Council has brilliantly explained here. I quote what the President-in-Office of the Council has said here: 'Decisions have been taken; it is now a matter of implementing them," you said. One decision for you was as follows: the Council has decided to set up a number of meetings of the competent preparatory bodies in order to carefully examine what is stated in some of the documents presented by the Commission. At this rate, with this attitude, we will not be able to cope with this crisis! It is high time for the Member States to assume their responsibilities. The Council must drive the Member States. What we see in the Member States is scandalous! Greece – Mr Papadimoulis is right, there are only 400 refugees out of the 160 000 distributed, and he is right. But there is also an excuse for Greece to pretend that it does not need to make any major efforts. We have a grand coalition in Berlin that is losing itself in the dispute; the citizens are catching up with the failure of the state in Germany. This cannot continue! There is a fear situation in the population. Fear is making citizens mad, and this fear must finally stop by solving this crisis. The solutions are obvious: we need a common coastguard, we need common border management, we need a rapid aid force based on Article 78, we need a common right of asylum and migration, we need funding for UNHCR and World Food Programmes, we need shuttle diplomacy from Mrs Mogherini. There are many things we can do. Let us finally do it!

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Greece must better protect its external borders. So, apart from the fact that Greece has 13 676 kilometres of sea border and 1200 larger islands – I am not talking about the smaller ones – I ask you what you actually want with it and what you imagine, what Greece should do. For with a view to Greece, my question would be this: should the Greeks, who are currently helping to rescue thousands of refugees and for that reason receive no solidarity at all from the majority of the Member States, who send refugees back in their boats or perhaps give away return tickets to Aleppo? What you mean by the slogan 'securing borders' frankly scares me. Because it drives even more people to their deaths, and that is no blink of an eye from the proposal of the right-wing populist AfD in Germany to introduce the firing order at the border, or rather to reintroduce – to be honest. Shooting at refugees, declaring war on them and not their persecutors – that is a crime, I want to say very clearly! And we must also say one thing: the rise of the right in Europe and the violence against refugees, which spreads like a virus, has its causes. Namely, that this House is not saying that violence against refugees is a crime. That is it, and it must be punished in this way. That is why we cannot tolerate refugees being tortured in Bulgaria, hate speech actually being perpetuated throughout the various countries and also torching the refugee shelter in Germany. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: – This is the opportunity to clarify a ruling by the first Vice-President of the European Commission, Frans Timmermans. Last week, Frans Timmermans said in a strongly-in-a-half interview in the Dutch media that 60% of migrants arriving in the European Union are not refugees, but economic migrants. In the meantime, Eurostat, Frontex, the IOM, the UNHCR, EASO and your own information have contradicted this. But Frans Timmermans has been silent for a week, and while he keeps quiet he is quoted, repeated, abused and the support for the reception of refugees continues in my own country and throughout the European Union. So this is the time for clarity. Are Frans Timmermans' statements on these percentages the official position of the European Commission or not?

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: – Madam President, I think we can all agree that the migration crisis last year was probably the single biggest catastrophe to hit the European Union in its history. In fact, I would go as far as to say that it has put the very existence of this project in jeopardy. What is amazing is that the EU’s own actions helped cause the problem in the first place. When Chancellor Merkel and the Swedish Government committed the equivalent of cultural suicide and invited everyone who had a Syrian passport to come to the continent, it was obvious to all of us what was going to happen. People would attempt to come in their droves, people would die in the seas, there would be migrant camps overflowing, Member State would be pitted against Member State, the Schengen Agreement would collapse, and it would be a golden opportunity for the Islamic fundamentalists to bring carnage to our continent. It was also obvious that there would need to be U—turns, as we have seen performed in the past couple of months by both the German and the Swedish Governments. Now we are facing an even bigger crisis. The numbers coming this year to Europe will no doubt dwarf those of last year. We are facing a summer where the movement of people from the Middle East and North Africa will no doubt reach biblical proportions. What is the European Union offering to solve this problem? The answer is more of the same: more concessions, more EU, more money, more misery, not only for the migrants but for many of its own citizens. We have to put a stop to this madness, and the answer is not making the same mistakes over and over again: it is restoring proper border controls, just as the Australians have done for the past five years. However, for the UK to achieve this goal, we must vote to leave this organisation in the up-and-coming referendum. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, do you believe that the migrants waited for Mrs Merkel's permission to leave the place where they could no longer live, subjected to terror, bombs and deprivation of liberty? Do you think they waited for that authorization?

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I think that when Angela Merkel said that Germany would accept everyone who could prove that they were Syrian, a huge number of people came, and that is why fake Syrian passports are now on sale on the Turkish black market for EUR 500 a go. That is why one in three people who turn up and say they are Syrian in Germany turn out to have fake passports. What you are doing is putting European citizens’ lives at risk. In fact, you saw what happened in Cologne recently and I am telling you now that is a taster of what is to come across our continent.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the question arises as to whether, after two years, because this problem has been afflicting Europe for two years now, there really is the political will on the part of the Commission, on the part of the European Union in all its forms, to actually tackle the problem. Because, from what I can also understand from today's debate, It seems to me that there are two visions. There is a bit of a vision of those who have ideology and therefore say that all refugees are good people, they all need them, we welcome them all, maybe we also give them our homes. Just the other day, in my city, 22 refugees were put in a hotel and will also be offered training and work courses, something that so many Italians, my fellow citizens, do not have. You have to be careful to do these things, because then maybe someone gets angry, but you have the solution so much by saying that they are populists. Obviously it is enough to solve everything with this.  On the other hand, however, the thing that surprises me is that there is perhaps no interest. When ten thousand children disappear, when I may see that some of these people are being recruited by mafias, when I see that some people, as happened last week in Italy, are arrested for drug dealing – and they are asylum seekers – when I see the events in Cologne, I think that perhaps there is something obscure in this European Union. That someone might not have an interest in getting all these people in? Because it almost seems to me that someone wants to create chaos. Creating chaos, I don't know why, but obviously there are important interests that someone doesn't want to eradicate.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: "When people's lives are at risk, they are of course given asylum, but in the first country they come to. There, their lives are no longer in danger. And why are they going further? Because a blonde from Berlin promised them high allowances. Did she do it out of stupidity? It is difficult to say, but I am afraid that Bruno Gollnisch may be right that someone wants to get rid of Europeans from Europe and bring in more meek slaves from other continents in their place. However, when Mao Tse-tung died and the rice allocation system for cards was over, the number of Chinese decreased by 100 million. Likewise here, ladies and women, these 10 000 died because refugees registered one child in several families, and when fingerprints were introduced, 10 000 children mysteriously disappeared somewhere. More besides, I think that the European Union should be destroyed!

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I greet the Commissioner and also the Presidency of the Council, Minister. First of all, Mrs Ernst, you asked the question: what is Greece supposed to do? Finally, fully cooperate, finally cooperate fully with Frontex, cooperate fully with EASO, finally offer full transparency in the area of registration, finally be ready for a kind of refugee policy together with the Member States and not see itself as a pure transit state through which everything is passed through, but really full cooperation. Then, conversely, I also expect the Member States to be prepared to take in refugees and not to regard Greece as the country that takes in the refugees alone, as Greece's sole responsibility. That would be European common ground, that would be European cooperation. Furthermore, However, I also expect that we will be prepared to think a little further, for example to establish protection zones and to make resettlement areas outside the European Union. Because only if other states on the African continent or in the Middle East are willing to participate, can we perhaps solve a little more than just a few who may be coming to us via the Mediterranean. However, if we want a larger concept that contributes to this and leads to fewer refugees, then we must also remember to work on the African continent and not always think exclusively of the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, I have listened to what the representatives of the Council and the Commission have told us, who have said that they are immigrants who are not entitled to asylum. Do you not think that we should, after all this time, have a very clear rule, which we should tell our governments to apply uniformly in the European Union, so that we know very clearly what we are doing with these people who are coming, obviously, some for lack of money, others because of the war?

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – There are clear differences: firstly, those who are refugees, who have to be taken in on humanitarian grounds because they fear for life and limb, and secondly, those who are looking for a better future – these are economic migrants, who, however, must comply with the laws that apply to the respective countries and cannot claim the humanitarian right for themselves. This means that economic migrants must first be repatriated, because they cannot apply for asylum on the basis of asylum, but must comply with the law of the country in their own right. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Thank you very much, Mrs Hohlmeier. You said exhaustive things about Greece. My intriguing question would be to what extent you agree with me and that the Member States may also have to contribute – and in a significant way – to support Greece, for example by taking in more refugees. Where is your protest? I would very much like to know.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Sometimes, Mrs Ernst, it would be wise to listen to me. That is exactly what I answered just now in my speech. I said that, on the one hand, I expect full cooperation from Greece on the issues of registration, in the persecution of traffickers and the proper first arrival of asylum seekers. On the other hand, I have said that I expect the Member States, if Greece is prepared to do so, to make a serious contribution, so that Greece also knows that it can rely on redistribution and on the possibilities that exist correspondingly through redistribution in the other Member States. Cooperation can only be done together.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, lately we are only hearing alarmist statements about the future of Schengen and the European Union from our leaders. Indeed, we risk losing a great European achievement, Schengen, to which Romania rightly aspires to join. This should be replaced by firm action and we should put aside "blame games" and national rhetoric. As long as we continue like this, we will not be able to find any solution.  We need joint European action, a review of the Dublin system, which is outdated, and the implementation of a European mechanism for the effective monitoring and control of our external borders, with a rapid response capacity, as announced by the Council, but which is still in an embryonic state. And, of course, we need to increase cooperation with Turkey, which is an essential partner to meet this challenge. That is why we must ensure that the joint action plan with Turkey, decided at the end of last year, is fully implemented by both sides: by us, the EU, and by Turkey. The EU must support Turkey in concrete terms and Turkey must increase its efforts in managing the migrant flow. Both sides must act coherently.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We do not see the migration crisis as a legal crisis, but a political one. The law is there, we just have to apply it. The German government has had a pull effect with its welcoming culture. In doing so, it puts considerable pressure on the Member States as a whole. We no longer have five to twelve, it is exactly twelve o'clock. In other words, the EU must now prove that it is capable of acting.  First of all, we need to make an honest analysis. We are talking about aid. Aid is voluntary and aid must also be possible, it must be permanently affordable. After all, we cannot expect anyone to help until they themselves become in need of help. And that is why it is absolutely unacceptable for a single country to set the standard for other countries. Instead, we must finally go and see what the reception capacities we have in the EU are. In order to do this, it is necessary to determine what can be done there in the individual countries. And we also have to determine what we want to do there, with the involvement of the citizens.  I do not think it is okay to set the standard somewhere from afar without involving the citizens. Otherwise, the aid cannot succeed. And, of course, migration policy must not be allowed to become inhumane. A party, or even its representatives, who are advocating a firing order against defenseless refugees, must be politically opposed. We must do this together, and we will have an easy fight, because this party will have few useful arguments. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – You said that the citizens must be involved. I think that the citizens have been exceptionally involved. The Red Cross across European countries has organised the lives of asylum seekers. It's been a fantastic activity. How dare you say that the citizens have not been involved. After all, the problem here is in the decision-making process between the Member States and the European Union.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for that question. Indeed, it is absolutely remarkable in the most positive sense how much many members of our EU, our citizens, are involved and working. But what is crucial is that we must involve the citizens in this basic question, which must be answered: how many people do we want to welcome here in our EU, how many can we take in? This is a crucial question, and the citizens must be asked about it.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The other day, a lynch mob went out to abuse refugee children in stockholm's inner city, and at the same time 39 people, many of them children, died in the dark waves of the Mediterranean. What is happening across Europe at the moment is appalling, and it is provoked by an unresolved refugee situation. It is unresolved in that there are some countries that have taken a great deal of responsibility, while very many countries have done nothing at all.  We must remember that only together can we challenge this crisis. It is only together that we can gain control of the external border and together we can fairly share the responsibility of the people fleeing their countries in order to seek refuge in Europe. Not through the countries' race to the bottom when it comes to reception. Not through closed borders. Not by letting hate win. Not by sitting with your arms crossed and waiting for someone else to take responsibility, as is being the case in many countries.  We need to be minded right now. It's time for that. Europe has, in fact, faced greater crises than this throughout history. The generations of our parents and grandparents managed to unify this continent after two bloody wars. We have a duty to live up to our moral responsibility and take it here and now, and no country can slip away from it.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Ms Wikstrom, do you accept the blue-card question?

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Of course, Mr President, I am happy to receive any question from any colleague.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. "In Poland, we respect the decision of Sweden, the Swedish people. I will repeat, we respect the decisions both about opening up, about the culture of hospitality – as in Germany – and then, as I understand it, the painful decision for you to close borders and restore control. But this is a decision made by Sweden and by the Swedish people. My question: are you also able to accept the sovereign decision of poles or Czechs on this matter?

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: answer ("blue card"). The question is justified. I am prepared to take responsibility for European solutions and for European decisions. This means that Sweden's external border is the same as Greece's border with the Mediterranean. Together we should take responsibility for guarding this border and, when it comes to the responsibility of refugees, then we must all remember our own history in Europe, our own modern history.  We have seen Hungary, we have seen Czechoslovakia where people have been forced to flee. They've been received. We know that Poland has received a large number from Ukraine, for example, and we must recognise that, but together we can also take responsibility for those who are forced to flee Syria, from Eritrea and from other places in the world where life is under great threat.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Violence against refugees, migrants and non-white people is on the increase in Sweden, Germany, France, Greece, Bulgaria, and the list can be made longer. There are many of our friends among our neighbors who are afraid now. They don't dare go out. When they go out, they look around and they don't take their children with them. It's real terror.  We know that racists and Nazis are capable of committing violent crimes. But the question is, what do the rest of us do? What language do we use, what policies do we put in place? Do we do things that legitimise their polarized worldview, when the extreme right here suspects refugees as terrorists, when Denmark makes disgusting laws that make it legal to plunder refugees, when Sweden closes its borders, when national politicians and EU politicians pist refugees against welfare instead of expanding our aging societies, well, then we will, we rake, or you , time here.  The racists become a tail of haters on social media and in the streets and squares. A different policy is needed. A policy that welcomes refugees, who save lives in the Mediterranean and which directs resources to the countries that receive refugees so that we can launch a coalition of pro-refugee, European countries that work together in solidarity for a dignified reception. A new policy is needed, my friends, it does not require an EU super-border policy that is angry with Greece because they do not stop refugees – it is refoulement – a different policy is required.  (The speaker declined a question ("blue card") from Marek Jurek.)

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: – Mr President, I am also speaking in the context of the Syria donors’ conference going on this week. The 2015 appeal for the Syria crisis was less than 60% funded by January of this year, and that has had real repercussions both for the amount of food available in the camps and in the societies and countries surrounding Syria in the region where less than 50% of the children are currently receiving education. So do the Council and the Commission believe that all Member States are making adequate contributions to support the work of the UN in the region? People have referred to people coming without documentation. Well, in countries in conflict, documentation disappears, and one of the other issues arising is statelessness – not least for those children born en route. Can we please hear what the proposals are from the Commission and the Council to actually deal with the issues of statelessness and prevention of it for vulnerable children in particular?

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Despite your fine words in this House, the naivety of this issue must stop. There is, of course, a limit when the problems of excessive immigration eventually become overpowering for a country. Unaccompanied minors who are clearly considerably older than the age they have indicated are reported, the media in my country are reported daily.  Girls are harassed daily in bathhouses and sexually abused in public places. Just recently, a 22-year-old girl was brutally murdered by a so-called unaccompanied minor claiming to be 15 years old. It is a great shame that you in this House do not want to raise these problems in any way.  We in Sweden have reached the limit now. We have no jobs, no housing or money to deal with the mass immigration that we experienced last year. The Schengen Agreement is falling, and I am happy about that. Europe is a failure that is becoming increasingly obvious to the People of Europe.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the European mechanism for helping refugees in Turkey is a market for dupes. The European Union will pay 3 billion euros to Turkey in the hope of fixing the 2 million Syrian refugees there.  Turkey, however, has no intention of complying with this agreement. The proof: President Erdogan came to Strasbourg in 2015 to challenge the Union by criticizing European civilization and calling on the Turks of France to refuse to integrate. The truth is that Erdogan voluntarily lets Syrian migrants leave Turkish ports for Europe. He rejoices in what is happening to us, he feeds the wave of migration that overwhelms us. The Union is weak by nature because it is an above-ground bureaucracy cut off from the souls of the European peoples. It will lose its $3 billion without getting anything in return.  The solution is to abolish the Schengen agreement. Each state must regain control of its borders to stop the flow of migrants and deal on an equal footing with Turkey. If I take the example of my country, I say that France will defend its interests much better when it is outside the Schengen area, and even outside the European Union.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, the debate on Schengen and Greece is a lever of the European Union for more decisive implementation of repressive measures by the SYRIZA-ANEL government, by unsyming the necessary refugee monopolies. You do not decide to return, as you say, deport them back to the hell of wars that the European Union itself and its allies have created and exacerbated. Your European borders mean graying borders in the Aegean. The walls rise with Schengen in place and thus inflame the trafficking rings, while the last economies of refugees are seized by the break-up of the fascist hordes.  Schengen does not abolish controls, but extends them electronically with biometrics and a file. It is the application of Schengen provisions 19 and 26 that imposes border controls at the visible risk of en masse trapping thousands of desperate refugees in Greece. There is an urgent need for the direct transfer of refugees to their final destination countries, and for the people to step up their fight for a world without exploitation, imperialist wars and refugees.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Mr President, external borders must be secured and defended. Member States must meet the requirements of the Schengen Code. Those who encounter problems must be supported, willingly or unwillingly, by European entities: Frontex, for example and, I hope, very soon, the European Border Guard Corps. I call on the Commission to urgently develop common standards for assessing the level of border security, as required by the Internal Security Fund Regulation. The Schengen area must be defended at all costs. Avoiding loss of life and reducing the flow of refugees cannot be achieved without stopping conflicts in the countries of origin and stopping people in the areas of departure. Turkey and the states of northern Africa need support. The amounts decided must bring concrete results. The way in which these amounts are to be budgeted must be clear and transparent. The simplest solution is to transfer in the following year all unused amounts in the current year. The current MFF already foresees a low total. The 100% use of the amounts already committed by Member States resolves the need to finance contingencies. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: blue-card question. – You made the point at the very beginning that external frontiers must be protected. My question is very simple. When it comes to the Greek border with Turkey, you make that point very clearly, and so do many other people here in this Chamber. Would you say the same thing about Turkey violating Greece’s airspace and waters, or would you have a double standard? We have to be clear on that point. Is it a European border or not?

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Europe's external borders must be protected, secured and, of course, defended, regardless of who is on the other side of the border. So, in the case of Greece-Turkey, it is the same. Greece has an external border on Europe, it must fulfil everything required by the Schengen code.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Mr Vice-President, Mr Minister, we share the Commission's commitment to the refugee crisis, whether to move towards a dignified and shared reception of asylum seekers, to improve the management of our borders or to strengthen our instruments of cooperation with our partners. All of these devices are welcome. There remains the funding of these measures and therefore their sincerity. The 2016 budget agreement signed two months ago has exhausted most of the budgetary margins. By the Commission's own admission, we are now condemned to financial arrangements, I quote: 'creative'. These creations do not respond to any ordinary procedure, and the ease for Turkey is an example. The EU budget is being strengthened, but without touching the ceiling of the multi-year financial framework. The heads of government can thus suggest, with a rather hypocritical message, that the Union is not being strengthened. The Europhobes of this House feed on these half-truths, these false pretences. Mr Council representative, tell your colleagues to stop having a shameful Europe. Each council is delegated more responsibilities for the Union, but what are the means to implement them? This year we have an opportunity to review the multi-year financial framework. We can take the Union's budget up to its responsibilities. Since we spoke with Commissioner Moscovici this morning about important progress on the taxation of multinationals, why not consider this tax at EU level? This would put an end to the sterile competition that is destroying our national taxation and significantly reduce national contributions to the EU budget.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Threats to the security of the Union are destabilisation in the south and Russian politics in the east. Migration is one of the effects in both cases. With regard to the South, I accept the support mechanism for Turkey, I support peacekeeping in our southern neighbourhood, I support Frontex's actions and assistance and the voluntary support of our southern members in strengthening the borders, I support France's support after Article 42(7).  As regards the eastern neighbourhood, Poland has welcomed almost one million migrants, 99 or even more, and even more of them are economic migrants. No one deports them, we try to give them jobs and decent living conditions. The only thing we would require is that Poland, in the context of immigration policy, is not stigmatised in this House and in the media.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, a lot has been said about what should be done, but maybe we should ask ourselves the question: how will history judge us? What will the history books write about these debates, let’s say 100 years from now? I think they will say that the year 2016 started on a very positive note with a real miracle on New Year’s Day, because we found that in Europe, there are 507 million feminist, humanist, civilised, enlightened people, who have respect for women overnight. So that is fantastic. But no, seriously colleagues, testosterone has no religion, and I would like to point that out to my Swedish colleague, who apparently has forgotten about the Vikings, who went around Europe raiding, raping and pillaging. But the history books will also write about the complete inability, the complete paralysis of the biggest economy in the world in trying to solve a manageable problem – because this is a big challenge, yes, but it is entirely a question of managing. The history books will write about the biggest economy in the world just looking the other way when children are drowning, when children are being abducted by criminal gangs in order to be abused, when women have to give birth in fields. The biggest economy in the world, sitting on its hands and not acting, and in the meantime wasting time talking about things like national sovereignty. Well national sovereignty does not pay the rent. We do not need more red cards. We do not need more paralysis. Do we want to go down in history as a black period, a period of paralysis, or do we want to be the architects of a big leap forward and a new period? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Although I share in part the problems you have identified, I have a very simple question: so what do you think is the solution? What I see is that while it was about the enlargement of the European Union, everyone was extremely enthusiastic. On the other hand, when it comes to deepening, each Member State has a very, very different opinion on things: Germany lets everyone in, Hungary no one, and then I can go on. What is the solution in your opinion?

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card answer. – It is not rocket science really. I think there is a massive pile of solutions on the table. This Parliament has proposed solutions. The Commission has proposed solutions. The Council has even decided on a couple of solutions, but it would be really nice if they would actually execute what they have decided, if we could speed up the decision-making process. We do not have years, we do not have decades; we have to take decisions now. It is not about new proposals, new ideas: it is about action. It is about decisions. It is about carrying out what has actually been agreed. That is what I propose, dear colleague.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, the disturbing revelation that more than 10 000 refugee children are missing across the EU is proof, if proof were needed, that Europe is failing appallingly in this humanitarian crisis. The institutions of the EU have displayed nothing but continuous inhumanity by maintaining the ‘fortress Europe’ approach to this crisis. After fleeing wars, battling the winter elements and making crossings via land or sea, refugees are faced with enforced detention. It is abundantly clear that the kneejerk reaction and policies adopted by several Member States are failing miserably. The refugees that are fleeing barrel bombs and drone strikes should be met with open arms; instead they are detained, or pushed into the criminal claws of human traffickers and abusers. Families are torn apart and childhood innocence is destroyed for ever. Little children are trafficked for sex work or slave labour. Organised criminal infrastructure is exploiting the refugee crisis and European policy is making its job easier. The provision of safe and legal routes for refugees and asylum seekers is the only way to prevent this dreadfulness.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, the Minister has said that non-refoulement is a key principle of European policy, and I agree. I hope that was your statement in response to the policy proposal that Greece should return refugees back to Turkey, where they cannot find refugee protection and would even possibly be returned to Syria. I hope that you are also being as clear to Heads of State and Government who have been proposing – again to Greece – that Greece should close its borders, because you cannot close the border unless you violate the Geneva Convention and let people drown. I think we have to be absolutely clear on that because, if that ever happens, then Europe really loses its reason for being. The challenge that we are facing is certainly great, but we can tackle it together. This is a moment when we see, once again, that we absolutely need Europe, now more than ever. Then we can also address this challenge.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, we have seen arson attacks against migrants and refugee centres in some European countries, and we have seen attacks by migrants in Cologne and other cities as well. Why is it that the right is so quick to condemn brutal attacks by migrants, whilst the left condemns attacks on migrants, but neither side seems willing to recognise or even acknowledge both? Should we not rather condemn all criminal violence, whoever the perpetrators, unequivocally and without question? In other words we should condemn the violence that we have seen from fascist protesters and condemn just as strongly the same violence done by so-called anti-fascists. And when we pause to reflect, let us remember that European Union principles have spectacularly failed in what needed to be an incredible humanitarian response, but one done in the right way, when there are 2.5 million in Turkish refugee camps and millions more in countries like Lebanon and Jordan too. Every problem we see today was predictable, was predicted by us, and has been ignored by the Commission.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – Mr President, the refugee crisis has clearly demonstrated two things: the Union's negligence in the security of the external borders and the lack of a common decision on the resolution of the refugee crisis in the Member States. The wrong choices of the European authorities a few months ago today have negative social consequences that our women and children feel, first and foremost, and the current situation is getting worse every day. Firstly, how can Schengen borders be secured if the external borders are weak? This is a question that the European Union has lost sight of as it tried to impose immigrant quotas on Member States. The fact that Greece is unable to protect and secure its borders, or that there was an impossibility in implementing security measures, can only lead us to the conclusion that the European Union should have taken more clear support measures for the Member States. We cannot be part of the crimes committed by some so-called refugees against our own peoples. Let us not forget that last year we chose to take in refugees into the Schengen area, but we kept outside the Schengen area states that share the same European values as, for example, Romania and Bulgaria. Can we still talk about solidarity, colleagues? Can we really not realize that this situation will lead to a clash of civilizations, whether we want to or not? Slowly, the fight between European citizens and the refugees we have supported by the European Union will worsen. European citizens must not come to feel offended because they are a Christian majority. European women have the right to walk down the street and feel safe.  Think ten times before making other wrong decisions!

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after the euphoria of the suicidal open-door politics comes the cruel time of disillusionment.  Economic disillusionment first: those who thought that men were only interchangeable economic actors, untied from their culture, began to realize their mistake. These German bosses who saw illegal migrants as the new economic miracle now know that the majority of these young men will not enter the German market and that 80% of them have neither the level nor the training of a German worker. Cultural disillusionment too: the singers of multiculturalism take reality in the face like a boomerang. Explosion of rape in Europe, assaults in public swimming pools, delinquency of all kinds, not to mention terrorist infiltration.  Let us thank the nations of Central and Eastern Europe for their courage in confronting reality, they who defend our European borders, and let us cease to think that turning the Schengen page is killing the European idea. The real Europe can only be realistic, it can only be a thorough cooperation between sovereign nations.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: – Mr President, some say "Another debate on Schengen, on refugees ..." Yes, because today one of the foundations of the European Union, namely the area of freedom, security and justice without internal borders, is put to the test. It is our historical responsibility to protect it and to prove the sustainability of European values even in a crisis. And when we talk about European values, very quickly comes a place for action, not just words.  I will put two emphasis: Schengen first. It is clear to all of us that the stakes are now also Schengen. It is very important that we continue to talk about its preservation, not forgetting what the economic consequences will be, the consequences for European integration.  Ensuring security at the European Union's external borders is the condition for its preservation and therefore we will not tire of repeating it: commitments made by Member States to close border management gaps and comply with registration, relocation and return procedures.  And here I would very much like good examples of countries like Bulgaria to be quoted more often. The positive results achieved in the fight against smuggling and trafficking in human beings and border protection show Bulgaria's readiness to be a reliable member of the Schengen area. "Yes" to the coordinated approach, "yes" to cooperation with third countries. However, let's not forget – we concentrate on the short-term and do not lose sight of the long-term!

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Since Jean-Claude Juncker gave his memorable State of the Union speech here on 9 September, we have known what to do. In the following part-session, we dealt with it again and again. The problems have become greater, and they are now endangering the whole of the Union, because there is nothing substantially changing, because ideological fog makes us disoriented and because the Member States are practising in the Black Peter game and a Union-wide blame game is under way. It is enough! Something has to change! I hope that the dutch people's proverbial pragmatism, you in the Dutch Presidency, will overcome this blockade. We finally need sufficient resources for the countries of origin, we must finally put our relationship with Turkey on a neighbourly basis, we must finally guarantee a functioning European border management and we need a distribution of solidarity within the Union. But this will only work if we finally set up these repeatedly promised hotspots, Commissioner! We must finally register the people who enter. Then what has happened again to these 10 000 young people does not happen, as Europol has revealed these days – that they have simply disappeared. We need normality, we need more realpolitik, and it must be human rights compliant and efficient.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: – Anyone who thinks that the massive influx of asylum seekers and fortune seekers can be combined with the principles of our social welfare state is wrong. Continuing to muddle is not an option. This is also the case with the Dutch Presidency, which wants to return asylum seekers from the Greek islands by ferry to transit country Turkey in exchange for a limited number of transfers to our continent. My party, the NVA, has long been in favour of a systematic return policy. How else can you guard borders? Registering and managing migration flows is not enough. We therefore see several good elements in the Dutch proposal which bear strong similarities to our proposals to tackle the refugee crisis.  The fact that not all colleagues agree with this was demonstrated by statements made today and in recent days. Some suggest giving money to asylum seekers in the refugee camps. This could increase prices in those camps, causing the EU to indirectly start sponsoring people smugglers. There are also colleagues who advocate unlimited immigration to Europe by issuing tourist visas to asylum seekers. These are unrealistic proposals with perverse side effects. Ladies and gentlemen, let us think constructively with the Council of Ministers. That is the least we owe to European citizens. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Thank you, Mrs Stevens. I agree with a systematic approach. It is right to control the external borders so that we can keep the Schengen borders free internally. But how do you feel that there are members in your group who say in all seriousness that we should use firearms against unarmed refugees at the Schengen borders internally? Against women and children! This has been confirmed in writing and said several times. This is not a random, quick statement.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: "blue card" answer. I would like to say very clearly from our group - and I can speak from our group - that we are completely distancing ourselves from that statement. Shooting people is unacceptable! I think I'm clear. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: "blue card" question. – I was a little triggered when I heard you say: there are people here who advocate for unlimited immigration and tourist visas for refugees or asylum seekers. I would like to know who you have heard pleading for this, because I have not heard anything like this. I think it's good to keep the discussion pure.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: "blue card" answer. – Surely there are certain members of certain groups who advocate humanitarian visas as a kind of legal migration channel? You can't deny that, can you?

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, if today we put a videotape of the last debate on the screen, many people would perhaps not notice the difference. It is that similar to the previous debate. And, unfortunately, we do not see the results. The Minister speaks of hot spots. Yes, maybe there has been a certain improvement, but I have spoken to people from the hot spots, and the current situation is still very much unacceptable. The Commissioner was closer to the real situation in speaking of poor implementation. I could not agree more. Poor implementation is a reality. We have made mistakes, and we have also maybe introduced certain measures at an inopportune time. Maybe some of the measures were not the right ones, but it is also true that we are not implementing the decision of the Council. But the same should also apply to the fact that if we want a united EU we should make sure that nobody can break ranks and speak out about any related issue without consulting their partners in the European Council. So the two things have to apply. What do we need? We definitely need a united EU; we need to stop accusing one another, and we need a certain shift in policy. The ALDE paper refers to issues of border control – Frontex – but we need rapid deployment and temporary protection. Why has the directive never been used? We need a return control, and when this bears fruit, burden-sharing and shared responsibility have to apply as well.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Mr President, seventy years from now, the whole of humanity will wonder how these kinds of atrocities could be committed in Europe against people fleeing wars. They will be ashamed to belong to the same human race as those who today confiscate their valuables from refugees or those who mark these people with numbers on their arms. The far right is no longer alone in its racist and xenophobic positions. It is accompanied by European institutions and much of the governments of the States. Some do it from the seats and some on the street, but it's the same violence. Last Wednesday we heard in this Parliament a Danish minister say that the invasion of refugees must be stop. On Friday, a group of Nazis marched through the streets of Stockholm beating up immigrants. Border closures, deportations, overcrowding in the fields are as fascist as walking the streets with a swastika on the lapel.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner Avramopoulos concluded with something very important. He said that we must find solutions that are consistent with our own core values, and I fully agree with that. The problem is that our solutions do not always. For example, the introduction of internal border controls is not in line with our core values, because they jeopardise the whole of Schengen.  Nor is it in line with our values to stop people fleeing for their lives with better external border controls and on the grounds that they do not have proper passport documents, because it jeopardises the right of asylum and we are bound by it. If we really want to live up to our core values, we must start prioritising the root causes of people coming here, and not least we must show solidarity between the countries of the European Union.  It is not okay for a few countries to accept hundreds of thousands of asylum seekers when others take a few hundred. It is this lack of solidarity that forces some of our EU countries, including my own Sweden, to take measures that we would rather not see in Europe and which actually jeopardise our entire cohesion.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the immigration emergency has shown the true face of this Europe, which is certainly not based on principles and ideals of solidarity but on selfishness and pettiness. Selfishness of the Member States, where everyone thinks about their own borders and leaves the problems to others, and pettiness of the Union, which would like to get rid of the issue by relying, at a very high price, on Erdogan's help and blackmail. Europe is always at the forefront of the defence of rights in every part of the world, but turkey and all its internal problems are being silenced in shameful and complicit silence. According to Brussels' intentions, the money should go to the refugees. I would like to know on what basis this security is based, since I do not think it will be at all easy to see how the money will actually be used.
