In recent months, many desperate people have left for Europe, even with the complicity of the Turkish authorities. I wonder, therefore, who is guaranteeing that this will not continue. Next week I will be in Turkey for more information and to try to shed some light on this situation, which is still a long way from being clear.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, your European functioning is marked by failure. Firstly, the failure of Schengen and the great return of national borders, since at the slightest problem, many countries have re-established borders, which proves that the border is a central element of state policy. Then there is a human tragedy: one million migrants arrived, three million expected, 3,800 deaths in the Mediterranean, 10,000 missing minors, explosive situations, such as in Calais, France, or Cologne. It is also found that 62% of these migrants are economic migrants and not refugees. Then, Europe's weakness in relation to Turkey, a country that mistreats human rights, plays with the European Union on the one hand, and the Islamic State group on the other, and which enjoys 3 billion euros in aid without any control. Finally, the European cacophony. Good feelings do not replace the seriousness of the acts and the failure of the policy, even the Court of Auditors has questioned the costly and totally ineffective programs of your immigration policies. We must therefore give the people a voice. Democracy is the government of the people by the people and for the people.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, the ancient Greek word 'panic' is the most accurate characterisation of how the European Union has dealt with and continues to deal with the serious problem of refugees and migrants. At first she became indifferent and then, when the issue became uncontrollable, she began the oriental haggling with Turkey over how much money she should give to ban the country's corruption rings in which state officials are involved from promoting illegal immigrants in Greece.  Turkey, unsurprisingly, took this opportunity and began blackmailing the European Union and asking for more money than the three billion it has been approved to receive. You must realise that Turkey is not a reliable interlocutor, does not fulfil its obligations and takes every opportunity to promote its national interests.  If we want to put financial pressure on Turkey, we must, for every illegal immigrant coming from Turkey to Greece, impose a hefty fine which is deducted from the money that Turkey must receive. We're going to make her understand that we know how to make economic oriental bargains, too.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: – Between 2,000 and 3,000 migrants a day still arrive in the EU unmanaged. Due to this large crowd, a small fraction of arrivals register, if at all register in the right way, hotspots do not work. Let us finally say frankly that this is not a problem with the lack of solidarity between member states. With this kind of workload, the system can't handle the situation. It creates tensions between Member States, governments and social groups. The number of thousands of arrivals arriving every day seems to be destabilising Europe. Therefore, the safety of European citizens and the stability of Europe must be the primary responsibility and responsibility of all European decision-makers. It has now become clear at eu decision-making level what those who have faced the migrant influx since the summer have seen: europe is predominantly dealing with a non-asylum seeker. Most of the arrivals are economic migrants, young or middle-aged men, and the majority of unaccompanied minors are young boys aged 14-18. Within days, Europe must master the chaotic situation at the external borders – this must be nothing more than a technical issue. Only a stable Europe can help, solidarity with those most in need, those entitled to refugee status.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I do not want to stop you for long in this exciting debate in front of almost 10% of my colleagues and a completely unoccupied front row. I am not saying this as a reproach, because I understand that the other 90% want to work instead of hearing for the sixth time what you are hearing here today. I refuse to read my speech at all, because I have nothing new to say to you, because I no longer feel like telling the Council to see once again that the Member States are finally getting on their hooves. And I am sorry, Commissioner, And I can hardly hear you again and again pointing out how well you have worked, how well we have worked and that they are not working so well.  The whole thing is intolerable for the people who look at it if there is anyone who sees it on the net, and it is intolerable for Members. We should consider together how we can make a little more steam with the measures that Mr Verhofstadt has mentioned in part, if nothing comes from the Member States themselves. Don't take it personally, but it doesn't make sense to me anymore, so I'll give you 22 seconds now.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Mr President, last year the migration pressure shifted from the central Mediterranean to the eastern Mediterranean route. Greece does not register the migrants as it should, which is understandable from the Greek point of view, as the relocation mechanism does not and will not work. The development is not sustainable. Germany, for example, expects to spend EUR 50 billion on migrants this year and next. There are hundreds of thousands of frustrated young migrant men in Germany, Sweden, Finland and other countries with no realistic chance of finding employment or even decent accommodation. The social and political consequences of migration will be severe. We must have the courage to admit that we cannot solve this crisis by taking people in. No matter how many we accept, there will be millions more coming from Africa and the Middle East. We should consider starting systematic pushbacks, at least in the eastern Mediterranean and the Balkans, sending applicants back to camps and processing all applications there. If those people make it to Europe, they will stay here, whether or not they are granted international protection. We must stop asylum-shopping. Each Member State should be obliged to refuse to accept asylum applications from people who are arriving from, and via, another Member State.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, I would like to say to the European institutions, the Council and the Commission, that the message they sent a few days ago, a message of defiance towards Greece and a hypothetical quarantine of this country, was not a message of good policy, nor a well-inspired message. Of course, since you want to keep Schengen - we all want it - let us consider the Greek border as the European border. Let's not try to play and dissociate from each other. I was in Lesbos on Saturday and Sunday. I've seen the work of the Greek coast guard and border guards. I saw the Greek boats, more Greek boats from elsewhere than Frontex boats on site. I saw the work they were doing in collecting refugees at sea. I visited the visitor and registration centre in Lesbos, which is one of the main access islands to the European Union. In January last year, there were 700 arrivals, compared to 33,000 arrivals in January of this year. These arrivals were managed by the Greeks, little helped by Frontex, whose support should of course be strengthened. Migrants are checked, registered and photographed. The job is done. So let's be really supportive of each other and then make decisions.  The first of the decisions I ask you to take is to demand that Turkey stop the trafficking of criminals and criminal smugglers. 3,000 euros per adult, 1,000 euros per child and half fare in the event of a storm, plus lifejackets which are usually fake lifejackets. This would already be a concrete, necessary and vital action by the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Diane JAMES
text: blue-card question. – I have just heard a plea, almost a demand, that Turkey do a lot more. Is the MEP who made those statements now advocating that we fast-track Turkey’s EU membership, with all of the problems that Turkish membership would bring to the Economic Union and European Member States? That is a very bizarre statement to make, may I add.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: "blue card" answer. Thank you for that, colleague. I have always been opposed to Turkey's entry into the European Union. I consider that it would be a mistake for us, that we can think of a European Union of several circles, but in no way do I want Turkey to be part of our European Union. I then consider that we should have a little more strong relations with Turkey, a little more political will and political courage at home and dare to tell them that yes, we demand that they stop the activities of traffickers and criminals before even talking with them. I doubt that tomorrow we can give 3 billion - which we do not have - to Turkey and that this amount is enough to prevent the arrival of migrants and refugees. I have a lot of doubt about that.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Mr President, the umpteenth debate, the umpteenth finding of failure. Worse, things are getting worse. No, the European response is not up to the level of the humanitarian crisis at our borders. Less than 0.5% of the world's refugees threaten the richest area in the world. Four hundred people welcomed out of the 160,000 announced. Yes, the attitude of the Member States is a disgrace! We are attacking Greece, but where is the solidarity with it? This country is eight times less populous than Germany, one of the poorest countries in the European Union - and we know why - must be the policeman for the whole of the European Union, or it is excluded. However, no one seems to question the sharp change in the flow of refugees into Eastern Europe in early 2015. Yes, Turkey has a responsibility in this regard, and yes, it is time to ask. Yes, it is time to ask ourselves about the use of European Union funds. The Court of Auditors has published a report: we must be able to examine it. Finally, what are the consequences of the Europol report on the disappearance of 10,000 children from the European Union?

name: Eva JOLY
text: Mr President, the four themes of this debate are a faithful summary of the moral failure of the European Union, which finds no fault when its Member States violate fundamental rights, ignore the European texts. A Union, where we pretend to debate with Denmark, which shamefully legislates on the confiscation of migrants' property, where we receive Orban, who builds walls and gives all rights to the army, where the Dutch Presidency plans to exchange refugees with a country that is known to do not respect the fundamental rights of refugees , where far-right parties are allowed to make the most criminal proposals, where citizens and humanitarians are about to be criminalized when they save refugees from certain death. A European Union where, at the same time, Greece and the Greeks are threatened, who, with their limited resources, are trying to honour European values, where Germany is vilified, which shows solidarity, where we ignore every proposal for a common solution put forward by the Commission, where we remain deaf to the calls of the European Parliament. Moral bankruptcy, there is definitely no other expression to describe what is currently happening in Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: "blue card" question. After hearing my colleague, I have a question for my colleague, who finds her to say to many: how many illegal immigrants or refugees do you keep at home, given that she is so smart and good?

name: Eva JOLY
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, France, which must take its share of refugees, has so far, I believe, taken in only 62 of the 160,000 people who were to be spread throughout the European Union. Norway, which has taken its share, had promised to take in 10,000 refugees. It has reduced this quota to 7,000 and has just returned, by -28 degrees Celsius, 29 Syrians that it left in Murmansk when it was -38 degrees Celsius.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: I am struck by yet another incredible, impressive worldly strangeness of this debate here in that firmly secure hemisphere of the European Parliament. World strangeness! Face it, colleagues, Schengen is dead! There is no longer any support in public opinion, any more than for your foolish plan to make Turkey a member of the European Union.  Turkey, which was a country that started with a good order between church and state and which is now slowly slipping towards an Islamic regime with a dubious role in the case of Isis, a very dubious role on human rights and on the Kurds. Finally, Turkey is a country that is now blackmailing us with this flow of illegal immigrants into Europe. So there are plenty of reasons to throw this foolish plan of this European Union straight into the bin, because including an increasingly Islamic country of this size in the European Union is the most common thing you could do.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Turkey wants eur 3 billion more to finance the reception of refugees and strengthen the coast guard. I'm sorry, but the last I heard was 5 billion euros. Firstly, we need to make a few more of a how are the EU and the Member States supposed to produce these huge sums? Well that is right, the EU is supposed to account for EUR 500 billion and the Member States for the rest, based on GDP.  This would in principle mean that my country, Sweden, which received almost 200 000 asylum seekers last year and had to borrow money to finance this mass immigration, should now pay some SEK 900 million to a corrupt country such as Turkey. Turkey is seen as a transit country where very few migrants want to stay for a long time. Why do we think that eu funds should put an end to the pressure or reduce the pressure so that fewer people cross the Mediterranean?  Looking only at the month of January: it can be seen that thirteen times more people came from Turkey than in the same month of the previous year. I wonder, where did the border guard go?  (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" question. After this speech, I would like to ask Mrs Winberg whether it is not surreal for her to be in a debate about violence against refugees, against asylum seekers, whereas in her country, after hundreds, perhaps thousands, of incidents in asylum centres where aid workers have been attacked, a fatality has now fallen for the first time among those aid workers. A Swedish woman, as you know, was stabbed to death by a young asylum seeker.  So my question to Mrs Winberg is: is it not very strange to be in such a discussion when this has happened in your country?

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: answer ("blue card"). "Yes, it is very strange, and I would like to start by saying that I condemn all forms of racism, violence and murder. As we heard here, a young woman was murdered in a home for unaccompanied minors as recently as two weeks ago. The other day I heard about a home where the staff had to hide because it was aggressiveness and domestic violence. You see what's happening, the fear we're talking about, a virus of fear. Our girls dare not go to bathhouses, you are afraid to be out on the town and house. So why is this not highlighted in the debate? That is clearly correct.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Why are we lying to each other here? We have to admit that the hotspots are not working, the repatriation is not working, the protection of the external borders – Schengen – is not working, Dublin is not working, the reticence of refugees in Turkey is not working, the donation of money to Turkey is not working, the relocation plans are not working, the common asylum policy is not working. Here, it is always called for the retention of the community of values of national politicians, especially from the left. Where are the demands against refugees and asylum seekers in our country? Are they allowed to do anything? We saw it in Cologne, we all know the examples: they grop women, they threaten them, they plunder them, they rape them. And if they do not respect these things of our community of values, then they do not belong in an integration course, but then they belong out of Europe, preferably in the same way that they came.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: – The way in which the European Union is coping in a crisis situation will have a huge impact on its continued functioning and, in general, on its raison d'être. One element of the European Union's effectiveness is the skillful use of resources, including financial resources. The European Parliament is following the issue of the Mechanism for Turkey very closely. I would therefore like to ask the Presidency: what is the consequence of this decision today? What is the fulfilment of the commitment of the Member States? How will the mechanism for Turkey affect what we call the unity of the budget today, that is, the creation of mechanisms around the budget? We were in Amsterdam recently for a conference on the budget, and I therefore think that, in the light of these serious discussions, we need to reflect on new instruments that are changing the way the European budget works. We need to solve this now, because difficult situations will continue, and we must therefore be prepared for very difficult and very complicated times. Hence my question: what about the mechanism for Turkey?  (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Would you not agree with me that the situation with Turkey is purely a sign of the weakness of the EU and its inability to deal with this migrant crisis? It is actually being played with – made a fool of – by Turkey and having to resort to bribes to ask Turkey to do what really should be the right thing to do anyway.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Your question, of course, contains an accusation, so it is difficult to answer today what the motivations are. One thing is certain, of course, that Turkey is using this situation for its own interests. Here I absolutely agree. But for us, the interests of the European Union, the interests of our citizens, are the most important. Therefore, the question is whether we will create a mechanism that is fair, transparent and effective. But I agree that the situation is indeed very difficult and concerns Turkish interests.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: – The Schengen Convention is perhaps the most important expression of a Europe that rejects open, free and national egotism. For a Europe that is not torn apart by borders, but by the freedom of liberal democracy. Today, Schengen is under serious threat. Refugees are the pretext, but in reality it is something else. It is about the re-spread of nationalism, the politics of exclusion and exclusion in Europe. Anyone who fires national flags on the acreads of the European Parliament wants to turn back the wheel of history. And we can't accept that. We cannot allow anti-European and populist parties to force their will on us. We must not allow European asylum policy to become a prisoner of far-right parties and ideologies. We know borders and fences don't help. They don't stop refugees and they don't protect us from terrorists. That requires other means, European unity, common will. The safety of citizens is our top priority and we cannot sacrifice our freedom, our Europeanity, on the altar of security. Restoring borders, suspending or denunciing Schengen would mean the end of the European idea. Of course, there would be parties and governments in Europe that would welcome this, but we are not going to give them that pleasure. Europe is not a conglomerate of nations competing with each other, but a common home for all who want a home, prosperity and security, and Schengen is the main institution for this.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, Turkey has around two million refugees during this period and must be supported in managing the flow of refugees. The EUR 3 billion for refugee assistance also includes the contribution of the Member States of the Union. I consider it appropriate to vote on this mechanism, because the Union is currently the main donor in addressing the consequences of this crisis.  But we also need solutions other than financial ones (let's keep giving money), because this crisis will get worse in the period ahead. The effects of these conflicts – among others, and the continued flow of refugees – must be combated through collective action. That is why there is a need for effective cooperation with Turkey, but also transparency in spending the money that Turkey receives.  Finally, I would like to recall the 'tolerance paradox', which says that when a tolerant society tolerates an intolerant idea or culture, tolerance risks being destroyed. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Thank you, Mrs. Macovei, for accepting this blue card. I listened carefully to you when you talked about the need to donate and help Turkey. However, the fact is that King Abdulah declared today that Jordan will no longer be able to take in refugees. The fact is that there are also over 1 million refugees in Lebanon, 1 270,000 of them in Jordan. Do you think it is necessary, when it comes to these countries, as well as Turkey, to fully involve the United Nations so that we really have everything under control?

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I have a technical question about your presidency, which I really think is very neat. However, I have a problem when I repeatedly report with a blue card and your staff and you look in a different direction. How am I supposed to do it in the future? I shout at the table like that, knock on the table, should I scream loudly? Please help me: How should I do it so that you can see me when I show a blue card?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, I do not want to ask a blue card question, but I would like to point out something that may have escaped your attention. Previously, Mrs Guzman spoke to Parliament and wore a t-shirt that read on 'Anti-fascist Action' and has taken to Twitter and all social media. I think that is forbidden by Parliament, because I too could wear a Golden Dawn People's League shirt and be here. But you can see I'm not doing it. It must be pointed out and observed.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: We have taken note of the question raised by you, but we must give the floor to Mrs Macovei, to answer that question, and then we should have discussed it. I've got it.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: answer to the question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure by Ivan Jakovčić. – The answer is simple: we must work with all the states that have refugees and we must establish our common interest. This is not to welcome everyone, to the european Union, but to be able to sort and send to Arab states where people are safe.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioners, both the European Asylum System and the 1951 Geneva Convention relating to the Status of Refugees require asylum seekers to present themselves without delay to the authorities after crossing the border illegally.  Unfortunately, refugees often abscond, choose bypass routes and risk their lives because they know that registering and granting refugee status must be done in the first country of arrival, which they would like to avoid, given the workload of these countries' reception systems.  At the same time, border guards in frontline countries are entrusted with the responsible task of ensuring security and controlling the flow of migrants. Therefore, when asylum seekers purposefully choose hard-to-reach, dangerous routes in the dark part of the day instead of designated crossing places, it is difficult to talk about the correct application of the principle of non-refoulement. Apparently, dublin admissions rules and the relocation system are not adequate to reality. I fear that until we establish a single reception system based on a centralised and fair distribution of asylum applications, incidents will continue to occur.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL). Ladies and gentlemen, I think we are tragic. We are tragic because we repeat a debate every month with virtually no proposals from anywhere. There are no proposals from Parliament, from the Commission, there are no proposals from the United Nations. But there is a fundamental difference in this debate from the previous ones. In the previous we said winter is coming, now we say spring is coming. There's still a key difference. A few hundred dead have been added.  Turkey has taken on a lot of weight, but who controls the money if they actually go for the reason they are given? Tie Lebanon up. 20% of its population are refugees. These figures we are talking about are 0.1% of Europe's population. Fences, ladies and gentlemen, what role do they play, wherever they are? Who gives the weapons to the militants in Syria? Why doesn't anyone denounce that?  In the previous debate I said that if I was a refugee and listened to this conversation I would find a way to go drown. I think people have heard of us and that's exactly what they're doing. I close with a phrasing. I have not heard a proposal, nor from the Commission, and I wonder what they are really thinking today after tens of thousands of dead and after ... (The President removes the floor from the speaker.)

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, representatives of the Council and the Commission, I cannot fail to express a certain sense of embarrassment at what is going on in Europe and, moreover, today, they make us a little - I have to tell you - notaries of reality: the representative of the Council tells us that he is very concerned about the figures that Europol has given on unaccompanied minors; the representative of the Commission reminds us of the dead so far in the Mediterranean.  And I think it is a very obvious picture of what is happening in Europe: crippling European institutions and Member States which do not fulfil their commitments and have begun to fail to respect European law.  And it seems to me that we are currently facing a very serious situation.  Me, all I demand from here is that you at least do what's in your hand. And what is in his hand is, at the out point of view, that the Charter of Fundamental Rights be enforced; European law to be enforced everywhere, not only in Poland, but also in Denmark and in any other country of the European Union; and to enforce the commitments of the Member States, because, to this day, the emergency relocation mechanism, no one has met their goals. Finally, Spain has so far taken in eighteen refugees. It's a real shame. Please enforce at least the commitments reached by the Member States a few months ago.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, a European EU passport and access to the European lifestyle are now an aspiration for millions worldwide who are proving daily that they will go to enormous lengths to secure those objectives. Now, this cannot and should not continue. Chancellor Merkel and Germany have unleashed a migrant onslaught that is threatening Member States’ and citizens’ security, social cohesion and economic prosperity. Schengen and Frontex are clearly unable to withstand or cope with this enormous migrant pressure. Reactive European Union policy-making is just not working: we are seeing that every time we are here and at our mini-plenaries. A radical rethink is now required, and it will be necessary to make some really hard choices. The immediate priority has got to be to remove the carrot. No stick is then required. Stop the flow and the problems that come with it. 27 Member States should not have to shoulder the consequences of another Member State’s – in this case Germany’s – ill-conceived and ill-thought-through ideology.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: – Minister Koenders said at the beginning of the debate that how we deal with migrants reflects who we are. But does the Minister realize that the way these fortune-seekers treat our women and our children shows just as well who they are? There has just been another stabbing at the asylum centre in Almere! Mr. Koenders, how is it that the assailants and the perpetrators of violence are still eligible to stay? Why aren't they deported immediately? Mr President, Turkey is besieging us with millions of these fortune-seekers, and the Union is now offering Turkey eur 3 billion to stop this invasion. But the Turks see our weakness and they are demanding more and more: already five billion! And the EU is being blackmailed. Giving money away and with creepiness, you don't buy safety. Turkey should not get 5 billion, not 3 billion, not a penny at all! After all, we get no choice but misery. Mr President, the borders must be closed, because blackmail by Turkey is not a solution, but part of the problem.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: The situation at the moment is horrendous and, Commissioner Avramopoulos, you used figures from the IOM today to emphasise this once again. That is justified. Your colleague, Mr Timmermans, - I regret that he is not here today - may also like to juggle a bit with numbers. For example, he claimed last week that 60 percent of refugees entering Europe come from areas that you can't assume are entitled to refugee status. These would be mainly people from North Africa, whereas Frontex's figures show that between 89 and 97% of the people who entered in December are from Syria, Iraq or Afghanistan.  So either Frontex is wrong or the first Vice-President of the European Commission does not know the difference between an Afghan and a Moroccan. But in both cases, the European Commission is a fool. I would like to ask you to clarify this at least today. Because clarity is crucial in this case.  That is why Minister Koenders asked about the plan of his party leader Diederik Samsom in The Hague. It has already been called 'the Dutch plan' by a colleague, and I would also like to say that there is no misunderstanding about it. Will the Dutch Presidency actually work on this plan? Or should we all conclude here that it was just a test balloon for the headlines?

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, many Members have referred to the Europol report, which indicates that 10 000 unaccompanied minors now in the European Union are being exploited. Europol is probably the most respected agency in this House, and I know, having spoken to the colleagues involved, that its figure is just a snapshot. There has never been a refugee crisis in which the managed trafficking of minors has been so brutal and so systematic. And in the coming weeks and months you will see more horror stories of the kind that we are witnessing. I am not saying this for good effect, but for the benefit of all those who believe that we have the luxury of giving up: giving up on the Commission’s plans; giving up for not having done anything; giving up on the Member States which are doing less than other Member States doing more. If we have that luxury, and if you think that we can do that, then just understand that in the coming weeks, minors will be coming from Syria as genuine asylum-seekers. There is no ambiguity to their status under the Geneva Convention, whether the European Union exists or not. Therefore, we have work to do in Parliament, on the Borders Agency, on Dublin. So in our comfortable offices, let us get on with that work; let us work with the Commission. Yes, make that repeated boring speech. Now to the Dutch Presidency. There are those Member States which are not doing their work. They are not protecting the external borders or relocating. We know that, and so let as repeat the message to Member States which are not doing their work or taking responsibility: do it now – take responsibility. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149(8))

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: "blue card" question. President Moraes is right. Do you think that three years ago in Italy we unanimously approved in Parliament the granting of legal status to minors, without allowing them to enter the asylum seeker procedure. Only in this way, by no longer making them a number, can they be saved from the links of crime. I'd like to know what the president thinks about this.

name: Claude MORAES
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, Mr President: I never get a blue card – my speeches are always so boring – so thank you very much. I was in fact indicating, Ms Mussolini, that Italy is one of those countries on the front line. Italy and Greece are on the front line; there are countries like Sweden and Germany taking more than anyone else; and then there are those Member States not doing enough. But this is not a blame game. It is about Italy having been on the front line and therefore maturing its policies. I agree with what you are saying, but I say to those colleagues who do not want to take more refugees for the European Union that, had the European Union not existed, these people would have come to what is called the continent of Europe. People heard King Abdullah this morning talking about how his country is now unable to cope. Italy would have had mature policies because it was on the front line. So I agree that this is happening and that those Member States which are not taking responsibility should work towards an organised solution.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, the current migration crisis has illustrated that the 1951 Geneva Convention and the subsequent 67 Protocols are ill-suited to the modern world of mass communication and global travel. Mechanisms that were devised in the wake of the Second World War were based on the premise that those facing genuine state persecution would be allowed refuge in a neighbouring safe country. They were not designed for people crossing the globe across countless safe states in order to reach countries offering the most generous welfare systems and asylum policies. Neither was the Convention designed with the idea that individuals could transfer their refugee status from one state to another, as we are seeing now in the case of many who have left safe refugee camps in Turkey in order to reach Europe and then claim asylum again. 2016 will see a new UN Secretary—General elected, probably from an eastern European state. Speaking personally, I believe that the EU should take this opportunity to press for reform of the 1951 Geneva Convention to address these very valid concerns or else the Convention will no longer be respected or applied.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, thank you very much to the members of the Commission, who are resisting in this debate thousands of words that we are speaking.  Everything the Council has said is fine, but it does not do what it says. And today we have talked about values, Mrs Ferrara spoke; the Council spoke; Mr Pittella spoke, but values are encouraged by acts and by example, not words. And what the Council and the States , many of them – are really promoting is insolidarity and dehumanisation. And so it is, and so it must be said.  The fate of those who escape From Syria, Afghanistan or Eritrea affects us, whether we like it or not, and escape from the same totalitarian killers who want to end our freedom.  More than one million refugees have arrived in Europe because, in 2014, the World Food Programme reduced its fund by 40% and they panicked. A quarter are minor and 10% are unaccompanied minors and 10,000 are lost or out of proper protection. And it's a scandal.  And this is possible because of a long chain of mistakes and negligence, largely sought after, because many of the European governments do not want to know anything about joint responsibility, they do not want to know that those who need us must be treated humanitarianly.  And the reason for the disaster is the lack of a Community asylum policy. The rooting of collective insensitivity and the perversion of stigmatizing those we should be protecting is a disaster. And it's cruel.  We are suffering – and we have also spoken today, here, of viruses – the worst of the possible viruses, the one affecting the nervous system of the European Union, our hearts.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to hope that it is not a problem for this Parliament that some members wore a shirt with the words 'Anti-fascist action' as the spread of new fascisms throughout Europe, as what Moni Ovadia authoritatively called the new holocaust taking place in the Mediterranean Sea.  I believe that today we need words of truth about these three billion given to Turkey, that is to say to the Erdogan Government, that is to say to a government that continues to massacre the lives of the Kurdish people on a daily basis. I believe that we have given this three billion to outsource borders, to stop refugees fleeing and to prevent them from arriving in Europe. We have given three billion to Erdogan's Turkey, that is to say to a government that also has highly ambiguous relations with Daesh, precisely in order to outsource the problem of reception.  We propose that these three billion be given to the UNHCR, that it be given to those NGOs that work materially on a daily basis for the construction of a humanitarian corridor, which is the only civilised thing that this Europe could do.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Madam President, I am not pleased to know that this Parliament has said and repeated, time and time again, what should be done and is not done. Even less so, I am pleased that the Council and the Commission, in their words, are right to us. Useless. We continue to leave it to each State to fulfil our European and international obligations, but today Europe is synonymous with silence, concealment, omission, inaction and irresponsibility.  Three hundred and sixty-eight dead, Mr. Avramopoulos told us. We are all complicit in these deaths, as we are of the ten thousand evaporated minors. The agreement with Turkey is even more disturbing: three months to confirm this — Italy did so yesterday, at last - but we have not yet begun to effectively implement this agreement for welcome. And we are not able to prevent them from still leaving Turkey in small boats, to die in sight of the volunteers waiting for them on european beaches, on the beaches of the Greek islands. The answer is not Frontex. The answer is in joint and responsible action. Fewer walls here; more action in the most effective places of origin distributed among all Member States, with the will and commitment of so many cities that have made it clear that they are ready to take responsibility. Europe is starting to pay a very high price for not existing, if not, for not acting like Europe. Let us stop passing our blame and work together: Council, Commission, Parliament, everyone, together. In Greece, in Turkey, in Denmark, in Barcelona, in Stockholm. Leadership, commitment and moral authority.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), a question with a "blue card" addressed to Mrs Eeonora Forenza. Madam President, but my question is not about Mr Maragall, it is about the previous speaker, Mrs Forenza, who said that we should give the three billion to NGOs. Is he aware that NGOs are involved in illegal activities? Recently in Greece, members of the NGOs, who were members of a movement promoting illegal immigrants from Turkey to Greece, were arrested. Do these people want us to give the money? Are these the actions he wants us to reward?

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: answer to a "blue card" question by Georgios Epitideios. I do not think we can continue with the holocaust of thousands of women and men. I believe that we must fully assume political responsibility as the European Union and as Member States. I believe that what is happening to Greece, which is basically being forced to file migrants on pain of a further seal, is further evidence of the incivility in which this Europe is rapidly slipping.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Madam President, the european Union's inability to cope with the great migration crisis in Europe is obvious.  You are talking about refugees, external border controls and the future of Schengen, but the urgency today is to put an end to the mass arrival of illegal immigrants, the vast majority of whom are coming to Europe for economic reasons, to re-establish control at the borders of States in order to apprehend and deport foreigners whose asylum applications have been rejected. The urgency is to free ourselves from european jurisprudence which prevents the return of foreigners who refuse to respect our customs and customs. The urgency is not to make illusory concessions, nor to give billions of euros to Turkey to detain immigrants, but to review our relations with this country, which supports the jihadists in Syria and Libya.  You are talking about an upsurge in violence and incitement to hatred against refugees and migrants in Europe, when women have just been raped and sexually assaulted by asylum seekers in several European cities, while Christian refugees are victims of violence and even murdered by other refugees because of their religion.  I can only be appalled that you persist in this ideological blindness.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: – Madam President, I am relatively content that the Council seems to have resurfaced, because I was going to start by saying that on this sixth, seventh or eighth occasion that we are having this debate – and we will probably have 10 more – this House and the Commission are in relative harmony of views about what should be done, how we should do it and the fact that we should act. It is the Council, it is the Member States, that simply do not manage to give themselves a line to follow and to act: be it in terms of joint protection of our external borders – because all our external borders are our joint external borders, they belong to all of us, and it is the Member States that have to control them; be it in terms of resettlement of migrants all across the continent, where a number of our governments believe that they are just not concerned, and the others are therefore unable to take real action; be it in terms of the Turkey Fund or of the other funds, where we cannot permanently act as if the Union budget gave us enough leeway to mobilise all the funds necessary. Half of it depends on the Member States, and the Member States are simply not paying. They are paying in single euros, just as they are willing to resettle individual refugees, whereas we would need tens of thousands or hundreds of thousands, or in the case of the euros, billions. This is one of our problems today. In the framework of this problem today, populism is on the rise. I will conclude by saying that one of our groups, the Conservative Group – it happens to be them right now, but this goes for a very particular part of them – harbours Members of Parliament, one of them at least, who have tried to advocate that there should be a shoot-to-kill order on European borders. If this continues, we are in serious trouble, because some of their voters might try to take a gun in hand and act.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Madam President; You know what's going on? That this isn't a theater. It is not a theatre in which every month we expose here, The Members, our desperation because no action is taken. And the Commission and the Council , especially the Council, which is changing presidency , are patiently listening to see if It is the parliament of Parliament's word. You see, we're making history: history. It is being the story of the cruellest inefficiency facing the European Union ever.  This is not a theater; this is a meeting of political representatives who are demanding that our governments, the Council and the Commission cease their cruel inefficiency. Because it can be ineffective in many areas, but here we are talking about human lives.  And now, we all look to Greece: this has been the deadliest month in Greece in recent years. Hundreds of people are dying in the Mediterranean. It has already become a phrase made: "the Mediterranean, our cemetery".  But that is responsible, Ladies and gentlemen of the Council, Ladies and gentlemen, you have responsibility: all those of us who have an obligation to push, to require national governments to take charge of a solution that is possible. It is possible to save human lives and it is necessary to apply the laws we have given each other.  This is not a theatre: it is a Parliament and we demand that you act. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), question with "blue card" . – Mrs Valenciano, you said earlier that the Aegean and the Mediterranean have become a vast graveyard. So I ask you: who is pushing these people to get into a rotten car and cross the waters of the Aegean? I answer for you: Turkey. That's where the problem starts, and you have to admit it.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: "blue card" response. –Well, it's not a question, is it? It's a statement you do. In any case, I'm not talking about responsible. You see, the European Union does not provide any legal avenue to access our borders for people fleeing war who are protected by international conventions. We do not offer legal avenues. Do you know what we offer you? Put them in the hands of traffickers or at the bottom of the sea. That is the European Union's proposal. And besides, you know what we're doing? We don't take care of them. We don't give them humanitarian aid. Three mistakes. Three cruel inefficieties for which all Europeans are responsible.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, we all agree that the uncontrollable influx of refugees into Europe must end, that we must stop it, and at the same time we all know that border control is primarily in the hands of nation states, not the European Union. Some can handle it, others can't handle it. If the European Commission wanted to do something fundamental, it would have to rewrite budgetary rules, it would have to change the entire budget, it would have to cut funds elsewhere, and it would have to direct a much larger part of that money towards the protection of external borders. We all know that's not going to happen, so the only other way is to leave that protection in the hands of nation states. To try to help them, not to block their activities, not to criticise those who have chosen to protect the EU's external borders, and to make it clear to those who cannot do so that they simply cannot be part of the Schengen area, because there is no other way. So, among other things, the European Commission should prepare some easier rules for restoring temporary internal borders within the EU.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Madam President, the President-in-Office of the Council said earlier that in the face of the refugee crisis, we must find common and effective answers. He is absolutely right, and I share his position, but we must face reality, Madam President. The truth is that there is no common management of the common external borders. We need to change that. The truth is that the removal of internal border controls is being suspended in a growing number of countries. We have to stop this mechanism. In truth, the refugee distribution plan is now a sad farce. We need to end this plan or make it work. In truth, despite the promise of a cheque, a first cheque, of 3 billion, Turkey still does not control its maritime borders and lets a mafia of smugglers develop a real industry. Madam President, we must stop doing the belly dance in front of Erdogan and talk to him in a different tone.  In truth, and despite the launch of registration centres, so-called economic migrants are left in the wild, from where they will grow tomorrow the ranks of illegals in either country. Registration centres must also be reception centres. The truth is, the return policy is a mirage. It has to be organized. Madam President, there is an urgent need. We need a European surge, and the ball is in your hands.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), question with "blue card" . – I wanted to ask you, apart from the necessity of the 'hot spots' you mentioned – and we agree – do you agree or not that we should also decide to set up 'hot spots' outside the Member States as recorded in its resolution by the Council of Europe?

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, dear colleague, I thank you for your question, but I think first of all that if we set up registration centres in our territory, it is so that they are used for something and not just for bureaucratic registration. Once people have been registered, if we let them go in all directions, we will not be able to implement an essential element of the Commission's programme, namely relocation. So there is no point in registering refugees if nothing happens afterwards. So the first requirement is to do what we are committed to doing properly.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). – Ladies and gentlemen, you naturally understand that we are discussing corpses, whose numbers are growing every day, and you are talking about better guarding the european Union's external borders, and you are also proposing cooperation with Turkey which is challenging precisely these borders. So make it clear, what do you mean? Are we under attack by an army? Desperate and hungry, women and children, we have before us. What do you suggest? Minefields, ditches, snipers? And don't ever hear about re-launches, Schengen suspensions and other big mouth.  And finally, stop hiding behind Greece. You blame her for an alibi, because you refuse to take even your own minimum responsibility for a problem that your own policy has created, and today I have not heard any self-criticism in this Chamber. So what do you want? What are you editing? What have you decided? Rebuild concentration camps? Make Greece the Lebanon of Europe? Should Europe become the incubator of Nazism and fascism again?  The solution is one, ladies and gentlemen, I have said it many times before in this Chamber and it must be implemented immediately. Safe routes for refugees, and by analogy hosting them in all the Member States of the European Union.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In the refugee debates of recent years, we have always heard the mantra of the evil fortress of Europe, especially from the left. And I was already warning about this cheeky lie at the time. Because Europe is still not a fortress. Our borders were and still are open like a barn gate, like a Swiss cheese, if you will.  We do not have any protection of our external borders, and more than a million immigrants clearly demonstrate this. Now Turkey is to put a stop to this migration of peoples. Turkey is asking for five billion, in addition to the 750 million so-called pre-accession aid already transferred each year.  This is bazaar, it is pure blackmail, and I fear that Turkey will continue to trample on fundamental rights, will continue to arrest journalists, continue to wage a campaign against the Kurds and Europe will dance on its nose. In any case, Turkey is not an option to replace our lack of determination in border security.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: Madam President, stop the policy of migrant quotas, which sends a disastrous message of incitement to illegal immigration. I went to the refugee camps in Lebanon and Jordan. I've taken stock of their situation. Following the news on old television sets, they believe they will be welcomed, fed, housed, cared for in Europe. I spoke to men and women who were desperate to see the inertia of the international community in the face of the crisis in Syria and Libya. This is the source of the problems. Forced into difficult living conditions, some prefer to attempt to cross the Mediterranean at the risk of their lives.  Reality is not the dream you let them hope for. The photo of little Aylan moved the world. How many children lost their lives last week at sea in general indifference?  Europe is overwhelmed, unable to cope with the massive wave of migrants it has itself encouraged and is threatened by the infiltration of terrorists among migrants.  Some invoke the great principles of Europe, when we are unable to provide real security for our peoples, unable to ensure the reception and integration of so many migrants, unable to return illegal immigrants who devote asylum channels. We pay a high price. Schengen is under threat, our external borders are submerged, the Calais Jungle has become europe's largest slum and France's shame. The European ideal is not to encourage uprooting of populations. Our financial aid must be judiciously directed to be effective, to Lebanon, Jordan, humanitarian organizations, to keep migrants in their cultural crucible. If you do not want our European peoples to turn to populism, stop promoting a policy that destabilizes and worries them.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I must tell you honestly that I am almost speechless, I am shaken, I am ashamed, frustrated, and I am appalled at the debates I have to listen to in this House today. We say, "Oh, it's great, Turkey can take care of two million refugees, we'll give you a little bit of money." Do we want to say in all seriousness that we, as a European continent of 500 million citizens, are not in a position to take care of two or even three million refugees? Is that the message that we are overwhelmed by this? I find it appalling how we are talking about people fleeing war, political persecution or poverty, and who treat some – including here in this House – like annoying drifts that can be stacked anywhere in the world. Maybe at some point it's gone by itself. The main thing is that we don't have to worry. The number of refugees coming to us is not the great challenge. The problem is that we have not had a European strategy for dealing with refugees for years. They happen to arrive in Italy, Greece and Bulgaria, and the expectation is that they must stay there. Germany is complaining and saying: One million refugees, but now it is good. 800,000 refugees arrived in Greece last year. Under the current rules, they should all have stayed in Greece. How is this supposed to work? We do not have a refugee crisis – we have a European crisis of irresponsibility! I find it appalling how recklessly we are going to destroy this Europe for the sake of our own convenience! (The speaker refused to answer a question from Mrs Hohlmeier under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Madam President, listening to this debate, can I suggest, colleagues, to us all: we have got a problem. We need to be more precise in the language that we use. I hear the word ‘migrant’ used to describe people fleeing war and persecution. These are not migrants; these are genuine refugees, people to whom we can and must offer refuge. I have heard the word ‘migrant’ used to describe people from all parts of the world coming to Europe in search of a better life. These are not migrants; these are economic migrants, and they are people who invariably have no lawful claim to residence here. Finally, I have heard the word migrant applied to Europeans who live or work in a European country not of their birth. These are not migrants; they are European citizens exercising the right of free movement, something they are perfectly entitled to do. Colleagues, if we are not more precise in our language, not only are we confusing the public, but I suspect at times we confuse ourselves as well.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – I do not think there is any need to underestimate the information of people who, as refugees, migrants, asylum seekers, come to Europe. They know they're not welcome here anymore. That here, even today in the European Parliament, we are discussing more about how to deter, stop, fence and reject them. Put simply, there are too many to accept broadly, in accordance with the ethics and values to which we refer in such speeches. We did not think about what was going to happen to us in Europe when we approved and participated in the wars that drove these people out of their homes and made them, today, with their families, humiliated on our roads and borders, dying on overturned boats. We did not think about this when we prioritised violent interventions over political and diplomatic solutions. We've heard a lot of emotional speeches here today, a lot of anger about our powerlessness. I'm not going to be a part of this. I would just like to stress that, at the moment, everyone – High Representative Mogherini and all European governments – must urgently support the peace talks in Syria, which can only restore confidence that refugees will have nowhere to return when the time comes. And then we will have to find political solutions for other countries from which people are fleeing to Europe.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Madam President, these days, these days, we should remember the case of Anne Frank and how the United States could have saved her life and that of her family if they had not been denied a visa to emigrate. The slow paperwork and fear that Nazi spies would infiltrate among the refugees - I don't know if this rings a bell – frustrated asylum seekers that would have saved thousands of lives.  Measures such as those adopted in Denmark or the Commission's recent threats against Greece are outrageous on a continent with a recent history as traumatic as ours. The European Union must already act, lead to a diplomatic exit to the Syrian civil war, cut off the supply of arms to the area and carry out an effective policy of welcoming refugees, both in the countries of the region, such as Turkey, Lebanon, Jordan, and in Europe.  And the European Union must assume its responsibility to guarantee the right to asylum. Ensuring the right to asylum and the proper integration of refugees requires mobilizing resources and changing our political priorities.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Madam President, because of the repetition scourge, I would ask you to call for moderation of the dictions. This is the third time that I have heard from the Left that, despite the sadness of the situation at Europe's external borders, is in no way, in any way, in proportion to the atrocities of the Nazi era. I hear here that comparisons to the Nazi era are made. I heard twice that the previous speaker compared the way in which refugees were treated with the Holocaust. Holocaust is a unique crime under the Nazis, and I ask you here to intervene and declare that these comparisons are inappropriate and should not be used any further.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in 2015, one million migrants overwhelmed Europe and the invasion continues and will continue. Border states, such as Italy and Greece, have found themselves facing an unprecedented social emergency on their own, and our citizens have had to deal with the tragic social consequences of mass immigration, with the uncontrollable increase in violence, in crime in our cities, with Islamic terrorist madness. The Union's external borders are a sieve. The situation is untenable and can only get worse. Without the right controls on who arrives at sea or on land, without a serious common immigration policy and without mandatory returns for the thousands of illegal immigrants living on the shoulders of our people, the European Union will not survive the social pressures of this immigration emergency. The European Union has slept soundly in recent years, dreaming of a united and strong Europe. It is time to wake up because the dream of a united European Union has turned into a nightmare for our people.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Madam President, first of all, I would like to welcome what the last speaker of the Conservative group has just said, that we must be nuanced when it comes to all these words, 'refugees', 'migrants', etc., but I would like to draw his attention to the fact that the first to cultivate these confusions is the British Prime Minister, David Cameron. That is why we now have huge problems negotiating the British proposal, which is nonsense, as much as this crisis. But I'm glad there are Conservatives who understand the crux of the problem. Having said that, I would like to emphasise the issue of refugees in its 'external affairs' dimension, in particular on the fact that, as soon as the negotiations resume in Geneva, the European Union is trying to exert its full weight on these negotiations. We are weakened in this context, because, it must be said, we have not heard the cry of the Turks, the Jordanians, the Lebanese, who have been alerting us for years about the refugee crisis and the efforts they have made. We responded very, very late. That is a lesson we need to learn. I would also like to say a word about the importance of our partnership with Turkey, because I know that there are many people here in this House who are completely irresponsible when it comes to Turkey. For reasons related to their partisan affairs, they are prepared to flout Turkey, to put it in impossible situations, without understanding that we need this partner to solve the refugee crisis.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Madam President, when at the end of last year the EU pledged to provide a facility of EUR 3 billion to Turkey to help them assist with the 2.75 million refugees that they have received from Syria, it was hailed as a key tenet of the EU’s response to the refugee crisis. This facility was meant to start to provide grants and other financial support as of 1 January 2016, and it is appalling that here we are, more than a month later, and still EU Member States are fighting over how much they will contribute to the facility. My country might have been quickly prepared to pay its share, but I remain deeply disappointed that the United Kingdom has opted out from taking its share of refugees in the joint relocation scheme. Initially it was said that only EUR 0.5 billion would be provided from the EU’s own budget. The rest would be genuine new money from the EU Member States. And yet to date, that figure has risen to EUR 1 billion from the EU budget. We must make sure that it rises no more. President Juncker was right when he said that these EUR 3 billion are a question of credibility for the EU. And on a day when there are those in my own Member State, sadly, who want the European Union to fail that test of credibility, we have to make sure that it succeeds. As my political group has emphasised, whatever the crisis, our shared values must remain the same. And I call on all Members here to go back to your governments and to get them to commit the money so the facility can offer the humanitarian development support that is so desperately needed.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I have great respect for the talkers, but if I were to ask now how many of you were in the refugee camp, how many hands would they raise now? I don't know, I don't ask that question. I myself have been in a refugee camp this year. I devoted part of my leave to this, because it was in Kurdistan. And I ask you, very many of them do not want to go to Europe at all, they want to go back to where the Islamic State is now. I think it is necessary and worth giving money not only to Turkey, but also to the Kurds, so that its inhabitants stay there, because they are close to their homes.  And finally, let's not be a hypocrite! Today we are talking about European solidarity. I remember when the President of France – now speaking to my French friends – spoke here in December 2007, saying that the climate package is great for the old Union, but not for the new one. Did you talk about European solidarity at the time? And did my German friends talk about European solidarity when they built Nord Stream with the Russians? So we need to talk about European solidarity in all its dimensions, not just in this one.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Madam President! We have a crisis of solidarity in the European Union, a crisis that is manifested in the form of a paralysed European Union. For the first time, freedom of movement, which is, after all, one of the cornerstones of the European Union, is not something we can take for granted. Europe has failed, we have failed. Neither institutions nor we politicians have had the answers that citizens can rightly expect. This is all because the political will is not there.  Of course, the European Union is the crucial framework if we are to solve the problems together. But the EUROPEAN Union is not a button that you can just press, and then everything will resolve itself. If the Member States do not bring something to the community, then there will be no community. And what we are seeing at the moment is that across Europe governments are talking about common solutions but acting nationally.  Then it is important to say that we all have a responsibility to solve the problems. We must find these solutions together! The Member States must also understand and deliver this. This is urgent and it can appropriately take place at the European Summit here in mid-February. So it is therefore an invitation to the Council to take action. I believe that we share the analysis many of us share, that if we are to have common solutions, then it requires will, and that will must be mobilised here in mid-February.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Madam President, too many years later, the Council announces that it has taken the appropriate decisions and that it is now time to take action. The Commission suggests that the more refugees we expel, the more people will rely on European asylum policy. The European People's Party rives that will not allow the right of asylum to be abused. ALDE says D-Day is February 18th. Ladies and gentlemen, it's been thousands of dead on D-Day. And some Members boast of heart and solidarity when their parties demonstrate and do the opposite where they govern. An Italian colleague was talking about perverse play that brings together incapacity and unwillingness. And hypocrisy, I'd add. I can only add that Samuel Beckett could have located his theater of absurdity here. Ladies and gentlemen, to those who have not done so, I encourage you to travel to Lesbos, Ceuta, Presevo or Calais. So they would know better what is going on and this debate would be very different.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, earlier we heard the President of the Socialist Group tell us, with scum on our lips, that Europe's problem, in these times of migration catastrophe, was the virus of fear, which would settle among Europeans. A speech applauded by the PRESIDENT of the EPP, Merkel's spokesman. Let Mr. Pittella spare his abundant saliva, spare his fragile nerves and therefore welcome some of these so-called refugees home! At the expense of the vital interests of our peoples, you claim to defend a community of values, but your values are abstract and disembodied, in the service of dangerous and utopian ideologies. No, your values are not ours, your priorities are not ours, for well-ordered charity begins with oneself, that is, by one's own. Now, you want to help illegal immigrants at all costs before our citizens, always others before ours and of course yourself before everyone else! For it is not you who pay the consequences of your crazy decisions, but our most modest and fragile compatriots. When I saw that this debate was about violence against migrants and not about the violence committed by them, from Cologne to Calais, I first thought it was a slip of the day. But no, you really dare everything, and that's what we recognize you for!

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE). Madam President, in an environment of threat to the Schengen area we must be honest with ourselves and our citizens. Closing borders is a political choice, not a necessity. Selection of specific states that do not want refugees on their territory, do not care about European values and international norms and star in blame-transfer games. Greece is struggling to control - as far as possible - a vast sea area in the Aegean Sea, where Frontex experts consider effective control to be impossible, respects international law, cooperates with European agencies and above all saves human lives.  The European Union is well aware that the largest human trafficking networks are operating on the coast of Turkey with a huge turnover, committing the most abhorrent modern organised crime, but is not exerting the necessary pressure to create 'hot spots' outside European territory, in accordance with the Council of Europe resolution. We insist on this so that no more people are lost and we call for Turkey to be obliged to respect the agreements it has signed and to honour its commitments.  It is no use threatening Greece, which, because of its geographical position, has borne the brunt of the biggest refugee crisis since the Second World War. Let's all take responsibility. Any collapse of the Schengen area will be solely our responsibility and will not be due to the migration crisis. The big loser will be Europe itself and its values.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: – Madam President, today is Groundhog Day and, as in that magnificent Bill Murray film, our days and debates are repeated with little change. We're just not living a comedy, but we're experiencing one of the biggest dramas of recent years.  Winter has arrived, refugees continue to flee war, many of them fail to reach our countries because they die along the way and, if that were not, Europol launches us the other day that there are 10,000 missing children on our borders. The word "urgency" has fallen short.  Since October we have been talking about the refugee aid programme in Turkey, little progress has been made, to say the very thing. Vice-President Timmermans defined the creation of this instrument as translating our intentions into concrete actions. Twenty-four hours after its presentation, this Parliament already had a concrete funding proposal, ready to enter into force on 1 January, and the Council, two months later, is still unclear: neither how to finance nor what needs to be done. They say they're studying it and they'll keep us informed. Seriously? What are you waiting for? What has to happen for the Twenty-eight to unlock the negotiations?  We cannot continue with eternal and sterile discussions about funding, asylum policy, or how to deal with the ins and outs of refugees. Please put your batteries on, close the necessary agreements, do what you have to do, because people are dying at the gates of our house.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: – Madam President, the more things change, the more they stay the same. We continue to waffle on the migration issue, and while there is great frustration over the lack of progress, not enough of us are willing to admit that close cooperation with our neighbours is essential if we are ever going to bring the situation under control. Turkey is, whether some like it or not, a key partner in the overall management of the migration crisis that is hitting us much closer to home, and Turkey’s overall political relationship with the EU is simply not part of this debate. Let us not forget that Turkey has shown goodwill by providing care for over two million refugees who have already poured into the country. Obviously, any funds given to Turkey must be carefully monitored, but processing centres, shelter, food and education over there will go a long way to stemming the problem over here.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Madam President, it is the policies of interference and aggression of the USA, NATO and the European Union that are at the root of conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa. Policies that do not hesitate to finance and promote extremist forces, to carry out multimillion-dollar contracts for arms sales to dictatorships such as Saudi Arabia, with a view to the economic and geopolitical dominance of those regions.  This is the bottom line of the mass exodus of millions of people arriving on the European continent fleeing hunger, misery, war and death. To fight this Parliament for the defence of human rights and i would condemn without tibiezas the response to this reality.  The walls, the fascist laws of humiliation of refugees, the concept of fortress Europe, the financing of neighbouring states to contain the wave of refugees in authentic concentration camps, are the mark of brutality and inhumanity of the European Union. Those who manage to survive such solidarity, they are left with miserable reception conditions that precede compulsory repatriation.  History will condemn those who now shut up or support these policies.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, how difficult waking is the awakening is! Across Europe, the immigrationist ideology, which you have promoted, has been shattered. Everywhere, reality has regained its rights: attacks, mass rapes, anti-Semitic attacks and other beatings of Christians are the consequence of your blindness. But rather than listen to the patriotic movements in Europe, which predicted the debacle, you still refuse to acknowledge your wrongs and are desperately looking for palliatives.  However, your remedies will aggravate the evil, because financing Turkey, which is playing a murky game with the group "Islamic State", is irresponsible, because it is criminal to refuse to send back migrants massively, because not taking responsibility for the rising tensions between migrants and local populations pushed to the limit by acts of barbarism is cowardly and despicable. On behalf of the peoples of Europe, Mr Juncker, stop the damage and listen to us.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: – The disappearance of a huge number of emigrating children in the European Union raises the question of the level of security in refugee camps. It also shows the weakness of IT databases about people coming to Europe. We know that some of these children did not have any documents, but after all, they have undergone initial registration in the Union. Now we fear that they are being forced into slave labour or even prostitution by gangs.  How can these children be found if we still do not have an integrated system of all databases in the European Union, such as Eurodag, the Schengen Information System and others, and european institutions such as EASO, Frontex or even Europol do not have full access to them? How can an investigation against smuggling gangs be carried out effectively if the relevant services in the Member States do not always want to fully exchange the necessary information? Finally, how is Frontex supposed to coordinate the protection of the external borders if it cannot use the Schengen Information System in the country with the greatest wave of migration? How it finally happened that we set up Frontex in the Union, then created the Schengen Information System, and then blocked the possibility for these institutions to work together not only in times of peace, but also in times of crisis.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: – Madam President, we need to answer one question today – does the EU want to manage the migration crisis or only deal with the consequences? If the answer is "governance," we don't do it. The ancient legend of Sysyph and the stone continues to be an emblem of this policy. We have not solved a single problem of people fleeing war and death, we have not stopped economic migrants, we have not reassured our own citizens. Instead of solidarity solutions – separatist alliances of Member States without adequate Council response, new walls and fences and attempts to destroy Schengen.  The crisis has put Europe in an emergency, emergency measures are required for extremely short periods of time. There is a need to strengthen the security services and border authorities in strict compliance with human rights and international treaties. This is what our citizens want, but the Commission is slowing down the adoption of the border protection regulation. Applies a double standard as to why it excludes Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia from the scope of the new agency. There have been attempts at buffer zones between Schengen Europe and transit countries. Dublin needs to change, but the first-country admissions clause is not removed. How will a permanent relocation mechanism work when the temporary one has not yet been activated? What is the recapitulation from La Valletta and the Western Balkans?  And one more thing, Commissioner, the Balkans are a complex region – there conflicts are born quickly and never fade, let's not play with fire! Isolating Greece is unfair. Is it her fault that the agreement with Turkey is not working? This is a European, not a Greek problem. It is high time that the Council in February carried out a full review of all policies so far and come up with a programme, with concrete actions and deadlines.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, representatives of PPE, S&D, ALDE, GUE, this debate is absolutely unconditional evidence of the complete failure of the policy that you, your Commission and your governments have been leading in recent years with regard to illegal immigration, the insane ransom policy for Turkey, despite its support for Islamic State and Salaphite terrorism.  Everything we at ECR warned you about happened. For four hours, your leaders theatrically and, forgive me, hypocritically try to justify themselves for the tweeted failure of the so-called integration of misguided multiculturalism, of quotas for illegal immigrants, and so on. The startling hypocrisy, the violence in Cologne and other European cities, the millions of illegal immigrants, the attacks they carried out all over Europe, the disorder at Europe's borders, the thousands of missing children, the victims of all exploitation, are all your responsibility and your fault, and this cannot be denied.  Stop hypocrisy and justifications, admit your guilt and defeat, spare the empty talk!

name: Reimer BÖGE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Indeed! The systems we have created were for normal times and were not resilient to crises. There is also a lack of implementation of existing agreements. I would also like to say here that the protection of external borders must become a common matter, and this also applies to the fair distribution of the burden – including finances – in dealing with the refugee crisis, as Article 80 of the Treaty states.
