Defining safe countries of origin was and is overdue. But without development and stabilization in the Middle East and Africa, we will be surrounded in the long run by failed states, and the influx will never end. I think that our neighbourhood policy also needs to be reviewed and refocused in general. Now we are talking about a Turkey facility – the Commission's original proposal: 500 million from the budget, 2.5 billion from the Member States. Without Parliament's involvement, Commissioners, it suddenly says: one billion from the European budget. In future, we will not deal with each other as partners, to put it very clearly! Now, with a view to the donors' conference to be held in London on Thursday, I hear that the European Union will make a commitment of 2.2 billion and beg everyone to double the commitments. Is this fresh money now, or does it come from the October 2015/2016 package of 9.2 billion? And then, Madam President, they say that Macedonia and Serbia should receive aid from the Syrian Mandate Fund. Also true, but do we forget that we have previously taken 500 million out of the European budget and removed our neighbourhood and candidate countries? This is household juggling. Pocket tricks are part of the circus, not serious fiscal policy, to end the refugee crisis.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – While the European Commission is working hard to formulate a common response to the refugee crisis, we see little of this in reality. The lack of solidarity within the EU is at the root of this. Viktor Orbán's Europe, the old Europe of fences is getting closer every day.  Last week I finally heard a different sound from a European country. The Dutch government launched an alternative plan to provide refugees with a safe legal route to Europe on a large scale. There was talk of 250 000 resettlements per year. As far as the PvdA is concerned, this may even be a little more ambitious.  I also heard a government that says that we should not be paralysed by a number of crossbenchers within the EU, but should now take the lead with benevolent countries. The illegal route managed by the people smugglers must therefore become an unattractive alternative. How, we can argue about that. Unfortunately, the Commission had a quick answer ready and the plan was shot down in advance. How many alternatives do you think there will be for the Europe of fences? Commissioner Avramopoulos, can you explain here why the European Commission rejects the direction of thinking of this plan and can Minister Koenders explain how support is being recruited within the Council for this plan?

name: Peter van DALEN
text: – Good to see Mr. Koenders and his team here. Welcome! There are stacks of plans on the table on how the European Union should tackle the refugee issue. And I'd say let's stop making more plans. It's time for action! The Dutch Council President is due to hold a summit this month and - I say as a Protestant - according to the model of a pope election in Vatican City. You don't come out until a decision has been made and white smoke can be seen. The concepts of warm-heartedness and control should be the starting points of that conference. Europe warmly captures people whose lives are at stake because of war or persecution of faith. But there is no place for asylum seekers from, for example, Morocco, Algeria and Albania. They can make a living in their own country. And then let Europe set up development aid in such a way that it goes well there. Finally, we must prevent Turkey from being insescribed to the EU at a time.  For both them and the EU, a good neighbourhood programme is by far the best option.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, since the beginning of this refugee crisis I have been told that the Union should be required to act on two different levels: one more immediate, one long-term, one to deal with the emergency, one to get to the root of the problems.  It is not by announcing far-flung legislative measures that we are facing emergencies. That's the way it was with search and rescue operations. The States did not want to respond at first and only faced with the tragedies in the Mediterranean granted more support.  The same is true of Schengen now. The emergency relocation mechanism remains weak, hot spots in Greece and Italy remain without the necessary means, return operations remain unappropriated and, if that were not enough, national, isolated and selfish measures still proliferate. Without responding immediately to the urgency, states, not refugees, are putting Schengen in danger.  Of course, the reintroduction of internal border controls is a possibility available to Member States, but they are temporary measures, they do not solve any problem. Free movement within the Schengen area has always been reinforced as a counterpoint to common external borders.  The new Schengen evaluation mechanism, which we proposed in 2013 and which was recently used in Greece, has shown that the Union has the capacity to identify the problems, but as is clear from this crisis, the Union needs tools to respond to these problems when Member States fail to do so. FRONTEX should therefore be strengthened.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which For the current 2016 budget, the European Union has mobilised everything that the medium-term financial framework makes possible. Billions have been allocated to eliminate the causes of flight and to help Member States deal with the refugee crisis. This includes the fact that the EU budgetary authority has allocated the contributions from the EU budget to the agreed trust funds.  Unfortunately, the Member States are still a long way from that. My question to the Member States is: why do they agree on these instruments when they are obviously unwilling to use them? The European Parliament has shown that it has a constructive role to play in dealing with the refugee crisis. That is why, as a member of the Committee on Budgets, I find it strange that this House only ever learns about the financing of the Turkish facility from the newspapers.  As far as I know, neither the Presidency of the Council nor the Commission has yet consulted the EP on this matter. I think you should make up for that as a matter of urgency.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, some people accuse Greece, quite unfairly, of allegedly not restricting refugee flows in the Aegean. In fact, they threaten Greece with expulsion from Schengen even though they know that this is not foreseen. Do you think, ladies and gentlemen, that the issue of the halt to the thousands of refugees brought by the Turkish slave trade in the Aegean will be solved by the new Frontex? Where's he going to do what? Is he going to sink boats full of refugees?  So you have not wondered why thousands of refugees risk drowning in the Aegean Sea to come to Greece and do not choose to go from Turkey to Bulgaria? Why has Greece become a magnet for refugees? But because it is the only Schengen country that is adjacent to Turkey and as a Schengen country it provides travel documents that refugees get to go to Germany.  If Greece leaves Schengen, then 90% of the refugees will not come to Greece. That is why I have already proposed on 11 December that Greece close the borders and withdraw from the Schengen Treaty. The negative consequences for my country will be minimal and the benefits enormous. So let go of bilingualism. After all, Schengen has been suspended in Germany, France, Sweden, Austria and Denmark. Apply the relocation of refugees. Stop attacking Ankara, create "hot spots" in Turkey.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: PPE). Madam President, despite the justified reservations, we must promote to Turkey the money that has been approved to meet the needs of the two and a half to three million refugees who have fled to Turkey. The longer we delay, the sooner the refugee will get out of control. We have two months of difficult weather ahead of us in the Aegean, which means that the flows will be fifty to sixty thousand people a month. But from April, and with the help of good weather, flows could reach one hundred and fifty thousand people a month, destabilising the European Union.  Only if Ankara's policy changes and becomes more restrictive will refugee flows be drastically reduced. But to see if the Turkish government is cooperative, we must first meet the basic economic needs of refugees in Turkey. After all, we are urgently responsible for a rapid reduction in refugee flows. If we financially support the refugees in Turkey and it does not respond, then we will pursue a strict policy towards it. But we must first send the money to assess Ankara's reaction and make final decisions.  Many of my colleagues believe that by delaying or aborting the sending of the money we will punish the Turkish regime for which I do not have a particularly positive view. But I believe that by delaying the sending of the money we are punishing two and a half to three million refugees and ourselves.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in addition to the debate we are having at this time and in these weeks and months in Parliament, a high debate, which has to do with Europe's values, there is a parallel debate – and this is not a debate – that leads President Weber alone against the Italian Government. We, on the other hand, will need politics and not accountants' questions and reasoning, as President Weber always does. I wonder, for example, why not a single word has been said on this day about your party colleague, the President of Hungary, Mr Orbán, who is building barbed wire in our Europe. This, for example, would have been a debate on this subject. This is a very complex issue. We need to talk about politics. We need to build on Europe's values, to think about Schengen and how Shengen is attacked, how refugees are welcomed on our continent, how italy and Greece are helped and how refugee camps in Turkey are helped. And instead we're thinking about that.  Perhaps, and this is a question I am asking myself and leaving it to the House, the real attack that Weber is making is not on President Renzi, but perhaps it is an attack on the Commission and on Mr Juncker.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: – I am European, but first of all Bulgarian. In this form, the European Union is doomed and Schengen is completely dead – a burst bubble. New Berlin walls divide Europe. Europe at several speeds turned poor Europeans into a ghetto. Mrs Merkel invited refugees to secure cheap labour for the German economy. European leaders are helpless – they cannot make simple decisions. We are making excessive concessions to the Erdogan regime, which trades oil with DAESH. I do not support giving €3 billion to Turkey to protect our common borders.  Turning poor European countries such as Bulgaria and Greece into buffer zones is an insane crime against European citizens. You're blackmailing poor people for crumbs. Let Germany pay that $3 billion on its own and Europe will support Bulgaria in protecting the European border. These 3 billion should go to the Bulgarian and Greek border police, not to Turkey.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Dear Sirs, allow me four brief remarks. Firstly, the issue of violence against refugees is relevant. They are mostly vulnerable children. We have heard that as many as 10 000 children have disappeared on European soil. Europol foresees that organised crime abducted or purchased by them is being abused for sexual slavery or for exploitative work. On the other hand, we should be concerned about at least one other vulnerable group, these are European girls, we know why. So member states are facing the important question of how to fill the security vacuum in which they have been hovering for two decades. Secondly, Turkey. The EU must work credibly and with Turkey to contain the migrant waves, but we must not rely 100% on them or on others. Above all, we must rely on ourselves, especially on joint actions. Thirdly – Schengen. This is one of the European Union's greatest achievements. Today, the European Union is on the test and with it. Thank Goodness that the European Union has offered at least part of the solution with the Border and Coast Guard, which is given new powers to protect our external borders. And fourthly – regardless of Greece's future status, the European Union must be rescued at all costs. That's why we should urgently stop or stem the migrant wave. In this context, it should take alternative measures. If this does not go in Greece, let us give aid to Albania, Macedonia and Bulgaria. Finally, we must start returning economic migrants immediately.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President; Commissioner, here we are again in a long and sad debate which is not about refugees, it is about a Europe badly hurt by indifference to the multiplication of children who, like Aylan, are not an image in the news, but a human being, many human beings drowning on our beaches. And in the face of the collapse of Schengen, disappeared in combat. And in the face of decisions marking an hour of infamy in the Council, abandoned to the extension of the suspension of the free movement of persons for two years, or to the confiscation of property to finance the stay of persons seeking refuge between us. Worst of all, this revelation we have known about Europol, for which ten thousand children, no less than ten thousand children, have disappeared into the hands of illicit trafficking networks, abandoned in the hands of vermin. It is imperative to make decisions so that what Jacques Delors once defined as a bicycle that, if not pedaled, falls, does not become this Europe in its darkest hour, in which it retreats, in disunity and in insolidarity, into a state of permanent alarm, in which it is abandoned to its fate not only to its most vulnerable frontier , which is Greece, but millions of desperate human beings.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We have heard a long list of touching declarations on immigration. The most one is missing from this long list: credibility. Why do we actually remain silent when someone specifically cries out for help, or when we hear uncomfortable truths? For example, when we hear the truth about violence against refugees, against Christian refugees from immigrants, not somewhere far away, but in refugee centres in our cities. In this case, the specific facts of which the European Parliament is informed are contained, for example, in this resolution and have been waiting for many weeks to be considered. Because it is uncomfortable to hear that exile and immigration are not only different concepts, but sometimes downright opposite. This is not about solidarity, but about imposing multiculturalism on those countries that have so far been fortunate enough to avoid it.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is facing enormous migratory pressure at its external borders, which is putting a strain on the resilience of several treaties, including Schengen. Despite the difficult situation, we must be able to strike the right balance between the protection needs of asylum seekers, thus respecting our international obligations and the impossibility of receiving economic migrants. According to the latest and unfortunately not very precise data, between 500 and 5 000 migrants cross the Turkish-Greek border every day. We are grateful to the European Commission for the legislative proposals it has put forward in recent months, but we must work towards finding a solution in the very short term. I am convinced that the European Union already has a useful legislative acquis and that these rules must be fully applied, just as I am convinced that Schengen must be defended, but we must not exceed a pre-established limit. The creation of hotspots and the quota mechanism, which as it appears to be lacking, are certainly two of the priorities that the European Union must put in place for this phenomenon. The European Union must also reach a final agreement on funding 3 billion euros to Turkey to control the flow of refugees in the period 2016-2017. Turkey can be a geographically important partner in achieving the objective of controlling flows. That, at this historic moment, Europe cannot afford to welcome everyone.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, indeed, 2 and a half million refugees, mainly Syrians, are officially welcomed on Turkish soil. This cannot leave us indifferent, especially since these migrants are, sooner or later, destined to return to their country or to go to an EU country. Turkey is indeed in a geostrategic situation of major importance and we must be aware of this. This creates obligations for Turkey itself, but also for the European Union. The idea of the Union helping Turkey is a perfectly smart idea, which I support, but it must be translated into transparency. Who pays for these aids? The states, the EU budget or both? Who actually receives these aids? The Turkish government or NGOs? And who controls the use of these funds?  These are all questions that must be answered. Every must be done so that Turkey can welcome refugees on its soil with dignity.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Madam President, I believe that the refugee crisis touches us all and above all I have to say that it has touched the European Union itself. As much as we are critical or self-critical we must say yes, we may not have done what had to be done, but if everyone did what the European Union did, today we probably would not be discussing refugees.  What did others do when the European Union, in 2015 alone, provided financial assistance for the wider issue of some eighteen billion? How many discussions, how many efforts, how many actions and how many actions did the European Union take when the Arab League, the United States of America, Russia, and other European countries that are not part of the European Union, in fact, did nothing and observed with apathy or often criticized the European Union?  But we have to say something very important. The refugees are not created by Greece. Greece welcomes refugees. At the same time as some other countries are erecting walls and barriers, Greece is raising the bar of solidarity, and the tried and tested Greek people with their economy tested, with few means at their disposal, proved to be a model and an example. I believe that those who continue to shoot Greece do not love the European Union itself and those who believe that Greece should stay out of Schengen is because they want to undermine and blow the European Union up.  I believe that if we want to seek responsibility we must look to Turkey, which essentially leaves the refugees and sends them to Greece. What do some people want, Greece to send the refugees back to Turkey? And one last thing, Madam President, I would like to say that the Greek people and the Greeks of the islands deserve it, and the initiative must also be supported by the European Commission, Commissioner, in order to receive the Nobel Peace Prize for the effort and heroism they have shown towards refugees.

name: Soraya POST
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I have been sitting since three o'clock and listening, and I must confirm a great deal of disappointment at this debate and the level of debate at all. I feel ashamed and horrified at what needs to be listened to, and I am ashamed of our 500 citizens in Europe.  I think we're putting a lot of risk right now. We are risking our dignity, we are risking the whole of the European project and we are risking all our trust in europe as a project by the international community. If we cannot stand up for human rights, if we cannot protect humanism, who will?  We are talking about IS, we are talking about racism: they are based on the same ideology. We have it in Europe and we have it to fight against in the Middle East. We must be steadfast and we must work together. The lack of respect shown by the Council towards Parliament and the Commission is not worthy of cooperation.  According to Amnesty's latest report, EU officials are violating children and women. Commission, what are you going to do? We have to deal with these issues. It is our responsibility, as we have said when we were elected: we must stand up for the equal value of all people. If we do not manage to do so, we are risking the future of the whole of Europe and of Europe.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Madam President, it is high time to give a clear vision of the direction of development of THE EU's migration policy – whether to maintain the open-door policy for all or to reduce permeability and ensure the security of European citizens, without this being contrary to international law. I have repeatedly pushed for increased control and security at European external borders – something my country Bulgaria has long done. A shared responsibility for their security will lead to more trust between Member States and ensure that one of the European Union's greatest achievements, freedom of movement, is maintained. It is therefore essential that the new European Border Office has a mandate to guard not only the Schengen borders, but also all the EU's external borders.  However, ensuring the security of European citizens requires public and political support for the actions of European border guards. Unfortunately, Bulgarian border police officers, who do the difficult task of guarding the extremely choppy terrain on the border with Turkey, are often criticized by foreign NGOs. I consider this unacceptable, especially given that repeated checks on compliance with European legislation and the effective work of border police have refuted these claims.  Last but not least, I would like to draw attention to the need to cooperate with the EU's neighbourhood, especially those that house the most refugees or are on the migration route to Europe. A productive partnership with them will inevitably lead to a more effective fight against trafficking in human beings and a reduction in the migratory flow.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Sfortunatament qegťdin f'sitwazzjoni fejn minflok tindirizza l-problema tal-immigrazzjoni fil-qalba tagťha, l-Unjoni Ewropea qed tispièa ddur madwar il-problema, b'policies li jindirizzaw biss il-konsegwenzi. Din hija issue li tmur lil hinn mill-fruntieri tagťna, u li tirrikjedi azzjoni konżunta ma' bosta pajjiżi internazzjonali. L-isfidi li gťandna quddiemna, qegťdin jimminaw ukoll il-fruntieri u l-liżijiet Ewropej, li qatt ma kienu ppjanati gťall-kriżi li gťandna llum. Case in point, il-ftehim ta' Schengen u anki r-regulations ta' Dublin. Il-proposta li l-immigranti jiżu rilokati, gťada m'hijiex qed taťdem, u l-piż qed jibqa' jinżarr l-aktar minn dawk li qegťdin fuq il-fruntieri. Hu inutli, li nippuntaw subgťajna lejn pajjiż wieťed. Ir-realtà hi li l-pajjiżi li qegťdin fuq il-fruntiera ma jistgťux jitťallew aktar gťal riťhom mingťajr gťajnuna. Hemm bżonn policies Ewropej li juru bis-serjetà li l-problema qed tiżi managed mill-pajjiżi kollha. Inkella se nibqgťu induru madwar il-problemi mingťajr qatt ma nindirizzaw il-problema kif suppost, u nťallu l-problema tikber ferm akbar milli hi bťal'issa.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have to say that in recent weeks I have always been annoyed by the saying 'we need a European solution to the refugee crisis'. Actually, we have them. After all, we actually have very good laws – of course, there is still a need to turn a screw here and there. We are in an exceptional situation, but in fact the laws we have on asylum and immigration are not bad.  However, many Member States simply do not comply with it. This is something that the citizen should do at home, simply ignore the laws and rules that have been adopted! Surely it is not acceptable for Member States not to abide by the law or to honour their commitments. The UNHCR does not receive the promised money and cannot provide for the refugees accordingly. Frontex does not receive the long-promised increase in staff and finances and, of course, no further powers. Turkey will not receive the promised EUR 3 billion. What is eur 3 billion? That sounds a lot, but let us consider how much has already gone to Greece, and let us consider how much 'cheaper' it would be for the Member States to pay these EUR 3 million instead of taking in all the refugees. In fact, I also assume that not everyone wants to go to Europe, but wants to wait near home until they can go back. Where has the much-sungend European solidarity gone? This seems to exist for some Member States only when it comes to receiving money from the European budget. That solidarity is then needed. But that must not be allowed to happen, of course! It cannot be the case that Member States should simply refuse and that others should bear all the burden on their own.  I believe that such Member States must be held accountable, and I believe that the Commission should take action in this direction. There are also mechanisms – I am advocating infringement procedures. Moreover, we should consider whether such Member States really still need to receive the subsidies from the European budget.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam President, Mr Commissioner, Mr Foreign Minister Bert Koenders, good to see you again. I think we all know that the Dublin system has collapsed, and now Schengen is next in line if we do not act. This situation is a direct result of the lack of solidarity and of a common European approach to the refugee crisis. It is due to the lack of efficient control of our European external borders and the fact that too many Member States are failing to take their share of refugees. While some count their asylum applications in tens of thousands, others are counting them only in hundreds or even less. Member States who are bearing the brunt of the current influx of refugees, such as Germany, Sweden, Denmark, or Austria, are being forced, unfortunately, to adopt the extraordinarily harsh asylum laws that we are seeing today. It takes effort to keep up with the huge number of refugees, unfortunately. The reason for all of the problems is that Europe is failing to address, first of all, the root causes of the refugee crisis, as well as, of course, failing to cooperate in solidarity. Only four Member States meet the UN target of giving 0.7% in ODA. Money is desperately needed for the UNHCR and other agencies. I appeal to the Commission and Council to act on this and to encourage Member States to take their responsibility both for refugees and for tackling the root causes that have led people to flee.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Madam President, Schengen is in danger and must be protected. No situation, however complicated, can jeopardize our freedom of transit. Yes, and you also have to save lives and maintain the principle of non-return.  Our efforts must go in two directions: first, stop the war in Syria; and, secondly, to assume the responsibilities and commitments made in the area of resettlement, relocation, infrastructure, staff or financial aid , I am talking about solidarity.  I urge the Commission and the Council to adopt a final agreement for the financing of the EUR 3 billion committed to Turkey; I defend, and clearly, their governance and conditionality. Let the Council blockade be over now.  It is necessary the full and urgent operation of the hotspots, key pieces to order arrivals in our territory. All States must assume their responsibilities, both those who must register and identify, and others who must proceed with resettlement and social and economic integration, ensuring, until the end of the conflict, the integration they can provide, because refugees want to return to their homes, which is where they really want to be. I'm talking about a transient emergency.  In the meantime, our external borders need to be protected more and better and returned to those who are not subject to international protection. All this wrapped up and protected by the Charter of Human Rights.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I fully agree with what the Commission and the Council have said. However, we are still a long way from finding common answers and I fear that we will not find any, at least until these joint discussions are followed by ambitious and shared political decisions and measures implementing the decisions taken by the Council and Parliament. It is scandalous that to date only 400 requests for relocation have been accepted by the Member States. Migratory flows are unstoppable if long-term emergency and political measures are not implemented jointly, all within a legal framework for respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is true, Commissioner, that the saving of human lives and the principle of non-refoulement are not negotiable values. Without a forward-looking vision on the part of Europe, we will be the victims of an unprecedented political failure, as well as in the hands of extremist, xenophobic and populist forces, as well as deprived of the European Union's main achievement, namely the free movement of persons, the end of which would mark the decline of the project of European integration.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, I find you extremely brave at noon today. What could you have done in that time! You could have looked at the question of why the EU's previous Mediterranean programmes are experiencing such delays, such as the DCI. After all, they affect almost 80% of the projects and the money, in an area where we urgently need to invest. They could also have dealt with the question of how much money the refugees actually receive from the refugees. They could also answer the question of why new money, for example for trust funds, should do what the previous one cannot. I would like to work here with many colleagues to find common solutions. I support the proposals you have made. I support the Commission's proposals and would like to call for others, for example for all Member States, which themselves benefit greatly from the solidarity of the EU partners, but themselves do not show solidarity. Mrs Sommer has already mentioned this. I believe that the display of torture instruments has always worked in the EU, and that is why I believe that it would also help in this case. Withholding money is a language that is understood even without an interpreter. It's about all of us. It is not about Germany, about Turkey, Italy or Greece – it is about all of us. That is why the severely schizophrenic Members here should also be allowed to say that all those who demand common ground but belong to parties whose governments at home refuse precisely this common ground, I would like to say that if you had remained silent and been ashamed, the debate would not have been so deceitful. This debate is necessary, but it would also be important for those who are the problem to be named.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Madam President, having sat here for the past four and a half hours, I still think it right that we are having this debate. But, as I think we can all agree, our citizens are demanding concrete action from Member States. They have heard enough talk. We all have. If states cannot come together on the pressing issues of our time, then it is no wonder that people lose faith in the political process. It is useless agreeing on legislation when there is no expression of political will. When it comes to Schengen, we must understand that we do not have internal borders because we promised that our external borders would be more secure. One is dependent on the other. We trusted Member States to fulfill their obligations and in some cases we have been let down. So it is clear that we need more, and stronger, measures, but that alone will not be enough. We need a holistic global approach that looks at every single aspect. On returns, yes, people must be returned strictly in accordance with non-refoulement, and yes, we must give those who seek protection the chance to ask for it, but when you are found not to be eligible for protection, you must be sent back safely and swiftly. Those who are genuinely in need of protection should be able to find it in our Europe and other safe countries. Of course there are challenges, but the way forward is to have a two-way approach. People fleeing war must be given the rights they are entitled to, but it is also fair to expect respect for the values upon which the EU is built. Finally, the recent attacks in European cities and the rise in populist xenophobia in Europe are disturbing. The events in Cologne and the recent racist attacks expose underlying issues that must be addressed. We need to come down harder on hate, and as politicians we have a particular responsibility here that we should not ignore.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Council representative, to resolve the refugee issue I leave here a very simple recipe, an appeal: respect the values of the European Union, to practice the de facto solidarity carried out with concrete actions which Robert Schuman was speaking in the famous declaration of 9 May 1950.  Faced with common problems only with common action and concrete actions can we solve, and only in this way will we have peace, we will overcome the challenges and, in particular, this challenge of the refugee crisis.  But solidarity that does not mean just receiving, a solidarity that also means giving and it is unacceptable that Member States that receive billions from the European Union budget, hundreds of millions, will not be able after giving a penny to resolve this issue.  In view of this problem that we have, I leave a few questions here: is there a Member State that refuses to contribute? Are the amounts for each Member State defined? Can this support be extended to Jordan and Lebanon? Who will monitor and monitor execution on the ground? It is important to act, with transparency, with credibility and before it is too late, to act without populism, radicalism and national selfishness.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, while Member States display divisions, children are dying at sea. We have to save all, and treat all coming to Europe with dignity. It is the refugees who are in crisis, not us. For children, Europe must mean safety and protection. You know what needs to be done; there are no national solutions – we have common rules on reception, registration, resettlement, relocation and return. What is missing is the political will from the Member States. To the Council: time to act together, share responsibility. At least give funding to improve conditions for refugees and give protection in Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey, and step up the fight against smugglers by all means possible. Strengthen the Asylum Support Office and Frontex. It is smugglers who should be afraid, not refugees. Let’s face it: Turkey is part of the solution – short term and long term – but not all coming to Europe have the right to stay. That is why it is so important to take fingerprints and to differentiate between those who have the right to international protection and economic migrants. Effective external border control is a precondition for freedom of movement in Europe. Internal border checks must be temporary and a last resort and must respect the rules. It is time for the Member States to be serious about the cost of non-Schengen, and the Council is playing with fire.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, I think that the European Union must act more quickly, because the situation in the migration crisis is not improving. I want to make three comments, but very serious. I think that if the EU has to take care of someone, it is the children who are the most vulnerable group, and I think that we need to create an instrument, to create a safe environment so that children who are not accompanied are placed in safe centres where they will be looked after and not be safely on the street. I think this is a task that Frontex and other components can focus on immediately. The second thing is the Council's action and the establishment of border and coastguards. You have been called here for the Council of Ministers to act on this matter on 18 February, and I call again, this would be a concrete step towards security, which is a precondition for the further solidarity that has been discussed here.

name: Anna HEDH
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thousands of people are currently fleeing war and oppression to our continent, Europe. Our duty as fellow human beings to provide protection is crystal clear. The EU treaties and rules also rightly emphasise human rights. The EU Treaties also emphasise human rights, including the right of asylum. But now that people are seeking refuge in Europe on a larger scale than that, the construction of Europe is trembling.  Some, even members.m of my own European party such as Robert Fico in Slovakia, refuse to accept their responsibilities. Worse still, he also piles racist statements on high. President Juncker has promised on a number of occasions that the Commission will take a decision in January on redistribution from my country, Sweden, to those countries that have taken less responsibility. Can the Commissioner confirm when this will happen?

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: I would like to respond very briefly to mr Kirkhope's words. It is punishment that he compares the fallout of Louis Michel, a colleague who turned red and angry because he didn't get the word, to someone who calls for the shooting of refugees. Four and a half hours we have now debated! There are not a thousand ways to solve this crisis. We know what needs to be done. I'm making a call. I'd like to ask you, don't go to sleep. Don't take a vacation anymore. Council and Commission, get to work. Every day, people die on their way here. We know what the solutions are. Finally, I would like to quote two short points: 1. Ten thousand children are missing. I would like to hear from you what action plan has been put in place to track them down and get them out of the hands of criminals; 2. My husband has a different skin color. My children have a different skin color. I feel racism rising, even in my country. What are you going to do to stop racism? There is only one answer to this: make sure that this refugee crisis is addressed. Make sure that people of different skin colour also have a decent future here in our Europe.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, we have heard criticism of Greece for the delay in the operation of refugee and migrant registration centres on the Aegean islands. Everyone needs to understand that a country facing an unprecedented economic crisis has objective difficulties in welcoming and controlling a wave of refugees and migrants that more than doubled in 2015 compared to 2014.  Instead of blaming Greece for ignoring its efforts with its meagre means, deal with the Erdogan regime, which systematically violates what it agreed with the European Union and funnels people to Greek territory at will by blackmailing for even more money from Europe At the same time, Turkey benefits from the slave trade, since the profits of traffickers flow into its economy and encapsulate them and regime officials Europe must show real solidarity with Greece and speak in the language of sanctions to Mr Erdogan

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Migration would be the subject of this consolidated debate. In fact, the title is consistently about refugees and asylum – it also indicates that they do not face reality. I quote the opinion of a Catholic archbishop published in the press: "The vast majority of immigrants are not refugees, they are not Syrians and they are not families. Muslims cannot and do not want to adapt. They came into combat territory, not to adapt, but to conquer." Well, that is what we should be facing, but what issues are we dealing with here: the ban on return and the so-called acts of hatred against migrants. During these three to four hours, I was of the opinion that the majority of Parliament, in the fascination with a false thought of tolerance, would unwittingly become the landlords of the new conqueror. I do not believe that this is what the electorate wanted of you, but that it was about protecting their security and protecting European culture.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – The system of free movement, otherwise known as the Schengen area, is a great achievement for the European Union. I am convinced that it must be maintained. I find it difficult to understand the statements made by some politicians who have pointed out that we do not have to provide funds to deal with the refugee crisis, but at the same time these politicians are increasingly considering the abolition or suspension of Schengen for several years. It's supposedly not going to cost anything. I want to make it clear that the refugee crisis cannot be solved without financial injections, and the abolition of the Schengen area would lead to us all having to pay even more. It is important to bear in mind that it was still possible to provide for the temporary reintroding of border controls for each Member State if necessary. I do not know whether the Schengen authors have been referring to a crisis such as that of the current one, but I understand why some countries are taking on tightened controls, but in my opinion, the word is 'temporary'.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – I would like to refer in a few words to the Schengen area, which is our common acquis and of which we should be proud and defend. It is a bold, unique and innovative project that has been one of the European Union's business cards for many years. It laid the foundations for the practical implementation of the principle of the free movement of goods of services and persons. A permanent suspension of the operation of the zone would entail too much cost not only politically, but also economic and socially. We just can't afford it. I therefore believe that, in a crisis situation, our action should move towards strengthening this system. All efforts should be focused on strengthening the schengen external borders and immediate, effective steps should be taken to this end, and appropriate measures should be put in place.  In addition, particular attention must now be paid to the partnership to resolve the immigration crisis with Turkey. In this area, the Union has already taken concrete action. At the moment, we must ensure that the agreement is implemented efficiently and effectively by both sides.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, last Thursday I was proud to be Portuguese. The national parliament, unanimously from right to left, rejected the new Danish law to confiscate values for refugees and delay family reunification.  Policies like this not only remind us of an ominoso past, but directly play the game of terrorists fleeing refugees. Portugal has been ready for months and waiting to receive refugees, but they are not coming, because the relocation system is not working.  Hotspots in Greece and Italy are not properly equipped months after they were announced. Let us make no mistake, only if we act together at European level can we deal with the crisis. Destroying Schengen will not bring more control to our borders or fewer refugees, only more confusion and misery, and it will make even more use of traffickers.  To act European means not to tolerate ministers who cover us with shame by suggesting to others to push or sink refugees arriving on our shores, ministers preparing laws to criminalise NGOs and volunteers assisting refugees, ministers who close their ears to the alarming news of thousands of refugee children missing at the hands of traffickers. We cannot finally allow our governments to continue to feed the business of traffickers and the illegal influx of refugees by refusing to open legal and safe avenues to process asylum applications and protect the refugees we can take in.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, Mrs Gräßle, I can understand your intellectual reflections that, alternatively, we could perhaps have done something different. Nevertheless, I would like to thank all the almost 150 speakers most warmly for this high-level debate and, in particular, to pay tribute to those who have been here from the outset. I think we agree that there is a great deal of point in helping those countries that are directly in the neighbourhood of Syria and bear the bulk of the refugee burden. This is also out of the point of view – not from a cynical point of view, but from a deeply human point of view – that we must ensure that those who have remained in the region as refugees, including those who are refugees in Syria – and here we are talking about seven to eight million – that we are providing financial support here so that these people can remain in the region. to be able to enter the country with a peace that i hope will come soon and help to rebuild the country. This, too, is the stability that we need in the region, namely to rebuild a destroyed country of 23 million people and to ensure that peace is at least found in at least one part of the region. That is why every euro we invest here – not only in Turkey, but also in Lebanon, Jordan, and ultimately also in parts of Syria and parts of Iraq – is well-invested money, also from the european Union's point of view. I say this in particular to some finance ministers who may see things a little differently here. With regard to the Turkey Facility, the famous three billion, the Commission, after difficulties among the Member States, like different considerations, that we have finally been able to – and, Mr Böge, I will come to your criticism – to set up a billion for two years, perhaps making it easier for the Member States to set up the remaining two billion. This is a stock pile-up. It is not the case that these three billion are being made available to Turkey up front; these three billion are a maximum for two years and are intended to provide appropriate support in the face of all the undeniable burdens on Turkey to cope with the refugee influx. This money will be used exclusively in Syrian refugee camps in Turkey, for training, health care and the provision of shelter. Very importantly, this money is managed by us, by my staff in DG NEAR. Turkey has, so to speak, a consultable status. Of course, it makes sense to ask them where and how the money is to be used effectively. But the administration, the management, is with us, and the use is based on a needs assessment. This will be completed in mid-February. It also finds out where and how and to what extent these needs actually exist. These three billion, by the way, are, after all, just one element in an action plan aimed at putting relations with Turkey on a new footing. I say this because, although not in the debate today, but in the public debate, there is always criticism – especially in recent days – that we are virtually not responding or not responding to human rights violations or to the non-respect of fundamentals as a European Union. I can assure you that, particularly in the negotiations that are under way, in the preparation of Chapters 23 and 24, there will not be a millimetre of compromise sacrificing the fundamentals, the rule of law; they are non-negotiable. There are standards here that must be respected. And, Mr Böge, you are right, I too would have liked and would like us to have simpler and more manageable financing mechanisms here. But, frankly, we face the challenge: let us help or lose ourselves in institutional discussions, to set up the money in some way, additional budgets et cetera. I think it's like the question of whether the fire brigade should go to extinguish, or whether we are going to go to a comprehensive public procurement, what extinguishing products we buy and when and until when. So this is really about saying: OKAY, we have to put the money up, we have to set it up. I would like to take this opportunity to thank Kristalina Georgeva and her team for doing a great job here.  This is a point that my friend Dimitris Avramopoulos will perhaps also address: the composition of the flow of refugees, particularly in the Western Balkans, has already changed significantly in recent weeks and months, and today we can talk about the fact that 40% or less of the refugees are actually Syrians. The others come from other countries. The UN High Commissioner for Refugees told me only last Wednesday that 45% of Afghan refugees arriving in Greece were born in Iran. Surely you can't assume that these are just babies. So here the complexity of the refugee flow has already taken on a dimension that must also be addressed politically. My final point is that in all our negotiations we will only be able to act from a position of strength if we are able to secure our own borders. This must be the top priority, because only in this way can we maintain Schengen, a Schengen that now benefits our people and who are accustomed to finding borderless mobility, particularly in Central Europe, which has found its way into daily practice. The first priority must therefore be to ensure external border security. I hope that the negotiations in the Council based on the Commission's proposal will indeed lead to a clear result and that we will reach a clear result and a clear mandate here relatively soon in order to implement things.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by expressing our thanks for this fruitful and – in terms of length and endurance – marathon-like debate. It really has been very useful. I very much welcome the fact that we all share the same objectives of honouring the values of Europe by respecting the rights of refugees and making sure that we preserve the Schengen area – one of the most tangible achievements, if not the most tangible achievement, of European integration. You can rest assured that the Commission will not hesitate to use all the means that it has in order to do so; that point has again been made very clearly today. And now some words in Greek. Είναι αυτονόητο ότι όλες οι χώρες μέλη της ζώνης Σένγκεν οφείλουν να εφαρμόζουν τα προβλεπόμενα από τον συνοριακό κώδικα. Είναι μια βασική αρχή που όλα τα κράτη μέλη οφείλουν να σέβονται. Όμως, θέλω να είμαι σαφής για μία ακόμα φορά. Ποτέ δεν τέθηκε, ούτε τίθεται θέμα αποκλεισμού χώρας μέλους της Σένγκεν από τη ζώνη Σένγκεν. Αυτό ούτε καν προβλέπεται. Πολλές δε από τις ελλείψεις που παρατηρούνται, που σημειώνονται, σχετίζονται αναπόφευκτα και με τις μεταναστευτικές ροές. Αυτό αναγνωρίζεται από όλους, και αυτές καλύπτονται και από τη συνδρομή των κρατών μελών, αλλά και της ίδιας της Επιτροπής.  Η Επιτροπή άμεσα και έμμεσα στέκεται στο πλευρό της Ελλάδας και όλων των κρατών μελών που είναι αυτό τον καιρό υπό πίεση, και θα μου επιτρέψετε τώρα αφού έκανα αυτή την επισήμανση, την τόσο ξεκάθαρη, να συνεχίσω και πάλι στα αγγλικά. Mr President, I would also like to say a few words and give an answer to what Guy Verhofstadt said at the beginning. What we are trying to achieve with the establishment of hotspots presents many common features with the concept of the European Rapid Refugee Emergency Force (ERREF) that Mr Verhofstadt has proposed to establish. In operational hotspots, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO), Frontex, Europol and – where necessary – Eurojust are all already working on the ground and with international organisations to swiftly identify, register and fingerprint incoming migrants. The Commission has deployed teams on the ground to improve coordination. None can – or will – take over the borders of any Member State. We want to be very clear on that. But all Member States, according to the principle of solidarity, have to – and do – offer support to the frontline Member States to deal with this unprecedented pressure. The sovereignty of Member States is ensured by the Treaties. Yes, delays exist, but it is the wrong strategy to change strategy only because of panic. On this point, I very much agree with the intervention of the Chairman of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), Claude Moraes: we will succeed, and we can only succeed, together. Greece is accelerating this implementation, and debates like the one here today are once again sending the right messages to all governments to do their part of the commitments. The Commission will certainly keep playing its part and much more. We will not stop the implementation of the comprehensive approach of the European Union’s migration agenda. In March we will issue a communication on migration management, announcing further steps to be taken. Also in March, we intend to table a modified smart borders proposal. We also intend to present an ambitious migration management package, including a proposal to reform the Dublin system. A structural EU resettlement scheme, as well as legal migration and integration initiatives such as the revision of the blue card, will also be part of the package. I count on the full support of Parliament in the preparation of these proposals. As I said before, we all have to do our share and not hide our heads in the sand or just look for simple solutions – which, I am afraid, do not exist. I look forward to working with you on the pending proposals. There is a lot of work ahead of us. Let us do it together.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me first say that I appreciate the many comments made during this this debate. I also understand some of the frustrations that were expressed by many Members of different political persuasions. It is clear that the management of the flow of asylum seekers into Europe is a stress test for all of us, for our countries and for the confidence within and between our societies. It makes no sense to use the asylum seeker debate for narrow political agendas or narratives. That is a luxury we simply cannot afford. Blame games are easily played, and simplistic solutions are easily found, for what is in reality a very complex humanitarian problem. In my view, European cooperation and solidarity remain key. I agree with the many colleagues here who have said it is very good to have a lot on paper, but the question is how we put it into action. The Presidency is extremely active with the Member States in putting conclusions into action with Turkey and Greece on screening and border controls. Concerning the Western Balkan road, we are working in partnership with Lebanon and Jordan to – as, I think, Ms Piri said – come up with a model which ends the cynical business model of smugglers, the reason why people are killed on the seas. That is what we have to stop, and it turns out to be a little bit more complex than we thought. I share all the frustrations that people have expressed here tonight – people are still dying on the seas every day. Maybe there is no white smoke yet, but pessimistic panic does not help. There is no reason for complacency. Let me say a few words about values, a few words about hot spots, about questions that were raised as to the future of Schengen on the principle of non-refoulement and on the issue of Turkey. First, on values. The point made here by most Members, although others will not agree, is that we are faced with a stress test of our European values. We all have to realise that we cannot be comforted by the reactions on this issue in our societies from all sides right now. The Council is perfectly aware of the difficult situation of refugees massively fleeing conflict regions or migrants who, for other reasons, are trying to reach to Europe. We will do everything possible to improve the situation. I think Mr Pittella spoke about that. These are our values that are at stake, but the values are not so easy to put into practice, because it leads to confrontations in our societies, to fear and then to reactions to this fear. We will, therefore, have to balance the different identities that we have in our societies in a manner consistent with our democratic values. We could talk about it for much longer but it is key that we realise that together we must try to build a consensus around this. I have heard a lot of opposing views on this, and this is very legitimate; it is a common problem. We will have to search for solutions in our societies to deal with this. On external policy and external values, I can mention some measures that have already been adopted, such as the support given by the EU budget and by Member States in particular to help the UNHCR to respond to the needs of refugees in camps established close to their places of origin, in particular in Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey. Just yesterday I came back from Addis Ababa where I discussed this with the African Union. Discussions, and more, are also taking place about how we can conduct very practical follow-up to the Valletta Agreement. The Commission is also providing additional support to its partners operating in origin or transit countries outside the European Union. In parallel to these measures, the European Union is contributing to the development of safe and sustainable reception capacities in the affected regions and the provision of lasting prospects and adequate procedures for refugees and their families until they can be returned to their country of origin, if possible. If necessary, we will examine and adopt measures aimed at improving their situation. A lot more can be said about the origins of this crisis as well, but we can leave that for another debate when we will discuss issues around Syria and conflict resolution there. On hot spots, yes, it is true that progress has been too slow. We can all agree on this. A network of hot spots in Italy and Greece is a cornerstone of the EU’s efforts to ease the migratory pressure, ensure the identification of those third-country nationals in real need of international protection and facilitate return operations. Well-functioning hot spots are crucial to stemming the migration flows and ultimately safeguard the Schengen area. The European Council expects a Commission report assessing the progress in the set-up of the hot spot areas which will update the information presented in December 2015, and the Council itself is also monitoring the situation on the ground, through integrated political crisis response (IPCR) reports. We are very proactive at the moment because that is a challenge right now. If you want to translate the declarations into actions you have to be very hands-on. In the European Union we are used to more long-term issues of development and of development cooperation. Here we have to react immediately, and our systems are not necessarily used to that, so we have to change that. With that hands-on way of working we can also counter some of the legitimate criticisms on things that are going too slowly. Without prejudice to the Commission’s upcoming report, we can say that since December progress has been achieved. We should also recognise this. In Italy, two new additional locations were declared operational, in Pozzallo in Sicily and in Trapani, and in Greece work is under way to ensure that two hot spot areas, in Theos and Leros, are made operational soon. Furthermore, the reception capacities in both Italy and Greece have increased, including through the support of Member States and the specialised EU and UN agencies. We are not there yet, but we must pursue this effort with renewed commitment, and we expect the European Council to deliver a strong message to all relevant actors to make quick progress on the reception and identification of migrants. Italy, for instance, reportedly now has a rate of 100% for registration and fingerprinting. This is important progress. It has also ensured that disembarkation is done via the hot spots. Greece has informed us that migrants can only leave the hot spot areas by ferry if they can present registration papers. Greece has put in place a number of measures to increase the security of documents and to check if the migrant is indeed registered. Greece should also receive additional Eurodac machines in the coming days. A lot of questions were raised around Schengen, and correctly so. It is one of the cornerstones and success stories of European cooperation, if not European integration. The continuing flow of migrants over the past months has seen several countries temporarily re-imposing border controls – Germany, followed by Austria, Denmark, Finland, the Netherlands, Norway, Slovakia and Sweden. This temporary reintroduction of border controls is in line with the Schengen acquis, subject to strict conditions involving a serious threat to public policy or internal security and time limitations. That is an issue. The migration pressure has not decreased, and time is running out. The only way to go beyond the maximum time limit during which internal border controls may be carried out is to adopt a Council recommendation based on a Commission proposal under Article 26 of the Schengen Borders Code. This is a scenario that involves an elaborate procedure under the Schengen evaluation mechanism. This scenario should result in a series of measures protecting the overall functioning of the Schengen system, a system which is at the heart of the European project and one of its greatest achievements, as I mentioned. On this basis, the EU Interior Ministers discussed the matter informally in Amsterdam on 25 and 26 January 2015. There was broad support for inviting the Commission to make a proposal for a recommendation under Article 26 of the Schengen Borders Code. We are committed. The Presidency is committed to maintaining the Schengen system. It will do all it can to find, in cooperation with the Commission, Parliament and the Member States concerned, a solution to the current problems. Coming back to the principle of non-refoulement, there were quite a few remarks on this issue. This remains a key principle of our politics. In order to ease the migratory pressure on front-line Member States and to ensure the identification of those third-country nationals in real need of international protection, the Council is working hard to operationalise the network of hot spots and to speed up the implementation of the relocation and resettlement mechanisms adopted in 2015. In that context, the issue of non-refoulement remains extremely important and a principle. On Turkey, the establishment of the EU common list of safe countries of origin is, as many have stated here this afternoon, a very complex issue and one that the Council preparatory bodies are currently discussing. The final decision will have to be reached later on the basis of a very precise assessment on the EU-Turkey joint action plan, as welcomed by the European Council at its meeting in October. This is, as you know, part of a comprehensive cooperation agenda based on shared responsibility, mutual commitment and delivery. I just wanted to answer a question from Mr Verhofstadt. This does not mean that money is automatically sent to the Turkish Government. That is not the case. We are in the process of working with the Turkish Government on assurances that this is not a blank cheque to the Turkish Government but funding for programmes that have to alleviate the conditions of refugees in Turkey. I think Mr Olbrycht also mentioned the MFF in this context. We had a conference in Amsterdam last week where many speakers argued that the migration crisis demonstrates the need for more flexibility in the EU budget to allow us to have the resources available to meet unexpected challenges. We will try to move that forward within the time that we have in our Presidency to see how much more flexibility we can bring to our budget, something which is so badly needed in this crisis.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. – The solidity of our convictions is tested in times of greatest difficulty. Unfortunately, the action of some Member States in the face of the refugee crisis has revealed the great erosion to which humanist and democratic values are currently subject to a crisis of a global dimension such as this is not resolved by the adoption of individually delineated national strategies. Europe cannot view the issue of refugees as a problem that begins and ends at the Greek, Italian, Cypriot or Maltese borders. We are facing a crisis affecting Europe as a whole, which requires a one-on-one, concerted and shared responsibility response. Nationalist rhetoric, isolation and repression are not the answer. The refugee crisis needs two-dimensional solutions: on the one hand, Europe must ensure the conditions to welcome people fleeing war and violence with dignity, without prejudice and without prejudice; on the other hand, it must commit itself to conflict resolution, collaborating with the countries and regions from which these people come. Only a joint solution that at the same time act on the causes and sustains the consequences will be right, effective and consistent with European principles.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. – Europe is in no way able to find a solution to the worst migration crisis since The Second World War. It has to be acknowledged that the situation is no longer under control, as substantial political decisions are delayed. If there is no way to manage the migration crisis, the Schengen system will have to be stopped for a couple of months, as Donald Tusk has warned. This would not be a good solution; but in particular, mechanisms must be put in place in the European Union to ensure effective protection of the EU's external borders, to provide detailed checks on arrivals, to distinguish genuine refugees from conflict zones from those trying to enter the EU for completely different reasons. Member States must reach an agreement, without waiting for the march to be reached. the establishment of an EU summit on a clear migration management system, otherwise this mass and uncontrolled immigration can have negative political and economic consequences across the EU.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – We must now bring order to the chaos and stop national panic football. Some think we should push refugees back to the open sea, others that we should open fire at the border. We certainly do not see it that way. Our priority remains to ensure that people do not drown at sea and that we get a grip on the flow of refugees. There is only one good approach to this: the roll-out of an EU border and coastguard to monitor external borders and assess applications in hot spots at the external borders. We must combine this with closer cooperation with Turkey and investment in reception camps in Syria's neighbouring countries, so that living conditions there improve dramatically and the number of people coming here decreases sharply. Those plans are on the table.  It is high time that major steps forward will be made at the forthcoming European summit in two weeks' time. We must stop blaming each other and the Greek Government must finally agree to European support for border security. If we do not do so, it will be at the expense of the most vulnerable, the war refugees, who need our help most.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – We are again faced with a long and sad debate which is not really about refugees, but about a Europe badly hurt by indifference to the multiplication of children who, like Aylan, are not an image in the news, but a human being, many human beings drowning on our beaches. And in the face of the collapse of Schengen, disappeared in combat. And in the face of decisions marking an hour of infamy in the Council, abandoned to the extension of the suspension of the free movement of persons for two years, or to the confiscation of property to finance the stay of persons seeking refuge between us. Worst of all, this revelation we have heard from Europol, for which ten thousand children have disappeared into the hands of illicit trafficking networks, abandoned in the hands of vermin. It is imperative to make decisions so that this EU in its darkest hour, in which it retreats, in disunity and in insolidarity, in a state of permanent alarm, in which it abandons its fate not only to its most vulnerable border, which is Greece, but to millions of desperate human beings, to change course at once.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. – Only two certain things emerge from this debate, namely the 'cross-border' role that Europe, and in particular some border states, such as Italy and Greece, is having in the issue of immigration by welcoming everyone indiscriminately and that of its citizens-financiers without their knowledge that they will pay 3 billion euros to Turkey to detain the many refugees from Syria. It is a pity, however, that visa liberalisation will be granted... so we'll still be invading.  And in this House, thanks to the usual hypocrisy, this is not said! Few things need to be done: suspend Schengen without further delay, real and serious controls at the EU's external borders, compulsory returns for illegal immigrants. Only in this way, perhaps, will it be possible to stabilise what is now a totally out of control situation, despite the good intentions that we have heard again today. It is time for Europe to wake up... and maybe it's already late

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – The European Union has been through a series of controversies on the refugee crisis. Member States must overcome this phase of polarisation in relation to the re-distribution of refugee quotas in the EU and work together in a joint action to better manage the situation of these people fleeing the terror of war.  Of course, the situation of economic migrants is different and must be made clear: if, following the analysis of the request of a third-country national, it is considered that he does not fall within the status of asylum seeker, repatriation is resorted to.  In recent years, many political analysts have found a drift of the concept behind the European Union: solidarity. It is not only solidarity between Member States (the principle of the welfare state that redistributes income), but also their solidarity with third countries or people whose integrity is under threat, such as Syrian refugees fleeing war. We must not forget at any time that the European Union is a land of values and must therefore undoubtedly be found in our actions.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. The suspension of Schengen has been on our Europe for some time now, threatening the four fundamental freedoms and the principles of democracy. A possible closure of Schengen would have devastating consequences for the European Union, for individual Member States and for the single market. At times like these, the voice of those who yearn against the European project seems to prevail, of those who build walls of refoulement, of those who identify in refugees and refugees enemies to be fought, to be found, to be punished.  The answer lies, however, in facing these challenges (the refugee emergency, the security of citizens) with the conscious expectation that the achieved degree of civilization imposes on us the logic of reception. Is it not feasible to go back to a national dimension, now little more than provincial? The Member States have the political courage to organise real coordinated control at the external borders. Schengen cannot die! With the suspension of Schengen, Europe would die!

name: Jørn DOHRMANN
text: Written. Paying Turkey to handle some refugee facilities has been interpreted by some as a blue-beak egg, which, in a blow, solves the problems of the refugee and immigration flows that are flooding Europe. But how can we be sure that it benefits the European Union? It might make sense that we help Turkey financially so that it is better able to deal with the refugees and migrants. However, the fact that Turkey, in return for helping people with a religion, culture and a foundation of values similar to their own, is being given easier access to Europe, makes no sense in my view.  Nor should we be subject to Turkey's blackmail and to promise more dynamism in the accession negotiations, because Turkey should never be part of the European Union. Turkey has about 80 million inhabitants who, if necessary, would have free access to Europe. So free access for people with precisely different religion, culture and values. The EU-Turkey agreement will therefore only create even more problems and not solve anyone.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. - Open borders within the EU are non-negotiable. Developments in the wake of the current refugee crisis and the response to the Paris terror must not lead to the abandonment of Schengen. With Austria, Germany, Sweden, Denmark and France, five EU states have already introduced temporary border controls. In practical terms, border controls already include significant restrictions on the free movement of goods in the EU and the freedom of movement of Europeans. Traffic jams with waiting times of more than one hour, such as those occurring at peak times at the checkpoint on the A8 Salzburg-Munich, could become the order of the day in the future if border controls are reintroduced. This will have a negative economic impact on the EU's internal market and significant burdens on travellers. This is already noticeable and can be quanted in figures. However, let me say that, despite the current increase in border controls, Schengen is still in force. Priority controls in the fight against crime and terrorism can also be covered by Schengen. We in Europe must do everything we can to ensure that the current exceptional situation does not become a regular state of affairs. This includes a European action plan calling for solidarity between EU Member States in the refugee crisis, an alternative to Dublin III and, above all, a clear commitment by the European Parliament and the Member States to the principle of open internal borders.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – We are again faced with a long and sad debate which is not really about refugees, but about a Europe badly hurt by indifference to the multiplication of children who, like Aylan, are not an image in the news, but a human being, many human beings drowning on our beaches.  And in the face of the collapse of Schengen, disappeared in combat. And in the face of decisions marking an hour of infamy in the Council, abandoned to the extension of the suspension of the free movement of persons for two years, or to the confiscation of property to finance the stay of persons seeking refuge between us. Worst of all, this revelation we have heard from Europol, for which ten thousand children have disappeared into the hands of illicit trafficking networks, abandoned in the hands of vermin. It is imperative to make decisions so that this EU in its darkest hour, in which it retreats, in disunity and in insolidarity, in a state of permanent alarm, in which it abandons its fate not only to its most vulnerable border, which is Greece, but to millions of desperate human beings, to change course at once.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. There are those in Europe who are under the illusion that by raising walls we can stop the flow of migrants. But the phenomenon of immigration cannot be stopped, it is an epochal phenomenon that must be governed and managed. And if you close the borders and question Schengen, we are on a very dangerous ridge: Schengen is a pillar of Europe, and if Schengen collapses, Europe collapses.  I agree with the Commission's proposals, but I would like to stress first, to amend Dublin, then to evaluate Schengen. To do the opposite would be unfair as well as wrong. First, the distorted mechanisms on the reception of migrants must be corrected, only then will Schengen be assessed. It is certainly not by giving ultimatums or setting deadlines that a European migration policy is being built. The position of the countries that want to close Schengen is very serious.  It means turning our backs on the thousands of desperate people who are arriving, but it also means, and above all, flying our backs to the other Member States of the European Union at the forefront of crisis management. Countries that founded and built this Union. It is too easy to close the doors when the situation is difficult. Without Schengen, we will no longer be able to call it the Union either.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – The Council has presented us, through the Foreign Minister, with statistical data showing that millions of uncontrolled refugees have been received, without distinguishing whether they are war refugees or economic refugees. This has put pressure on European citizens and has also induced terror. We are people and we have to show solidarity. But we need organized solidarity, not chaos. The Council and the Commission must lay down clear rules on the control of transit to Europe, irrespective of the border and the conditions of asylum and return.  We cannot have more Europe within the Union. There is the right of asylum enshrined, but also the right to safety is established at our home. Refugees must be helped, but they must respect our culture, our customs, our traditions, and not the other way around. I hope, President Juncker and Minister, that you will speed up the resolution of the case and not the treatment of the effects.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. – We are again faced with a long and sad debate which is not really about refugees, but about a Europe badly hurt by indifference to the multiplication of children who, like Aylan, are not an image in the news, but a human being, many human beings drowning on our beaches. And in the face of the collapse of Schengen, disappeared in combat. And in the face of decisions marking an hour of infamy in the Council, abandoned to the extension of the suspension of the free movement of persons for two years, or to the confiscation of property to finance the stay of persons seeking refuge between us. Worst of all, this revelation we have heard from Europol, for which ten thousand children have disappeared into the hands of illicit trafficking networks, abandoned in the hands of vermin. It is imperative to make decisions so that this EU in its darkest hour, in which it retreats, in disunity and in insolidarity, in a state of permanent alarm, in which it abandons its fate not only to its most vulnerable border, which is Greece, but to millions of desperate human beings, to change course at once.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – One of the European Union's most important responsibilities is humanitarian action and assistance to those in need. However, the common task is also to care for European values, our cultural identity and the safety of citizens.
