Unfortunately, in the current situation, it is more difficult to fulfil such roles than it was even 10 or 15 years ago, because Europe is unable to accept all those who need help and the concerns about their reception are becoming increasingly apparent among Europeans. In order to fulfil our international obligations, we must seek many parallel paths of action. One of them is undoubtedly aid to refugees currently on Turkish territory. However, the Turkish State cannot remain alone in this action. Help is needed, including financial assistance. However, this is not a purchase of the possibility of passivity in the refugee crisis. The most important objective facing the European Union is to conduct a policy to end all hostilities in the area. Without this, the suffering and misery of these people will not be overcome quickly. By then, creating the best possible conditions and conditions that do not include human dignity, among other things, in the camps is what the Union can do now, with a rapidly noticeable effect. To sum up, in addition to the many actions we need to take in the context of the migration crisis, prudent financial assistance to the Turkish side is one possible solution.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – Schengen is now under fire and has become the subject of many debates. 26 European countries have reintroduced border controls. People take Schengen and the right to freely move within the Union for granted, without giving a second thought that 30 years ago a whole list of cross-border activities were not possible for many European citizens and businesses. The opening of EU borders proved to be highly beneficial for cross-border commuters, tourism, trade, investments, labour and financial markets and has an enormous effect on the European economy. The cost of restoring the EU’s borders would simply be enormous and I do not think that anyone at this stage could even estimate the consequences that this would have on the European integration project. Europe’s problem is not Schengen or lack of internal borders, it is the lack of mutual trust and solidarity among the Member States. The EU should focus on how to stem the flood of migrants at its origin, and not on building walls and fences. Only then will the security and wellbeing of its citizens be safeguarded.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. The Schengen Treaty must be defended for what it is and represents: Europe, a common area of freedom and security, an area of fundamental values. I therefore welcome the shared sense of responsibility in the Commission's proposal to set up a European coastguard for the control of external borders. It is, of course, important that all the guarantees of respect for fundamental rights that Europe carries out are provided.  Recent data, provided by, among others, the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, indicate that there are still many obstacles to access to legal aid and a lack of information provided to asylum seekers in hot spots. Our priorities, as Members of Parliament and as European citizens, are the establishment of active relief to save lives, the need to open safe and legal access routes, the facilitation of family reunification and adequate training of border staff in order to better identify people in need of protection.  Respect for fundamental rights must be an integral and indispensable part of our security policies.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – Once again, in plenary, we discuss the state of emergency with refugees. Today, this is happening in the context of the European Commission communication of 27 January, which states that passport checks at borders can be introduced over a period of two years. All attention is currently focused on Greece following accusations of mismanagement of its external border.  However, it is far from the only country to be under pressure from refugee waves. Bulgaria, where I come from, is also an external border of the European Union. I stand by the view that control of the EU's external borders needs to be strengthened. Emergencies also require emergency measures. However, questioning the Schengen area is unthinkable to me. The free movement of people is one of the fundamental principles of a united Europe.  Closing the borders, which the nationalists insist will not solve the refugee crisis with a magic wand. A single European policy is needed, but not permanently blocked in the Council.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: in writing. – The Schengen arrangement is a critical component of the single market, allowing for free travel of people and goods between Member States. So it is a major facility designed primarily for the Member States. This arrangement has been ‘saturated’ by the waves of refugees arriving in Europe last year. Consequently we are now in a less enviable position to have to suspend it, in order to control that refugee flux, thus depriving the citizens of the Member States of its clear advantages. It is, therefore, a big step backwards, both in terms of upholding our own values – free travel – and in providing our citizens with a facility we, the older generations, have grown accustomed with and the new generations have grown up with. We have arrived here not because the Schengen arrangement is not good, but because it was abused and its functioning conditions – proper screening at entrance – have not been applied properly. So, instead of suspending Schengen, with all the consequences, it is advisable to review the rules for its proper implementation. I agree that that is easier said than done, given the internal implications of the refugee crisis upon some of the Member States, especially Germany, in front of crucial regional elections.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – In recent years, the EU is facing the worst migration crisis of the decade. It is noticeable that the increasing number of newcomers is not war refugees, but from safe-kept countries, in other words economic migrants. Some of those arriving in the EU also come from refugee camps in Turkey, arguing for extremely poor living conditions there. We still do not find, or perhaps we do not have sufficient political will to find a solution to stem the flow of migrants. However, time is still less and less, as the free movement of persons within the EU, one of the fundamental values and achievements of European integration, is already strawberry. What? Individual EU members must be able to exercise their right to reduce their attractiveness to economic migrants – Europe must get rid of the image of a light economic well-being guarantor among migrants determined to cross the EU border illegally. At the same time, the Community must take real action in a joint effort to strengthen the external borders. Most importantly, however, various estimates show that providing the necessary assistance to refugees in countries bordering the EU is more than five times cheaper than within the EU. This should be an incentive for Member States to allocate funds to maintain such refugee centres in the EU's neighbourhood, in particular Turkey. In exchange for its support, the EU must require Turkey to pay more attention to ensuring the protection of the border with the EU, as well as to the transparent use of these funds and to the closer coordination of migration policies between the EU and Turkey.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: in writing. I have been to Lampedusa in the last few days. And you only have to go there, to understand the absurdity of the statements made by The Minister of Defence French, who I hope will want to go and look the people who arrive in the eye. That you don't see any terrorists, but you see so much despair. Just go there to come to a simple conclusion: in Lampedusa there can be no hot spot. The island is not an adequate place, nor is the structure currently used as a hot spot, which, moreover, was supposed to be just a pilot project and not remain so in the long term.  Lampedusa has always been a champion in the first aid and reception, but within 48 hours people should be transferred elsewhere, in order to be relocated to other EU countries. And instead they get stuck there even weeks, without even shoes at their feet or a canteen to eat in. Stuck on the island, paying for the inability of European governments to implement the Council decisions in which they sit, and to start the promised relocations. Relocations are lagging behind unacceptable and unjustifiable.  It is little wonder that people are afraid to register if they are not given a certain perspective on their future first. Dear governments, take your responsibilities.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing – We have once again named the problems we have and their solutions, but their application itself in practice is very leaky. We do not have mechanisms, as after deciding that migrants must leave the EU because they do not meet the requirements for asylum and protection, how to actually return them to their country of origin or transit. We are eagerly awaiting what will happen once the climate conditions for migrants warm and more favourable, but only the cooperation of all 28 Member States and the unification of asylum and migration policy within the EU can stem the uncontrolled influx of migrants, while at the same time providing protection for those who apply for it and are also entitled to it under international law. We do not yet have statistics available for 2015, but in 2014 member state authorities issued 470,000 decisions ordering third-country nationals to leave the EU by administrative or judicial decision, but only made 192,445 effective returns. There are 280,000 left in the EU who were due to return but did not return. That is why the question arises – how does the return policy work for us in practice? Do we have information about those who remain in the EU, what they are actually doing and where they are?

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: in writing. – Calls for the Schengen borders to be closed for 2 years shows that the EU, led by the right and misled by the far-right, is in absolute silence. This would be a huge blow to the idea of a united Europe – not just because of the inevitable economic damage, but because free movement is the most vivid symbol of all the EU's achievements.  The proposal to close our doors, lock the door and wait for the storm to pass is a dangerous illusion - no country can deal with such problems on its own. Our answer is more, not less Europe – where necessary. Instead of walls, we need effective external borders. From more Europe in the areas of security, information sharing, counter-terrorism, foreign policy. From a stronger European commitment, including financial, to support UN agencies as well as the countries that house the most refugees.  Although they have met all the membership criteria, Bulgaria and Romania unfairly remain outside the Schengen area, which would contribute a lot to security and strengthen the Union's external borders. We strongly oppose any ideas to create "buffer zones" within the EU to become large refugee camps. The Dublin mechanism does not meet the new conditions and urgently needs to be reviewed.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The EU has failed to respond to the urgent need for protection and humanitarian assistance for refugees. As a result in 2015, almost 4,000 refugees died off the coast of the Union. The Mediterranean became a cemetery. And the death toll in 2016 continues to grow dangerously. 10,000 unaccompanied refugee children have been lost in the EU. In Turkey, the country that has been given the title of safe destination and today we are discussing its financial support, we know that thousands of refugee children are working illegally in industry and millions of refugees are struggling to survive without any support from the Turkish state.  The EU cannot continue to play with the dignity and lives of refugees. We have to stop the crime now! The funds allocated to border fencing and turning Europe into a murderous fortress should be used to welcome refugees and transport them to their countries of destination. It is equally important to immediately strengthen practical solidarity with host countries, such as Greece, which receives the largest waves of refugees.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – As all well know, it is crucial that we tackle the refugee crisis at its origins in order to manage this inflow in the long term. And to do this we must look beyond our unpredictable neighbour, Turkey. The Kurdish forces, particularly the Peshmerga in Iraq, have been central to the struggle against Islamic State, meanwhile they have conceived and sustained a stable territory which has yet to be recognised as a nation in its own right. It is impossible for us to ignore the legitimacy and importance of the Kurds as pro-Western political actors in this conflict-ridden region. Therefore it is essential that we, the European Union, vigorously support them in their efforts to extinguish Islamic State and defend democracy.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – Current EU and NATO policies do not hesitate to finance and promote extremist forces, to carry out multimillion-dollar arms contracts to dictatorships such as Saudi Arabia for the economic and geopolitical dominance of those regions. It is therefore the policies of interference and aggression of the US, NATO and the European Union that are at the root of the conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa. This is the bottom line of the mass exodus of millions of people arriving on the European continent, fleeing hunger, misery, war and death. To fight this Parliament for the defence of human rights and i would condemn without tibiezas the response to this reality. The walls, fascist laws of humiliation of refugees, the concept of Fortress Europe, the financing of neighbouring states to contain the waves of refugees in authentic concentration camps are the mark of the brutality and inhumaneness of the EU. Those who manage to survive so much "solidarity" have miserable reception conditions that precede a compulsory repatriation.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – EU asylum and migration policies have lamentably failed in 2015. We have to turn this failure into a functioning European response to the migration crisis. In order to do so we must understand what went wrong. We did not respect our own rules: neither the Dublin Regulation nor the Schengen Regulation was respected. We did not respect our own decisions: out of 5 hotspots in Greece we have one; out of 6 in Italy only 2. We did not secure the EU’s external borders, the European Border and Coast Guard is still in its making. The European Council made majority decisions when unanimity is the way to go in highly sensitive issues. It was decided by majority to relocate 160 000 refugees but not more than 300 have been effectively relocated since. Relocation will not fly. Finally we mixed up things that should not be mixed. There is confusion between refugees and migrants since we lack the criteria to distinguish between them. We also confuse migrants coming outside of the EU and ‘internal migrants’ who in fact are European citizens who benefit of the fundamental right to free movement. There is no more time. European crises needs European solutions, worked out in genuine solidarity.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. – I have previously pointed out that the protection of our common external borders is inadequate, and I therefore welcome the fact that Greece and its fulfilment of its obligations in the protection of our external borders are now being examined. Similarly, it must also be examined how refugees who come to Greece are treated, whether all procedures are followed, return policies are applied or where they are transported further. Not only in Greece, but also in Italy, the EU has invested a large amount of money in recent years, and I am rightly asking what this money has been used for and how it has contributed precisely to dealing with the refugee influx. I am unequivocally in the hope that Greece should immediately remedy any misconduct that the Commission finds problematic. However, if this, too, should be insufficient, I want other steps to be considered to protect borders by the EU itself to correct greece's failure. I consider the exclusion of Greece from the Schengen area to be a last resort, but at the same time I do not rule out the need to resort to it in the event of serious redress errors.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – When discussing the wave of refugees coming into the European Union, we need to combine this with a discussion about support for Turkey. 1.1 million refugees came to the European Union in 2015. Turkey currently has nearly 3 million refugees, mostly from Syria, in various camps. Europe is not coping with the current wave of refugees and it is not difficult to predict what would happen if this wave were exacerbated by refugees currently in Turkey. It should therefore receive strong SUPPORT from the EU, in particular the means to provide refugees with civilised living conditions. Similarly, Jordan and Lebanon, which are struggling with the effects of the Syrian war and the influx of its victims into their territory, should be treated in the same way. This is, of course, an important action, but it is of an ad hoc nature. The most important thing would be the strong involvement of the international community in reducing the war in Syria. The European Union should be as active as possible in this area. The wave of refugees is mainly the result of the war in Syria. As long as this war lasts, its victims will seek a better life.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – To discuss the refugee crisis is to discuss the crisis of purpose and values that is destining the European Union. The three key points of the debate on refugees, borders and Schengen dramatically illustrate this reality. On the one hand, they highlight the difficult coexistence between the economic crisis and the reception of refugees, as has been the case with Greece. On the other hand, they underline the weaknesses of the common security and defence policy (CFSP) at a time when the strengthening of the Union's external border is affirming itself as the most robust way of safeguarding free movement within the interior. Finally, with the question of the practice of withholding refugee sweins in Denmark, it is the clash of values that is exposed. There is an urgent need to tackle the refugee crisis with a new impetus for growth and jobs in Europe. Economic and social recovery is the best antidote to overcome and overcome the self-destructive dynamics that, spontaneously or manipulated by populist currents, threaten to weaken and even destroy the European project. I therefore call for the urgent launch of a consistent plan to strengthen the Union's external border, launched at the same time as a plan to take up the priorities for the sustainable development of the European area.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Iratxe García Pérez, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on the new Strategy on Gender Equality and Women's Rights after 2015. (O-000006/2016 - B8-0103/2016) (2016/2526(RSP)).

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Author. – Mr President, we are once again talking about equality in this European Parliament. I'm sure many of those who have been present at this debate could use a sit-in and listen to what we have to say. Because equality is a priority, too, in our work and in our political commitment. Because women are 50% of the population of the European Union and politics cannot be done behind us. Therefore, the first thing we are asking is to be heard and to know well what this House's approach is to the question we are moving to the Commission today. Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union require the Commission to implement policies on equality between men and women, because we are talking about a principle and a fundamental value of the European project. The current strategy was completed in 2015. In June 2015, this House was already positioned in this regard, with a debate on what the content should be and what guidelines should be that the European Commission should propose in the new gender strategy, in the new strategy of equality between men and women. A public consultation was also opened, where more than 90% of the people who participated in it established that it was essential, that it was essential and that it was urgent that this political priority should become a commitment on the part of the European institutions and, therefore, that a new gender equality strategy be launched. Since June 2015, when this House has been mostly positioned and urged the European Commission to carry out this work, we have been waiting for the Commission's response. And the Commission's reply was that, in December 2015, it adopted a working document drawn up by the Commission services, which we find very respectable. It seems to us that it has content that needs to be taken into account, but we believe that it completely loses the commitment that should be made on a political level. Because a working document has no budget. Because in a working document you cannot see what the implementation of the measures put in place will be like. Because a working document cannot be evaluated. And for policies to succeed, budgeting is needed and evaluation mechanisms are needed.  That is why we stress the need for a strategy of equality between men and women by the College of Commissioners, because this has to be a commitment of the whole College as a whole and must be debated and approved by the European Commission, which, at the moment, has a responsibility to launch the policies of equality between men and women. Because we're talking about fighting gender-based violence. We're talking about a pay gap. We're talking about reconciliation between personal and work life. We are talking about fundamental issues on the European Union's political agenda, and that we have an obligation to be able, together with the Member States, to implement. Because in recent years we have seen how, together with all the crises that occurred within Europe — the economic crisis, the refugee crisis, the social crisis - finally, the great harms of all of them are still women. And, therefore, to lose the gender perspective in all policies and to be able to understand that transversality is fundamental is an indispensable issue and that we will continue to claim on the part of this Parliament. We therefore also take advantage of this debate to ask the Commission why it has not adopted, in a public and transparent manner, a new communication on the strategy for gender equality. We want to know why this document has not been adopted, it has not been discussed, it has not been approved by the College of Commissioners. And we want to know what the Commission is waiting for this to be the case, so that you can also discuss how, through the various policies, through the work of the various Commissioners, progress can be made on the principle of equality between men and women. And we also want to know how the European Commission will work with the Presidency and the trio of presidencies to present, throughout 2016, a strategy of equality between men and women. Term. It's critical. It's enforceable. We would have liked to have had Mrs Jourová, the person responsible for this matter at the College of Commissioners, here today. But I keep insisting, this is not a compartment policy, this is a cross-cutting policy and political commitment must be at the base of the whole European Commission.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for the opportunity to clarify the Commission’s intention for gender equality policy during its mandate. The Commission published its ‘Strategic Engagement for Gender Equality 2016-2019’ on 3 December 2015 as its framework plan for future actions to improve gender equality. The strategic engagement is a follow-up and continuation of the Commission’s 2010-2015 strategy for equality between women and men. The priorities in the 2010-2015 strategy for equality between women and men remain valid. The wide consultations and the evaluation that we carried out to prepare the strategic engagement clearly confirms this. While progress has been achieved, further action is needed to secure the necessary changes. Gender and gender equality is an important part of the Juncker Commission’s agenda. As you know, this Commission also embarked on a better regulation programme, refocusing its activities and instruments. As a representative of the Commission and a member of the College, I can confirm to you that the new strategic engagement is the official Commission position, which has the political support of the entire Commission. It is set out in its 2016 Work Programme: the Commission is engaged in practical work to promote gender equality. As was explained at the constructive exchange of views with the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) on 14 December, we should focus on the delivery of change on the ground. The strategic engagement describes how gender equality actions will be focused on five priority areas during this Commission mandate: increasing female labour-market participation and equal economic independence; reducing the gender pay, earnings and pension gaps and thus fighting poverty among women; promoting equality between women and men in decision-making; combating gender-based violence and protecting and supporting victims; promoting gender equality and women’s rights across the world. It also confirms the integration of the consideration of gender equality into every aspect of European Union interventions. There are more than 30 key actions to be implemented in each of the five priority areas identified, as well as objectives and timelines for these actions, responsibilities in the Commission’s services and funding available to support progress. Together with timelines and indicators, the strategic engagement defines a baseline against which future progress will be measured on a regular basis. The strategic engagement builds on the targets agreed at EU level. In particular it supports reaching the European Union’s 2020 target of a 75% employment rate for both men and women. It is a concrete planning instrument for the Commission which other stakeholders are welcome to join. On 15 January 2016 the Commission participated in the Council’s Working Party on Social Questions, which held a first exchange on the draft Council Conclusions on the strategic engagement for gender equality. The Dutch Presidency expressed its intention to have the Council Conclusions adopted at the March meeting of the Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council (EPSCO). The strategic engagement for gender equality provides a basis for gender equality actions in the coming years and in particular covers the key issues Parliament identified in its June 2015 resolution. It represents the Commission’s work programme for gender equality policy for 2016-2019.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, we are meeting this evening in this Chamber of the Strasbourg Parliament to re-debate the crucial issue of gender equality, in favour of an oral question that a number of political groups have wished to address to the European Commission and which pointed the finger and stigmatised the fact that the Commission had not published a document on a certain type of status , a communication on a strategic commitment but only a working document that sets out its roadmap and lists its commitments and lines of action for the period 2015-2019.  Quite frankly, on a personal basis and on behalf of the EPP Group, the semantic quarrels and the debates, a little anecdotal - forgive me, I do not want to hurt anyone - on the question of the status and form of this or that document, little to do. What matters is the political will, the commitment, the intensity with which a number of areas of action are identified as well as processes, methods, methodology. From this perspective, the methodology, the areas of action, the commitments published by the European Commission, by Commissioner Jourova, in the working paper correspond exactly to the priorities and concerns of the EPP Group. We want a concrete, pragmatic, effective, operational approach, through measurable, measurable objectives, evaluation procedures, we want to emphasise the need to properly transpose, to properly implement existing legislation before considering possible new legislative proposals. In short, we want to be useful, concrete, pragmatic and focus on what we can do usefully as the European Parliament, as members of the Committee on Women's Rights, as a European institution, to stimulate Member States and put pressure on them to fulfil their responsibilities. Once again, it is this intensity and political will that the EPP Group has clearly underlined in its motion for a resolution.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. We are the representatives of the European people. Today, the majority of parliamentarians – the European Parliament, we – are once again calling for our right. We have a moral right to the equality strategy being continued in Europe. And we demand this right with great self-confidence. We have a majority decision by Parliament, and Parliament calls on the Commission to launch a strategy for gender equality. We also have the unanimous tailwind of the Member States, which are fully behind the strategy. And we have the support of the citizens of the EU, who, in the course of a survey, clearly voted in favour of the 'yes' vote on equality issues. Commissioner Jurova constantly asserts that an internal working document is about the same as a strategy or communication. And Mrs Jurova knows that this is not true. It is a weaker paper that she is presenting to us. It is a lukewarm paper that it is presenting to us, and it is therefore a devaluation of the issue of equality and a devaluation of the people of Europe. I personally had a conversation today with Martin Schulz, the President of Parliament, and I personally drew his attention to the maladministration. He will talk to Mr Juncker again in the near future and he will ask for fairness for Parliament, because Parliament deserves fairness. Anyone who acts against women's rights weakens Europe. Anyone who acts against equality is a sexist. Those who prevent a strategy are missing basic democratic values. We want a strategy, and we want it now. I think everything has been said on this subject. I would like to give Mrs Jurova some of the remaining 30 seconds to reflect. (The President began to continue on the agenda) No, Mr President, I have ten seconds to speak, and during this time Mrs Jurova is supposed to reflect. I also hope that you, as Commissioner, will reflect, and I hope that we will have a strategy. (Applause from the speaker's group)

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Left-wing groups are calling for the promotion of ideological, gender-based demands: the sexualisation of children, the promotion of LGBTI, gender parity, a change in both the definition of gender and the family. You have led to a situation where traditional families may feel discriminated against because they are constantly hearing that they are non-modern, backward, non-European.  The number of anti-discrimination regulations adopted so far by the European Parliament is huge. There is therefore no reason to take more. My group is against the resolution of the left, proposing a completely different, rational approach. Dear! It's time to get back to the roots. It is necessary to build on the values on which the European Union has been founded. Do not be ashamed of the Christian heritage, we can draw wisdom and strength from it.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Commissioner Jourová for her efforts to make gender equality a reality in the European Union. She demonstrated that she is really and sincerely committed. I am referring in particular to the mediation efforts in the Women on Boards Directive negotiations with the Council and to the fact that she is trying by all means to relaunch the maternity leave file by proposing a roadmap towards a broader approach to a work and private life balance. However, I cannot hide my disappointment while being confronted with a staff working document instead of a proper comprehensive strategy for gender equality. I am not criticising the measures adopted in the document, but I do denounce, in the name of my group, the downgrading of the strategy, especially because it happened against the clear position of this Parliament, since the Noichl report was adopted with a large majority, and against the clear statements of 22 Member States. Moreover, the evaluation of the past strategy resulted in a specific call to further strengthen the strategic approach adopted in 2010 and not to weaken it. In light of those signals sent by the Commission, by the entire college, my question is: should we consider the inequality affecting more than half of the population of Europe as red tape? Is this the message? My last comment concerns the behaviour of some groups in the House. They have once again demonstrated, as the previous speaker showed, that they do not take gender equality seriously.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The European Parliament is doing an important and systematic job for greater equality and our report on a new gender equality strategy is a good example. Unfortunately, we note that gender equality work in the EU as a whole and the Commission in particular have stagnated. It is extremely serious because gender inequality is a trampling on women's right, and it is a democratic and social problem.  I will not bore you with statistics, but it is so extremely clear that we live in a society where women do not have the same access to power and resources as men. That is something we need to change. We have a lot of work ahead of us, and in order to get anywhere in the work on gender equality, we need political vision and concrete commitments. That is why the Council wants a gender equality strategy. That is why we in Parliament want a gender equality strategy. It's political leadership.  In fact, blocking the development of a gender equality strategy, as the Commission is now doing, is perfect for power and a display of patriarchal arrogance. No, we do not want our centuries-old traditions of oppression of women and of oppression of LGBTQ people.  No thanks, it is time to move forward, it is time for a rethink in the Commission. You can still develop a gender equality strategy. It is time to throw away the patriarchal yokes and create a more feminist Europe. That is what women and men in Europe expect, and a new gender equality strategy is a first step.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, equality between women and men must be ensured in all areas. This is a very short and clear message from Article 23 of the European Charter on Fundamental Rights, and this is a very clear task for us as legislators, including the Commission, the Council and Parliament. How do we reach a society with sound protection for working mothers and fathers? How do we reach a society with abundant female voices in top positions in the economy? How do we finally end violence against women in the EU? For all of this we need confidence, we need political will, but most of all we need a very clear strategy. I have been elected to a legislative body to do a lot of things, that is true, but especially to fix legislative shortcomings and, more specifically, to fix legislative shortcomings on women’s and girls’ rights. Historically the European Union has delivered on this, but from my mandate so far I can say that the track record is really weak. The withdrawal of the Maternity Leave Directive and the postponement of the Women on Boards Directive are just two of the very many frustrating and alarming developments that we have seen. Let us now take the chance to turn this around and to make this Commission and this mandate a success for girls’ and women’s rights. Because girls’ and women’s rights are the unfinished business of the 21st century.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we are once again at the fair of falsehood and hypocrisy. We are talking about large posters, slogans and objectives, which are purely ideological in nature but which are light years away from the real reality that we women live in and from all the problems that we are forced to face on a daily basis. We want equality of rights which always remains only formal and which is not reflected in any substantive policy. We write resolutions that call for equality between the sexes and equal opportunities. There are many, really many, beautiful words, but what we have done and written so far has served any good? Is the life of European women better from year to year or worse? Unfortunately, we have to note that the serious phenomena of discrimination and inequality, which we so strongly condemn, continue to happen, despite all the actions taken. We are told by the chronicles, the data collected and the economic analyses carried out. We have also seen the maternity leave directive come to a standstill in recent months, we have suffered the stalemate of the directive on women on the boards, while in Europe women are increasingly alone, increasingly unemployed, poorer and more and more violated. It's time to say enough! We want targeted and concrete action from the Commission now!

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – When we talk about equality between men and women, we are actually talking indirectly about motherhood. The different salary amounts in the same position, the pay gap, as well as the different pension gap, the pension gap, are symptoms of the hypocrisy of our society. We do not consider motherhood or childcare to be valuable work. A woman is even financially penal for it, whether in the form of pay gaps, low maternity benefit or failure to recognise the importance of household care and children for social well-being. We talk a lot about women's rights to free choice, but at the same time we are pushing them into the formal economy with their specific policies. I would therefore very much like the efforts of both the Commission and this House to focus on the cause of the problem. The first step would be to clarify concepts, because gender equality is not the same as equality between women and men. And the second, more challenging step is to recognise the economic and social value of motherhood and the care that women in families carry out. Even then, the debate on policies to promote women's status in society will become meaningful.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, commissioner, why does equality between women and men, the founding principle of the European Union, no longer deserve, I say 'more' because so far it has been the case, a Commission communication, a real programme of action with a budget, an evaluation and even legislative measures if it is necessary? Would we have achieved our goals? If that were the case, I apologize, but I think there are still difficulties with regard to the employment rate of women, that there is still discrimination, that there is still violence and that there are still and above all gender stereotypes. So I ask the question: why not a communication? In the last two years, however, there have been communications from the Commission. I quote a few: a communication on the noise level of the engines, a communication on the civilian use of piloted aircraft systems, a communication on package travel, and I could continue. But when it comes to women, we are told 'ah no no no no no no', especially not, we need administrative simplification, we need the REFIT programme, we need maternity leave to fall by the wayside. That is the Commission's position, and I regret to hear Mrs Le Grip say that this is semantics. It's not semantics, it's politics, it's politics that sets priorities. Today, the European Commission has not defined women's equality as its priority.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The term 'gender mainstreaming' is based on Article 8 of the EU Treaty, which states that 'in all its activities, the Union works to eliminate inequalities and promote equality between men and women'. This sentence does not come from me, it is the European Commission's response to my parliamentary question on clarifying the concept of gender in the European context. Definition of gender free according to Estrela, Rodrigues, Noichl and colleagues – it is no longer about the actual equality, which suffers from a false and completely distorted definition. Gender does not mean sex education in primary schools, gender does not mean a perverse human right to abortion. Ms. Noichl even advertises dealing with the killing of toddlers. Gender does not mean either: today man, tomorrow woman, the day after tomorrow quite something else. No, anyone who says gender means equality between women and men – point, and nothing more. I would like to go further here: when we talk about equality, we have to talk about planning for the future, and then equality must be seen where parents and the childless are on an equal footing.

name: Louise BOURS
text: – Mr President, for once I am in agreement with some of you and happy to point towards the failure of the EU Commission in its gender equality strategy. After all, the only thing it has produced is a staff working document; very useful indeed if you are caught short in a public convenience without toilet paper. But I have to ask, what have the numerous EU strategies, funding initiatives and quangos actually achieved? Do I feel more empowered and safer than ever before? No, in fact I would argue the reverse is true. I am sure many of those women in Cologne, Sweden and elsewhere feel exactly the same. What did you think was going to happen when the EU opened the door to millions of people from countries and cultures where women are treated as second class citizens and LGBTI people are treated even worse? The wilful cover-up at the facts surrounding Cologne and elsewhere by politicians, the authorities and the press shows you that European politicians care more about political correctness than actually protecting the safety and rights of women. The EU is clearly trying to deny that this kind of violence even exists. What about trafficking? A UK Government report says that free movement within the EU is extensively exploited by organised criminals to bring human trafficking victims to the UK. Europol says free movement makes it more difficult to detect these operations. It is the perfect environment for the criminal gangs to act with impunity. The current EU gender strategy is, and will continue to be, an absolute failure. Whilst the UK remains in the EU, women, LGBTI people and the rest of society are less safe and less secure.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Mr President, there is a saying that sometimes trees do not let us see the forest, and this is what should not happen to us in this debate, where equal rights between men and women, particularly since 2015, are fundamental. The important thing is the goal and we cannot allow the way to achieve it to confront us.  It is proven that the most advanced societies are those in which women's rights are most consolidated. So many women have struggled in the last century, that they have even given their lives so that today we can sit here writing laws that we believe are favorable for a fairer society.  But there is still a lot of evidence to go through on equality, such as equal pay. Where is it written that a woman has to earn less than a man for a job of equal value? Not to mention, of course, the greatest of inequalities, gender-based violence, on which so much is legislating, but with so little result.  It is our responsibility to make necessary laws and it is the Commission's duty to monitor compliance in all States and, therefore, we support the practical approach that the Commissioner is giving to this strategy.  The important thing is to reduce inequality: that is what should be our priority. Women don't care what name we give to strategies, but they are effective, and under no circumstances should we, under any circumstances, downgrade the objectives or means of achieving it.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, from the data we have on gender equality, we should be concerned about a concerted strategy on an effective way of combating the problem of inequality and discrimination. If the data we have already indicated to us the frank need for action, I am more concerned about the data that remain unascertained, because of the Commission's inability to ensure reliable information collection mechanisms. Moreover, this has been recognised here by the Commissioner herself: the case, for example, of female genital mutilation. Parliament has given clear guidance, but the Commission does not act or want to act and what it offers us is a consultation and work document of no interinstitutional value. The European Parliament has done its job. The Commission, not so. I'm afraid you don't even understand why this House has given the priorities. This is the only way to excuse this document which, it seems to me, shames the idea of strategic political action and, by the way, of the common good. There are consequences in political action, the same serves your inaction. In practice, what is done is to postpone the problem and during this postponement more women die. We treat the fundamental rights of 50% of the population as second-rate rights. This document, presented by the Commission, is incipient. It reflects only one thing: disrespect for all women. The absence of Commissioner Jourová here in this House is a symptom of this.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Commissioner, I want to thank you, and I also want to apologise to the Commissioner, who is currently at a data protection hearing and is perhaps more sorry than we are for not being able to hear this important debate. I would like to applaud the working proposal for a document that is truly practical, without unnecessary ideological proclamations. I appreciate the emphasis on implementation, monitoring and evaluation of existing impacts rather than promises on the production of new and new legislation and regulations. I like the fact that the Commission wants to set an example, that it wants to push for 40% of women to be represented in the top and middle positions of the governing bodies, and I think we should note that. I appreciate the focus on specific objectives, measures on women or parents who have children, want to care for these children, but also want to work and want to further develop their professional careers. That is why the Commission is proposing and will also promote and promote in the Member States the flexibility of parental leave, the flexibility of forms of work to strengthen women's chances of employment in the labour market. And I think it is also up to us, in the European Parliament, to add what is lacking there, at least for me, and that is precisely the greater appreciation of women who care and want to look after their children, because they see their irreplaceable place there, and that is their motherhood and family care. And I think that the most discriminated group is women and parents who take care of their children and invest in the future of Europe and the Member States instead of savings into their pension accounts. We should pay our support and attention to these.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Mr President, the development of the post-2015 gender equality strategy is an emergency, but also a concern at European level. As such, I believe that it is essential for Europe to improve public awareness in the Union on issues of equal rights in the labour market in the field of labour law and in overcoming cultural stereotypes.  On the other hand, there is a need to improve the skills and abilities in the field of equal opportunities and gender of managers and staff employed in the structures of local and central public authorities, social partners, but also among civil society organisations and the media.  In order to be able to make the best use of women's potential, it is necessary to promote women's entrepreneurship and self-employment, regardless of their field of activity, especially since in Europe women earn on average 17.8% less than men. Such gender pay gaps have a significant impact on women's earnings over life, as well as on their pensions. At the same time, we also need involvement in what agriculture means. The European Commission must coordinate its efforts to include appropriate solutions for women in agriculture in the future strategy. But for all this there must be political will and pragmatic approach on the part of the Commission.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, I think we are in a dilemma where we might ask ourselves the question: is quality or quantity important to us? If we think we will solve the issue of gender equality by creating as many legislative frameworks as possible and constantly producing new strategies, then we can propose them every day. But if we really care about eliminating inequalities between women and men, then we need to worry about the quality of these proposals. Our priority must be the implementation and evaluation of existing instruments, notably those promoting women's rights to education, decent working hours and equal pay, health insurance, as well as reducing violence against women. I do not think that the lack of a new strategy or working document issued by the Commission undermines the Commission's gender equality efforts. I am pleased that the Commission has taken the necessary steps to create a work-life balance which currently represents the biggest obstacle for women to choose to make career breakthroughs while caring for family at the same time. I must recall that the Women on Boards Directive is still on hold and maternity leave has been withdrawn to the detriment of the mothers of the worker. We haven't agreed on the basics, and we already want to create some new strategies. We need to take it one step at a time, address priorities, analyse existing legislation, and only then create new regulation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – Commissioner, it is lovely to see you here, but at the same time I want to say that, indeed, I am disappointed that the Commission has provided only a working document and not a strategy. And we said that to Commissioner Jourová as early as December, when she presented this working document to our FEMM Committee. Of course, those strategic objectives can be accepted, they are good, but the measures, the concrete actions set out in this working document, are unlikely to be able to achieve those objectives, because they are certainly insufficient. Indeed, I would like the Commission to examine this possibility: does the Commission not think that a European Observatory on Violence against Women should be established as soon as possible at the European Institute for Gender Equality, because this is a very important point. A European coordinator in the field of preventing violence against women and girls should lead it. I would also like to ask the Commissioner to ask how the Commission has decided on the publication of a written statement initiated by our Parliamentarians on the European Year against Violence against Women, as many as 400 Parliamentarians signed and supported such a written declaration last year, but this is not the year yet, which is very much needed. And yet: does the Commission not plan to specifically review the already truly unrealised and under-performance of 2006. Directive on equal opportunities for women and men in the labour market, especially when it comes to men's and women's wages. And to the end, I would certainly like normal cooperation between the Commission and the European Parliament, and I believe that, in this case, the Commission must recognise that it has stumbled on gender equality policy, has done so unwisely, but this can be corrected. I very much hope so.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have been a member of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality for seven years and I have been strongly supporting the strategies presented by the European Commission on equality, women's rights and gender equality for seven years. This year the Commission has presented us with a working document containing its priorities. The left of this Parliament has been very strongly critical of the Commission's method and is saying that this document lacks legal force. I do not agree with this approach for two clear and distinct reasons: the first is that I am a pragmatic woman who looks at the promised results and concrete solutions to real problems; secondly, having another strategy where new legislation on gender equality is promised, when there are already directives that have not yet been implemented in the Member States, does not make much sense. The working document, as set out by Commissioner Jourová, contains many positive references such as the desire to strengthen creativity and innovation, and to encourage female entrepreneurship at all levels of education and training. There is a road map on work-life balance, which has a strong economic motivation to support women's active participation in the labour market. In short, instead of sitting here arguing over the level of the document, let us roll up our sleeves and work to ensure that women play a leading role in Europe.

name: Anna HEDH
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In December 2015, the Commission announced that the proposed post-2015 gender equality strategy would have the legal status of an internal working document instead of a public communication. The internal working document was named "Strategic Commitment to Gender Equality between 2016-2019". The 341 Members who voted through the post-2015 strategy for gender equality are not only disappointed and outraged at the legal downgrade, but also at the fact that the Commission has now renamed the internal working document as something reminiscent of an official strategy. It's scam.  As so many times before, I am now calling for a response from the Commission. Why are you failing what previous Commissions have succeeded in delivering a public communication on a strategy for gender equality? If the Commission wants the EU to be a leading player in, for example, the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals, I call on the Commission: swallow the pride, do it all right – there is still time for that.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Although the situation has improved in recent years as far as women's employment in the labour market is concerned, despite education and training, young women have not become more economically active. At the same time, they work for lower wages than men. This also has a serious impact on the future, as today's wages also show the extent of tomorrow's pension. Today, there is still a big difference between women's and men's pensions, which increases the vulnerability of older women. In addition to the necessary regulations and compliance with them, it is particularly important to contribute to changing our perception of the role of women in society. The previous strategy has steered the gender balance in the right direction, which is why the guidelines for the coming years are important. What steps do you plan to take to further promote women's training? How do you intend to act to ensure that having children does not disadvantage women, either in terms of the pay gap or in retirement? These issues are also not incidentally important because the current demographic trends in Europe do not give much cause for optimism. Childbearing is shifting to a later date, while couples are having fewer and fewer children. Member States should therefore encourage and encourage childbearing. One way to do this is to allow for different flexible labour market opportunities. This way, women who want a family but are also committed to their careers are not forced to choose.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank my colleagues for their unstinting work trying to persuade the Commission to do the right thing: to publish a comprehensive and ambitious communication on a gender equality strategy, which is so urgently needed. We need a plan that is holistic and brave, a plan that tackles the many faces of gender inequality, and this plan must ensure that gender is mainstreamed into all aspects of European policy. For example, in recent months I have been working on anti-poverty policy, and the truth is that we will never be able to meet the EU’s anti-poverty targets by 2020 without striving for true gender equality. The economic crisis and austerity policies have disproportionately affected women. Single women are much more likely to be in precarious employment and to struggle to heat their homes and put food on the table. So what we need is policy coherence from the European Commission, revolving around one ambitious strategy to address the gender perspectives in all areas, including a much more social and gender-sensitive European semester. I look forward to seeing the Commission take this action that we so urgently need.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: – Madam Chairman, experience has shown that even when we have a strategy on gender equality, the changes in this field are very small in the European Union. That is why it is particularly worrying that we now have no strategy at all on gender equality, let alone other important documents such as a strategy on combating violence against women. As many as 90% of EU citizens consider this strategy necessary. The Commission downed their wishes to a working document. It's a slap in the ass to all women in the European Union. Major changes are coming in the Member States. In my country, Croatia, there is a debate at the moment about medically assisted reproduction, about the law on life partnership, the right of a woman to have an abortion. Yesterday, many citizens took to the streets demanding a society of solidarity, tolerance and equality. The European Union must be an example of preserving the values of tolerance and equality, especially in these turbulent times.  That is why I call on the Commission to adopt a new strategy on gender equality as soon as possible, according to guidelines adopted by the European Parliament. We would expect some things to be implied in 2016. But unfortunately, on issues of gender equality it turns out that we always take one step forward, two steps back. The gender equality strategy should not be something to develop a discussion about, but our commitment.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When I travel in Austria, I am often asked: yes, what does the EU bring me? And then I can start: for women, so much has been achieved over the years that has really substantially improved women's lives: guidelines, measures. Wonderful, only the pace has slowed down enormously, and now it seems that there seems to be a stalemate, particularly in the Commission. I know that the Member States often say: huch, there is subsidiarity, and then they slow down what is possible. I am absolutely aware of this. Nevertheless, the Commission should not be discouraged. Because women are beaten, they are sexually harassed. Women have different health problems than men. The supervisory boards still look sad: almost no women, many more men. Women are unemployed differently from men, marginally employed, part-time. Women and digitalisation are also such an issue, and women and gender budgeting. So you see, Commissioner, that there is so much to do, an infinite amount of work to be done. And what is currently on the table from the Commission, I would call equality strategy, something small, cute, but nothing where we can really assert ourselves in substance. We therefore need a genuine strategy for equality!

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Madam President, just picking up from Comrade Regner’s beginning, she said people often ask: ‘what does the EU do for me?’ Well, when I go home and I tell people that we were having a debate on a new Commission strategy, you can often see that they are not immediately convinced that that is necessarily going to make a very big difference to their lives. When you go home and tell them that you are having a debate about the fact that actually the Commission has not got a strategy, you can hardly blame them for looking a bit sceptical about whether we are all wasting our time here. That is a real shame, because women where I live and represent need help from us here and from you there, because they are not going to get it from our own government. The pay gap between men and women in my region under the Tory Government has now increased to GBP 5 500 a year. That is a very big gap, and the Tories are not going to do anything about it. Their recent changes to the tax and benefit systems have affected women three times worse than they have affected men, and the Tories are not going to do anything about that. They are looking to us and to you to do something about that. So this non-strategy, which is weak on disability, pay and domestic violence, is really not good enough for us to do our jobs, and so I have to say to the Commissioner: man up. (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Arne Gericke under Rule 162(8))

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – Women in the European Union on average have a lower salary than men. We are at greater risk of poverty in old age. We are much more burdened with household chores. In the labour market, we often see women being put up as a condition of having a working relationship, not having children for a few years. Women who have more young children are more difficult to get to work because of the potential for increased absenteeism due to child illness. We are in a minority of leadership positions, both in the economy and in politics. No woman has ever chaired the European Commission, and there were only two women in the European Parliament. In order to change this, we need a political commitment at the highest level, but instead of 2015, the Commission Staff Working Document is before us. In doing so, the President of the Commission sent a message that the issue of gender equality is a minor issue, given his statement that the Commission will be more ambitious on bigger issues and more modest and more restrained on smaller issues.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, gender equality will be difficult to achieve without a strategy that eliminates, or at least myths, the structural nature of the inequalities still present in our society. Public policy must in practice result in genuine equality of access and control over available resources and resources. The principle of substantial equality inherent in every constitutional charter and recognised by the European Union as a fundamental right must be given effect. The Commission's two-pronged approach to this issue is well known, with the integration of all gender-based policies, supported by specific measures to remedy inequalities. I have already spoken here about the moral obligation that cannot be put back to work on a radical change of mentality. The delay means, without stopping the compression of human rights, a reduction in European economic potential, where growth in innovation, research and training is not accompanied by sufficient active participation of women. I therefore agree with the need and urgency for the Commission to present a new strategy for gender equality.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the European Commission's new strategy on women's rights aims at gender equality in the Member States of the European Union, where violations of women's rights are often observed, but also discrimination against them.  In particular, there is a gender pay gap in the labour sector, currently 16.4%, and a corresponding pension gap of 39%. In addition, women often work part-time. Women are the group of the population most affected by both austerity and memoranda.  In Greece, which has been impoverished by the Memorandums, the new anti-insurance bill leads women freelancers and farmers, but especially rural women, to now have more than 80% of their annual income for insurance contributions and taxes. That is why all these women, together with the rest of the Greek people, are fighting against the troika and will participate the day after tomorrow in the massive general strike.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President; it is not to detract from her presence, which I thank, but we deserved, I believe, for the importance of doing this debate with Commissioner Jourová. One also demonstrates whether the issues are taken seriously while present in the discussions. But having said that, I also want to say that we do not want to degrade a gender equality strategy to a simple working document. Among other things, because we have very alarming data on the increase in inequality in Europe. Eurostat tells us that, in more than nine countries in the European Union, the wage gap has increased. It also tells us, for example, that the Institute for Gender Equality, that there is only one woman for every twenty-five men at the top of responsibility in the European Union. If you don't think this deserves a gender strategy... Also, let me tell you, you have strategy on issues such as maritime security, energy. Doesn't gender equality merit a strategy? I think so. Parliament is going to ask you tomorrow. The Council has asked you to do so. Please rectify and present a strategy.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, thank you for giving me the floor, I think you are thus implementing, in a good example, the equality of chances of us Members represented here in this Chamber. First of all, to Mrs Jourová, I think that she has always spent long evenings with us, also on this issue, and the fact that she is absent here is due to her negotiating an agreement on data protection, so I want to say to the previous speaker that I see this as a legitimate excuse. But on the subject itself, I think that, of course, the ratio that applies in nature, which is determined by nature – 52% in favour of women and 48% against men – is, of course, not respected in many positions, it is not respected at European Union level. On the other hand, we should never allow women to be disadvantaged. What I heard from my colleague Šulinová is very startling to me. But gender equality shouldn't be a political fetish, sometimes I feel like it's happening.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, it is regrettable that in 2016 we are still forced to discuss this topic. Despite centuries of struggle, women are still daily victims of discrimination and various forms of violence. I am glad that there is an awareness of this problem, and I believe there is a will to solve it. But I'm afraid we've been groping in place for some time because our methods aren't effective. The legislator and the executive branch at Member State level have not yet found a way to drastically punish open discrimination against women, and at European level, unfortunately, rules and gender quotas are imposed on private companies instead of conducting quality awareness-changing campaigns. We have come to the point that politicians take the right to regulate even relationships within families, and such immature and harmful attempts will justifiably create resistance among people. We must always bear in mind, this battle is won in heads and hearts, not on paper. Let's act accordingly and we'll be successful.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their contributions. It was really important to hear their opinions, proposals and suggestions. I would like to reiterate once again that the priorities of the strategy for equality between women and men for 2010-2015 remain valid. We need enforcement and implementation and we need a real action plan and actions on the ground. We know that all Member States must have their own national action plans and programmes. They must have their instruments, because we all agree that gender equality needs to be implemented in all political sectors. We as Commissioners – myself, Tibor Navracsics and Maria Javorova, for instance – must understand gender equality in our portfolios, move in this direction and to see how to implement our priorities. Why are we proposing the Strategic engagement for gender equality 2016-2019? Because it is a reference framework for increasing efforts to promote gender equality at all levels – at European, national, regional and local level. We need a coordination mechanism and better cooperation between Member States so as to encourage Member States to improve their instruments. We repeat once again that we have 30 key actions to be implemented in each of the five priority areas identified, as well as objectives and timelines for these actions together with the responsibilities of the Commission services. We need target benchmarks, timelines and the possibility to improve gender equality policies in a real way. There must be a little more governance to see how to implement those budgets. We have seen a great many strategies expire, but looking at implementation enforcement reveals a big gap between kind words and the real-life implementation of these strategies. I would like to thank you very much indeed. We are ready to cooperate and exchange our views and we are ready to continue in our debates. From the Commission side we need to be very active in improving gender equality.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Four motions for resolutions were sent to me to conclude the debate. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 3 February 2016 at 12.30. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), in writing. – Unfortunately in 2016 we are still talking about gender inequality and the need to safeguard women's rights. Women of all ages are subjected to violations of their rights in a variety of ways, such as violence - verbal or physical - sexist comments, inequality in the workplace or even difficulty accessing education.  For this reason, there are not enough complaints, resolutions and condemnations, but a complete legislative framework, in order to radically address this shameful violation of women's rights. The new EU Strategy on Women's Rights and Gender Equality is moving in this direction.  Our main concern is to fully implement existing European legislation, but also to introduce new proposals on this issue. Only if the Member States fulfil this obligation will we be able to talk about a Union, inspired by equality between men and women.  Apart from the political route, however, a radical change in the culture of citizens is necessary. There are two nurseries for the development and formation of characters as well as perceptions, especially in young people. Family and school. It is only through them that the change we all want for our Europe can take place.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next point is the oral question referred to the Commission by Matthias Groote, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Bas Eickhout, Merja Kyllönen and Piernicola Pedicini, which concerns the Commission's measures in case T-521/14. Sweden v Commission (obligation to define criteria for hormone disruptive substances) (O-000003/2016 - B8-0107/2016) (2016/2536(RSP)).

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Endocrine disruptors are found everywhere in our everyday lives and affect people. They are found in food packaging, in our children's toys, in our clothes and in our drinking water. The researchers link these substances to a wide range of diseases: diabetes, cancer and the risk of problems with fertility.  It is particularly ominous that babies, toddlers and foetuses are particularly vulnerable and that effects on these can last later in life. There are many of us who are concerned about the way things are going in our daily lives and the European Parliament has been very active in pushing the issue for proper legislation. The S&D Group has also been a driving force for a long time.  I am now proud that Sweden has pushed for the Commission to respect its obligations and to start the important work of devising scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors. Here, however, we seem to have a Commission that puts this on the bench and gives itself the right to refuse to comply with European law.  The decision of the European Court of Justice at the end of last year is clear. By failing to take measures to adopt scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors, the Commission has violated EU law, and that is completely unacceptable.  I would therefore like to hear from the Commission here today that it will take action and correct its infringement of the law. I would also like to hear that the process of developing scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors will stop, and I would like to hear that people will be given their responsibilities and work to protect the health of the people of Europe as it is obliged by the European Constitution. I expect this debate to become clear on the part of the Commission.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: author. – Madam President, if you were to ask someone to make a list of top priorities of what is important in his or her life, there is a big chance that one’s health tops the list, and that is what this debate is about. It is about health, and that is why it is so important. The issue we are discussing here is very clear and straightforward. We have a legal text, called the Regulation, and in this legal text there is a legally-binding mandate for the European Commission to adopt scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors by December 2013. It is not written in Chinese. We have many official languages in the EU, but Chinese is not one of them. So it is very clear and straightforward: by December 2013, the European Commission had to adopt scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors. I must say I can be extremely flexible if there are technical reasons for not being on time, but I am very inflexible when there are political reasons behind not meeting a deadline, and of course that is the case here. The Court ruling is extremely clear: the Commission should have adopted the scientific criteria in December 2013. To quote from the Court ruling: ‘There is no provision of the Regulation which requires an impact assessment’. So I am not against an impact assessment; I think it is a very valuable tool in this case too. But before starting an impact assessment, the Commission should have adopted the scientific criteria. I understood that already in July 2013 they were ready, there somewhere on a big dust pile somewhere in the Berlaymont Building. I would say: get rid of the dust and table them as soon as possible – that is, within a few weeks.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, as soon as you were inducted, I would say your inauguration, as Commissioner for Health, the Green Group had informed you that one of the priority issues would be the problem of endocrine disruptors. It was 2014, it's 2016 and you haven't done anything.  It took the intervention of the Swedish Minister of Health, the European Parliament and the Member States to refer you to the European Court of Justice, which condemned you for inaction, without reservation.  This sentence of 16 September explicitly states that the Commission does not respect the law and has even violated European Union law.  Moreover, when you are still asked about it, you hide behind an economic impact study, when the Judgment of the Court is clear, namely that this impact study is not necessary, and in addition you exceed your right. Despite this judgment, you persevere to continue this study.  Commissioner, how can we work together if the Commission does not respect The rights, the law, the European treaties? How much trust can we have between us? We therefore ask you to act in the coming months, even very quickly, to define these scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors. You already have them in your drawers, as my colleague Mr Gerbrandy said, because the Environment Directorate had done them. Therefore, as of tomorrow, you can release these scientific criteria. Take action, Commissioner, and act quickly.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: Author. – Mr President, according to the Biocidal Products Regulation, the Commission was to adopt delegated acts by 13 December 2013 specifying the scientific criteria for determining endocrine disrupting properties. This did not happen. In failing to adopt delegated acts, the Commission has clearly failed to fulfil its obligation to take measures for which it has legal responsibility.  Sweden took the Commission to the General Court in July 2014, supported by a few Member States, including my country, Finland, for dereliction of duty. The lawsuit was won in December 2015. Despite the decision of the General Court, the Commission has been very resentment with regard to the adoption of delegated acts defining the criteria. Why has the Commission been so slow in defining the criteria? Indeed, there are several examples of the Commission's desire for power to adopt delegated acts on matters not covered by delegated acts. And once, when delegated acts are rightly needed by the court, they can be pulled out of the roads, mainly by hotties. Hormone disruptors are a very serious matter. Under greatest threat are fetuses, which, if exposed, can get changes in their organs and metabolism. Therefore, delegated acts must be brought to the table immediately in order to obtain scientific criteria for determining endocrine disrupting properties and soon! Or, Commissioner, do we have to come from the Commission to pick them up first-hand?

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very pleased to have this opportunity to clarify the position of the Commission following the General Court’s judgment in the case of Sweden versus the Commission concerning the criteria to identify endocrine disruptors.
