Today I want to dispel all doubts – once again, dispel all doubts – regarding the Commission’s intentions. It seems that there has been some misunderstanding, so let me be very clear. The Commission has a firm intention to comply. This is a judgment of the Court – and we will do this. In the judgment of 16 December 2015, the General Court ruled that the European Commission had breached European Union law by failing to set criteria – constant criteria – to identify endocrine disruptors. And it is true. The Court stated that according to the Biocides Regulation the Commission had a clear, precise and unconditional obligation to adopt delegated acts to set the criteria by December 2013. That was three years ago. In addition, the Court ruled that there is no provision in this regulation requiring the carrying out of an impact assessment. This is also, from the Court’s side, a crystal clear position. But let me continue. I know that the reaction of the Commission to this judgment has been subject to some criticism, and this is okay; in a democracy, this is normal. In particular, the decision to finalise a nearly-completed impact assessment was called into question, notably by some honourable Members, and I have read with attention the many letters addressed to President Juncker or myself, including those from Members of this House. I have read them very carefully. I have all the papers on my table. However, the Commission would like to clarify that the impact assessment acts as a useful and even essential tool to guide its future decision on the criteria. And I fully agree with you when you mention that, yes, the impact assessment is really interesting too, especially when we debated criteria, because we need the criteria. The World Health Organization (WHO) definition on endocrine disruptors is not enough. Ms Rivasi was with me in conference debating different positions and how it is not easy to describe criteria. This is about criteria. The Commission decided in 2013 to undertake an impact assessment in view not only of the scientific complexity of the issue but also of the fact that this will be a pioneering work. There is indeed no legislation setting a precedent in this area; we all know that very well. First, science is not unanimous on how scientific criteria should be defined, and we heard those debates together. Diverging views still exist – still exist –within the scientific community on critical points, on how endocrine disruptors should be identified, because we must speak about regulatory issues. Second, we are defining the scientific criteria in a regulatory context, and views diverge among regulators worldwide – second options. In fact there are no legally-binding criteria in third countries for identifying endocrine-disrupting chemicals. The European Union is a pioneer in this aspect. Moreover, within the EU some Member States support a hazard-based approach and others a risk-based approach. Those differences exist today. We are facing those differences all together. The evidence gathered during the impact assessment will enable us – and here I also include the Members of this Parliament – to have a say in all the measures, to take a duly informed decision. Let me be very clear once again. The Commission is fully aware that the deadline has passed and has every intention to comply with the judgment of the Court. Have no doubts about that. The preparation of the impact assessment is well advanced and, in response to the judgment of the Court, the Commission will present, before summer this year – 2016 – new scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors. As you know, two separate axes need to be presented. First, an implementing regulation containing the criteria which will be applied to the chemical substances falling under the Plant Protection Product Regulation and under the so-called PRAC procedure. Second, a delegated act containing criteria applicable under the Biocidal Products Regulation. Once again I can reassure Parliament that the Commission is committed to complying with the judgment. We will therefore present, before this summer, criteria which will be specified in an objective manner based on scientific evidence. I am not the judge when science has different opinions, but we need to understand that today we are ready to see more and more convergent views from different schools and different debates. Our legislation in these two areas is considered to be among the strictest in the world and I will ensure that a high level of protection for human health and the environment, including from endocrine disruptors, is fully maintained. The interim criteria for defining endocrine disruptors set in the plant protection and biocidal products legislation are legally binding till those days and applicable. Of course it is not enough; of course we must move immediately to seeing possibilities of, by this summer, having some constant endocrine disruptors criteria. I hope you have found helpful and positive the transparency provided throughout the whole of our preparatory work last year. I was personally very attentive to communicating regularly and openly with you on this complex issue and I intend to continue to do so. We should aim together to adopt the best decision on this very important matter and I count on your constructive support for the next steps that will now come in the very near future.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner Andriukaitis, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The free definition of criteria for hormone-active substances, the so-called endocrine disruptors, is extremely important from the point of view of health protection for European citizens. However, the question is very complicated and very technical and therefore only serious to be answered by scientists and experts. This question is not suitable for political games or ideological debates. Since 16.12.2015, we have had a judgment of the European Court of Justice which shows that the European Commission has missed a deadline. We would not have needed a trial for this finding. What we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats made clear months ago is still true: the Commission must complete the impact assessment as soon as possible and draw up the criteria quickly. Commissioner, here I take you at your word: if you manage to do so by the summer of 2016, that is a good step in the right direction. It would be wrong to assume that the judgment of the European Court of Justice would lead to the Commission cancelling the impact assessment and abandoning the criteria altogether. It is important, as the Commissioner has just made clear, how controversial this issue of the definition of endocrine disruptors is. The often very emotional debate of recent months shows that we had more than 27 000 submissions from citizens during the consultation alone, but more than 25 000 came from a few NGOs. We must now gather facts and establish the criteria scientifically. I have just understood the Commissioner that the Commission is now on the right track. In this respect, for my group, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, support in this direction!

name: Pavel POC
text: for the S&D Group. And all this time, Europeans are exposed to chemicals that cause cancer, affect the psyche, cause miscarriages, teratogenesis, infertility, diabetes, that's far from it. Commissioner, you know this better than I do because you are a doctor. For as long as I can remember, I have been talking to the Irish Presidency, the Lithuanian, Greek, Italian, Latvian, Luxembourg about the problem. Today, the Netherlands says that this is a priority for its Presidency and they are not even here, so that is a tragedy. Commissioner, it wasn't that long ago that we talked about this in this hemicycle, and that's when I said it wasn't your fault. It's not true anymore. You promised you'd figure it out, you didn't keep it. Today you promise a quick solution, and can you believe it if you dare to say that science is not united on this issue? Well, that's complete nonsense. So far, the Commission has not respected the General Court, it has not immediately submitted criteria that are long overdue, and that is also your responsibility. That leaves a few questions. What is the real reason that the Commission has not respected Parliament for years, it does not respect European citizens, the scientific public, and now it does not even respect the General Court? Is this a TTIP negotiation? According to a letter from the U.S. side, the legislation would disrupt negotiations. We saw the letter, of course. Or is it the industry lobby that has forced this shameful, pointless, pointless impact study to mentor scientific knowledge? Whatever it is, the Commission has failed, you have failed personally, and I am sorry, because I trusted you. We're going to get glyphosate authorization for the next 15 years instead of criteria, thanks. And if we are asking whether you are asking what is destroying European society's confidence in the EU in every way, it is cases like this. Fix it and fix it now.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner Andriukaitis, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has For years, the WHO has warned that pesticides, plastics, and many other products contain chemicals that cause harm to human health, humans and animals, even in the smallest doses. The increasing number of cancers and other diseases has been shown to be linked to the use of these chemicals. The risks of endocrine disruptors are not new. But what is the Commission doing? It merely initiated impact assessments, it missed a deadline, apparently forgetting that we are burdened every day with substances that have a negative impact on our hormonal system. Why has the Commission missed this deadline and is accepting this risk? After all, it is high time that the citizens of Europe were protected from these substances. Because that's what they expect from us. We were elected to this House for this purpose and not for representing the interests of the chemical and pharmaceutical industries.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – You started well by saying that you are going to follow the law and the judgment of the Court of Justice. But then you became very unclear about what is going on with the impact assessment. I will make it very clear once more: the Court of Justice has said that only scientific criteria should apply. They were finished in 2013, so they can be published now. Why do you still need until the summer of 2016? Is that because you still want to wait for the impact assessment? If that is the case, you will go directly against the court's ruling, because that has said that the impact assessment should not play a role in determining the scientific criteria. If you do, you will go against the court's ruling, and that is a disgrace to the Commission.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Court's ruling has recognised that the Commission is lagging behind in defining scientific criteria for detecting endocrine disruptors. The delay was justified by the need to carry out a cost-benefit assessment, a questionable exercise since the criteria for scientific evaluation cannot be adapted to commercial needs. A recent paper published in The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism in March 2015 estimated an annual health cost in the European Union due to exposure to endocrine disruptors of between 165 and 256 million euros. These figures refer to only 5% of the substances recognized. What makes the Commission's delay more indefensible is the social cost of pollution by endocrine disruptors paid each year, among others, by some 60 000 newborns who come into the world with major cognitive delays due to exposure in utero to these compounds, children to whom we have stolen the future.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, it is still a shame that the European Commission is being condemned on an issue as serious as that of endocrine disruptors, even though the European Parliament has been sounding the alarm for a very long time.  We are of course in favour of impact studies, but it should have been done much earlier and we should have had it already. We do ask that the criteria for endocrine disruptors be defined on the basis of truly scientific studies. We have to ask ourselves the following question: when is there a danger to human health? We need to answer all of those questions.  The industry will, of course, have to find other solutions, and one can imagine that the delay that has been made comes from pressure from a few lobbyists, and that is unfortunate. The European Commission, which talks about better legislation, now has a real subject on which it should bring real added value in public health and propose European legislation.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Madam President, this is a political scandal. The court's decision urges us to react quickly, because it is not a technical problem, but a public health problem.  Today, Europeans die of cancer because of pesticides, for example, which are one of the endocrine disruptors. There are also packages, children's toys, cash register tickets that contain these substances. It is therefore a question of defending the health of Europeans and ensuring that cancers, malformations, but also other consequences for our health can be avoided.  This is, of course, also a serious financial problem. This has been said: endocrine disruptors represent a cost equivalent to almost 1.3% of our European gross domestic product. Now that the European Court of Justice has issued its judgment, now is not the time, Commissioner, to tell us that there is going to be a procedure with an impact assessment. No, as several stakeholders have pointed out, you now have to define criteria that effectively protect us.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Madam President! To the Commissioner: this is, as I said many times, a scandal! And it is not true that there is so much disagreement about the scientific evidence. We just have a very, very thorough study in Denmark, which has been published throughout Europe and which shows, on the one hand, that the influence on children's, on the brain of the unborn child is quite dramatic, and on the other hand shows that there are serious consequences for boys/men's fertility.  What may be unclear is how much the industry will suffer financially if it does not come together and find alternatives and phase out. It is not our job to help the industry do so by any other means than by making clear demands. Then most industries can figure out how to phase out and find viable alternatives. In addition, we have suggested that there may be exceptions, something that is excluded. It is completely irrelevant to devote such efforts to please an old-fashioned inventive industry instead of taking into account the health of citizens.

name: Ivo BELET
text: I do not think we should repeat that endocrine disruptors are obviously causing a great deal of concern, not only here in this House, but among the population as a whole. It is about products that we use daily in clothing, furniture, electronics, glue, cosmetics, you name it, and that are therefore present daily. It is therefore essential that we remove this unrest and finally come up with clear scientifically based criteria. It is very good that you are announcing here that you will come up with these criteria in the short term, but as soon as possible, and it is also very good that we will be communicating very broadly and very clearly about this.  It seems that everything is bad now and that nothing has happened yet, but perhaps it is useful to point out that we already have strict rules - as you have already referred to, Commissioner - for the use of chemicals in toys and in plastic. And, of course, we also have the Reach rules under which the impact of endocrine disruptors is systematically investigated. But it is indeed now time to take those steps forward. The judges' ruling - you said it yourself - leaves nothing in doubt. In the context of maximum consumer protection, we must now take these steps so that not only consumers but also producers know where they stand in the short term and so that they know what alternatives they need to come up with.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: – Madam President, endocrine disruptors are potentially dangerous substances. These substances are found all around us: in packaging, detergents, toys, personal hygiene products and pose multiple health risks. It must therefore be identified, classified and regulated.  The criteria for classifying these substances should be based on scientific evidence and not on economic reasons. When it had to establish these criteria, the Commission was in a hurry and assessed only the socio-economic costs and benefits, instead of worrying primarily about the impact on health.  We're not talking about a minor problem with negligible impact. We are talking about a major public health problem, which we urgently need to address. I do not see the signal from the Commission that it understands this need to act quickly. On the contrary, he first delayed a decision for a year, then set his priorities wrong.

name: Bart STAES
text: – The fuss surrounding the criteria, the postponement and the conviction, which of course has everything to do with the lobbying of the chemical industry. Part of the controversy in this discussion is the industry's argument for potential as one of the criteria. That's a perfide political trick to actually say: only those hormone disruptors that are most potent, the strongest, we can take them into account. Commissioner, I have two bottles here, a bottle of Poire Williams eau de vie from France, 43 degrees. I have a bottle of Belgian beer here, a Duvel, 8.5 degree alcohol. Would you dare say, Commissioner, that the Poire Williams is alcohol and the bottle of Duvel is not? Well, that's exactly what the industry is trying to do around hormone disruptors. The hormone disruptors with the most potency, the strongest, these will become hormone disruptors and the others will not. Commissioner, you know that we have the right of veto over the criteria you will bring. I warn you, our group will veto the criteria if it mentions potential.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Madam President, the presence of endocrine disruptors in our environment raised concerns in recent years because harmful effects have been observed on reproduction, growth, the development of human life and the environment.  Endocrine disruptors represent a challenge, as their effects depend on both the level and timing of exposure, being especially critical when exposure occurs during development. Some of my colleagues – and I am profoundly convinced that they have the sincere goal of protecting citizens’ health against possible endocrine disruptors in the best way – were harsh with the Commission. However, I believe that – despite the Court of Justice decision – the original intention of the European Commission to have an impact assessment first was the best way of arriving at criteria that are scientific and proportionate. The process is under way, and I welcome the determination, expressed here, of Commissioner Andriukaitis to speed up the process. There is no legal vacuum now; people are being protected by legislation that is in place: by the REACH Regulation, which applies for industrial chemicals. This EU regulatory framework is enforced and regularly updated with the latest science. The goal, in the end, is to define the criteria that can best identify substances that can actually cause harm under realistic conditions. This allows us to regulate: that is, to ban or severely restrict their use, as appropriate. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, Mr Buoi, you say: 'Endocrine disruptors must be eliminated as much as possible, because they are a problem'. However, the problem with endocrine disruptors is that there is no dose, there is no threshold. At a very low level, there may be a greater effect than at a high level. That is why they really need to be defined so that they are removed. It is not a question of trying to eliminate them as much as possible. As soon as there are any, you have to be able to remove them or, if you do not have alternative molecules, you have to tell the industry that they have two years to find a solution.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, Mrs Rivasi, I fully agree with you, I said the same thing. I also understood the original intention of the European Commission to do a study to see exactly what the clearest criteria are. If the scientific community does not support these criteria, it will be very difficult to define them properly.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, by refraining from adopting delegated acts aimed at defining scientific criteria for the identification of substances with endocrine disruptors properties, the European Commission has failed to fulfil its obligations under the regulation on the release on the market and use of biocidal products. After numerous appeals from the European Parliament, the Court of Justice of the European Union also, following sweden's appeal, recognised that the European Commission had violated EU law. With this delay, which has lasted since September 2013, the European Executive is demonstrating that it is unable to respond to the real needs of European citizens and that it is unable to protect their health. No more delays justified by the possible consequences for the functioning of the internal market, and that is enough with the long waits for the definition of impact analyses. Following the Court's ruling, we expect measures to be taken quickly to establish scientific criteria for the identification of substances with endocrine disruptors properties, which is absolutely necessary to ensure the health of European citizens.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, you are in the process of undermining consumer confidence in our consumer protection policy. It is scandalous that the Commission itself is breaking rules that it should monitor and comply with. I am a farmer myself and i do not understand why the effects of hormone-altering substances in pesticides have not been assessed to this day.  How many substances have been authorised which do not actually meet the criteria for authorisation, but which are in circulation and which endanger users and consumers and the environment? You just spoke of a misunderstanding. I don't think that was a misunderstanding. I rather believe that you have really buckled in front of the agricultural lobby, which fears the loss of many resources, but also of the chemical industry, which naturally fears that its business model will collapse.  They really need to take consumer protection interests more seriously. I appeal to you, and the same applies to the criteria for cosmetics – here too you must act. We cannot circulate cosmetics where endocrine disruptors do not matter.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Many everyday objects include the so-called endocrine disruptors. Think of the pan we need for frying, think of the lacquered wooden floor on which we walk barefoot, the plastic butterbread can that we give our children to school, or pesticides. The consequences of contact with these substances can be, as has been said several times, for example infertility, breast cancer or diabetes. There is therefore a very urgent need for action here, Commissioner. In December, the ECJ delivered the judgment just discussed; Scientific criteria for these substances should therefore have been established by the end of 2013 at the latest. I referred to this in a question in writing last year. In principle, therefore, it is a question of strictly regulating these dangerous substances, because there are really strong indications that these substances are harmful and also have serious social consequences. For example, relevant economic studies have shown that the diseases caused cost our health funds almost EUR 160 billion a year. A strict and appropriate legal framework can therefore help to protect people's health much better. And that is precisely the precautionary principle. If there is only the slightest doubt that an active substance is harmful to health, this active substance must not be authorised in Europe. It should and must be as simple as that. I therefore appeal to the Commission: be the advocate of consumers and not the advocate of large chemical companies! I am sure that the latter will find alternatives.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: – Madam Chair, I welcome this decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union, as the Commission has failed to honour its commitments on an issue of u sthuthing public health and the well-being of our citizens. With endocrine disruptors we have 2 big problems. One is that they have a very negative effect on our health, affecting the hormonal system of man, and the other that we are surrounded by them in everyday life, in clothes, in food and beverage packaging, in the plastic that we use in everyday life. Various theories are knitting around endocrine disruptors and inaction by the European Commission, some of which are completely unrealistic. However, if the Commission ignores this Judgment of the Court, its credibility will take a strong hit. That is why I call on the European Commission to respect its own rules, to respect the decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union and to finally adopt criteria for dealing with endocrine disruptors. They must be scientifically based, enforceable and, most importantly, serve public health.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Endocrine disruptors can cause cancer and affect metabolism and the ability to have children. Foetuses and young children are particularly sensitive to influences. If a fetus is exposed to an endocrine disruptor, it can have effects on brain development.  The European Commission was given the task of protecting people against endocrine disruptors. Instead, it chose to drag the issue to the fore and protect the chemical industry. Now the Commission has been convicted by the Court of Justice for this. I think it is time for the Commission to take its mission seriously and start protecting people, the environment and health instead of industrial interests.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Dear Commissioner and colleagues, in the European Union in recent years we have seen an increased incidence of chronic diseases, including cancers linked to hormones, breast cancer in women and prostate and testicular cancers in men, obesity, diabetes and cardiovascular disease, as well as reproductive problems: miscarriages, reduced fertility and infertility. That chemicals such as BPA and PBDE and pesticides, especially when combined, play an important role in this, notes a growing body of scientific research. Endocrine disruptors have great potential for harmful or irreversible effects, with the cost of the disease annually estimated at around €150 billion. It is therefore necessary to take measures to protect health, especially for vulnerable groups such as pregnant women, infants, children and adolescents. We know enough to act. If there is no will to act, there is interest behind it, albeit shrouded in unity of science. Protecting citizens from health threats is one of the three strategic objectives of the European Union's health policy. Therefore, in the area of health, where we should be closer to citizens, only consistent action by the Commission is necessary and permissible. Hormonal disruptors should be placed in the prevention center.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! Cancers, malformations, miscarriages, brain damage, etc. The list of the damage caused by endocrine disruptors is long. The vast majority of the researchers who work on this believe so. That is why we must also thank Sweden for having led the Court of Justice of the EUROPEAN Union to clarify that the European Commission has been in a state of displeasing on this matter, and that is therefore unacceptable! I know that this is a complex issue, but it is no excuse for not responding in order to protect citizens' health. There are many people who ask me why the European Union has not reacted. Well, the answer is: I don't know! I think it's embarrassing. And that does not increase citizens' confidence in the European Union.  Let us not delay the matter. The more we do this, the more the European Commission becomes responsible for citizens' health problems. Come on with that definition! Now set some lower exposure limits and make an action plan! Not tomorrow, not next year, not in the fall, but now!

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, hormone disruptors affect not only human health, but also the intelligence level of future generations, europe as a whole. We all know that they have long-lasting, long-term and irreversible effects. Often the consequences are not visible until the next generation. These criteria are therefore urgent and scientific evidence is not lacking at the moment either. The consensus of scientific experts is also very broad on how to define hormone disruptors and also how to measure effectiveness. It is not, therefore, a lack of criteria, but that the Commission has not presented them to this Parliament. We cannot move forward with pesticide legislation, biocidal legislation, food packaging or REACH clothing concentrations and fire protection chemicals. Most recently, the court has ruled that there is no need for an impact assessment. It is a question of survival and human health. Not about what, for example, is the economic impact. On its own right, the Commission is also demanding compliance with the principle of law from the Member States, for example in the case of Poland and Hungary. The least that can be expected of the Commission itself is for it to respect the principle of law itself and to remedy this omission and to bring the criteria to Parliament very quickly without a specific impact assessment. Otherwise, I personally suspect that the will and desire to defend the health and credibility of citizens is seriously at stake.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the Commission's position is unsustainable and incomprehensible.  Five years? We could say that we have known and talked about the harmful health effects of endocrine disruptors for over twenty years; speaking after all of public health insecurity.  It is not to be acknowledged that it is justice that has had to intervene to tell him that there is no reason to prolong this leave of office; that there is no reason to invent consultations or socioeconomic impact studies to define scientific criteria around endocrine disruptors. The Court has told you that health and science are above economic interests.  Today he announces, at last, that by the summer we will probably have these scientific criteria. I hope that is finally the case, but above all, it imposes the criterion of public health above economic interests, which seem to be twisting or influencing very clearly on this trajectory and this journey around endocrine disruptors.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – In general, I consider it right for the Commission to try in advance to estimate the economic and social costs of adopting new legislation. However, in this case, I would expect the Commission to bear in mind, above all, the issue of human health. If the suspicion that endocrine disruptors cause a decrease in fertility not only of fish, but also of humans is definitively confirmed, it will be too late.  However, I believe that, together with investments in filtration systems, Member States should also address sources of pollution. What we need more than carbon filters is a change in the reckless approach to the use of these substances, be it agriculture and livestock farming or, for example, mass consumption of hormonal contraceptives.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, we are discussing the increase in endocrine disorders and diseases observed in recent years in a large part of the population. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that mimic hormones and interfere with the hormonal system resulting in fertility disorders, neoplasms and various cancers.  These substances are found as has been said in many everyday products and the individual consumer cannot know their existence, especially since these items often do not carry a statement of content. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to review existing relevant legislation and to have more requirements concerning chemicals contained in products such as foodstuffs In addition, changes should be made with regard to the evaluation, authorisation and restrictions of these substances in the above products, as well as greater transparency in determining whether a substance , in this case, has the qualities that should be prohibited.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Madam President, 16 December 2015 will remain a date engraved, I imagine, on the Commission's shelves. This is the first time that it has been condemned by the European courts for failing to do so on this issue of endocrine disruptors. A shame all the same, you will admit, for the guardian of the treaties ... However, the scientific community and the European Parliament have been warning for a long time about the harmful effects of these substances on health. The only thing I abstained from reach in 2006 was precisely because these endocrine disruptors were not defined by objective criteria. It has been ten years, Commissioner, ten long years and, singularly, three years now, that the Commission is obliged to provide these criteria. I listened very carefully, you said... 'we have the firm intention to comply with the judgment of the Court before summer' We take note of this, Commissioner, but we will remain vigilant, with Sioux's vigilance. You have not given us any reason to trust you so far.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Commission is shrouded in tattered excuses for not doing what it was legally obliged to do: to present by December 2013 criteria for the identification of endocrine disruptors, substances that interfere with the human hormonal system, which are potential causes of serious diseases. Invoking an alleged scientific uncertainty to do nothing but a known expedient to put ahead of safeguarding the public interest, at the forefront of safeguarding public health, other very diverse interests, economic interests, in particular the chemical industry lobby.  The endless and biased impact assessments only corroborate this. The truth is that this serious lack of the European Commission, and the unacceptable stance of throwing forward what should be done right now, turns out to be very convenient in a context where, as we know, ttip is being negotiated with the United States and where, as we know, endocrine disruptors are a hot spot of this TTIP and where , as we know, the United States has very permissive legislation in this regard. The European Commission's position is unacceptable and deserves to be denounced.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his willingness to debate an issue that is fundamental to the health of our citizens. The Commission intends to have an impact assessment carried out to define the criteria which, in turn, will be used to identify endocrine disruptors. But the Biocides Regulation set the deadline for definitions in December 2013. The study was not required by any provision and in any case this did not exempt you from compliance with the deadlines.  The Commission, which is supposed to defend the EU treaties, has gone its own way, although several Members had written to Juncker reminding him of his obligations under the Treaties. I would therefore ask you to ensure that the operational definition of endocrine disruptors is ready as soon as possible. We cannot wait until June for the criteria and December 2016 for classification. I would also ask you to commit you to maximum transparency and dialogue with the scientific community and Parliament. Protecting citizens and the environment and applying the precautionary principle are the priority, before any kind of commercial and economic interest. The Commission has an enormous responsibility towards citizens suffering from infertility, malformations and endometriosis, a responsibility that it absolutely cannot shirk.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I generally support the Commission's approach, but at this one minute I would like to be quite strict. According to the comments I made, on 20 March 2013 the European Food Safety Authority issued the opinion requested by the Commission, precisely as regards the scientific criteria, on 20 March 2013. The deadline was December 2013, nothing happened. And in February 2014, the Commission announced that it would carry out an impact assessment. Well, I think it is unequivocal to convict the Commission of acting carelessly, breaching all deadlines. I do not know what she has been doing all year since the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority was published. And I think that officials and senior representatives of the Commission are being paid by European citizens for service, I think quite nicely. It would therefore be appropriate for the Commissioner to stop telling fairy tales, because although this judgment was handed down before Christmas, it is not possible to tell fairy tales even in February.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first I would like to say very openly that I am a medical doctor. I practised as a medical doctor for 27 years, and I know very well what cancer and other diseases mean. I am still a medical doctor today. I say to those who mentioned that I have an interest in the debate on these industries: be open about it. That would be very nice, because I am very honest and I like honest debates and fair games. Some Members said that I represent the industry; I am sorry, but that is a very unfair argument. I met several times with endocrinologists, toxicologists and biochemists. A few weeks ago I debated together with our senior advisers and organised meetings between different groups of scientists. I would like to invite you to debate very openly because we must speak about scientific evidence and about real arguments. It is very important for all of us, because I have never agreed to be on the side of industry. My first responsibility is to public health. I am very proud that I have very many allies here. I am very happy that we are maybe ready to fight against alcohol, tobacco, sugar and salt, because they are extremely damaging, especially tobacco. When we really speak about people’s health I will be very happy to have so many allies here in this House. Speaking of this difficult issue, as you will remember, last year I said that the impact assessment was not about economic and social aspects. It is about scientific criteria and how to define potency, exposure, qualification and so on. I am not a biochemical scientist, and this is not such an easy debate. Last year we organised three round tables and organised conferences together and held debates. If you think I am on the side of the industry, please show me how this can be. I am very honest. My diploma is as a medical doctor. I am responsible and I am ready to work. In our reduced assessment time we started with methodology and debated with GFC. There are 600 chemical materials to be evaluated on this. I cannot see how we could deal with it any quicker. Please show me. Please help me. I am also green like you, but I will not play a game I consider to be dishonest. I am ready to say very clearly that we are ready to move forward as soon as possible and to do our job.  It would be nice to have a result by the end of 2016 maybe. Today we decided to give ourselves until the summer to decide. Please do better. I wish to be very open and very transparent, but I ask you also to work together and to be transparent in all questions. Speaking of all questions related to health, I will be very happy to speak about electronic cigarettes and tobacco and about all the bad things we currently face. These are very difficult conditions for the European Union to speak about public health issues and how the cost of public health could be reduced in the European Union. The figures are terrible. I am ready to do my job but, believe me, first of all we need manageable regulatory criteria. I do not think this is so easy because these issues are very complex. But when I hear such populist arguments, I am sorry but I must respond that I am very open and transparent. I will never be in a lobby on any given side. But it is a very difficult job. We all must debate very seriously and deeply about how to assess, how to regulate, how to understand and how to move forward. I am doing my job. I have been in office only for one year and four months. I have lost one year and four months. I would like to know how to be more effective, but we must all be effective together. We are ready to do our job and to move forward as much as possible to come up with some criteria by the summer and to set a very good example for the wider world, because we are pioneers. Thank you dear colleagues, we are ready to do our job based on scientific evidence and present criteria, perhaps by the summer if possible.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – Since the December court ruling, we have been awaiting a signal from the Commission in recognition of its failure to put a system in place to protect our citizens’ health by identifying and banning or limiting, to the fullest extent possible, substances that disturb our endocrine systems. Chemicals found in pesticides and everyday items such as food containers, cosmetics or items of clothing can contain endocrine disrupting components that harm human health and the environment. Because these are hazardous at very low levels of exposure, we cannot simply draw safe levels of exposure, as we do with other kinds of chemicals.  The Commission had a proposal ready almost three years ago, based on independent expert input, which would have seen light within the deadlines we mandated. Instead, the chemical lobby’s version about costs and risks to crop yields caught the then Secretary-General Catherine Day, based on impact assessments from the UK and Teagasc, the Irish agriculture and food development authority. Her decisions have brought action to a screeching bureaucratic halt, and it is time for President Junker to act upon the court’s decisions and remedy this hazardous legacy of Ms Day’s.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – A preliminary impact assessment of the legislation on the possible ban on pesticides containing hormone disruptive substances has been expected by both manufacturers and users for 3 years. The European Court of Justice ruling in Sweden v European Commission appears to have led the Commission to rush into the preparation of the impact assessment or to dispense with the impact assessment. In order to assess the appropriate health, economic and social impacts, the Commission should carry out thorough work which cannot be carried out in a few months, especially not to be missed. I would remind the Commission of compliance with the provisions of the Guidelines on Impact Assessments. In particular, a preliminary impact assessment should be carried out for both legislative and non-legislative acts, as well as delegated and implementing acts.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The potential withdrawal of certain active substances included in plant protection products is a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council. Endocrine disruptors, as they are referred to, are substances with potentially high environmental impacts. On the one hand, some of them pose a potential risk to human health, some of which are, for example, carcinogenic. They can also pose a threat to fauna: they can affect reproduction (getting into the waters limit the fertility of fish) or even the disappearance of certain species (ED compounds with mass extinction of bees are studied). On the other hand, they are very effective, and their use reduces the consumption of plant protection products in general. A total ban on their use can mean large crop losses due to the lack of effective alternative measures. There is also a risk that some farmers will start importing funds unofficially, e.g. from Ukraine, the composition and harmfulness of which will not be known. In order to protect the environment effectively and at the same time not impose a disproportionate burden on farmers, the assessment criteria should be revised in such a way that all active substances are not included in the category of so-called endocrine disruptors, but only those that have a negative impact on the environment and human health.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – If we misdefine the criteria for endocrine disruptors, thereby preventing the use of extremely useful and safe plant protection products, we will cause great harm to our farmers. Depriving them – and indeed us, because I am a farmer myself – of the necessary work tools will seriously reduce agricultural productivity, reduce the competitiveness of European agriculture and lead to a drop in incomes. Moreover, a reduction in investment in the plant protection industry will result in job losses and, to some extent, a halt to the research that industry is conducting together with independent organisations. I am strongly of the opinion that we should establish criteria defining substances that are actually dangerous. However, first we need to carry out comprehensive, thorough studies to obtain a full risk assessment of the use of hormonally active substances in protective and biocidal products. Innovation in agriculture is extremely necessary, but development must take place sensibly, after careful consideration of the possible effects of legislative decision-making. The European Commission's proposal to introduce amendments to the legislation, taking into account the partial results of the analyses, seems to be a mis-erred idea that could complicate procedures and disrupt the functioning of the European market. Let us wait for a full assessment of the effects of endocrine disruptors to be completed, and only then will we consider the relevant legislation.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. – The protection of the health of European citizens is not yet guaranteed. An excellent example is the European Commission's delay in adopting scientific criteria for identifying endocrine disruptors. This was mandatory until December 2013. MePs have information that these criteria have already been developed, but under the guise of various procedures do not want to publish them. While this happens, human hormonal disorders and diseases, including early puberty, genital deformity, certain forms of cancer and metabolic disorders, are only increasing. Anomalies continue to be caused to wildlife species, their reproduction, behaviour, immunity activities are disturbed. Today, we not only need criteria, but also more research. Around 800 substances are counted, which are known or suspected to have an effect on hormone synthesis, but only a small proportion of them have been studied, so very important studies should be carried out in the future and should be supported by the European Union.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I would like here to denounce the European Commission for its inertia on the issue of endocrine disruptors. These cause cancer, hormonal disturbances, altered sperm quality, early onset of puberty. The Commission, by not publishing the scientific criteria for defining these disruptors and by not proposing an update of the legislation, has made itself outlawed in the eyes of European law. Worse still, the European Commission, by its inefficiency in this matter, has a share of responsibility with every new victim caused by this scourge that affects the health of millions of Europeans. The Commission, which was found guilty by the European Court of Justice, justified itself by invoking its willingness to make an impact assessment. What a bad joke! The Commission would like to buy time and play the game of mega industrial groups that it would not do otherwise. It is unacceptable to treat the health of Europeans with such little respect! Science must continue its research, but the citizen must not be a guinea pig! We need to regulate these substances!

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the Commission's statement on transparency and control of clinical trials (2016/2534(RSP)).

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to express my deepest sympathies to the victims of the tragic incident that occurred recently during a clinical trial in France and to their families. I fully trust that the French authorities have taken all the necessary measures to address this situation and are doing their utmost to clarify exactly what happened. I am personally in close contact with the French Minister of Health to monitor the situation and any new developments related to the investigations. It is important that we all wait for the outcome of this investigation before drawing any conclusions. Clinical trials are essential for the development of new medicines and to improve, compare and refine treatments using already—authorised medicines. Clinical trials are often the last hope for patients suffering from rare or serious conditions. In areas such as paediatric oncology, for example, there are clearly established links between participation in clinical trials and the life expectancy of patients. It should not be forgotten that a certain risk is associated with any clinical trial. Clinical research is a sector in which Europe is a world leader. Offering Europeans patients the best, most innovative treatments under the highest standards of patient protection remains the main objective of regulation in this area. We can all agree that transparency is an essential component of clinical research. It should be possible to know which clinical trials are ongoing, where, by whom, what their purpose is and what are the recruitment criteria. Some of this information is already available via the existing EU Clinical Trials Register managed by the European Medicines Agency, with which I am in constant contact. Furthermore, once a trial has been completed, its outcome – whether positive or negative – should be made publicly available. Additionally, the European Medicines Agency (EMA) has pro-actively engaged in a policy to release clinical study reports submitted to the agency as part of the application for marketing authorisation of human medicines before this summer. This will make Europe a true frontrunner as regards the release of data concerning clinical trials. This transparency initiative creates a bridge from now until when the new clinical trial regulations become applicable. This will trigger real improvement as regards transparency. All information on clinical trials authorised by Member States will be stored in a new European Union database managed by EMA, with some exceptions which were defined during the legislative process. The whole content of the European Union database will be publicly available. Furthermore, in cases of overriding public interest, all information concerning specific trials will immediately be made publicly available. The European Union database is being developed by the European Medicines Agency. This IT tool is crucial for the correct functioning of the new regulation. It will have to handle the flow of information concerning the thousands of clinical trials ongoing every day in Europe. It certainly constitutes a complex and challenging IT project. While understanding all the difficult technical challenges, I regret to say that this project is running behind schedule. All concerned parties – EMA, Member States and the Commission – will have to step up efforts to make the EU database operational as soon as possible, in order to enable the full implementation of the new regulation. To date, there are no elements indicating that the application of the new regulation would have prevented this incident in France. I am sure that EMA has, and will deploy, the necessary technical resources. The Commission will monitor this closely. I also call on all Member States, because cooperation between EMA and the Member States is sometimes very difficult. I call on them to scale up their constructive collaboration on this project. Madam President, honourable Members, let me conclude by underlining once again the importance of increased transparency of clinical trials in Europe. This will be achieved under the new regulation on clinical trials. I appeal again to all interested parties to work constructively together in order for the regulation to become applicable as early as possible.

name: Matthias GROOTE
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The clinical trials and the accident that took place in France, it must be said, are a huge disaster. I would like to express my condolences once again to the victims who have been injured. There was also one fatality. Nevertheless, following the disaster at Northwick Park Hospital in the United Kingdom in 2006, the EMA issued guidelines on how to conduct clinical trials. I think that was very right. We have had a very high level of security and there have been tens of thousands of volunteers taking part in clinical trials. But the question now is: what is the Enlightenment? What is the state of play of the investigation? Perhaps you can be a little more precise, Commissioner. And what impact does this incident actually have on the implementation of the current legislation that we have adopted in Parliament and with the Council on clinical trials? And what can we expect from the database you mentioned? The whole thing is treated very transparently and openly. When can we expect the database, which was co-decided in the course of the legislation, to be implemented and to be online?  What must certainly be taken into account once again is that we are finding solutions for the patients at this stage 1, who were affected in this case. Are there any suggestions from the Commission that we may need to make some improvements in this regard? In the course of the investigation and also the findings of the investigations, do we perhaps have to reconsider our legislation at this point? Or what is the state of play in the investigation? My group would be interested in that, and I would like to thank you once again, Commissioner, for having the debate on this important subject so quickly, which has, of course, also occupied the public and moved a great deal.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, I will echo Mr Groote's words from the outset. Until now, in fact, clinical trials have always had good press. Those who participate, medical staff, often, or medical students, are happy to contribute to biomedical research. Then there was this accident in Rennes on Sunday, January 10: one dead and five people hospitalized during the test of an analgesic product carried out in Phase 1, that is to say on a small group of healthy volunteers. An extremely rare but serious accident, which justifies our debate tonight. I would also like to convey my thoughts to the families of the victims and to those who are still fighting for their health. This is an opportunity tonight to remind us that these clinical trials are more than ever an indispensable step before any drug market and that Europe must remain a strong place in this research. I hope that the country where I come from, Belgium, which manufactures 15% of European medicines, will continue to be recognised for its expertise in this area. I would like to ask our Commissioner two questions about transparency. Is it true, Commissioner, that the publication of all the results of drug tests, one of the flagship measures of the new European regulation which Parliament has hardly negotiated, is being postponed from May 2016 to 2018?  Is it also true that the current trend of laboratories in Europe is to set up parallel groups in Phase 1, which are groups where patients receive a higher dose from the outset without prior testing? In any case, this is what happened in Rennes, the six victims being precisely those who had received these famous higher doses.  We know that Europe is facing increasing competition from elsewhere in this sector, but you will of course agree with us that the race to validate its clinical trials must never come at the expense of the health and safety of European citizens.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Before a drug enters the market and even before clinical trials take place, they are routinely tested on animals. And for each drug, thousands of animals such as rats, rabbits and dogs are used. The use of great apes is already prohibited in Europe. Animal tests are unethical, they cause a lot of pain and stress in the animals, but above all are completely unreliable. The predictive value of animal models is extremely low and there is no guarantee that drugs are safe because they have been tested on animals. Using these dodgy tests, human lives are being put at risk, as was shown in France last month. According to the French Minister, this drug had been extensively tested on animals, even chimpanzees. Therefore, two questions to the Commissioner: is it true that these substances have been tested on chimpanzees even though this is prohibited in Europe? Are you going to stimulate the development of reliable models based on the human body? We can then stop nonsensical animal testing and at the same time prevent further casualties.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, just a word to say that, with regard to the debate earlier, we are not questioning your honesty. We are only questioning the fact that the impact study must be separated from the criteria. What I would like to say about clinical trials is that on January 17, one person died in a clinical trial organized by the Biotrial Laboratory in Rennes, and five other people had significant neurological problems. I would also like to send all my thoughts to those families who are affected. The problem with this death is that we are faced with the non-transparency and opacity of laboratories that test their molecules, in this case a Portuguese laboratory called Bial. We obtained the protocol for the clinical trial in question, which was published by the National Agency for the Safety of Medicines and Health Products in France on 22 January. However, we were not able to obtain two records: the experimental drug, which indicates the pharmacological effects of the drug being tested, and the preclinical trials on animals, particularly chimpanzees. The Agency did not publish them because they could not obtain them. The Portuguese laboratory hides behind the trade secret. However, the Commission and you, Commissioner, have the power to put pressure on the European Medicines Agency, which I contacted and who informed me that it would delay the publication of this database until 2018, which answers Mrs Ries's question. So it's very important. You have the power to push the EMA to quickly set up this database so that we have access to these clinical studies.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a Phase 1 study assesses the safety, tolerance and pharmacological profile of new molecules, so that not many people are normally involved. However, it must be borne in mind that every year there are thousands of volunteers, often young students who, since they cannot afford to study, habitually participate in clinical trials, often unk knowingly risking their lives. The centre that carried out the research – and here I fully agree with what Mrs Rivasi said – defends itself by claiming that it has proceeded in full application of international regulations and that it has faithfully followed all procedures. But we in particular want to know what was done before we got to human experimentation. What kind of animal testing has been carried out? What other tests were conducted before putting lives at risk? We want to know if all this could have been avoided, because a clinical death and five serious admissions out of ninety patients are heavy numbers and it is clear that, as often happens when there are adverse events in health care, too many people are silent.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Madam President, it is true that the death of a healthy volunteer in a Phase 1 clinical trial is obviously a tragic accident and we are sending all our thoughts, not only to his family but also to the families of those in hospital. I am very much looking forward to the various reports that the French Ministry of Health has sponsored. I hope that they will shed light on the circumstances of this tragedy. I have questioned whether this debate should be had now, when we still have only very partial evidence on this matter and the investigations are ongoing. Above all, we must avoid engaging in the game of conjecture that is already circulating blithely in the media. We do not know where the error is. In the protocol? On the site of the clinical trial? In the contents of the sample? The dose of the chemical? We can imagine everything, and now we need transparency.  What needs to be remembered is that clinical trials are absolutely necessary to hope to bring to market innovative medicines useful to patients and that accidents of this kind, fortunately, remain rare. Fortunately, mr Commissioner reminded us, we have a new regulation which must have very strong transparency obligations, particularly with regard to information on phase 1 trials and the publicity of them. This regulation must be implemented as soon as possible. It is a top priority, it is important, and that is why I call for the responsibility of the Commission and the European Medicines Agency to monitor the progress of this issue.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the tragedy and the tragedy in Rennes raises questions about several points. First of all, we can be alarmed that the French health authorities were not notified until four days after the trial was stopped by the company that carried out it on behalf of the Portuguese laboratory. I believe that information on experimental protocols must be accessible to the public, who have the right to know all the effects of the drugs they are prescribed. In 2014, when the Clinical Data Regulation was adopted, we were able to advance transparency by ensuring that clinical study reports were not considered commercially confidential once the drug was granted marketing approval.  However, statements from pharmaceutical companies, as well as from the European Medicines Agency, are converging to reduce the scope of this regulation, which will come into force in May 2016, with a view to strengthening a certain industrial protectionism. The European Medicines Agency has thus provided a procedure that allows firms to censor their clinical study reports before they go online and imposes various restrictions that make these reports unusable for analysis or research purposes. Full publicity of clinical trial data is the condition for reassuring European citizens. Finally, in the wake of this tragedy in Rennes and within the framework of this regulation, which I recall, will be in effect at the end of May 2016, we will have to pay particular attention to certain clinical trials involving drugs used out of control, since they can be considered as low-level trials, i.e. less well supervised. There is a risk of abuse and new health scandals. I call on the Commission and the European Medicines Agency to pay attention to these practices. Let us not forget that the Mediator scandal was attributable to non-marketing authorization.

name: Julia REID
text: – Madam President, speaking as a pharmacologist who has been involved in clinical trials, both commercial and academic, I know how important clinical trials are in pharmaceutical development. However, the whole process is fraught with difficulty, and some of the drugs we use today, such as aspirin, would be unlikely to get approval. Regarding the track record of EU clinical trials legislation, in my experience the results to date have not been great. In the UK, the Clinical Trials Directive of 2001 made life very difficult for those of us involved in clinical trials, so much so that in my own field of small-scale phase IV trials, research was virtually curtailed. The Directive has since been replaced by the European Clinical Trial Regulation, which will be fully implemented this year. Will it be an improvement? I doubt it. Regarding transparency, UKIP strongly supports transparency in clinical trials. However, we believe that the UK Parliament and not the EU should be exclusively in charge of regulating this process.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to express my regret, to express the condolences felt to the victim's family and also to wish for rapid improvement to those other people, five people, who have been hospitalized.  Volunteers participating in a clinical trial know they are at risk, but these risks need to be minimised, controlled and compatible with the need and importance of these trials. In this accident that we are discussing here, which occurred in France, one of the eight volunteers died, the other five had side effects. A fully transparent investigation is needed, the causes need to be ascertained and, in this sense, in order to look for the causes, it is therefore crucial to make known, at least to those concerned, the autopsy report and also the medical reports. If we know these reports, we may have some light, we may know the causes of this accident.  There is still a need for speed in the whole investigation and, of course, I insist, nothing can be hidden, everything has to be made available, the causes have to be known and i would ask the Commissioner if the medical reports, whether the autopsy report is already known and whether, at least, the interested parties will have access to it.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, clinical trials are essential for determining the safety and efficacy of medicines. And for this, the participation of patients, who have to be confident that they are guaranteed their safety, is crucial and essential. For this, transparency is inexcusable. It is true that the facts that have occurred in France are not common, but it is not understood that we do not know, at the moment, the data or what has happened for this to happen. This cannot be, as has been reported here, under trade secret. This is not the only conflict of interest between the lack of transparency on the part of industry and the interests of public health, as evidenced by the debate on drug prices. This highlights the need for this new Regulation, but I also believe that we need to consider new measures to improve the necessary transparency for patient safety and also to promote and improve research, so necessary to tackle all these diseases.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, how increasing health gains by developing new medicines and at the same time reducing risk and increasing the attractiveness of innovation processes is the key issue for health systems and citizens who are discussing it here at the moment.  Scientific progress in health has saved millions of lives and heals or mitigates more and more diseases. This positive acceleration requires strong and transparent regulation. The answer is not a heavy regulation, applied with differentiated deadlines and criteria, State by State. The answer is more transparency and more knowledge sharing.  The recent example, which was the case with the clinical trial in Rennes, France, should encourage us even more on the path that has been charted. We have an obligation to implement in cooperation a scientific and legal platform that enhances innovation and health while minimizing the risks associated with clinical trials. And that is why, Commissioner, I congratulate you on your decision to create a database that supports this process.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the course of clinical trials, the safety and well-being of patients must be protected with every effort. The recent tragedy in France shows, however, that this is not always the case: the five hospitalizations and the death of volunteers as a result of the intake of an experimental molecule provided for in the programme for the development of a new drug represent a very serious fact. Fortunately, what has happened in France is rare, but it is clear that much more can be done in terms of the safety of trials. Regulation (EU) No 536/2014 on clinical trials will not enter into force in full until 2018. In the meantime, we cannot allow further tragedies to happen. The Regulation provides for the need for in-depth studies to gather as much information as possible before administering a drug to humans and obliges Member States to share all available information, including through the sharing of the European database on clinical trials and by making the results of phase 1 of trials public. I expect clarification from the Commission on progress in implementing the regulation and possible measures to speed up entry into force.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: – Madam President, I also join with all those who expressed condolences to the victims of this very tragic case. We all understand that this tragic case shows that the regulation, which was adopted as far back as April 2014, should be implemented as soon as possible. It should maybe also be amended because, as I understand it, the regulation makes no provision for these first phase trials. Now we talk about the database and expect that it will help. When we look at the archives we see that in September 2014 the Commission said that all the preparations would be ready and work on the database would start in December 2014. So why is it taking so long? I ask you to give us a bit more information about the database: what it will contain, accessibility, but also the reasons why it is all taking so long.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I believe that, of course, no clinical trial should end with such a tragic record of dead and injured people who are hospitalised, and I would therefore like to express my sincere condolences to them. On the other hand, I think that these conclusions are actually quite premature, and even the debate seemed somewhat pre-ed before what the objective findings are supposed to bring, which is why I also signed up to this speech. I want to support the Commissioner's efforts to obtain as much objective information as possible on this matter and only then, if necessary, to assess at political level what has happened. I do not want to be involved in a match or in a sprint of strong statements on this very subject, when objective information is still lacking. In doing so, I would like to support the Commissioner, as opposed to my previous contribution on that previous point.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, we are discussing transparency and control in the clinical trial process in the wake of the recent tragic incident in France, where we had one dead and five people still in danger and in hospital.  Clinical trials aim to develop medicines and improve the medicinal treatments applied, while within the European Union investments in clinical research exceed EUR 20 billion per year However, there are often cases of lack of transparency and control in clinical trials. In addition, there are often also cases of concealment of any negative results in preliminary clinical trials, and publication of only the most wanted results.  Therefore, in order to ensure transparency in clinical trials, all pharmaceutical companies should declare and make public the results from the early stages of clinical trials, as defined by the World Health Organisation.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, citizens should be able to rely on health authorities, ethics committees, public or private entities investigating the development of new drugs. But for this to happen, they must be assured first of all of the right to truth and transparency.  It is necessary that the data, all data, on new medicinal products in the testing phase, studies and tests carried out, are in the public domain and can be properly scrutinised. It is necessary that the reports and opinions of entities such as the relevant ethics committees, the companies involved, in particular those conducting clinical trials, are available to the public, allowing the scrutiny of the precepts of good practice, international guidelines, so-called guidelines, and the ethics of studies, and free information on the progress of investigations and possible errors made and their consequences. No trade secret can deny or overtake this right to truth and transparency.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to say that true transparency of clinical trials is essential, absolutely. It should be possible to know which clinical trials are ongoing, where and by whom, and what the purposes and outcomes are. Absolutely. We are working in very close cooperation with EMA. I would like to answer in more concrete detail because there were very big problems with standards and technical issues relating to data at the moment. With regard to such a tragic event in France, as you know, investigations by both the French authorities and by the police are ongoing and the causes of the incident are not yet known. Several clinical hypotheses are being worked on, but as you know, for legal reasons I cannot comment on the investigation. Sorry, but now is not the time to comment, because it is a very sensitive situation. I trust that we will soon know all the details, but we must check, wait and see when the investigation will be finished, and then we will be ready to ask all questions about transparency and other issues. But this investigation is currently ongoing and we have no possibility to intervene at the moment.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. – The medicines sector has played an essential role in combating disease and new threats to public health by providing more and better therapies to European citizens. There is, however, a long way to go, whether in the fight against cancer and new epidemics, or in the fight against organisms resistant to antibiotics and diseases linked to ageing. The process of innovation in the medicinal product sector is therefore of fundamental importance for all of us. Without questioning this reality, however, it should be noted that there is no risk-free technological innovation and that, therefore, we must be well aware that clinical trials deal with human lives. In my country alone, about 10,000 people are currently involved in clinical trials. Last month's absolutely tragic incident in France, which resulted in a death, cannot happen again! I believe that the commercial interests of companies cannot prevail in view of the safety of citizens and the transparency of testing. Serious adverse reactions should be reported early and compliance with control and monitoring processes for greater safety.
